title: Books of The Times
description: DEFEAT OF AN IDEAL. A Study of the SelfDestruction of the United Nations. By Shirley Hazzard. 286 pages. AtlanticLittle, Brown. $8.50.

title: French Now Ask: And After Gaullism?
description: PARIS, Feb. 28From the start of the Fifth Republic in 1958 until its leader's resignation in 1969, the French question was After de Gaulle, what? The conventional answer was Gaullism.

title: Concern That Runs Buildings Is Ruled Subject to Pay Law
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Supreme Court ruled today that a real estate management company cannot escape paying its employes the minimum wage by contending that each building it manages is a separate business too small to be governed by the labor law.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A City Council committee unanimously approved bill yesterday to require pharmacies to conspicuously post the prices of the most commonly used prescription drugs.

title: G.A.O. Investigating Secret Gift Of $200,000 to Nixon Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The General Accounting Office is investigating an unreported $200,000 contribution solicited by and secretly given to President Nixon's reelection campaign by Robert L. Vesco, a New Jersey financier who is under Federal charges of securities fraud, G.A.O. officials said today.

title: Big Day at the Big A
description: The New York racing season opens today at Aqueduct with a program headed by the Paumonok Handicap. A tax remission from the State Treasury has in a great measure enabled the New York Racing Association to open the campaign, which will embrace 249 racing days through Dec. 15.

title: Yonkers Closing With Crowds Down
description: YONKERS, Feb. 28Figures for the first of three harness racing meetings at Yonkers Raceway are expected to show, following tomorrow night's closing, a drop of 11.7 per cent in average nightly attendance over the corresponding local racing dates of 1971 But the fiscal statement is expected to show an increase of 2.7 per cent.

title: Subsidy Curb Halts Work On 580 Apartments Here
description: Work has been suspended on four housing projects in the city that would provide apartments for 580 families, owing to the withholding of Federal rentsubsidy funds by the Nixon Administration. John E. Zuccotti, chairman of the City Planning Commission, said yesterday.

title: Diabetic Hofstra Coed Is Found Dead After an Apparent Overdose of Drugs
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 28A 20yearold Hofstra University student died this morning, apparently of an overdose of drugs, one day after 28 other Hofstra students were arrested on charges of selling dangerous; drugs.

title: Helmsley May Buy Plaza Hotel
description: The worldfamous Plaza Hotel may soon be sold.

title: BRAVES ACQUIRE MORTON OF EXPOS
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 (UPI)  The Atlanta Braves continued to revamp their pitching staff today when they acquired Carl Morton, a righthanded pitcher, from the Montreal Expos in exchange for Pat Jarvis, also a righthander. Morton was the sixth experienced pitcher acquired by the Braves since the end of last season.

title: MISS LYNN TAKES 2 SEATING SPINS
description: BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 28This was a bizarre day in the world figure skating championships.

title: $105,000 Is Bid Price For Seat on Exchange
description: The market for seats  or memberships  on the New York Stock Exchange was quoted yesterday at $105,000 bid and $170,000 offered. On the bid side, this represents a decline from $125,000 last Thursday.

title: Advertising: 5 Hurdles to Clear
description: In the view of Joseph R. Daly, president of Doyle Dane Bernbach, five major hurdles face the agency business during the next five to 10 years. (Is that all?)

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Gen. Weyand Will Head Army Forces in Pacific
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)  Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, now United States commander in Vietnam, was named today to become commander in chief of all Army_ forces in the Pacific.

title: Dillon, Metropolitan President, Terms Vase Purchase Legal
description: Douglas Dillon, president of he Metropolitan Museum of Art and its acquisitions committee, yesterday defended the museum's purchase of its 2,500yearold Euphronios vase, Calling the acquisition completely legal.

title: Arthur Daley
description: This has been a pretty good fortnight or two for those mere mortals who have just been enveloped in the trappings of demigods and ushered among the immortals at various halls of fame. Baseball, pro football and basketball all received additions of late and most have been of highoctane quality. The one that pleased me most, perhaps, was the tapping of an old friend, Billy Evans, for Cooperstown.

title: United Merchants Appoints
description: Martin J. Schwab, president of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., has been appointed chairman of the company's executive management committee. He succeeds Merwin R. Haskel, who remains a committee member and chairman of the company.

title: Legislature Moves to Kill Primary for Chief Judge
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28A bipartisan bill was introduced in the Legislature late today that would abolish the statewide primary for chief judge of the Court of Appeals.

title: Moynihan Asks Realism in Ties to India
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 28Ambassador Daniel Patrick Moynihan today urged a new realism in the uneasy relations between India and the United States.

title: Associates First Extends Its Tender Offer to Taicott
description: Associates First Capital Corporation, a subsidiary of Gulf & Western Industries, said yesterday it was extending its tender offer to holders of the common and three classes of preferred stock of Taicott National Corporation. The offer, which was to expire March 2, will not close until March 23.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 28Cornell University has made what may be the largest single acquisition of Vietnamese books and documents, university officials announced today.

title: Napoles Retains Crown By Stopping Lopez in 7th
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 28 (UPI)Jose Napoles, the aging but still brilliant world welterweight champion with blood streaming down his right cheek, kept his title tonight by knocking out Ernie (Indian Red) Lopez of Los Angeles with a vicious right uppercut to the chin at 1 minute 36 seconds of the seventh round of their scheduled 15round fight.

title: SOL WARSHOW
description: Sol Warshow, executive vice president of the Warshow Manufacturing Company of 4000 First Avenue, Brooklyn, maker of officefiling supplies, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 8888 20th Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Voting Heavy After Close Irish Race
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 28It won't make that much difference, said James Connell, but it's time we had a change. After 16 years in power they forget about you.

title: Armed Indians Seize Wounded Knee, Hold Hostages
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., Feb. 28Militant Indians held at least 10 persons hostage in the historic settlement of Wounded Knee today, exchanging gunfire with Federal officers and firing on cars and lowflying planes that came within rifle range.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The furniture in the two model rooms Lord & Taylor unveiled yesterday on its eighth floor is more handcrafts than anything else.

title: 2 Appointments Fill Accounting Board
description: The new apparatus that will write the accounting rules for corporate financial statements a reorganization that has taken just 11 months to put into effectwas completed yesterday.

title: U.N. AVIATION BODY CONDEMNS ISRAEL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 28The Assembly of the International Civil Aviation Organization voted today, 105 to 1, to condemn the Israeli action that caused the crash of a Libyan airliner last week.

title: Czech, Polish Officials Killed in a Plane Crash
description: MUNICH, March 1 (Reuters) The Interior Ministers of. Poland and Czechoslovakia were killed in an aircraft crash last night, the Warsaw radio reported today.

title: ANACONDA RAISES PRICE OF COPPER
description: The Anaconda Copper Company announced yesterday that it was increasing its price for copper wirebars, the industry's major product, by 4 cents to 60 cents a pound. The move was the most significant of several made in the metals, chemicals, tobacco, wood products and electronics industries. The increase by Anaconda was the third since Jan, 1 when the price for the item, which makes up about 90 per cent of theindustry's primary production, stood at 50.5 cents a pound.

title: Margin Calls by Brokers Being Heard More Often
description: The kind of call a customer hates to get from his stock brokerthe margin callis on the increase these days as one fallout from the recent market decline. A survey of both large and small brokerage houses indicated yesterday that margin calls are showing a moderate rise. We're at the amberlight stage, not the redlight stage, one margindepartment official said.

title: Campaign in France: No Hoopla, Little TV
description: PARIS, Feb. 28Picture a hotly contested national election in which a corpse, a 15yearold alleged arsonist and a group of respected abortionists have all figured as big political issues. That is France in 1973.

title: Governors Told Aid to States Won't Drop
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28Anxious Governors received White House assurances today that the overall total of Federal aid to the states was not going to be cut. Yet in 2 hours of discussion with President Nixon's top budget staff, the Governors were unable to discover what programs the Federal money would pay for.

title: Proxmire Declares Nixon Erred on Economic Steps
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)  Senator William Proxmire said today that President Nixon had made grave economic mistakes that would mean higher prices for all Americans.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Spring Arrives Today For Outdoor Bettors
description: Ten bucks, the man in the frayed coat was saying, trying to control the urgency in his voice. It's a 35dollar watch.

title: $PORT$CA$T
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28Hi, sports fans! This is your everyhour, ontheminute, uptotheminute, sportsbulletinsatanymoment news of the world of sports. And talking at you out there are yours truly, Bill Bellclapper, and my great sidekick and expert on tax angles and everything else financialH. P. Morgan. Give us the top of the sports news, H. P.

title: Congress Is Asked to Clear Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Nixon Administration sent to Congress today legislation seeking to clear the way for construction of a pipeline to tap the oil riches of Alaska's North Slope.

title: South African Students Planning Protest
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 28Students at Englishlanguage universities throughout South Africa began to organize protest campaigns today against the Government's banning, of eight leading members of the National Union of South African Students.

title: Former Top G.I. and 2 Others Plead Guilty in Kickback Case
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb, 28 (UPI) Willian O. Woolridge, the former first sergeant major of the Army, and two codefendants pleaded guilty today to criminal charges in connection with the operation of servicemen's clubs in Vietnam.

title: Peace Seems to Reign In Tense Laotian Area
description: HAT DUA, Laos, V Feb. 28 Both Government and Communist forces have been through this refugee settlement in the northern Vientiane plain since the ceasefire went into effect last Thursday, and the jittery population seems anxious to avoid offending anyone. Essentially, the region is at peace.

title: Jesse Gray in Race
description: Assemblyman Jesse Gray of Manhattan formally announced, his candidacy for the Democratic mayoral nomination yesterday, becoming the first black and the seventh announced candidate for the Democratic nomination. Details on Page 28.

title: Twins for the Jim Ryuns
description: Jim Ryun's wife, the former Anne Snyder, gave birth to twin boys yesterday at Cottage Hospital, Santa Barbara, Calif. Each weighed 6 pounds 1 ounce. The Ryuns also have a daughter, Heather, 3. Ryun is the worldrecord miler.

title: Player Unit Votes For Pact, 220
description: MIAMI, Feb. 28  Baseball's player representatives, who paved the way for a threeyear peace by deciding two weeks ago to remove the reserve system from negotiations for a new basic agreement, voted unanimously today to recommend to their teammates ratification of the agreement with their owners.

title: Vanden Heuvel Backed, for D.A. By New Democratic Coalition
description: William J. vanden Heuvel was endorsed as a candidate for Manhattan District Attorriey by the liberal wing of the Democratic party last night.

title: In Chinese Shops, Hostess Bought Extra Time to Enjoy Party
description: It was 5:30 on a recent evening when Mrs. Norman Kee began to cook in the kitchen of her Beekman Place penthouse. Two hours later she was ready to serve a 12course Chinese dinner for eight. And in that twohour period she even had time to shower and change for the party.

title: Notes on People
description: The president of Kent State University in Ohio, Dr. Glenn A. Olds, said I think a person that engages in harddrug traffic; particularly to hook the young, ought to be shot. Dr. Olds, at a news conference at Kent, added, I personally view the consequence, both of the habit and the impact of hard drugs, to be murder. It's a more dangerous kind of murder, in my view, than that which results from a gun. He said he preferred to leave the question of the legalization of marijuana to the courts.

title: MAYOR OF YONKERS SEEKS COUNTY POST
description: YONKERS, Feb. 28Mayor Alfred B. Del Bello, a Democrat, announced today that he would run for Westchester County Executive to end 34 years of what he termed complacent, apathetic, and inbred Republican party control in Westchester.

title: Community Indictment
description: Under pressure of lawsuits and journalistic exposs, a state panel has put forth sound recommendations for correcting the worst of the unspeakable conditions a the Willowbrook State School for the Mentally Retarded. All that is lacking is a timetable, a budget or the requisite sense of official urgency about implementing the proposals.

title: Chaney Tallies 32
description: BOSTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) Don Chaney scored a career high 32 points tonight to lead the Boston Celtics to a 118111 victory over the Golden State Warriors in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Primer for Neophyte Players
description: WORLD'S SECONDFASTEST ANIMAL: The thoroughbred race horse.

title: Reluctant F.B.I. Gave Aide Of Nixon Watergate Files
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28L. Patrick Gray 3d, the acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that he had originally resisted making the bureau's files on the Watergate affair available to the White House, but that he had finally allowed a record of the investigation to be given to a Presidential assistant.

title: James P. McAllister Dies; Appellate Law Secretary
description: James P. McAllister, law secretary to Justice Marcus G. Christ of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, Second Department, died Tuesday evening in Good Samaritan Hospital, West Islip, L. I., apparently of a heart attack. He was 37 years old and lived at 25 Waterford Drive, Wheatley Heights, L. I.

title: School Cost Curb Approved
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 28 (AP)  The State Senate approved today legislation that would give citizens veto power over new school buildings whose costs exceeded limits set bythe state.

title: Duquesne Routs Xavier
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 28 (AP)Ruben Montanez had 26 points to help Duquesne's basketball team to an 8973 victory over Xavier tonight. The Dukes shot 60 per cent.

title: Sports, Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: TV : C.B.S. Offers Honor Thy Father Adaptation
description: Honor Thy Father, being shown from 9 to II o'clock this evening over the Columbia Broadcasting System, comes wrapped in some heavy credits. Based on the bestselling book by Gay Talese, the film uses a script by Lewis John Carlino and its cast includes Raf Vallone, a fine Italian actor, as Joe Bonanno, one of the top bosses in the American Mafia The credits, unfortunately, are considerably more impressive than the results.

title: Oil Takeover Pact Announced by Iraq
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 28Iraq and the Westernowned Iraq Petroleum Company have reached a settlement on last year's nationalization of the company's oilfields and assets, President Ahmed Hassan alBakr announced tonight.

title: SEARS DECLARES HE ARRANGED GIFT
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 28  Former State Senator Harry L. Sears Said today that he dissuaded Robert L. Vesco, the financier, from contributing $500,000 to President Nixon's reelection campaign last year because it would have been open to an unfavorable interpretation in light of Mr. Vesco's troubles with the Securities and. Exchange Commission.

title: Open to LoveOr Suffering
description: The bare facts are that on the evening of March 1, 1932, our 18monthold child, Charles Lindbergh Jr., was taken from his crib in our home near Hopewell, N. J., and a note was left on the window sill from the kidnapper demanding a ransom for his safe return. After ten weeks of negotiation and contact with the kidnapper and the handing over of the demanded ransom, the dead body of the child was found in the woods a few miles from our home.

title: Aeros Win 4th in Row, 3.2, Beating Oilers in Overtime
Assembly Hails Vietnam G.I.'s, But the Wording Causes Debate
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28A con??tion between supporters and opponents of the war in Vietnam took place in the Assembly today over a resolution honoring the veterans of that war.

title: A SCHOOL GUARD SOUGHT BY POLICE
description: A security guard recently assigned to Washington Irving High School in the Gramercy Park area was accused yesterday of trying to break into a safe at the school.

title: DR. ROSWELL S. COLES, DEAN AT WAGNER, 68
description: Dr. Roswell S. Coles, who retired in 1969 as dean of special services at Wagner College, Staten Island, died Tuesday at his home in Highland Lakes, N.J. He was 68 years old.

title: CURRAN BENEFITS HOCKED BY JUDGE
description: A temporary court restraining order blocking the National Maritime Union from, beginning payment today of an estimated $1million in retirement benefits to Joseph Curran, the union's president, was signed last night by United States District Judge Robert Ward.

title: Greece's Press, After Relative Freedom, Is Coming Under Growing Pressure
description: ATHENS, Feb. 28After period of relative freedom, the Greek press is coming under increasing pressure from the armybacked Government to maintain silence on sensitive issues in a campaign that has left publishers and journalists confused and angry.

title: Chris Evert Triumphs, 61, 62, In First Professional Contest
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., 28  Chris Evert, playing her first match as a professional, easily defeated Michele Gurdat of Belgium, 61, 62, in the opening round of a $50,000 tennis tournament today.

title: HIGH COURT LETS BANK LINK STAND
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The Justice Department's first effort to block acquisition of a relatively small city bank by a statewide bankholding company failed today, in the Supreme Court.

title: Pronovost Goals Top Blues
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 28 (UPI) Jean Pronovost scored two goals tonight to lead the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 42 National Hockey League victory over the St. Louis Blues. The triumph moved the Penguins to within 1 point of the fourthplace Blues in the West Division.

title: U.S. AIDE OUTLINES TACTICS ON WAGES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28An official of the Cost of Living Council said today that the council's new director, John T. Dunlop, expected to practice active but quiet intervention in major labormanagement negotiations this year, in pursuit of noninflationary settlements.

title: Canarsie School Boycott Reported Voted by Parents
description: Parents angry over the delay in approval for a new zoning plan for the schools in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn decided last night to boycott the area's six elementary and two junior high schools today, Alan Enrlichman, the president of the Concerned Citizens of Canarsie, said.

title: Shift at European Parley
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 28 (AP)The 34 nations taking part in preliminary consultations for the European security conference agreed today to change from open full sessions to a private and informal working group with a reduced number of delegates from each country. They decided to begin the new procedure tomorrow morning.

title: Events Today Theater
description: OUT CRY, a play by Tennessee Williams. Stagd by Peter Glenville. Starring Michael York and Cara DuffMacCnrmick. At the Lyceum Theater, West 45th Street, at 7.

description: Page

title: C.I.A. AD NAMES ESPIONAGE CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28James R. Schlesinger, the new Director of Central Intelligence, has named William E. Colby, former head of the American pacification program in South Vietnam and a longtime intelligence operative, as director of clandestine operations.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Safety Standards Vary at Ski Areas
description: Despite the growing popularity of skiing in the metropolitan area, neither New Jersey nor Connecticut has any law mandating regular inspection of ski lifts.

title: March Soybeans Futures Drop As 15c Daily Limit Is Removed
description: March soybean futures, no longer under the 15centabushel daily limit, tumbled 20 cents a bushel during the session yesterday to $6.35 a bushel. The delivery closed at $6.39, compared with Tuesday's close of $6.55 and a record high this week of $6.81 on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports of changes in stockholdings by major stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The reports include the following:

title: Times Plans Effort To Quash Subpoena Served on Reporter
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times, said yesterday that all legal steps would be taken to quash a subpoena issued by President Nixon's reelection committee for material on The Times's coverage of the bugging of the Democratic National Committee's headquarters.

title: Market Place:
description: The commodity markets have long been regarded as Wall Street's own special method of committing financial suicide.

title: Tiny Clam A Threat To River
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28A pesky, fastmultiplying Chinese clam has been discovered in the Delaware River at several points between here and Trenton.

title: ROBERT E. GOUGH JR.
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28 (AP)  Robert E. Gough, Jr., vice president and general manager of The TimesPicayune Publishing Corporation died today. He was 72 Slears old.

title: FRANCIS B. FOLEY, EXPERT ON STEEL
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 Francis B. Foley, a leader in metallurgical research and past president of the American Society for Metals, died yesterday in Coral Gables, Fla., on a visit to his daughter. He was 85 years old and lived at Alden Park Manor in Germantown.

title: FRANK S. ESTILL SR., EXF.A.A. SAFETY AIDE
description: GLEN HEAD, L. I., Feb. 28Frank S. Estill Sr., a retired member of the flight safety standards division of the Federal Aviation Agency at Kennedy Airport and a pioneer pilot, died yesterday in Somers, N. Y. He was 76 years old and lived at 9 Rose Street here.

title: Over Their Heads
description: DUNMORE, Pa.It is nearly nine months since our usually docile Susquehanna River overflowed its banks in WilkesBarre, Pa., as a result of Tropical Storm Agnes and her heavy rains. And what do we have to show for nine months of cleaning and rebuilding? Not much more than streets a little cleaner than they were and a few building facades looking more modern than their proprietors had ever hoped. And a couple of thousand people in debt to their Government which, through continual public relations bombardments, has told them how wonderful it is and how fortunate they are. Despite the millions upon millions of dollars poured into the Wyoming Valley for recovery operations, we've been shortchanged by an Administration that thought it was politically expedient to send a lot of men, women and money in an election year to an area that has been a Democratic stronghold for years, and by a Congress that is too lazy to get off its duff to pass some effective legislation to prevent similar postdisaster fiascos in the future.

title: Times Declares Dividend
description: The New York Times Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share on the Class A and B common stock, payable on March 26 to stockholders of record on March 16. It was also announced that the annual meeting of Times shareholders would be held on April 24 at 11 A.M. at Town Hall here.

title: RIDDER TO PURCHASE PAPERS IN WICHITA
description: Ridder Publications, Inc., said yesterday it had reached an agreement to purchase the con trolling interest in The Wichita Eagle and Beacon morning, evening and Sunday newspapers published in Kansas' largest city.

title: Dublin: Ferment Has Outlet on Stage
description: DUBLIN The political tur bulence in the North of Ire land found its first dramatic outlet in the work of a major writer when Brian Friel's new play, The Freedom of the City, recently explodes on the stage of the Abbey Theater here. In a setting starkly evocative of a clanstrophobic ghetto covered witl graffiti of sectar ian politics, the stream of gas billowed from the rubble of a Derry street while the air was filled with the noises of water cannon and rubber bullets. Then the bullets became real, and a woman and two young men lay dead. The time is a Saturday afternoon in February, 1970, after a banned civil rights march has been scattered, leaving three victims. But the date could have been Jan. 30, 1972, and the number of dead 13, because in its external trappings, Mr. Friel's play is a bitterly ironic documentary on Bloody Sunday, on disastrous overreaction by security forces, on the subsequent Widgery tribunal of inquiry and on the response to the killings by churchmen, politicians and people.

title: Police Divers Recover Murdered Woman's Jewel Box
description: Police Department scuba divers recovered a jewelry box from the East River yesterday that they said had been identified as belonging to Mary Hample, the 83yearold Widow who was murdered last week.

title: Paintings Worth $600,000 Stolen in South of France
description: MARSEILLES, France, Feb. 28 (AP)A thief beat a guard unconscious tonight and stole six paintings by Rubens, Corot, Dufy and Ingres from the Longchamps Museum. The police gave $600,000 as an estimate of their value.

title: Air Force Is Given Approval to Begin Production of F15
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) The Air Force announced today that it had received approval for the first 30 production models of its new F15 air superiority jet fighter.The action sets in motion production that eventually could reach 749 airplanes at a cost of about $7.8billion.

title: 2 Pointers Blaze a Trail To Kennels in Colombia
description: Eduardo Vargas is a trail blazer in the Colombian dogshow world. I was the first to have beagles in my native land, he said, and the secand with Australian terriers. I've just bought two pointers in England and they will be the first in Colombia. Then there are only eight standard poodles in my country and I have two of them. The 28yearold Vargas, who heads his own advertising agency, has been in dogshow activities for only four years, but he has moved ahead quickly. In addition to the pointers' and poodles, he has 11 Aussies, five cocker spaniels three beagles.

title: Farm Prices Rose by 3% in February to a Record
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) Farm prices, led by further increases for meat animals, jumped 3 per cent in February and averaged 22 per cent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: GRAFITTI SCORES IN HIALEAH STAKE
description: MIAMI, Feb. 28The two best mares in Florida met head on in the $63,600 Black Helen Handicap at Hialeah today and it was a pity the race did not end in a dead, heat. It almost did, as Grafitti held off Summer Guest to win by a neck

title: Wounded Knee, S.D., a Symbol Of Bitter Past and Future Hope
description: Wounded Knee, S. D., a cluster of drab buildings on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in the southwest corner of the state, was the site of the last armed incident pitting Indian against the United States Government.

title: CUOMO IS TESTING MAYORAL WATERS
description: Mario M. Cuomo, the Queens lawyer who won public notice by helping to fashion compromises in two of the city's more notable neighborhood squabbles Corona and Forest Hillshad 400 people to breakfast yesterday to see if they might like to draft him for Mayor.

title: Soviet Hopeful on Grain Crop In '73 as Weather Is Favorable
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 28  Spring has come early to key farm areas of the southern Soviet Union after a remarkably mild winter, and Russians are beginning to view this year's grain crop prospects with some optimism after the disastrous 1972 harvest.

title: Poison Prevention Week
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) President Nixon today designated the week beginning March 18 as National Poison Prevention Week and urged all state and local governments to prevent accidental poisonings, especially among children.

title: Rise of 7.15 in Dow Index Breaks a String of Losses
description: The stock market managed to sustain a rally yesterday for the first time in six sessions.

title: CHANGE IN POLICY FOR CHILE ASKED
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 28Former President Eduardo Frei Montalva said today that if the antiMarxist opposition scored a clear majority in the legislative elections Sunday, it would demand a change in the Government's socialist policies.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: Kennedy Battles Nixon's Vetoes in New Arena: Court
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The spiffy young lawyer walked toward the bench, grasped the courtroom lectern firmly with both hands and cleared his throat.

title: Stefanich Rolls 300 Game
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 28 (AP)Jim Stefanich, a 31yearold righthander from Joliet, Ill., rolled a 300 game today and took a 35pin lead in the $80,000 Miller open bowling tournament after the opening sixgame block. The 11time champion posted games of 198, 227, 195, 226 and 266 before closing out his first set with his 16th career perfect game.

title: Intricate Maneuvers Ease Crisis at Paris Conference
description: PARIS, Feb. 28The United States and North Vietnam, through some intricate diplomatic maneuvering today, seemed to ease the crisis over the delay in American prisoner releases and to pave the way for concluding the international conference on Vietnam Friday.

title: The Drug Program
description: Governor Rockefeller's overkill drug program fortunately seems headed for defeat. Even among those lawmakers who originally cheered the Governor's words the loudest when he delivered them in the ornate Assembly Chamber in Albany, there are many who now sheepishly admit the need for amendments and modifications. Life terms for everyone? No distinction among kinds of drugs? The Mr. Bigs and the experimenters treated alike? A series of democratically conducted public hearings exposed these absurdities.

title: Lavine Sees a Big Threat In U.S. Welfare Reforms
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28The State Commissioner of Social Services, Abe Lavine, warned the Legislature today that the new Federal welfare reforms contained Trojan horse dangers for the state, including the addition of as many as 300,000 new recipients to the adult case load.

title: Collision Kills 1, Injures 20
description: CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 28 (AP) A busload of preschool children collided head on with a car in southeastern Stark County today. The driver of the car was killed and the 20 persons on the bus were injured. The driver killed was John Prati, 20 years old, of Waynesburg, according to Chief Sheriff's Deputy Lew Napier.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA DOWNS FORDHAM
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 28 (AP)South Carolina, hoping for an atlarge bid to the National Collegiate basketball playoffs, used superior height to down Fordham, 7772, tonight.

title: PENNEY REPORTS RECORD PROFITS
DOLLAR DECLINES TO LOW IN EUROPE
description: LONDON, Feb. 28The United States dollar fell to its lowest permissible level against half a dozen currencies of Europe today and required fresh support from the European central banks.

title: Rangers Earn Tie With Hawks at 33
description: Two proud teams, attempting to claw their way back to respectability, treated the Madison Square Garden fans to a fine hockey game last night.

title: Receiver Named by Court For Goldstein, Samuelson
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 Demands by customers for return of their investments, or payment of profits, piled up today at the offices of some 20 commodity option firms operating in California following a Federal court action that closed down the nation's largest dealer in such trading.

title: Lemaire Paces 52 Rout
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 28 (UPI)Jacques Lemaire recorded his 36th goal of the season and added two assists tonight as he led the Montreal Canadiens to a 52 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Not Much Of A Peace
description: The first month of ceasefire in South Vietnam has not been gratifying for anyone, except for the release of the first group of American prisoners. Fighting continues at unacceptable levels, international control is nowhere really in evidence, and not even a beginning has been made on the longerrange question of the political development of Vietnam.

title: 61st Appeal for Neediest Sets a Record
description: The 61st annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended yesterday with contributions totaling $1,058,988.21, a record, from 12,814 donors.

title: Personal Finance
description: One of the problems in buying a used car is that someone may have tampered with the odometer, which records the car mileage.

title: Dispute Is Resumed as Leaders Ask Start on Capitol Extension
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28A decadeold dispute over extending the West Front of the Capitol broke out anew today as Congressional leaders called for a prompt start on the project.

title: New Action Leader Chosen by President
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI)  Administration of ficials announced today that President Nixon had chosen Michael P. Balzano Jr., 37 years old, to, head the Action Agency that coordinates Government volunteer work.

title: Belshazzar and Belshazzar's Feast' Given by Handel Society Under Simon
description: Stories about rulers who see handwriting on the wall but decide to ignore it are never out of date, so there was a kind of compound relevance and interest in the Handel Society of New York's concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night. Stephen Simon conducted Handel's oratorio, Belshazzar, cutting it drastically in order to end the night with Walton's version of the same Biblical tale, Belshazzar's Feast.

title: SmallArms Fire In Vietnam Injures A U.S. Copter Pilot
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, Feb. 28  An unarmed American military helicopter carrying a Canadian and an Indonesian member of the International Commission of Control and Supervision was hit by smallarms fire today 12 miles south of here. The American pilot was severely wounded in a leg.

title: Chess: A Lesson in Demolition From The Intercollegiate Tourney
description: The University of Chicago's A team topped a record 108 teams from 23 states, three Canadian provinces, the West Indies and the Dominican Republic to win the recent PanAmerican Intercollegiate Team Championship tournament at Columbus, Ohio.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Elusive Hare
description: Hanson Carroll of Norwich, Vt., his two young sons, Jay and Chris, and I had packed into the area on skis and snowshoes to hunt snowshoe rabbits, also known as varying hares, with handguns. A large hare whose brown summer pelt turns white as the shorter days of winter approach, the snowshoe rabbit is normally hunted with shotguns, but we knew, encumbered as we were with packs and ski poles, that the compact handguns would be easier to carry.

title: CONGRESS PASSES EXTENSION OF AID
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) The House and Senate passed and sent to the White House today a resolution extending temporary financing until June 30 for foreign aid and two Government departments.

title: After Sinai
description: No useful purpose is served by an acrimonious debate over the assignment of blame for the downing of a Libyan airliner in the Sinai peninsula last week. It should not have happenedno one disputes that. Israelis justify the actions of their triggerhappy pilots, but they express no joy over those acts; this attitude contrasts with the obscene satisfaction voiced by many Arabs, including Arab governments, after some of the bloody Black September attacks.

title: JACKIE WASHINGTON SINGS AT NEW CLUB
description: Reno Sweeney, the new supper club on. West 13th Street, is, commendably, giving new performers a helpful showcase helpful to the performer because Reno Sweeney's Paradise Room, where the singing takes place, is interestingly atmospheric, and helpful to Reno Sweeney in its early stages because performers looking for a showcase do not usually cost yery much.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The Securities and Exchange Commission has ordered a second temporary stay of its rule that sales of taxexempt securities by banks and other financial institutions to brokerdealers must be delivered no later than 10 business days after the settlement date.

title: A RABBI DISCERNS JEWISHTE BLOG
description: The head of the New York Board of Rabbis sharply receded yesterday the concept that there is no Jewish vote and called on all mayoral contenders to recognize that Jews had problems, concerns and rights.

title: Havenfield Reports It Plans To Leave Securities Field
description: The Havenfield Corporation, a small member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday it was going out of the securities business. Recently, the firm sold off its 10 domestic and foreign branches to other brokerage concerns.

title: U.S. Reserve Assets Fell $97Million During Month
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 Reuters)United States reserve assets fell $97million to $13.054billion in January, the Treasury Department reported today.

title: Three Tankers Purchased
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP)  The General American Transportation Corporation announced today it had purchased three large tankers from Fred Olsen & Co., Ltd., Oslo, Norway, for $25.5million cash.

title: S.I. Toonerville Trolley Gets New Cars
description: For Staten Islanders it was like finally getting jets after 50 years of Sopwith Camels. The first new equipment for the Staten Island Rapid Transit system In a halfcenturya shiny train of three colorful, airconditioned coacheswas christened yesterday afternoon by Mayor Lindsay.

title: Council Acts on Hiring School Guards
description: The City Council moved yesterday to transfer the authority to hire school guards from local school boards to the central Board of Education to try to prevent the hiring of criminals.

title: Bullets Bow, 10296
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 (UPI) Don May and Fred Carter did the clutch scoring in the fourth quarter tonight to lead, the Philadelphia 76ers to a 10296 victory over the Baltimore Bullets.

title: People and Business
description: Anthony Favill Tuke, a son and grandson of two former chairmen of Barclays Bank, Ltd., will become chairman on Oct. 1 He will succeed Sir John Thomson, who has been chairman of the bank, parent of the world's fourth largest financial institution, for more than a decade.

title: Ohio Standard Joins Group Planning ShaleOil Study
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said yesterday that it had brought together a group of 12 companies to study a new method of removing hydrocarbons from oil shale.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PRICES ARE MIXED ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market did not quite succeed in breaking their losing streak yesterday and finished mixed in steppedup trading.

title: C.A.B. May Cancel 22to45Day Fare
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28There is a strong chance that the Civil Aeronautics Board will decide in the next two or three weeks to cancel the 22to45day transAtlantic air fares, the lowest available on scheduled fights, a board official said today.

title: How to Get to Track By Subway, Bus or Car
description: Besides horses, Aqueduct has its own subway station. The track in Ozone Park, Queens, can also be reached by car or bus.

title: UNIONS CRITICIZE PUN ON PENSIONS
description: Leaders of public employe unions throughout the state charged yesterday, that the uniform pension law proposed by the State Pension Commission would provide inferior pensions for future employes and would jeopardize the whole structure of collective bargaining in the public sector.

title: John F. Kraft, Opinion Analyst For Political Figures, 48, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 John F. Kraft, a political polltaker whose surveys were used widely by elected officials and aspirants to office, died at his home today of a lung hemorrhage. He was 48 years old.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: IRONCLAD Castiron buildings, those old ones with the rows of iron columns from top to bottom, have been attracting a following in the last few years, enough to stimulate the founding of the Friends of Cast Iron Architecture in 1970 and bring it to a membership of 625 today. Most of New York's castiron buildings are on the West Side, south of 23d Street, perhaps 250 of them in all heights and widths and all dating back to the last century.

title: EDWARDS & HANLY SUING ANACONDA
description: Edwards & Hanly, the prominent Wall Street brokers and investment bankers, brought suit yesterday against the Anaconda Company and Champion International, Inc., for $1.2million in commissions that the brokers claim.

title: CASCADE IS FIFTH IN FLEET STANDING
MRS. MEIR SEEKING $515MILLION AID
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28Premier Golda Meir of Israel, on her current visit, to the United States, is seeking $515million in grants and credits, largely for the purchase of additional weapons, Nixon Administration officials said today.

title: Two Met Prodigals Return in Top Shape
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28  Aside from Dick Allen and his $675,000 contract, the talk of the town in baseball circles today was the New York Mets' reclamation project: Jim Fregosi and Cleon Jones.

title: SHIPS PULL BACK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The United States started to sweep Haiphong harbor of mines yesterday and then, abruptly, stopped all operations and moved its mineclearing task force to sea, according to wellplaced Defense Department sources.

title: Mayor Offers $1.5Billion Plan To Correct City Sewer Failures
description: A $1.5billion master program for citywide stormsewer and sanitarysewer construction to correct the failures of the past 30 years was disclosed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: The Odd Couple
description: Vice President Agnew has taken to describing the Nixon Administration's antipress campaign in which he is one of the principal gladiators as really just a goodnatured skirmish between friendly antagonists. In a speech the other day to the Minnesota Press Association, Mr. Agnew argued that the antipress campaign's chilling effect on the First Amendment, on the freedom of television to comment about the President, and on the vigor of investigative journalism is attributable to the press's own paranoia rather than any real danger.

title: Buoyant Knicks Go After Bucks
description: Feeling somewhat better about themselves after Tuesday night's 12391 rout of the Boston Celtics, the New York Knicks moved on to Milwaukee yesterday for a game against the Bucks tonight, to be televised here on Channel 9 at 9 P.M.

title: Equity Financing
description: INA Corporation announced plans yesterday to repurchase up to 1.45 million of its common shares, subject to approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, whose stoCk closed up 1 at 383 on the New York Stock Exchange, said the reacquired shares would be used for possible acquisitions and other corporate purposes.

title: Con Ed Says It Will Give Notice of Service Cutoff
description: An elderly widow's complaint has resulted in new rules about the cutting off of service to customers who fail to pay their electricity bills to the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: Science Ship Taken in Tow
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Feb. 28 (AP)The Government oceanographic ship Albatross IV, battered by heavy seas, was taken in tow today by a Coast Guard cutter. The 180foot craft, manned by 18 crewmen and 10 scientists, had reported that she had lost steering and was taking on water.

title: Australia Says She Will Protect Secrecy of the U.S. Bases There
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 28  Australia said today that she would stand by her commitment to maintain the secrecy of the controversial United States military installations in this country.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: State and City Move to Avert Cuts in Welfare for Disabled
description: The city and state administrations moved yesterday to avert slashes in welfare payments for aged, blind and disabled relief recipients when the Federal Government takes over those categories next Jan. 1.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Commission for Social Development10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Pollution Pact to Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)  Nixon sent to the Senate for ratification today an international convention designed to regulate the dumping of wastes and other pollutants in international waters.

title: InterestRate Advance Slows As Pressures Appear to Soften
description: Interest rates crept higher of balance yesterday amid some indications that the recent heavy pressures on the credit markets might be moderating at least temporarily.

title: Majesty of Black Woman Photo Show Is Opening
description: The women are black, women, in the words of the artist, an Armenian photographer named Arthur Tcholakian, caught in a moment of truth.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: KARL GEROLD, 67, A GERMAN EDITOR
description: BONN, Feb. 28Karl Gerold, one of West Germany's senior newspaper publishers, who contributed to the postwar revival of Democratic journalism in Germany, died today at his home in Frankfurt. He was 67 years old.

title: Tough Trade Bars Against Japan Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) Commerce Secretary Frederick B. Dent was urged today to enact tough trade policies against Japan until the United StatesJapan balanceoftrade deficit is corrected.

title: 2 PROCESS SERVERS ACCUSED OF PERJURY
description: Two process servers were indicted yesterday on charges of perjury, stemming from alleged sewer service of sum monses on a Brooklyn family faced with mortgage foreclosure proceedings.

title: RANGEL PERFORMS IN KEYBOARD DEBUT
description: Cesar Rangel, a young Venezuelan who studies piano with Beveridge Webster at the Julliard School, made his local recital debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night in the Carnegie HallJeunesses Musicales Series.

title: Bridge: Report on World Olympiad Called One of Best in Series
description: For the cognoscenti who like to study the styles, systems and performances of the experts, there is nothing to compare with the annual series of world championship handbooks published by the American Contract Bridge League.

title: RAILROAD STRIKE DISRUPTS BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Feb. 28  Strikes disrupted industry and and, transportation throughout Britain today as the fight againat the Government's antiinflation measures bit deeper.

title: Survey Finds Majority of Unwed Girls Do Not Use Contraceptive Devices
description: A national survey of unmarried, adolescent girls has indicated that, among the 2.4 million who have had sexual Intercourse, more than half failed to use any form of contraception the last time they had sexual relations.

title: RETIRED ADMIRAL HELPS ELLSBERG
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 The defense has set out with its first witness in the Pentagon papers trial to dispute the Goyenunent's basic contention that Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. have harmed the national defense.

title: Minor Quake Shakes Area From Trenton to Baltimore
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28A minor earthquake lasting about six seconds shook the Philadelphia area at 3:21 A.M. today, waking residents throughout the city and in an area from Trenton to Baltimore.

title: Jerry Jeff Walker Musically Reflects Style of Southwest
description: Jerry Jeff Walker, who opened at Kenny's Castaways, 84th Street off Third Avenue, on Tuesday and continues there through Sunaay, is a country and Western folk singer with an accent on the Western. Mr. Walker is in his early 30's, comes from Oneonta, N. Y., and is best known for his song Mr. Bojangles, from 1968. Since then he has continued to travel about, spending a good deal of time in the South and Southwest, and the styles of those regions have rubbed off on his manner and his music.

title: General Cites Problem Caused By ExAide's. Overrun Report
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 Gen. John D. Ryan, the Air Force Chief of Staff, testified today that we had a hell of a problem on our hands after a former cost analyst, A. Ernest Fitzgerald, disclosed a $2billion cost overrun on the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's C5A transport plane contract.

title: U.S. PLAYERS RETAIN CUP IN COURT TENNIS
description: The United States retained the Bathurst Cup in court tennis by winning the doubles for a 41 triumph over England yesterday at the New York Racquet and Tennis Club.

title: JOHN SHERDON, HEAD OF PRINTING FINANCE
description: John S. Sherdon, director of financial management for the Printing Industries of Metropolitan New York since 1949, died of a heart attack at his home, 26 Reed Drive, Roslyn, L. I., Tuesday. He was 60 years old.

title: 4Party Commission Meets on P.O.W.'s
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March IThe chief delegates to the fourparty Joint Military Commission met in Saigon today.

title: LANSKY CONVICTED IN CONTEMPT CASE
description: MIAMI, Feb. 28Meyer Lansky, the reputed underworld financial figure, was found guilty here today on a criminal contempt charge.

title: A Nelson Concert Blends Live Music With Use of Tape
description: On the basis of his concert Tuesday evening at the Kitchen, Larry Nelson would appear to be a composer with innumerable good ideas, a fine ear for the blending of live and electronic color and a sense for form and focus that still needs a little developing.

title: A British Soldier Guarding Children In Ulster Is Killed
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 28A British soldier was shot dead today as he guarded children on their way home from school.

title: Italy Plans to End Atlantic Ship Runs
description: ROME, Feb. 28  Italy will withdraw her statesubsidized passenger ships from service between New York and Mediterranean ports and from all other longdistance routes within the next five years under a bill that the Government sent to Parliament today.

title: Despite Tragedy, Met Is Her Home Now
description: She is being seen around town more and more, mostly at concerts or other musical events. Her social calendar it fullusually in connection with the Metropolitan Operaand everywhere she es she attracts attention. She would rather that this did not happen.

title: Parents Let Girl, 3, Puff Marijuana to Fatten Up
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Feb. 28 A clam digger and his wife have been charged with giving their 3yearold daughter some puffs on a marijuana cigarettean attempt, they told the police, to help her gain weight.

title: MARY FINNEY DIES; CHARACTER ACTRESS
description: Mary Finney, a character actress, died Tuesday of emphysema at her home at 234 West 13th Street. Her age was 68.

title: BREWSTER RHOADS, TRIAL LAWYER, DEAD
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 (AP) C. Brewster Rhoads, a lawyer who participated in United States Supreme Court cases involving the dismissal of Communist teachers and the reading of the Bible in public schools, died today of a heart attack while vacationing at Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived in Huntington Park.

title: 6 Senators Are Denied Power for News Talk
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The office of George M. White, Architect of the Capitol, refused today to allow the use of electrical outlets in the Capitol Rotunda for a televised news conference by six Senators.

title: HANOI RAID COST SET AT $25MILLION A DAY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (Reuters)The American bombing of North Vietnam last December cost more than $25million a day but was so precise that Hanoi residents felt it safe to come out and watch the attacks on military targets, a Defense Department official said today.

title: JOBS IN CITY DOWN 3D YEAR IN A ROW
description: The number of jobs in New York City decreased last year by 68,000, according to figures released yesterday by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. The yearly decline was the third in a row.

title: Jesse Gray Is No. 7 in Mayoral Race
description: Assemblyman Jesse Gray of Manhattan yesterday became he first black to announce his andidacy for the Democratic mayoral nomination. Mr. Gray, who made his formal announcement on the steps of City Hall, is the seventh announced canlidate for the Democratic nomination.

title: Mystic Is Bracing To Refloat Whaler
description: MYSTIC, Conn.They are getting ready to refloat the Charles W. Morgan.

title: Newswomen's Club Here Elects Five New Officers
description: The Newswomen's Club of New York has elected Mile Andre of The Daily News as its president, it was announced yesterday.

title: PLEDGE TO ROGERS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The White House said today that North Vietnam had given new assurances that all American prisoners of war would be released within the 60day period agreed to last month.

title: Life Term for Pushers
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Feb. 28 (UPI) The New Mexico Senate passed today legislation requiring mandatory life imprisonment without the possibility of parole for convicted narcotics dealers. The bill must be approved by the House.

title: STRIKE BY TEACHERS SET FOR PROVIDENCE
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 1 (AP)A strike was called by Providence school teachers today in protest of plans for dismissal of 141 teachers.

title: 10 Held for Selling Methadone After East Side Clinic Is Raided
description: The police raided a private methadone clinic on the Upper East Side yesterday that they had kept under surveillance for two months and arrested 10 persons on charges of illegally selling methadone.

title: Business Briefs
description: A Federal judge signed yesterday a final judgment, ordering the Crane Company, a maker of plumbing and other products based in New York, to avoid unlawful recip rocal purchasing agreements with customers and suppliers.

title: DEFENSE SCORES IN EXTORTION AS
description: CAMDEN, March 1 (AP)The prosecution in the Federal extortionconspiracy trial of four present and former Atlantic City officials was blocked today from tendering in evidence a number of checks that it said amounted to 10 per cent of certain expenditures in the construction of the $15million Convention Hall Annex in Atlantic City.

title: No Choice on Rents
description: The continuing acute shortage of apartments in New York City, especially at rents middleclass families can afford to pay, necessitates City Council approvalwith amendmentsof the threeyear extension, of rent controls recommended by Mayor Lindsay.

title: Japan Denies Plan To Act Against U.S. For Nixon's '71 Acts
description: TOKYO, March 1 (AP)The Foreign Ministry took the highly unusual step today of formally denying that the Japanese Government planned any retaliation against the United States for the economic and diplomatic shocks to Tokyo resulting from President Nixon's initiatives in 1971.

title: U.S. Ambassador to Sudan and His Aide Reported Seized by Guerrillas at Party
description: WASHINGTON, March 1The State Department received reports today that Palestinian guerrillas in the Sudan had captured five diplomats, including the United States Ambassador and outgoing charg d'affaires, and were seeking to exchange them, for several hundeed prisoners, including Sirhan han, the murderer of Robert F. Kennedy.

title: Leading Jockey Suspended
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 1 (AP)Nelson Menard, leading jockey at the Fair Grounds, was suspended for a fiveday period today for what track stewards, called careless riding.

title: Hofstra Students Split on Drug Raids
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 1 Hofstra students who took a hard line on the use of drugs on campus and another group critical of the administration for its cooperation with the police in drug raids met separately today to make their positions known.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 1.5 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose; to 146.1 from 144.6 last week.

title: Italians Seek F.B.I. Aid on a Greek Cup
description: ROME, March 1The Italian authorities today asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to inquire about a Greek cup that had been offered for sale in the United States, in the belief that it might be crucial in establishing the origins of the Euphronios vase bought by the Metropolitan Museum of Art last year for about $1million.

title: DR. EARL DEARBORN, PHARMACOLOGIST, 57
description: NEW HAVEN, March 1Dr. Earl H. Dearborn, a leading pharmacologist and president of the Miles Research Division of Miles Laboratories, Inc., died of cancer yesterday. He was 57 years old.

title: ROGERS SATISPIED
description: PARIS, March 1The international conference on Vietnam completed its work today, and 12 foreign ministers initialed an agreement providing a means to call the conference back into session if the ceasefire breaks down. The document is to be signed tomorrow.

title: JUDGE IS SEEKING DALEY AS WITNESS
description: The judge in the trial of H. Rap Brown called on Connecticut authorities yesterday to compel the appearance of Robert Daley as a witness.

title: Rawalpindi Students Burn British Library
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 1Students set fire to the British Council Library in Rawalpindi today after the arrival of the coffins of two Pakistani youths shot by policemen in a raid on the Indian High Commission in London last week.

title: Untaxed Cigarettes Seized
description: FORESTVILLE, Md., March 1 (UPI)  Maryland policemen seized a record haul of untaxed cigarettes in a New Yorkbound tractortrailer today and arrested the driver. A spokesman for the Maryland controller's office said that the illegal cigarettes bought in North Carolina filled more than half of a 50foot trailer. The rig was driven by Edward Paulix, 45 years old, of Maspeth, Queens.

title: DAVIDSON DEFEATS Y.M.I. FIVE 88.77
description: RICHMOND, March 1 (AP)Davidson survived a secondhalf scare for an 8877 victory over Virginia Military, Furman walloped Appalachian State, 10168, and William and Mary beat the Citadel; 9772, today in the opening round of the Southern Conference basketball tournament.

title: Equity Financing
description: Nomura Securities Co., Ltd., of Tokyo said it had completed placement of 400,000 shares of Continental Telephone Corp. with Japanese institutions, a transaction in which Burnham & Co. and E. F. Hutton acted as financial advisers. The company's stock was down  at 21 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Fairchild AX Fighter Contract Upheld After Federal Reviews
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I., March 1The Air Force announced today that it was signing $186million contract with the Republic Division of Fairchild Industries here and the General Electric Company to build the AX fighter.

title: CORD A. MEYER
description: Cord A. Meyer, a retired realestate man, died yesterday in a nursing home. He was 93 years old and lived with, his daughter, Mrs. Florence Gillen, on Christian Avenue in Stony Brook, L. I.

title: MEDIA AND ELITISTS ASSAILED BY AGNEW
description: LOWELL, Mass., March 1Vice President Agnew renewed his attacks tonight on the news media and on the elitists that he said had seized the Democratic party.

title: PEKING PROPOSES TALKS WITH TAIPEI
description: PEKING, March 1China announced today an offer to hold direct negotiations with the Chinese Nationalist Government in Taiwan and delivered a warning agaiinst any attempt to replace the American presence there with that of someone else, an oblique refrence to the Soviet Union.

title: MISS MAGNUSSEN WINS WORLD TITLE
description: BRATISLAVA, Czechoslavakia, March 1 (UPI)  Karen Magnussen of Vancouver, Brit ish Columbia won the women's world figure skating title tonight with a runaway victory over America's Janet, Lynn, whose brilliant freestyle exhibition couldn't overcome her mistakes yesterday.

title: New Boycott Cuts Canarsie School Attendance
description: A new boycott sharply cut school attendance in Canarsie yesterday as demonstratorsdemanding the future exclusion of black pupils from outside the areamarched in front of eight schools in the largely white Brooklyn community.

title: WESTBURY OPENS A 72NIGHT STAND
description: WESTBURY, L. I., March?? Harnessracing fans will turn their attentionand in most instances their money  to Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.

title: Abortions Cheaper Than Anywhere Else Planned
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, March 1An outpatient abortion and sterilization clinic, the Palisades Medical Group, is scheduled to open here April 15, according to Dr. Robert M. Livingston, who with 19 other Bergen County obstetricians and gynecologists will staff the new facility.

title: Vietcong Captive Tells of 7Year Ordeal
description: WASHINGTON, March 1Douglas K. Ramsey, a 38yearold Foreign Service officer who spent seven years in Vietcong captivity, told today of forced marches, isolation, bedberi, malaria, meals of monkey, dog and bear meat, crude cages, shackles, chains and the jungle burial of a fellow prisoner.

title: Indians at Wounded Knee Free 11 Held for 2 Days
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., March 1  Senators George McGovern and James. G. Abourezk of South Dakota announced tonight that the 11 hostages held at Wounded Knee by militant American Indians hid been told that they were free to go. But, the Senators added, the 11 were staying because their homes are in the tiny hamlet.

title: Public Disclosure Urged For TaxAssessment Cuts
description: The chairman of a City Council committee looking into charges of irregularities in realestate tax assessments said yesterday that the city's Tax Commission should be forced to make public a list of all property owners who receive tax assessment reductions after private hearings with Tax Commissioners.

title: Dr. Richard Sheinblatt Weds Caryl Goldshine
description: Miss Caryl Goldshine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Goldshine of Sarasota, Fla., was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Richard Sheinblatt, son of Mrs. Michael Sheinblatt of Elizabeth, N. J., and the late Dr. Sheinblatt. Rabbi Ronald Sobol performed the ceremony in Temple EmanuEl.

title: SoSo Hamburgers Better With Cheese
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday, are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Vietcong Captive Tells of 7Year Ordeal
description: WASHINGTON, March 1Douglas K. Ramsey, a 38yearold Foreign Service officer who spent seven years in Vietcong captivity, told today of forced marches, isolation, beriberi, malaria, meals of monkey, dog and bear meat, crude cages, shackles, chains and the jungle burial of a fellow prisoner.

title: Currency Turmoil Cited
description: With the international money markets once again in turmoil, the Federal Reserve System pumped massive amounts of funds into the money market this week.

title: Automobile Sellers Are Now Required To Certify Mileage
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 Sellers of automobiles must certify from now on that the, mileage shown on the odometers is accurate to the best of their knowledge.

title: Maxwell House lncreases Wholesale Coffee Prices
description: One day after the Cost of Living Council lifted controls on the price of coffee in the United States, the Maxwell House division of the General Foods Corporation announced yesterday wholesale price increases on its ground and soluble coffees. Other leading coffee producers said they had not yet reached a decision on whether to raise prices. Also announced yesterday were an increase of onehalf cent a pound in the price of leadand increases in other metals, chemicals; automobiles and fibers.

title: Interest Rates Climb
description: Interest rates moved still higher yesterday in apparent response to revived fears about the international currency markets and steppedup demands for funds to finance the vigorous business expansion.

title: The Governor's Deterrent Theory
description: NEW HAVENPublic officials have finally reacted to a national crisis which has long torn at the quality of urban life and which has, more recently, invaded the suburbs.

title: N.A.A.C.P. URGES SHIFT BY BRANCH
description: The head office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People repudiated yesterday a compromise plan endorsed last week by the association's Atlanta branch that would limit the degree of school integration in Atlanta's inner city.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 2, 1973

title: COPPER TRADING CURTAILED HERE
description: Trading in copper futures on the Commodity Exchange was so brisk yesterday that the closing bell was rung at noon instead of the usual 2:10 P.M. Another shortened session is planned for today.

title: Congress Acts to Restore Rural Aid
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 Congress stepped up its demands today that President Nixon spend, funds as it directed.

title: JOHN E. O'GARA DIES; EXMACY OFFICIAL
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., March 1 John E. O'Gara, from 1935 to 1950 vice president and general manager of R.H. Macy & Co., the New York department store, died today in Good Samaritan Hospital, West Palm Beach. He was 77 years old.

title: Most Ancient Art Smuggled, Curator Says
description: The curator of ancient ar at the Cleveland Museum said yesterday that 95 per cent o?? ancient art material in this country has been smuggled in.

title: Watson Is Leaving 51st State; Associates Cite Interference
description: Patrick J. Watson, host and editor of The 51st State daily news program on WNET Channel 13, said yesterday he was leaving the station March 31 for Personal reasons.

title: MISS MAGNUSSEN WINS WORLD TITLE
description: BRATISLAVA, Czechoslavakia, March 1 (UPI)  Karen Magnussen of Vancouver, British Columbia won the women's world figure skating title tonight with a runaway victory over America's Janet Lynn, whose brilliant freestyle exhibition couldn't overcome her mistakes yesterday.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, March 1The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the week totaled an estimated 15.9 billion tonmiles, 12.2 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same week totaled 506,035 cars, 9.7 per cent above last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 13.2 per cent above last year.

title: FRANCIS H. LEWIS
description: Francis Harry Lewis, who retired in 1952 as an appraiser and examiner for the United States Customs Bureau here, died Monday at his home, 9935 59th Avenue, Rego Park, Queens. He was 93 years old.

title: GROCERIES UP 2.4% HERE IN JANUARY
description: Grocery prices in the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area rose 2.4 per cent in January, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics disclosed yesterday.

title: ADMIRAL PRESSED IN ELLSBERG CASE
description: LOS ANGELES, March 1In his first crossexamination of a defense witness in the Pentagon papers trial, the prosecutor spent today trying to discredit a former planner for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who had previously testified that disclosure of the papers had not damaged the national defense.

title: U. S. Jury Indicts 2 Sons of H. L. Hunt For Tapping Phone
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) Two sons of H. L. Hunt, the Texas oil millionaire, have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of tapping the telephones of Hunt Oil Company employes, the Justice Department said today.

title: COWLES IS DROPPING CONTRACT RENEWAL
description: Gardner Cowles, founder and chairman of the board of Cowles Communications, Inc., has elected not to renew his employment contract, which had been extended to March at the company's request last Dec. 31, when it was scheduled to expire.

title: Blue Cross Told to Cover Some Ineligible Ill People
description: TRENTON, March 1Blue Cross of New Jersey was ordered today to extend its coverage to many people now barred because of illness.

title: [Reprinted From Yesterday's Late Edition]
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 28 (UPI)Jose Napoles, the aging but still brilliant world welterweight champion with blood streaming down his right cheek, kept his title tonight by knocking out Ernie (Indian Red) Lopez of Los Angeles with a vicious right uppercut to the chin at 1 minute 36 seconds of the seventh round of their scheduled 15round fight.

title: HOUSE BILL ASKS MARKET CHANGES
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) The chairman of a House subcommittee today asked Congress to make sweeping changes in two of the most controversial areas of the stock market.

title: Red Smith
description: When the Supreme Court turned back Curt Flood's break for freedom last June, Bowie Kuhn welcomed the decision as constructive. Now, he said, baseball could reshape the reserve system for itself through renewed collective bargaining. I am confident, he said, that the players and the clubs will both take a most responsible view of their respective obligations to the public and the game. Now that another round of collective bargaining has been concluded, one wonders whether the commissioner's confidence remains unshaken. Those Sports obligations to the public et cetera have been of discharged by forgetting them for three years. Through the negotiations, the owners' The Times position on the reserve clause was firm: Don't mention it before 1976 at the earliest. Still, the players did gain important ground in the agreement they have just ratified, and anyway, the chances are the struggle over the reserve system is one they couldn't win sat the negotiating table or even through successful strike. Any concessions the owners were forced to make on paper would probably be nullified by socalled gentlemen's agreements.

title: LINDSAY DEMANDS FORCEFUL MAYOR
description: Mayor Lindsay assailed Senator Jacob K. Javits, Governor Rockefeller and President Nixon yesterday in a purely political speech in which he said that the next Mayor must be a progrespive and independent Democrat who would not kowtow to President Nixon or to Governor Rockefeller.

title: Concord Hotel Closes in Labor Deadlock
description: The Concord Hotel, the largest resort hotel in the Catskills, suspended operations last night in a labor dispute.

title: Advertising: Cutty Sark's Story
description: Now here is the heartwarming, but previously secret, story of how an ad agency won a multimilliondollar Scotch account with a 160yearold battle cry.

title: Brandt and Heath Meet on Dollar Influx
description: BONN, March 1The West German Government tonight ordered currency markets closed tomorrow in response to a massive influx of more than $2.5pillion in speculative money.

title: Red Cross Month
description: March, is Red Cross month throughout the country, and in this city the Red Cross is giving a dual emphasis to its campaignasking New Yorkers to volunteer their services as well as to contribute the necessary funds. Marking the important contribution they make, Mayor Lindsay has presented a certificate to the American Red Cross volunteers citing distinguished and exceptional services in New York for their dedicated efforts toward the alleviation of human suffering in our city.

title: People and Business
description: Threeandahalf years ago, Harry S. Pack, a profesor of business law at Long Island University, paid about $40,000 for a onethird interest in a small upstate New York bank. Today, Mr. Pack, no longer in the groves of academe, is chairman of a bank near the St. Lawrence Seaway that resulted from a merger of his first bank and two othersand is treasurerof a new Wall, Street municipal bond house as well.

title: McGuire Command Shifts
description: McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N. J., March 1 (AP)Maj. Gen. Ray M. Cole assumed command today of the 21st Air Force, headquartered here. He succeeds Maj. Gen. Roland A. Campbell, 55 years old, who retired.

title: U.S. HOUSING AIDB DEFENDS FREEZE
description: The Nixon. Administration's top housing official in the New York area differed sharply with city officials yesterday over the impact of the Administration's controversial freeze on new housing subsidies.

title: Trade Bill Under Wraps
description: The President has not yet disclosed the precise contents of the trade bill he intends to submit to Congress, but the Administration's advance ballyhoo makes what lurks beneath the veil sound like the most exciting package since Little Egyptappealing to business and labor, to farmers and housewives, to balanceofpayments optimists and pessimists, to freetraders and protectionists, and even to Democrats and Republicans alike.

title: 42,352 Car Licenses Held Up Over Pines
description: The city's Parking Violations Bureau has held up the registration of 42,352 autos in the first quarter of 1973 to force their owners to pay all their accumulated parking fines.

title: Volcker Sees No Need for New Dollar Devaluation
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 The latest monetary crisis caught this capital by surprise. As far as is known, no United States action is contemplated or is being requested by beleaguered European countries, though there was telephone contact during the day.

title: Squires Top Q's, 125124, On Final Shot of the Dane
description: NORFOLK, Va., March 1(AP) Fatty Taylor dropped in a baseline jumper at the buzzer tonight aS the Virginia Squires beat the San Diego Conquistadors, 125124, in an American Basketball Association game. Taylor's score came after he stole the bail from Stew Johnson.

title: U. S. Birth Rate Drops to a Record Low
description: WASHINGTON, March 1American birth and fertility rates last year dropped to their lowest levels in history, and even the absolute number of babies born was the smallest hi 27 years.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: There are probably no pastimes more innocuous than birdwatching, but the town of Gill, Mass., may have some doubts about this.

title: Ottawa Wins 3d in Row, 21
description: OTTAWA, March 1 (AP) Wayne Carleton's goal with 3 minutes left in the third period gave Ottawa a 21 World Hockey Association victory over the New York Raiders tonight and lifted the Nationals into serious contention for a playoff berth.

title: THROAT OBSCENE, JUDGE RULES HERE
description: Criminal Court Judge. Joel J. Tyler yesterday found the film Deep Throat obscene indisputably and irredeemably and began a process that could resuit in a fine of more than $1million for its principal exhibitor in Manhattan.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, March 1  Someone from the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics told Bill Boylan, the Monmouth College basketball coach, that a victory over Trenton State last night would mean a spot in the N.A.I.A. tournament. So, Monmouth defeated Trenton State, 8375, and gained a berth in the Section 31 tournament, along with Dowling, Marist and Glassboro State.It came as a shock to us to be picked, Boylan told the New Jersey College basketball writers today. We have been playing well in the past few weeks and have won seven in a row, but with a 13and13 record who would expect something like this?

title: Urban League Chief Challenges Nixon View on Gains by Blacks
description: WASHINGTON, March 1Vernon E. Jordan, executive director of the National Urban League, said tonight that the free enterprise system had failed blacks, and he challenged President Nixon's conclusions in his human resources message to Congress earlier in the day.

title: HEINZ POSTS A LOSS FOR THIRD QUARTER
description: Extraordinary charges of $25 million in the third fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31 resulted in a net loss of $17.6million for the H. J. Heinz Company, according to a report by the Pittsburghbased food company yesterday.

title: Mazdas With Wankel Engines Meet '75 Standard
description: DETROIT, March 1The Environmental Protection Agency issued test results today that showed that two Mazda automobiles with Wankel engines met Federal emission standards for 1975.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: School Boycott Back in Canarsie

title: U.S. Begins a New Inquiry on Vesco
description: United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. has begun criminal proceedings against Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier who made a secret $200,000 contribution to the Finance Committee to Reelect the President.

title: Ditka Retires to Coach Receivers for Cowboys
description: DALLAS, March 1 (UPI)Mike Ditka, who caught more passes for more yards than any other tight end in pro football history, retired today to become the receiver coach for the Dallas Cowboys.

title: AntiAbortion Bill Voted By Legislature in Maine
description: AUGUSTA, Mr. March 1 (AP)  The Maine Senate approved today, 24 to 7, an antiabortion proposal that would amend the Federal Constitution to give every human the right to life regardless of the stage of biological development.

title: Laborites Receive A Painful Setback In 2 ByElections
description: LONDON, Friday, March 2The Labor party suffered a painful setback in two parliamentary byelections today. In one case it lost a seat to an unofficial Labor candidate and in the other it narrowly held off a challenge by a Scottish. nationalist.

title: DEFENSE OUTLE IN NATO WILL RISE
description: LONDON, Feb. 28Deferse spending by the United States' allies in Europe is scheduled to rise significantly this year, but trained manpower available for armies, navies and air forces is to decline.

title: Japan Demands Equality
