description: WASHINGTON, March 1The other day, when former Premier Sato of Japan was in Washington, he said with the gentlest courtesy that he hoped the United States, Europe and Japan could do a better job of consuiting with one another about their common economic, monetary, political and security problems.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 2, 1973

title: Uruguayans, Their Life Ever More Drab, Are Apathetic After Coup
description: MONTEVIDEO. Uruguay There is a current fascination here with sentimental old tangos recalling bygone and better days.

title: MONETARY CRISIS FLARES UP AGAIN; DOLLAR WEAKENS
description: ZURICH, March 1A fresh monetary crisis swept across Europe today, less than three weeks after the dollar was devalued for the second time in 14 months. It brought heavy selling of the weakened dollar, and foreignexchange centers in Europe and Japan were ordered closed tomorrow.

title: State Pension Plan Faces Major Surgery
description: ALBANY, March 1The uniform pension plan proposed by the State Pension Commission appears doomed in its present form, the chairmen of legislative committees holding public hearings on the proposal said today. They added that was headed for major revialen.

title: Kahn Begins Jail Sentence
description: Irving Kahn, former head of the Teleprompter Corporation, surrendered yesterday to begin serving a sentence of five years in prison as a result of his conviction on charges of conspiracy, bribery and perjury. Kahn was convicted in Federal Court here in 1971 for having paid $15,000 to city officials in Johnstown, Pa., to obtain an exclusive cabletelevision franchise for Teleprompter.

title: Interests in Peace
description: International endorsement of the Vietnam peace agreements and the rapid resolution of the block on releasing American war prisoners are reassuring signs that North Vietnam, as well as the United States, continue to regard the Jan. 27 ceasefire arrangements as serving their best national interests.

title: Seatrain Lines Accused by U.S. Of Favoring European Shippers
description: Seatrain Lines, one of the nation's biggest containership carriers, was named by the United States Attorney for New Jersey yesterday in a 674count criminal information alleging that it granted illegal rebates, discounts and preferential rate treatment to European shippers in 1970 and 1971.

title: Profit in Year Off 25%
Colgate Hits 73.7 Per Cent, Routs Fairleigh, 73 to 54
description: RUTHERFORD, N. J., March 1  Colgate University, making 73.7 per cent of its fieldgoal attempts, routed Fairleigh Dickinson University tonight, 7354.

title: Retirement Put Off
description: WASHINTON, March 1 (AP) President Nixon issued today an executive order exempting a Federal Trade Commission member, A. Everette MacIntyre, from compulsory retirement until Feb. 20 of next year, Mr. MacIntyre, 72 years old, had previously continued to serve under a Presidential exception, which expired three days ago. Without such an order, Federal officials must retire at age 70.

title: Eastern League Vetoes Rule
description: PHILADELPHIA, March (AP)  The Eastern Baseball League has decided against using the designated pinchhitter rule adopted by the American League, Roy Jackson, the league president, said today.

title: J. Anthony Forstmann To Wed Charlotte Ford
description: When Charlotte Ford is married to J. Anthony Forstmann on May 1, she will be spared the expense of changing the initial on her silver.

title: Stage
description: OUT CRY, a Play by Tennessee Williams. Directed by Peter Glenville; lighting and setting by Jo Mielriner; costumes by Sandy Cole; Production stage manager, Alan Hall, Presented by the David Merrick Arts Foundation and Kennedy Center Productions, Inc. At the Lyceum Theater, West 45th Street.

title: People in Sports: Eangle Voted Into Hall of Fame
description: Charles (Rip) Engle, who became one of the nation's foremost college football coaches with his achievements at Brown and Penn State, was named to the Football Hall of Fame yesterday. The announcement was made by Dick Kazmaier, the awards chairman.

title: Records: Ethel Waters
description: Amidst the recent flurry of interest in Billie Holiday and Bessie Smith, the third basic voice in the jazzbluespep panorna of the twenties and thirties has been almost overlooked. Maybe it's because Ethel Waters is known too well now as an actress. Or maybe it's because her important days in the jazz and pop, if not the blues, fields were too long ago (although, in actuality, no longer ago than Bessie Smith's).

title: PEKING PROPOSES TALKS WITH TAIPEI
description: PEKING, March 1China announced today an offer to hold direct negotiations with the Chinese Nationalist Government in Taiwan and delivered a warning agalinst any attempt to replace the American presence there with that of someone else, an oblique refrence to the Soviet Union.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: TRIBES IN RWANDA REPORTED TO CLASH
description: MUSSELS, March 1 (AP)A renewal of tribal slaughter has been reported in East Africa, where thousands died last year in clashes between the Tutsi and the Hutu. A Belgian Government spokesman confirmed today that there is a serious situation in Rwanda, but he declined to comment on reports of recent bloodshed in the former Belgian colony.

title: Pudding Show Appeals to Steinern
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1The 125th annual version of the Hasty Pudding show, that zany diversion for bored intellectuals, opened here last night, and despite the fact that the Hasty Pudding Club began to admit women last month, no one dreamed of allowing any on stage. But Gloria Steinern and Julia Child were present, the latter spooning pudding into Jack Lemmon, an alumnus.

title: Vietcong Identify American P.O.W.'s Who Will Be Released This Weekend
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fridaf, March 2Delegates of the Joint Military Commission met today and the Vietcong turned over to United States delegates the names of 27 American military prisoners and seven civilians who are to be released this weekend.

title: Bergen G.O.P. Counters 2 Insurgent Court Suits
description: HACKENSACK, March 1 The Bergen County Republican Committee has asked for the dismissal of two court suits brought by. Republican insurgents who are seeking, among other things, to examine the organization's financial records.

title: ChoateRosemary Hall Appoints a President
description: Charles F. Dey, dean, of the Tucker Foundation at Dartmouth College, will become president of the Choate School and Rosemary Hall, coordinate schools at Wallingford, Conn., when the Rev. Seymour St. John retires this June after 26 years as headmaster of Choate.

title: Music: A Twin Bill at the City Opera
description: The New York City Opera's coupling of Stravinsky's Oedipus Rex and Orff's Carmina Burana, by no means as temperamentally congenial for twinbill purposes as Cav and Pag, makes sense of another theatrical kind. The spring season's first performance of the two works one purposely static and austere, the other purposely crude and sensuousmade for an effective contrast, musically and intellectually.

title: Newark School Official Charged in Flag Offense
description: NEWARK, March 1Adhimu Chunga, the 19yearold schoolboard member and follower of Imamu Amiri Baraka, the black nationalist, was charged today with violating a state statute for refusing to stand during the salute to the flag.

title: Council Curbs Gas Tanks And the Massage Parlors
description: The City Council yesterday overwhelmingly approved bills designed to get rid of illicit massage parlors, to prevent the construction of large, volatile liquefiedgas storage tanks and to restrict the city's use of tax returns to verify incomes of MitchellLama tenants.

title: . Chief of U.S. Volunteers
description: WASHINGTON, March 1When her younger son quit school, Mrs. Michael P. Balzano Sr. said, she did not press the issue. When a boy doesn't want to go to school what do you do? she said today from her home in New Haven during a telephone interview. Her son, Michael Pasquale Balzano Jr., eventually went back to school, all the way to earnin a Doctorate in political philosophy. Today, the 37yearold political theorist was named director of Action, the Federal agency that administers volunteer programs such as the Peace Corps abroad and Volunteers in Service to America.

title: MILE RECORD SET BY LINDAS CHIEF
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 1 (UPI)Linda's Chief, the favorite, raced to a fivelength victory over Ancient Title in the $56,900 San Jacinto Stakes today in the trackrecord time of 1:33 45 for one mile at Santa Anita.

title: Dispute Splits Advanced Study Institute
description: PRINCETON, N. J.  The Institute for Advanced Study, that unique institution of scholarship at the highest level, where Einstein worked and Robert Oppenheimer ruled, is being shaken by the greatest crisis of its four decades.

title: Manhattan Wins, 77 to 63; Keeps N.I.T. Hope Alive
description: Manhattan College may have come alive just in time. The National Invitation Tournament committee is begging for local entry and the Jaspers defeated West Virginia, 7763, last night in the first game of a college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

title: Ward Posts 23% Gain
description: Consumer buying rose sharply in the nation's department, variety and catalogue stores, last month, providing several of the country's largest retailers with big sales gains over the yearearlier month.

title: Moslem Editor in Greece Is Jailed Under Press Law
description: ATHENS, March 1  A Moslem editor in northern Greece has received the heaviest punishment ever imposed under the press code that went into effect just over two Years ago.

title: St. Louis Ends Loss String
description: BOSTON March 1 (AP)Bob Plager and Garry Unger scored goals 24 seconds apart early in the third period and the St. Louis Blues held on tonight for a 43 National Hockey League victory over the Boston Bruins.

title: Critics Assail Bipartisan Plan To Kill Primary for Chief Judge
description: A bipartisan bill to abolish the statewide primary for chief judge of the Court of Appeals was denounced yesterday as an illegal, insidious deal between Governor Rockefeller and the Democrats.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WOMEN WRIGHTS The American Women Playwrights Association is only three months old, barely starting along the road to its goal: to let women writers have opportunities to develop their talent. It is part of the feminist movement but not a militant group in that the women who work with it approach all topics, not solely women's lib situations.

title: 3 NEW YORKERS GAIN IN U.S. COURT TENNIS
description: Howard Angus of England recovered from the loss of the opening set and gained the semifinal round of the United States amateur court tennis championship by 56, 62, 62, 63 over Jerry Bijur of Philadelphia yesterday at the New York Racquet and Tennis Club.

title: A Vietcong Office at U.N. Considered by Waldheim
description: PARIS, March 1Secretary General Waldheim said today that he had discussed the possibility of a Vietcong liaison office at United Nations Headquarters and that Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh had said her Provisional Revolutionary Government favored opening one.

title: Navy's Big Guns Ready For I. C. 4A Title Shot
description: Four years ago track and field athletes at Army and Navy were forced to withdraw from a major championship meet because of protest statements drawn up by rival collegiate athletes against the expansion of the war in Indochina.

title: Stars Subdue Chaparrals After Slow Start, 119112
description: SALT LAKE. CITY, March (AP) The injuryplagued Utah Stars, paced by Willie Wise's 31 points, downed the Dallas Chaparrals, 119112, in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery said yesterday that malicious false alarms had declined in February, the fifth such monthly decline. False alarms, the biggest nonfire problem faced by firemen, dropped 1,165 from last year's level, to 5,627. The total number of malicious false alarms in January and February, 1973,. was 11,597, down from 13,843 for the first two months of 1972, he said, adding: In terms of manpower and equipment, the decline is significant.

title: Gray Says Mitchell Blocked Interview With His Wife on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, March 1L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, told a Senate committee today that his agents had wanted to interview Mrs, John N. Mitchell during their investigation of the Watergate affair but that they were refused permission to do so by Mr. Mitchell.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: John: V. Kenny, former Hudson County political leader, was released yesterday morning from a Federal prison hospital in Missouri, where, he had been sent last May. after pleading guilty to six counts of incometax evasion. Kenny, who is 79 years old, reportedly suffers from heart and other ailments. He was wheeled out of the hospital to a car and was greeted by members of his family.

title: A Vietcong Office at U.N. Considered by Waldheim
description: PARIS, March 1Secretary General Waldheim said today that he had discussed the possibility of a Vietcong liaison office at United Nations Headquarters and that Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh had said her Provisional Revolutionary Government favored opening one.

title: Return to Wounded Knee
description: Such is the history of this nation's dealings with the American Indian that indignation over the current violence at Wounded Knee, S. D., is inevitably tinged with shame. Americans of today need not assume burden of guilt for what the white man did to the Indians over a period of four centuries; but it is fair enough that they should feel guilty for the squalor which the remnants of a proud civilization have since been livingfrom the last armed confrontation in 1890 to this week's exchange of heavy gunfire.

title: They Build Something Large And Floaty and ... Awesome
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y.What's pale pink, baby blue, homemade and flies?

title: Scheduled Outlays In Building Climbed By 14% in January
description: Contracts for future construction reversed a downward trend in January and rose to the highest level since last September.

title: Pentagon Rebuffs Grumman, Litton Over Price Rises
description: WASHINGTON, March 1The Navy rejected today demands by the Grumman Aerospace Corporation and Litton Industries, Inc., for large price increases for armaments.

title: Judge Bars Suit to Prevent Jailing of Coast Newsman
description: LOS ANGELES, March 1 (UPI)  A taxpayers' suit by three fellow newsmen, seeking an order against the use of public funds to jail a Los Angeles Times reporter, William T. Farr, was dismissed yesterday.

title: Sports Today
description: Brown at Columbia, 8 P.M.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ROGERS SATISFIED
description: PARIS, March 1The international conference on Vietnam completed its work today, and 12 foreign ministers initialed an agreement providing a means to call the conference back into session if the ceasefire breaks down. The document is to be signed tomorrow.

title: BUS DRIVER LOSES PLEA TO VOID CASE
description: NEW CITY, N.Y., March 1 The attorney for Joseph Larkin, the driver of the school bus that collided with a freight train in Congers last March 24, sought unsuccessfully today to obtain dismissal of the charges of criminally negligent homicide against his client.

title: ENVIRONMENT CURBS HELD HOUSING LOSS
description: Environmental restrictions are likely to exert a small but significant restraint on total housing activity this year, a housing expert said yesterday.

title: Fine Music by Lenny & Danny & Isaac
description: The Pension Fund Concert of the New York Philharmonic, on Wednesday evening, was literally a relaxed evening of niusical chairs. Leonard Bernstein played the piano and later conducted. Daniel Barenboim played the piano and later conducted. Mr. Barenboim conducted for Isaac Stern. Mr. Bernstein conducted for Mr. Barenboim. How did Mr. Stern refrain from picking up the baton?

title: Cecil Kellaway, Actor, 79, Dies; Was Twice an Oscar Nominee
description: HOLLYWOOD, March 1 (AP) The longtime character actor Cecil Kellaway, known best for his roles as a kindly doctor and family friend in scores of movies, died here on Wednesday. He was 79 years old.

title: TeenAger Sentenced to Die For Boston RapeMurder
description: BOSTON, March 1 (UPI) A teenager convicted of raping and murdering a 57yearold woman last year was sentenced yesterday to die in the electric chair.

title: Pentagon Rebuffs Grumman, Litton Over Price Rises
description: WASHINGTON, March 1The Navy rejected today demands by the Grumman Aerospace Corporation and Litton Industries, Inc., for large price increases for armaments.

title: Lynch's Party Is Defeated In Ireland After 16 Years
description: DUBLIN, Friday March 2The Fianna Fail party, which governed Ireland for the last 16 years, was toppled from power in the general election on Wednesday by a coalition of Fine Gaelits traditional rivaland the smaller Labor party.

title: TRANSAMERICA NET UP FOR 4TH QUARTER
description: The Transamerica Corporation increased it consolidated net income in the fourth quarter to $21.2million, or 31 cents a share from $12.8million, or 19 cents a share, in the 1971 final quarter, bringing the full year's results up 41 per cent to a record, John R. Beckett, chairman and president, reported yesterday.

title: List of Baseball Holdouts
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: President Formally Drops Plan For Guaranteed Annual Income
description: WASHINGTON, March 1President Nixon formally abandoned today; at least for the time being, his plan for a welfare reform program that would have provided for a form of guaranteed annual income.

title: Bread Tax Repeal Asked
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) Eight Senators introduced today legislation to prevent further rises in the cost of bread by repealing the socalled bread tax, which they said adds about 2 cents to the price of a loaf. The tax is collected from millers, who pay 75 cents for each bushel of wheat converted to flour, and produces about $400million a year.

title: 3 Stores Destroyed By Fire in Union City
description: UNION CITY, March 1 (UPI)A generalalarm blaze burned out three twostory commercial buildings and forced 50 people to flee nearby hotel yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: Mrs. Jill Ruckelshaus, the wife of William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has joined the White House staff as a $50aday consultant. Mrs. Ruckelshaus will work for Ann Armstrong, a White House counselor, on liaison with women's organizations. Mrs. Ruckelshaus has a reputation as a militant feminist. All of which provoked Mrs. Martha Mitchell, the wife of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, to say: I resent that Jill Ruckelshaus is in the White House with Ann Armstrong and all her liberal Ideas. I don't know who placed her in the position.

title: Interior Aide Approved
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) The Senate today approved the nomination of Jack O. Horton as Assistant Secretary of the Interior.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: Inglewood, Calif.Jose Napoles, 146 pounds, Mexico City, knocked out Ernie (Indian Red) Lopez, 146, Los Angeles, 7 rounds; Napoles retained world welterweight title.

title: West 80th St. Takes On the Pushers
description: On the face of things, some of the people who live on 80th Street between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenue seem to get along with the dope pushers and junkies who also inhabit the block.

title: 3 OF BRONX INDICTED IN TAVERN SHOOTING
description: A Manhattan grand jury yesterday indicted three Bronx men who were arrested after the shooting of a police lieutenant in an attempted tavern holdup in Washington Heights.

title: Knicks Conquered By Bucks, 114100
description: MILWAUKEE, March 1  A minirally led by, three reserves, and an odd technical foul earned by Coach Red Holzman were the only entertaining features of the evening for the New York Knicks tonight as they absorbed a 114100 licking at the hands of the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: DR. EDWlN K. MORGAN, UROLOGIST, 73, DIES
description: Dr. Edwin King Morgan, Brooklyn urological surgeon, died yesterday in the Long Island College Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: U.S. Birth Rate Drops to a Record Low
description: WASHINGTON, March 1American birth and fertility rates last year dropped to their lowest levels in history, and even the absolute number of babies born was the smallest in 27 years.

title: 2 More Ventures in U.S. Announced by Japanese
description: Two more Japanese compsnies  Hitachi Metals, Ltd., and Nippon Seiko  announced yesterday their first manufacturing investments in the United States through joint ventures with American companies.

title: Like Old Times: Yankees 95 Favorites
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 1  The Yankees pitched and batted their way through a routine workout today, but there was nothing routine about two other sit uations that developed off the fields.

title: Dr. Harold E. B. Pardee Dies; Electrocardiographic Pioneer
description: Dr. Harold E. B. Pardee, an ternationally known cardiologist and pioneer in electrocardiogram research, died Wednesday at his home, 770 Park Avenue. His age was 86.

title: Oilmen, 3 Years Assembly, In the Race for City Controller
description: Assemblyman Antonio Oliviers, a Manhattan, DemocratLiberal, announced yesterday that he was running for. Controller.

title: U.S. Ambassador to Sudan and His Aide Reported Seized by Guerrillas at Party
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 The State Department received reports today that Palestinian guerrillas in the Sudan had captured five diplomats, including the United States Ambassador and outgoing charg d'affaires, and were seeking to exchange them for several hundred prisoners including Sirhan Sirhan, the murderer of Robert F. Kennedy.

title: Mrs. Meir Says Israel Feared a Suicide Bombing by Airliner

title: Movies: 'Thief Who Came to Dinner':Movies: 'Thief Who Came to Dinner' Jacqueline Bisset and Ryan O'Neal Star The Cast
description: Bud Yorkin's "The Thief Who Came to Dinner" is about a based young computer analyst named Webster (Ryan O'Neal) who chucks the straight life to become the best adjusted, most successful jewel thief in Houston, nicknamed the chess burglar because of his fondness for leaving chess pieces at the scenes of his crimes.In the course of his upward movement Webster falls perfectly in love with an amused society girl (Jacqueline Bisset), befriends the sober-sided insurance investigator (Warren Oates) who tries to trap him and causes the nervous breakdown of The Houston Chronicle's chess editor (Austin Pendleton). Webster suffers a superficial gunshot wound at one point.It would be difficult to name any contemporary film with less sense of consequence than "The Thief Who Came to Dinner," yet it's this quality that gives the comedy its buoyancy even when its sense of humor fails. It's the quality of a lot of old Hollywood comedies that one is inclined to remember as being funnier than they were simply because they were cheerfully mindless of awful possibilities.It's also the quality that Peter Bogdanovich almost exhausted himself to achieve in "What's Up, Doc," and while "The Thief Who Came to Dinner" is not so funny, Yorkin, the director ("Start The Revolution Without Me"), and his screenwriter, Walter Hill, haven't tried so hard.The film, however, has been carefully castthe principal roles as well as the supporting characters. By being almost too beautiful to be either true or good, O'Neal and Miss Bisset further remove the comedy from the sort of reality in which jewel thieves are probably hopeless neurotics. Both Oates and Pendleton are maniacally serious about themselves and therefore extremely funny, as are Ned Beatty, as a Houston jewel fence, and Jill Clayburgh, as O'Neal's first wife, who, remembering how bored she was with O'Neal as a computer analyst, wants to return to the man who has become a jewel thief. "I was short-changed," she says curtly."The Thief Who Came to Dinner," which opened yesterday at Loew's State 2 and the Beekman, is no avalanche of hilarity, but it respects a kind of comic make-believe that is rare in movies these days. You can like it without laughing a lot.

title: France and the Dream of a Third Force
description: PARISThe dominant subject in France is the elections of this Sunday and March 11. The vote will be for renewal of the National Assembly, last elected in June 1968, The composition of that Assembly reflected the great fears aroused by the events of May 1968. The Gaullist party then established by itself a majority and together with its allies took 358 of 487 seats. But the two subsequent referendums as well as the 1969 Presidential election demonstrated a shrinking of the. Gaullist electorate. This is again con firmed by all the opinion polls.

title: Bridge: Double RoundRobin Event Provides HeadtoHead Play

Yet in the metropolitan area, between tournaments, he has few opportunities for such contests. An attempt to satisfy this need has been devised by Jon Wilkinson in conjunction with Ethan Stein and the Sniffen Court Duplicate Bridge Club.

title: Currencies Afloat

Official foreign exchange markets are closed, monetary wise men are debating behind closed doors about how to reopen them, and President Nixon has proclaimed the dollar will not be devalued. But through the tumult, and the fears that financial confidence may crumble, basic changes are taking place in the international financial mechanism, which for most of the postwar period has been founded on the assumption that currencies should have defined, relatively fixed values in relation to each other.

Mr. Loggins was exuberantly innocent, full of a natural high, as he stomped joyfully, about the stage. Clarity begins at home, according to Loggins and Messina  they allowed no electronic intrusion to swamp lyric ideas. And vice versa.

It consists of a single large, lowlying black sculpture by Salvatore Romano and a group of slender, highrising white sculptures by William Sellers. A good installation turns the gallery into a black and white unit by which all the sculptures, in spite of being walled off into two oneman shows, become part of a single highly effective display.

description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Belfast Gunmen Kill Catholic Bus Driver In a Protestant Area
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 2A Roman Catholic bus driver was shot dead ate the wheel of his bus today MI a Protestant area of West Belfast. He was the third Catholic killed by Protestant gunmen in the city in the last 24 hours.

title: Paris Accord Signed
description: Twelve foreign ministers signed in Paris yesterday a formal declaration endorsing the Vietnam ceasefire agreement. An article on the ceremony and the text of the declaration appear on page 6.

title: FEUD OF ESPOSITO AND TROY ANNULS A JUDGESHIP PACT
description: A bipartisan agreement that would have eliminated a primary and election fight over the Court of Appeals chief judgeship collapsed yesterday as the result of a feud between two of the state's top Democratic leaders,. Matthew J. Troy Jr. of Queens and Meade H. Esposito of Brooklyn.

title: Four New Issues Manage To Hold Firm for Week
description: Four new issues, fledglings in the lessthanrobust current stock markets, made their public trading debut this week and, in company with their more seasoned counterpart equities, barely managed to hold their own on the overthecounter market.

title: Scheffing and Staub Grow further Apart ...
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2  The New York Mets batted 500 today in a pair of sensitive highlevel conferences: They failed to sign Rusty Staub, but did establish ground rules for Willie Mays.

title: N.D.C. Endorsement
description: The New Democratic Coalition is a collection of Reform Democratic clubsperhaps a hundred or so in New York City and its suburbswhich today is holding representative assembly to consider candidates for the three citywide offices to be filled at the polls this year Mayor, Controller and City Council Presidentas well as for chief judge of the Court of Appeals.

title: Attendance Off Sharply in Canarsie School Boycott
description: The Canarsie school boycott in Brooklyn cut deeper into pupil attendance yesterday leaving four schools virtually empty and seriously affecting four others, as behindthescenes efforts were being made to end the new protest by white parents against the busing in of black children from the nearby Brownsville area.

title: President Declares Killers Must Be Brought to Justice
description: WASHINGTON, March 2President Nixon tonight described the killing of the two American diplomats in the Sudan as acts of terrorism and demanded that the perpetrators of the crime must be brought to justice.

title: People and Business
description: Abraham L. Pomerantz, perhaps the bestknown of the nation's stockholder derivative lawyers, received some good news and some dad news last week. The 69yearold lawyerwho has spent more than 37 years representing stockholders who sue corporations on the behalf of all other stockholders of that companywas awarded $750,000 by the Federal District Court as a fee for his efforts in the suit brought by his clients against 10 owners of the Dreyfus Corporation.

title: Medicine, the Feminist Frontier
description: Recently, small ;teams of women have been traveling across the country equipped with a plastic speculum, mirrors and flashlight. In informal settings, surrounded by the curious, they show how a woman can observe her own cervix. I hesitate to use the word revolutionary but no other seems accurate to describe the effects of the demonstration. It is, in fact, a little like having a blind person see for the first timefor what woman is not blind to her own insides? Since the first demonstration two years ago, the interest in selfhelp (as it's come to be known) has spread throughout the country, a course is now officially offered at Antioch College.

title: F. VICTOR NISSEN
description: NORTH ADAMS, Mass., March 2F. Victor Nissen, a vice president and director of the Wall Streeter Shoe, Company here, which he joined in 1945, died Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: Blind Man Found Dead
description: A blind 80yearold man was killed this morning when he jumped or fell from his fifthfloor apartment in the South Bronx, the police reported. They said the man, Cirello Gomez, of 916 Southern Boulevard, was found lying on a secondflor ledge at 6 A.M. by a tenant in a secondfloor apartment who had heard a loud thud. The tenant called the police and Mr. Gomez was taken to iLncoln Hospital, where he died an hour later.

title: Melba Mqore Puts Songs in a Pattern At the Copacabanaa
description: Melba Moore's big, mischievous eyes sparkle as brightly as aver in her current appearance as the Copacabana, and the urgent gospel shout that she pulls up from the well springs of her vocal resources is still an exhilarating and exciting sound. But She has a hard time maintaining pace and interest during the hour she spends on the Cope floor.

title: Japan to Continue Float and Peg Market Reopening to Outcome of European Talks
description: TOKYO, March 2 (UPI) Japan plans to continue the floating of the yen for some time after the foreign exchange market reopens, Finance Minister Kiichi Aichi said today.

title: Local Board Denies Any Blame In Hiring Accused School Aides
description: Community School Board 3 struck back yesterday at charges by the central Board of Education and the City Council that the community board was responsible for the hiring of two school guards and a school aide who turned out to have had criminal records at the time of their employment.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: DetroitLen (Stinger) Hutchins, Detroit, outpointed Eddie (Red Top) Owens, Boston, 10 rounds, heavyweights; Jack O'Hallaran, Boston, outpointed Al (Blue) Lewis, Detroit, 10, heavyweights; Ron Harris, Detroit, outpointed Ruben Arocha, San Diego, 10, welterweights.

title: End of YouthProject Aid Urged on Urban Coalition
description: Dr. Eugene S. Callender, president of the New York Urban Coalition, is calling on his board of directors not to approve, the coalition's traditional financing of the Mayor's summer youth program this year, partly because of what he called inadequate financial accounting for previous allocations.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: A Movement of Strength In Art by Lester Johnson
description: The new paintings of Lester Johnson on view at the Martha Jackson Gallery, 32 East 69th Street, reveal the artist moving from strength to strength. Mr. Johnson's exhibition of two years ago, coming just in advance of what proved to be a revival of critical interest in representational, or figurative painting, impressed me a great deal. He seemed to have established, then, in his largescale canvases of men milling about on city streets a really viable use of the human figure.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and, dcor (four triangles to none.)

title: PRESIDENT SEES HANOI AID BACKED BY THE CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, March 2President Nixon promised today that postwar aid to North Vietnam, if approved by Congress, would be financed from existing defense and foreign aid funds, not from further slashes in the domestic side of the budget.

title: RULING ON GIFT DATA MADE IN VESCO CASE
description: Evidence concerning a secret cash contribution of $200,000 to President Nixon's reelection campaign, said to have been made by Rohert L. eVsco, was provisionally excluded yesterday from the securities case against the financier.

title: Effective Devaluation Of Dollar Increasing
description: As the value of the dollar has continued to decline in the foreignexchange markets, the result has been to increase its effective devaluation in relation to the currency values that were agreed to by the major powers at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington in December, 1971.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, March 2Just like the mailman, Irving Taylor, a 59yearold trimming buyer  collars, buttons, laces and cuffsseldom, fails to keep his appointed rounds. The only difference is that Taylor succeeds in doing it more oftenand faster.

title: A Friendly Mrs. Spook Gives Fonds for Kaspar
description: Kaspar, Peter Handke's critically acclaimed play about a mute boy's struggle with language, has had a week added to its, limited engagement at Brooklyn's Chelsea Theater Center thanks to an anonymous benefactor whom the cast calls Mrs. Spook.

title: Ohio Mayor Turns Son Over to Police In Marijuana Case
description: AKRON, Ohio, March 2 The Mayor of Stow, an Akron suburb, has turned his 19yearold son over to the police for dispensing marijuana to a minor  a crime that in Ohio carries a maximum penalty of 30 years to life.

title: Contrasts With Loss
Jets Set Back Sharks, 21, For Ninth Straight Victory
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, March 2 (UPI)The Winnipeg Jets stretched their winning streak to nine games tonight, defeating the Los. Angeles Sharks, 21, in a tightchecking World Hockey Association game.

title: Those Special Interests
description: In his effort to eviscerate the Government's social programs by means of a regressive budget, President Nixon likes to present himself as the defender of the public interest against the selfish clamor of the special interests. Thus, in his message on human resources the other day, he asserted too often public policy decisions have been founded not on the longrun interests of all the people, but on the shortrun interests of special groups of people.

title: Indians Bid U.N. Send Observers to Dakota
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2A group of American Indians asked the United Nations today to send observers to South Dakota, the scene of recent disorders, to protect the lives, property and rights of their brothers.

title: Date on Met's Vase Check Incorrectly Transmitted
description: Because of an error in transmission between United States officials and Italian authorities in Rome, the date of a $1million check from the Metropolitan Museum of Art to Robert E. Hecht Jr. was incorrectly given as Nov. 13, 1972.

title: First Waste Dischgrge Permits Issued Under Clean Weiter Law
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 2Indiana issued today the first discharge permits in the nation under Federal legislation that is designed to clean to all waters of the United States by 1985.

title: British Bill Rate Rises
description: LONDON, March 2 (Reuters) The average rate at today's tender of British Treasury Bills rose to 8.1232 per cent from 8.0600 per cent last week. The Bank of England set its minimum lending rate at 8 per cent, unchanged.

title: Colonels 109107 Victims
description: LOUISVILLE, KT, March 2The New York Nets dissipated a 16point thirdquarter lead tonight against the Kentucky Colonels, then rallied to pull out a 109107 victory on Bill Melchionni's 15foot turnaround jump shot with 4 seconds to play.

title: Out Beyond Liberalism
description: To build a new American majority for social change, there must be precise program, bold enough to respond to the challenges confronting our society, politically astute enough to appeal to millions of men and women. A program located on the left wing of realism.

title: ELLSBERG TRIAL HEARS M'CLOSKEY
description: LOS ANGELES, March 2Representative Paul N. McCloskey testified today that disclosure of one of the vol umes of the Pentagon paper could not have been used to the injury of the United States or to the advantage of a for eign nation.

title: Allende Belittles the Election Chances of His Foes
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 2 President Salvador Allende Gossens predicted confidently today that the Opposition would fail to emerge from the legislative election on Sunday with a twothirds Senate majority that would threaten him with impeachment.

title: U.S. Steel Names Officer
description: William L. Fader has been named vice presidentEastern steel operations for the United States Steel Corporation. He succeeds Robert A. McClure, who is retiring after 37 years with the company. Mr. Fader, who takes over his new post on April 1, has been general managerEastern steel operations since 1970.

title: DAVID S. GRDBER
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 2 David S. Grober, a Senior partner in Stanley Marks & Co., a New York Stock Exchange member firm, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 27 Crossways. His age was 46.

title: 2 BELIEVED SPARED
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Saturday, March 3The Sudanese Government announced early today that Black September commandos had executed, two American diplomats who had been held hostage since Thursday night.

title: Leon W Kapp Dead at 70; Retired judge in Jersey
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., March2 Former County Judge Leon W. Kapp died today at the Orange Memorial Hospital His age was 71 and he Lived here.

title: U.S. Reported Set to Bolster Reservation Arms
description: WASHINGTON, March 2Responding to reports that the Indians who took over the Wounded Knee settlement in South Dakota are armed with a .30caliber machine gun, the Justice Department plans to move in heavier armament to match theirs, according to a Senator who met with the Indians yesterday.

title: Curbing Dollar Investing Abroad Is, Ruled Illegal
description: WASHINGTON, March 2A. Federal judge ruled today that Presidents Johnson and. Nixon had no legal authority to impose and continue the fiveyearold program of controls over dollar outflows for direct corporate investment abroad.

title: 17,500 $20 Bills Descend On L.I., All Counterfeit
description: WEST ISLIP, L.I., March 2 Some thought they had found a real instant windfall, but the 17,500 $20 bills that scattered in the breezes late last night off the Robert Moses Bridge to Fire Island and then drifted up on the beaches of the Great South Bay today were all counterfeit.

title: Soviet Union Ice Dancing Pair Takes 4th World Title in Row
description: BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, March 2 (AP)  Ludmila Pakhomova and Alexander Gorshkov of the Soviet Union won their fourth consecutive dance title today and Ondrej Nepela held a commanding lead for the men's crown in the world figure skating championships.

title: MARCEL HOROWITZ
description: Marcel Horowitz, chairman of the board and founder of the Alva Agency of the United States Life Insurance Company here, died yesterday in Brissago, Switzerland. He was 79 years old and lived here until a year and a half ago when he moved to Lugano, Switzerland.

title: Roberson Quits as Coach
description: IRVINE, Calif., March 2 (AP) Bo Roberson has resigned, effective tomorrow, as varsity track and field coach at the University of California at Irvine. His assistant, Sam West, has been named interim successor.

title: Outlook For Stennis Good
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, who had been regarded as dangerously ill from gunshot wounds, is much improved and on his way to full recovery, his doctors at Walter Reed Army Hospital Medical Center reported today. A spokesman for the 71  year  old Senator told reporters that Mr. Stennis's name was removed from the seriously ill list today and that his outlook for recovery was good. Mr. Stennis was robbed and shot twice outside his northwest Washington home Jan. 30.

title: U.S. Official Rules Boston Schools Are Segregated
description: BOSTON, March 2A Federal administrative law judge ruled today that Boston operated a dual school system that was segregated in violation of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

title: 1972 Deficit Reversed
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation reported net income of $9,655,000 in the fourth quarter in contrast to a loss of $121,447,000 in the period a year ago. Preferred dividend requirements of $4,755,000 in 1972 reduced earnings per share to 9 cents. Revenues for the period were $728,802,000 against $616,459,000.

title: REV. GEORGE BAUER
description: MARYKNOLL; N. Y., March 2The Rev. George Bauer, a Maryknoll missionary priest for 47 years, died here last Friday. His age was 76.

title: 4 South Vietnamese Describe Torture in Prison Tiger Cage
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 2A group of recently released political prisoners, reportedly spirited into Saigon secretly, described today how they were beaten, tortured and ultimately crippled during years of confinement at the Government's island prison on Con Son.

title: Saigon Warns Newsmen On Breaking Regulations
description: SAIGON, March 2 (UPI)South Vietnam will be forced to deal severely with foreign journalists who deliberately violate our rules and regulations, a Government spokesman said today.

title: West Chester State Leads In Women's College Swim
description: WEST CHESTER, Pa., March 2 (AP)West Chester State won three events today in the Eastern Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for Watnen's swimming and diving champlonships.

title: MARKET TO MEET
description: BRUSSELS, March 2Western Europe intensified preparations today for joint defense against the wild influx of dollars as the European Economic Community called an emergency meeting of the Council of Ministers Sunday to deal with the third monetary crisis of the last three weeks.

title: MARKET TO MEET
description: BRUSSELS, March 2Western Europe intensified preparaz tions today for joint defense against the wild influx of dollars as the European Economic Community called an emergency meeting of the Council of Ministers Sunday to deal with The third monetary crisis of the last three weeks.

title: History of the Dispute
description: Last Oct. 26, after two weeks of wrangling and demonstrations, the central Board of Education ordered that children living in Tilden Houses, a largely black project in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn be admitted John Wilson Junior High School in the Canarsie section.

title: Upset in Ireland
description: When Prime Minister Lynch unexpectedly dissolved the Irish Parliament and called a new election last month, most observersincluding some opponentsviewed it as another shrewd maneuver by the Taoiseach. He had called a snap election under circumstances less favorable for his Fianna Fail Government in 1969 and won an absolute majority in the Dail. It was widely expected that he would match or improve that showing this time.

title: J. Percy Page of Alberta, Coached Girls' Basketball
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, March 2 (Canadian Preas)J. Percy Page, former Lieutenant Governor of Alberta and coach of the wellknown Edmonton Grads women's basketball team, died last evening. He was 85 years old.

title: President Declares Killers Must Be Brought to Justice
description: WASHINGTON, March 2President Nixon tonight described the killing of the two American diplomats in the Sudan as acts of terrorism and demanded that the perpetrators of the crime must be brought to justice.

title: GRANDDAUGHTER SEIZED IN RUN
description: The granddaughter of an 83yearold widow murdered on the Upper East Side last week was arrested yesterday and charged with homicide.

title: CHRIS EVERT WINS, JEANNE DEFEATED
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 2 (AP)  England's Virginia Wade had to, change her tactics today to beat 15yearold Joanne Evert, younger sister of Chris Evert, 75, 64 in the quarterfinals of the $50000 S. & H. Green, Stamps women's tennis tourney.

title: Business Briefs
description: Shape Asks Division of Pennsy System

title: New Breathing Plastic Process
description: WASHINGTON, March 2Ezekiel J. Jacob, a consulting chemist who has operated his Brooklyn laboratory since 1941, believes he has found the way to economical manufacture of poromerics, or plastics that breathe. Such finely pored materials are useful for shoe uppers, raincoats and upholstery. Patent 3,718,561 was granted Mr. Jacob this week for his electrical process. He puts a metal plate on each side of a sheet of plastic containing salt, and immerses the resulting sandwich in water. When current is turned on, heat develops and the salt grains wash out, leaving tiny holes.

title: Saigon Newspaper Fined Over Veteran's Interview
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam March 2 (Reuters)A Saigon newspaper reported today that it had been fined one million piasters, or about $2,300, for contravening the Government's press laws.

title: Playoff Preparation Is Concern As Knicks Enter Homestretch
description: Playoff preparation, pure and simple, is now the concern of the New York Knicks as they enter the final 12 games of the regular season by facing the Baltimore Bullets at 8 o'clock tonight at Madison Square Garden and tomorrow afternoon at College Park, Md., (Channel 7, 2 P.M.).

title: Bridge Unit Elects Chief
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., March 2 (AP)Milton Zwickel of Catskill has been elected chairman of the New York State Bridge Authority by its members.

title: Amiss, 112, Leads England To 272Run Cricket Start
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, March 2 (Reuters)Dennis Amiss scured 112 runs for England today on the opening day of the first cricket test against Pakistan.

title: A Parched State in India Living on Little but Hope
description: POONA, India, Feb. 27Hungry cows nibble beneath stones. The trees are bare. The fields are parched. Villages are empty, except for dogs thirsting for water.

title: Princeton to Pick Casciola As. Football Coach Today
description: Princeton will name Bob Casciola, an alumnus from the class of 1958, as its had football coach today. Casciola, currently, head coach of the University of Connecticut, is to succeed Jake McCandless, who resigned last Jan. 13.

title: U.C.L.A. Clinches Title
description: LOS ANGELES, March 2 (AP)  Topranked U.C.L.A. captured its seventh straight Pacific8 Conference basketball championship tonight, drubbing California, 9065, to run its winning streak to 69 games. Bill Walton committed his fourth foul just three minutes into the second half and did not return to the game but still wound up with 15 points. The victory gave U.C.L.A. the league title for the 11th time in the last 12 years.

title: Two Senators Attend A 35Second Session
description: WASHINGTON, March. 2 (AP)With just two Senators in attendance the Senate met for 35 seconds today, which was long enough to designate a temporary presiding officer and adjourn until Tuesday.

title: Dartmouth Is Defeated
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 2 Princeton scored its first victory in three basketball games, defeating Dartmouth, 8469, tonight in Jadwin Gymnasium. The Tigers, still have shot at the Ivy League title although Penn clinched at least a tie for the crown against Harvard in Philadelphia.

title: STATE PANEL ASKS TIGHT TO COLLEGE
description: ALBANY March 2  A special commission named, by Governor Rockefeller last fill has recommended that all high school graduates in the state be guar anteed access to college with adequate financial support and at the Governor nominate the members of the State Board of Regents.

title: DOLLAR IS SOUND
description: WASHINGTON, March 2President Nixon said today that there will not be another devaluation of the dollar.

title: Six Killed as a Crane Drops Through Virginia. Building
description: BAILEYS CROSSROADS, Va., March. 2 Six persons were tilled, 34 injured and 14 were reported missing today in the collapse of a partly completed highrise apartment building in this suburb of Washington, D. C.

title: British Vote Sets Back Tories and Labor
description: LONDON, March 2  The voters of ChesterleStreet, an industrial area of County Durham in northeast England, have reelected a labor party candidate to represent them in Parliament, returns showed today.

title: 80 Countries Agree on a Wildlife Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, March 2Representatives of the United States and 79 other countries agreed today to a treaty prohibiting commercial trade in 375 species of wild animals that are in danger of extinction.

title: Visibility Termed Bad Where Bus Was Hit by Train
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., March 2 Mrs. Lois Gaines, a school crossing guard at the Congers grade crossing where a freight train rammed a school bus a year ago, told a jury today that visibility at the crossing was bad for drivers going in the direction the bus was traveling.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Declaration on Vietnam CeaseFire Accords Signed by 12 Foreign Ministers in Paris
description: PARIS, March 2The United States, the Soviet Union, China and nine other partiesinclud?? the opposing Vietnamese ??joined today in signing ?? formal declaration obliging ?? to respect the Vietnam ?? fire agreement strictly and do nothing to upset it.

title: Market Place:
description: Investors proved once again yesterday that they will not tolerate disappointmenteven in a company that winds up with sparkling earnings gains. The Victim this time was Redman Industries, Inc., a leading producer of mobile homes, motor homes and garden apartments.

title: Flamingo to Draw 9 Today
description: MIAMI, March 2Last year the flamingos were too pregnant to fly and this year the big horse is staying in his barn, but just the same Hialeah will give $91,520 to the winner of the 44th Flamingo Stakes tomorrow.

title: INDIAN CHARGED WITH KIDNAPPING
description: GALLUP, N. M., March 2 (AP) Bail for a young Indian accused in the abduction of Gallup Mayor Emmett Garcia was set at $85,000 today, and Gov. Bruce King called for a state police investigation into related violence that left a student Indian leader dead.

title: Nixon Gets Heart Award
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI)  President Nixon accepted the American Heart Association's heart of the year award today on behalf of former Presidents Dwight D. Eisenhower and Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: MACKELL ASSAILS INQUIRY ON OFFICE
description: Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell, making public a financial statement showing his net worth as just over $100,000, charged yesterday that the investigation of his office by the special state anticorruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, was politically motivated.

title: Dance: Premiere of Everybody in Bed
description: James Cunningham is one of the better known avantgarde dance creators in New York City. Personally I have seen a few pieces of interest from him. Otherwise, I would not have presented myself at the Riverside Church on Wednesday night with meek hope. It was a disappointment.

title: ROBERT J. PLAUT
description: Robert J. Plaut, general manager of the New York, office of the. General American Transportation Corporation, which he had been with since 1947, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. He was 50 years old, and lived at 4 Glen Eagles Drive in Larch, mont, N. Y.

title: Two Shot in Battle With Police Called In Earlier Shooting
description: An earlymorning gun battle in Brooklyn between the police and four men wanted for questioning concerning an earlier shooting incident resulted in the wounding of two of the gunmen.

title: Harry Rudolph, 66, Led Eastern Basketball League
description: Harry Rudolph, former president of the Eastern Basketball League and one of its top referees, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 165 West 66th Street.

title: CORNELIA M. RUNYON
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 Mrs. Cornelia Montgomery Runyon, sculptor and widow of Charles Runyon, a New York lawyer, died yesterday in a nursing home in Alexandria, Va. She was 85 years old.

title: Missing Man's Body Pound
description: NORTH SALEM, N. Y., March 2The state police today reportedfinding the body here of a 32yearold man from Stamford, Conn., with two bullets in the head. It was identified as that of Joseph Pellicci, a restaurant owner, who had been reported missing a month ago. The police said the body had apparently been lying behind a stone wall along an isolated road for three to four weeks.

title: Peanuts Ordered Seized
description: CINCINNATI, March 2 (UPI) The United States Attorney's office here ordered the seizure yesterday of 13,000 pounds of peanuts it said were contaminated by rodent excrement. The peanuts tame from two Suffolk, Va., companies and were shipped to F. W. Hinz and Sons Company, a local distributor, last Nov. 2930.

title: Dow Up by 11 After Early Drop
description: The stock market recovered yesterday from a heavy wave of morning selling and managed to close with a modest gain.

title: Transcript of President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: WASHINGTON, March 2Following is the White House transcript of Press dent Nixon's news conference today

title: Marjorie Langley Ryan, 88, Harbor Pilot and Lawyer
description: Mrs. Marjorie Langley Ryan, a lawyer who was also the first and perhaps the only woman licensed as, a, harbor pilot in New York Harbor, died Wedsnesday at her home In the Essex House on Central Park South: She was 88 years old.

title: Laos Premier Backs Negotiator Criticized as Giving Too Much
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 2 Prince Souvanna Phouma, Premier of Laos, publicly went to the defense of his chief peace negotiator today in the face of Cabinet charges that the Vientiane Government conceded too much to the Communists to obtain a peace accord.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Government payments account for only 1 per cent of the income of the New Jersey farmer, but account for 12 per cent in Texas, 8.5 per cent in Kansas and 4.6 per cent in Iowa, according to the. State Agriculture Department. Phillip Alampi, the State Agriculture Secretary, said 40 states received more money from the Federal Government than did New Jersey.

title: Five Evenings a Week Their Home Is Somebody Else's Castle
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  Donald and Marianne Fogelsanger don't bother to advertise the 22room, historic 18thcentury mansion thiay rent out  along with their antique vermeil punch cups and sterling silver finger bowls  for elegant, private parties.

title: Quakers Down Harvard
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 2Pennsylvania moved within one victory of its fourth straight Ivy League basketball championship tonight and was assured of at least a tie for the crown by defeating Harvard, 8675, at the Palestra.

title: 2Mile Liberty Park Is Planned A long Jersey City's Waterfront
description: TRENTON, March 2  Plans for a new urban park that would stretch two miles along the Jersey City waterfront will be announced here tomorrow by the New Jersey American Revolution Bicentennial Celebration Commission.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, MARCH 3, 1973
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Profit Drops for Some Brokers Seen for January and Febniary
description: A number of stock brokerage firms had red ink on their books In January, and the profit situation grew even worse in February, according to Wall Street sources.

title: Black Worker Hurt By White Opponents Of Kawaida Project
description: NEWARK, March 2  A black laborer on the Kawaida Towers project was knocked down and kicked by white opponents of the project today after he left the site to get coffee.

title: Man, 21, Stabbed to Death In an Argument in Brooklyn
description: A 21yearold man was fatally stabbed last night during what the police described as a confrontation with several other men on Myrtle Avenue near Nostrand Avenue in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: I.B.M. Sets New Pricing In a LeaseTerm Plan
description: The Intarnational Business Machines Corporation anpounced important pricing change by instituting a term lease plan.

title: In War or Peace, Vientiane Goes Own Way
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 2 The Laotian ceasefire, which went into effect Feb. 22 and was received in capitals around the world as a major development, has not had the slightest visible effect on Vientiane, which was and is by far the most peaceful capital in Indochina. Through decades of war Vientiane has remained an oasis in a desert of destruction and totalitarian rule. Here lambs and lions of all political stripes have continued to drink together in peace despite the war ravaging the countryside.

title: WILLIAM F. BUTLER
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 2 (AP)William F. Butler, city editor of The Rochester TimesUnion from 19291937, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Batavia. He was 82.

title: Pound Sterling Climbs To as High as $2.56
description: LONDON, March 2 (Reuters)Some American visitors to London had to pay up to $2.56 to buy a pound sterling here today.

title: Robert Smith Plays Couperin's Ordres On the Harpsichord
description: Francois Couperin apparently composed some 220 pieces for harpsichord, and Robert Smith seems determined to play his way through all of them at the Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: JERSEY CITY SITE FOR 2MILE PARK
S.O.R.C. Series Victory Unofficially Munequita's
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, March 2 One of the peculiarities of yacht racing often occurs when everybody but the race committee knows who won the regatta. Today the crew of Munequita was doused in champagne for its victory in the Southern Ocean Racing Conference series while the committee fidgeted over the failure of its radio communications.

title: Federal Force Rings Wounded Knee
description: PINE RIDGE, S.D., March 2  Government officials said here tonight that aids fired this morning from the seized Indian hamlet of Wounded Knee struck an F.B.I. car, part of the Federal force that continued to surround the hamlet. It was not immediately clear whether the parked car was occupied at the time.

title: Text of Declaration by Paris Conference on Vietnam
description: PARIS, March 2 (Reuters) Following is the text of the declaration of the international conference on Vietnam signed here today:

title: Cleo A. Noel Jr.
description: WASHINGTON, March 2When he was named. Ambassador to the Sudan a few mouths ago, Cleo A. Noel Jr. confided to friends, It be good to get back home.

title: New Yorkers Get Some Power On Military Issues in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, March 2For the first time in recent, memory, New. York representatives will have considerable clout over the military in Congress.

title: Hanoi Attitude: Keeping U.S. on Hook

title: SOME CHEMICALS SHOW PRICE RISES
description: The Dow Chemical Company, the Stauffer Chemical Company and the Borden Chemical division of Borden, Inc., announced price rises yesterday on a variety of chemicals. Most of the remaining copper companies followed the lead of the Anaconda Company, the Copper Range Company and the Cities Service Company and increased copper prices by about 4 cents a pound. Dow said it was raising its prices for bulk chlorine chlorine and caustic soda by $5 a ton. The increases were said to apply only to those customers, including textile, pulp and paper companies buying below published list prices. The company added that no customer would pay higher than list prices.

title: Rise in Blacks' Income Is Easing
description: WASHINGTON, March 2The total income of blacks in the United States was estimated today at a record $51billion for 1972 by Andrew F. Brimmer, a member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The total would be an increase from $46billion the preceding year. The black economist said, however, that the advancement in blacks' income, which was steady during the sixties, had slackened in recent years.

description: LONDON, March 2 (Reuters)British reserves rose $260million in February to $5.918billion, the Treasury reported today.

title: The P.O.W.'s: Focus of Division
description: LOS ANGELES, March 1 For the last four years, the prisoners of war have played a leading role in the bitter national debate over Vietnam. And as they return from captivity, they remain the focus of deep and angry divisions that have not been obliterated by their homecoming. The prisoners are a touchy subject because even the most outspoken war critics feel sympathy for them as human beings and rejoice at their reunions with their families.

title: Business Records

title: Kansas Senate Passes Bill Calling for Death Penalty
description: TOPEKA, Kan., March 2 (UPI)  The Kansas Senate has passed a death penalty bill although the Supreme Court has voided the capital punishment laws of all the states.Senator J. C. Tillotson, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said that the Court's objection to the original laws seemed to be that they left to the discretion of the jury or the judge whether a defendant should be given life imprisonment or death.The bill passed yesterday would make the death penalty mandatory if a person was convicted of murder committed deliberately, willfully, maliciously and with premeditation. In addition, mandatory capital crimes would be killings cornmitted during the commission of felonies such as air piracy, kidnapping and arson.

title: Soviet Union ice Dancing Pair Takes 4th World Title in Rotv
description: BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, March 2 (AP) Ludmila palchomova and Alexander Goithkov of the Soviet Union won their fourth consecutive dance title today and Ondiej Nepela held a commanding lead for the men's crown in the world figure skating championships.

D., March 2  Government officials said here tonight that shots fired this morning from the seized Indian hamlet of Wounded Knee struck an F.B.I. car, part of the Federal force that continued to surround the hamlet. It was not immediately clear whether the parked car was occupied at the time.

The company, in reporting its sales, noted that February this year had 28 days against 29 the year before. Levitz had 51 furniture warehouse showrooms in operation at the month's end against 32 the year before.

description: LANSING, Mich., March 2 (UPI)The owner of a Lansing garbagecollection agency said yesterday he had pulled his trash containers from three movie theaters here, becausethey were showing Xrated films.

description: PLEIKU, South VietnamThey live in a former prisoner of war camp on an isolated rise overlooking the Pleiku airfield, nearly 5,000 hill tribespeople who fled from the Communists last spring.

title: Lunacy at Large
description: The murder of an American ambassador and charg d'affaires by Palestinian fanatics stirs disgust among civilized people. Is the world to be given no respite from the outrages committed in some misguided quest for justice in the Middle East? Only criminal lunatics could believe that attacks on unwitting diplomats far from the scene of any grievance could serve any worthy cause. The action in Khartoum of the Black September guerrillas, terrorists who claim to represent the interests of the Palestinian people, is neither heroic nor condonable by any standard of values.

Behind all this hubbub is a quiet but impornumismatic story.

And his Council of Economic Advisers reported a strong sense of optimism with regard to the nation's unfavorable balance of payments.

There is not much danger of your running out of paper.

title: Bridge
description: Giving useful information is an obvious' part of the game, and is constantly important in bidding and defense. Less obvious, and a delicate art in its own right, is the giving of misinformation to the opponents. Less obvious still, and an area that many players never consider, is the giving of noninformation. If you have a choice of honor cards, you should tend to play a card that an opponent already knows you have, rather than supplement his knowledge.

title: ExSenator Guy Gillette Dead; Iowan, 94, in Congress 18 Years

title: U.C.L.A. Runs Streak to 70

The victory was the 70th in a row as U.C.L.A. extended its record winning streak. But the mighty Bruins trailed, 2518, at halftime before stopping the upsetminded Cardinals.

title: Soviet Union

Since the Russians did not honor copyrights, anything published in the West could be translated and published at Will in the Soviet Union, and vice versa. Only the authors suffered, for neither side was obliged to pay them royalties.

title: Montclair State Girls Win
description: PARAMUS, N. J., March 3Montclair State captured its second New Jersey women's intercollegiate basketball championship in three years tonight by defeating Glassboro State, 6639, at Bergen Community College. The victory was the 14th in 15 games for the state champions and qualified them for the Middle Atlantic regional tournament, starting Thursday at Lock Haven (Pa.) State. Joanne La Vorgna led the winners with 18 points.

title: Little Richard et al. Give Garden Fans More 1950's Rock
description: As he was throwing his shoes and shirt into the audience, Little Richard. asked, Are you ready for me to leave? The audience at Madison Square Garden on Friday night urged him to stay, and Richard, retaining his silver lame trousers, leaped, on top of the piano to sing Long Tall Sally. And more. And more.

title: IT'S MY ALLPURPOSE 9 TO 5 NOMATTERWHAT DRESS
description: Now comes the shirtdress, the go everywhere, do anything, Grab a hot dog, the Duchess of Windsor is waiting, Another Mother for Peace, I can't live without you shirtdress. The Rothschilds may fumble, stock markets may tumble, but the shirtdress is here to stay. Nothing dropdead, mind you, but what becomes a legend most. Eminently wearable, comfortable and presentable, which are not dirty words. Halston nursed it and rehearsed it to a throwaway chic for rich girls who didn't want to look rich anymore, and now everybody who is anybody is shirting up a storm at cost control prices. So much for Phase I. Phase II, at long last, is the return of the pastels. Not really younger than springtime (nothing ever is) but flattering, becoming and outrageously cosmetic. Mostly the spring shirtdresses have long sleeves, easy waists (sometime with matching belts) and hemlines just above the knees. The over all look? As understated as Le Montrachet Marquis de la Guiche (1969).

title: Vietnam
description: PARISThe international conference to endorse the Vietnam ceasefire wound up in solemn diplomatic ceremony right on schedule last week, another milestone on the long and tortuous road to peace. But as has so often happened in Vietnamese affairs, nothing was quite what it was planned or seemed to be.

title: CURLING FAVORED IN RURAL CANADA
description: VANGUARD, Saskatchewan  These are the long, cold nights on Canada's prairies, and in a remote village like Vanguard, the most popular place to be as the harsh wind races across the frozen plains is the curling club, an oasis of warmth and friendship.

title: Thomas Nolan 3d Will Wed Miss McNeal
description: BROOKHAVEN, Pa. March 3Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. McNeal have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Donna McNeal, to Thomas J. Nolan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nolan Jr., of Alpine, N. J. The wedding is planned for September.

title: RIGHTS COALITION IS BEING REVIVED
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 The civil rights coalition of the sixties, badly split in recent years along political, philosophical and racial lines, has been called to meet next week to develop a strategy to fight President Nixon's social policies.

title: GUARD UNIT GETS A DIFFICULT QUOTA
description: BISMARCK, N. D., March The North Dakota National Guard has been told by officials in Washington that it must recruit 20 blacks this year to bal ance its membership racially.

title: Crossing Over And Other Tales. By Richard Elman. 176 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $6.95.
description: Richard Elman's stories in Crossing Over are inconsequential, disgruntling. At $6.95, figure he's shorted you about $5 worth. The collection has been edited hopefully: to give the impression of a hardening, a growing into form. The least corporeal, most irksome stories come firstthe ones with nameless characters that begin, Once upon a time when he was a man and she a woman, they got lost somehow and couldn't find each other anymore. A large inventory of dwarfs and giants' and oneeyed folk, Elman as Alice's caterpillar, hash in his hookah. The Part I stories are meant perhaps to have the force of parables, but they are wearisome, trivial at best; and humor, which might salvage expectation, occurs only in haphazard bursts.

description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: U.S. Medical Team to Visit Hanoi to Study Need for Aid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3A medical team including four physicians will leave tomorrow for North Vietnam on a weeklong survey of the country's postwar rehabilitation needs, according to qualified sources here.

title: Schedule of Hearings By Council This Week
description: Following are the open hearings scheduled for this week by committees of the City Council at City Hall:

title: EKG Test Lures Hundreds in Middlesex
description: EDISONThree of Al Byington's friends had heart attacks last month. And so when the 40yearold Iselin resident heard that the Middlesex County Heart Association would be giving free electrocardiograms at the Menlo Park and Woodbridge Shopping Malls, he decided to stop by and see if I'm still alive.

title: The Old, he Poor the Unemployed
description: AMHERST, Mass.  The object of President Nixon's new federalism (which is neither new nor federalism) is to balance the budget, dismantle ineffective social services, and to provide more money for the military. It is submitted to the people not in this bald fashion, however, but as a reduction in Big Government, and a return to localism and voluntarism, that is to grass roots democracy. The notion that voluntarism and local authorities can deal effectively with the national and global problems which crowd about us is without support in logic or history, and is dangerous to the well being of the Republic.

title: Miss Newmyer Plans Nuptials
description: WASHINGTON, March 3Miss Barbara West Newmyer, press representative for the Columbia Broadcasting System here, plans to be married this summer to Mark W. Johnson, senior attorney in the Washington office of C.B.S.

title: Flower Shows
description: THE Long Island Nurserymen's Association will open its third Garden Show at the Long Island Arena Friday. In keeping with the rising public concern on environmental problems, the theme will illustrate gardening for today and tomorrow. Among the exhibitors will be Atlantic Avenue Nursery, Bay Ridge Landscape, Inc., Flower Time, Anton Hren Nurseries and Panfield Nurseries. The show hours will he from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. daily. It will continue through March 18th, when the show will close at 7 P.M. Tickets are $2 for adults; $1 for children.

description: IN THE words of the rampant clich of the times, there was good news and bad news last, week for the worlds of business and finance. But whether one outweighed the other was difficult to ascertain. This is certainly a hypertensive era in the economic realm, with Amerman economic policy in question, the international political and economic situation in turmoil and the domestic financial markets envoloped in an exceedingly pessimistic mood.

title: Richard Halliday, Producer, 67; Was Husband of Mary Martin
description: Richard Halliday, a theatrical producer and the professional manager of his actress wife, Mary Martin, died yesterday in a hospital in Brasilia, Brazil, after surgery. He was 67 years old and lived at their nearby ranch in Anapolis.

description: LONDON, March 3Mrs. Dorothy Dear Hutton, widow of Edward F. Hutton, the financier, and Viscount Weir of Kilwinning, Ayrshire, Scotland, were married today in Glasgow Cathedral.

title: Headliners
description: Somebodyin this case, America's Big 4 automakerssaid it couldn't be done; the Federal air pollution control standards for 1975 were unrealistically strict and probably couldn't be met. Last week, a Japanese company met them. The Environmental Protection Agency reported that two Mazda autos with Wankel engines had passed its 1975level tests ... with models not all that different from those on the road in 1973.

title: BRIGHTEN YOUR CORNERS (Wherever you are)
description: Keep your city beautiful. Paint a few murals (no graffiti, please) or at least wear cheerful colors and a happy smile. Mrs. Patrick Savin (left), a stockbroker's wife, thinks her doublefaced Originala coat is a good investment. At $555, it should be. The skirt calls for a further investment of $175, to order. Fifth floor, Saks Fifth Ave. Earrings, Cadoro.

title: AfroAntillean, exile New York
description: In Manila a friend laughed and said to me despairingly: How can we have a national identity and our own language after living 300 years in a Spanish monastery and 50 in Hollywood? Like the Philippines, Puerto Rico passed from Spanish to American rule in 1898 and suffers the very heavy burden of uncertain national identity and of linguistic dispersion. Indeed, the rebellion against influence from Spain and North America is a central preoccupation of Puerto Rican poetry. But unlike the Philippineswhere Spanish is quickly fading, English (the lingua franca) imperfectly known, and Tagalog (the national language) native to only a few provinces in LuznPuerto Rico continues to have Spanish as the medium of speech and litera.

title: Amy Williams Wed to Theodore Kurz
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 3  Miss Amy Louise Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Frederick Williams, was married here this afternoon to Theodore Bremer Kurz, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Leo Kurz of Bay Village, Ohio.

title: Youth Is Hospital Suicide After Fleeing Reformatory
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 3 (UPI)A 15yearold reformatory fugitive being treated for a drug overdose leaped to his death from the window of his fourthfloor hospital room, the police said today.

title: The Gun Business on the Defensive
Notes: Supermarket Charier Flights
description: SHE: Honey, if you're going out you might as well drop by the supermarket and pick up some ground chuck, a quart of milk and a can of beans.

title: CHINESE ICBM BID REPORTED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 China is reportedly developing an intercontinental ballistic missile that is even larger than the largest one in the Soviet arsenal and is also building concrete and steel silos to protect it against surprise attack.

title: Dance
description: THE City Center Joffrey Ballet is back in town for a sixweek season, only a month of which still remains. This is an interesting company  number three in rank of American classic ballet troupes, but very much one with a repertory, reputation and spirit of its own.

title: Plan to List MobLinked Concerns Is Still Studied
description: Six months after Mayor Lindsay endorsed a Police Department plan to drive organized crime from the city by publicly identifying their business interests, the Lindsay administration has not made available the promised information.

title: CITYEMPLOYE LIST REOPENED TO VIEW
description: Locked away for four months, the city's only complete list of municipal employes and their home addresses and salaries available for public scrutiny has been quietly restored for inspection.

title: New and Recommended
description: SLEEPERS JOINING HANDS, by Robert Bly. (Harper, $5.95.) Poems that seek to discern the whole meaning of the dominion of life and death over America.

title: Death Valley, They Say, Is the Devil's Work
description: DID God make this land? Warped, slashed, torn, squeezed, pounded, twisted, scoured, then set afire? Or was it, as some say, conjured by the Devil himself? There is something satanic about Death Valley. Its jagged, blistered beauty exists for itself alone. Its naked mountains, jutting escarpments, blinding salt flats and infernal heat don't welcome life. This unforgiving, uncompromising land demands to be met on its own terms. Entering here is intruding upon some paleolithic time, feeling a prehistoric loneliness unknown to man. The dried river beds hide dinosaur spirits in their folds, and there is only the sound of a millionyearold wind.

title: Lawrence F. O'Brien 3d Will Wed Helen Powell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Augustus Powell of New York and Locust Valley, L. I., have announced the engagement of Mr. Powell's daughter, Miss Helen Marie Powell, to Lawrence Francis O'Brien 3d, son of Lawrence Francis O'Brien, former Postmaster General of the United States, and Mrs. O'Brien of New York and Washington.

title: Dorie Hankin Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Rankin of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorie Ellen Hankin, to Daniel Gubin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Gubin, also of New York. A spring wedding is planned. Miss Hankin and her fianc are students at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. She was graduated summa cum laude from City College and he, cum laude, from that institution, where both were elected to Phi Beta Kappa. The future bride's father is president of Harry Hankin Insurance Company.

title: Volpe Arrives in Italy
description: ROME, March 3The new United States Ambassador to Italy, John A. Volpe, arrived here today. Among those meeting him at the airport were the Mayor and town council of Pascosansonesco, a small town in the Abruzzi Mountains from which Mr. Volpe's parents immigrated to the United States.

title: Anne Leavitt Plans Bridal
