description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: Regazzoni Satisfactory
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 4 (AP)Clay ReHgazzoni of Switzerland was reported in satisfactory condition today after suffering burns on his arms and hands during a collision in yesterday's South African Grand Prix.

title: 6 Yankees Still Unsigned; Matty Alou in Camp Today
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 4Six players remained unsigned and seven uniforms unworn today as the Yankees drew closer to their opening exhibition game against Minnesota on Wednesday.

title: Miss Swiger Bride Of Michael Luftman
description: RYE, N. Y., March 4Miss Susan Wolfe Swiger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Swiger, was married here this afternoon to Michael Eric Luftman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Luftman. Rabbi Irving M. Koslowe of the Westchester Jewish Center performed the ceremony at the Swiger home.

title: Brion L. Foreman Bride of Roy Lunitz
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 4  Miss Brion Lissa Foreman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Foreman of Scarsdale, N. Y., was married here this afternoon to Rev S. Lunitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Lunitz of Teaneck, N. J.

title: INDIAN SHIFT SEEN IN TIES TO SOVIET
description: NEW DELHI, March 2India spurred by the improvement of relations between the United States and China, is undergoing a delicate turn in her relations with the Soviet Union.

title: Guerrillas' Bravado Breaks at the End
description: As murder and terrorist blackmail faded into stalemate and finally surrender over three days at the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Khartoum, reports from the scene showed the resolve of the eight Palestinian guerrilla invaders Crumbling.

title: James W. Young, 87, Officer Of Thompson Ad Agency, Dies
description: James Webb Young, former vice president and director of the J. Walter Thompson Company advertising agency, died Saturday in Santa Fe (N.M.) Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived on his ranch at Pena Blanca, near Santa Fe.

title: Vietnam Veterans On City Relief Put At 4,000 in Study
description: A preliminary investigation has reported that 4,000 veterans who served during the period of the war in Vietnam are on the city's relief rolls, Mrs. Eleanor Holmes Norton, chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights, said yesterday.

title: UTILITY CONCERNS JOIN IN GAS POOL
description: At the urging of the State Public Service Commission, the 14 utility companies supplying New York State with gas have agreed to form a voluntary association known as NYGAS to find ways of overcoming the worsening shortage of natural gas in the state.

title: DR. HUGH CHAPLIN A PEDIATRICIAN, 85
description: Dr. Hugh Chaplin, a pediatri cian and ioneer in the developmeat of health programs in the city's daycare centers, died yesterday at the Medical Health Center, Meadow Lakes in Hightstown, N.J., at which he lived. His age was 85.

title: Rangers Beaten by Canucks, 43
description: A stormy assault, in which Ranger fans seemed ready to leave their seats to help their heroes on the ice, fell short last night and the New Yorkers were upset by the Vancouver Canucks, 43.

title: Now What Of Stalin's Legacy?
description: Twenty years after his death and nearly half a century since he succeeded Lenin at the helm of the Soviet state, Stalin's legacy and image baffle the historians and psychiatrists as deeply as ever.

title: Records: John Wayne
description: Patriotism, if hardly the last refuge of a record producer, does take many forms in the music business today. Familiar are the young and longhaired expressing their antiwar feelings, lefthanded patriotism. Occasionally, this is countered by such songs as those supporting First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., or major hit recordings such as the Ballad of the Green Berets. The late Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen even went on record. Many people assailed Jos Feliciano in righteous indignation for singing a soul version of the National Anthem.

title: DOUBT EXPRESSED ON TRUCE TEAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 5A major provision of the Vietnam peace agreement has been virtually written off as no longer possible to carry out, according to wellinformed sources here.

title: 34 Prisoners of Vietcong Are Released
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Monday, March 5Thirtyfour American and foreign prisoners of war were released by the Vietcong in Hanoi today and flown to Clark Air Base, marking the midpoint of prisoner releases scheduled to be completed by March 28 under the Paris ceasefire accord.

title: Aid to Handicapped Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March (UPI)Senator Charles H. Percy proposed today that businessmen be given tax incentives to make their buildings more accessible to handicapped persons. The Illinois Republican said stairs, curbs and other barriers impeded the handicapped in shopping, using public transportation, gaining employment and participating in many other daily activities.

title: Flyers Rout Leafs, 100, As MacLeish Scores 4
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (AP)  Rick MacLeish scored four goals and had three assists as the Philadelphia Flyers blanked the Toronto Maple Leafs, 100, tonight and held a 1point lead for second place in the National Hockey League's West Division.

title: 20 Years Of Stalin's Heritage
description: Stalin's ghost still haunts the Soviet Union. He has been dead twenty years now. More than half the 250 million people of the U.S.S.R. have only the vaguest memories of that tyrant's sway or were not even born at the time of his death. Yet the man himself and his colossal role in shaping the vast empire ruled from the Kremlin are still considered too politically radioactive to be discussed publicly at length or with candor within the broad realm of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

title: Ami Avivi Marries Eve Hass in Tel Aviv
description: Miss Eve Suzanne Hass, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Robert Has of New York, and Ami Avivi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Yosef Avivi of Tel Aviv, were married there yesterday morning by Rabbi Chaim Levene.

title: Wounded Knee Is a Tiny Armed Camp
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., March 4I'm supposed to be on sentry, the young Indian in the bunker in front of the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church was saying this morning as he held a .22caliber rifle with a stock held together by tape. But I've only got one bullet. I guess if they come I should shoot myself.

title: Friend of Antiwar Activists Says He Still Prefers Jail to Testifying
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 4After 19 months in jail, Donald Bruce Grumbles said last night that he would return to prison again and again if necessary rather than betray the trust of friends.

title: Miss Evert Wins $10,000, Taking First Final as Pro
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 4With a new car given to her as a gift and new clothes coming from a deal with a New York manufacturer, Chris Evert got a hefty start on a savings account today as she picked up her first paycheck as a tennis pro.

title: Irish Football Results
description: IRISH LEAGUE

title: Hunt for Education Chief Is Nearing End
description: TRENTON, March 4  The State Board of Education is about to complete the screening of prospective candidates for one of the most controversial jobs in New Jersey governmentCommissioner of Education.

title: TV: Orthodox Jews Meet Violence on Gunsmoke
description: In an unusual episode tonight at 8 on the Columbia Broadcasting System, Gunsmoke settles rapidly into a very usual plot line. After shooting up the local saloon and terrifying the customers, a whiskyswilling villain and his two brothers come upon a family of new settlers. The bully amuses himself by dragging off the younger son at the end of a rope. The boy is found fatally injured. Enter Matt Dillon (James Arness) in search of justice.

title: Boris LovetLorski, Sculptor, Did Busts of Four Presidents
description: Boris LoydLorski, a sculptor whose subjects included four Presidents as well as Toscanini and Albert Schweitzer, died early yesterday at his home, 131 East 69th Street. He was 78 years old.

title: Huge Motorcade Presses Canarsie School Boycott
description: Parents of publicschool pupils in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn intensified their boycott efforts yesterday, sending a motorcade of nearly 400 automobiles through the streets of Brooklyn's School District 18 to seek broader support in their dispute with the Board of Education.

title: Many British Families Told to Stop Using Gas
description: LONDON, March 4 (AP) Half a million British families were ordered today to stop using gas as supplies fell to a critical level as a result of strikes.

title: DR. JOHN MORRISON, EXEDUCATION AIDE
description: Dr. John Cayce Morrison, a former New York State Assistant Commissioner of Education, who from 1954 to 1958 directed a study of the teaching of Puerto Rican children in the New York City school system, died Wednesday in Pittsburgh. He was 86 years old.

title: METS HOPE STAUB WU SIGN TODAY
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4  Willie Mays set a style record in the New York Met fraining camp today by driving around in his pink Imperial with Say Hey license plates. But for sheer performance, the Mets were even more impressed by Rusty Staub's endurance at the bargaining table.

title: Advertising: F.T.C. Asked to Act
description: As a result of the lengthy hearings concerning modern advertising practices held by the Federal Trade Commission in the fall of 1971, a series of wideranging recommendations for action is being Made to the commission.

title: ROBERT C. VINCENT, LAWYER, DIES AT 62
description: NORTH PALM BEACH, Fla., March 4  Robert C. Vincent, a New York lawyer and counsel to the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom there, died here yesterday at his home. He was 62 years old and maintained residence also in Bedford Hills, N.Y.

title: Guinea Reports Rebel Arrests
description: DAKAR, Senegal, March 4 (AP)  President Skou Tor said today that Guinea had arrested a group of rebels who infiltrated the army in an effort to topple the Government. He gave no details of the reported plot.

title: Ball Raises $1.8Million
description: The St. Mary's Ball in Palm Beach, Fla., Saturday night raised $1.8million, a record total in the long history of charity balls in America. Page 36.

title: Controversial Prisoner Is Exuberant on Return
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, March, 4 (AP)Colhdr. Richard A. Stratton was a prisoner in North Vietnam for six years and captivity made him a famous and controversial figure.

title: Cambodian Town Shelled
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 4 (AP)  Communist gunners fired seven mortar rounds into the Phnom Penh suburb of Ta Khmau last night, killing two people, including an infant, and wounding 12 military men and civilians, the Cambodian military command reported today.

title: Jordanians Doom A Leader of Fatah And 15 Guerrillas
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 4One of the prominent leaders of Al Fatah, the main Palestinian guerrilla organization, and 15 other commandos are to be executed in Jordan.

title: MISS ROSS AND TOZZI JOIN MACBETH CAST
description: Elinor Ross and Giorgio Tozzi, two singers who have entered the cast of Verdi's Macbeth since its initial performances by the Metropolitan Opera some weeks ago, appeared in the work on Saturday night with Sherrill Milnes in the title role and Franco Tagliavini as Macduff. Francesco MolinariPradelli conducted.

title: INDIANS GET OFFER ON ENDING SEIZURE
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., March 4 The Justice Department Uptight offered the militant Indiins entrenched at Wounded Knee a settlement under which they would leave the village beginning at 8 A.M. tomorrow, but would remain subject to future Federal prosecution.

title: VATICAN REFUND SOUGHT BY VETCO
description: VENTURA, Calif., March 4A small, familybuilt industrial firm here, amazed to learn that the Vatican has quietly acquired an interest of nearly onefifth of its stock, is trying to persuade Papal authorities to surrender the shortterm profits of their speculative splurge.

title: U.A.W. Ford Leader Retires
description: DETROIT, March 4 (AP)James O'Rourke, vice president of the nation's largest United Automobile Workers local, is retiring after 30 years of labor activity. Mr. O'Rourke, 62yearold vice president of the 30,000member Ford Local 600 for the last eight years, was In the forefront of the 1941 FordU.A.W. strike.

title: Rumanian Gymnasts Victors
description: DENVER, March 4 (AP) The Rumanian national team, On an American tour and meeting a nonnational team for the first time, defeated the Denver School of Gymnastics, 189.45 points to 184.55, last night.

title: BOND CALENDARS GROWING LARGER
description: The money and capital markets will resume operations this morning in an atmosphere bordering on quiet desperation, because of the latest foreignexchange turmoil.

title: Staten Island's Future
description: Once again the fate of southern Staten Island is in the hands of the Legislature. A vote is probable this week in the Senate on Senator John J. Marchi's bill to create a South Richmond development corporation.

title: British Football Results
description: RUGBY LEAGUE

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:A consolidation of the Federal Governnient's multitudinous activities relating to energy resources is obvionsly desirable, but steps now being taken are inadequate to solve the energy crisis.

title: UNION CHIEFS BALK AT 5.5% GUIDELINE
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 Leaders of major unions will contract negotiations coming up in 1973 are virtually unanimous in declaring they will ignore the Government's wage guidelines and demand wage increases of substantially more than 5.5 per cent.

title: Dangerous Split
description: For many years, New York City's aggressive Civil Service unions used to milk the taxpayers by going to the State Legislature in Albany to extract benefits on top of their already avergenerous benefits from City Hall. Now a reverse twist on this unhealthy type of double decking threatens to wreck the vastly improved, machinery on which the city currently relies to bring rationality into its troubled labor relations.

title: Personal Finance
description: The nation's corporations last year paid out about $16billion in dividends, and the total probably will increase this year. However, with inflation on the rise, investors will have to make their dividend money work harder than ever.

title: Wounded Knee Is a Tiny Armed Camp
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., March 4I'm supposed to be on sentry, the young Indian in the bunker in front of the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church was saying this morning as he held a 22caliber rifle with a stock held together by tape. But I've only got one bullet. guess if they come I should shoot myself.

title: Floating Rate
description: The protracted dollar crisis has reached a breaking point. European governments seeking to maintain fixed exchange rates against the twicedevalued dollar were hit by massive waves of dollar selling last week and have been compelled to close their foreignexchange markets through this week.

title: Islanders' Crisp Traded
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (AP)The Philadelphia Flyers announced tonight that they had traded a defenseman, Jean Potvin, for the New York Islanders' center, Terry Crisp. The trade was made just before the National Hockey League's midnight deadline.

title: HONOR KILLING FOUGHT IN BERM
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March A man who choked his 15 yearold daughter to death be cause he said she flirted with boys, has just been releasec from prison on a presidentia pardon after serving nine months of a sevenyear sen tence.

title: Allin Takes Florida Golf by 8 Shots
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 4Brian (Bud) Allin, a 28yearold golf professional and Vietnam war veteran, smashed five 1973 Professional Golfers' Association tour records today in winning the $150,000 Florida Citrus open by 8 strokes with a 23underpar total of 265.

title: Prestige of Stalin Now Reviving
description: MOSCOW, March 4  Two decades after his death on March 5, 1953, Stalin enjoys great latent prestige among the Soviet people and a much more favorable popular reputation than Nikita S. Khrushchev, the man who dared denounce him for his vast political purges.

title: GreekAmericans Capture New York York Soccer Cup Final
description: In the most significant soccer game every year in this areathe New York final for the United States Challenge Cupa Hungarian and a Yugoslav combined for the winning tally for the New York GreekAmericans yesterday against New York Hota.

title: Mel CAPTURES WORLD CUP EVENT
description: STE. ANNE DE BEAUPRE, Quebec, March 4 (AP)Gustavo Thoeni of Italy won World Cup slalom today after Claude Perrot of France, who had placed first, was disqualified for missing a gate in the opening heat.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: State Report Awaited in School Strike

title: Influx of Investors Bolsters Commodity Future Prices
description: People fleeing from the dollar converged with those rushing to buy commodities again last week, and the resultant friction tore a wider hole in the consumer's pocket.

title: Federal Economist Sees No Single Villain Behind Food Prices
description: Everybody's looking for a villain, said Dr. Don Pearlberg, agricultural economics director of the United States Department of Agriculture in Washington. Well, there isn't any villain.

title: AMNESTY IS OPPOSED BY 7 OF 10 IN POLL
description: Seven out of ten adults surveyed opposed unconditional amnesty for young men who left the country to avoid military service in Vietnam, according to the latest Gallup Poll on the subject.

title: International Agreement Aids Container Shipping
description: The movement of export and import cargoes in containers, the port's predominant method of handling water  borne foreign  trade shipments, is expected to be facilitated as a result of a recently negotiated international convention.

title: The American Dream
description: In his detailed message to Congress on human resources, President Nixon has outlined a major retreat by the Federal Government from its social responsibilities. He seeks to abolish the community action programs begun as part of the Johnson Administration's war on poverty and to, dismantle the Office of Economic Opportunity established to direct that war. He would withdraw Federal money for neighborhood mental clinics, hospital constriction and regional medical programs. He abandons his own plan for welfare reform.

title: 10,400 Fans Attend Pro Track Opener; 3 Marks Bettered
description: POCATELLO, Idaho, March 4 (AP)  Three world indoor records were bettered before 10,400 fans last night in the first leg of the United States professional track and field tour.

title: Total of Puerto Rican Descent in City Put at 846,731
description: In a final report on 1970 Hispanic population figures, the Census Bureau announced yesterday that New. York City had 846,731 residents of Puerto Rican descent in that year, a figure several hundred thousand lower than the total claimed by various Puerto Rican leaders in the city.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: SHOW AND TELL At least two media will mix tonight and tomorrow at 8 in the Kitchen, that chamber of electronic wonderment in the Mercer Arts Center, 240 Mercer Street. The work to be performed is Alvin Lucier's The Queen of the South, a last year's piece by the composer, who will also be one of the six performers playing it. Mr. Lucier, who has been associated with the Sonic Arts Union and Wesleyan University, is an oldguard avantgarde music man who has long been searching for the esthetic in unusual sources.

title: A New Passaic River Plan Proposed
description: BASKING RIDGE, March 4The Army Corps of Engineer. will announce within a week floodcontrol plan for the Pas saic River. Already, the plat is being denounced by the Pas saic River Coalition, the water shed association for the entire Passaic River Valley.

title: IRISH SURVEY SHOWS UNITY IS UNPOPULAR
description: DUBLIN, March 4 (AP)Fewer than a third of the Irish believe that national unity represents the best solution to the Northern Ireland crisis, an opinion poll reported today.

title: Edward Grassmann, Sold Land for Newark Airport
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., March 4Edward J. Grassmann, a real estate investor and civil engineer, who had sold land to the Port of New York Authority for Newark Airport and Port Elizabeth, died Friday. He was 85 years old and lived here.

title: Crime Puts Hollis In State of Alarm
description: On a sunny afternoon the quiet streets of Hollis with their tall shade trees and comfortable singlefamily homes can still conjure up the atmosphere of smalltown America of 40 years ago.

title: Mohammad Out for 119 Helps Pakistan Near English Total
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, March 4 (Reuters)  Sadiq Mohammad completed his third test century, a 5hour effort, as Pakistan moved to within 8 runs of England's first innings' total of 355 on the third day of the first test today. At the close, Pakistan was 347 for five wickets.

title: Palm Beach Ball Nets $1.8Million for St. Mary's Hospital, a Record
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., March 4Roman Catholic nuns and Palm Beach socialities teamed up as sisters of charity for the St. Mary's Ball last night and raised $1.8million on behalf of the local hospital.

title: UNION CHIEFS BALK AT 5.5% GUIDELINE
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 Leaders of major unions with contract negotiations coming up in 1973 are virtually unanimous in declaring they will ignore the Government's wage guidelines and demand wage increases of substantially more than 5.5 per cent.

title: Rep. Rosenthal Incited Disorders, Greek Says
description: ATHENS, March 4An Athens newspaper said today that Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, had incited the recent student disorders in Greece to obtain a pretext for a Congressional debate on the Greek Government.

title: PRESIDENT FINDS END OF CITY CRISIS, WITH DIP IN CRIME
description: WASHINGTON, March 4President Nixon asserted in radio address today that the quality of life was on the upswing again in the nation's cities and towns, and that the hour of crisis has passed in American community life.

title: Adina Berzon Wed in Suburb
description: MONSEY, N. Y., March 4Miss Adina Berzon, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Bernard L. Berzon of Brooklyn, New York, was married here this afternoon to Samuel David Gertz, son of Mrs. Rubin Gertz of Balitmore, and the late Mr. Gertz.

title: Church Moves in a Procession Up Park
description: Members of St: Peter's Lutheran Church, which has packed up and moved eight tunes in its 111year history in east midtown, locked St. Peter's big wooden doors behind them yesterday as the bell tolled in their Gothic steeple at Lexington Avenue and 54th Street.

title: Youthson IND Terrorize Riders and Rob Man 82
description: Five youths terrorized 25 passengers yesterday afternoon on one car of a Bronxbound DID subway train, robbing an 82yearold man of $60 and his wristwatch at the point of a gun.

title: Connally, Hailed by Nixon, Reported to Look to 1976
description: HOUSTON, March 4Nine months after he left the Nixon Cabinet, John B. Connally is more than ever a prince of the rich Texas establishmenta rancher and real estate venturer and a soughtafter lawyer and business counselor to some of the biggest bankers and oilmen in the state.

title: Congress to Begin Study Of SportsRelated Issues
CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: NIXON'S BROTHER CALLED IN INQUIRY
description: Edward C. Nixon, Presiden Nixon's youngest brother, form er Attorney General John N Mitchell, and Maurice H. Stans former Secretary of Commerce were invited yesterday to tel what they know of a secret $200,000 cash contritiutior made by a New Jersey finan cier last April to the Finance Committee to Reelect the President.

title: Miss Elkins Has Nuptials
description: HOUSTON, March 4Miss Margaret Elise Elkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Anderson Elkins Jr., was married here last night to Russell Charles Joseph, son of Mr. and Mrs, Richard Stevens Joseph of Richmond.

title: Stage: Modern Venice
description: An opening fanfare of jazz, a Pucci and Gucci glint, and a Venice observed by Fellini and Viscontithese are the attitudes indicated by Ellis Rabb's staging of The Merchant of Venice, which opened last night at Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater. It had rather more chic than sense.

title: Sports Issues Stir Congress
description: Early last week, Senator John Tunney introduced a bill in the United States Senate asking for the appointment of a commission to study America's participation in the Olympic Games.

title: Competitive Questions Cloud Banking
description: Can the Government block the merger of two banksor of any other companies, for that matterthat do not compete with each other, but which might, someday, potentially become competitors? The question is a prickly one, and the Supreme Court did nothing to clarify the issue last week when it split, 4to4, over whether the First National Bancorporation, Inc., of Denver could acquire the First National Bank of Greeley, Colo. The effect of the tie vote will be to allow the merger to go through, but it will settle none of the basic issues that had been raised in what had been billed as a landmark case.

title: MRS. MEIR SCORES GIVING INTO ARABS
description: Israel's Premier, Mrs. Golda Meir, scored some European nations yesterday for submitting to what she said was Arab terrorist blackmail in releasing Arabs apprehended for terrorist acts.

title: Oratorio Society Sings Premiere Of Mompou Sacred Improperios
description: The noted Catalan composer Fedetico. Mompou will be 80 years old next month, and the Oratorio Society of New York held its first rehearsals 100 years ago this month. Both celebrants were alive and well Sunday afternoon, at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle.

title: GreekAmericans Capture New York Soccer Cup Final
description: In the most significant soccer game every year in this areathe New York final for the United States Challenge Cupa Hungarian and a Yugoslav combined for the winning tally for the New York GreekAmericans yesterday against New York Rota.

title: Lindsay Sings and Dances and Does a Shtik, but He Never Answers the Question
description: The Mayor of New York was dancing, prancing across a stage and telling jokes. He was early Fred Astaire, or at least it was early Astaire's two expressions he was using, the one where he frowned before he told a joke, and the one where he raised his eyebrows after he had told it, and the Mayor was more or less socko.

title: The Political Contract: A Favor
description: Most widespread of all these pleasures is the somewhat dubious one of handling contracts.

title: DESPERADO TAKES PEKINGESE HONOR
description: Emidio and, Karen Franzoso have only two Pekingese. They brought one, Ch. Ho Dynasty's Desperado, from their South Bound Brook, N. J., home yesterday to the 111th specialty of the Pekingese Club of America, at the Hotel McAlpin, and left with a couple of pieces of silverware as the fawn sable was named best of breed.

title: Brighter Dollar Outlook Calms Overseas Markets
description: LONDON, March 4The mood in European and other investment and currency markets at the end of last week reflected a spreading awareness that either there is nothing economically wrong with the dollar or, if there is, a European solution can be found to cope with it.

title: U. S. Role at Monetary Talks Uncertain
description: WASHINGTON, March 4The United States left uncertain tonight whether it would attend a conference next week of the main industrial countries on the current international currency crisis.

title: Books of The Times
description: Of these two reports on Black Panther trials, it is Donald Freed's Agony in New Haven: The Trial of Bdbby Seale, Ericka. Huggins and the Blick Ranther Party that IS the bigger book and does the brawny work of grasping for apotheoses, to use one of Mr. Freed's favorite Greekrooted words (the Agony of his title is not just any old agony you might find lying around the attic; it's Ag'ony, (G. agon), his epigraph explains, meaning A struggle or contest ... a match between combatants ... the argument introducing a classical tragedyirt short; one of those expensive antique words that you put on the mantelpiece along with stycbomythia and eudaemonisrn). By contrast, Edwin Kennebeck's Juror Number Four: The Trial of 13 Black Panthers as Seen From the Jury Box is all modest in its intentions and all quiet in its conclusions. Yet it is Mr. Kennebeek who grabs you and makes think about the system, not Mr. Freed.

title: Walter D. Van Riper, 77, Dies; Was Jersey Attorney General
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., March (UPI)Walter D. Van Riper former New Jersey Attorney General, died of a heart attaci yesterday at the Boca Rator?? Hotel. He was 77 years old and lived at 22 Harbor Terrace it West Orange, N. J.

title: Furs for Spring and Summer
description: You don't have to be an Eskimo to wear furs in spring and summer. Furriers think every woman needs a little fur to fill in her wardrobe after the mink coat goes to storage. It might be a little jacket or a fur sweater to wear with daytime pants or skirts. Or a tiny something to, keep her from getting goosebumps in airconditioning come July.

title: Bridge:
description: A team of young, Brooklyn experts led the field of 52 teams into the fourth and final session of the Greater New. York Bridge Association's Swiss team championship at the New York Hilton here last night.

title: Containers Get Advice On Buying Cheap Meats
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI)For consumers up in arms about soaring meat prices, the Agriculture Department is offering a handy guide to cheaper eating.

title: Eight in Custody of Khartoum's Army
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan March 4Eight Black September commandos ended their occaution of the Saudi Arabian Embassy here at dawn today, emerging in single file from the building where they had killer two American diplomats and Belgium's charg d'affaires.

title: Nets Play Waiting Game and Lose
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 4  The Carolina Cougars kept the New York Nets waiting an hour and a half beyond the scheduled start, then added the indignity of walloping them, 123111, at the Nassau Coliseum this afternoon.

title: Celtics Triumph Over Braves, 125113
description: BOSTON, March 4 (UPI) Paul Silas scored 26 points and Dave Cowens added 22 as the Boston Celtics defeated the Buffalo Braves, 125  113, tonight in a National Basketball Association game. Randy Smith of the Braves led all scorers with 32 points.

title: DESPERADO TAKES PEKINGESE HONOR
description: Emidio and Karen Franzoso have only two Pekingese. They brought one, Ch. Ho Dynasty's Desperado, from their South Bound Brook, N. J., home yesterday to the 111th specialty of the Pekingese Club of America, at the Hotel McAlpin, and left with a couple of pieces of silverware as the fawn sable was named best of breed.

title: KERR TO INCREASE FORCE AT KHAN
description: NEWARK, March 4 (UPI)In response to requests by black supporters of the controversial Kawaida Towers highrise development, Edward Kerr, the acting Newark Police Director, has said he will increase police security at the North Ward construction site.

title: BERNSTEIN LEADS PROGRAM OF JAZZ
description: Said Leonard Bernstein from the Carnegie Hall stage on Sunday morning: I lest played jazz in public during World War II. He then proceeded into an efficient version of Meade Lux Lewis's early nineteenthirties boogiewoogie classic, Honkytonk Train Blues.

title: 106 P.O.W.'s Released, 34 Due Today
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Monday, March 5 United States planes landed in Hanoi again this morning for more prisonerofwar releases less than 12 hours after 106 American fliers arrived here from Hanoi yesterday looking pale but generally healthy.

title: The Barn Where the Big Horses Live
description: MIAMI, March 4Secretariat stood serenely in his stall while Edward Sweat worked over him with a rub rag, grooming every hair. The red horse's coat bloomed with a coppery glow that seemed to come from within. He was the big kid on the block last year when he spreadeagled the 2yearold division and he has continued to grow and fill out. At 3 he is a strapping dude, magnificently muscled, giving a sense of controlled power even in repose. He is very well behaved, said Lucien Laurin, and a lot of that is the man who takes care of him. Patience, kindness, understandingit all goes into making a good horse. The trainers words were easily laudible to the groom, but Edward Sweat worked on methodically, giving no sign that he heard. Secretariat remained in this stall yesterday while Hialeah distributed $140,800 to lesser colts in the Flamingo Stakes. Laurin saddled Angle Light for the race and sent him out to collect $14,080 dollars in third money for Ed Whittaker of Toronto. Earlier in the winter the trainer did not reject the possibility that Secretariat might try for one or two of Florida's $100,000 purses, but several weeks ago he announced his decision to wait for later races in New York.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: OXRIDGE JUMPS WON BY MISS KITTERMAN
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 4Kathy Kitterman, the junior jumping champion of Argentina last year, piloted Chablis to victory in both open jumper classes today at the closing session of the twoday Ox Ridge Hunt Club winter indoor horse show.

title: Bank of Commerce Plans Empire National Merger
description: An agreement in principle has been reached for the merger of Bank of Commerce, New York City, with the Empire National Bank of Middletown, N. Y. Bank of Commerce is a subsidiary of Financial General Bankshares, Inc., a multibank holding company based in Washington.

title: Regazzoni Satisfactory
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Afriea, March 4 (AP)Clay Regazzoni of Switzerland was reported in satisfactory condition today after suffering burns on his arms and hands during a collision In yesterday's South African Grand Prix.

title: Meanwhile, in Saigon
description: PARIS, March 4A South Vietnamese neutralist who fled to Paris years ago to avoid arrest by the Thieu Government is now planning to go home. During the International Conference here last week he met some Saigon officials and asked whether he could return safely. Of, course, they said: It was time for national reconciliation, and they wanted him home.

title: Roberta Flack Wins Two Grammies for Her Records
description: Roberta Flack, the black souljazz singer, won 2 of the 47 Grammy Awards presented Saturday night in the 15th annual ceremonies conducted by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciencies. Part of the program was televised nationally over the Columbia Broadcasting System from the Tennessee Theater in Nashville.

title: Drop in City's Welfare Rolls in December Was a Record Monthly Deci??
description: Another decrease in the city's welfare rolls  a drop in December of 9,579 people, described as the largest monthly decrease in the city's historywas announced yesterday by Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman.

title: ST. JOHN'S, COLUMBIA MET SWIM WINNERS
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., March 4  St. John's, Columbia and Stony Brook won their respective divisions in the seventh Metropolitan intercollegiate swimming championships last night, ending three days of competition at the Stony Brook University pool.

title: Film: Baxter! Arrives
description: Baxter! is a sincere, quite solemn film about the breakdown of a teenage boy who has a speech defect. Roger Baxter (Scott Jacoby) cannot say his r's, a psychic disability he sports as if it were a service ribbon commemorating the most epic squabbles of his uninterested parents. When they are divorced and his mother (Lynn Carlin) moves from California to London with Baxter in tow, the boy goes steadily to pieces.

title: OneDay Strike by Teachers Is Ended in Providence, R.I.
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 4 (AP)Providence teachers and the School Committee ratified a tentative agreement today ending a teacher strike that closed the city's schools Friday. Schools will open tomorrow, the School Committee said.

title: City Will Publicize Names Of Landlords Who Harass
description: A new policy of regularly publishing the names of landlords fined for housing violations described as harassment of tenants was announced yesterday by Nathan Leventhal, City Commissioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance.

title: METS HOPE STAUB WILL SICK TODAY
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4  Willie Mays set a style record in the New York Met training camp today by driving around in his pink Imperial with Say Hey license plates. But for sheer performance, the Mets were even more impressed by Rusty Staub's endurance at the bargaining table.

title: Robert J. Hamershlag Dies; ExStook Exchange Governor
description: Robert J. Hamershlag, a founding partner of Hamershlag, Borg & Co., Inc., stockbrokers, and a former governor of the New York Stock Exchange, died Saturday of a heart attack in Ocho Rios, Jamaica, while on vacation. He was 79 years old and lived in Katonah, N.Y., and at 219 East 69th Street.

title: In Italy, New Hope Stirs the Tomb Robbers
description: CERVETERI, Italy, March 4Overnight, Euphronios has become a household word in the Etruscan tomb country around here.

title: LongTerm Judgeships Urged For the Governor's Drug Plan
description: State Senate Majority Leader Warren M. Anderson said yesterday that he favored longer terms than six months for any judgeships that might be created to enforce Governor Rockefeller's proposals for longer jail terms for drug sellers.

title: Consumers Seek Ways to Meet the High Cost of Eating
SnowMaking Keeps Skiers on Slopes Despite Temperatures
description: VERNON, March 4While temperatures in the metropolitan area reached into the sixties, a scattering of hardy skiers spent the weekend on ski slopes in northwest New Jersey, happily free of long lines wating for lifts.

title: Brooklyn Beats City College In Tourney Final by 6964
description: Brooklyn College won the ninth annual City University basketball tournament by defeating City College, 6964, yesterday at the loser's Mahoney Hall. City led, 6258, with 3 minutes 55 seconds left when Brooklyn reeled off 9 straight points to clinch the victory.

title: Eight in Custody of Khartoum's Army
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 4Eight Black September commandos ended their occupation of the Saudi Arabians Embassy here at dawn today, emerging in single file from the building where they had killed two American diplomats and Belgium's charg d'affaires.

title: Nixon Asked to Declare A Moratorium on Meat
description: DRUMMOND ISLAND, Mich., March 4The 700 residents of this resort island in Lake Huron have asked the White House to help them lead a national moratorium next week against buying or eating meat as a protest. against rising prices.

title: ISRAEL ASKS DRIVE AGAINST TERRORISTS
description: TEL AVIV, March 4Israel today called on all countries, including Arab, to join in a drive against Palestinian terrorists.

title: Objects Sighted in Sky
description: STROUDSBURG, Pa., March 4 (AP)The state police have confirmed reports that strange objects with flashing lights were seen flying over Saylor's Lake in the Pocono Mountains resort region. The objects were not identified.

title: Irish Football Results
description: IRISH LEAGUE

title: BADILLO AND KOCH WILL STAY IN RACE
description: Two liberal Democratic mayoral candidates, Representatives Herman Badillo of the Bronx and Edward I. Koch of Manhattan, insisted yesterday that they would remain in the race despite the endorsement of Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal by the New Democratic Coalition.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: World Elsewhere: The New American Foreign Policy, by James Chace (Scribners, $5.95).

title: Bus Service Scheduled After L.I.R.R. Mishap
description: Bus service will be provided this morning for all commuters on the Port Jefferson branch of the Long Island Rail Road east of the Huntington station because of a derailment last night.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Sports Today
description: BOWLING

title: A Group For Both Mothers, Toddlers
description: Googolplex is a sort of nursery school on West 68th Street. It is also a mathematical concept that strings masses of zeroes after the. figure 1, but that's beside the point. Helen Weissman (whose husband, Stephen, used to be a mathematician before he became a rare book dealer) just liked the sound of the word. Just right, she decided, for a kind of nursery school.

title: Iran's Arms Outlay to Rise
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 4 Premier Amir Abbas Hoveida today presented to Iran's Parliament a budget of nearly $7billion of which nearly $2bil1 lionan increase of more than 45 per cent  is for military expenditures.

title: Nixon's Presidency: Crisis for Congress
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 You just think we're dumb, Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, told George P. Shultz, Secretary of the Treasury and Counselor to the President, during a recent hearing on Capitol Hill.

title: Ball Raises $1.8Million
description: The St. Mary's Ball in Palm Beach, Fla., Saturday night raised $1.8million, a record total in the long history of charity balls in America. Page 36.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MIAMI, March 4 (AP)  Gulf stream Park opens a 55day program tomorrow with the running of the $20,000 added Appleton Handicap in two divisions and the 1973 debut of the filly champion, La Prevoyante.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The French left scored heavy gains in yesterday's legislative elections, but almost certainly not enough to upset the Gaullistled Government. With about twothirds of the votes counted, the Government coalition appeared strong enough to assemble a majority of Assembly seats after next Sunday's runoff elections and stay in power for five more years. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Federal Economist Sees No Single Villain Behind Food Prices
description: Everybody's looking for a villain, said Dr. Don Paariberg, agricultural economics director of the United States Department of Agriculture in Washington. Well, there isn't any villain.

title: Soviet Copyrights
description: In a welcome decision, the Soviet Government has at last decided to become a party to the Universal Copyright Convention. It is a useful Anther step in the evolutionary integration of the Soviet Union into the international organizations and agreements which facilitate normal cooperation in many fields. The precursor of the present move was Soviet adherence Several years ago to the international structure of patent protection.

title: The DoGooding Goodyear Blimp Goes International
description: ROME, Feb. 28The Goodyear blimp has gone international.

title: GERALDINE NICOSIA, INTERIOR DECORATOR
description: Geraldine Nicosia, an interim designer, died yesterday at Wickersham Hospital after a long illness. Her age was 62, She was the wife of Dr. Joseph Nicosia, a physician, of 25 Sutton Place South.

title: Policeman Wounds Bandit As IND Holdup Is Foiled
description: An armed man who attempted to hold up an IND change clerk in the Second Avenue and Houston Street station escaped yesterday after being wounded by a Transit Authority policeman.

title: TROOP PULLOUTS RESUMED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) The United States resumed the withdrawal of American troops from South Vietnam today and moved a naval minesweeping force back into position off Haiphong.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Vandals Damage A Synagogue

title: The Constitution on Powers
description: WASHINGTON, March 4  Following are certain provisions of the Constitution regarding the delegation of powers between the Congress and the President:

title: KNICKS DEFEATED BY BULLETS AGAIN
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 4For the second time within 24 hours, the Baltimore Bullets whipped the New York Knicks in the fourth quarter of a National Basketball Association game today, and their 10697 victory created a little suspense about the rest of the regular schedule.

title: 250 From U.S. Saved As Ship Sinks at Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 4 (Reuters)  More than 250 American passengers were evacuated from their cruise ship last night when an engineroom explosion tore a hole in the vessel shortly before it was to leave here for Haifa, Israel. The ship, the Cyprioteregistered Sounion, sank in Beirut harbor.

title: Ellsberg Trial: Now the Focus Is on Secrecy
description: LOS ANGELES, March 4From the start, many constitutional authorities have seen the Pentagon papers trial as a major test of the Government's authority over information and the public's access to it. But until Friday, when defense testimony began on the Government's system of classifying secrets, the crucial First Amendment implications of the case had been somewhat obscured. They had been touched upon by lawyers for Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. in their opening statements to the jury. Now, in the coming days, the defense will open as broad an attack against the classsification system as the trial judge will allow.

title: Radar Probe Points to Large Chunks of Matter in Saturn's Rings
description: In the first suuccessful radar probe of Saturn, astronomers at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., have determined that the planet's distinctive rings appear to be composed of large chunks of solid material in orbit like a swarm of tiny moons.

title: Stage: O'Casey's Juno
description: NEW HAVEN, March 4Arvin Brown's production of Sean O'Casey's Juno and the Paycock, which opened Friday at the Long Wharf Theater, is exhilarating for the audience and restorative for the play.

title: Taxes Cost Workers 2 Hours Each Day
description: Two hours and 39 minutes of the average American's eighthour working day is used to earn money to pay taxes, the Tax Foundation reported today.

title: Capitalism, for Better or Worse
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.What is the present distribution of income and Wealth in the. U.S.A.? Wealth is distributed much more unevenly than income; thus, the richest 10 per cent of the population receive 29 per cent of personal income but own 56 per cent of the national wealth, while the poorest 10 per cent receive 1 per cent of the income and are in debt, to boot. At the top of the wealth distribution, 1 per cent of the wealthholders own 25 per cent of physical and financial wealth. Among those with incomes in excess of $100,000, inherited wealth amounts to 57 per cent of total assets.

title: Parents vs. Religious Communes
description: Patrick Alexander was a member of a religious commune near Los Angeles last November when his father and an uncle lured him into a car, drove him to a San Diego metel and kept him locked inside for four days until teams of local fundamentalist Christians had persuaded him to leave the sect.

title: At Polling Place Near Paris, 11 Stacks of Choices
description: PARIS, March 4It is a tradition in Francenot always observed nowadaysthat male voters wearing hats uncover their heads in front of the ballot box.

title: President at Camp David
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., March 4 (AP)President Nixon flew by helicopter today to the Maryland mountains and his secluded Camp David retreat.

title: EAST ERM CITY DISMAYED BYWBST
description: BERLIN, March 4Displaying a sense of disenchantment with the West, a middleaged East German said that he was upset by commercials shown on West German television.

title: Total of Puerto Rican Descent in City Put at 846,731
description: In a final report on 1970 Hispanic population figures, the Census Bureau announced yesterday that New York City had 846,731 residents of Puerto Rican descent in that year, a figure several hundred thousand lower than the total claimed by various Puerto Rican leaders in the city.

title: Raiders Drop to Fourth In 42 Loss to Blazers
description: If the fans of the New York Raiders were not so stoical, tolerant and patient, their situation would be untenable. They needed all those virtues yesterday afternoon as their heroes floundered into fourth place in the Eastern Division of the World Hockey Association.

title: Blues Recall O'Shea
description: ST. LOUIS, March 4 (UPI)The St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League recalled a right wing, Kevin O'Shea, from their Denver farm club today.

title: A JERSEY P.O.W. AMONG RELEASED
description: There were tears and laughter in the Linden, N. J., home of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Coker yesterday as their son, Lieut. George T. Coker, began his long journey home from the Vietnam war.

title: New Delhi: Quiet Rhythm of Culture
description: NEW DELHISlowly, the summer heat envelops the boulevards, the parks, the bazaars and shacks of the capital. The bougainvillea and marigolds shimmer in the gardens. By midmorning, with the air sweet and the sun burning through the haze, the men in white dhotis start unlocking their stalls, and snake charmers crouch beside hotel entrances to play their flutes softly. The city is pulsing with music festivals, concerts, movies and art shows. If there is a crisis a day in the newspapers  on any given morning there may be a hunger strike, a food shortage, a walkout, a denunciation, a resignation, a rumor and a brutal clash somewhere between the police and a mob there is also a flow of gentleness, a quiet rhythm that balances the gaudy violence and misery.

title: Foes of Allende, Victors In Vote, Fallshort of Goal
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 4  The Opposition today won a large majority of the vote in legislative elections that were considered a crucial test for the Marxist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Music
description: As everyone who cares about such matters must know by now, Alexis Weissenberg plays the piano about as brilliantly as anyone now before the public. His Schumann recital at the Hunter College Assembly Hall went from one technical tour deforce to another, winding, up with a positively Horowitzian performance of the Symphonic Etudes. And yet, the listener was more often overpowered with admiration for the pianism than the music.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 5, 1973

title: LEFT SHOWS GAIN IN FRENCH VOTE GAULLOSTS DOWN
description: PARIS, Monday, March 5The French Left scored heavy gains in yesterday's legislative elections, but almost certainly they were not enough to upset, the Gaullistled Government.

title: Bostonians to Get Whistles
description: BOSTON, March 4 (AP)The Beacon Hill Civic Association announced yesterday plans to distribute several thousand Londontype police whistles to residents of the area in an effort to Cut crime.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 2d Contract Soon for 2d Ave. Subway

title: Chicago Banker Elected National Y.M.C.A. Head
description: A Chicago banker, E. Stanley Enlund, was elected chairman of the national board of the Young Men's Christian Association yesterday.

title: PRESIDENT FINDS END OF CITY CRISIS, WITH DIP IN CRIME
description: WASHINGTON, March 4President Nixon asserted in a radio address today that the quality of life was on the upswing again in the nation's cities and towns, and that the hour of crisis has passed in American community life.

title: Dr. Annetta J. Kimball Marries
description: Dr. Annetta June Kimball and Thomas Garrard Weaver, a product manager with the healthcare division of Johnson & Johnson in New Brunswick, N. J., were married here yesterday afternoon in the St. RegisSheraton.

title: WOMAN KILLS ROBBER IN BAR WITH HIS GUN
description: A gunman was shot and killed yesterday by a woman patron in a Bronx tavern after she wrested his pistol from him as he and two accomplices reportedly were preparing to commit a holdup.

title: Parents vs. Religious Communes
description: Patrick Alexander was a member of a religious commune near Los Angeles last November when his father and an uncle hired him into a car, drove him to a San Diego motel and kept him locked inside for four days until teams of local fundamentalist Christians had persuaded him to leave the sect.

title: Guerrillas' Bravado Breaks at the End
description: As murder and terrorist blackmail faded into stalemate and finally surrender over three days at the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Khartoum, reports from the scene showed the re. solve of the eight Palestlniafi guerrilla invaders crumbling.

title: Throngs of Arkansans Unite to Mourn Winthrop Rockefeller, Healer of Division
description: WINROCK FARM, Ark., March 4The Rockefellers came down from the East to mourn and eulogize their Southern brother, Winthrop, today on the scrubby Arkansas mountain that he nourished and made to bloom.

title: 9 in Youth Gang Seized With Fire Bombs on Roof
description: Nine members of a youth gang known as the Dynamite Brothers were arrested on a tenement rooftop in the East Village last night where they had allegedly assembled 13 Molotov cocktails for a suspected fight with the Royal Javelins, a Bronx gang.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Once again the Museum of Modern Art has scooped the stores. In its current new acquisitions show, which remains through. March X18, are a hifi turntable, a digital clock and a disposable thermometer so new that production and marketing are just commencing.

title: U.S. Men's Team Chosen For Soviet Indoor Track
description: RICHMOND, March 4 (AP)Only six Americans from last year's victorious United States squad will participate in the second indoor SovietAmerican track meet here March 16. The teams announced today was based on the finish of Americans in last month's Amateur Athletic Union indoor championships in Madison Square Garden.

title: St. John's to Test Penn in N.C.A A.
description: Penn continues to own the Ivy League in basketball. The Quakers won their fourth straight championship by overwhelming Dartmouth, 7446. Along With St. Joseph's and Furman, which also won Saturday night, Penn completed the cast of six teams for the National Collegiate Eastern regional tournament.

title: OXRIDGE JUMPS WON BY MISS KITTERMAN
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 4Kathy. Kitterman, the junior jumping champion of Argentina last year, piloted Chablis to victory in both open jumper classes today at the closing session of the twoday Ox Ridge Hunt Club winter indoor horse show.

title: Urban Leaders Welcome Plan For Lesser U.S. Role in Cities
description: WASHINGTON, March 4In the face of President Nixon's restructuring and dismantling of major social programs, the nation's cities will seek to save what they can and build on what is left, Mayor Roman S. Gribbs of Detroit, president of the National League of Cities, said today.

title: New Jersey sports
description: RUTHERFORD, N. J., March 4When he was 7 years old, weight lifting was his sport. At 9, he was playing rightfield for his Little League baseball team and halfback for his Pee Wee football club. Now at 20, Torn DePoto is the No. 1 man on the Fairleigh Dickinson University fencing team.

title: Total Income Gains
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America yesterday reported assets of $33.9billion for the year ended Dec. 31, 1972, up 8.8 per cent, or $2.7billion from 1971.

title: P.O.W. Wives Who Chose New Life Face Dilemma
description: LOS ANGELES, March 5Comdr. Raymond A. Vohden had been a prisoner of war for more than six years when he wrote to his wife, Bonnye, and urged her to make new life.

title: BLACK ASSEMBLY PASSES KEY TEST
description: DETROIT, March 5If State, Representative Hannah Atkins of Oklahoma and others are right, the yearold National. Black Assembly passed a major test here last weekend in its somewhat labored struggle to create an effective nationwide political organization for blacks.

title: RIGHTISTS RBEL ON ECOLOGY LAWS
description: BOISE, Idaho, March 3Two actions of the Idaho State Senate have focused attention on the growing rebellion of con servatives in the West against the strictures of environmental protection legislation.

description: International

title: GOVERNOR WEIGHS WIDER DRUG STEP
description: ALBANY, March 5Governor Rockefeller, said today that he was giving very serious consideration to proposing the death: penalty for organized crime figures convicted of trafficking in drugs.

Mrs. Meir Sees Peace for Mideast
description: Premier Golda Meir of Israel said last night that we believe honestly and sincerely and without doubt that the day will come when between our neighbors and between is there will be no more wars.

title: GOVERNOR WEIGHS WIDER DRUG STEP
description: ALBANY, March 5Governor Rockefeller said today that he was giving very serious consideration to proposing the death penalty for organizedcrime figures convicted of trafficking in drugs.

title: Brooks Industries Planning a Merger With Peck & Pal
description: The boards of Brooks Industries, Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., apparel producer and operator of retail stores, and Peck & Peck, Inc. of New York, yesterday approved acquisition of Peck & Peck by Brooks. An undisclosed number of shares of Brooks common is involved in the purchase.

title: Human Reward
description: Should any human being serve another? Is it right for one person to devote the greater part of his life to caring for the domestic chores of someone else? And is this, whether wrong or right, desirable?

title: Judge Rules Against Madison Ave. Mall
description: Merchants on Fifth and Madison Avenues won a round yesterday in their battle to prevent the city from creating 13block pedestrian mall on Madison Avenue.

title: Plan to Cut Aged's Medicare Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, March 5Alice Brophy, director of the New York City Office on Aging, asked a Senate subcommittee today to reject the Nixon Administration's proposed changes in the Medicare program for the elderly.

title: Parole Is Granted but Then Revoked for a Harlem Six Inmate
description: AUBURN, N.Y.After serving eight and a half years in various New York prisons, one of the original Harlem Six has been granted parole, only to have it revoked.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: U.S. Indicts 2 Process Servers

title: MODEL CITIES AID IS ALLOCATED HERE
description: The Nixon Adminstration announced yesterday that New York City would receive more than $45million in new funds to keep the local Model Cities program going through June 30, 1974.

title: Canadian Pipeline Study
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)  Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that 40 members of Congress had joined him in urging President Nixon to begin environmental studies of a Canadian oil pipeline as an alternative to the Alaska route.

title: CONGRESS WARNS 2 SPORTS GROUPS
description: WASHINGTON, March 5Congress urged the National Collegiate Athletic Association and Amateur Athletic Union today to resolve their differences over an impending American tour by the Soviet national basketball team or face legislation on the administration of amateur athletics.

title: Walter W. Hess Jr. Weds Mrs. Straus
description: Mrs. Barbara Straus and Walter W. Hess Jr., both of New York, were married Friday in PortauPrince, Haiti. Mr. Hess is a partner in L. F. Rothschild & Co., investment banking firm.

title: Mothers Fear End of DayCare Aid
description: They make a happy couple, the Mother and daughter, riding the subway each morning down' from the Bronx.

title: HIGH COURT UPSETS A CITY ANNEXATION
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 The Supreme Court ruled today that the City of Petersburg, Va., cannot annex property that shifts its population majority from black to white without changing the way it elects its local government.

title: Federal Controls Urged For Methaqualone Drugs
description: The chief of the Government's antidrug forces has recommended that a group of drugs including Sopor and Quaalude be placed under Federal controls as being dangerous to users.

title: Consumer Installment Credit Reached High During January
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 Manufacturers' inventories rose again in January, but less than in most recent months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Badillo Urged by Abrams To Give Up Mayoral Race
description: Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams, a leading supporter of Representative Herman Badillo, yesterday called on Mr. Badillo to drop out of the mayoral race so that liberal Democrats could unite behind Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal.

title: A.&P. LAUDS COURT FOR BLOCKING G.&W.
description: A United States District Court, by issuing an order blocking a tender offer by Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., for 3.75 million shares of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, exercised commendable diligence and judicious restraint in protecting the public interest, attorneys for A. & P. argued in a brief filed yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor,

title: ExReporter Named to Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)  Joseph A. Loftus, a former reporter for The New York Times and The Associated Press, today was named acting special assistant for public affairs by Secretary of the Treasury George P. Stultz.

title: U.S. Dollar Strengthens In MajorCurrency Float
description: World currency markets functioned well in private trading yesterday as the governments of the major industrial nations with official dealings in foreign exchange closed  left their currencies free to find their own levels in the markets.

title: American Military Men Shop at Hanoi's Airport
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 5 (Agence FrancePresse)Gia Lam Airport today experienced an unusual occurrence as American military personnel bought souvenirs in the arrivaldeparture hall while waiting to pick up prisoners of war who were being released.

title: RAIDERS, COUGARS PLAY TO 44 DRAW
description: The New York Raiders made up a 40 deficit last night to tie the Chicago Cougars, 44, with a theatrical flourish in a World Hockey Association game at Madison Square Garden.

title: High Court Affirms El Paso Divestiture; 15Year Fight Ends
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The Supreme Court approved today a plan under which the El Paso Natural Gas Company must divest itself of $290million worth of energy resources, property and pipelines to form a new utility in the Pacific Northwest.

title: BOWLER STROLLS ON MEMORY LANE
description: When Harry Smith was in his prime as a professional bowler, he would call his wife JoAnn and say Honey, I didn't make the cut, and she would say you're kidding.

title: Tragments Found in Italy Are Linked to Euphronios
description: ROME, March 5Italian police said today they had found and seized fragments of pottery attributed to Euphronios, the Greek painter of the $1million vase now in the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, in the home of a bootleg excavator near here. The vase has been the subject of investigation on the part of Italian authorities and the F.B.I. on the ground that it may have been smuggled out of Italy.

title: KHE SANH AIRSTRIP IS REPORTED IN USE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 5  Highly placed American officials said today that North Vietnamese troops had hurriedly rebuilt the old United States Marine airstrip at Khe Sanh and begun using it for courier flights into South Vietnam in violation of the Paris ceasefire agreement.

title: SUDAN IS PLANNING TO TRY GUERRILLAS FOR CAPITAL CRIME
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 5 The Sudanese Foreign Minister said today that the Black September commandos who killed two American diplomats and a Belgian here last Friday would have an early trial on murder charges.

title: DEFENSE AIDES FIRM ON GRUMMAN PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, March 5Two top defense officials, in separate forums, took seemingly unyielding positions today on the Administration's refusal to grant price increases to the Grumman Aerospace Corporation for production of the F14 jet fighter.

title: Pope, at Installation of Cardinals, Details Possible Reforms in Electing Successors
description: ROME, March 5Pope Paul VI today described reforms he was considering for the papal election system.

title: SAIGON TO LET PRESS TALK TO COMMUNISTS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 5 (Reuters)The South Vietnamese Government announced today that it would allow foreign newspapermen weekly access to North Vietnamese and Vietcong delegates to the FourParty Joint Military Commission at their closely guarded compound on Tan Son Nhut air base.

title: Continuing AvantGarde Music Includes a SellParodying Work
description: One could hardly accuse the program sponsored Sunday night by the League of ComposersInternational Society for Contemporary Music and the Carnegie Hall Corporation of unseemly frivolity, even if the one first performance did have an element of donnish wit about it. Otherwise the bill of fare, presented at Carnegie Recital Hall as part of the oddly named Continuing AvantGarde series, stuck soberly to earnest academicism.

title: Coins to Get New Look For 1976 Celebration
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)  The United States Mint proposes to put revolutionary designs on the dollar and halfdollar coins to honor the 200th anniversary of independence in 1976, the mint director, Mary Brooks, announced today.

title: New Archbishop of Washington William Wakefield Baum
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The new Roman Catholic Archbishop of Washington is returning to the city where he began to make his mark in 1964. In that year. William Wakefield Baum became the first director of a committee set up by the bishops of the United States on ecumental and in terreligious affairs. He has never lost interest in achieving closer relations with other religions.

title: U.S.S. Midway Returns
description: ALAMEDA, Calif., March 5 (APThe attack carrier U.S.S. Midway sailed under the Golden Gate Bridge Saturday to end an 11month Vietnam tour.

title: Absolute Immunity for Newsmen Urged by Three at House Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 The President of the America Newspaper Publishers Association, the managing editor of The New York Times and president of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association strongly recommended to day a Federal law to grant newsmen absolute privilege tO refuse to disclose confidential sources and unpublished, information in judicial proceedings.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Natienal Steei and Shipbuilding: Company has been awarded a contract to build four 85,000 deadweight ton tankers for Third Group, Inc., of Lake Success, N. Y. The total purchase price will be $112.8million. Delivery is scheduled to lake place from December, 1975 through December, 1976.

title: THALER CONVICTION UPHELD ON APPEAL
description: The conviction of former State Senator Seymour R. Thaler on charges that he had Sold $250,000 worth of stolen securities was affirmed here yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: BIG BOARD POSTS MODEST ADVANCE
description: The stock market eked out a modest gain yesterday in slow trading as Wall Street awaited developments from the international monetary front.

title: Judge Halts Deep Throat
description: CLEVELAND, March 5 (UPI) A judge in Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court ruled today that the movie Deep Throat was obscene and issued a temporary restraining order against its showing. Judge George White viewed the film in private this afternoon before making his decision. He said that he would rule in five days on whether to make the restraining order permanent.

title: Notes on People
description: Mrs. Roberto Clemente filed a $5million negligence suit in connection with the plane crash off Puerto Rico on Dec. 31 that killed her husband, a star baseball player for the Pittsburgh Pirates. Mrs. Clemente and her three sons charged negli gence against the McDonnelDouglass Corporation, which made the plane, a DC7, and the CurtissWright Corpora tion, which made the plane's engines. The suit was filed in United States District Court, Manhattan.

title: C.I.A. Will Curb TrainingIt Provides Police Forces
description: The new director of Central Intelligence has informed Congress that the agency has decided to curb the training it been providing local police departments in the United States.

title: Publisher Is 100 Years Old
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 5 (AP)It was work as usual for E. K. Gaylord, editor and publisher of The Daily Oklahoman and the Oklahoma City Times, who observed his 100th birthday today. He addressed a joint session of the Oklahoma Legislature after company executives joined him in a special luncheon marking his birthday.

title: JUDGE RULES OUT MALL ON MADISON
description: Merchants on Fifth and Madison Avenues won a round Yesterday in their battle to prevent the city from creating a 13block pedestrian mall on Madison Avenue.

title: 6,000 Have Been Indicted For Draft Law Violations
description: WASHINGTON, March.5 (AP) With the draft halted for the first time since 1947, something under 6,000 young men are under indictment for draft law violations, a Selective Service reports.

title: State High Court Weighs Attacks by Poor on Zoning
description: TRENTON, March 5Two cases considered landmarks in efforts to open up middleclass and upperclass suburbs to the poor went before the State Supreme Court today.

title: BLOSSOM DEARIE AT HOME IN SONG
description: There is nothing quite like Blossom Dearie. She is blonde, saucy faced, an excellent musician and a singer with a gentle, intimate, slightly breathless voice that is, nonetheless, firm and precise and beautifully articulate. She is also the possessor of a remarkable repertory of delightful songs that are, for the most part, decidedly off the path traveled by most of her contemporaries.

title: High Court Affirms El Paso Divestiture; 15Year Fight Ends
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The Supreme Court approved today a plan under which the El Paso Natural Gas Company must divest itself of $290million worth of energy resources, property and pipelines to form a new utility in the Pacific Northwest.

title: EXPERT DESCRIBES LUNAR CATACLYSM
description: HOUSTON, March 5  The fourth of the annual lunar science conferences, catchbasins for the flood of data from the Apollo moon landings and launching pads for theories of cosmic range, opened here today with a discussion of a new scenario of the moon's turbujent past and somnolent present.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., March 5It's been four days now since Paul Lape of Seton Hall set a Madison Square Garden record for most assists in a college basketball game and no one has called him Big P or Paul The Dream or Dollar Paul or Mr. Assists. Actually, Lape just wants to be called Paul Lape.

title: Lunch Bill Gaining
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)  Legislation to require the Agriculture Department to make full use of funds appropriated for the School Lunch Act for the fiscal year ending June 30 was passed today by the House. The rollcall vote that sent the measure to the Senate was 352 to 7.

title: BARAKA AT SITE; WORKERS AREN'T
description: NEWARK, March 5Imamu Amiri Baraka, the black nationalist, visited the site of the embattled Kawaida Towers housing project today in a show of support for construction of the 16story highrise project.

title: KILLINGS SHARPEN ARAB DIFFERENCES
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 5The slaying of two American diplomats in Khartoum by Palestinian Black September guerrillas has sharpened antagonisms between Arab moderates and radicals.

title: Jersey Voids Part of Law On Desecration of Flag
description: TRENTON, March 5  The New Jersey Supreme Court struck down a key section of the flag desecration law as unconstitutional today, overturning the conviction of a young ice cream vender who celebrated the Fourth of July holiday three years ago by placing peace symbols on American flags displayed on his truck.

title: HANOI TO BOYCOTT TALK IN DISPUTE EVER ITS P.O.W.'S
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 6A North Vietnamese official said yesterday that the Communists would boycott further meetings of the FourParty Joint Military Commission because of a dispute over the exchange of Vietnamese war prisoners.

title: Prices on Amex and OTC Rise As Turnover Slows Markedly
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market finished higher yesterday in much slower trading.

title: Marathon Big Stride For Women
description: America's bestknown female marathoner made a strong pitch for longdistance equality yesterday during the weekly track writers' luncheon at Leone's.

title: GAY PIEIRE, $20, AQUEDUCT VICTOR
description: Gay Pierre ran in front al the way in the $10,000 feature at Aqueduct yesterday to take the sixfurlong allowance race by two lengths from Sai Through. The most dramatic moment came just after the finish when Jorge Velasquez riding Sail Through, fell from his mount.

title: LITTON CONTRACT STIRS G.A.O. DOUBT
description: New doubts about the ability of Litton Industries to mee?? agreed prices and delivery dates in its 30ship: destroyer contract have been raised by the General Accounting Office.

title: Legion Rebuts Nader
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI) The American Legion disputed today Ralph Nader's charge that Vietnam veterans were being shortchanged because the Veterans Administration is overwhelmingly oriented to the problems of older veterans who dominate the veterans' lobby. In a statement, its National Commander, Joe L. Matthews, said that among its membership of 23 million, there were 450,000 Vietnam veterans and that the legion was totally committed to reevaluating and improving veterans' benefits to keep pace with changing conditions.

title: Last Third of February and Full Month Bear Out Expectations
description: DETROIT, March 5Sales of both domestic and foreignbuilt new cars were at record levels in February.

title: I Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: 34 MORE CAPTIVES ARRIVE AT CLARK
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, March 5When I was told on the airplane that I might make a short speech, the first thing I thought of was to add up the years of captivity that the men in this group had served. I stopped counting at 150. It's over that 150 years for 34 people is a long time. But there is no sorrow in this group today. Note whatsoever. I think right now that this is the happiest group of men in the United States or anywhere else in the world.

title: Advertising: Has a Bubble Burst?
description: The brand management system, started 46 years ago by Procter & Gamble and now used by many multiproduct companies, could be at the heart of many of the advertising industry's current problems.

title: Nixon's Presidency: Centralized Control
description: WASHINGTON, March 5Frederic V. Malek is a 36yearold selfmade millionaire with boyish blue eyes, degrees from West Point and Harvard Business School and a reputation for being a super manager and an effective but restrained hatchet man in the jungles of Washington bureaucracy.

title: Helstoski Will Forgo Bid for Governorship
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)Representative Henry Helstoski announced today he would not seek the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

title: Legislator's Brother Killed As 2 Fellow Policemen Err
description: Patrolman Irving E. Wright, a brother of Assemblyman Samuel D. Wright of Brooklyn, was shot and killed by two patrolmen in Harlem early yesterday morning. He was chasing an armed man who had just held up an allnight grocery store where Patrolman Wright was moonlighting.

title: Production of Steel Shows an Increase Of 0.4% for Week
description: Steel production for the week ended March 3 continued its upward trend and totaled 2,919,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was 0.4 per cent higher than the 2,908,000 tons poured a week earlier and was the second highest tonnage since the week ended May 15, 1971 when 2,927,000 tons were produced.

title: People in Sports: An Old Goalie
description: Jacques Plante, playing his 17th National Hockey League season, received a deafening ovation in Boston Garden on Sunday after being traded to the Bruins from the Toronto Maple Leafs. He responded by shutting out the Chicago Black Hawks, 40.

title: The Disappearing Crisis
description: President Nixons series of messages on the State of the Union is turning into a prolonged flight of fantasy. Having proclaimed in a previous installment that environmental problems are well in hand, Mr. Nixon announced on Sunday that his Administration has caused the urban crisis to disappear.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Now that men are cutting their hair, shearing their beards and wearing buttondown collars, it's no time to show wild and woolly designs for them. Carlo Palazzi, whose shop on the Via Borgognona in Rome is an international gathering place for men interested in clothes, is certainly not about to buck the trend.

title: Vera Panova, Soviet Author Of War Novel, The Train
description: MOSCOW, March 5Vera Panova, a popular Soviet author, died yesterday in Leningrad. She was 67 years old.

title: Allende Shows Strength in Election but Stalemate in Chile Remains
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March The Marxist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens showed surprising strength in Sunday's legislative elections and increased its representation in both the Senate and the Chamber of Deputies.

title: State to Be Asked For Rent Controls In Nassau County
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 5State legislation to empower Nassau County's 64 villages, three towns and two cities to establish rent controls on a localoption basis will be introduced in the Legislature tomorrow, County Executive Ralph G. Caso said today.

title: New LowPrice Color TV Is Introduced by RCA Corp.
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday the lowestpriced solid state color television receiver in its history. The new set will be in the company's XL100 line and will be priced at $379.95 for a 15inch model.

title: Chess: What Hath Larsen Wrought? His Monster Is on the Loose!
description: Little did Bent Larsen know, five years, ago when he let Larsen's Opening loose on the chess world, what a Frankensteinian monster it would become.

title: SCRIBNBR THAIS GET ETHNIC DATA
description: Acting without notice and on orders from School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner, teams of school officials moved suddenly into a Queens school district yesterday to conduct an ethnic census of the staff that local authorities, had refused to make.

title: 10 More Berths Filled for N.I.T.
description: The National Invitation Tournament, with an eye toward increasing attendance in the early rounds, placed a heavy emphasis on local basketball teams and selected Manhattan, Rutgers and Fairfield yesterday.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: Plan to Cut Auto travel in Los Angeles Basin Scored at Hearing
description: LOS ANGELES, March 5A Federal proposal to reduce auto travel in the Los Angeles Basin by 82 per cent was roundly criticized today as the Enviromnental Protection Agency opened hearings on ways the area might meet the Federal air quality standards.
