description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) Secretary of State William P. Rogers told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today that he was confident, peace could be maintained in Vietnam, but he said that prospects for a political settlement were questionable.

title: N.B.C. RESHUFFLES ITS NEWS DIVISION
description: A reorganization of the news division of the National Broadcasting Company, involving new appointments for five top executives, was announced yesterday by Richard C. Wald, President of N.B.C. News.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Transposing the old advice to Go West, young man, 24yearold Michael Wren, assistant basketball coach at Fairleigh Dickinson, left a productive college career to come East to find his fortune.

title: Canadiens Thwart Islanders' Rally, 3 to 2
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 6 The score read Montreat 3, the Islanders 2 tonight, Another New York defeattheir 54th, setting a National Hockey League record.

title: LEROY R. KINNEY
description: LeRoy R. Kinney, for many years an executive of G. R. Kinney Company, Inc., shoe manufacturer, died Friday at his country home in Saranac Lake, N. Y. He was 71 years old and lived also at 305 East 40th Street.

title: U.S. MAY RESIST DOLLAR DEFENSE
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Paul A. Volcker, Under Secretary of the Treasury for monetary affairs, indicated to Congress today that the United States would resist possible European demands later this week that the United States start defending the exchange rate of the dollar by intervening in foreign currency markets.

title: SENATE VOTES BILLS ON AID TO VETERANS
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) The Senate passed today three bills increasing benefits for veterans by $1.2billion. The bills go to the House.

title: U.S. Arts Unit Budgets for 1976 Fete
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Nancy Hanks, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, told a Congressional committee today that the endowment expects to approve nearly $30million of its budget for next year for projects connected with the nation's bicentennial celebration in 1976.

title: Nixon Fills a Trade Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)  Anthony Jurich was named today by President Nixon as chairman of a textile trade policy working group of the Council of International Economic Policy. Mr. Jurich succeeds David M. Kennedy. As senior adviser to Mr. Kennedy, the White House said, he conducted textile negotiations with Japan, Taiwan, Korea, Hong Kong and Portugal.

title: Advertising: TV Deals With V.D.
description: By this time everyone in the New York metropolitan area with normal TVviewing habits has seen the spot that opens with a pretty young woman answering the phone with, Oh, hi Larry. Something wrong? You think what? V.D.!

title: Waldheim Denies Being Slighted in Paris
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Match 6  Secretary General Waldheim denied today that he had in any way felt slighted by what had been characterized in Paris as his shabby treatment at the Vietnam peace conference.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE AUTOGRAPH HOUND. By John Lahr. 239 pages. Knopf. $6.95.

title: Come April 1, Postmen Can Wear Street Shorts
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)  The Postal Service authorized walking shorts today as part of the official uniform after April 1. It said the shorts were optional but would be available to all 250,000 letter carriers and others who meet the public. The shorts must be worn with black kneelength hose. The postman also can leave off his heavy cap if he wishes.

title: MS WILL MISS METS' FIRST TEST
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6  Yogi Berra made out his first lineup card of 1973 today and it did not include Willie Mays, who reported to the New York Mets' training camp this morning with his first swollen knee of 1973.

title: Nixon's Presidency: A Nation Is Changed
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 For four years, Nixon Administration officials traveled the nation telling audiences that the Federal Government, over which they were presiding, was flawed in many ways as a means of delivering services to the public.

title: MRS. MAX KAYNARD
description: Mrs. Rebecca Kaynard, the mother of Samuel L. Kaynard, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board for Brooklyn, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 84 years old and lived in Stuyvesant Town. Mrs. Kaynard was the widow of Max, Kaynard.

title: Notes on People
description: Most people get to go to a psychiatrist, said Jerry Wilson, the District of Columbia Police Chief. I get to go to the President. Mr. Wilson was invited to a White House chat with President Nixon after word had spread in Washington that the Chief was thinking of changing jobs.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TRIPLE PLAY Even if you get to the wrong floor you should find something doing tonight at 8 in New York University's Loeb Student Center, La Guardia Place and Washington Square South, where three events are unfolding at that time. On the fifth, in the Top of the Park, Gwendolyn Brooks, the black poet who was recognized by the outside world even before there was general appreciation of the new black poetry, reads her poetry in an appearance with Dudley Randall, a poet from Detroit whose Broadside Press publishes black Sets.

title: A DEADLINE GIVEN TO PENN CENTRAL
description: Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia yesterday gave the Penn Central Railroad's trustees until July 2 to file with him either a practicable plan of reorganization for the 20,000mile, system or a proposal for its liquidation.

title: No Balls for Tennis Tourney
description: MANILA, March 6 (UPI)A lack of tennis balls caused an indefinte postponement today of the Philippine national open tennis championships. As a result of a new tariff law, customs officials had levied a 100 per cent tax.

title: Sister M. Philomena Yonker, Headed Dominican College
description: BLAUVELT, N. Y., March 6 Sister M. Philomena Yonker, dean emeritus of Dominican College of Blauvelt, died in Nyack Hospital on Sunday.

title: MUNEQUITA TAKES YACHTING CROWN
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, March 6Bob Derecktor's 54foot sloop Salty Goose capped her Southern Ocean Racing Conference debut with victory in the final Nassau Cup, but large custom yachts such as Goose faded in the spray of production 37footer when the final results were posted today.

title: Ellsberg Witness Asserts Military Falsified Reports
description: LOS ANGELES, March 6A Central Intelligence Agency analyst testified today at the Pentagon, papers trial that he had attended conferences, in Saigon and Hawaii And at the agency, in which the military purposely diminished estimates of enemy strength in Vietnam.

title: 9 Tons of Marijuana Worth $4.6Million Seized in Florida
description: CROSS CITY, Fla., March 6 (AP)  The police unloaded more than nine tons of marijuana valued at $4.6million from a barge grounded on an island sandbar in the Gulf of Mexico today in what United States customs agents described as the largest marijuana haul in the nation's history.

title: A Missionary Heritage
description: Pearl Buck was the daughter of a missionary family and that fact colored her entire life: the books she wrote, the causes she took up, the, audience she sought and ultimately her position as a writer. She was herself a missionary in the fundamental meaning of the word. Less concerned with theological orthodoxy (she resigned from the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions after a controversy), she felt it her duty in life to search out and defend the humanity common to all men: Orientals and Westerners, black Americans and children of mixed blood, the mentally retarded and the powerless. Her humanitarianism took many forms and some commentators felt that the energy and resources she put into these projects should have gone into the writing of her books, which became, after she won the Nobel prize in 1938, facile, slack, undistinguished.

title: Lon Nol Asks Vietnamese Reds To Hold Talks on Troop Pullout
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 6 (Agence FrancePresse) President Lon Nol said today that Cambodia was prepared to hold discussions in Phnom Penh or elsewhere with representatives of the North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces on the withdrawal of foreign troops from Cambodia and the exchange of prisoners.

title: EXDEMOCRATIC AIDE GETS MISTRIAL HERE
description: A Federal Court jury, after five days of deliberation, failed to reached a verdict in the trial of Louis Beck, a former treasurer of the Democratic party in the state, on charges that he had arranged the sale of $500,000 in stolen securities.

title: ROBERT L. CONLY
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Robert L. Conly, a senior assistant editor of National Geographic magazine, died here yesterday of a heart attack. He was 55 years old.

title: ISRAELIS ANNOUNCE PAYMENTS IN CRASH
description: JERUSALEM, March 6The Israeli Government announced today that it would pay $30,000 in compensation to the families of each victim of the Libyan Arab Airlines jetliner shot down by Israeli jet fighters over the Sinai desert nearly two weeks ago.

title: ROSE GETS $117,500; $85,000 FOR POWELL
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 6 (AP)Pete Rose, the Cincinnati Reds' left fielder, ended his sixclay holdout today, agreeing to a contract estimated at $117,500, the Reds said.

title: A DEADLINE GIVEN TO PENN CENTRAL
description: Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia yesterday gave the Penn Central Railroad's trustees until July 2 to file with him either a practicable plan of reorganization for the 20,000mile system or a proposal for its liquidation.

title: Queens Druggist Shot by Police As He Hunts Burglar in Store
description: A Queens druggist, prowling the basement of his store, pistol in hand, after discovering a burglary, was shot in the chest by a patrolman early yesterday after the druggist ignored an order to drop his gun and fired a shot, the police reported.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Says Rocket Sold to Japan Can Be Converted to Military Missile
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 The A.F.L.C.I.O. complained to Congress today that the McDonnell  Douglas Corporation, with Government encouragement, was helping Japan to to produce a rocket that could be converted into a military ballistic missile.

title: World Monetary Game
description: I don't think they play at all fairly... and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can't hear oneself speakand they don't seem to have any rules in particular: at least, if there are nobody attends to themand you've no idea how confusing it is all the things being alive...

title: Garment Union Makes Key TopLevel Changes
description: The Executive Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union made important toplevel changes yesterday that marked the emergence of a younger leadership and appeared to foreshadow the line of succession.

title: Texas Stand on Asia Funds
description: AUSTIN, Tex, March 6 (UPI) The Texas, Senate went on record today as being overwhelmingly opposed to any reconstruction money for North or South Vietnam as long as fighting continues there.

title: U.S. AND HUNGARY AGREE ON CLAMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) The United States and Hungary signed an agreement today to settle claims for wardamaged and nationalized American property in Hungary.

title: 5,000 Elderly People Lobby in Albany
description: ALBANY, March 6  An army of elderly people invaded the Capitol today to lobby with legislators for increased aid to mitigate the effects of recent Federal legislation.

title: Pearl Buck Is Dead at 80; Won Nobel Prize in 1938
description: Pearl S. Buck, the author of more than 85 books and winner of the Nobel and Pulitzer Prizes in literature, died yesterday at her home in Denby, Vt., after a long illness.

title: 5 Ask Slow Change as 5 Back New Areas of Competition
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 A 10member advisory committee to the Securities and Exchange Commission split 5 to 5 today in a report recommending different approaches to creating a single central market system in listed securities.

title: English in Sight of Victory Over Pakistanis in Cricket
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, March 6 (Reuters)  England's cricket team, with a 67run, firstinnings deficit in the first test with Pakistan, closed the fourth day today with 134 for three wickets and a lead of 67.

title: Jersey Legislator Prevents Dismissal Of a Criminal Case
description: ALMONESSON, N.J., March 6Assemblyman Kenneth A. Gewertz, a maverick politician who is gaining a reputation as a foe of crime, has forced the reopening of a criminal case a Cherry Hill judge was about to dismiss.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 7, 1973

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Supreme Court Hearings On Local Rent Laws End
description: TRENTON, March 6The State Supreme Court today ended a twoday hearing on the question of whether local governments in New Jersey have the power to enact their ownrentcontrol laws.

title: Now, the Death Penalty
description: While many people sincerely believe that no penalty can be too severe for the Mr. Bigs who engage international trafficking in hard drugs, Governor Rockefeller's suggestion of the death penalty only underscores previous flaws in his response to the drug problem a whole.

title: Counsel to Nixon attended F.B.I. Watergate Quizzing
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 Acting F.B.I. Director L. Patrick. Gray 3d said today that John W. Dean 3d, a Presidential counsel, had been present when White House employes were interviewed by F.B.I. agents about the Watergate bugging case. He called Mr. Dean's attendance not normal procedure and said that it had occurred against his personal wishes.

title: Writers Guild Strikes Major Producers on Coast; Union Seeks Almost Fourfold Increase in Wages
description: LOS ANGELES, March 6 (AP)The Writers Guild of America went on strike against major television and movie producers on the West and East Coasts at 12:01 A.M. today.

title: Mrs. Kekich Discusses Exchange of Families
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 6  Mrs. Susanne Kekich discovered herself in a spotlight more glaring than the Florida sun today after Fritz Peterson and Mike Kekich, the Yankee pitchers, had disclosed yesterday they had exchanged families last October.

title: M'GRATH LEADER IN OPEN BOWLING
description: Mike McGrath, a lanky lefthander from El Cerrito, Calif., completed his first 16 games last night in the United States open bowling tournament with a total of 3,668 pins at Madison Square Garden. He was the leader by 73 pins with only one eightgame qualifying block remaining in the $75,000 event sponsored by the Bowling Proprietors Association of America.

title: Winsor Brown French 2d, 68; Cleveland Press Columnist
description: CLEVELAND, March 6Winsor Brown French 2d, who had been a film critic and a travel columnist for The Cleveland Press from 1933 until his retirement in 1968, died today at his home. He was 68 years old.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Fannie Mae Reports Climb In Yields at Mortgage Sale
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (Reuters)The average yield on fourmonth commitments to purchase governmentbacked 7 per cent mortgages was 7.750 per cent at the Federal National Mortgage Association's free market auction, up from 7.726 per cent in the previous such auction on Feb. 20, the assodation reported today.

title: Jersey Legislator Prevents Dismissal of Criminal Case
description: ALMONESSON, N.J., March 6Assemblyman Kenneth. A. Gewertz, a maverick politician who is gaining a reputation as a foe of crime, has forced the reopening of a criminal case a Cherry Hill judge was about to dismiss.

title: Gibson Playing Games, Imperiale Says On Leaving Stormy Kawaida Meeting
description: NEWARK, March 6A meeting called today by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson to find a solution to the racially explosive Kawaida Towers controversy ended after an, hour with no reportable progress.

title: MRS. RUSHTON SKAKEL
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 6 Mrs. Anne Reynolds Skakel, wife of Rushton W. Skakel, board chairman of the Great Lakes Carbon Corporation of New York and a brother of Mrs. Ethel P. Kennedy, died Sunday after a long illness at Greenwich Hospital. She, was 41 years old.

title: PAUL KLETZKI, 72, CONDUCTOR, DEAD
description: LIVERPOOL, England, March 6Paul Kletzki, the Polishborn conductor, died in a hospital here last night after collapsing during a rehearsal with the Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra for a concert that was to have been played tonight. He was 72 years old.

title: COMMUNISTS INVITE NEWSMEN IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 6 (AP)The Vietcong peacekeeping delegation issued a blanket invitation today for foreign newsmen to meet with Communist officials.

title: Bridge:A New School Hete Offers Classes at All Play Levels
description: New York City has long been firmly established as the bridge capital of North America, with Los Angeles as its only rival. The growth of the game here seems assured, because there is a bountiful supply of young experts, many of whom are not simply players but are willing also to contribute in other ways, as organizers, writers or teachers.

title: Papp's Troupe to Replace Lincoln Repertory
description: Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival, with Mr. Papp as producer and president, will replace the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center. In a major change of artistic policy at the center, Mr. Papp will emphasize the production of new American plays instead of revivals at the Vivian Beaumont Theater and will turn the 299seat Forum Theater into a yearround home for Shakespeare.

title: 1,200 Apartments To Be Cooperatives In Renovotion Plan
description: Forty buildings containing nearly 1,200 apartments throughout the city will be rehabilitated and converted to tenantowned cooperatives as part of a major new publicly assisted housing program announced by Mayor Lindsay yesterday.

title: Business Briefs
description: BankMerger Plan Challenges Law

title: DEFENSE SUMS UP IN EXTORTION CASE
description: CAMDEN, March 6 (AP)Defense lawyers completed their summations today in the Federal extortionconspiracy trial of four present and former Atlantic City officials.

title: To the Workers
description: Jenkintown, Pa. In bed your faces haunting me. What do you think of tonight?

title: NEWSMEN RECEIVE STAY ON SUBPOENA
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Judge Charles R. Richey of the United States District Court here gave attorneys for 10 jouralists today until next Tuesday, to file motions to get subpoenas quashed that have been served on them by President Nixon's campaign organization.

title: Timely Remarks Postponed
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)Representative Bertram L. Podell, Democrat of Brooklyn, took the House floor today to note that this is National Procrastination Week. Because of this, he said, I will put off my remarks on the subject uutil a later time. Then he sat down.

title: SUPPORT DEMAND SEEN FOR DOLLAR
description: PARIS, March 6The nine Common Market countries are expected to make a joint demand that the United States support thedollar in the international financial markets at next Friday's emergency meeting of the major industrial countries' finance ministers in Paris.

title: 2 Robbers Get $32,015, A S.I. Man's Life Savings
description: Two thugs stole an elderly man's life savings$32,015 in cashyesterday after surprising a woman tenant in the Richmond Terrace housing project at 151 Jersey Street, New Brighton, S. I., and forcing her to unlock a neighbor's door.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: 88 Fighters Have a Date With a Dream
description: They wear brown street socks with black boxing shoes. They wear terrycloth bathrobes, the sleeves split so the gloves will go through. They wear undershirts or basketball jersies. They do the All shuffle.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New Haven teachers went on strike yesterday and were quickly served with an injunction. School Board President Stephen Papa said the school administration and substitute teachers were managing well in the strike, conducting classes of sorts for the system's 21,400 pupils, even serving food in the cafeterias. In some schools, however, pupils scattered back onto the streets this morning as soon as they saw they could.

title: Drug Dealer Slain as He Tries To Rob Undercover Patrolman
description: One of two suspected narcotics dealers who tried to rob an undercover patrolman in an East Harlem hallway was killed last night when the patrolman summoned help from backup men in the street.

title: Nation's Cup Scheduled
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) The Washington International horse show will conduct a Nation's Cup competition next fall for the first time, officials said today. In such competition foreign riders and horses compete as teams officially representing their countries.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company yesterday said it was offering holders of its common stock rights to subscribe for 4,072,409 additional shares of common at a subscription price of $25.65 per share on the basis of one new share for each 15 shares held of record yesterday. The offer expires March 27. An underwriting group headed by Blyth Eastman Dillon and Dean Witter will purchase any unsubscribed shares. The company's stock closed at 27, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Brown Tops Rhode Island, Clinching Winning Season
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 6 Brown University's basketball team clinched its first winning season in 13 years by downing the University of Rhode Island, 7159, tonight at the Providence Civic Center. The Bruins' wonlost record is 1411 with one game remaining.

title: French Bargain on Runoff Vote; Centrists May Support Gaullists
description: PARIS, March 6Politicians negotiated frenetically behind scenes today on the deals that, almost as much as the ballots, will decide the final outcome of France's legislative runoff election next Sunday.

title: Insurers Are Warned of Tax Jeopardy in Variable Policies
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 Johnnie M. Walters, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, warned the life insurance industry today that the new variable life insurance policy that it plans to sell could jeopardize some of the special treatment that the industry now receives under Federal tax laws.

title: Black Businessmen Fight Plan to Change U.S. Help
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The Small Business Administration has proposed changes that blacks say would force white investors out of one of the Administration's most successful minority business programs.

title: IN STATE GET AID
description: Federal grants totaling $200, 031,620 for nine sewagetreatment projectsone in Staten Island, one in Brooklyn and seven upstatewere announced yesterday, making possible early starts on the longplanned major plants that will treat by 1979 virtually the last of the city's raw sewage.

title: Court Says I.B.M. Violated Order in Destroying Data
description: A Federal court judge ruled here yesterday that the International Business Machines Corporation had violated a specific court order when it persuaded a competitor, the Control Data Corporation, to destroy a vast quantity of documents it had prepared for an antitrust suit against I.B.M.

title: Stolen Car Halted Alter Chase; Policeman Says He Was Target
description: Two fugitives suspected of a series of robberies drove a stolen car along the Fifth Avenue sidewalk in Harlem for nearly five blocks yesterday afternoon in a wild chase before policemen of the citywide anticrime unit forced them to a halt.

title: 80 FREED P.O.W.'S ON THEIR WAY TO U.S.
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Wednesday March 7 (AP)Tvienty American former prisoners of war took off this morning for the United States.

title: REV. ERWIN JAXHEIMER
description: The Rev. Dr. Erwin R. Jaxheimer, who had been pastor of St. Luke's Lutheran Church in Woodhaven, Queens, for 40 years at his retirement in 1950, died yesterday in Christ Hospital, Jersey City. He was 93 years, old and lived at 8825 215th Place, Queens Village.

title: People and Business
description: George P. Shultz, Secretary of the Treasury, yestary was named chairman of the United States section of the joint United StatesSoviet Union commercial commission and also head of a new EastWest trade policy committee. He replaces the former Secretary of Commerce, Peter G. Peterson, as chairman of the commission. Mr. Peterson is on special assignment for President Nixon.

title: NATIONALS HALT JETS' STREAK, 52
description: OTTAWA, March 6 (UPI)The Ottawa Nationals won their fifth straight World Hockey Association game tonight, defeating the Winnipeg Jets, 52, as Wayne Carleton got two goals.

title: JUDGE DISQUALIFIES VESCO CASE LAWYER
description: A Federal judge yesterday disqualified a lawyer in a proceeding preliminary to the Securities and Exchange Commission's fraud case against financier Robert L. Vesco and 41 others.

title: CELTICS CONQUER BRAVES, 127112
description: BUFFALO, March 6 (AP)Dave Cowens and a substitute guard, Art Williams, led a fourthquarter Boston drive that carried the Celtics to a 127112 National Basketball Association victory over the Buffalo Braves.

title: NARCOTICS CENTER IS RAIDED IN BRONX
description: The headquarters of a $50,000aweek narcotics operation in the Melrose section of the Bronx was raided last night by a team of heavily armed policemen from the Seventh Narcotics District, the police reported.

title: Capitalism, for Better or Worse
description: For a month and a half Joyce remained in the correspondence department. . . . He had to write between two hundred and two hundred and fifty letters a day. . . . The effect was to wear out his trousers. He had two large patches on them, and to conceal these he had to keep on his tailcoat even during the August heat.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: No one would deny the need for order in the world monetary system. However, I doubt whether your call for a true central bank to quell monetary anarchy [editorial Feb. 23] meets the point.

title: PUBLIC TV SEEKS INCREASE IN FUND
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting board of directors voted yesterday to ask Congress for a twoyear authorizatior for increased funding that would total $140million in 1974 and 1975.

title: Review 1  No Title
Slither, 'Film of Illogical Events.:The Cast:
description: One week after he has been let out of prison after serving two years for car theft, Dick Kanipsia (James Caan) is ready to go back in. Clearly prison is sanity's sanctuary. The straight world has been occupied by lunatics.First off, there is the assassination attempt when persons unknown storm the farmhouse where Dick is visiting a former prison mate. Dick, an aging athlete, has the sweet, uncomplaining resilience of the none-too-bright but things like that worry him. So, too, does the kindly truck driver who gives him a ride and then, for no apparent reason, threatens to break his arm.The most ba???fling creature??? however, is Kitty Kopetsky (Sally Kellerman), who offers to give him a lift to the beach and proceeds, among other things, to hold up a lunch counter. Kitty, a pill-popper, confides: "There's this battle going on inside me. The forces of evil against the forces of light." She pauses, then adds with a beatific smile: "I'll swing with the winner."All of this is just the beginning of "Slither," a comedy-melodrama about America going to the madhouse in mobile homes, or specifically, about a cross-country trailer chase by Dick, Kitty, and Mr. and Mrs. Henry Fenaka (Peter Boyle and Louise Lasser) to locate what someone describes as "wealth beyond your wildest dreams." Actually it's $312,000 (which is not quite beyond my wild-were embezzled seven years earlier by Barry Fenaka and Dick's now-dead prison friend.For almost three-quarters of the way (which is about one-quarter of the way furest dreams) in funds that the???r than most films of this sort), "Slither" is as funny and bizarre as it means to be. A sort of wet-blanket of reason eventually is thrown over the narrative when W. D. Richter, who wrote the original screenplay, feels compelled to supply explanations for a lot of the perfectly illogical events we've accepted earlier. Until then, "Slither" is a most entertaining, thoroughly anarchic morality play about an innocent who wakes up to find that his land has been taken over by greedy but mostly ineffectual body-snatchers.Because few American comedies are ever bothered by such visions, I may have enjoyed???"Slither" somewhat more than is warranted by the bright but inconsistent material. The movie is the first directorial effort of Howard Zieff, who is credited as the man who thought up those comic Benson ??? Hedges TV commercials, which, one might think, would be no guarantee that he could make a feature film as good as this one. As short as they are, however, commercials do depend on a sense of timing and casting, both of which are obvious here.Miss Kellerman, Mr. Boyle and Miss Lasser do the sort of thing they've done before, though better, but Mr. Caan ("The Godfather"), one of our best young leading actors, is a real surprise as the Candide-like ex-con. He is funny and dim without ever being dumb, which, for most actors, is as difficult as playing Lear."Slither" opened yesterday at the Coronet Theater.

title: Theater: Shepard's Tooth of Crime
description: Sam Shepard's new play, The Tooth of Crime, given last night at the Performing Garage on Wooster Street by the Performance Group, confirms all of the playwright's promise and establishes him as a major theater figure. The play had its American premiere last November at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N. J. That production, far more conventional than this New York premiere, was for various reasons preferable. But first something about the play.

title: Pakistan and England Drawl In First Cricket Test Match
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, March 7 (Reuters)Pakistan and England drew the first cricket test today.

title: A Math Instructor's Duties Multiply
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 7 Tray Patterson of Garden City, L.I., entered Room 113 in North Hall at Nassau Community College today and greeted his mathematics teacher with, You're doing very well, Mr. Bruns.

title: MRS. CARLTON HAYES
description: Mrs. Evelyn Carroll Hayes, widow of Carlton J. H. Hayes, who was Seth Low Professor of History, at Columbia University and Ambassador to Spain, died yesterday at her home, 88 Mornmgside Drive. She was 83 years old.

title: Members of Black Army Sought In Bronx StreetbyStreet Hunt
description: Policemen and Federal agents were looking yesterday for members of the Black Liberation Army or accomplices who are suspected of having been involved in two shootouts Tuesday with the police in the Morrisania section of the Bronx.

title: Horde of Ghost Refugees Get U.S. Food in Vietnam
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, March 7Many tens of thousands of nonexistent refugees from Quang Tri Province are being fed at American expense. American and Vietnamese officials close to the problem agree that cheating and corruption at all levels of involvement  from refugees getting an extra pound or two of rice a day to high Government officials in the upper reaches of a kickback pyramid exceed previous, experience, however rich.

title: NoNonsense Woman Steward Runs a Tight Dog Show Ring
description: Mrs. Edith Nash Hellerman his been active in the dog show world for nearly four decades. Although best known as a judge, she's been a successful breeder and ex hibitor, a charter members of the Kennel Club of North ern New Jersey end a leader in stevsrarding. Now living, in Severn, Md., she has a reputation for running a tight ring. My name's Hellerman, she said, and the accent's on the first syllable when I'm judging. I have no sympathy for the steward who complains after working for an hour or two. We each have a job to do. I tell them, to get the dogs into the ring and I'll get them out.

title: MISS EVERT ROUTS CINDY BRINKER, 15
description: DALLAS, March 7 (UPI)Chris Evert ruined the bigtime tennis debut of Cindy Brinker today.

title: EXTORTION CASE GOES TO JURORS
description: CAMDEN, N. J., March 7 (AP)A jury began today to deliberate the Federal extortionconspiracy case against four present and former Atlantic City officials.

title: Mutilated Body of Boy, 10, Is Found on the West Side
description: A 10yearold boy was found dead yesterday in the basement areaway of a West Side apartment building. He had multiple stab wounds of the neck and chest and had been sexually mutilated, the police said.

title: Equity Financing
description: An offering of 206,250 common shares of Daniel Woodhead, Inc., producers of electrical spedeities for industrial use, at $23.75 per share was reported sold out yesterday by underwriters headed by Blunt Ellis & Simmons Inc., Chicago.

title: TUTSI ARE LOSING JOBS IN RWANDA
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, March 7 Many commercial and industrial undertakings in the East African nation of Rwanda are reported to be at a virtual standstill after an exodus of Tutsi employes, who were forced out of their jobs by gangs of militant Hutu tribesmen.

title: Study Calls Nixon Budget A Disaster for the Poor
description: Extensive analyses that depicted President Nixon's new budget policies as confronting the city with harmful effects on most, people and a disastrous impact on the poor were made public yesterday by the Community Council of Greater New York.

title: NEW BUFFALO MAYOR SEEKS RENAISSANCE
description: BUFFALO, March 7 (AP)In his first address since being sworn in, Buffalo's new Mayor said he hoped his inauguration day would be marked in history as the beginning of our renaissance  the day Buffalo started to become the finest city in the world.

title: New Role Leaves Bing Speechless
description: Sir Rudolf Bing, former general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, signed yesterday for a leading role in the New York City Opera Company production of Hans Werner Henze's The Young Lord. Sir Rudolf will play Sir Edgar, a role that is entirely mimed but pivotal to the plot.

title: Options Dealer Signs a Consent Decree
description: BALTIMORE, March 7 (AP) The First Federated Commodity Trust Corporation, which reportedly earned over $20million in paper profits for investors in less than six months, signed a consent decree today, agreeing to halt certain business practices.

title: Indians Given Till Tonight To Leave Wounded Knee
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S.D., March 7  The Federal Government issued an ultimatum today to the Indians holding this settlement, telling them to move out by nightfall tomorrow.

title: Station House Wanted Posters Seek WellGroomed Policemen
description: A new kind of Wanted poster will be posted in all New York City police statons, according to a directive issued yesterday by the Police Department. The Wanted, however, are not gangsters; they are 30,000 New York City policemen.

title: Notes on People
description: President Nixon is exOcted to designate his Counselor, Anne Armstrong, to supervise the Cabinet Committee for Opportunities for Spanish  speaking Citizens. Mrs. Armstrong, the only woman Counselor in the White House, holds CabinetMember status in the Administration, except that she is not in the lines of succession to the Presidency. Her office Confirmed that she would sassume the Spanishspeaking citizens' job, but did not specify what it entailed.

title: Jane Fonda Boycott Urged
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 7 (UPI)  A resolution was submitted to the Maryland General Assembly yesterday, declaring Jane Fonda, the actress, persona non grata because of her antiwar sentiments and calling or a boycott of her movies. There were no objections.

title: Air Travelers Take Checks for Granted
description: WARSAW, March 7If that's a camera, the security agent said at Lydda Airport, in Israel, take a picture with it. The passenger smiled.

title: 8,368 of 9,736 Students Absent On 5th Day of Canarsie Boycott
description: A boycott of schools by white parents in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn went into its fifth day yesterday, with 8,368 of the area's 9,736 elementary and juniorhigh school pupils staying out of classes.

title: EAST GERMANS RULE ON FOREIGN NEWSMEN
description: BONN, March 7East Germany has issued a detailed decree defining the activities of foreign correspondents and requiring them to obtain permission through its foreign Ministry for almost all visits and interviews.

title: New jersey Sports
description: NUTLEY, N. J., March 7When a man spends 80 hours a, week training harness horses, he has little more than a nodding acquaintance with his family.

title: Marshall and Expos Agree
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 7 (AP)The righthanded relief pitcher, Mike Marshall, has agreed in substance to terms or his 1973 contract with the Montreal Expos and is flying to camp to sign his contract. General Manager Jim Fanning said he would meet with Marshall tomorrow and added, I think Mike will be in uniform before the end of the day.

title: Meany Offers Tax Reform Plan Asking Levy on Excess Profits
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, offered Congress a $29billion tax reform package today. He said he was saddened by reformers' estimates that they lacked the votes to make sweeping changes.

title: I.C.C. Reduces Free Time Allowed on Freight Cars
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI)  The Interstate Commerce Commission moved today to ease a critical shortage of freight cars by cutting the time shippers are allowed to keep the cars free of charge.

title: Pirates' New Right Fielder Runs Into Some Problems
description: BRADENTON, Fla., March 7 (UPI)  The Detroit Tigers jumped on Pittsburgh's Bob Johnson for four runs in the second inning, including a home run by Jim Northrup, and coasted to an 8.3 exhibition victory over the Pirates.

title: AQUEDUCT'S FARE IS FIT FOR A KING
2 Bombs Defused
description: Two apparent bombing attempts, one at an El Al Israel Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport and the other at an Israeli bank on Fifth Avenue have been thwarted by the police. Details on Page 6.

title: CARMEN ROLE SUNG BY MARILYN HORNE
description: The Henry Lewis family did very well Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera when the openingnight Carmen was brought back for a series of spring performances after a rest of a few months.

title: HOUSE RESTRICTS SECRET MEETINGS OF ITS OWN PANELS
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Heeding the pleas of reformers, the House voted today, 370 to 27, to place strict limits on secrecy within its own committees.

title: Bridge: Bayonne Player Places 10th In McKenney Trophy Tilt
description: The standings in the McKenney Trophy for 1972, recently published by the American Contract Bridge League, show as usual that players in the Southwest are the prolific collectors of master points. The winner with 1,387, the fourthhighest ever, was a Dallas physician, Dr. John Fisher, with Californians taking the next four places.

title: ARMY IS DEFENDED ON ITS TROOP DATA
description: LOS ANGELES, March 7The Government attempted today at the Pentagon papers trial to shore up the accuracy of the Army's estimates of enemy troop strength in Vietnam end at the same time to discredit a Central Intelligence Agency analyst who challenged those estimates.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES CLIMB TO RECORD
description: Soybeans for delivery this Month soared to a record $7 a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Last summer soybeans sold at about $3.25 a bushel.

title: Surprising Penn Makes Hockey Bid For E.C.A.C. Title
description: As if Penn has not been causing enough trouble by winning the Ivy League basketball title year after year and improving its football to the point of challenging for the Ivy championship, it has been putting life into its hockey team. This paid off with a major upset Tuesday night when the Quakers beat, Boston University, 7 3, in the opening round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference hockey playoffs.

title: U.S.SOVIET TALKS ON ARMS TO RESUME
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI)  President Nixon said today that talks with the Soviet Union on strategics arms would resume in Geneva on Monday with the United States delegation headed by U. Alexis Johnson.

title: Seminar Finds Wide Gulf Separates Police and MinorityGroup Citizens
description: Police attitudes are going to have to change a lot before there is a better relationship between blacks and Puerto Ricans and minority police. The community has been stepped on too long and, the police are going to have to show something positive.

title: Saigon and Communists Begin 2d Phase of Prisoner Exchange
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 8The South Vietnamese and the Communists began their second round, of prisoner exchanges this morning near the ruins of Quang Tri city after a bitter dispute that disrupted the work of the FourParty Joint Military Commission.

title: Bitter Racial Dispute Divides Gosvenor House
description: The dismissal of Grosvenor Neighborhood House's first black program director last summer has triggered a bitter and continuing dispute for control of the Upper West Side center.

title: Bus and Truck Collide in Texas; At Least 15 Are Reported Dead
description: FORT STOCKTON, Tex., 7 (AP)  At least 15 persons were killed tonight when a passenger bus and a truck collided headon at a narrow bridge east of here, the Texas Department of Public Safety said.

title: Dozing Man Seized In a Stolen Vehicle With Gun and Pills
description: Two policemen opened a front door of a car yesterday to see whether the man sprawled on the front seat was dead or asleep.

title: New C.A.B. Inquiry on TransAtlantic Fares Begun
description: Asserting that illegal fare rebating in the bitterly competitive transAtlantic airfare marketplace had resumed after a lull, the Chat Aeronautics Board said yesterday that it had opened a new investigation at Kennedy International Airport.

title: 3 City Aides, Including Levy, Indicted In the Nadjari Inquiry on Ticket Fixing
description: The president of the City Tax Commission and two other city officials have been indicted on charges of fixing more than 1,000 parking tickets, and Mayor Lindsay and his staff have been accused of attempting to cover up the alleged scheme.

title: Carbon Petroleum Seen by Analysts as Having Only Small Effect
description: The stick in the closet of mandatory price controls on petroleum products brought out Monday by the Nixon Administration is not expected to have much clout.

title: Reporter Found Guilty Of Bribing Policeman
description: NEWARK, March 7Ron Porambo, a reporter for Channel 13, was convicted this afternoon in Essex County Criminal Court of the bribery of a Newark policeman.

title: Bangladesh Chief Winning by Big Edge
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Thursday, March 8Sheik Mujibur Rahman, who led Bangladesh to independence, won a big personal victory last night in the nation's first general election.

title: Richard L. White, 74, Led Hardware Manufacturers
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., March 7 (AP)Richard L. White, a former president of the American Hardware Manufacturers Association, died Monday at the age of 74.

title: WelfareCurb in Albany, One Reciuiriok InPerson Interview
description: ALBANY, March 7  The Senate passed two bills today to require welfare recipients to show proof of identity in facetoface interviews for certification or recertification and to fill out an 11page application before assistance can be given.

title: MRS. COURT TAKES RIGHT CHALLENGE
description: SAN DIEGO, March 7 (AP) Mrs. Margaret Court has accepted the challenge of Bobby Riggs to determine whether women can play tennis on a level with men, a spokesman for Riggs said today.

title: Hochberg Seeking To Unseat Abrams As Bronx President
description: Charging that Borough President R6bert Abrams was not a spokesman for the mainstream in the Bronx, Assemblyman Alan Hochberg announced yesterday his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the Bronx borough presidency.

title: Cooke Calls for Sacrifices During Lent
description: Cardinal Cooke, Archbishop of New York, urged Roman Catholics in an Ash Wednesday message yesterday to return to traditional fasting and selfsacrifice this Lent as penance for the horror of abortion and the other grave sins of selfishness in our society.

title: DENIAL OF TRAIN JOB TO WOMAN DEFENDED
description: A Long Island Rail Road official said yesterday that a woman who had applied for a job as a trainman or engineer failed to get a job because she did not meet the height requirement and also because she would probably not have had the strength and weight to carry out certain duties.

title: COFFEE REVEALS HIS TOTAL ASSETS.
description: TRENTON, March 7 (AP)Richard J. Coffee, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, reported today that his net worth was $382,532 and called on other candidates to make similar disclosures.

title: Gunman at Alexander's Killed in 5Story Fall
description: A man who reportedly took $475 at gunpoint from a cash register in the record department of Alexander's de partment store on Lexington Avenue at 58th Street last evening died in a fall from a fifthfloor window after security guards had chased him into a stairwell.

title: Voter Drive Set for School Elections
description: The Board of Elections announced yesterday that it would start a special voterregistration drive, using volunteers and special deputy registrars, for the community school board elections scheduled for May 1.

title: Nixon Farm Policy and Its Political Stakes
description: WASHINGTON, March 7A farmer visiting the Department of Agriculture walked into a conference room the other day worriedly looking for his cashmere topcoat, fearful that someone had taken it Mother farmer looked across a table at several companions and remarked: Farmers can't accept prosperity without fear.

title: Adirondacks Can't Wait
description: In response to concern voiced at public hearings, the Adirondack Park Agency has devised its preliminary plan limiting the uses of private lands within the boundaries of that great preserve. The changes, while taking valid criticism into account, do not appear to threaten those environmental protections for which the agency was appointed. For the most part they provide for slightly increased densities in the various categories landsuch as allowing fifteen buildings per square mile rather than ten on these resource management lands which make up more than half the private acreage the park.

title: Mayor Jordan to Disclose Decision on Running Mates
description: JERSEY CITY, March 7On the mantelpiece in Mayor Paul Jordan's secondfloor office in City Hall is a statue of Don Quixote with a sign on its base reading, Our Leader.

title: MISS ZURBRIGGEN WINS CUP SLALON
description: MOUNT ALYESKA, Alaske March 7 (UPI)  Bernadette Zurbriggen of Switzerland skied to victory today as the World Cup leader, Annemarie Proell of Austria, missed gate and fell during the giant slalom.

title: Blue Shield Proposes 5% Cut, But State Hints It's Not Enough
description: TRENTON, March 7  In response to the state's demand for a rate reduction, the MedicalSurgical Plan of New Jersey, known as Blue Shield, today proposed a 5 per cent cut in its premium rates for individual and small group subscribers effective July 1.

title: World Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: MORTGAGE BANKER IN MERGER PACT
description: The Industrial National Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Mortgage Associates, Inc., of Milwaukee.

title: Study Links Respiratory Illness To Use of Gas Stoves in Homes
description: DURHAM, N. C.  Studies made by the Environmentel Protection Agency have yielded preliminary indications that people who live in homes with gas stoves are more susceptible to respiratory ailments than people who use other cooking devices.

title: LAWYER FOR NIXON TOLD R.B.I. HE GAVE FUNDS TO SEGRETT
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 Herbert W. Kalmbach, President Nixon's personal lawyer, told agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation last year that he had paid between $30,000 to $40,000 in Republican party funds to Donald H. Segretti, a 31yearold lawyer who reportedly ran a covert political sabotage operation for the Republican party during last year's Presidential election campaign.

title: DALEY ASSOCIATE DECLARED GUILTY
description: CHICAGO, March 7County Clerk Edward. J. Barrett, a wheelhorse in the Cook County Democratic organization, was found guilty today of bribery, income tax evasion and mail fraud.

title: 6 Sudanese Including 2 Who Worked for Libyan Embassy, Are Charged With Plotting Against Nation
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 7 (Reuters)Six Sudanese, including two men who worked at the Libyan Embassy in Khartoum, have been arrested and are to stand trial on charges of plotting against the state.

title: Useless Ulster Vote
description: It is hard to dispute the characterization by Catholic political leaders of today's referendum in Northern Ireland as dangerous, disruptive and divisive. This useless exercise cannot improve prospects for a viable political solution in the troubled province; the only hope is that it will not wreck whatever chance may now exist for a start toward cooperation and peace between Ulster's sectarian communities.

title: Horde of Ghost Refugees Get U.S. Food in Vietnam
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, March 1Many tens of thousands of nonexistent refugees from Quang Tri Province are being fed at American expense. Amprican and Vietnamese officials close to the problem agree that cheating and corruption at all levels of involvement  from refugees getting an extra pound or two of rice a day to high Government officials in the upper reaches of a kickback pyramid exceed previous, experience, however rich.

title: Women May Find Numerous Benefits Are Possible Through Life Insurance
description: The average young businessman, according to an informal survey, gets a call from insurance salesmen about once a month, while the average young careerwoman, married or uhmarried, never has been approached by a life insurance salesman.

title: Average Yield Hits Peak At Fannie Mae's Auction
description: WASHINGTON, March (Reuters)  The average yield of 7.951 per cent recorded on the Federal National Mortgage Association's issue of $44.3million in fourmonth commitments to buy conventional home mortgages is the highest since the program began a little over a year ago.

title: PRICE INCREASE SET BY MONSANTO UNIT
description: The Monsanto Company announced yesterday that its Monsanto Plymers & Petrochemicals Company unit would increase prices of styrene monomer by 0.5 cent a pound, beginning April 1.

title: NETS TURN BACK COLONELS, 9189
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 7 The Nets, sluggish kir three quarters, came alive in the final period tonight and edged the Kentucky Colonels, 9189, in an American Basketball Association game at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: TRUDEAU SENDING SHARP TO VIETNAM
description: OTTAWA, March 7  The question whether Canada should keep the 250 military observers she has in Vietnam is so politically explosive at home that Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau is sending Mitchell W. Sharp, the External Affairs Minister, to Saigon and Hanoi urgent talks.

title: Union Carbide to Add Unit
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that it would spend in excess of $5million to construct a facility for the manufacture of molecular sieves near Reggio on the southern coast of Italy. Molecular sieves are used mainly by the petrochemical, natural gas and petroleum refining industries.

title: A Soviet Pixie Invades the United States
description: She has no steady boyfriend, loves all fruits from watermelons to grapes and understands enough English to cherish the thousands of affectionate letters she continues to receive front enthralled Americans.

title: Mr. Lindsay's Decision
description: The surprise announcement by Mayor John V. Lindsay yesterday that he would not seek a third term as Mayor, and that this determination must be regarded as final, will be greeted by. New Yorkers of every political persuasion as an honorable, courageous and forthright decision that can only bring greats credit to Mr. Lindsay. It will also bring some clarification to the mayoral campaign.

title: Lyle and Yankees Are Still Far Apart
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 7If Sparky Lyle is hearing Pomp and Circumstance these days, the strains are coming from his record player in Danvers, Mass.

title: Representative to File Suit to Force Party to Stay Neutral.
description: HACKENSACK, March 7Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. will file a suit this week, demanding that all 21 of the state's Republican county committee chairmen be required to abide by New Jersey primary election laws, his campaign coordinator said today.

title: ENDOWMENT HEAD SEEKS A FUND RISE
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The head of the National Endowment for the Humanities took his turn today describing what his agency would do if it had twice as much money to spend next year.

title: Big 10 Playoff Is Set
description: CHICAGO, March 7 (UPI)If Minnesota and Indiana tie for the Big 10 basketball championship after Saturday's final games, they will meet in a playoff at Illinois Monday night to determine the league representative in the National Collegiate tournament. They are tied for first with 103 wonlost records.

title: ROBERT O'BRIEN, WON NEWBERY BOOK PRIZE
description: Robert C. O'Brien, who was honored in 1971 by the American Library Association for the year's most, distinguished literary book for children, died Monday in Washington of a heart attack. He was 55 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Budgetary Cuts Analyzed Here

title: Indians Given Till Tonight To Leave Wounded Knee
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S.D., March 7  The Federal Government issued an ultimatum today to the Indians holding this settlement, telling them to move out by nightfall tomorrow.

title: Miss McIlwaine, Original Artist, Presents Songs
description: Ellen McIlwaine and David Amram, who opened Tuesday night at Kenny's Castaways (84th Street off Third Avenue), sang popular music of eclectic origins, but the former was markedly more effective and coherent about it.

title: CANADIENS DOWN MAPLE LEAFS, 4??
description: MONTREAL, March 7 (UP) Marc Tarcliff and Guy Laflet scored in the first minute an a half tonight as the Montrea Canadiens stretched their ur defeated streak to nine game by beating the Toronto Mapl Leafs, 41.

title: Stock Fraud Scandal Having a Long Run in Texas
description: HOUSTON, March 7  The Sharpstown scandal, a multimilliondollar Texas stock fraud, is now having a long run in the state and. Federal courts after playing on the Texas political stage for two years.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: G.O.P. IN SUFFOLK DROPS INCUMBENT
description: BLUE POINT, L. I., March 7 The Suffolk Republican or ganization voted tonight to deny nomination for a third term as County Legislator to R. Thomas Strong, one of four persons under indictment for his alleged role in the Tiana Beach land case.

title: Lame Duck Mayor Faces Power Slippage
description: John V. Lindsay, who became a lame duck Mayor at 10:56 yesterday morning, now faces a slippage of power, an exodus of top city officials, the disMantling of some cherished progranis, a slowerpaced government bureaucracy and politicians and bureaucrats who believe that they can thwart him with impunity.

title: South Carolina Sets Back Duquesne Five by 9079
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., March 7 (AP)South Carolina, headed for the National Collegiate Basketball Tournament, combined a tight zone defense and clutch outside shooting tonight to end its regular season with a 9079 victory over Duquesne.

title: Chess: Just Trying to Be Brilliant Isn't Always Good Enough
description: There is no way to aim deliberately to play a brilliant game. One may hear a player say, Today I will play a brilliant game, but this kind of remark has emotional significance only, characteristically, it is uttered by those whp need some filip for their selfconfidence.

title: Confidence on U.S. Effort To End Deficit Is Voiced
description: CHICAGO, March 7A qualified confidence in the ability of the United States to compete in export markets and wipe out a trade deficit that exceeded $6billion last year was asserted today at the opening of a major world trade conference here.

title: People and Business
description: John J. Balles, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, warned yesterday that overhaul of the machinery controlling international trade and finance would not achieve international stability unless the United States subdued inflation and restored stability to its domestic economy.

title: On Italy's Black Market, Dollar Continues Strong
description: ROME, March 7The United States dollar is consistently stronger on the Italian foreigncurrency black market than probably anywhere in Western Europe.

title: Tougher Phase 3
description: The Administration's decision to reimpose price controls on the nation's largest oil companies has inevitably been labeled the first swing of the stick in the closet. But that metaphor may be a misnomer as applied to the 1 per cent average pricerise limit now set on oil and gasoline prices. For, as John T. Dunlop, director of the Cost of Living Council, has stressed, this was not a punitive action.

title: HOUSE RESTRICTS SECRET MEETINGS OF ITS OWN PANELS
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 Heeding the pleas of reformers, the House voted today, 370 to 27, to place strict limits on secrecy within its own committees.

title: Attica And Wounded Knee
description: It is not too latebut very nearly so for Federal officials at Wounded Knee, S. D., to draw back from a confrontation that has been hardening into a pattern grimly reminiscent of what happened at Attica prison a year and a half ago.

title: Tailor Shop That's So Convenient It Pulls Up to the Curb
description: GLENDALE HEIGHTS, Ill.  Dave Rompel is an automobile salesman. He wanted a new suit the other day. So he strolled back to his employer's garage, stepped into a truck, and ordered a suit.

title: JAPAN PROPOSES NEW SOVIET TALKS
description: TOKYO, March 7The Japanese Government hinted today that it was prepared to remove the major obstacle to concluding a peace treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: SAIGON EXPELLING A U.P.I NEWSMAN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 7An American journalist was ordered expelled from South Vietnam today and a South Vietnamese official said the Government was considering similar action against several other newsmen.

title: SCHOOL CONTRACTS DELAYED THIRD TIME
description: The Board of Education put off action yesterday, for the third time since December, on two district contracts with a computer service company because, board members said, the Bronx District Attorney was looking into aspects of the concern's operation.

title: Amer. Hockey League
description: TUESDAY NIGHT'S GAME

title: People in Sports: Prothro Sues
description: When Carroll Rosenbloom dismissed him as coach of the Los Angeles Rams last January, Tommy Prothro kept quiet. It seems, however, he was only biding his time, for it was disclosed that he had filed a $1.9million breachofcontract suit against Rosenbloom and the Rams.

title: MYRON WITHAM
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., March 7 (AP)Mytan Witham, a former mathematics teacher at Dartmouth College, Purdue University, the University of Colorado, the University of Vermont and St. Michael's College, died today. He was 92 years old.

title: ROBINSON SETS PACE IN U.S. OPEN BOWLING
description: Jay Robinson, a 29yearold righthande?? from Los Angeles, spilled 1,825 pins yesterday and with 5,410 for the 24game qualifier led a 64man advance into the quarterfinals of the $75,060 United States open bowling tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: Music: A Barzin and Simon Jubilee
description: Anniversaries are for celebration. It was 25 years ago that Abbey Simon first played with the National Orchestral Association, with Leon Barzin at the podium. So in the nature of an anniversary the American pianist returned to the National Orchestral Assoc dation in Carnegie Hall Tuesday night and made a real celebration out of it. He played not one but three concertos  Mozart's in C (K. 467), Beethoven's in G, and Brahms's in B flat.

title: Interleague Use of DH Up to National League
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 7 (AP)At the request of Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, the National League began a poll of its teams today on whether they favor use of the designated hitter for exhibition games on the road against American League clubs.

title: School Race Clash In Oklahoma Brings A Citywide Curfew
description: FREDERICK, Okla., March (AP)  Mayor Wilbur Brown proclaimed a state of civil emergency today, and imposed a 6:30 P.M. curfew for this community after racial violence flared at the city's high school.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)The National Association of Securities Dealers said today it had expelled four member firms for violation of its rule of fair practice. The firms are the A. & T. Funding Corporation, Franklin Square, L. L.; FoxRaffe Company, Inc. Seattle; First Investment Planning Company, Washington, D. C., and the Magnus Securities Corporation, McLean, Va.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FINISHING TOUCHES The Jews of Germany, AusWean& other Germanspeakbig areas had a long and ilparlous history that came to a fiery end with the Third Reich (there are still communities there, but they are inuscule). It is in New York that a major part of the work of collecting everything pertaining to that history is done, at the Leo Baeck Iniitute (named for one of the most eminent German Jews), 129 East 73d Street (RH 46400).

title: Mayor Receives Ovation
description: Mayor Lindsay was accorded a standing ovation by 800 guests at the City Club of New York's 80th anniversary dinner at the New York Hilton Hotel last night. Twentythree persons received For New York awards at the dinner.

title: A City School Helping Cooks Become Chefs
description: Class HT(E) 427 arrived at 8 A.M. armed with long knives, white hats and aprons. It was the first fullscale meeting of this term's advanced course in haute cuisine at New York Community College's hotel and res., taurant management school.Class HT(E) 427 arrived at 8 A.M. armed with long knives, white hats and aprons. It was the first fullscale meeting of this term's advanced course in haute cuisine at New York Community College's hotel and restaurant management school.

title: Slot Machine Bill Passed
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., March 7 (UPI)The Nevada Assembly passed without opposition today a bill intended to curb the loss of millions of dollars to slot machine cheaters in the state. The measure sets fines of up to $5,000 and prison terms up to 10 years for persons who tap the machines.

title: BOMB IS DEFUSED AT EL AL FACILITY
description: Two apparent bombing attempts hereone at an El Al Israel Airlines terminal at Kennedy Airport, and the other at an Israeli bank on Fifth Avenue have been thwarted by the police.

title: Lame Duck Mayor Faces A Slippage of His Power
description: John V. Lindsay, who became a lame duck Mayor at 10:56 yesterdays morning, now faces a slippage of power, an exodus of top city officials, the dismantling of some cherished programs, a slowerpaced government bureaucracy and politicians and bureaucrats who believe that they can thwart him with impunity.

title: Panther Convicted Of Attack on Police
description: Richard Moore was convicted yesterday of attempting to kill two policemen who were assigned to guard District Attorney Frank S. Mogan's apartment on Riverside Drive on May 19, 1971.

title: STOCKS RECOVER PROM EARLY FALI
description: A selling wave smashed into the oil stocks yesterday and dominated the activity on the New York Stock Exchange in response to the Nixon Administration's surprise move to reimpose price controls on the nation's 23 largest petroleum companies.

title: A Scramble for Mayor
description: Mayor Lindsay's sudden and dramatic decision not to seek reelection sent shock waves not only through his newly adopted Democratic party but also the Republican and Liberal parties, as befitting a politician who was a. Republican most of his political life, was reelected four years ago on the Liberal line and jumped to the Democratic party 18 months ago. The Lindsay decision, one of the bestkept political secrets in recent years, caught even politicians close to him by surprise, to that its impact, was not fully measured immediately.

title: Four Legislators Accused of Annoying Health Aide
description: ALBANY, March 7  The Albany Medical Center hap complained to state officials that four Assemblymen alarmed a health technician last week with vulgar language and physical annoyance as they were undergoing free heart tests.

title: Four Restaurants Climb to 3 Stars in Michelin Guide
description: PARIS, March 7Claude Peyrot, a 39yearold chef here who has been called a young saint of the kitchen, was awarded something far more important than a halo todaythree stars in the justpublished 1973 Michelin guide.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by major shareholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange made no insiders report available this week.

title: Mays, Knee Improved, Engages in Light Drill
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Via., March 7 Willie Mays said today that his swollen right knee felt better, but he again limited his workout in the New York Mets' camp and repeated that knee ailments could end his career.

title: Big 10 Playoff Is Set
description: CHICAGO, March 7 (UPI)If Minnesota and Indiana tie for the Big 10 basketball championship after Saturday's final games, they will meet in a playoff at Illinois Monday night to determine the league representative in the National Collegiate tournament. They are tied for first with 103 wonlost records.

title: REPUBLICAN AHEAD FOR BEGICH'S SEAT
description: ANCHORAGE, March 7State Senator Don Young, Republican of Fort Yukon, appears to (have won yesterday's special election to fill the seat, of Representative Nicholas J. Begich, Democrat of Alaska, who is believed to have died in a light plane accident last Oct. 16.

title: 80 MORE P.O.W.'S ARRIVE IN THE U.S.
description: Eighty more freed prisoners of war arrived back in the United States yesterday, returning to military bases across the country for reunions with their loved ones.

title: 197576 Auto Emission Standards: Costly Overkill
description: To the Editor:Auto emission standards now mandated for 197576 will burden the nation's motorists with undue costs and the economy with an unnecessary drain of resources without contributing measurably to public health. For this reason, believe a reply is in order to a recent letter to The Times from Jerome Kretchmer and Fred Hart stating opposition to the industry's application for a oneyear postponement of the '75 standards as provided for in the Clean Air Act of 1970.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Trainer Has Tuberculosis; Giants Undergo Retesting
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 7 The San Francisco Giants' trainer, Al Wylder, was sent home today after: a tuberculosis test turned up positivii. Dr. E. C. Sailer, team physician, ordered Wylder to Undergo treatment at St. Luke's Hospital in San Francisco.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE SINGLE PARENT EXPERIENCE. By Carole Klein. 241 pages. Walker. $7.95..

title: Suit in Atlanta Challenges Use of Revenue Sharing to Free Local Tax Money for Banned Purposes
description: ATLANTA  Charging that the Mayor of Atlanta had played a shell game with revenuesharing funds, the American Civil Liberties Union of Georgia has filed a suit in Federal District Court that could have major national impact on the use of these funds by state and local governments.

title: EXHIBITION BASEBALL
description: AT BRADENTON, Fla.

title: REFUGEES MOVING BACK TO MANAGUA
description: MANAGUA, Nicarligua, March 7 (AP)Much of Managua is still uninhabitable, but every day more people Who fled from the Dec. 23 earthquake are returning from the provinces.

title: NIXON NAMES BLACK TO HIGH H.U.D. POST
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) President Nixon today nominated H. R. Crawford, black manager of a privately owned subsidized housing unit here, as Assistant Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: BURNS ASKS SPEED IN MONEY REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, indicated to Congress today that he strongly doubted that floating currency exchange rates would provide a permanent solution to the world's currency problems.

title: BLOCK PLEADS GUILTY IN KITTY HAWK CASE
description: SAN DIEGO, March 7 (AP)Airman Apprentice John Brown, 20 years old, of Houston, pleaded guilty today to charges of riot and assault aboard the carrier Kitty Hawk last October, declaring, We attacked whites, do matter what the group.

title: Works by Buenos Aires Choir Range Widely in Time and Style
description: The Cantoria de la Basilica del Socorro, a 19member mixed choir from Buenos Aires, presented a cappella program Hunter College Playhouse on Tuesday night. The concert, conducted carefully and selfeffacingly by the choir's founder, Jesus Gabriel Segade, ranged widely in time and styleBeginning with Byrd (Missa Sine Nomine) and Schutz (two motets), It worked its way up to Stravinsky, Poulenc, Britten and Berta.

title: Klassen Concedes Postal Deficiencies But Promises Gain
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) Postmaster General E. T. Klassen said today that the Postal Service was so hellbent on reducing costs that we perhaps lost track of service, but he promised the Senate Post Office Committee that mail service would get better.

title: Talks Open in French Air Control Strike
description: PARIS, March 7 (Ap) The French Government opened negotiations with striking air controllers today while most foreign airlines maintained their boycott of France.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Upstate Town Cool To XRated Filims

title: Report Says Night Courts Ease Delays in Queens and the Bronx
description: The establishment of night courts for the first time in the Bronx and Queens on an experimental basis 18 months ago has significantly speeded up the pace of criminal justice throughout the city and saved $1.3million, in court costs, according to a report made public yesterday.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 8, 1973.

title: Knicks Wallop 76ers, 12094
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 7Although the caliber of opposition was distinctlf second rate, the New York Knicks finally returned to form tonight as they drubbed the Philadelphia 76ers, 12094, before a crowd of 7,069 at the Spectrum.

title: Vesco, in Costa Rica, Criticizes the S.E.C.
description: Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier who fled the country to escape possible arrest in a grand jury investigation of his activities, turned up yesterday in San Jos, Costa Rica.

title: 3 Firemen Save Dogs; 21 Survive
description: Twentyseven dogs and puppies that lived with a wor, man who cared for strays were carried from a burning Lower East Side tenement by firemen early yesterday.

title: Advertising: InFlight TakeOver
description: With the April issue of Mainliner magazine, United's inflight publication, Jeff Butler's idea of a nationl advertising medium in the sky will no longer be pie in the sky. And, at least, EastWest Publications, Los Angeles, will Hire up to its name.

title: Marshall and Expos Agree
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. March 7 (AP)The righthanded relief pitcher, Mike Marshall has agreed in substance to terms of his 1973 contract with the Montreal Expos and is flying to camp to sigh his contract. General Manager Jim Fanning said he would meet With Marshall tomorrow and added, I think Mike will be in uniform before the end of the day. Marshall had a 148 wonlost, record and an earnedrunaverage of 1.78.

title: Jersey Urged to Act on Pollution crisis
description: TRENTON, March  Because of the Pollution of its streams, rivers and waterways, New Jerky faces a water quality crisis that can be over come only if the state totally revises and unifies its sewage control and water supply laws, a legislative study commission reported today.

title: WHALERS CONQUER CRUSADER SIX, 10
3 Journalists Disagree Sharply Over Need for Press Immunity
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 Three journalists divided sharply today in testimony before a House Judiciary subcommittee on whether a Federal law was needed to protect newsmen from revealing confidential sources in answer to subpoenas in judicial proceedings.

title: Brooklyn College Defeats Lehman for Title, 85 to 68
description: Brooklyn College won its first Knickerbocker College Basketball Conference championship by defeating Lehman College, 8568, last night at Pace College court. Brooklyn ended the conference part of its schedule with a 72 wonlost record and 199 over all.

title: Flyers Deadlock Rangers, 2 to 2
description: The Philadelphia Flyers, hockey's most penalized team, and whose players claim the referees pick on them, tried their muscles against the Rangers last night and gained a 22 tie.

title: BLUE RIBBON CITED ON HEALTHCODE LAG
description: The Blue Ribbon, a popular MermanAmerican restaurant at 145 West 44th Street, was among 11 food establishments cited by the Health Services Administration yesterday for failing to correct violations of the city's Health Code.

title: A.E.C. Lowers Estimate Of Atom Power Growth
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The Atomic Energy Commission remained optimistic today over thelongterm growth of nuclear, energy as a source of electric power although some of its earlier estimates have been revised downward.

title: Carrington Seeded First
description: Art Carrington of Elizabeth, N.J., and Bob Barker of Sands Point, L.I., were seeded first and second yesterday for the annual Eastern men's indoor tennis championship starting to morrow night at the Stadium Tennis Center in the Bronx.

title: Nixon's Popularity Declines 3 Points In Gallup Survey
description: President Nixon still has the support of 65 per cent of Americans, according to the latest Gallup Poll, but his popularity has slipped a little in recent weeks. The survey was taken Feb. 1619 and the results were released yesterday.

title: Holtzman Ends Holdout
description: MESA, Ariz., March 7 (AP) Ken Holtzman, a 19game winner for the world champion Oakland A's last year, came to terms on his 1973 contract today, the club announced.

title: HUTCHESON TAKEN BY SHECKY GREEN
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., March 7  Shecky Greene continues to be the smash hit of the Florida winter racing season The 3yearold colt, named fox the nightclub comic, left 'em laughing once again today when he equaled the track record at Gulfstream Park with an easy victory in the $31,900 Hutcheson Stakes.

title: Mrs. Friedan's Essay irks Feminists
description: It was billed, as a speakout of the feminist community to rebut alarms sounded by Betty Friedan concerning a possible takeover of the women's liberation movement by manhaters, lesbians, pseudoradical infantiliats and infiltrators trained by the F.B.I. and the C.I.A.

title: Arthur Daley
description: BRADENTON, Fla., March 7Strangely enough, the Pittsburgh Pirates of today bear a striking similarity to the Pittsburgh Mates of last year, even though they no longer have a Roberto Clemente to grace their lineup. Despite the dire predictions or the doomsday prophets that the shocking death of a mighty Roberto in a plane crash would send Pittsburgh morale tailspinning, no such thing has happened.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In a move to augment the community service role of libraries, Mayor Lindsay yesterday signed a twoyear contract with the Administration and Management Research Association, a nonprofit organization, to establish a system of information and referral to City services in all Brooklyn Public Library branches.

title: Jury Gets the Case of Driver Accused in BusTrain Crash
description: The CITY, N.Y., March 7The jury began its deliberations today in the trial of Joseph Larkin, the driver of the school bus that was struck by a freight train in nearby Congers last March 24.

title: Slain Policeman Will Get Inspector's Funeral Today
description: An inspector's funeral will be held at 11 A.M. today in Concord Baptist Church, Marcy Avenue and Madison Street, Brooklyn, for Patrolman Irving Wright, who was shot to death by two fellow policemen who mistook him for a holdup man.

title: To the returning P.O.W.'s: This list may be a little far out for you dudes, a little heavy, but it's what we've been into while you were gone. Dig?
description: This semiofficial glossary was assembled by the United States Air Force from information supplied by families of prisoners in North Vietnam to acquaint the returning P.O.W.'s with slang expressions now used in America.

title: A Scramble for Mayor
description: Mayor Lindsay's sudden and dramatic decision not to seek reelection sent shock waves not only through his newly adopted Democratic party but also the Republican and Liberal parties, as befitting a politician who was a Republican most of his political life, was reelected four years ago on the Liberal line and jumped to the Democratic party 18 months ago. The Lindsay decision, one of the bestkept political secrets in recent years, caught even politicians close to him by surprise, so that its impact was not fully measured immediately.

title: 11 Die in Japanese Fire
description: KITAKYUSHU, Japan, Thursday, March 8 (Reuters)  At least 11 people were killed and 100 injured today in a fire that destroyed a fivestory hospital in this southern Japanese city, the police said.

title: LAWYER FOR NIXON TOLD F.B.I. HE GAVE FUNDS TO SEGRETTI
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 Herbert W. Kalmbach, President Nixon's personal lawyer, told agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation last year that he had paid between $30,000 to $40,000 in Republican party funds to Donald H. Segretti, a 31yearold lawyer who reportedly ran a covert political sabotage operation for the Republican party during last years Presidential election campaign.

title: 15 DIE IN BRISBANE IN FIRE LAID TO ARSON
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Thursday, March 8 (AP)A nightclub fire killed 15 persons early today, and the police said that arson was the cause of the fire.

title: 25,000 Responses Sought In Choices for '76 Poll
