description: Dr. George R, Gallup, the pollster, said yesterday that 25,000 responses in a metropolitanarea poll on urban problems, scheduled to begin March 17, would be phenomenal.

title: WITNESS RECALLS BROWN'S CAPTURE
description: A 28yearold patrolman told a jury here yesterday how he shot and captured H. Rap Brown, the black militant, on West Side roof shortly after the armed robbery of a nearby tavern on Oct. 16, 1971.

title: Jersey Urged to Act on Pollution Crisis
description: TRENTON, March 7  Because of the pollution of its streams, rivers and waterways, New Jersey faces a water quality crisis that can be overcome only if the state totally revises and unifies its sewage control and water supply laws, a legislative study commission reported today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The grandchildren of John V. Kenny, the deposed Hudson County Democratic boss, laid claim yesterday to $695,000 in bonds used in evidence at the trial of former Jersey City and Hudson County officials and later turned over to the Internal Revenue Service to pay Kenny's back taxes. In a suit filed in United States District Court, in Newark, John K. Hanly of New Rochelle, N. Y., and Margo Hanly Hermann of Essex Fells said they, not their grandfather, owned the bonds and that the I.R.S. should return them.

title: Army to End Vietnam Role
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 7 (UPI)The United States Army will officially cease operations in Vietnam on March 15, ending nearly eight years of involvement in the country. The 6,000 remaining American troops will be under the command of the Military Assistance Command in Vietnam.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Boeing Company received a $62.4million Air Force contract for operational and maintenance ground support equipment for the Minuteman missile force, it was announced yesterday.

title: Manor Earnings And Sales at Highs
Governor Hits Support of Plan for Oil Port in Raritan Bay
description: TRENTON, March 7In his first major political attack in the Republican gubernatorial campaign, Governor Cahill charged today that Representative Charels W. Sandman Jr. had written off portions of New Jersey proposing a deepwater port in Raritan Bay for oil supertankers.

title: DANIEL RIESNER, FORMER G.O.P. AIDE
description: Daniel J. Riesner, former secretary of the New York County Republican Committee and a lawyer and civic leader, died yesterday in Sarasota, Fla. lie was 79 years old and lived at 920 Park Avenue.

title: Chrysler Plans Expansion
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 7 (AP)The Chrysler Corporation this year will spend $4million for new machinery and add 140 employes to the payroll at its New Process Gear transmission and axle plant here, it was announced today.

title: U. S. and Soviet Complete Ice Study in Bering Sea
description: MOSCOW, March 7Soviet and United states ships and planes have braved snowstorms and heavy seas in the last three weeks to complete an unusual joint research project on ice and weather patterns in the Bering Sea, between Alaska and Siberia.

title: Aides In on the Secret Kept it to Themselves
description: Late Monday night, sitting in the Grade Mansion living room, a hotplate at his side holding a late supper, Mayor Lindsay made a series of telephone calls and, in between, said to his wife:

title: Skiers Told to Be in Condition
description: Downhill skiing is not exercise in the true physiological sense of the term, Dr. Lewis J. Krakauer of the Corvallis (Ore.) Clinic told more than 300 orthopedic surgeons at SnowmassAtAspen, Colo. This type sport does little to train muscle endurance or to increase cardiac conditionmg. Dr. Krakauer, one of the featured lecturers at this week's four  day postgraduate course sponsored by the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons, emphasized that downhill skiing might even be harmful to the poorly conditioned heart.

title: China Assails New. Siberia Names
description: HONG KONG, March 7China strongly denounced the Soviet Union today for giving new Russian names to a number of towns in Far Eastern Siberia that previously bore names of Chinese origin.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: In 1909, the establishment of the Hawaiian Islands National Wildlife Refuge marked the nation's first attempt to preserve the ecological integrity of at least a portion of this fascinating Pacific archipelago.

title: Panther Convicted Of Attack on Police
description: Richard Moore was convicted yesterday of attempting to kill two policemen who were assigned to guard District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's apartment on Riverside Drive on May 19, 1971.

title: MARBURGER PRAISED BY EDUCATION BOARD
description: TRENTON, March 7 (AP)The State Board of Education said goodby today to Education Commissioner Carl I. Marburger and issued its judgment that history would view his term as one of progress and benefit to the state.

title: TV: The MarcusNelson Murders
description: The somewhat dubious trend to threehour television specials continues this evening at 9 o'clock on the Columbia Broadcasting System, with The MarcusNelson Murders. The film is remarkably well produced, directed and acted. It is also disturbing, on its own level and on a level doubtlessly unintended by its executive producer and writer, Abby Mann.

title: A Lawsuit Charges Laxity on Tax Fund To Aid Candidates
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Common cause, the socalled citizens lobby, has accused the Nixon Administration in a lawsuit of undermining the public financing of Presidential campaigns by failing to tell taxpayers how they can support the new system at no expense.

title: Music: Monroe and Bluegrass Boys
description: Evidence of the rising interest in country music in New York was apparent at pair of concerts given Sunday afternoon and evening by bill Monroe and his Bluegrass Boys at the New York Law School Auditorium. Roth concerts attracted overflow crowds with so many hopeful listeners turned away that. the Bluegrass. Club of New York will bring Mr. Monroe back for two more concerts on Saturday afternoon and evening in the same hall.

title: Can SaySo Make It So?
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The urban crisis is over.

title: Business Records
description: Chapter XI pedition for an arrangement by;

title: 2 ENVOYS BURIED IN SIMPLE RITES
description: WASHINGTON, March 7In solemn, spare ceremonies under gray skies, two career diplomats slain by terrorists in the Sudan were buried side by side today at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Clark Aids Magee Defense
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 7. (UPI)  Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark joined the defense of Ruchell Magee yes. terday after the California Supreme Court ruled that he could participate.

title: LINDSAY ASSERTS HE WILL NOT RUN FOR A 3D TERM, BUT BARS COMMENT ON THE GO VERNORSHW AND SENATE
description: Mayor Lindsay ended months of increasing suspense yesterday by announcing that he would not seek reelection for personal considerations, although he said that I believe I could win a third term.

title: 500 Operas Later, Merrill Looks Back
description: Robert Merrill, a star of the Metropolitan Opera for more than two decades, knows something about making a great voice last. And .. last ... and .... last.

title: LON NOL'S BROTHER RESISTS U.S. MOVE
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 7The United States has been trying to bring about a change in Cambodia's leadership to halt the nation's decline under pressure from Vietnamese Communists and Cambodian guerrillas, but the effort has apparently been set back by the Government's strongman, the President's brother.

title: YIELDS ON BONDS SHOW FEW RISES
description: The thrust toward ever higher levels of interest rates was blunted yesterday in a generally subdued credit market session.

title: PRICES AGAIN RISE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market registered their third consecutive advance yesterday although the upswing Was, not as large as on Tuesday.

title: Tennis Tourney Monday
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., March 7A tournament to determine the United States tennis team for the ninth World Maccabiah Games in Israel in July begins Monday at Kutsher's Country Club. Sixtyfour men, and 16 women are competing.

title: French Weekly Accuses Government Of a Widespread Wiretap Operation
description: PARIS, March 7  A vast wiretapping operation was attributed to the French Government today by a national magazine.

title: CANADIENS DOWN MAPLE LEAFS, 41
description: MONTREAL, March 7 (UPI) Marc Tardiff and Guy Lafleur scored in the first minute and a half tonight as the Montreal Canadiens stretched their undefeated streak to nine games by beating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 41.

title: Holtzman Ends Holdout
description: MESA, Ariz., March 7 (AP) Ken Holtzman, a 19game winner for the world champion Oakland A's last year, came to terms on his 1973 contract today, the club announced.

title: SAMUEL W. SCHWARTZ
description: EVANSTON, Ill., March 7 (AP)Samuel W. Schwartz, retired president of the El Producto Cigar Company and brotherinlaw of Arthur J. Goldberg, dormer Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, died of a heart attack at his home, here yesterday. He was 73 years old.

title: But Cost of Living Unit Reportedly Does Not Foreclose Action
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 The White House denied today that the Administration was considering price controls on raw agricultural products and meat on the hoof.

title: JAPAN PROPOSES NEW SOVIET TALKS
description: TOKYO, March 7The Japanese Government hinted today that it was prepared to remove the major obstacle to concluding a peace treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: EUROPE PREPARES FOR MONEY TALKS
description: PARIS, March 7With important monetary meetings scheduled for tomorrow and Friday, the French and West German cabinets convened today against a background of gloom in European capitals over the prospects for joint Common Market defensive action in the dollar crisis.

title: Sport Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Consurners Union Issues a Warning Against Buying of Microwave Ovens
description: MT. VERNON, N.Y., March  The Consumers Union warned the public today not to buy microwave ovens, saying it had found measurable radiaation leakage in 15 leading models and thus it was not convinced that they are completely safe.

title: MRS. ELLES ELVOVE
description: YONKERS, March 7Mrs. Marjorie R. Elvove, coordinator of English studies for the Yonkers public schools, died yesterday at her home, 11 Priscilla Avenue. She was 48 years old, the wife of Elies Elvove.

title: Forest Hills Told: Resurface Courts or Lose U.S. Open
description: The United States Lawn Tennis Association, in a virtual ultimatum to the West Side Tennis Club of Forest Hills, Queens, has informed the club that unless it converts from grass to a synthetic surface, the United States Open championships may be taken elsewhere after this summer's event.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: News Summary and Index THURSDAY, MARCH 8, 1973
description: International

title: JAPAN BANKER TO GO TO CURRENCY TALKS
description: TOKYO, March 7The Governor of the Bank of Japan, Tadashi Sasaki, rather than the Finance Minister, Kiichi Aichi, will represent Japan at the conference of finance ministers scheduled to open in Paris Friday, the Japanese Government said today.

title: Gimbel and Shapiro Assay Future for Retail Chain
description: Despite the Loews Corporation's recent, increase in its holdings of Gimbel Brothers' common stock to 19 per cent from 10 per cent, making Loews the largest shareholder in Gimbels, Bruce A. Gimbel, chairman of the 130yearold retail company, said yesterday he still considered the conglomerate's purchase an investment.

title: BURNS ASKS SPEED IN MONEY REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, indicated to Congress today that he strongly doubted that floating currency exchange rates would provide a permanent solution to the world's currency problems.

title: Swarthmore Raises Fees
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa., March 7 (AP) Swarthmore College announced today an increase of $250 a year in college charges for the 197374 school year, bringing the annual figure to $4,200.

title: Boy, 9, Run Over by Train
description: A 9yearold Brooklyn boy was run over by a Penn Central freight train yesterday at Glenwood Road and East 43d Street, in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn. The youth, Joseph White of 1742 Troy Avenue, was found shortly after the train had passed at 3 P.M. Both his legs had been amputated and three fingers of his right hand were missing. He was reported in critical condition at Kings County Hospital.

title: Indian Food Chief Says Poison Was Found in Grain From U. S.
description: NEW DELHI, March 7 India's Food Minister said today that recently arrived shipments of American grain had included some poisonous seeds but that they had been detected before the grain could be distributed in droughtstricken areas of the country.

title: 2 Holdouts Face Release
description: SARASOTA, Fla., March 7 (AP)General Manager Stu Holcomb of the Chicago White Sox had a solution for part of his holdout problem today. He asked waivers for the purpose of unconditional release on an outfielder, Jay Johnstone, and an infielder,, Ed Spiezio, both holdouts.

title: The Closed Booth
description: For millions of Americans, the voting booth is closed on Election Day. These are the people who failed to get their names on the registration lists. It is possible criticize them for apathy or inattentiveness. But it also possible to inquire why local govermnments make it so difficult to register.

title: Meatless Days Urged
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 8 (UPI)To protest the soaring price of food, particular beef, the Rhode Island Senate last night passed a resolution asking the Governor to proclaim one day a week during April

title: RECORDS ARE SET FOR PORK BELLIES
description: Prices of frozen pork bellies reached records yesterday, both for cash and futures contracts, and shoppers will soon feel the impact at their supermarkets when they buy bacon.

title: SQUIRES TROUNCE NETS, 130 TO 118
description: RICHMOND, March 8The Virginia Squires defeated the New York Nets,. 130118, in an American Basketball Association game tonight as 15 players hit double figures.

title: WHOLESALE INDEX OF PRICES SURGED DURING FEBRUARY
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The wholesale price index rose sharply again in February, partly because of increases in food costs but also because of the Iargest onemonth rise in 22 years in the prices of industrial commodities.

title: Papp and the Future of Lincoln Center
description: With the naming of Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival as the new theater constituent at Lincoln Center, many feel that Lincoln Center has, in Mr. Papp, a director with the force and personality to give theater its rightful, equal place among the constituents. Mr. Papp has always been a controversial figure  a colorful pugnacious infighter not afraid to speak his mind or to make mistakes. And some people, including some of his admirers, worry that he has made a mistake in going to Lincoln Center. The feeling is twofoldthat he is spreading his energies thin and that by his expansion he is limiting the opportunities for others: New York becomes a Joseph Papp festival.

title: OnceNotorious Welfare Hotel Dedicated as Housing for Aged
description: Mrs. Hilda Altholz, a 65yearold widow, showed Mayor Lindsay her pleasantly furnished fifthfloor apartment and asked when she might vote for him for. Governor. The Mayor replied that he hadn't made any plans for future races but that he liked her Upper West Side apartment.

title: Trevino Leads by 4 Shots On RecordEqualing 64
description: MIAMI, March 8  Despite 106 bunkers and eight lakes, Lee Trevino scored a 64, his low round of the year, to lead the $150,000 Doral Eastern Open turnament today by four strokes.

title: U. S. AND INDIANS REACH CEASEFIRE
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., March 8A ceasefire agreement between Federal officials and militant Indians holding this reservation hamlet was reached tonight, but gunfire broke out on the perimeter of Wounded Knee and two In dians were wounded, neither seriously.

title: Passports Available in Bronx
description: Leo Levy, the Bronx County Clerk, announced yesterday that overseas travelers can obtain passports in the Bronx County Building, at 851 Grand Concourse, as well as at the United States Passport Office in Manhattan,

title: OFFDUTY POLICEMAN WOUNDED IN SUFFOLK
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., March (UPI)An offduty New York City patrolman was wounded tonight by a Suffolk County policeman atfer allegedly firing at a patron outside a bar here, the police said.

title: 5 Suits Attribute Brain Damage To Drug's Use Before Surgery
description: ST. LOUIS, March 8Separate suits filed here charge that a drug given to a 12yearold girl and a former airline stewardess before surgery caused irreparable brain damage to the patients.

title: People and Business
description: John B. Halverson, who held the posts of president and chief operating officer, has left U.S. Financial, Inc., a West Coast building and mortgage company based in San Diego that has been under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Whether he resigned or was dismissed was not disclosed; the company would say only that Mr. Halverson is no longer an employe of U.S. Financial.

title: FRANK ABRAMS DIES; A LEADER IN A.J.C.
description: Frank Abrams, honorary vice president of the. American Jewish Congress, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived here andi in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: GUARD'S RECORD SHOWS 5 ARRESTS
description: A school security guard, sought for a week after he was accused of trying to break into a safe at Washington Irving High School, was revealed yesterday to have an arrest record dating to 1946.

title: New ArbitrationUnit Head
description: Robert Meade, who has been regional director of the American Arbitration Association in Syracuse, has been named regional director for the association's office here. The announcement was made yesterday by Robert Coulson, assodation president.

title: Free Sterilization Offered
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 8 (UPI)  A bill to permit male welfare recipients 65 years olds or older to undergo a sterilization operation at state expense was signed into law by Gov. David Hall yesterday.

title: 47 Injured in 2 Outbreaks At the Annandale Prison
description: FLEMINGTON, N. J., March 8  Fortyseven persons 79 prisoners and 18 correction officers  were injured in two outbreaks at the state's Annandale Youth Correction Center that began yesterday afternoon and continued into the early hours of this morning.

title: PIIAT CRITICIZES FRENCH CONTROL
description: MADRID, March 8  The Spanish pilot who has been blamed by French authorities for a midair crash that took the lives of 68 persons Monday accused French air traffic controllers today of not having responded to his messagesapparently, he said because they did not understand English very well.

title: Nixon Signs Agency Bill
description: WASHINGTON March 8 (UP) President Nixon signed legislation today permitting the Departments of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare and the foreign aid program to continue operations until June 30 even though to appropriation bills have been passed by Congress.

title: Prison Doctor Is Indicted As Plotter of Murder of 3
description: TRENTON, March 8  Dr. William R. King, a former state prison psychiatrist, was indicted today by the state grand jury on six counts of soliciting the murders of three persons.

title: NO FRAUD IS FOUND IN U.S. MIN DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)The Justice Department found no criminal wrongdoing by past or present Government workers and no criminal fraud by companies involved in last year's $1billion United StatesSoviet grain deal, Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz said today.

title: Underground Nuclear Test
description: MERCURY, Nev., March 8 (AP)A nuclear device with a force of 20 to 200 kilotons was detonated underground today, the Atomic Energy Commission said. It was the first announced test of the year. The device, codenamed Miera, was detonated at 8:10 A.M. 1,966 feet below the desert surface at Yucca Flats, a spokesman said.

title: N.A.A.C.P. SCORES ATLANTA BRANCH
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced yesterday that it had suspended its Atlanta branch, which had worked out a compromise desegregation plan with the Atlanta school board.

title: LONDON IS SHAKEN BY TWO BOMBINGS LAID TO THE I.R.A.
description: LONDON, March 8Terrorists struck in London today, setting off two large explosions, near Trafalgar Square and at the Old Bailey, the Central Criminal Court. One man was killed and 243 were injured.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: A quarterpage advertisement in the sports section of last Sunday's edition of The New York Times extolled the deadly charms of what is described as the world's first selfpropelled fishing lure.

title: HINTERSEER WINS CUP GIANT SLALOM
description: MOUNT ALYESKA, Alaska, March 8 (AP)Hansi Hinterseer of Austria, with a combined time of 3 minutes 45.37 seconds, took first place today in the men's World Cup giant slalom.

title: A Golden Raisin Pie
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Beame Running for Mayor As a OneTerm Candidate
description: City Controller Abraham I Beame, who lost a bid for th?? mayoralty eight years ago, a?? nounced yesterday that he wa?? a candidate for the Democrati?? mayoral nomination and indi?? cated that he would be a one term Mayor.

title: A.M.A. PANEL WARNS ABOUT DIETING BOOK
description: CHICAGO, March 8 (AP)An American Medical Association committee said today that dietary recommendations in the book Dr. Atkins' Diet Revolution were unscientific and potentially dangerous to health.

title: Back to Confusion
description: YANUCA ISLAND, FijiThe strategic balance of the western and southwestern Pacific has been significantly altered by U.S. military withdrawals taking place in Okinawa and South Vietnam and the political balance, there really is one, may be changed by the new attitudes of recently elected socialist governments in Australia and New Zealand.

title: How Badillo Lost Crucial N.D.C. Vote
description: At last week's designating convention of the New Democratic Coalition, Representative Herman Badillo's campaign manager declined to cast a vote that could have blocked the mayoral endorsement of Mr, Badillo's main opponent, Assemblyman Albert Blumenthal.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI)Representative Margaret Heckler, Republican of Massachusetts, proposed legislation today to end what she termed insulting discrimination against working women by stores and credit companies. Her bill, titled the Equal Consumer Credit Act, would make it a crime for creditors to discriminate on the basis of sex or marital status in issuing charge accounts credit cardsa practice that she said was rampant throughout the country. A similar measure was introduced in the Senate last month by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey.

title: 3 Bishops Order Makarios Unfrocked
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 8Archbishop Makarios, the.President of Cyprus, was ordered unfrocked today by three Bishops of his church, who charged that he had violated church law by holding public office. But the President scoffed at the decision, calling it of no value whatsoever.

title: Jane Barasch Wed To Peter E. Ratner
description: Miss Jane Barasch, a therapist on the staff at the Elizabeth (N.J.) General Hospital, Community Mental Health Center, was married here yesterday evening to Peter Edward Ratner, who expects to be graduated in May from the Columbia Law School.

title: Scientists Find Protons Grow at High Energies
description: Two independent sets of experiments, involving the highest energy collisions ever achieved in a laboratory, have shown that the proton, one of the fundamental building blocks of the atom, gets increasingly fat when accelerated to great energy.

title: Jordan, in Jersey City Race, Names Running Mates
description: JERSEY CITY, March 8Mayor Paul T. Jordan announced today that he would seek reelectior May 8 and named his running mates for City Council posts.

title: ARGENTINE REBELS SEIZE A PUBLISHER
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 8Leftist guerrillas today kidnapped an Argentine newspaper owner and forced his masscirculation daily to publish one of their statements.

title: U.S. and Hanoi to Open Aid Talks Next Thursday
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The United States and North Vietnam announced today that the first meeting of the new joint commission to discuss future economic relations between the two countries, including possible American aid for reconstruction, would take place in Paris a week from today.

title: CHRIS TAYLOR GAINS IN TITLE WRESTLING
description: SEATTLE, March 8 (AP) Two defending champions, Chris Taylor, and Tom Milkovich, won firstround matches in the National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling championships today while third, Bill Murdock, was beaten decisively.

title: Performance Level Set in a Police Test
description: The commanding officers of 15 Brooklyn precincts have begun programs under which patrolmen can be punished if they fail to earn enough points by making arrests and issuing traffic tickets.

title: College, School Results
description: Colleges

title: BRITISH FOOTBALL
description: By Reuters

title: COLLEGE LOSES BID TO CURB REPORT
description: TRENTON, March 8  A State Superior Court judge today upheld the right of the American Association of University Professors to publish a report that is critical of Rider College.

title: U.S. Aides Ask Laos to Halt Offensive
description: SAVANNAKHET, Laos, March 8American officials have quietly but firmly complained to Laotian military officers about at least one continuing operation by the Government that they consider a clear violation of the ceasefire accord.

title: Law Day Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)  President Nixon today proclaimed May 1 as Law Day U.S.A.

title: Agnew on Connally And '76
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  Vice President Agnew talks Presidential politics these days if courtesy demands it, but he thinks all this talk about him and John Connally in 1976 is meaningless at this early date.

title: Plane Flying Army Sky Divers Crashes in Carolina, Killing 14
description: SILER CITY, N. C., March 8 (UPI)  A plane carrying members of the Army's Golden Knights parachuting team to a Kansas performance exploded and crashed here today, killing all 14 persons on board.

title: Firemen Find Two Bodies After Blaze in Queens Home
description: The bodies of two men, one with a stab wound in the neck, were found by firemen who put out a fire last night in a onestory wooden building at 10201 164th Road, in the Hamilton Beach section of Queens.

title: Pentagon Says That Minesweeping Is Without Result So Far
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The Defense Department said today that it had yet to find and recover or to explode any mines after two days of minesweeping in Haiphong Harbor and in the Gulf of Tonkin.

title: Underground Nuclear Test
description: MERCURY, Nev., March 8 (AP)A nuclear device with a force of 20 to 200 kilotons was detonated underground today, the Atomic Energy Commission said. It was the first announced test of the year. The device, codenamed Miera, was detonated at 8:10 A.M. 1,966 feet below the desert surface at Yucca Flats, a spokesman said.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Amex, Reorganizing, Sets Policy Unit
description: As part of a major reorganization, the American Stock Exchange formed yesterday a new staff unit  office of the chairman of the board.

title: REPEAL ADVOCATED FOR MINIMUM TAX
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI) The United States Chamber of Commerce called on Congress today to repeal the minimum tax, a 10 per cent levy on the taxsheltered income of millionaires.

title: Slaying of a 10YearOld Leaves West Side Fearful
description: Luis Ortiz, his neighbors on West 107th Street recalled yesterday, was shy and not given to talking with anyone he didn't know. That, as they puzzled over it made the murder of the likable 10yearold even harder to understand.

title: Dr. Stuart W. Harrington, Thoracic Surgeon, Dead
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., March 8 (AP)Dr. Stuart W. Harrington, who specialiied in breast and lung surgery at the Mayo Clinic, died today in his home here. He was 83 years old.

title: BusTruck Collision Kills 7 and Hurts 23
description: BAKERSFIELD, Tex., March 8 (UPI)A Greyhound bus carrying adults and several children collided with a truck on a bridge last night and burst into flames, killing seven persons and injuring 23 others.

title: Tuition Plan At the City U. Under Attack
description: ALBANY, March 8Democratic legislative leaders, Mayor Lindsay and officials of the City University of New York today attacked the recommendations of a Special Commission on Higher Education appointed by Governor Rockefeller last October.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nixon Says Cities Won't Lose Funds With Block Grants
description: WASHINGTON, March 8President Nixon assured Congress today that if it enacts his plan to turn Federal urban programs into special revenue sharing no city will receive less money, even though the basic concept of Federal funding will be changed.

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS PRICERISE DATA
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The Senate Banking Committee approved today an amendment to the Economic Stabili. zation Act that would require greater public disclosure of the sales, costs and profits of some corporations.

title: MANHATTAN FIVE DOWNS FORAM AT GARDEN, 9574
description: Manhattan, playing its last game before the National Invitation Tournament, punished Fordham, 9574, last night in the second game of a college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

title: Draft Order by Birthdays
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI)Following is the order of priority by dates for possible military induction of men born in 1954, as determined today in the fifth national draft lottery conducted by the Selective Service System:

title: Performance Standard Is Set For Patrolmen in a Test Here
description: The commanding officers of 15 Brooklyn precincts have begun programs under which patrolmen can be punished if they fail to earn enough points by making arrests and issuing traffic tickets.

title: Baraka Pleads for Black Unity At Opening of 3Day Symposium
description: A passionate plea for black unity and a blistering attack on proponents of integration by Imamu Amiri Baraka opened threeday symposium on culture and the black struggle at Queens College yesterday.

title: DRAB GUERRILLAS CURBED BY SUDAN
description: CAIRO, March 8 (Reuters)The Sudan has told Arab countries that she has banned all Palestine commando activity in her territory following the killing of three Western diplomats in Khartoum by Black September guerrillas.

title: Indictments and More
description: The indictment of the president of the City Tax Commission and two other city officials on charges of fixing parking tickets for political friends comes as further evidence of deplorable laxity in the Lindsay Administration. The grand jury presentment handed down with the indictments charged that an earlier inquiry into this matter by the city's Department of Investigation had been inadequate and ineffectual. That inquiry appeared designed less to expose wrongdoing than to sweep under the rug.

title: Penn State Captures Lead In Eastern Gym Tourney
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 8 (AP)Penn State opened a big lead today in its effort to hold the Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastics League championship.

title: Recital
description: Ruth Laredo is about as big as a hummingbird. As she sits at the piano, her hands sometimes appear to hover over the keys, a blur to the eyes if not to the ears, extracting sweet music from the most bitterly difficult pages of Ravel's La Valse or Debussy's Feux d'artifice. But what hummingbird ever packed the power Miss Laredo brought to bear in her recital at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night?

title: Money Supply Grows
description: Corporations are continuing to borrow heavily, banks are stepping up their borrowing from the Federal Reserve, the money supply is growing faster and interest rates are climbing.

title: U.S. Aide in Indian Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The Justice Department official in charge of the Government's efforts to resolve the South Dakota crisis is Ralph Earnest Erickson, who, like the embattled Indians, is product of a rural, less than affluent upbringing.

title: MILWAUKEE ROAD TO PETITION I.C.C.
description: The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad announced yesterday it would file a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission today asking that the Burlington Northern merger proceedings be reopened for inclusion of the Milwaukee Road into the Burlington Northern system.

title: 5 P.O.W.'S GREETED BY FAMILIES HERE
description: Five released prisoners of war landed at Kennedy International Airport last evening for joyous reunions. Two others were greeted by a crowd of 2,000 at Fort Monmouth, N. J.

title: Christensen Wins Slalom On Sunny Day in Vermont
description: HANCOCK, Vt., March 8In near tropical weather that found many spectators watching the proceedings in shirtsleeves, Peik Christensen of Denver University captured the National Collegiate tworun slalom today over courses that were surprisingly fast.

title: Brother of Johnson Sued For Debts Totaling $14,562
description: AUSTIN, Tex., March 8 (AP) Court records show a total of $14,562 in garnishment suits filed against the estate of former President Lyndon B. Johnson for debts allegedly owed by his brother, Sam Houston Johnson.

title: Benjamin de Arriba y Castro, Spain's Oldest Cardinal, Dies
description: BARCELONA, Spain, March 8 (UPI)Benjamin de Arriba Castro, Spain's oldest cardinal, died today after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: 3 Bishops Order Makarios Unfrocked
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 8Archbishop Makarios, the President of Cyprus, was ordered unfrocked today by three Bishops of his church, who charged that he had violated church law by holding public office. But the President scoffed at the decision, calling it of no value whatsoever.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OUTGOING INN The jazz outplays the muted hubbub at the crowded bar and tables of Rust Brown, a new (six months old) restaurant at 168 West 96th Street (8507080), where the Herman Foster Trio holds forth Wednesdays through Sundays after 10 P.M.

title: East Germans Halt Reunions of Young With Kin in West
description: BERLIN, March 8  East Germany has halted a familyreunion program under which at least 1,000 young people had been scheduled to join their parents in the West.

title: JERSEY APPROVES DISTRICTING PLAN
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 8  The New Jersey Legislative Apportionment Commission adopted a new redistricting plan here this evening for this year's State Assembly and Senate elections.

title: HOGAN WILL SEEK 9TH TERM AS D.A.
description: After months of what he called the anguish of indecision, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan announced yesterday that he would seek a ninth term.

title: CATHOLICS IGNORE BALLOT IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 8Heavy Protestant voting and a Roman Catholic boycott marked the referendum today to decide whether Ulster should remain in the United Kingdom or become part of a United Ireland.

title: How Badillo Lost Crucial N.D.C. Vote
description: At last week's designating convention of the New Democratic Coalition, Representative Harman Badillo's campaign manager declined to cast a vote that could have blocked the mayoral endorsement of Mr. Badillo's main opponent, Assemblyman Albert Blumenthal.

title: RighttoKnow Bill Voted
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., March 8 (AP)  The Vermont Senate adopted a righttoknow law today that Is intended to give the public free access to information about actions of state and local agencies and legislative bodies.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, March 8The season is over for most of the New Jersey college basketball teams. And the coaches, in their last weekly luncheon, tried today to analyze attendance problems.

title: LONDON IS SHAKEN BY TWO BOMBINGS LAID TO THE Is R. A.
description: LONDON, March 8Terrorists struck in London today, setting off two large explosions, near Trafalgar Square and at the Old Bailey, the Central Criminal Court. One man was killed and 243 were injured.

title: Harris Stars in and Directs 'The Hero,' Twilight of an Athlete:The Cast
description: Forty years old, fading star of the Tel Aviv soccer team, not much to show for a life of hard play except slowed reflexes, rich in feelings, of courseand frustrationsbut with nothing you could call a brain, he marshals his meager resources to face his greatest crisis: his Last Big Game. He is pursued by his past and haunted by his future. His fans are fickle, his apartment's a mess and his car won't go.He is Eitan, played by Richard Harris and the subject of Mr. Harris's "The Hero," and I've only begun to list his problems. Perhaps the biggest is Nira (Romy Schneider), beautiful sculptor with a burgeoning career and a fine new car. Eitan loves Fira, and after six years of courtship still doesn't know what to do about it. But his worst problem may be the littlest: Nimrod (kim Burfield), a kid from a kibbutz who lives for soccer and idolizes Eitan. He is a constant reproach. While Eitan drowns his sorrows in vodka Nimrod refuses ice cream conesso as not to break training.Anyone familiar with the tradition of the Last Big Game can supply the rest: the careless friends, the callous owners, the fears of age against the demands of youth. It all comes too easily, a kind of prepackaged drama with the fatal distinction that not only is the story formula, but the emotional response must be formula as well.As a director, and as an actor, Mr. Harris isn't about to deny himself indulgences. His performance is full of too many emphases, appeals to sympathy, expressions of imprecise rage. But his movie is equally mannered. And it is simply the nature of the medium that it can survive an excessive performance better than a gratuitous camera angle or a passage of lyrical slow-motion intended to force a feeling.When Eitan faces his team's managers (he is being offered a contract that will effectively put him out to pasture) he sits on a low stool in the center of an almost bare roomlike Joan of Arc before the ecclesiastical court at Rouen. A crooked gambler who bribes him to throw the game (you thought you'd escaped that?) materializes out of the shadows, and tempts Eitan with a convertible that almost glows in the dark. But the game itself is thrown away in a confused mess of fancy editing, and whatever might have shown the meaning in an athlete's life is lost in an attempt to make cinematic points.Through this movie, as through so much of her mature career, Romy Schneider moves like a bemused enigma, beautiful, mysterious and unexciting. The boy, Kim Burfield, is an accomplished actorbut he is directed very broadly, for a style to match Mr. Harris's. But there are no career predictions to be made from "The Hero." Though it opened here only yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room, it is not a new film, and it played at European festivals three years ago under the name "Bloomfield."

title: Rhine Enlists Its Grave Robbers
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, March 8At a time when illegal digging for ancient art treasures is making headlines elsewhere, museum directors in the Rhineland are coping quietly and successfully with the phenomenon by hiring amateur grave robbers.

title: F.B.I ACCUSED EY CAMDEN 28
description: CAMDEN, March 8  The Camden 28, accused of destroying draft files in 1971, charged today that Federal, Bureau of Investigation policy had created the raid.

title: C.B.S., N.B.A. Agree
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Basketball Association announced yesterday that the television network would broadcast N.B.A. games for three years, starting with the 197374 season.

title: Folk Music
description: Doubts concerning the current health of folk music can easily be dispelled by a visit to Paul Colby's Bitter End on Bleecker Street or Gerde's Folk City, West Eighth Street.

title: 3 Groups Organize Coalition in Support Of Public Workers
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 Three organizations representing more than two million public employes joined today in a formal coalition with the aim of achieving parity with private industry for workers in the public sector.

title: City Hall Barred Dismissal Of 2 in TicketFixing Case
description: Commissioner of Investigation Nicholas Scoppetta disclosed yesterday that the Lindsay administration had ignored a recommendation of his predecessor to dismiss two of the three city officials who were indicted on Wednesday on charges of fixing more than 1,000 parking tickets in Brooklyn.

title: Rocky Night at Garden Tonight
description: I hope he still can't hit as hard as he used to, or we'll end up in a street fight. He is Tony Zale, and the speaker is the man Zale knocked out twice, Rocky Graziano, in two of their three world middleweight championship brawls a quarter of a century ago.

Nicholas Scoppetta disclosed yesterday that the Lindsay administration had ignored a recommendation of his prodecessor to dismiss two of the three city officials who were indicted on Wednesday on charges of fixing more than 1,000 parking tickets in Brooklyn.

title: Carrier Going to Pacific
description: ALAMEDA Calif. March 8 (AP)  The Coral Sea will be the first attack carrier deployed to the Western Pacific since the Vietnam ceasefire when she sails tomorrow, the Navy says.

title: Red Smith
description: MIAMI, March 8Hunter's Marauders were playing Staller's Brawlers and the coaches were clearly ahead of the hitters. Coaches and managers in the Baltimore organization were doubling as pitchers in a sixinning struggle between pickup teams managed by Billy Hunter and George Staller, who work on the coaching lines for Earl Weaver during the regular season. Weaver sat on a funeral parlor chair in the sun looking intelligent and svelte. Earl was the greatest manager on earth in 1970 and the greatest in the American League in 1969 and 1971, but last year he wasn't even the greatest in the American League's Eastern Division. This may explain why his weight has plummeted like his team's batting average, giving him the soigne look, If this guy hits one, a Baltimore newspaperman said, the hall will never he found. He hits 'em over those palm trees and the ball is still rising when it disappears. They had to send him out of camp early last year because he was embarrassing' the regulars.

title: House Offered Bill to Ban Commodity Option Trading
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)Representative Paul Findley, Republican of Illinois, introduced legislation today that he said would have the effect of banning commodity option trading. The legislation would bring all commodities traded on exchanges under the Commodity Exchange Authority.

description: Two independent sets of experiments, involving the highest energy collisions ever achieved in a laboratory, have shown that the proton, one of the fundamental building blocks of the atom, gets increasingly fat when accelerated to great energy.

description: March 9, 1973

Y., March 8A recordsetting performance by Curtis Hayden in the 500yard freestyle, coupled with a firstplace finish in the 400yard medley relay tonight, enabled Princeton to take a surprising lead after the first day of competition in the Eastern Seaboard Swimming and Diving Championships.

description: I know one thing for sure, said the black man hurrying along Marcy Street to Patrolman Irving E. Wright's funeral. I don't want my son to be a cop. He can be a truck driver or a ditchdigger, but not a policeman.

title: WELLESLEY SAYS IT WON'T CO COED
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., March 8Concluding that coeducation is a failure in terms of women's education, the trustees of Wellesley College have decided to buck the current national, trend and continue to award degrees to women only.

title: WHOLESALE INDEX OF PRICES SURGED DURING FEBRUARY
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 The wholesale price index rose sharply again in February, partly because of increases in food costs but also because of the largest onemonth rise in 22 years in the prices of industrial commodities.

title: Books of The Times
description: Fantastic! Twelve years ago, in 1961, there appeared among us a large, labyrinthine novel called V. (in which, among 10,000 other things, the 22d letter of the alphabet was convincingly made to stand for just about anything you wanted in to). It was by a young writer named Thomas Pynchon, of whom we knew virtually nothing, and it was, to say the least, oat of the more remarkable first novels to be published in this country in several decades. Four years later came a sort of postscriptural squiggle, a short but mysteriously beautiful novella called The Crying of Lot 49 (whose title could also be read in a number of different ways), but we still knew very little about Pynchon except that he could write. Then a long silenceno surfacing, no interviews, no rumors, no word. And now, seven years later, like the screaming ... across the sky with which it begins (It has happened before, but there is nothing to compare it to now.), comes Pynchon's third novel, Gravity's Rainbow (the number of ways you can read this title are practically infinite). And though we still have learned nothing of Pynchon's extraliterary life, we now know he is one of our literary treasures. For Gravity's Rainbow is fantasticfantastically large, complex, funny, perplexing, daring, and weirdweird as an experience you've never been though before. Fantastic!

title: HINTERSEBR WINS CUP GIANT SLALOM
description: MOUNT AiLYESKA, Alaska, March 8 (AP)Hansi Hinterseer of Austria, with a combined time of 3 minutes 45.37 seconds, took first place today in the men's World Cup giant slalom.

description: Mixed prices and slow trading characterized the performance of stocks yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market.

title: Allott Gets Post From Man He Aided
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Former Senator Gordon Allott of Colorado, who was defeated for reelection last November, has been given a $60,000ayear Government job by a fellow Republican whom Mr. Allott approved for a top patronage position in the Post Office nearly 20 years ago.

title: BRICE M. MACE JR. OF FOREIGN SERVICE
description: Brice M. Mace Jr., a career Foreign Service officer and an agricultural economist, died yesterday of cancer. He was 84 years old and lived at 360 East 72d Street.

title: Too Few for a Blizzard of '88 Reunion
description: The Blizzard Men and Ladies of 1888 are defunct. No longer do they meet, as they had since 1927 to mark the March 12 anniversary of the great snow that engulfed and isolated the city 85 years ago.

title: Saigon Frees 500 Communist P.O.W.'s
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 8 (Reuters)South Vietnam released 500 Communist prisoners of war to the North today, but one of them, a North Vietnamese corporal, refused to cross the border and decided to remain in the South.

title: DOW CHEMICAL SETS AN OXIDE PRICE RISE
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it would raise its price for ethylene oxide by 0.5 cent a pound, beginning April 1. The new price will be 7.5 cents a pound.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 2.3 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 148.4 from 146.1 last week.

title: Saigon, Explaining Newsman's Ouster, Charges Distortion
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 8  The Government elaborated today on its charges against an American correspondent who has been ordered expelled from South Vietnam.

title: Advertising: L.&M. Makes Shift
description: After 12 years as a client of J. Walter Thompson, Liggett & Myers is moving all of its cigarette brands to other agencies. The total billings involved are estimated at $12million.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two tuberculosis associations asserted yesterday that the Hackensack Meadowlands development would violate cleanair standards. They threatened to file suit in Federal court unless the United States Environmental Protection Agency made a full inquiry of the development.

title: NORTH CAROLINA UPSET, 54 TO 52
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., March 8 (AP)  Phil Perry's layup that just beat the final horn in overtime gave cellardwelling Wake Forest a 5452 victory over secondseeded North Carolina today in one of the great upsets of Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament history.

title: Such Good Friends of Solzhenitsyn
description: MOSCOWNow that Zhores Medvedev has poked, as a good friend, in our family life in the columns of The New York Times, I feel obliged to step in, especially since Aleksanclr Solzhenitsyn himself maintains an approving silence.

description: WASHINGTON, March 8 The White House expressed concern today at the release of what it termed raw, unevaluated material from the files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation that linked a former high aide of President Nixon to an alleged political sabotage operation last year.

title: Terror Moves From TV Screens to the Streets
description: LONDON, March 8 The terror of Northern Ireland, visible nightly on television screens, has always seemed far away to Londoners. But today, they had their own panic: bloodshed, sirens, smoldering automobiles, piles of smashed glass and tales of horror.

title: Witnesses Call Drug Plan Harsh
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 8The consensus of more than 100 witnesses Who testified on Governor Rockefeller's controversial penalties for narcotics offenses is that the proposed penalties are too rigid and severe, several members of the State Senate and Assembly Codes Committees said today as the 11th and last of the statewide hearings was held here today.

title: MICROWAVE PERILS HELD EXAGGERATED
description: WASHINGTON, March (AP)  While acknowledging that certain mechanical factors of microwave ovens could be improved, the Federal Food and Drug Administration said today that the magazine Consumer Reports had exaggerated the dangers to human health.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Terrorists struck in London yesterday, setting off two large explosions that killed one man, injured more than 200 people and created more chaos than the city had seen since World War II. Authorities believe the bombings, near Trafalgar Square and at Old Bailey, the Central Criminal Court, were the work of the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army and that they had been timed to coincide with the referendum in Northern Ireland on British control of the province. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: ELLSBERG TRIAL TOLD ABOUT LIE
description: LOS ANGELES, March 8A Central Intelligence Agency analyst testified today in the Pentagon papers trial that he had been lied to in a definite attempt on the part of the Government to prevent me from testifying in this court.

title: Carnival's High Toll in Rio
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 8, (AP)A total of 150 bodies were delivered to the morgue here during the annual fourday carnival that ended early yesterday. Most of the dead had been shot, knifed, orb drowned or had fallen from high places.

title: MICROWAVE PERILS HELD EXAGGERATED

title: Billy Taylor Plays As Piano Soloist, Showing Virtuosity

Wednesday, as part of Town Hall's 5:45 Interludes series, Mr. Taylor appeared as an unaccompanied piano soloist, a situation that gave him opportunities to show his virtuosity in ways that do not usually arise either with a trio or a big band.

description: MIAMI BEACH, March 8 (UPI)Miami Beach's supply of drinking water is contaminated with organisms from human waste, Dr. Milton Saslaw, Dade County health director, told the County Commission today.

description: The United Hospital Fund has announced that it gave grants totaling $136,498 to hospitals in the city in 1972. The money, raised through campaigns of the hospital fund and the Greater New York Fund, helps in launching demonstration projects and special studies for more economic and more effective health care, said Douglas T. Yates, the hospital fund director.

description: WASHINGTON, March 8Congressional challenges to President Nixon's budgetcutting continued today with House passage of a $2.6billion vocational rehabilitation bill that was vetoed last fall.

title: Class Is Going to ItalyBut First the Little Matter of Earning Money for the Trip
description: Toni Ross raffled off concert tickets. Susan Schorr hemmed skirts. Eric Edelman ran errands and distributed leaflets. Jon Pintoff and his friends had jackets, sweatshirts and Tshirts made up with the school name on them and sold them for a little more than they cost.

title: Salina (Cont.)
description: SALINA, Kan.Writing in answer to my article (OpEd, Feb. 15), Lloyd L. Brown made a valid complaint (OpEd, Feb. 26). That is, it was valid thirty years ago when he was a soldier stationed near this Kansas town.

title: Spotlight on the I.R.S.
description: The nature of the assignment given the Internal Revenue Service guarantees that it will never enjoy wide popularity, however necessary its function. Nevertheless, the I. R. S. has operated for many years with surprisingly little Congressional oversight or organized public criticism. Now, however, a Senate Appropriations subcommittee has listened to critical testimony about the I. R. S.'s operations and asked it to do more to pratect individual taxpayers' rights. The Senators have also called on it to diminish secrecy about private tax rulings. And Ralph Nader had added his voice to the antiI. R. S. chorus, calling for a three year Congressional study of the agency.

Dr. King, 52 years old, was charged with trying to enlist a Trenton State Prison inmate and a state police detective, who posed as a professional killer, in a scheme to kill his former wife, her present husband and her sister.

title: ...Through the Roof
description: The destructive effects of President Nixon's illadvised decision to relax mandatory wageprice controls find alarming expression in the official wholesale price report for February, first full month of Phase 3. Not only did the unbelievably steep climb of food prices continue, with meat prices again far out in front, but buyers had to reckon with a disturbing new factor directly traceable to the premature ending of Phase 2: a sharp upsurge the industrial segment of the index.

title: Notes on People
description: Edith Irving, the wife of the imprisoned author, Clifford Irving, was sentenced by a Zurich court to two years for her role in Switzerland in the Howard R. Hughes autobiography hoax. A court official said Mrs. Irving, whose husband is serving a twoandahalfyear sentence in Feedral prison, would be eligible for parole in about 15 months.

title: DIPLOMATIC AGENT WINS COAST STAKE
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 8 (AP)Laffit Pincay Jr. had four winners today at Santa Anita but wound up third in the $34,900 Sierra Madre Handicap, won by Diplomatic Agent, his first victory since 1971.

title: Aid at S.I. Blast
description: Your Red Cross in New York responded immediately to the Police Department's request for assistance at the site of the Feb. 10 storage  tank explosion on Staten Island. Minutes after the blast, relatives of the men who had been working at the tank began arriving at the scene. The Red Cross set up a shelter at the 122d Precinct station house on Hyland Boulevard and for 24 hours Red Cross volunteer disaster workers and volunteer nurses joined members of the clergy to comfort the families and to register the men reported missing.

title: Witnesses Call Drug Plan Harsh
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 8The consensus of more than 100 witnesses who testified on Governor Rockefeller's controversial penalties for narcotics offenses is that the proposed penalties are too rigid and severe, several members of the State Senate and Assembly Codes Committees said today as the 11th and last of the statewide hearings was held here today.

title: ALEX WARDEN
description: GREAT FALLS, Mont., March 8 (AP)Alex Warden, former publisher of The Great Falls Tribune, died yesterday in Palm Springs, Calif., hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Literacy Drive Brings Hope to Rural Brazil
description: PIRACICABA, Brazil Farmhands on the sugar plantations here are beginning to talk and dream about escaping their dreary condition.

title: Grumman Yields to Navy; Accepts Listed F14 Price
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation gave in yesterday to the Navy's demand that it produce the next batch of 48 F14 fighter planes at the $16.8million unit price in the existing contract. Grumman says this price is more than $2million below its unit costs.

title: Miss Evert and Miss Goolagong Gain in Dallas Tennis Tourney
description: DALLAS, March 8 (UPI) Topseeded Chris Evert defeated Lesley Charles of England, 60, 62, tonight to advance to the quarterfinals of the $37,000 Maureen Connolly Brinker tennis tournament.

title: 2 More Chopin Waltzes Found by Byron Janis
description: Byron Janis, the pianist, who found the autograph manuscripts of two of Chopin's waltzes in a French chateau in 1967, has found two other versions of them in Chopin's own hand in the Yale University library, he said Wednesday.

title: New Paper Published
description: GEORGETOWN, S.C., March 8 (AP)  The Georgetown American, South Carolina's newest daily newspaper, began publishing yesterday with a 16page edition. The morning paper has an initial circulation of 4,500, its publisher, Robert Cunningham, said.

title: Korean Leads at Singapore
description: SINGAPORE, March 8 (AP) Kim Seung Hack of South Korea shot a threeunderpar 68 today to take a onestroke lead after the first round of the $24,000 Singapore open golf championship.

title: ROBERT C. DE LELLIS, DIRECTOR OF P.A.L.
description: Robert C. de Lellis, executive director of the Police Athletic League, died yesterday of cancer at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived at 10849 63d Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Yesterday's Dances Put on New Footing By Joffrey Troupe
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet's current repertory is particularly strong on the stylized treatment of popular and social dances. Interplay comments on the nineteenforties; Jive does so for the fifties, and Trinity and Deuce Coupe say something about the sixties.

title: BLUMENTHALGBTS BACKING OF A.D.A.
description: The local chapter of the Americans for Democratic Action voted last night to support Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal for Mayor.

title: Jersey Study Unit Adopts New Apportionment Plans.
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 8The New Jersey Legislative Apportionment Commission adopted a new redistricting plan here this evening for this year's State Assembly and Senate elections.

title: SchoolBus Driver Guilty in 5 Deaths
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., March 8Joseph Larkin, who was driving the school bus that was hit by a train near here a year ago, was found guilty tonight of five counts of criminally negligent homicideone count for each Nyack High School student killed in the crash.

title: Screen: 'Ludwig,' a Study in Depravity, Arrives
description: Ludwig II became king of Bavaria in 1864, at the age of 19, and more or less misruled until he was certified insane, three days before his suicide in 1886. He was not a good man. Like A. A. Milne's King John, Ludwig had his whims and ways, only a few of which have put posterity in his debt: he was Richard Wagner's friend and patron through thick and thin, and he was responsible for the construction of some of Bavaria's maddest castles, including the spectacular Neuschwanstein. Yesterday's fiscal scandal is today's tourist attraction, but Ludwig was mostly a rotter.It's this aspect of Ludwig that seems most to fascinate Luchino Visconti, the great Italian director whose preoccupation with things Germanic is resulting in films of progressively less importance."The Damned" (1969), as operatic as it was, was a hugely effective evocation of a civilization's collapse as detailed in the terrible deeds of a Krupp-like munitions family. Visconti's adaptation of Mann's "Death in Venice" (1971) failed, but it failed with such consistent intelligence that one was always aware of a system of ideas within it."Ludwig," which opened yesterday at the 59th Street Twin 2 Theater, is opera buffa that doesn't know it. Visconti and his writers give us the story of Ludwig's reign (or, at least, the outline of it) in a manner that is meant to be grand but actually is just a frantic inventory of what historians usually call his excesseshis rather superficial appreciation for art and architecture, his love of sweets (which resulted in his teeth falling out) and especially his love affairs with a series of grooms, actors and other pretty fellows.Visconti has been such an intelligent film maker in the past that it's difficult to believe that "Ludwig" could be quite as bereft of ideas as it is. Is it about kingship? About the genesis of the Second Reich under the domination of the Prussian dynasty? About family? I don't think so. All of these things are touched upon at one point or another, in the almost three hours of running time, but always in what would be called telephone scenes in a contemporary dramathe sort of get-it-over-with scenes designed to give us necessary information as quickly as possible.Mostly "Ludwig" consists of the spectacle of Ludwig (Helmut Berger) getting more and more depraved, from the early scenes in which he delays his coronation to drink champagne from a goblet (in movies about depravity, people always drink from goblets, not glasses) to those in which he spies on one of his grooms bathing nude in the castle lake, until, toward the end, there's a full-scale, though fairly lethargic orgy. We've seen most of these things done better in other Visconti films.It may be one of my biases, but movies about royal personages, usually trike me as being essentially comic. It has something to do with a lot of ordinary folk trying to act like royals, and usually succeeding in looking only like stage extras. The royals in "Ludwig" all seem a little second-rate, even Romy Schneider, who plays Ludwig's cousin, the Empress Elizabeth of Austria, with whom he thinks he is sort of in love. It also has something to do with the rhythm of drama in which so much emphasis is placed on the arrivals and departures of royal carriages, on entrances up grand staircases and on people walking regally through doorways.These things give "Ludwig" an air of self-importance that it doesn't deserve, any more than it deserves the almost nonstop Wagner and Schumann on the soundtrack. The images can't compete.There is one interesting performance in the entire film. Trevor Howard makes a rather British Wagner, but he is a profoundly interesting combination of self-absorption, craftiness, genius and vision. Because everyone else acts as if trying to make an impression during the eruption of a volcano, the comparative understatement of Howard's performance rivets the attention.

title: F.T.C. Plans Suit To Block Pepsico On Rheingold. Bid
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday it would seek a court order to prevent Pepsico, Inc., from exercising control over the Rheingold Corporation.

title: Grumman Yields to Navy; Accepts Listed F14 Price
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation gave in yesterday to the Navy's demand that it produce the next batch of F14 fighter planes at the $16.8million unit price in the existing contract. Grumman says this price is more than 2million below its unit costs.

title: 12% Rise Expected In Company Profits
description: Despite inflation fears and monetary jitters, 1973 profits before taxes of United States corporations are currently expected to increase 12 per cent to a record of $96.4billion from $86.2billion last year, the economics department of the McGrawHill Publications Company stated yesterday in its annual survey of profit trends.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: About 2,000 policemen attended the funeral yesterday for Patrolman Irving E. Wright, who was mistakenly shot and killed Monday by two fellow policemen in Harlem.

title: 309 Soviet Jews Appeal to Jackson and Mills for Help in Getting Exit Visas to Go to Israel
description: MOSCOW, March 8  About 300 Jewish intellectuals appealed to leaders of the United States Congress today for help in emigrating to Israel.

title: BUTZ FORECASTS RECORD EXPORTS
description: CHICAGO, March 8  Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz forecast today a record shattering $11billion of farm commodity exports during the current fiscal year which ends June 30.

title: Hijacking Suspect Guarded In Spokane Hospital Room
description: SPOKANE, Wash., March 8 (UPI)The police posted a guard today outside the hospital room of a college student who has been wounded by an airport guard during a hijacking attempt that followed the shotgun death of the student's wife. He is Larry J. Bonner, 24 years old, a senior at Eastern Washington State College.

title: 17 County Aides Held In Contempt in Detroit
description: DETROIT, March 8 (UPI) Seventeen of the 27 Wayne County Commissioners were sentenced to jail today for contempt of court in a showdown over contract negotiations with the county's probation officers.

title: TV Demand May Keep Giants Out of Yale Bowl
description: NEW HAVEN, March 8 (AP)Yale University's secretary, Henry Chauncey, said today that Yale would not rent its stadium to the New York Giants unless WTICTV in Hartford is allowed to televise the games and WCBS in New York is blacked out.

title: How Participants Stand
description: BRUSSELS, March 8Following are the positions the major participants at the monetary conference tomorrow in Paris:

title: Connecticut House Backs Amendment On Women's Rights
description: HARTFORD, March 8  The Connecticut House of Representatives voted by a margin of more than 2to1 today to approve the proposed United States constitutional amendment giving equal rights to women.

title: NUMBERS CHOSEN IN DRAFT LOTTERY
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 Although the military draft is scheduled to expire June 30, the Selective Service System held today its fifth annual national draft lottery, for men born in 1954.

title: Actions on Bills Opposed by Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Following is a table of Congressional action this year on major legislation that President Nixon vetoed after Congress adjourned last year and on programs that the President proposes to terminate. All votes so far have been affirmative.

title: STYLISTICS PERFORM SOUL AT THE APOLLO
description: The Stylistics are one of the most successful acts in contemporary soul music, and their show at the Apollo Theater (253 West 125th Street) should provide a lot of pleasure for those who like such music sweet, suave and harmonized.

title: Baseball Signings
description: KANSAS CITYAmos Otis, outfielder; Tom Burgmeler, pitcher.

title: 2 Civil Rights Groups Weigh Merger
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 Two prominent civil rights leaders, Dr. Ralph David Abernathy and the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, will meet this weekend in an attempt to, resolve their differences and possibly to merge their organizations.

title: U.S. AND INDIANS REACH CEASEFIRE
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., March 8A ceasefire agreement between Federal officials and militant Indians holding this reservation hamlet was reached tonight, but gunfire broke out on the perimeter of Wounded Knee minutes later and two indians were wounded, neither seriously.

title: UNIT IN EGRESS SETS TRADE PUN
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 A SenateHouse subcommittee, with a number of individual dissents on specific points, recommended today a new trade policy for the United States that appears very close to what President Nixon is expected to propose shortly.

title: Dickinson Rolls 300 but Misses Objective
description: A prime example of what inconsistency can do to a bowler in a grueling professional tournament was experienced yesterday by Gary Dickinson in the $75,000 United States open sponsored by the Bowling Proprietors Association of America at Madison Square Garden.

title: Archibald Breaks Robertson's Mark As Kings Triumph
description: OMAHA, Neb., March 8 (UPI) Nate Archibald, scoring 29 points, broke Oscar Robertson's team season scoring record tonight as the Kansas CityOmaha Kings gained a 10593 National Basketball Association victory over the Baltimore Bullets.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Ralston Purina Company yesterday said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with an offering of 802,194 common shares for employes under its 1972 incentive compensation plan. The company's stock was up 1 at 41 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: At 19, She Hopes Her Days as a Prostitute Are Over
description: Her father is a prominent Ithaca businessman. Her stepmother is a social worker and Democratic bigwig. And Jenny is a former prostitute, trying very hard to go straight.

title: No Place to Go But Up
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 8 (AP)  Henry Vansant, former assistant coach at East Carolina University, was named today as head football coach at Guilford College, which has a 25game losing streak dating to

title: France's Contradictions
description: PARIS, March 8France, perhaps even more than other countries represented at tomorrow's emergency monetary meeting here, has taken a stand in which economic and political requirements are almost inextricably entwined.

title: Shortterm Rates Mixed
description: Interest rates floated a bit higher yesterday but the money and capital markets had a generally good tone that was not much affected by the report that wholesale prices climbed last month at the fastest clip since 1951.

title: Bridge: 5,000 Players to Compete In League's Spring Contest
description: ST. LOUIS, March 8The advance guard of 5,000 bridge players gathered here today, prepared to battle for the next 10 days in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring National Champion. ships.

title: Leary Denied Postponement
description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., March 8 (UPI)Superior Court Judge Timothy O'Reilly refused yesterday to postpone the trial of Timothy Leary, the LSD advocate, for escaping from prison. The trial will begin Tuesday.

title: MORE RETAIL CHAINS POST GAINS IN SALES
description: Several more large retail chains reported yesterday increased sales for February over the same 1972 month, continuing a trend evidenced in earlier announcements for the period.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: A quarterpage advertisement in the sports section of last Sunday's edition of The New York Times extolled the deadly charms of what is described as the world's first selfpropelled fishing lure.

title: SILVER FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Silver futures broke sharply in price on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, reflecting declining worry about the dollar and a belief that world monetary meetings in Paris might result in action to lessen currency speculation.

title: Canadian on Truce Unit Criticizes Communists
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 10 (Reuters) Canada sharply criticized the two Communist members of the International Commission for Control and Supervision of the Vietnam ceasefire today for failing to investigate allegations that the North Vietnamese had set up missile sites at Khe Sanh in South Vietnam.

title: Highs and Lows
description: New York Stock Exchange

title: Equity Financing
description: Electro/Data, Inc., Garland, Texas, yesterday announced its offering of transferrable rights to subscribe for up to 1,375,932 shares of its common stock was unsuccessful. The minimum number of shares was not subscribed for by the expiration date, March 6. Accordingly, monies that were received are being returned to subscribers and the company said it was exploring alternatives to meet cash requirements.

title: Rumanians Win Foils Cup
description: TURIN, Italy, March 9 (UPI) The Steaua fencing club of Bucharest won the European women's foils cup match for the third straight year, defeating Vasutas of Budapest, 93, in the finals. Dynamo of Moscow took third, beating the Milan Savings Bank, 96.

title: Duryea Seeks State Unit To Fund Local Stadiums
description: Assembly Speaker Perry S. Duryea called yesterday for the creation of a State Sports Authority that would be allowed to issue up to $350million in revenue bonds to help New York communities develop and modernize their sports facilities.

title: Alabama, N. Carolina in N.I.T. Field
description: The National Invitation Tournament basketball field was all but completed yesterday with the addition of Alabama and North Carolina to the 16team lineup. The tournament starts next Saturday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Nixons at Camp David
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., March 9 (UPI) President and Mrs. Nixon flew by helicopter late this afternoon to this retreat in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains, about 60 miles from Washington. The Nixons were met by unseasonably warm weather.

title: Six Roads Join Move
description: The Southern Pacific Company, which has an agreement with the Union Pacific Railroad to pay the Union Pacific $120million for the southern lines of the. Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific, in the event of a Union PacificRock Island merger, now wants the Interstate Commerce Commission to dismiss the complex case. In a petition to the commission, in which it was joined by six other Western roads, the Southern Pacific said it would be in the public interest to dismiss the case, which has been before the Commission for 10 yeats and has involved all the railroads in the West.

title: Indians Given Support
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 9 (UPI) An organization called Concerned Native Americans From Arizona staged a peaceful demonstration in front of the Federal Building here today in support of the Indians who seized the Wounded Knee settlement in South Dakota Feb. 28.

title: Adm. Charles W. Thomas Dead; Polar Explorer and War Hero
description: Rear Adm. Charles W. Thomas, retired Coast Guard polar explorer and icebreaking expert who captured two German weather stations in Greenland and an armed trawler in World War II, was killed with his wife, Lorinda, in an automobile accident in Ushuaia, Argentina, last Saturday, He was 69 years old and lived in Alton, N. H.

description: BASEBALL

title: POMILLION GOES TO 2 UNIVERSITIES
description: The Danforth Foundation of St. Louis will make grants totaling $80millionmore than a third of its moneyto Washington University and St. Louis University under a matching fund arrangement, the foundation announced yesterday.

title: HUDSON'S BAY CO. STEPS UP PROFITS
description: The Hudson's Bay Company reported yesterday higher operating net of $15.7million, or $1.16 a share, for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 against $13.3million, or 38 cents a share, in the year earlier.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: China to Free Downey of the C.I.A. Monday
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The White House announced today that the last three Americans held prisoner in China would be set free next week, one of them at the personal request of President Nixon to Premier Chou Enlai.

title: John J. Kelaher, President Of Jersey City Council, Dies
description: JERSEY CITY, March 9 John Maher, president of the City Council here, died yesterday in the Jersey City Medical Center apparently of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: ALVA ROSENBERG, DOG SHOW JUDGE
description: Alva Rosenberg, dean of American dog show judges, died Thursday night of a heart attack in Norwalk Hospital, Norwalk, Conn. He was 80 years old and lived at 526 Danbury Road in Wilton, Conn.

title: COCHRAN TAKES N.O.A.A. DOWNHILL
description: HANCOCK, Vt., March 9Bobby Cochran, the American Olympic star from the nearby village of Richmond, today paced the University of Vermont to the lead of the National Collegiate Athletic Association team skiing championship.

title: Attacks on 3 Boys Here Are Linked to Specific Suspect
description: The police disclosed yesterday that they had linked the murder of a 9yearold boy in Harlem last October with two other attacks, one fatal, against young boys on the Upper West Side, and were looking for a specific suspect. All three incidents involved stabbings and sexual mutilation.

title: U.S. and Cambodia.. At a Critical Crossroad
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 8  The United States has come to a critical juncture in its relationship with Cambodia. In the only country in Indochina that remains fully at war and where American planes carry out daily bombing raids, its policy has been stalemated by both friend and foe. North Vietnam has dashed American hopes that it will extend to Cambodia the scaling down of the war in South Vietnam and Laos.

title: KEOGH CAPTURES 2MILE RUN TITLE
description: DETROIT, March 9Mike Keogh squelched Dave Wottle's bid for a distance double tonight and moved Manhattan into contention for its first team title in the National Collegiate indoor track and field championship.

title: Vietnam Veterans Find Lack of Jobs And Snarl in Aid
description: CLEVELAND, March 9 (AP) Witnesses at a hearing on problems of Vietnam veterans testified here today that benefits in the G. I. bill of rights were inadequate, that jobs were limited and that veterans with drug problems were trapped by a contradiction.

title: Bundy Tells Ellsberg Trial Data Did Not Damage U.S.
description: LOS ANGELES, March 9McGeorge Bundy, one of the architects of America's Vietnam war policy, testified today that disclosure of three of the documents in the Pentagon papers case had not damaged the national defense.

description: John R. Bunting, chairman of the First Pennsylvania Bank, wants the Federal Reserve Board to assume almost direct control over the prime lending rate.
