title: Play Today At Six Sites In N.C.A.A.
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's richest annual showcase event, the major college basketball championship tournament, opens today as 18 of the 25 teams entered play in nine games from New York to Logan, Utah.

title: ADIRONDACK PLAN GIVEN BY AGENCY
description: ALBANY, March 9  A col troversial plan for regulatin the use and development of 3. million acres of private land the vast Adirondack Park we submitted today by the Adiroi dack Park Agency to Governo Rockefeller and the Legislatut over the objections of on agency member, who said was unconstitutional.

title: NEW CHIEF NAMED BY U.S. FINANCIAL
description: U.S. Financial, Inc., announced yesterday that E. T. Gravette Jr. will become its chairman of the board, chief executive officer and president when he resigns as president of Palomar Financial on or about next Thursday.

title: Hugh J. Schuck, 76, Dies; Former Daily News Editor
description: HOUSTON, March 9  Hugh J. Schuck, who retired as cable editor of The New York Daily News, in charge of stories filed by cable, on Dec. 7, 1969, after 35 years with the paper, died today in the Houston Methodist Medical Center, apparently of a heart attack. He was 76 years old and made his home in King of Prussia, Pa.

title: France and the Abortion Struggle
description: PARISWhatever the results of tomorrow's parliamentary elections, the new Assembly is expected to end the almost total ban on contraception and abortion which for decades has kept French women back in the Middle Ages.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, March 9 (UPI)The European Economic Community quietly killed an antiinflation plan today that would have cut tariffs on consumer goods from the United States and other nonmarket nations by 20 percent.

title: Dentist Given First Term For Medicaid Fraud Here
description: A 66yearold Brooklyn dentist was sentenced to prison yesterday as the city's first health practitioner to be convicted of defrauding Medicaid.

title: DENNIS CAREY, 69, LEADER IN JERSEY
description: SPRING LAKE, N. J., March 9Dennis F. Carey, who was the Democratic party chairman for Essex County for 15 years until his retirement in 1968, died yesterday in the Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune. He was 69 years old and lived here.

title: LEHMAN HIGH SHUT BY RACIAL TENSION
description: The new Herbert H. Lehman High School in the northeast Bronx, beset by a heritage of racial polarization and scuffles among students, went through another day of tension yesterday.

title: Military Talks in Laos Near a Breakdown
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 8 Talks between military delegations of the Vientiane Government and the Communistled Pathet Lao seemed close to a breakdown today, with no agreement on any aspect of the creation of peace  keeping machinery in Laos.

title: MAYORAL RIVALS LIST SUPPORTERS
description: Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal and Representative Herman Badillo, the frontrunning candidates for reform Democratic backing in the mayoral race, squared off yesterday in a namedropping contest as they listed supporters in rival news conferences.

title: Budget Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI)  B. A. Bridgewater Jr., 38 years old, of Chicago, was named today as associate director of the office of management and budget for national security and international affairs. Mr. Bridgewater formerly was a senior partner of McKinsey & Co., Inc., a management consulting firm.

title: Bombs in London
description: It is virtually certain that the cowardly fanatics who caused death, injury and destruction in London by exploding their bombs among hundreds of innocent passersby were I.R.A. extremists protesting the Ulster referendum on the issue of keeping Northern Ireland the United Kingdom or unifying it with the Republic of Ireland. Just why the bombers thought that they would help their cause by this outrage is a mystery probably best probed by psychiatrists.

title: WINE TALK
description: LONDONBerry Bros. & Rudd, a liquor store at 3 St. James's Street here, is one of the oldest establishments of its kind in the world, It goes back at least to 1699. The company originated and still owns Cutty Sark Scotch. Princes, statesmen, poets and American gangsters have been among its customers. And yet, for some reason, the store is best known for its peculiar practice of weighing people.

title: Bundy Tells Ellsberg Trial Data Did Not Damage U.S.
description: LOS ANGELES, March 9McGeorge Bundy, one of the architects of America's Vietnam war policy, testified today that disclosure of three of the documents in the Pentagon papers case had not damaged the national defense.

title: Art: Abstracts by Herbin
description: It is one of the paradoxes of the history of the School of Paris that abstract painting remained for so many years after its initial appearance (circa 1913) a minority interest even among members of the avantgarde. Neither Picasso nor Braque nor Matisse, whose innovations led to abstraction, was ever really interested in pursuing its implications in his own art. As late as the nineteenthirties, the pioneers of abstraction Mondrian, Kanclinsky and others  remained isolated figures on the Paris art scene, admired by small circles of the faithful but unheralded; if not indeed unnoticed, by the cultivated public that had no trouble accepting cubism, surrealism and other nonabstract pictorial styles.

title: N.M.U. Pension Trustees Vote $4,464.77 Monthly for Curran
description: The trustees of the officers pension fund of the National Maritime Union disclosed yesterday'that they had approved payment of a monthly benefit of $4,464.77 for Joseph Curran, retiring president of the 50,000member seamen's union.

title: Campus Notes
description: Last fall Cornell University started a new system of punishing campus lawbreakers by giving them the choice of paying a finethe usual penalty for pilferage of campus property or vandalismor volunteering for work on projects at the university or in the Ithaca, N. Y., community.

title: U.S. Investors Hopeful On Taiwan's Economy
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Ross D. Siragusa Jr., president of the Admiral Corporation, announced here recently that his company would increase its capital investment in Taiwan by more than 50 per cent to carry out a large expansion of its Taiwan production facilities.

title: Black Studies Get New Lexicon
description: College blackstudies programs, although still young, are beginning to develop a new lexicon, which scholars and students at a three day symposium at Queens College said was needed to convert the study of the black experience into practical tools in the black struggle.

title: Perth Amboy Is Ordered To Shut 25 Impure Wells
description: TRENTON, March 9  The State Environmental Protection Ijepartment ordered the Perth Amboy Water Department today to shut down 25 wells that help provide potable water for the city's 40,000 residents because of contamination.

title: Parents of Quints Get Hospital Bill: $13,000
description: CHICAGO, March 9 (UPI)  James and Lynn Baer, Who became the parents of quintuplets two months ago, got their hospital bill today $13,000,

title: New Braille Ends Ambiguities
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 In research funded by the Office of Education, a specialist in communication for the handicapped has invented a new form of Braille. Haig Kafafian has rearranged the patterns terns of raised of dots to avoid amWeek biguities that he says the blind now encounter. Patent 3,718,991 was granted Mr. Kafafian this week for his system of tactile characters and for the slate and stylus used in punching dots through paper so that they can be read by touch. He has given the Government rights under the patent.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TUCSON, Ariz., March 9 (AP)The Cleveland Indians traded Alex Johnson, an outfielder, to the Texas Rangers today for Rich Hinton and Vice Colbert, pitchers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A little more than just a year ago you lent your column to a comment that the United States was undervaluing its main reserve assetgoldand that this was something we could ill afford.

title: Trevino Maintains FourStroke Lead
description: MIAMI, March 9A thunderstorm halted the round for 30 minutes, but when play resumed today in the $150,000 Doral Eastern open, Lee Trevino continued his subpar golf and maintained his fourstroke lead with a 36hole total of 134.

title: ACCORD REPORTED AT WOUNDED KNEE
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., March 9Department of Justice officials said today that they had reached an agreement in principle that could end the 11day standoff between Federal forces and the dissident Indians who are occupying the hamlet of Wounded Knee, 15 miles northeast of here.

title: Arthur E. Sutherland Dies at 71; Authority on Constitutional Law
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 9Arthur E. Sutherland, Bussey Professor of Law emeritus of Harvard Law School and an authority on constitutional and commercial law, died last night of cancer. He was 71 years old and lived here.

title: Britons, Swiss Test French Air Control In Wake of Crash
description: PARIS, March 9 (UPI)Air experts from Britain and Switzerland met with French authorities today to discuss a traffic control crisis that has caused 35 airlines to cancel flights to and across France since the collision of two Spanish jetliners over Nantes on Monday.

title: Mail to Davits and Buckley Dominated By Letters From the Foes of Abortion
description: WASHINGTON, March 9What are New Yorkers writing about most to their Senators these days? Food prices? New York City problems?

title: Notes on People
description: Alan Paton, the South African author, said that although he is now 70 years old, he will continue to try to right wrongs. In a talk to students at Yale, Mr. Paton, long an opponent of apartheid in his own country, said: We may boast, and our Prime Minister has boasted, that we could eat the Zambian Army for breakfast, but I think we know that we would never eat another. He added, It's no use giving up, is it? Because then what are you going to do with your life?

title: Dave Anderson
description: In the cool of dawn, before the sun broiled the Jamaica foliage, Sandy Saddler ran with George Foreman around the Kingston reservoir.

title: Play Today At Six Sites In N.C.A.A.
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's richest annual showcase event, the major college basketball championship tournament, opens today as 18 of the 25 teams entered play in nine games from New York to Logan, Utah.

title: Vanden Heuvel Invites Hogan To Debate and Gets Acceptance
description: William S. vanden Heuvel, who is seeking the Democratic nomination as Manhattan District Attorney, yesterday challenged Frank S. Hogan, who has held the office 32 years, to a series of public debates, and Mr. Hogan accepted.

title: U.S. Offers Europe Help In Settling Money Crisis
description: PARIS, March 9The United States offered today cooperate with the European Economic Community to help settle the most severe monetary crisis since the nineteen thirties and to insure jointly an orderly exchangerate system.

title: BRITAIN HOLDS 10 IN TWO BOMBINGS
description: LONDON, March 9The terrorists who set off yesterday's two large explosions in central London were described today as members of a special squad sent here within the last 10 days by the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Jerusalem: Not a Barrier but a Gateway
description: King Hussein's recent statement dealt with the Middle East issues honestly, positively, comprehensively, brilliantly. No wonder that it has been hailed on all sides as a courageous step forward toward a peace settlement.

title: Seat on Big Board Sells At Nearly 3Year Low
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange sold yesterday at $135,000, or the lowest price paid for a membership in nearly three years.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The Journey Store, like so many of the shops on the Avenue of the Americas in the twenties, carries potted plants. But its scope is wider than that, extending to pillows, greeting cards, pottery, Plexiglas planters and a portrait studio. And it is hardly the usual neighborhood ventureit's run by 30 men and women, who design and make most of the stock and staff the store.

title: No Knockdowns, No Decisions, But a Garden Full of Memories
description: It started slowly in the bars around Madison Square Garden. A rustling tide of nostalgia tinged with fistic blood spilled a quartercentury ago.

title: Vietcong Says Peace Unit Is Discussed With Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 9Lieut. Gen. Tran Van Tra, chief of the Vietcong delegation to the Joint Military Commission, has disclosed that the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government and the Saigon Government have begun discussions of the joint ceasefire body they are to form.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A threeday sitin and strike of service employes the Interboro General Hospital in Brooklyn ended yesterday, and the workers, members of Local 144 of the Hospital Employes Union, returned to their jobs in midafternoon. The agreement was reached after hospital officials asked the police to remove workers who were sitting down in the main lobby and blocking the entrance to the dietary department. Six of the workers were arrested and charged with trespass, but, following the settlement, a hospital official said the charges would be dropped.

title: JOBLESS RATE UP DESPITE BIG RISE IN EMPLOYMENT
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The nation's unemployment rate increased slightly in February despite another big increase in the total number employed, the Labor Department reported today.

title: North and South Korea Revive Political and Red Cross Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 9North and South Korea announced today that they had agreed to resume political talks on improving relations and Red Cross talks on reuniting sepalrated families. Both talks had been discontinued for more than three months.

title: Commodity Options
description: The collapse this week of the nation's biggest dealer in commodity optionsa Los Angeles concern named Goldstein, Samuelson, Inc.  amid Federal charges of insolvency and fraud, has brought sudden attention to an esoteric form of speculation. Commodity options were banned from organized commodity exchanges in this country in the midthirties after the Government had found gross abuses in this method of speculation on prices of raw materials. However, the ban never extended to the buying and selling of commodity options in private deals. Since the widespread and sharp increases in commodity prices in mid1972, a number of concerns have advertised these options to the public.

title: Agriculture Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI)Joseph R. Wright Jr., a management specialist, was named yesterday to the $36,000ayear post of Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Administration.

title: JOBLESS PATE UP DESPITE BIG RISE IN EMPLOYMENT
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The nation's unemployment rate increased slightly in February despite another big increase in the total number employed, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Article 1  No Title
WALSTON TARGET OF S.E.C. CENSURE
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 The Securities and Exchange Commission issued an order of censure today against Walston & Co., Inc., suspended two of its branchoffice representatives and directed the firm to donate $15,000 to the Securities Investor Protection Corporation.

title: POLICE HOLDING 10 IN LONDON BLASTS
description: LONDON, March 9The terrorists who set off yesterday's two large explosions in central London were described today, as members of a special squad sent here within the last 10 days by the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Spain Announces Establishment of Diplomatic Ties With Peking
description: MADRID, March 9  Spain announced tonight that she had established diplomatic relations with China.

title: Policing the Market
description: When Mayor Lindsay named Bess Myerson as Consumer Affairs Commissioner four years ago, the general disposition was to shrug off the appointment as a quixotic expression of the Mayor's Fun City phase. Miss Myerson quickly made clear that she was as long on competency and dedication as she was on charm. Long after she leaves office at the end of this month, New Yorkers will reap the rewards of the tough consumerprotection laws she was largely responsible for getting on the municipal statute books and enforcing, with the Mayor's strong support. She did an unmatched job of warring on the hawkers of shoddy goods and services to assure that the people of this city would get value for their dollars.

title: U. S. HAS TOP ROLE IN BANGLADESH AID
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, March 9In an effort to heal its battered relationship with Bangladesh, the United States has emerged as her biggest source of aid.

title: IndianSettler Conflict in Brazil Is Said to Be Nearing Violence
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 9 Brazil's Xavante Indians are threatening violence to expel homesteaders and merchants who have settled on Indian reservation land, according to reports today from the National Indian Foundation.

title: NO LETUP IN CHAOS IN BRITISH STRIKES
description: LONDON, March 9 (UPI)Thousands of trains were canceled because of the railroad strike, gas workers threatened new action and nonmedical hospital workers throughout Britain continued their work stoppage.

title: Miami Beach Takes Steps To Purify Drinking Water
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 9Two huge chlorinators were flown in today to purify this resort area's drinking water, but health officials said that it would be a day or two before tap water was safe for drinking, making ice cubes and brushing teeth.

title: Jill Laporte Bride Of Robert Lilley
description: MILLBURN, N.J., March 9 Miss Jill Laporte was married here yesterday to Robert McGregor Lilley, son of Robert D. Lilley, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, and Mrs. Lilley. The bride, is the daughter, of Mrs. John H. Laporte and the late Mr. Laporte. Both families are of Short Hills. Mayor C. Thomas Thomas performed the ceremony in the Town Hall.

title: Connecticut Bond Offering Killed by Treasury Ruling
description: The Treasury has killed a giant bond sale by Connecticut and has apparently slammed the door on a complex, related refinancing plan by the state that would have enabled its cities and towns to pay off a portion of about $112million of borrowings incurred at very high interest rates with the Profits from socalled arbitrage operations in the bond market. This arbitrage, in basic terms, contemplated selling taxexempt bonds that can be marketed at relatively low rates and then investing the proceeds in Treasury securities that yield substantially more.

title: China to Free Downey of the C.I.A. Monday
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The White House announced today that the last three Americans held prisoner in China would be set free next week, one of them at the personal request of President Nixon to Premier Chou Enlai.

title: Greek Bronze on Sale for $3.5Million
description: An ancient bronze masterpiece reputedly by the great Greek sculptor Lysippus, reportedly found by two Italian fishermen in the Adriatic Sea in 1964, is now on sale in Munich, Germany, for $3.5million.

title: CONNORS RALLIES TO DEFEAT MAYER
description: PARAMUS, N. J., March 9Topseeded Jimmy Connors of Bellville, 111., rallied for a 517, 62, 62 victory over Sandy Mayer of Wayne, N. J., as the $15,000 Garcia tennis tournament at Bergen Community College opened tonight.

title: Ford Recalls School Buses To Check on Brake System
description: DETROIT, March 9 (UPI) The Ford Motor Company announced today that it was recalling 1,267 school buses to find about 125 that may need modification of the brake system.

title: Who Is Victim?
description: A strange and dangerous misperception has crept into the popular debate over newsmen's privilege and the freedom of the press. However obvious the correction may seem, the error is so carelessly and widely believed that it needs explicit exposure.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Mary Martin Gets Estate
description: The bulk of Richard Halliday's $650,000 estate will be used to set up a trust fund for his widow, Mary Martin. The will was filed Thursday in Manhattan Surrogate Court. Mr. Halliday, a movie and theatrical producer, died last Saturday at the age of 67.

title: Makarios Political Foe Backs Demand to Unfrock Archbishop
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus. March 9 (UPI)Gen. George Grivas, political rival of Archbishop Majorios, the President of Cyprus, said today that he supported the decision of three Greek Orthodox bishops that the Archbishop must be unfrocked. At the same time, a Greek Cypriote student group in Athens warned of civil war unless the Archbishop resigned the presidency.

title: NIXON ME TELLS OF TALK TO F. B. I.
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 John D. Ehrlichman, President Nixon's chief adviser on domestic affairs, said today that he had personally asked that a White House legal counsel sit in on an interview he had with agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation about the Watergate case.

title: Anthony's Bad Bowling Not Bad
description: If Earl Anthony starts to bowl badly again he may just run away with the $75,000 United States open at Madison Square Garden.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The police disclosed yesterday that they had linked the murder of a 9yearold boy in Harlem last October with two other attacks, one fatal, against young boys on the Upper West Side, and were looking for a specific suspect. All three incidents involved stabbings and sexual mutilation.

title: 2 U.S. INTERIOR AIDES ARE SUED FOR LIBEL
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 Two Interior Department officials are being sued for libel as the result of a partly erroneous press release issued last month after Federal officials broke up an illegal fur sales operation.

title: Exotic Spring Rites Aid Museurn
description: The yak kept knocking off the polar bear, the raccoon and the grizzly, and if that isn't your idea of how a roulette wheel works, you just aren't up on charity gambling as practiced at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was: 94337

title: ATKINS ISSUES REPLY TO A.M.A. CRITICISM
description: Dr. Robert C. Atkins yesterday denied charges by an American Medical Association committee that the recommendations in his bestselling book, Dr. Atkins' Diet Revolution were unscientific and potentially dangerous to health.

title: U.S Offers Europe Help In Settling Money Crisis
description: PARIS, March 9The United States offered today to cooperate with the European Economic Community to help settle the most severe monetary crisis since the nineteenthirties and to insure jointly an orderly exchangerate system.

title: Bridge: Exhibition Match Produces Exciting Finish at Tourney
description: ST. LOUIS, March 9The Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began at the ChaseParkPlaza Hotel here this afternoon and will continue for 10 days. First of the six major titles to be decided is the foursession open pairs, which attracted an entry of 576 pairs.

title: Soccer Rivals Play to Draw
description: KAISERSLAUTERN, West Germany, March 9 (UPI)F. C. Kaiserslautern played a 22 draw with H.S.V. Hamburg in the West German First Division soccer championship series.

title: Skaters to Race for Titles on L. I.
description: HICKSVILLE, L. I., March 9Speed skating, Americanstyle, in which the crowded competitors often resemble a group of people trying to get out of a locked closet, will be staged at Cantiague Park tomorrow and Sunday in the national indoor championships.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Harry L. Sears, the former New Jersey State Senator who helped arrange Robert L. Vesco's secret $200,000 cash contribution to the Nixon campaign, last year, said he was severing ties with the International Controls Corporation, which Mr. Vesco founded in 1965. Mr. Sears said he had terminated a $5,000amonth contract as an associate counsel to the Fairfield, N. J., manufacturing company, and planned to resign as a director eventually.

title: VOTERS IN ULSTER BACK BRITISH TIE
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland March 9The Protestant majority produced its expected huge vote and the Roman Catholic minority its expected huge refusal to vote in Northern Ireland's referendum yesterday.

title: ESSEX'S FUND SUIT PASSES OBSTACLE
description: NEWARK, March 9  A State Superior Court judge today denied a state motion for dismissal of a suit by Essex,County and its 22 munlcipali ties to require a statewide sharing of the costs of county courts, criminal justice and public assistance.

title: The Supreme Court as Moral Arbiter
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y.As a citizen of the United States, a Catholic priest and a teacher of law, I was not only shocked by the U.S. Supreme Court's recent decision on abortion, but I felt oddly reduced by it. I shall try to explain why.

title: YANKS CALL LYLE, PETERSON TO CAMP
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 9  Faced with two lingering holdout problems, the Yankees exercised today a seldomused legal maneuver to get Sparky Lyle and Fritz Peterson into training camp.

title: Queens Lawyer Receives 21 Months in Stock Case
description: Martin Roth, a 36yearold Queens lawyer, was sentenced yesterday to 21 months in prison on his conviction on charges of obstructing justice and filing false statements to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Prices Decline on Amex and OTC
description: Prices eased yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market in continued slow trading.

title: Antiques: Panel Finds Period Rooms Often Sterile
description: Some of the experts who have helped make period rooms in museums and historic houses more popular than baseball parks in recent years, questioned this week just how accurate and relevant such vintage settings are today.

title: Pig Pen, of Grateful Dead, Rock Group, Is Found Dead
description: CORTE MADERA, Calif., March 9 (UPI)  Ron McKernan, known as Pig Pen of the Grateful Dead to the nation's rock fans, was found dead in his apartment last night. He was 27 years old.

title: U.S. HAS TOP ROLE IN BANGLADESH AID
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, March 9In an effort to heal its battered relationship with Bangladesh, the United States has emerged as her biggest source of aid.

title: People in Sports: Aaron, The Undesignated Hitter
description: The usually imperturbable Hank Aaron of the Atlanta Braves is miffed with the baseball Hall of Fame over what he believes is a slight. The slugger is angry about a brochure issued by the hall telling of the exhibits in Cooperstown, N. Y., including the bats Aaron used for his 3,000th base hit and his 600th home run. But the publication fails to mention Aaron's name in connection with his achievements. He is so upset that yesterday, at the Braves' training camp in West Palm Beach, Fla., he said he might not send any more mementos to Cooperstown. Aaron, who needs just 42 more home runs to break Babe Ruth's record of 714, said, With all of the things I've done, I think they could at least include my name in that magazine.

title: Dance: Demanding Solo
description: The physically and emotionally demanding solo concert danced by Ze'Eva Cohen Thursday evening was the most rewarding she has yet presented. As is her custom, Miss Cohen created a program, at American Theater Laboratory, drawn from the works of selected contemporary choreographers.

title: U.M. W.'s Leaders Sue Ousted Board
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The new leadership of the United Mine Workers of America said today that it had filed a $10million lawsuit against 10 ousted executive board members who, the suit charged, had permitted wholesale looting of the union treasury.

title: U.S. Urged to Take Over Northeast Pennsy Route
description: John P. Fishwick, president of the highly profitable Norfolk & Western Railway, proposed yesterday that the Government nationalize the 458mile BostonNew YorkWashington right of way of the bankrupt Penn Central railroad and use the route for passengertrain service only.

title: PEARL BUCK BURIED ON HER FARM HOME
description: PERKASIE, Pa., March 9 (AP)The nine adopted sons and daughters of Pearl S. Buck buried her today under an ash tree on her Bucks County farm, a gravesite she chose herself in her own good earth.

title: Russian Roulette
description: The announcement that the Soviet Union would join the Universal Copy. right Convention can hardly have diverted most Americans from their morning coffee. However, its ramifications can affect all of us.

title: Study Finds Division On Proper Method Of Driving in Fog
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI)With fogrelated automobile accidents claiming more than 1,000 lives a year, safety experts cannot agree even on the basic question of whether drivers should use high or low headlight beams in fog, a Government report showed today.

title: Forest Hills Decides To Tear Up the Crass
description: The membership of the West Side Tennis Club voted last night to switch from grass to a synthetic surface for the United States Open this year. The United States championships, which go back to 1881, never have been played on anything but grass.

title: The Classics Revived
description: The Classics Revived is one of three good rainyday shows  but perfectly acceptable in any weather now on view at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 39th Street. The Classics exhibition, ideal for browsers and bibliophiles, is devoted to texts by classical authors  Homer, Plato, Aristotle, Vergil, among others  shown in ancient papyrus fragments and then in the printed and illustrated manuscripts of Renaissance artists of the 15th century and later, when classical scholarship became a fad.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on amendment to Senate resolution that would have made most Senate committee meetings open unless the committee voted to close meetings to the public. Amendment was defeated, 47 to 38, March 6.

title: British Bill Rates Rise
description: LONDON, March 9 (Reuters) The average rate at today's tender of British 91day treasury bills rose to 8.2244 per cent from 8.1232 per cent. But the bill rate increase, the second in successive weeks, failed to trigger a movement in the Bank of England's minimum lending Irate, which remained at 8.75 per cent.

title: Bridge: Exhibition Match Produces Exciting Finish at Tourney
description: ST. LOUIS, March 9The Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began at the ChaseParkPlaza Hotel here this afternoon and will continue for 10 days. First of the six major titles to be decided is the foursession open pairs, which attracted an entry of 576 pairs.

title: 2 TeenAgers Killed in Bronx By Police on Holdup StakeOut
description: Two patrolmen staked out at a Bronx supermarket that has been robbed frequently in recent months shot and killed two teenagers, critically wounded a third and captured two other suspects late yesterday afternoon, foiling what the police called another attempted holdup at the store.

title: PLAN TO REORGANIZE SET FOR CLINTON OIL
description: WICHITA, Kan., March 9 (UPI)A plan for reorganizing the Clinton Oil Company, without placing it in receivership, was approved yesterday in United States District Court.

title: BOYLE IS ACCUSED IN YABLONSKI CASE
description: ERIE, Pa., March 9A special prosecutor charged in open court here today that W. A. Boyle had personally transferred to a United Mine Workers official in Kentucky $20,000 in union funds that the state contends was used to hire the killers of Joseph A. Yablonski.

title: Inquiry Clears Slain Policeman; Reported Drug Tie Discounted
description: A packet containing an eighth of an ounce of cocaine may have been found on the body of Patrolman Irving Wright after he was fatally shot by two policemen Monday morning, the Police Department said yesterday in its official report on the ncident.

title: Robber Kills a Widow, 75; Beats 2d Elderly Woman
description: Fear and shocked disbelief following the robbery and murder of one elderly widow in the northeastern Bronx and the beating of another in the same building by the same man were expressed yesterday by residents of the neighborhood.

title: FRANK MARTI
description: Frank Marti, founder and president of F. Marti & Company, Inc., specializing in financing in Latin America, died on Wednesday. He was 77 years old and lived here.

title: Princeton Widens Lead In Eastern Swim Meet
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., March 9 Princeton opened a commanding lead tonight in the Eastern Seaboard swimming and diving championships, adding three first places to the pair of titles won last night.

title: Lethargic Market Drops, Awaiting Monetary News
description: Wall Street's attention remained focused yesterday on monetary matters in Europe, and the stock market slipped lower in lethargic trading.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: California Requires School Texts to Call Evolution a Theory
description: LOS ANGELES, March 9 The State Board of Education yesterday approved editorial revision in new science textbooks to label evolution as only la theory, not proved fact.

title: TRIAL OF NEWSMAN IN SET BY RHODESIA
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 9Peter Niesewand, the 29yearold Rhodesian newsman who was arrested on Feb. 20, is scheduled to go on trial here March 19 on charges of having violated the Official Secrets Act. The press is to be excluded from the courtroom.

title: Housing Paradox
description: In his message to Congress on community development, President Nixon adopts a remarkably paradoxical stance toward this nation's housing record.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THEATERGOING The play is not the thing if you're going to theater with the Municipal Art Society; the theater is the thing. The society is conducting tours of several brandnew houses in the Broadway area as well as of the oldest one still doing what it was designed for.

title: The End Of Innocence?
description: LONDON, March 10  Headlinewriting has long been a curious special art on British papers. There was a splendid example in the banner on last Wednesday's London Evening News.

title: Arab Terrorist Gang in Gaza Reported Wiped Out by Israel
description: TEL AVIV, March 9Israel said today that her security forces had wiped out an Arab gang reportedly responsible for the revival of terrorism in occupied Gaza last month.

title: Opera: MiniMet Debuts
description: Maurice Ohana's Syllabaire pour Phdre, one of those recent European operas that seem to have been composed by a committee and orchestrated by the I Ching, has run its scheduled course at the Forum, where it inexplicably held the place of honor as opening production of the Metropolitan Opera's MiniMet season.

title: JOHNSON OF F.C.C. HITS NIXON POLICY
description: Nicholas Johnson, the frequently dissenting member of the Federal Communications Commission, accused the Nixon Administration yesterday of seeking control of the communications media in a manner reminiscent of Nazi Germany.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN THE LAND OF MORNING. By Harry Mark Petrakis. 290 pages. McKay. $6.95.

title: Text of Communique on Currency Talks
description: PARIS, March 9 (Reuters) Following is the text of the communiqu issued at the end of the ministerial conference on the international monetary crisis here today:

title: On Canadian Prairie, French Is a Foreign Language
description: WALDHEIM, Saskatchewan  Henry Bueckert walked to the front of Bueckert's General Store and gestured toward the icecovered main street of this little farm village.

title: BRUINS TRIUMPH AS ORR STARS, 32
description: ATLANTA, March 9 (UPI)Bobby Orr scored his 20th goal of the season in the first period, got his 60th assist in the second period and dominated the Atlanta forwards on defense throughout as the Boston Bruins beat the Flames, 32, tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: SOVIET ROYALTIES FOR U.S. AUTHORS
description: MOSCOW, March 9  The head of the Soviet publishing industry indicated today that American authors might receive at least part of their royalties in dollars when Soviet adherence to the Berne Universal Copyright Convention takes effect May 27.

title: Peking's 20Year C.I.A. Prisoner
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., March 9When John Thomas Downey moved to New Britain as a young boy, one of his closest friends was Thomas J. Meskill, now the Governor of Connecticut.

title: PENN STATE TAKES EASTERN GYM TITLE
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 9 (AP)Penn State won the Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastics League title at Temple University tonight for the third straight year.

title: U.S. TELLS SAIGON OF WORRY ON PRESS
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)The United States has expressed concern to South Vietnam over the treatment of American newsmen, the State Department said today.

title: Nixon Committee Returns $655,000 to 3 Big Donors
description: WASHINGTON, March 9President Nixon's reelection committee said today that it had returned $655,000 to three big contributors, including $100,000 to Robert H. Allen, the Texas oilman. Mr. Allen was the source of $89,000 that passed through a Mexican bank to the leader of an alleged political espionage operation against the Democratic party headquarters here last June.

title: Store Volume Reported
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Retail sales eased in February but were still 14 per cent above a year earlier, the Commerce Department estimated today on the basis of preliminary reports.

title: Fit. Dix Drill Instructor Charged With Abusing Recruit Who Died
description: FORT DIX, March 9  A 34yearold drill instructor was ordered today to face a courtmartial here on charges of having physically and verbally maltreated a soldier during training march two months ago.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Dean Witter in Deal
description: Dean Witter & Co., Inc., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, will acquire Laird, Bissell & Meeds, Inc., under plans announced yesterday by the two New York Stock Exchange member firms.

title: Miami Beach Purifying Water; Officials Disagree on Danger
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 9Two huge chlorinators were flown in today to purify this resort area's drinking water, but health officials said that it would be a day or two before tap water was safe for drinking, making ice cubes and brushing teeth.

title: MISS BRYANT LEADS WOMEN'S GOLF AT 70
description: HOUSTON, March 9, (AP) Bonnie Bryant, the only lefthander on the Ladies Professional Golfers Association tour, had six birdies for a twounderpar 70 today and took the firstround lead in the $100,000 S. & H. Green Stamps tournament.

title: U.S. Indicts 19 Here As Drug Smugglers In Latin Connection
description: Federal authorities yesterday announced the indictment of 19 reputed heroin traffickers, dealers and couriers and the further disruption of the LatinAmerican connection.

title: 3 Arrested in Attempt To Steal 2 Tapestries
description: The police said yesterday that they had seized three men who were trying to escape with two antique Italian tapestries taken from the Manhattan School of Music, 120 Claremont Avenue, at West 122d Street. The 8by9foot tapestries were said to be 450 years old and valued at more than $20,000.

title: Duryea Seeks State Unit To Fund Local Stadiums
description: Assembly Speaker Perry S. Duryea called yesterday for the creation of a State Sports Authority that would be allowed to issue up to $350million in revenue bonds to help New York communities develop and modernize their sports facilities.

title: IRAQ OIL IS SEEKING LEBANESE PAYMENT
description: BEIRUT, March 9The Iraq Petroleum Company, with the backing of the British Government, is seeking compensation for the takeover by Lebanon of the company's small refinery and a section of the pipeline bringing oil from the Kirkuk fields in Iraq to Tripoli, Libya, on the Mediterranean,

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 10, 1973

title: ROME PROSECUTOR QUESTIONS HECHT
description: ROME, March 9  Robert E, Hecht Jr., the American expatriate who said he sold $1million Euphronios vase to New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art on behalf of a Lebanese coin dealer, was questioned by a magistrate here early this week and was advised to retain counsel on suspicion of having received stolen property of the Italian state.

title: GEWERTZ CHARGE DENIED BY JUDGE
description: CAMDEN, March 9 Judge Warren C. Douglas of Cherry Hill Municipal Court and James Greenberg, Prosecutor for Cherry Hill Township, today denied that there was anything improper in their handling of criminal assault case last fall.

title: TRANSPORT PLAN IS DRAFTED HERE
description: A privately sponsored plan to revamp New York City's transportation systems and make living with the automobile a little easier was disclosed yesterday.

title: Jersey Judge Denies Acting Improperly
description: CAMDEN, N. J., March 9Judge Warren C. Douglas of Cherry Hill Municipal Court and James Greenberg, Prosecutor for Cherry Hill Township, today denied that there was anything improper in their handling of a criminal assault case last fall.

title: U.S. Force Explodes 1st Mine Off Haiphong
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (Reuters)The United States minesweeping force off North Vietnam had its first success todayit detonated one mine.

title: Discovery of a Chinese Torah Stirs College
description: There is a tale, perhaps apocryphal, that the Western world first learned there were such beings as Chinese Jews when a missionary in the early 17th century overheard with astonishment the remarks of two Chinese men who were in Peking to take examinations for public posts.

title: GOSS OUTPOINTS SEELEY IN GARDEN
description: The remembrance of past greatness gripped the hearts of 4,115 fans in Madison Square Garden last night as they saw four former champions plod through exhibition bouts.

title: 2 Killed, 7 Injured In Lisbon Bombings Of Military Center
description: LISBON, March 9 (Reuters)Two men were reported killed and about seven others injured tonight in two explosions of bombs at Portugal's military administratiye headquarters in central Lisbon.

title: TV: An Excellent Long Day's Journey
description: The most common argument about Eugene O'Neill's Long Day's Journey Into Night centers on whether it is simply a great American play or the only great American play. Let's not get into that. For the moment, the more important thing to keep in mind is that Britain's National Theater production of the play will be given three hours, beginning at 8 this evening, on the network of the American Broadcasting Company.

title: NETWORKS OFFER A FREETIME PLAN
description: The three television networks pledged yesterday that in exchange for repeal of the equaltime rule, they would provide free broadcast time to the 1976 major party Presidential and VicePresidential candidates.

title: Nixon Picks Deputy Counsel And Foreign Policy Aides
description: WASHINGTON, March (AP)  President Nixon announced today a promotion within the White House staff and the appointment of four members of a recently created Commission on the Organization of Government for the Conduct of Foreign Policy.

title: CITY CLUB, AT 80, IN BUSIEST YEAR
description: In this, its 80th year of activity as one of the city's most energetic civic organizations the City Club of New York is unleashing a series of reports on government structure, city labor policy and corruption, to mention just a few.

title: WHITEHOUSE SAYS NIXON WILL VETO NEW FUNDS BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, March. 9 The White House warned today that President Nixon would veto a variety of bills pending in Congress and, as a last resort, would attempt to impound the funds they would authorize should his veto be overridden.

title: ROCKETS TRIUMPH OVER NETS, 120105
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 9 In a game that essentially meant little to either team, the Denver Rockets showed more interest in winning than the New York Nets and emerged with a 120.105 victory tonight before a crowd of 6,391 at Nassau Coliseum.

title: PACERS CONQUER COUGARS, 110105
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 9 (AP)The Indiana Pacers defeated the Carolina Cougars, 110105, tonight for their sixth straight American Basketball Association victory.

title: Psychiatrist Wins Bail In Murder Plot Case
description: TRENTON, March 9Dr. William R. King, the former, state prison psychiatrist in dicted yesterday on charges of soliciting the murders of three persons, pleaded not guilty today and was released on $40,000 bail.

title: ACCORD REPORTED AT WOUNDED KNEE
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., March 9Department of Justice officials said today that they had reached an agreement in principle that could end the 11day standoff between Federal forces and the dissident Indians who are occupying the hamlet of Wounded Knee, 15 miles northeast of here.

title: Aluminum Also to Rise
description: Prices for zinc and aluminum are headed upward again.

title: Kathryn Eickhoff Wed to A. J. Smith Jr.
description: NAPLES, Fla., March 9Miss M. Kathryn Eickhoff, vice president and treasurer of TownsendGreenspan & Co., Inc., economic consultants in New York, was married here today to A. James Smith Jr., owner of JacquesintheVillage, a jazz bistro in New York.

title: A GAULLIST TREND IS SEEN IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, March 9The critical support of centrist voters in the French national elections appeared today to be draining away from the left, drifting significantly toward the Gaullists and their partners.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS NIXON WILL VETO NEW FUNDS BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 The White House warned today that President Nixon would veto a variety of bills pending in Congress and, as a last resort, would attempt to impound the funds they would authorize should his veto be overridden.

title: Squiggles of New District Lines Called a Product of Bipartisan Political Design
description: TRENTON, March 9At first glance, the lines in the state's new legislative reapportionment plan look like jackstraws and random squiggles across the breadth of New Jersey.

title: U.S. Indicts 19 Here As Drug Smugglers In 'Latin Connection'
description: Federal authorities yesterday announced the indictment of 19 reputed heroin traffickers, dealers and couriers and the further disruption of the LatinAmerican connection.

title: Justice Roberts Testifies At Mackell Office Inquiry
description: State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts, the former Bronx District Attorney, made an unannounced appearance last week before the special grand jury investigating the office of District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens.

title: N.C.A.A. WRESTLING LED BY IOWA STATE
description: SEATTLE, March 9 (AP)Iowa State virtually clinched the team title today in the National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling championships.

title: JOSEPH A. FISHER
description: Joseph A. Fisher, who retired in 1960 as international presiIdent of the Utility Workers Union of America, died yesterday in Booth Memorial Hospital, Flushing, Queens. He was. 176 years old and lived at 16110 Jewel Avenue, Flushing.

title: Bites by Illegal Pets
description: Health Commissioner Joseph A. Cimino said yesterday that 162 people reported that they had been bitten by exotic illegal pets such as ocelots and lion cubs last year. Dr. Cimino estimated the actual number of bites to be five times the reported number. He said that some people were reluctant to report bites for fear of having the animal taken away from them.

title: Music: Elegant Poppea
description: How to describe the music of Monteverdi's L'Incoronazione di Poppea, composed in 1642, revived Thursday night at the State Theater by the New York City Opera Company? For this is early in the history of opera, and listeners, brought up on Mozartean opera, or bel, canto, or Verdi and Wagner, or verismo, are going to have to make adjustments.

title: The Vesco Affair
description: So much evidence of corruption in high Administration circles has been emerging in these past few weeks that it now requires President Nixon himself to reassure the country that every possible step has been taken to prevent the recurrence of any such episodes in or around the White House.

title: N.A.S.D. OFFERING NEWISSUE RULES
description: Proposed new rules, designed to strengthen the conduct of underwriters, and brokerdealers in the sometimes hot new issues market, will be mailed next week by the National Association of Securities Dealers (N.A.S.D.) to its members and a number of other interested parties.

title: Men, Who Gave Women the Suit, Are Borrowing a Few Ideas Now
description: Remember the flowering sports shirts of the Truman era? The ones that looked Gauguinesque or Hawaiian and that myriad American businessmen wore with Bermuda shorts in the early 1950's at their country clubs or on their European tours? Well, they're back. They're at Alexander's and their foliage is as brilliant as it was 20 years ago.

title: New Scene for an Old Movie House: a Bakony Museum
description: A museum is growing in what used to be the balcony of an old, movie theater and burlesque house on East Tremont Avenue near Crotona Avenue in the Bronx. It is being built there by Community School Board 12 at a cost of $400,000.

title: Maryland Wins, Gains N.C.A.A. Tourney Spot
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., March 19 (AP)Unbeaten North Carolina State wiped out Virginia with a 254 surge over 9 minutes and went on to a 6351 victory to gain the final of the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament tonight.

title: Marxist in Detroit Presses Class Struggle as a Judge
description: DETROIT, March 9With his long hair, goldenrimmed airplane glasses, blueandwhite shirt of fancy design, widebelted slimline trousers and tan cowboy boots, the lanky young man might easily have been mistaken for a law clerk as he casually mixed with people the other day inside the courtroom of Judge Justin C. Ravitz of the Detroit Recorder's Court.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 10, 1973

title: LIBERALS TO BACK REPUBLICAN JUDGE
description: The Liberal party is expected to endorse Associate Judge Charles D. Breitel, a Republican, for the Court of Appeals chief judgeship at a meeting of the Liberal State Committee, a high party official reported today.

title: Testimony Ended On Option Charges
description: LOS ANGELES, March 9 Testimony was completed in Federal District Court late today on a Government effort to place in permanent receivership the country's largest commodity options dealer for allegedly bilking thousands of customers in what it called one of the greatest frauds of the decade.

title: SANTIAGO SCORES AQUEDUCT DOUBLE
N.Y.U. FENCERS LEAD AFTER 2 WEAPONS
description: New York University surged into a 7point lead yesterday after two weapons in the 76th annual Intercollege Fencing Association championships at Alumni Gym in the Bronx.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WAYNE, N. J., March 9When two brothers participate in the same sport at the same New Jersey high school and eventually wind up on the same collegiate football and semipro baseball teams, brotherly comparison by coaches, spectators and even each other would be almost natural.

title: Explosion on East 81st Street Heavily Damages Car, Shattering Newly Found Calm in Area
description: It has been quieter on 81st Street between First and Second Avenues since the residents there succeeded last summer in closing down a noisy bar called the Tambourine.

title: Birth Defects Are Tied to Body Heat
description: GENEVA, March 3An Australian scientist's animal experiments, which produced a wide range of serious birth defects by slightly raising the pregnant mother's body temperature, have led the World Health Organization to investigate the implications for human beings.

title: 14 Lands and Observer Represented at Talks
description: Fourteen countries and one observer country were represented at the Paris monetary meeting yesterday. How did these 15 happen to be chosen?

title: Nixon Committee Returns $655,000 to 3 Big Donors
description: WASHINGTON, March 9President Nixon's reelection committee said today that it had returned $655,000 to three big contributors, including $100,000 to Robert H. Allen, the Texas oilman. Mr. Allen was the source of $89,000 that passed through a Mexican bank to the leader of an alleged political espionage operation against the Democratic party headquarters here last June.

title: VOGEL'S TWO HORSES WIN AT READINGTON
description: READINGTON, N. J., March 10Harold Vogel spent 10 hours as a spectator at the Four Seasons Farm horse show todaybut he left the event as a satisfied spectator.

title: State Gets U.S. Approval For $3Million Park Aid
description: ALBANY, March 10Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he had received certification for an initial $3million in Federal funds for the development of Riverbank State Park, a recreation area that will be built atop the $750million North River water pollution control facility being built along the Hudson River in Harlem.

title: Laurence Steinhardt Dies; Concert Violinist Was 59
description: Laurence Steinhardt, the concert violinist, died of leukemia yesterday at his home, 150 West 95th Street. He was 59 years old.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: March 16Triumph Sports Car Club of New Jersey rally school open to all; second of three lectureworkshop sessions to be followed by short rally (other sessions, March 23 and 30). Workshop at Giovanni's Restaurant, Orchard and Elm Streets, East Paterson, N.J., 7:30 P.M. Information: Anna Andrews, phone (201)2564397.

title: PRINCETON TAKES SWIMMING TITLE
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., March 10  Princeton won its first Eastern Seaboard Intercollegiate swimming and diving title since 1962 tonight as the threeday meet in the Army pool ended which saw with 10 meet recrds broken and three defending champions dethroned.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
Miss Carroll Plans Nuptials
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., March 10  Mr. and Mrs. Charles Carroll have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Antoinette Carroll, to John T. Donoghue, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Donoghue of Needham, Mass. The wedding Is planned for July 28.

title: He Makes Pillows of Every Shape and Fabric
description: Craig Carrieri began deigning three years ago, doLug belts and handbags. And the big companies knocked them off, he said. So he switched to knitted tops with amusing designs. The young fashion magazines loved them and featured them. And they got knocked off.

title: The Morning After
description: Writing in this Book Review on Feb. 18, John Leonard seemed to think the presentation of the idea of the Fifth Estate at the Four Seasons (on the occasion of my 50th birthday) came off better as presentation than as idea. A nice analysis then ensued to show how the evening would be a success only if Mailer made a fool of himself, for that was what people had paid to see. It was Mailer's pride, Leonard assumed, to manipulate that relationship, and he was right. He had put his finger on the precise pride. There had been the little hypothesis that when people wholly unaccustomed to paying their way into any party's were required to pay their way into mine, a concentration of attention would be then produced upon the founding of a Fifth Estate which could not be equaled in a year of quiet serious responsible conversations with responsible and serious people, particularly since one's hardearned Jamesian sense of stroke suggested that the most useful party ingredient in a city so evil as New York is curiosity. So it was declared by the invitation that one would make an announcement of national importance (major)this last parenthesis naturally opposed to anything of national importance which might be minor, a useful distinction. New York, I knew, would not come to the birthday but to the secret. And that was wellkept. (The woman nearest to one's life asked naturally for the secret. I'll tell you, but if the night doesn't turn out, you're bound to catch the blame. Tell me no secret.)

title: GALLUP FINDS PRICES DOMINANT CONCERN
description: Inflation has replaced Vietnam as the No. 1 problem facing the country in the latest Gallup Poll, released yesterday.

title: 3 YOUTHS TO PLEAD ON DEATH IN HAZING
description: LOS ANGELES, March 10Pleas to misdemeanor charges of hazing will be entered Thursday by three Pierce Community College students in the death of Fred Phillip Bronner, a 21yearold fraternity brother.

title: Notre Dame Faces U.S.C. on Saturday In Opener of N.I.T.
description: Pairings for the 36th National Invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden were announced yesterday by Peter J. Carlesimo, chairman of the selection committee.

title: N.Y.U. CAPTURES FENCING CROWN
description: New York University recaptured the Intercollegiate Fencing Association's threeweapon team championship yesterday at Alumni Gymnasium in the Bronx.

title: Synagogue site Issue in Queens
description: Lovely private homes and winding, treelined streets are the hallmark of uppermiddleclass Jamaica Estates, so when residents learned recently that a synagogue would be built in their neighborhood, a restlessness infiltrated many conversations.

title: Cure for Diseases Soughtin Sea Life
description: Some of the star performers at the Aquarium in Coney Island perform without a public audience. Away from the spotlight playing on the sharks, the penguins and the beluga whale, they fascinate the 30 scientists working in the New York Zoological Society's Osborn Laboratories of Marine Sciences, and they may offer clues to many of man's medical mysteries, such as cancer and various viral diseases.

title: More Hotels for South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 10 (AP)The Government has reported that South Korea plans to add almost 7,000 hotel rooms to its present 6,888 in an attempt to bring in more foreign tourists.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt disclosed yesterday that the state had withheld $11,008,750 from the City University during the 197071 fiscal year to make up for stateaid advances in previous years that his auditors said were given on excessive claims by the university.

title: Wendy Ryan Will Be Wed
description: HAMDEN, Conn., March 10  Miss Wendy Lee Ryan plans to be married June 2 to Perry Belmont Duryea 3d, whose father is Speaker of the New York State Assembly.

title: Snowmobile Races Lag As Temperatures Go Up
description: MALONE, N. Y., March 10 (AP)Trucks brought in tons of snow for the track at the annual world series of United States. Snowmobile Association today, but the races were slow and inconclusive.

title: Absolutely Nothing To Get Alarmed About
description: Ten years ago, in a widely praised novel, Charles Wright described the first stops on his journey toward selfunderstanding. The trip then was through the semisecret world of junkies and homosexuals. But the demimonde has come up town, and what was once subterranean is now public information, the stuff of that endless talk show called television. To continue the journal of his life, Wright has had to find newer, more private lower depths to chronicle. He remains in the streets, but the drama is more internal now, a private battle waged in the mind. Street life is still Wright's turf, but the young hustler of The Messenger has grown up. He no longer carries packages to strange offices and neighborhoods, little bundles of someone else's success. Now he cleans their floors and their silver.

title: Art
description: ITS title is The Far North: 2000 Years of American Eskimo and Indian Art, it opened Thursday at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and it is a revelation. Like many another revelation, it should not have come as a surprise, but it does. The material has been ready and waiting for years, but we have been blind or indifferent to it.

title: Argentines Voting Today For Civilian Government
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 10Argentines will vote tomorrow for the first time since 1965 in an election that will replace a sevenyearold military regime with a civilian government.

title: P.B.A. Joins Inquiry Into the Slaying of a Basking Ridge Black
description: BERNARDSVILLEIt has been almost two months since 21yearold William Wells of Basking Ridge was shot and killed by William Sorgie, a Bernardsville patrolman, and while the official investigation into the shooting has long since concluded, at least two private investigations continue.

title: N.B.A. LineUps
description: AT BOSTON

title: FOOD CRISIS SEEN FOR BANGLADESH
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, March 9 Bangladesh, a stricken nation, in economic disarray, now faces a perilous food shortage.

title: JAPAN SEES STEP BY U.S. ON GOLD
description: TOKYO, March 10Premier Kakuel Tanaka and Finance Minister Klichi Aichi indicated today that they expected the United States to restore, at least partly, the convertibility of gold.

title: A primer on the world's money
description: WASHINGTON. It is safe to say that 20 years ago hardly anyone in this country except economists and a few Government officials had ever heard of a thing called the balance of payments. Now, with the dollar devalued twice in 14 months against nearly all the major foreign currencies, the concept is not so strange, even though it may still not be clearly understood. Indeed, there was only one reason for the devaluations: a large deficit in the nation's international payments, which had been going on for years and which worsened drastically in 1971 and 1972.

title: Recordings
description: NINETEENTH  CENTURY American musical lifea mixture of carnival exhibitionism, parlor recitals and tepid academicism  presented an unlikely environment for the conception and development of any kind of important compositional practice. And it certainly seems as if the idiosyncratic 20th century tradition represented by composers like Charles Ives, Carl Ruggles, Henry Cowell, Ruth Crawford Seeger, Harry Partch, John Cage and Elliott Carter were spontaneously generated.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: If the present trend continues, some areas of Florida may soon have an overabundance of alligators, and if this happens the various state and Federal agencies as well as private conservation groups concerned with the reptile's welfare will have a delicate ecological and public relations problem on their hands, says the Wildlife Management Institute.excess alligators could have been trapped live and transplanted to states that are having difficulty in restoring the species, among them Georgia and South Carolina.

title: A Japanese Judge Is Skeptical of Jury System in U.S.
description: MORRISTOWNFor Hiroyuki Yamasaki, a 30yearold Family Court judge from Kumamoto City, Japan, the essential difference between United States and Japanese courts is the jury system. And after a month of studying the courts in New Jersey, he is not sure that the jury trial offers the best assurance of justice.

title: C.W. POST KEEPS CROWN IN TRACK
description: C. W. Post College captured seven of the 13 events at Queens College yesterday and won the team title for the fifth straight time in the Collegiate Track Conference indoor championships.

title: The parts fit together
description: An exploration of Bucky is the kind of tour that can use a guide. Consider some of the points of interest along with some of what might be called the side trips: He was removed from Harvard College as generally irresponsible; he thought of something called the Tensegrity Sphere; he can say 7,000 words in an hour for more consecutive hours than many people can stand; he concluded, early on, that Nature does not use pi; he took Marilyn Miller and the entire Ziegfeld chorus line out for dinner at Churchill's just for the hell of it; he drew the plans, complete right down to the final detail of a vacuum tooth brush, for a house that would hang from a mast; he developed the equation E=mcMrs. Murphy's horsepower); he designed the Geodesic Dome, and he has delivered the Charles Eliot Norton lectures one poetry.

title: Parasitic Wasps Put the Bite On Connecticut Forest Pests
description: An exploding population of parasitic wasps, each smaller than the head of a pin, is expected to virtually end this spring a scourge of elm spanworms that has defoliated Connecticut woodlands for the last three years.

title: Charter Unit Names Counsel
description: The State Charter Revision Commission for New York City announced yesterday the appointment of W. Bernard Richland as its special counsel. Mr. Richland was formerly chief of the opinions and legislation division of the city's Law Department and was counsel to the Nassau County Commission on Governmental Revision in the work of drafting a proposed new county charter in 1966. The 12member charter commission is to propose a restructuring of city government.

title: Saigon Yields to Press On Seeing Communists
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 10 (AP)  The South Vietnamese Government compromised with foreign newsmen today and agreed to expand press representation at a meeting next week with Communist peacekeeping delegates.

title: Nameposts Urged on Estates
description: BEDMINSTERAnonymity may be on the way out for residents of five Somerset Hills villages and towns.

title: Mailbox: City's Treatment of the Giants
description: To the Editor: Dave Anderson was simply wrong [March 4] in calling the city vindictive for not allowing the football Giants to play more than three games in Yankee Stadium next fall.

title: Providence Topples St. Joseph's, 8976
description: Ernie DiGregorio, the little man who puts the big go into powerful Providence, scored 31 points last night, 25 in the second half, as the Friars routed St. Joseph's, 8976, in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship played at St. John's gym in Queens.

title: Seton Hall Fencers Win North Atlantic Tournament
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 10 Seton Hall, cochampion last season, won the North Atlantic intercollegiate fencing championships today.

title: L.I. Teacher Loss Has Little Effect On Ratio to Pupils
description: The pupilteacher ratio for public schools in Nassau and Suffolk Counties has remained unchanged despite the fact that there are more than 300 fewer teachers in the two counties than were were last year.

title: New Home For A. H. S.
description: THE American Horticultural Society is widely excited over its new homeand no wonder.

title: Drug Crackdown in Bahrain
description: BAHRAIN, March 10 (AP)The official Gazette of this Persian Gulf state has reported a crackdown on illegal drugs, with possible prison terms ranging up to 10 years.

title: Catharsis for Tennessee Williams?
description: FELICE and Clare DeVoto are actors, brother and sister, perhaps halves of one personality, like the twoheaded sunflower they remember from their childhood. They have been abandoned as insane by their theatrical company, left alone on a stage in a provincial town. The stage, we are told, is a nightmare of debris.

title: Pictures of The Journey Back
description: The camera poses us, willynilly; it is seldom candid. A 5yearold will turn his best profile, will grit teeth: a sudden, silly carnivore saying cheese. Pictures of the Journey Back is a film within a novel. Consequently there are at least two sorts of selfoonciousness, two very antagonistic styles. Jack Matthews has conscripted half a dozen eternals for his group shot: death; a journey; the nude, fierce American West; the strife of youth and age. Old cowboy sets out to return estranged hippie daughter to mother's leathbedside. Hippieloverfilmmaker comes along to record the happening. He is a shill for the novelist; he holds up the applause sign, endorses cosmic significance. Even the harsh landscape barns it up: windmills, tornados, whatever, have an emblematic outline. The visual arts can chance this; muteness may be accepted as objectivity, selfeffacement before the event. A novel has other, more garrulous, business: to assert, to think, to take judgmental risks. A picture can be worth a thousand words. But a thousand words have themselves a particular, nonvisual value, no less seen.

title: Like Prospero, sure of his wand, his kingship and his splendor
description: Of all poets of this time, Robert Graves is the one who, without solemnity but with total dedication, has kept the idea of poetry sacred and the idea of the poet true. He has always disliked the idea of poets using poetry ambitiously in order to assert claims of greatness and universality, whether these were made by Virgil or Milton, or (as he considered) by poets of his own day like Yeats or Eliot.. His ideal of poetry is, I suppose, that of Catullus, in whose work the holy rage or passionate love in each poem seems exactly to equate the entranced but still measurably personal feelingthe situation of loving a girl or hating a rival out of which the poem arises.

title: EXTENSION URGED ON INSURANCE AIM
description: ALBANY, March 10  The State Insurance Department will soon ask the Legislature to extend for another four years an experimental openrating system in which insurance companies set their own premium rates.

title: Ribicoff Begins Fence Mending to Offset His Backing of McGovern
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Just about every Sunday since midJanuary Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff has been the host at brunch for local Democratic party leaders and officeholders back in Connecticut in what for him is an unusual mission fence mending.

title: CANADA CRITICAL, OF TRUCE PANEL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 10Canada vented her mounting frustration over the failure of the international peacekeeping commission to fulfill its mission today by publicly criticizing two members of the commission for obstructing an investigation of alleged Communist violations of the ceasefire.

title: HAWKS VANQUISH WARRIORS,117113
description: ATLANTA, March 10 (UPI)The Atlanta Hawks battled back from a 12point deficit at the start of the fourth period tonight and defeated the Golden State Warriors, 117113, for their sixth victory in a row.

title: Chuvalo Bout Put Back
description: CLEVLAND, Mach 10 (AP)The heavyweight fight between George Chuvalo of Toronto and Ernie Shaver of Warren, Ohio, which had been scheduled for March 27, has been rescheduled for May 9 because both fighters wanted more time to train.

title: S.C.I. HEAD SLATED FOR FEDERAL POST
description: ALBANY, March 10The Federal Bureau of Investigation has completed a background check of Paul Curran, chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, apparently in preparation for his appointment as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

title: PHOENIX SATISFIED IN FANNIN'S CASE
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 10, The City Council has cleared the city's staff of any wrongdoing in the controversial dismissal of drunken driving charges against Senator Paul J. Fannin, a Republican.

title: Bermuda Governor And Aide Are Killed By Shots in Capital
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sun day, March 11The police announced late last night that Sir Richard Sharpies, Governor of this British colony, and one other person had been shot to death.

title: New and Recommended
description: SLEEPERS JOINING HANDS, by Robert Bly. (Harper, $5.95.) Poems that seek to discern the whole meaning of the dominion of life and death over America.

title: Lucy Castles Affianced
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 10 The engagement of Miss Lucy Shepherd Castles, daughter of Mrs. John T. Castles and the late Mr. Castles, to John Duncomb Hough, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley C. Hough of Capel, Surrey, England, has been announced by her mother.

title: Daniel Riesel to Wed Rhoda Schutz
description: Miss Rhoda Sara Schutz, assistant counsel to the State Temporary Commission on the State Court System, plans to be married March 25 at the Lincoln Park Jewish Center in Yonkers to Daniel Riesel, an assistant United States Attorney and chief of the Environmental Protection Unit in the office of the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

title: Jane Ireland, a Student, Engaged
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn. March 10Dr. and Mrs. Elwood F. Ireland Jr. of Fairfield and West Dover, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Ireland, to Brian Thomas Silvestro, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin T. Silvestro of Fairfield. A June wedding is planned.

title: ST. LOUIS MAYOR BOWS OUT IN APRIL
description: ST. LOUIS, March 10After eight years of a flamboyant, controversial administration tainted by reoccurring scandal, Mayor Alfonso J. Cervantes will turn over his job next month to one of two men with more steady, conservative backgrounds.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: PENN OVERCOMES ST. JOHN'S, 6261, IN N.C.A.A. TOURNEY
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., March 10The University of Pennsylvania, Ivy League champion for the last four seasons, defeated St. John's, 6261, in an exciting openinground game of the 35th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship tonight.

title: Days of Cheap Food May Be Over
description: As food prices continue to soar, Washington officials have been offering relief in the form of promises that prices will decline sharply in the last half of 1973. Such an outcome seems to be predicated on recent changes in Government crop programs.

title: Allen Gilbert Weds Susan Lanigan
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 10Miss Susan Browne Lanigan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Lanigan of Ardsley, was married here this afternoon to Allen Gilbert, son of Samuel H. Gilbert of Radnor, Pa., and the late Mrs. Gilbert.

title: AllofaKind Family Downtown
description: To meet again, after an interval of 14 years, Sydney Taylor's wellknown Allof  aKind Family is a bit upsetting like going back to one's hometown hoping nothing has changed, finding that, indeed, nothing has, and then being irritated by the very familiarity, the predictability of it all.

title: Missing Mays Bark in Camp; Cards Stop Mets on 3 Hits, 40
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10Willie Mays was missing from camp for a time, Tom Seaver was sidelined with a sore throat, and to make the day complete the. New York Mets got only three singles while losing to the St. Louis Cardinals today, 40.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: It's hard to resist Maisie Ward when she writes about the Brownings, impossible when she writes about the Brownings' problem son Pen, who for all his gifts ended up a kind of Dorian Gray. Robert Coles's introduction points the lesson: no child could have survived the loving treatment he got from his ambitious parents.

title: Rev. Wilmina Rowland Is Wed to H. Many Smith
description: The Rev. Wilmina Rowland, the first woman ever to offer the opening prayer in the United States Senate, on July 8, 1971, was married in the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church yesterday to H. Maxcy Smith, a widower of St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Current Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: Sow Peas Early
description: IF there is room, plant peas. No garden vegetable, with the possible exception of sweet corn, is as delectable when picked tender and ready for eating within the hour, from vine to kettle as they say. At least one hundred feet of row is necessary to provide an adequate crop for a family of four.

title: Trenton State Acts To Review Goals
description: TRENTONTrenton State College, one of six New Jersey teachers colleges to expand into fully accredited fouryear state colleges over the last decade, is responding to the problems of the 70's by reevaluating its educational goals.

title: Rutgers Shows Harlem Artist's Work
description: NEW BRUNSWICKThe artist, wrote James Baldwin, in Notes of a Native Son, is the only meinber of a society who can afford to tell the truth about it. Acting on that premise, Faith Ringgold, an artist from Harlem, has been portraying the troubled faces of black and white America in her own forthright, commanding style for the last 10 years.

title: Soviet Officials Warned To Shun Costly Junkets
description: MOSCOW, March 10 (Reuters)Soviet ministries have received a warning to clamp down on officials who turn business trips into expensive junkets.

title: Spain, Catholicism, surrealism, anarchism
description: COMING: From the moment Christ dies on Good Friday right up to the, celebration of his rising on Holy Saturday the town of Calanda resounds to the ceaseless beating of drums. All afternoon, all through the night to the flare of torchlights, all through the following morning everyone, man, woman or child, beats until the tense goatskins burst or become ragged and bloodied. For the hands of the townspeople are now raw; the knuckles are bare bone; the fingers are open sores and the ancient, severe, monotonous, rising sound of the drums, the heartbeat of Calanda, can be heard for miles around the bleak Aragonian countryside.

title: MURRAY J. MARCHIONE
description: Murray J. Marchione, who retired last month as vice president of administration and finance of the Lummus Company, a designing, engineering and construction concern, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Jacob Klein, Lawyer, Dies; Realty Aide for Shuberts
description: Jacob Klein, a lawyer who handled real estate for the Shubert Brothers before his retirement 10 years ago, died yesterday at his home, 2 East 86th Street. He would have been 95 years old tomorrow.

title: Italian Chamber Passes Bill For Fighting Venice Floods
description: ROME, March 10The Chamber of Deputies has passed hardfought bill that would appropriate $500million to curb floods and other environmental dangers in Venice.

title: ASSORTMENT OF WORDS 27 by 20, by Kirk Dodd
description: ACROSS

title: Why did all the English artists hate him so much?
description: Roger Fry died in 1934, the most famous English art critic since Ruskin. He lived in a period that not only saw a hectic series of developments in painting  Impressionism, PostImpressionism,, Cubism, Futurismbut in which, for the first time, the arts of the Orient, Africa and Oceania were first widely recognized to be as important as those of the European tradition. Fry tried to identify a common denominator among what Valry called these mutually exclusive marvels; to do so he discounted both the artist's temperament and iconography, and came up with what he called vital rhythm.

title: Wheelock College Appoints
description: BOSTON, March 10 (UPI)Dr. Gordon L. Marshall, a native of Yonkers, has been named the new president of Wheelock College.

title: Ignition time, roll, injection, starsightsan authentic poetry of our period
