description: HICKSVILLE, L. L, March 10Mr. and Mrs. V. J. Calvacca have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jo Ann Calvacca, to Steven Wagner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wagner of Franklin Square.

title: Bonn Now Moscow's Top Trade Partner
description: MOSCOW, March 10The Soviet Union disclosed this week that West Germany, in a surge of selling fostered by improved political relations, had become Russia's principal trade partner, moving ahead of Japan.

title: May Nuptials for Diana Grand And James Masters, a Banker
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 10Mrs. Gordon Grand Jr., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Diana Knowlton Grand, to James Henry Peniston Masters, son of Mr. and Mrs, James Henry Masters of Pembroke, Bermuda.

title: McGrath Defeats Anthony and Takes Title in $75,000 U.S. Open Bowling
description: Mike McGrath of El Cerrito Calif., defeated topseeded Ear Anthony of Tacoma, Wash. 234222, yesterday to win the $75,000 Bowling Proprietors Association of America United States Open at Madison Square Garden.

title: Met. College Hockey
If Antiques Blossom, Can Spring Be Far Behind?
description: The new blooms of springtime and a harvest culled from the past combine in the annual Antiques Fair and Flower Show, which opened yesterday at the Coliseum for a run through March 18.

title: Montclair Library Getting Data Bank
description: MONTCLAIR  The Montclair Public Library is setting up a community center that will soon be able to answer questions on such matters as the availability of legal aid and health facilities and consumer and housing problems.

title: JACOB W. GROENDYKE
description: BRIELLE, N. J., March 10Jacob W. Groendyke, who retired in 1956 as vice president in charge of accounting for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died yesterday in a nursing home in Wall Township. He lived here.

title: Guatemala Coach to See N.C.A.A. Championship
description: Jorge Ruano, coach of the national basketball team of Guatemala, will tour the United States and conclude his visit at the 1973 National Collegiate basketball championship, March 24.26 in St. Louis.

title: Education
description: Contrary to a general public conception, a serious shortage of engineers is developing in the country. Enrollments at engineering schools have been declining over the past few years, and educators and manpower experts are now warning that key industries  and the economy as a whole  will be hit within two years by a crisis.

title: Gray Ghosts Of Iron Age Survive In Manhattan
description: Tucked behind the blunt end of the Flatiron Building in the continual twilight of Broadway and 20th Street, a shingled mansard roof crowns a fivestory structure embellished by every architectural detail known to Western man. There are curving glass bays, windows arched and balconied, endless variations on the columnandcapital themeevery antique motif, and all of them worked in cast iron.

title: Copter Identification Of Vehicles Is Sought
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)The Department of Transportation has awarded the Hoffman Electronics Corporation, El Monte, Calif., a $35,000 contract to develop an effective means of identifying vehicles electronically from a helicopter.

title: The Arts
description: I'm doing this for personal aggrandizement and to establish a cultural power base here in New York so as to take over the rest of the repertory theaters in the country, and to create a liaison with China and Russia.

title: ARAB CONFESSES, KHARTOUM SAYS
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 10One of the men accused of having assassinated two Americans and a Belgian at the Saudi Arabian Embassy here nine days ago has made full confession, describing how the group reached the Sudan, where its weapons were obtained and how the operation was directed from Lebanon, Sudanese authorities said here today.

title: Speed Skaters Watch the Elbows
description: HICKSVILLE, L.I., March 10It's getting pretty rough out there with the elbows. If they don't stop, I'll have to use a few myself.

title: Aussies Are All Out for 324 Against W. Indies in Cricket
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, March 10 (Reuters)A 78 by the wicketkeeper, Rod Marsh, led Australia to a firstinnings total of 324 runs today on the second day of the second cricket test with the West Indies. The first match was drawn.

title: Letters: The Ethics Of Travel Writing
description: To the Editor: No selfrespecting journalist who writes on travel could help but take umbrage at David Alpern's piece on John Wilcock (At Home With John Wilcock, an Influential Man Nobody Knows, Travel Section Feb. 4).

title: Home Improvement
description: WHEN old paint or varnish must be removed prior to a refinishing job  or simply, because it is desired to expose the natural wood or masonry againthe quickest and easiest way to get the job done is to use a prepared chemical paint remover. These contain powerful solvent's that soften and blister tip old paint, varnish or lacquer to that the film can be easily scraped off with a putty knife, wire brush or similar tool.

title: Miss Knapp Bride Of Richard Bremer
description: OFFUTT AIR FORCE BASE, Neb., March 10Miss Barbara Knapp, daughter of Maj. Gen. James Barclay Knapp, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Knapp of Bellevue, was married here tonight to RichEdward Bremer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard George Bremer of White Plains. The ceremony in the Strategic Air Command Memorial Chapel was performed by the Rev. John Ruef, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: France Briefed on Administration's Proposed Trade Bill in Effort to Gain Cooperation in Money Crisis
description: PARIS, March 10  The United States made another gesture of cooperation today to try to improve the international monetary climate as Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz briefed the French Finance Minister, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, on the Administration's trade bill.

title: Molly Narens Is Betrothed
description: CANTON, Ohio, March 10 Miss Molly Jane Narens and Peter Stephen Ross plan to be married here April 29 at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard L. Narens, who have announced the engagement of the couple. Mr. Ross is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Ross of Washington.

title: EINSTEIN COLLEGE TO MARK 20 YEARS
description: In keeping with the character of the worldrenowned scientist for whom the institution was named, the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University will observe its 20th anniversary on Thursday.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Miss Down Is Bride of Elihu Joyner Jr.
description: Miss Patricia Jane Down, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Down of Westfield, N. J., and Elihu Holland Joyner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joyner of Cumberland, Md., formerly of Larchmont, N. Y., were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Andrew Mullins performed the ceremony.

title: The New Plays
description: OUT CRY, a play by Tennessee Williams, got two favorable reviews, (Barnes, Times; Watts, Post), two mixed (Watt, News; Harris CBSTV) and six unfavorable reviews (Gottfried, Women's Wear; Wallach, Newsday; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Glover, AP; Gayer, UPI; Bookspan, WPIXTV).

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: ZURICH, SwitzerlandChristoph Grilebler is a portfolio manager under fire, but he thinks the attack is going to let up soon and is making plans accordingly.

title: U.S. Newspapers Increased In 1972 Despite Loss of 3
description: Despite the merger or demise of newspapers in Boston, Newark and Washington, the total number of newspapers in the nation increased by 12 and daily circulation rose by almost 300,000 in 1972, Editor & Publisher said Friday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Francis J. Roberts' March 4 letter on Cities and the Military deserves an answer. Mr. Roberts writes that our cities are cluttered, declining, and dispirited because of a lack of Federal aid. The armed forces, on the other hand, are seen as being adequately funded. In Mr. Roberts' words The money is available to pick up the garbage at Fort Dix, but not in Newark.

title: Martha Crosby, Douglas Jacobs Plan Marriage
description: MARIETTA, Ga., March 10 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Raymond Crosby have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Bayley Crosby, to Douglas Lee Jacobs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Hall Jacobs of Lanesborough, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: NaziZionist Linkin War Is Seen in a Soviet Novel
description: MOSCOW, March 10A recent Soviet historical novel that seeks to demonstrate a link between Zionists and Nazis in World War II has been favorably reviewed in the officially controlled press.

title: Miss Wade Gains Final By Beating Chris Evert
description: DALLAS, March 10 (UPI)Virginia Wade, relying on her sizzling service, handed Chris Evert her first tournament defeat of 1973 today, downing the teenage sensation, 26, 63, 97, in the semifinals of the $37,000 Maureen Connolly Brinker tournament.

title: 2 Men Are Seeking Careers in Nursing
description: NORTH BRANCH  A 38yearold poultry farmer and a 51yearold man who had labored long in the hotel industry will become next year the first male graduates of Somerset College's nursing program.

title: Disqualification Gives First To Hail Y'all at Suffolk
description: BOSTON, March 10 (AP)Southern Slugger, the favorite, outdistanced the field today in the featured $6,500 onemile handicap at Suffolk Downs. However, the officiails ruled the horse guilty of interference in the stretch and named Hail Y'all the winner.

title: S. J. Conway to Wed Brooke Mahoney
description: OLD FIELD, L. L, March 10Dr. and Mrs. Jesse Waring Mahoney have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Brooke Waring Mahoney, to Stephen Joseph Conway, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Conway of Katonah, N.Y.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 125 bookstores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Jersey's Earliest Season Is Begun at Garden State
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., March 10New Jersey put, its parimutuel horses and horseplayers to work here today, five weeks earlier than usual.

title: Enrollment Decline That Began in the 1960's Continues in Jewish Day Schools
description: The enrollment decline that began in the midnineteensix ties in the Jewish schools of the metropolitan area con. tinued last year, spreading to the allday schools, the only segment of Jewish education that had not previously been affected.

title: W. W. Scheuplein Jr. To Wed Judith Genter
description: OTTAWA, Ill., March 10Dr, and Mrs. Frank J. Genter Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Judith D. Genter, to Walter W. Scheuplein Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Scheuplein of Short Hills, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Battle of the Gadgets for Telephone Lines
description: Dr. Harold Padow is unhappy about the rising cost of his telephone answering service and its discourteous handling of his patients. However, as a dentist with a practice in Brooklyn, Dr. Padow needs such a service. So he has begun to investigate automatic telephone answering machines.

title: Man of Many Musical Hats
description: Although Lawrence P. Sobol sits in many chairs and wears many hats, all of them are musical because his selfdeclared mission in life is to be involved with people through music and to reach the highest possible level of artistic expression.

title: Silver Recalls Past With New Quintet At the Half Note
description: Horace Silver, one of the jazz powers of the nineteenfifties who went into semiretirement in the sixties, is back in action again at the Half Note with a quintet patterned on his groups of the past. Those Silver quintets usually featured a trumpet and a tenor saxophone, along with Mr. Silver's piano, playing tunes that had a strong melodic basis and that were developed with breaks, stoptime and an everpresent sense of ensemble.

title: Eugene Bull Connor Dies at 75; Police Head Fought Integration
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 10 (AP)  Eugene Connor, the Birmingham Police Commissioner who used dogs and fire hoses to break up civil rights demonstrations in the early nineteensixties, died here today. He was 75 years old.

title: TRAFFIC COP, 72, ROSEBEN MOE
description: Refusing to yield against the challenge of a presumed stronger rival, Mrs. Adele Rand's Traffic Cop won the $27,150 Roseben Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: At the Racetracks
description: SANTA ANITACougar II took the $170,000 Santa Anita Handicap by a nose from Kennedy Road. A stewards' inquiry did not change the order of finish. The winner paid $5.

title: Giants Can Play at YaleMaybe
description: NEW HAVEN, March 10The trustees of Yale University extended today an invitation with reservations to the New York Giants to use the Yale Bowl as the site for the professional football team's home games the next two seasons while the Giants' new stadium is being built in the Hackensack Meadows of New Jersey.

title: TRIUMPHANT WINS GULFSTREAM RACE
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., March 10Braulio Baeza packed his tack and returned to New York when Hialeah closed last Saturday, but said he would be back in Florida for selected mounts at Gulfstream. Thus far his selections have been first rate.Last Wednesday he returned to win the Hutcheson Stakes with Shecky Greene and today he rode Triumphant to a narrow victory in the $62,600 Down Handicap.

title: Miami Beach Says Water Will Be Pure by Tomorrow
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 10 (AP)Drinking water was still being boiled in this resort city today but officials said that a water contamination problem should be solved by Monday.

title: Jeanne Boisi, a Teacher, Affianced
description: OLD BROOKVILLE, L. I., March 10  Mr. and Mrs. James O. Boisi have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Marie Boisi, to Robert F. Sheehy, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Sheehy Jr. of Roslyn Heights.

title: Apples Are Always in Season at Farm Stand in Suffolk
description: Farm stands on the eastern end of Long Island usually sell homegrown produce from the nearby fields and by Thanksgiving they are shuttered. However, the Milk Pail, on the Montauk Highway between Water Mill and Bridgehampton is, an exception. Not only does it first open in September and stay in business throughout the winter but its crop is homegrown 350 miles away.

title: U.S. Aides Accused of Prying In Yugoslav Student Interviews
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 10A Yugoslav student organization has accused American diplomats here of prying into sensitive political and social issues during interviews with students seeking to participate in a summer work and travel program in the United States.

title: Money for The Museums
description: ONE of the least remarked upon of recent developments in the art world in this country has been the allocation of significant sums of Federal money for artists, critics, scholars, museums and other creative and institutional activities in the visual arts. The public silence that has greeted this outlay of Federal money is itself remarkable. No longer do knopnothing legislators hasten to denounce money spent on contemporary art as part of a Bolshevik plot. But the enlightened are equally reticent. I think it is fair to say that President Kennedy got more attention in the press by inviting Andre Malraux to dinkiera relatively cheap undertaking that did not require a single fiscal request to Congressthan President Nixon has yet received for his initiative in channeling much needed funds into the professional activities of artists and art institutions. Being generally left, or at least Democratic, in its political sympathies, the art world scarcely knows what to make of this unexpected generosity on the part of a Government whose leader is not (shall we say?) one of its most beloved living Americans, and so it does little or nothing to interrupt the silence. In public, that is. In the privacy of the mails, the applications for a share of the bounty continue unabated. And the grants received are already making difference in the conduct of our cultural life.

title: Devaluation Is Working for Detroit
description: When it comes to the recent devaluation of the dollar, the United States abounds in skeptics. Many observers of the business and economic scene question whether President Nixon's action last month will do any more to help the country's balanceoftrade problem than the previous devaluation.

title: TORONTO ACCEPTS SEXY TELEVISION
description: TORONTO, March 10  In need of income and publicity, a smallbudget Toronto television station tentatively scheduled a totally unabridged Xrated movie for its late Friday night show last fall.

title: The Untidy Disruptions Caused by the Weak Dollar
description: Price inflation in the United States has intensified the world monetary crisisthe most serious of the postWorld War II era.

title: No Drugs Linked to Coed's Death
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., March 10The Nassau County medical examiner reported here today that the death of a Hofstra University student a day after a drug raid on the campus last month was attributable to natural causes and did not involve the use of drugs as the police had at first hypothesized.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: How tiresome and repetitive are the countless columns of typography, and the infinite volume of words disgorged at seminars and symposia by creative people defending the aesthetics of their art; by marketing people divining the certain success formulas for product acceptance, and by media people proclaiming the science of the optimum mix.

title: Harlem Man, 34, Is Arrested in the Sexual Abuse of Boy, 12
description: A Harlem man was arrested yesterday and charged with the kidnapping and sexual abuse of a 12yearold boy. The victim told the police that his screams for help had been ignored by passersby.

title: Photography
description: TWO photographers whose work has been greatly underappreciated are presented back to back in the exhibit which opens at the Witkin Gallery next Thursday.

title: MANHATTAN WINS IN N.C.A.A. TRACK
South Huntington Five Tops Brentwood for Suffolk Title
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., March 10  South Huntington High School won the Suffolk County basketball championship today, upsetting Brentwood, 4037, in the final. The Wildcats finished second to defending champion Brentwood during regularseason league play.

title: Daughter to the Scrivans
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., March 10A daughter was born Feb. 23 to Mr. and Mrs. Michel Andrew Scrivan at the Greenwich Hospital. The child has been named Katherine Anne. Mrs. Scrivan is the former Miss Millicent Anne Cross of Fairfield. Her husband is director of facilities maintenance for Flagship International in New York, a subsidiary of American Airlines in the operation of hotels and air catering.

title: STRIP MINE STUDY FAVORS CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 The decade of struggle by land owners and environmentalists to curb coal strip mining in the Appalachian Mountains has been a battle over less than I per cent of the nation's coal reserves, according to a Gov renment report.

title: VIRGINIA SCORED ON RACIAL EFFORT
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The National Education Association, in a brief filed with the Supreme Court, says that Virginia public officials were responsible for a flight by white persons that left schools in Richmond predominantly black and those in the suburbs virtually allwhite.

title: TWO WOMEN SHARE LEAD IN TEXAS GOLF
description: HOUSTON, March 10 (AP)Mrs. Mary Agn Rathmell, a Houston amateur and the mother of four, carded a par 72 today and tied Kathy Whitworth at 144 for the secondround lead in the $100,000 S&H Green Stamps ladies golf classic.

title: Police Search Intensified For Slayer of Bronx Widow
description: The police intensified their hunt yesterday for a youthful assailant who had robbed and killed an elderly widow and brutally beaten another widow in the same apartment house where both lived in the North Bronx.

title: Forest Hills Conversion From Grass Ends an Era
description: Another era has passed in tennis with the demise of the grasscourt championships at Forest Hills.

title: Is Pan Am Coming Out of the Spin?
description: Ten months ago, shortly after being abruptly handed command of Pan American World Airways during the worst economic spin in its 45year history, William T. Seawell greeted shareholders in a cavernous hangar at Kennedy. International Airport.

title: GAS POCKETS FOUND AT S. I. BLAST SCENE
description: Meter readings indicating the presence of natural gas both inside the Staten Island tank that exploded Feb. 10 and in the sloping earth hill surrounding the tank have been found by Fire Department and United States Labor Department investigators. Forty persons died in the blast.

title: Odessa Stars in Gymnastics
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I., March 10Odessa (Tex.) Junior College, which captured its fourth straight team championship last night, continued its winning ways tonight by sweeping five of the six individual titles during the National Junior College Athletic Association gymnastic championships.

title: Music: The Minnesotans
description: The Minnesota Orchestra (formerly the Minneapolis Symphony) is celebrating its 70th anniversary this year, and on Friday night it came to Carnegie Hall to play a program of more than ordinary interest under the direction of Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, its music director since 1960.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Maybe now, with the disclosure of the arrangement between two lefthanded pitchers on the New York Yankees and their wives, moralists finally will have learned not to be outraged whenever a professional athlete surrenders to human nature. Fritz Peterson is living with Susanne Kekich while Mike Kekich hopes that his romance with Marilyn Peterson can resume. If you're outraged at the arrangement, fair enough. But don't be outraged merely because it involved major league baseball players. Or because athletes are supposed to be above such behavior. Or because they're supposed to be models for our youth. If you're outraged for those reasons, that's your mistake for endowing athletes with attributes and responsibilities that many of them don't possess, don't claim to possess and don't particularly want to possess. Some athletes deserve to be cherished as human beings. But not all. Don't expect someone to be a saint just because he can throw a curveball, any more than you'd expect someone to be able to throw a curveball just because he's a saint.

title: Breitel Wins Bipartisan Support as Liberal Party Endorses Him for Appeals Court Post
description: The state committee of the Liberal party yesterday, endorsed Associate Judge Charles D. Breitel, a Republican, for chief judge of the Court of Appeals, thus giving him bipartisan support for the post.

title: Miss Poole, a Nurse, Fiancee of Interne
description: POUND RIDGE, N. Y., March 10  Mr. and Mrs. William Lawrence Poole of Pound Ridge and East Otisfield, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Jane Poole, to Dr. August John Valenti, son of Mr. ind Mrs. Dante Valenti of Wayne, N. J.

title: Amateurs to Play Montclair Concert
description: MONTCLAIRMore than 250 enthusiastic amateurs will take part next Saturday night in an ambitious musical program at Montclair High School.

title: Lord Howick of Glendale Dies; Helped Crush Kenya Mau Maus
description: ALNWICK, England, March 10 (UPI)  Lord Howick of Glendale, who as Governor of Kenya helped crush the Mau Mau rebellion of the nineteenfifties, died here today at the age of 69.

title: KLM Again Avoids France
description: THE HAGUE, March 10 (Reuters)The RoRyal Dutch Airline KLM decided today to cancel all flights over France because two planes had come nearer each other than is permitted over Le Bourget Airport last night. KLM had just decided to resume flights over France, suspended after a collision this week of two Spanish airlines over Nantes. Because of a strike of air controllers, military personnel are manning their posts at airports.

title: Vietcong Call Off Vietnamese Prisoner Exchange, Charting Saigon With Attack
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 10 (AP)The Vietcong today called off scheduled Vietnamese prisoner exchanges, charging that Government forces had attacked one of the ?? turnover points and occupied it.

title: Giants May Go to Yale
description: The Yale Corporation has approved the use of the 70,000seat Yale Bowl for New York Giants home games. The decision is contingent upon approval of New Haven and West Haven and on a television issue. Section 5.

title: SOVIET GYM TEAM. MAKES U.S. DEBUT
description: HOUSTON, March 10 (AP)Olga Korbut, winner of three Olympic gold medals, and Ludmilia Tourischeva, winner of two, charmed an audience of 12,482 at the Astrodmoe tonight as six Soviet Union Olympic gymnasts opened a sevencity United States tour.

title: A second look ... at Mark Spitz
description: The face of Mark Spitz appears, many times magnified, smiling over a glass of milk to millions of freeway drivers from countless billboards; it interrupts television programs to discourse on the virtues of milkdrinking; it adorns the almost lifesize poster of the champion in starred and striped bikini with his seven Olympic gold medals artfully arranged across his chest, which is the pinup of the year and may be one of the bestselling posters ever marketed. It is a photogenic face, distinguished by dazzlingly perfect white teeth flashing a triumphant smile, decorated with dashing mustache and crowned by luxuriantly tousled black hair. Its resemblance to Omar Sharif's face is often noted, and like his face, it seems destined for stardom in the movies. In short, his face has become a supremely marketable commodity, which through the miracle of modern merchandising techniques, has become a nearly unavoidable fact of everyday life for millions of Americans.

title: New Look for Shakespeare?
description: ELLIS RABB, like certain other talented directors, is sometimes more interested in his vision of a play than in the play itself. His production of The Merchant of Venice for the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center (which I saw at a preview, by special courtesy of the management) is not really a production of The Merchant of Venice at all, but an original work of Mr. Rabb's, ingeniously superimposed upon Shakespeare's text.

title: If Recording Jazz Were Up to Me...
description: SOME 13 years ago, I lived for a brief timethe. record collector's fantasy. I was working as the a&r man for Candid, a sudden subsidiary of. Archie Bleyer's then prospering commercial label, Cadence. Archie was an ideal employer. He never questioned my musical judgment although I think he was rather appalled at some of the abrasive sounds which were coming out on Candid. The operation was finally shut down because of deficiencies in my commercial judgment, It was the wrong timein the free marketplace for the kind of undiluted jazz we were recording.

title: SALT and MIRV
description: The United States faces an exciting and unexpected ppportunity in the resumption of the SovietAmerican Strategic Arms Limitations Talks in Geneva tomorrow.

title: Architecture
description: HOPE springs eternal for Federal design. And falls on its face with predictable regularity. New people appear making new proclamations that from now on everything will be different and better, a few exemplary, or nearexemplary products materialize, and then everything settles back in the same old rut.

title: New Jersey Steps Up Effort to Preserve Landmarks
description: TRENTON, N. J. In an effort to keep ahead of increasing land development and highway construction, New Jersey is stepping up its landmarkspreservation program and in the process outdistancing its northern neighbor, New York State.

title: Begin at the Beginning
description: GET OFF to a good start this spring and schedule the very basic gardening practices properly. The ideal time to clean up is in the fall, but if time did not permit then, rake up leaves on the lawn now (if dry to walk on) and collect dead and decaying plant litter in shrub and flower borders. As the growing season progresses, this job can become increasingly difficult since tender young shoots can be damaged as they emerge from the soil.

title: Eagles Get Wright, Tackle, From Cards for Taylor
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 10 (AP)The Philadelphia Eagles acquired a tackle, Steve Wright, from St. Louis Cardinals today in a straight player deal for Mike Taylor, also a tackle.

title: Holman Harvey Dies at 78; Reader's Digest Staff Writer
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., March 10  Holman Harvey, a staff writer of the Reader's Digest for 25 years, died yesterday at the age of 78.

title: Knight and Alex Win Best Skipper Prizes In WARM Regatta
description: Chris Alex of Huntington, L.I., winning all four races in the Portsmouth handicap division with a Sunfish, and Carlton E. Knight Jr.. of Mamaroneck, N.Y., sweeping the FormulaS Sunfish Division, won the best skipper trophies yesterday in the second annual WARM regatta, the Winter AllClass Regatta Maritime of the New York State Maritime College.

title: Saw Mill River Puts On Different Show Today
description: Today the different show is being held at the Westchester County Center in White Plains. It's the Saw Mill River Kennel Club fixture and, as usual, there are no groups or bestinshow judging. Of the more than 1,000 shows held each year in America, Saw Mill stands as the rugged individualist, the only major event to adhere to that policy. Still it has drawn 1,012 dogs, and that is a limited entry. We turned back more than 200 entries, said John Archibald, Saw Mill's president, because being a benched show, we felt that the Center couldn't accommodate more and still be comfortable for exhibitor and spectator.

title: Posh restaurants are kind to long hair
description: Jim Quinn's Word of Mouth (1973 edition) is the funniest book I have read in donkey's years, funny enough to read aloud to guests. Unlike the vague and lofty reviews of most other restaurant guides, Mr. Quinn tells it like it isin essays that can run around a thousand words and more.

title: S. F. Russotto to Wed Marion Platt
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., March 10Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Platt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Colette Platt, to Scott P. Russotto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Prances A. Russotto of East Greenwich, R. I.

title: Dr. Pamela Meyer Plans May Bridal
description: Dr. Pamela A. Meyer and Dr. Barry S. Zuckerman, 1972 graduates of the Georgetown University School of Medicine, have announced their engagement and plans for a May wedding in North Andover, Mass.

title: Raskin Moves to Niagara
description: Daniel Raskin, assistant basketball coach at the University of Bridgeport two years, has been named an assistant basketball coach at Niagara University.

title: Ribicoff Says Nixon Is Wrong In Saying Cities Crisis Is Over
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that President Nixon was wrong in saying that the crisis in the cities was over. Mr. Ribicoff, chosen by Congressional Democrats to reply to a speech by the President on the cities, declared in a nationwide radio address:

title: Rhodesian Killed in Clash
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 10A 51yearold farmer in the police reserve was killed in operations against guerrillas 60 miles from Rhodesia's border with Zambia, it was announced yesterday.

title: XRated Radio Shows Are Protested
description: WASHINGTON, March 10What Senator Marlow W. Cook of Kentucky recently referred to in a hearing as the nation's First, Xrated radio show and others patterned after it have become the subject of listener complaints to the Federal Communications Commission, according to an F.C.C. spokesman.

title: Sports Week
description: PRO BASKETBALL

title: Cougar II Takes $170,000 Santa Anita Handicap by a Nose and Returns
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 10On his third try, Cougar II won the $170,000 Santa Anita Handicap today, but it took a photofinish and a 10minute inquiry study by the track stewards to establish the winner by a nose over Kennedy Road.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In EasternStandard Time

title: Don't ask about bras
description: Can a man write a book that explains the goals, visions, history and problems off the women's  liberation movement with sympathy, understanding and insight? Gene Marine, a West Coast journalist and husband of feminist Judith Van Allen, has almost succeeded in doing just that.

title: The Nation
description: The devalued dollar, still sagging despite two emergency operations in 14 months, was back in surgery this weekend. Topranking monetary specialists from the United States and the rest of the nonCommunist world huddled in Paris and Brussels to try to infuse new strength into the dollar's increasingly shaky position as pivot of the international exchange system.

title: 3 TOP FRENCH SKIERS SENT HOME BY COACH
description: PARIS, March 10 (AP)The French national ski trainer, Georges Joubert, has informed officials here he is sending home the leading members of the men's World Cup team, it was announced today.

title: The Road to Secession
description: Why did the slave South, in the face of seemingly overwhelming odds, embark upon a political course in 186061 that was destined not only to render her politically and economically impotent for decades to come but to destroy the socioeconomic institution she sought so desperately to preserve? That is the perennially intriguing question to which William A. Barney, a member of the history department at Trenton State College, addresshimself.

title: Surtees and Angus Reach J.S. Amateur Racquets Final
description: BOSTON, March 10 (Reuters) William Surtees, the defending champion, and Howard Angus, both of London, reached the final round of the United States amateur racquets championship today at the Boston Racquets and Tennis Club.

title: A Black Manager: Who Will Be First?
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10Twentysix years after Jackie Robinson broke the color line in the major leagues, baseball people are predicting that the first black manager will be appointed in the next season or two.

title: CANADIENS EXTEND UNBEATEN STREAK
description: MONTREAL, March 10 (UPI)  Guy Lefleur's 24th goal of the season, Frank Mahovlich's 33d and Ken Dryden's sixth shutout give the Montreal Canadiens a 20 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight to extend their unbeaten streak to 10 games.

title: Going Back Home Again to the North Shore
description: THEY say we can't go home again. Home to youth, innocence, idealism, romance. Yet all of us try, never acknowledging that the world we have left behind may have changed one way, and we another.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Forgotten Victory: The Battle of Springfield
description: SPRINGFIELD  Thomas Fleming, the historian, made his way among the gravestones at the cemetery here, near the site of a Revolutionary War battle that took place close to 200 years ago. Mr. Fleming stopped to look at the names on the stones  Reeve, Parsil, Vanarsdalen, Woolley, Littel.

title: How Japan entered the modern world
description: RAWLING samurai; politicians in smokefilled rooms (charcoal, not cigarettes); sinister agents of foreign powers, pockets crammed with arms contracts  all these cinematic elements tend to divert the eye from the real drama of Japan in the mid19th century. Renewed contact with the Western world confronted Japan with some quite real dangersof being reduced to some sort of colonial or semicolonial status, for example and with a problem no less acute, namely, how best to organize to repel the foreigners, or at least to minimize their impact. Similar pressures were to cuff the Chinese from one disaster to another, but in Japan they brought regeneration, prompting first the overthrow of the enfeebled Tokugawa government, in an efficient coup d'tat, and then a speedy and even more efficient dismantling of feudalism. And the rest is history.

title: Newspaper Give's Advice on PaperTraining Dogs
description: A 40page newspaper that contains instructions for training dogs to relieve themselves indoors is being distributed by the city's Environmental Protection Administration free of charge to pet owners who want to help control the city's doglitter problem.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: One day last week, Fred Pomerantz, the 72yearold chairman of Leslie Fay, Inc., and his son John, 39, the company's president, were discussing how they manage one of the most prominent sportswear and dress companies on Seventh Avenue.

title: Frankfurt Cites Drug Counts
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, March 10 (Reuters)Americans were involved in almost half the narcotics offenses committed in Frankfurt last year, Police Chief Knut Muller reports.

title: Pop
description: IN the realms of hip legend, astral pleasures, rock and roll and business as usual, the Grateful Dead stand higher than any other veteran American rock band.

title: Sandra Pellman Affianced
description: HARRISON, N. Y. Feb. 10 The engagement of Miss Sandra Jane Pellman to Mark Stuart Newman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Newman of White Plains, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Pellman.

title: Union Five Wins State Title
description: ALBANY, March 10 (AP)Union College scored a 6964 victory over Albany State today for the Eastern College Athletic Association's Upstate New York basketball championship. In the consolation game, St. Lawrence defeated Fredonia State, 6736.

title: William Walsh, Lawyer, to Wed Linda Zimmer
description: RUMFORD, R.I., March 10 Miss Linda Jean Zimmer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Basil G. Zimmer of Rumford, and William Christopher Walsh plan to be married here Aug. 18 in St. Margaret's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Movies
description: LOS ANGELES.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodaySaw Mill River K. C. allbreed and obedience, Westchester County Center, Bronx River Parkway, White Plains, N.Y.; 1,012 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: New Look, Not New Reality
description: CANBERRA, AustraliaOne of the wisest foreign appointments President Nixon has made since 1968 was naming Marshall Green Ambassador to Australia. This country feels it has been neglected too long by its big American brother.

title: Ecology Kit Used to Teach Youngsters
description: HOLMDEL  The Committee for a Better Environment is using a specially designed ecology kit to bring environmental education to: children in the primary grades.

title: DAILY NEWS OBJECTS TO A LONDON PAPER
description: The Daily News obpected today to the use of its logotype by The Sunday Times of London, whose magazine supplement a week ago used a cover made up to look like a Daily News front page as an introduction to an article about violence in New York.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: One Penn Plaza, the 57story office building between 33d and 34th Streets and Seventh and Eighth Avenues, has signed six new leases. The building is now more than 60 per cent rented, according to HelmsleySpear, Inc., its renting agents.

title: INQUIRY ON MIAMI HALTED BY A SUIT
description: MIAMI, March 10An inquiry into alleged corruption in Dade County's courts and local government has been halted, at least temporarily, by a legal action in Tallahassee.

title: Stanley Wayman Is Dead; Photographer for Life, 45
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)Stanley E. Wayman, who covered four Presidents as White House photographer for Life magazine, died today. He was 45 years old. His fatherinlaw, Denver Dickerson, former Lieutenant Governor of Guam, said Mr. Wayman died of an apparent heart attack.

title: Two ExP.O.W.'s Their Clashing Views Reflect Generation Gap
description: LOS ANGELES, March 10  Limit Col. Alan L. Brunstrom wants to go to Washington and shake hands with President Nixon, the man, he feels, who brought the prisoners home with honor and justified their sacrifice.

title: A Votre Sante With Homegrown Grapes
description: WASHINGTON WITH the increasing popularity of home winemaking, some gardeners have begun to grow their own wine grapes. In the Washington area, Chester H. Page of Silver Spring, Md., has found the local climate ideal for many of the FrenchAmerican hybrids, particularly some of the vitgorous white wine varieties.

title: Diane Ward Affianced
description: MIAMI, March 10Mr. and Mrs. Marshall H. Ward Jr. of Miami, formerly of Locust Valley, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Jennings Ward, to Nicholas Edwards, Long, son of Mrs. Ann Revis of Chicago.

title: AROUND THE
description: Indoors plant tomatoes, eggplant, peppers in a warm shady place; move to sunlight after seed germinates.... Start marigolds, zinnias, snapdragons and coleus for early bedding.... Finish up pruning chores.... Keep off the soggy lawns.

title: Jerez: A Stable world of Wine, Work and the Power of the Dons
description: ANDALUSIANS say, There is Andalusia and there is Ierez. Though why Jerez de la Frontera, which is technically part of Andalusia, should be different is not readily visible. Certainly not on the surface, anyway. The city is dryhot, with streets of restless dust, noisy motor scooters, sharp shadows and the one or two harmless madmen who, like lethargic dogs and public clocks giving different times, are nearly always to be seen in any sizable town in Spain's south.

title: Trevino, With 205, Keeps 4Shot Lead
description: MIAMI, March 10Lee Trevino's lucky number here seems to be four. He led the first round of the $150,000 Doral Eastern open by four strokes with a 64. He was still ahead by four after 36 holes yesterday. And today, after a oneunder par 71 at the Doral Country Club course, he continued to hold a fourstroke edge with a 54hole aggregate of 205, or 11 under par.

title: Anne Gocdman Is Betrothed
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn., March 10Mr. and Mrs. Jack Davidson Goodman of New Milford and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Howes Goodman, to James Danielly Finley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Finley of Red Bank, N. J. A spring wedding is planned.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
Rarities of the World on Sale
description: OME of the most soughtafter stamps of philately are being offered at one of the major auctions of the year on March 22, when the Robert A. Siegel Galleries present their 10th annual Rarities of the World.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONHonesty is always the best policy, said George Washington in his Farewell Address.

title: Unseeded McDermott Gains Eastern Tennis Semifinals
description: Ron McDermott became the only unseeded player to reach the semifinals of the Eastern men's indoor tennis championship yesterday when he defeated Ricky Meyer, 76, 36, 63, at the Stadium Tennis Center in the Bronx.

title: GERMANY RAISES MARK BY 3%, JOINS FRANCE IN FLOAT
description: BRUSSELS, Monday March 12Six of the nine member nations of the European Economic Community agreed today to link their currencies in a common float.

title: Some Sweetness...
description: MINNEAPOLISIs there, to borrow Arthur Schlesinger's phrase, a reign of terror against the press now going on in Washington?

title: 4 HELD IN ATTEMPT TO KIDNAP ACTRESS
description: An attempt to kidnap Neva Small, a singeractress who has appeared in Broadway plays, movies and opera productions, was disclosed by the police yesterday after the arrest of four young men accused of a dozen holdups in the city.

title: Limited Diplomacy
description: President Nixon's month of the Middle East has come and gone. Now the Administration must decide whether there is anything the United States can profitably do to soften tempers and reduce the danger war in that pivotal sector of the world.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: East Orange Teachers Continue Walkout as Negotiations Fail
description: The East Orange Education Association decided last night to resume a teachers walkout today after a fivehour negotiating session failed to resolve a dispute over budget cuts.

title: New York Had Smaller Share Of Ship Traffic in '72 Than '71
description: The Port of New York, although still in a commanding position as the nation's No. 1 trade terminus, lost ground last year in its share of the country's total vessel traffic. Data on ship arrivals, released by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, showed that New York in 1972 handled 19.8 per cent of all merchant ship arrivals at major continental ports. This compares with 20.5 per cent in 1971. Also, the rate of increase in traffic here last year was less than that enjoyed by the country as a whole.

title: Red Smith
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., March 11During Derby week in Kentucky some years ago, several guys walked into a Louisville restaurant with Piper Laurie, a movie starlet. Eddie Arcaro was dining with Conn McCreary and he leaped from his chair as though he'd been hit with a battery. Up to now, he said, charging over to join the group at the bar, I thought the prettiest thing in Kentucky was a horse! The knightly observation came back to mind the other day when they led a horse named La Prevoyante into the walking ring at Gulfstream Park. Movie starlets should be pretty as this filly. There were more Beautiful People in the paddock than you could stuff into the yacht Christina, and it was almost ludicrous the way they followed the filly around.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: SONDHEIM GIVEN MUSICAL TRIBUTE
description: Sandheim, a musical tribute, was presented at the Shubert Theater last night, and all of Broadway turned up to pay homage. Those who were not on the stage, seemed to be in the audience. It was an impressive celebration of the talents of the composerlyricist Stephen Sondheim, and a?? equally impressive demonstration of the way Broadway feels about him.

title: News Summary and Index
description: France's Gaullistled Government coalition won a renewed fiveyear mandate in yesterday's final round of legislative elections, with a markedly stronger showing than had been expected.. Returns from over twothirds of the contested districts in metropolitan France showed that the existing Government would have an easily workable majority in the new Assembly, even without help from the centrist Reformers, who are nonetheless likely to be represented in the Cabinet. [Page 1, Colunm 8.]

title: Psychosurgery to Face Key Test Today in Midwest Courtroom
description: DETROITFor the last 18 his 36 years, Mr. L. has lived the life of a forgotten man. A alleged murderer and rapist who is reported to have a lifelong history of uncontrollable pages, he has spent all his adult ears behind the locked doors of a state institution for the criminally insane.

title: SENATORS PLAN BILL ON PROPERTY TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI)Most states still assess and administer property taxes the same way they did a decade ago even though they have had expert guidelines for reform since 1963, a Senate subcommittee reported today.

title: NICIAI REVEALS ROOTING INTEREST
description: The team the National Collegiate Athletic Association didn't want won its openinground game in the basketball championships Saturday and the N.C.A.A. still doesn't want Southwestern Louisiana.

title: SecuritiesIndustry Unit Opposes Negotiated Rates
description: Wall Street's smoldering controversy over negotiated commission rates has flared up with a blueribbon panel of industry leaders stating its formal opposition to certain proposals endorsed by the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Rangers Win, 42; Stop Leafs' Rally
description: The New York Rangers, who had played ties against Chicago and Philadelphia in their last two Madison Square Garden starts, got back to their winning form at home yesterday by beating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 42.

title: Muse Is Princeton Coach
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 11 Bill Muse was named today soccer coach at Princeton. He was assistant coach at Hartwick last season. He replaced Jack Volz, who resigned last fall.

title: British Football Results
description: RUGBY LEAGUE

title: 3 LEADING RACE FOR GRIEF JUDGE
description: An appellate judge from the Bronx whose public electioneering has involved sending out, on request, copies of a biographical resume, emerged yesterday as one of the three leaders in the Democratic party's complicated struggle to pick a nominee for New York State's highest judicial post  chief judge of the Court of Appeals.

title: Didn't Intend to Hurt Israel, 5 Say as Spy Trial Closes
description: TEL AVIV, March 11Three Israeli Arabs and two Jews who have admitted that they trained with arms and explosives and passed information in clandestine visits to Syria said today that they had never intended to harm Israeli security or help Israel's enemy.

title: Henry L. Schenk Is Dead; Bank Executive Was 74
description: Henry L. Schenk, vice chairman of the board of the National Bank of North America, an affiliate of the CIT Financial Corporation, died Saturday of a heart attack in Miami Beach. He was 74 years old and lived here.

title: Need for Pennsy Doubted In Solving of Rail Crisis
description: The Federal official directly in charge of drafting a full and comprehensive plan for the preservation of rail transportation in the Northeast is not certain that a viable Penn Central Railroad is necessary.

title: NAVY DETERMINED TO RECRUIT BLACKS
description: SAN DIEGO, March 11 From the little neighborhood offices that recruiters occupy to the stately academy at Annapolis, the Navy appears determined to sign up more blacks.

title: Hopis Accuse Navajos Of Terrorist Incidents
description: WINSLOW, Ariz., March 11  The chief of the Hopi Indians has accused the much larger Navajo tribe of land grabbing and has said that the Navajos are using terror tactics to keep the Hopis from using land given them by the Federal Government almost a hundred years ago.

title: She Spends Her Day Piping In Music, Then Listens to More of Same at Home
description: When Joe, who works on the gumwrapping machine, arrives at the plant at 8 A.M., there's Muzak coming over the Speakers and, like a goodnatured Big Brother, it welcomes him with Not as a Stranger. At 9, when Brenda, the secretary, is getting the boss's coffee, she might be accompanied by strings playing If I Ruled the World.

title: Jersey Orders Two Milk Sellers To Increase Their Retail Prices
description: In this era of inflation, with government generally trying to hold prices down, the State of New Jersey finds itself in the peculiar position of having to order two milk sellers to raise their prices.

title: STAGE STARS IN PLEA FOR A SOVIET DANCER
description: LONDON, March 11 (AP)A group of British and American stage stars expressed concern today that one of the greatest dancers in the world is not being allowed to dance.

title: Mays Fined by Berra
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11Willie Mays conceded today that I made a mistake in leaving the New York Mets' training camp for two days, and Manager Yogi Berra promptly advised him that the mistake would cost $500.

title: Changing the Pattern
description: The prepossessing bulk of George Meany so dominates the labor scene that it is easy to overlook the substantial changes that are beginning to affect leadership patterns in some unions. The notion that the only instrument of toplevel turnover was the arrival of the undertaker losing its universality.

title: Clinton Captures P.S.A.L. Title
description: Steve Sheppard, a 6foot4inch senior and one of the most highly sought basketball players in the city, scored 29 points and picked up 22 rebounds to lead DeWitt Clinton to a 7269 victory over Haaren in the Public Schools Athletic League championships at the Felt Forum yesterday.

title: European Solution Urged By Bonn on Money Crisis
description: BRUSSELS, March 11We want the solution to be as European as possible, a leading West German official said this evening, explaining the policy with which the Bonn Government's delegation entered the crucial international currency negotiations here.

title: In London, Paris, Rome, Strikes Burden Living
description: LONDON, March 11An Englishwoman in Paris last week heard of a death in her family and tried to rush home to London. Few planes were flying from Paris because of the air traffic controllers' strike, but she managed to get a plane to Gatwick Airport, about 30 miles from London.

title: Sulphate Peril May Lead To Tighter Clean Air Law
description: DURHAM, N. C.A new villain is emerging in the air pollution picture, a situation that may call for eventual revisions in Federal air quality standards.

title: Mars Data Revive Scientific Debate
description: The longstanding debate as to whether there have been radical changes in the earth's spin axis has been revived with the observation on Mars of features suggesting pole changes on that planet.

title: Peronists Leading With 43% of Vote In Early Returns
description: BUENOS AIRES, Monday, March 12  The Peronist coalition held a solid lead early today in the national elections, but was falling short of the majority needed to win outright, according to official returns.

title: Lanigan Wins Skating Title and Elbow War
description: HICKSVILLE, L. I., March 11Unperturbed by the histrionics or elbows of Barth Levy, the defending champion, Bill Lanigan swept the five men's events today and regained the national speedskating championship.

title: Mob in Bangladesh Kills 4
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, March 11 (UPI)Four people suspected of carrying unauthorized weapons were beaten to death and a fifth was critically wounded by a mob in a village 75 miles south of Dacca, the police said today. The dead were identified as two proMoscow Communists and two student supporters.

title: W. Indies Trails in Cricket
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, March 11 (Reuters)Rohan Kanhai and Deryck Murray held the West Indies together in a sixthwicket stand of 62 today on the third day of the second cricket test against Australia. At the close, the West Indies, at 241 for five, was 83 runs behind Australia's firstinnings total of 324. The first match was drawn.

title: JOHN F. M'NAMEE
description: John F. McNamee, who retired as vice president of Club Razor and Blade Manufacturing Corporation of Newark in 1965, died yesterday in Sarasota, Fla., where he lived.

title: NIXON'S FUND DRIVE SHOWS MORE GAINS
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Money is still pouring into the coffers of President Nixon's 1972 relection campaign four months after Election Day.

title: Soviet Gymnasts Make U.S. Debut
Former City Aide Held In Murder of S.I. Youth
description: The former director of the city's Neighborhood Manpower Service Center on Staten Island was held without bail yesterday on charges of murdering a 19yearold service station attendant during a holdup last year.

title: Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Monetary Crisis Brings New Vocabulary With It
description: BRUSSELS, March 11Since the February dollar devaluation a new vocabulary has arisen on the international monetary scene. Followinuh are definitions of some key terms:

title: 150 Police Seek Leads In Sex Slaying of Boy, 10
description: In the drab squad room on West 100th Street, the detectives ground through the incessant routine of a major investigationcanvassing the trime scene again and again for witnesses, answering the constantiy jangling telephone, typing reports and checking files.

title: Newark Council to Caucus On Renomination of Keri
description: City Council President Louis M. Turco of Newark said yesterday he had called the other eight Council members to caucus at 10 A.M. tomorrow at City Hall to discuss Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's resubmission of the appointment of Edward L. Kerr as Police Director.

title: Peronists Leading With 43% of Vote in Early Returns
description: BUENOS AIRES, Monday, March 12The Peronist coalition held a solid lead early today in the national elections, but was falling short of the majority needed to win outright, according to official returns.

title: Ilene Kornblath Married to a Professor
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L.I., March 11Miss Ilene Kornblath, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Kornblath, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Peter Steven Rosenbaum, son of Mrs. Abner Kupperman of New York, and the late Leroy Rosenbaum. Rabbi Norman Belink performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai, assisted by Cantor Norman Belink.

title: A Weekend of Brahms at New School
description: Alexander Schneider, direcfor of the New School Concerts, came up with a somewhat off2 beat notion for a chambermusic presentation in the auditoIrium of the New School for Social Research in Greenwich Village. Entitled A Weekend of Brahms, it would encompass the three piano trios, the three piano quartets and one sonata each for violin, viola and piano, in three concerts.

title: Stage: Comedy a la TV
description: Has the Broadway theater really considered its relationship with television and, even, the movies? Last night a new play by Louis Del Grande opened at the Playhouse Theater. It was called 42 Seconds From Broadway. When I saw it at its final preview, I wondered how many hours it was from television.

title: All of Canned Mushrooms From Company Are Recalled
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 11 (AP)All canned products containing mushrooms manufactured by the Fred Mushroom Products Company of South Lebanon, Ohio, are being recalled nationally, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: According to McManus, the hero of The WhoreMother, poets are the hardestworking men in Ireland. They must be. Judging by the Irish novels I've read, every man, woman and child in the country is in competition with them. Applying melodramatic metaphors to Ireland seems to be the great national pastime: An old sow that eats her farrow. . . . A whoremother, etc. It is never spring . . . always autumn in Ireland, said one of these hardworking poets, and he may be right. Irish characters in fiction are powerfully fond of the dying fall, forever harking back, keening over their history, working themselves up to a rhetoric of poverty, politics, and ambivalence about themselves. In The WhoreMother, most of the characters seem simultaneously proud and apologetic about being Irish. We were born to selfdestruction, says one woman, and yet she glories in it, like a tragedienne with a juicy part.

title: BLUMENTHAL SEES A 2WAY PRIMARY
description: Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal pictured the Democratic mayoral primary yesterday as a twoway contest between him and Representative Mario Biaggi.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PERTH AMBOY, N.J., March 11When a family has contributed one son to the National Football League and another to the American Basketball Association, what does it do for an encore?

title: Textbooks Prove a Route to Profits
description: It isn't easy to set up a small business and keep it running while facing impatient creditors, arguing with slow payers and dealing with a disenchanted wife who leaves and eventually joins a West Coast religious cult. But it looks as if Marc Strausberg has accomplished this on his second tryan enterprise called MSS Information Corporation. The situation wasn't very promising a decade ago when Mr. Strausberg was a 28yearold New York sale representative for Allyn & Bacon, the Bostonbased textbook publisher. But he had idea.

title: Lodge Leaves Hospital
description: BOSTON, March 11 (AP) Henry Cabot Lodge, former Ambassador to the United Nations and South Vietnam, was discharged today from Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, where he underwent surgery Thursday for removal of the prostate gland. Mr. Lodge, 70 years old, is a former Senator from Massachusetts.

title: TV's Top Anchormen Assess White House Policy Toward Network News
description: Network television's four leading anchormenJohn Chancellor of the National Broadcasting Company, Walter Cronkite of the Columbia Broadcasting Sysiem and Harry Reasoner and Howard K. Smith of the Ameriean Broadcasting Companywere invited by The New York Times participate in a roundtable discussion last week to explore the relationship between the Nixon Administration and the television news medium.

title: Governor of Bermuda and Aide Are Assassinated
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 11A state of emergency was declared in Bermuda today in the wake of the murder last night of Sir Richard Sharpies, the Governor of this British colony, and his aide de camp.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OPERA BUFF Some like it sweet, some like it loud, but whatever way they like it, they can hear it at Bianchi and Margherita, the restaurant where music shares the Menu with the minestrone at 186 West 4th Street (2422756, 6759852). Like its much senior and more highly decorated competitor, Asti, at 13 East 12th Street, Bianchi and Margherita has a staff of singers who perform to piano accompaniment into the wee hours, drenching the diners and drinkers in either the best or the most popular in opera And musical comedy.

title: The N.C.A.A. Pairings In Regionals Thursday
description: East (At Charlotte, N.C.)Penn (215) vs. Providence (252); Maryland (226) vs. Syracuse (234).

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: SATURDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Nets Win and Near Playoff Role
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 11  The Nets turned back the Memphis Tains, 120113, at Nassau Coliseum today, and with the victory accomplished two things of significance.

title: Goolagong, Is Beaten In Net Final
description: DALLAS, March 11 (AP)Virginia Wade's bristling serves. and powerful forehand volleys were too much for Evonne Goolagong of Australia today and the English woman won the $12,000 first prize by taking the final of the Maureen Connolly Brinker tennis tournament. The scores were 64, 6.1.

title: ROBERT SIODMAK, FILM DIRECTOR, 72
description: ASCONA, Switzerland, March 11 (AP)Robert Siodmak, the film director and producer, died of a heart attack yesterday in a hospital in Locarno near here. He was 72 years old and had lived here for 18 years. His wife, the former Bertha Odenheimer, died seven weeks ago. They had no children. Two brothers, Curt of Three Rivers, Calif., author and director, and Werner of Israel, survive.

title: SUSPECT IN HOLDUP DISARMS POLICEMAN
description: A man suspected of a $4 holdup near Union Square yesterday afternoon disarmed a Transit Authority patrolman as the policeman was arresting him, but he was captured less than an hour later, north of Times Square.

title: Carpeting Is Popular On the IND
description: The Transit Authority is rolling out the red carpet these days  through Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx. The carpet, which is actually orange as well as red, is affixed to the floors of eight new subway cars operating on the D line of the IND.

title: Jersey Orders Two Milk Sellers To Increase Their Retail Prices
description: In this era of inflation, with government generally trying hold prices down, the State New Jersey finds itself in the peculiar position of having order two milk sellers to raise their prices.

title: Capitol Crime (cont.)
description: A bad idea never diesparticularly in Congress; it doesn't even fade away. If it's bad enough, it will be revived over and over again, as in the case of the extension of the West Front of the Capitol. Now that this misguided scheme has been proved economically and architecturally outrageous it would currently cost $60 million for some poorly planned office space achieved through the destruction of art and historyit is being pushed again by Vice President Agnew and the Congressional Commission for the Extension of the Capitol.

title: CARMINE GALLONE
description: ROME, March 11 (AP)Carmine Gallone, known for his epic film productions, died of a heart attack tonight in a hospital in Frascati. He was 77 years old.

title: Riley of Dolphins Retires
description: MIAMI, March 11 (AP)Jim Riley, a starting defensive end for the Miami Dolphins until he suffered a knee injury in last summer's preseason workouts, has announced his retirement from football.

title: Florida Cane Cutters: Alien, Poor, Afraid
description: BELLE GLADE, Fla.  Two West Indian sugar cane cutters, muscles bulging under their Tshirts, flattened themselves against the dark wall, careful that the floodlights illuminating the labor camp of wooden shacks did not touch their faces.

title: TERMS ON U. S. AID TO HANOI DEPICTED
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The White House will ask Congress to approve postwar aid to North Vietnam only if Hanoi begins living up to its part of the Paris agreement, Administration sources said this weekend.

title: Sara Koffman Wed To Robert Mantica
description: Miss Sara Jane Koffman and Robert Philip Mantica were married here at noon yesterday in the Hampshire House by Rabbi Joseph I. Weiss.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: ExCity Aide Held In Youth's Murder

title: Women's Rights Reach New High With Wings
description: Stewardesses for Women's Rights, a group seeking to change the sex symbol image of their jobs, introduced a symbol of their own at a twoday conference ending yesterday: a winged version of the female genetic sign, used originally in biological sciences and more recently, in various forms by the women's movement.

title: The New Federalism
description: LONDON, March 11When President Nixon calls for a renewal of American federalism, for dispersal of responsibility from Washington, he is on a theme that should be compelling. Centralized programs have been so disappointing in recent years as cures for poverty and social decay. Diversity and localism, once regarded as backward notions, are once again coming to be seen as essential in a continental country.

title: Advertising: Risque Magazines
description: The recently formed International Periodical Distributors Association says that its reporting service has found there are more than 60 antiobscenity bills in the works in various state legislatures that could well affect the magazines they handle.

title: $385MILLION DUE IN U.S SEWER AID
description: TRENTON, March 11The Federal Government has allocated $385million for construction of new and improved sewagetreatment systems: in the state over the next two years.

title: Susan Hawk Bride Of Leslie Brisman
description: NEW HAVEN, March 11Miss Susan L. Hawk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Hawk of Wilmington, Del., was married here this afternoon to Leslie Brisman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Brisman of Brooklyn, New York. Rabbi Arnold Jacob Wolf performed the ceremony in the Branford College Memorial Room at Yale University.

title: Mayoral Coalition Talk Abounds
description: Mayor Lindsay's withdrawal from the mayoral race last week reduced the chances of a rare DemocraticRepublican coalition to stop him, but high sources in both parties, are not ruling out such an alliance later this year to support Controller Abraham D. Beame if he wins the Democratic mayoral primary. Governor Rockefeller, knowing that a Republican mayoral candidate cannot win on the G.O.P. line alone, is said to be considering the possibility of insuring Mr. Beame's election as a good government candidate who would, cooperate with Mr. Rockefeller in tackling the city's problems by giving Mr. Beame the G.O.P. nomination if he wins the Democratic primary in June.

title: McGovern Differs With Nixon's Plan For Death Penalty
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI)Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, said today that he disagreed on both moral and legal grounds with President Nixon's proposal to reinstitute the death penalty.

title: Mrs. Meir, Home, Asserts Peace Policy Is Unchanged
description: TEL AVIV, March 11Premier Golda Meir returned here today from her visit to the United States and said that there is no basis for changing Israel's policy on a Middle Eastern settlement.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 12, 1973

title: CONNORS VICTOR IN TENNIS FINAL
description: PARAMUS, N. J., March 11  Jimmy Connors of Miami won his fifth tournament on the winter circuit today by crushing Clark Graebner of New York, 61, 62, in the final of the $15,000 Garcia event at Bergen Community College.

title: N.C.A.A. Threatens Champion
description: Chris Dunn, the national collegiate indoor high jump champion from Colgate, said yesterday that he has been warned about jeopardizing his collegiate track and field career by competing in the United StatesSoviet Union indoor meet Friday night at Richmond.

title: LIGHTNIN FORGES EARLY SAIL LEAD
description: MIAMI, March 11With the world oceanracing champion Ted Turner of Atlanta at the helm, the 39foot OneTon Class sloop Lightnin surged into the lead today as a small but select fleet of six boats got under way in the 811mile race to Montegd Bay in Jamaica.

title: Family of 5 Dies in Fire
description: UNION, Ky., March 11 (AP) A father and his four daughters died today when fire swept their rural home here, the authorities reported. The victims were Lawrence Hegge, 33 years old, and his daughters, Valerie, 12, Kimberly Sue, 10, Kelly, 8, and Marcell 2. The girls' 32yearold stepmother Judy Hegge, escaped by jumping from a bathroom window, officials said.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: Stage: Cole Porter's out of This World' Is Revived
description: In 1950, a beautiful, lavish production and some silver Cole Porter strains couldn't save Out of This World from Broadway doom. Neither could the star, Charlotte Greenwood, whose leggy, vaudeville capering warmly shattered the veneer of sophistication. The show's book, with a dash of the Amphitryon legend, remained a feeble Joe Miller joke about Mount Olympus gods and goddesses archly invading mortal bedroom.

title: Psychosurgery Will Face Key Test in Court Today
description: DETROIT, March 11For the last 18 of his 36 years, Mr. L. has lived the life of a forgotten man. An alleged murderer and rapist who is reported to have a lifelong history of uncontrollable rages, he has spent all his adult years behind the locked doors of a state institution for the criminally insane.

title: Woman in Cell Found Dead From Overdose of Narcotics
description: A 40yearold woman arrested for allegedly disrupting traffic at a busy downtown Brooklyn intersection was found dead of an overdose of narcotics in her detention cell early in the evening just before she was to be removed for arraignment, the police said.

title: Unidentified Man Shot Dead In Bar on the West Side
description: An unidentified man in his 50's was shot and killed last night in the washroom of a midtown bar. Earlier, two men had entered the establishment, the Broadway Pub at 133 West 45th Street, and conversed with the victim at the bar, according to the police.

title: U.S. Halts Pullout Until Reds Free Next Group of Prisoners
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 12 (AP)The United States announced today that it had halted American troop withdrawals from Vietnam until the Communists released the next to last group of American prisoners of war, scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday, and provide a list, and date of release for the final group.

title: Chutist, 18, Dies in Jump
description: ORANGE, Mass., March 11 (UPI)A parachutist from Hartford, Conn., fell to his death today when his parachute failed to open during routine jump, the police said. The victime was Randolph A. Dickey, 18 years old.

title: In London, Paris, Rome, Strikes Burden Living
description: LONDON, March 11An Englishwoman in Paris last week heard of a death in her family and tried to rush home to London. Few planes were flying from Paris because of the air traffic controllers' strike, but she managed to get a plane to Gatwick Airport, about 30 miles from London.

title: Trevino Struggles To 1Shot Victory
description: MIAMI, March 11I didn't mean to make it that close, confessed Lee Trevino after he won the Dorai Eastern open by one stroke today. His final 71 for 276 earned the first prize of $30,000 and enabled the talkative Texan to become the pro tour's leading moneywinner as he displaced Bruce Crampton, who finished in a secondplace tie here with Tom Weiskopf.

title: Legislature in 11th Week of Leisurely Pace
description: ALBANY, March 11 The Legislature enters the. 11th week of the 1973 session tomorrow after nearly three months during which it has acted on only one major issue passage of a modified form of nofault automobile accident insurance. Compared with the pace of some past sessions, that record is above average, since the lawmakers have dealt fairly early with a major bill. But the pace is still a long way from the orderly deliberative process that the Republican majority leaders of both Houses they desire.

title: Sticks and Bones Wins Favor in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, March 11David Rabe's prizewinning play, Sticks and Bones, whose cancellation by the Columbia Broadcasting System television network stirred controversy in the United States last week, has been having a highly successful run here since November.

title: WHITES CONTINUE NEWARK BOYCOTT
description: A leader of the white student boycott at Newark's Vailsburg High School said that the fiveweekold protest would continue today despite a compromise decision issued by the State Education Commissioner, Carl L. Marburger, during the weekend.

title: Bridge:
description: ST. LOUIS, March 11  A Minnesota pair with no previous claim to tournament fame captured the open pair championship title here last night at the ChasePark Plaza Hotel in the opening event of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: SELLING OF MARKS DISCLOSED BY FED
description: The Federal Reserve moved actively in the foreign exchange market in late January and throughout February to slow the climb in the value of the West German mark and to keep trading orderly.

title: DR. HAROLD ZAHL, 68, ARMY RESEARCHER
description: HOLMDEL, N. J., March 11 (AP)Dr. Harold A. Zahl, former director of research of the Army's electronics laboratory and a noted physicist, died today at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank. He was 68 years old.

title: Midwest Strained As Grain Sales Glut Railways and Ports
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 Record shipments of grain have overloaded railroads and ports and spread severe financial problems along a network reaching into the major grainproducing areas of the Midwest.

title: Senegal a Haven for U. S. Film Makers
description: MALIKA, Senegal, March 6Priest, Harlem's super hustler of the controversial but commercially successful motion picture Super Fly, has taken his wealth of street wisdom from grimy upper Manhattan to the desert sands and lush riverbed jungles of Senegal.

title: Results of Water Testing In Miami Expected Today
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 11 (AP)  The results of tests to learn if chlorinization has eliminated contamination from this resort city's water supply will not be known until tomorrow.

title: Clutch Is Seen Slipping on Interest Rates of Bonds
description: The nation's creditmarket clutch no longer seems able to prevent soaring shortterm interest rates from engaging the bond market and driving up longterm rates as well.

title: GAULLIST CROUP RETAINS POWER FOR FIVE YEARS
description: PARIS, March 11The GaulIlistled Government won a renewed fiveyear mandate in today's final round of legislative elections with a markedly stronger showing than had been expected.

title: Governor of Bermuda and Aide Are Assassinated
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 11A state of emergency was declared in Bermuda today in the wake of the murder last night of Sir Richard Sharples, the Governor of this British colony, and his aide de camp.

title: White House Plans Changes in Legal Aid to Poor That Critics Say Will Weaken Program
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The White House is drafting fundamental changes in Federal legal services for the poor aimed at decentralizing them and, in the eyes of its critics, seriously undermining the program.

title: REV. DR. J. P. WILLIAMS
description: The Rev. Dr. John Paul Williams, a professor in the religion department of Mount Holyoke College from 1940 to 1967, died Wednesday in Claremont, Calif., where he lived. His age was 73.

title: Steward of Jet Downed By Israel Reported Dead
description: PARIS, March 11 (Reuters)JeanPierre Burdiat, the French steward who survived the crash of a Libyan airliner forced down over the Sinai Desert by Israeli jets when it went off course on Feb. 21, was reported to have died of his injuries in a hospital here last night.

title: Personal Finance: FlightInsurance Plans
description: Air travel is just about the safest form of transportation today, but air crashes receive so much publicity when they do occur that millions of people refuse to fly anywhere without first buying flight insurance.

title: 4 ARRESTED AT N.Y.U. IN MARIJUANA RAID
description: Two New York University students and two other men were arrested last night after two plainclothes anticrime policemen entered a dormitory suite off Washington Square and seized just under a pound of marijuana, the police reported.

title: F.B.I. Agent Shot as Indians Warn U.S.
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., March 11A Federal Bureau of Investigation agent was shot and a militant Indian was injured this afternoon when gunfire erupted at a roadblock set up by the Indians to control traffic into this occupied village.

title: Midwest Strained As Grain Sales Glut Railways and Ports
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 Record shipments of grain have overloaded railroads and ports and spread severe financial problems along a network reaching into the major grainproducing areas of the Midwest.

title: Tunisia's Economy and Her President Are Apparently Now in Better Health
description: TUNIS, March 2President Habib Bourguiba and Tunisia's finances appear in better health than they have for years. Thus this little North African country is feeling relaxed, even though none of its basic problemspoverty, unemployment and an uncertain political futureare close to a solution.

title: Italian Industrialists Injured
description: GENOA, Italy, March 11 (AP)  Leopoldo Pirelli, 47 years old, president of the Pirelli Rubber Company, and his brother Giovanni, 54, were injured in an automobile accident tonight in a highway tunnel near Genoa, the police said. Both suffered serious burns and were hospitalized.

title: School Bus and Car Collide
description: CASSADAGA, N. Y., March 11 (AP)A school bus and an automobile collided near this Chautauqua County village this afternoon, injuring at least 29 pupils, none of them seriously, sheriff's deputies said.
