The bus was carrying about 30 students of the Cardinal Mooney High School, near Rochester.

title: City Intensifies Its Fight Against Pistol Company
description: Gears whirred and machine presses thumped at the plant of CDM Products, Inc., on the second floor of an eightstory loft building at 141145 Wooster Street, three doors south of Houston Street, last week.

title: SCRIBNER WIDENS CHOICE OF STUDIES
description: High school students in the city school system, particularly those in the 11th and 12th grades, will be allowed greater initiative in shaping their own study program under a new set of directives sent to their grincipals by Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner.

title: NORDIQUES TRIUMPH OVER RAIDERS, 61
description: QUEBEC, March 11 (AP)Rayland Leclerc scored two goals tonight as the Quebec Nordiques defeated the New York Raiders, 61.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: MAKARIOS BACKED SOLIDLY BY GREEKS
description: ATHENS, March 11 With rare unanimity, the Greeks have sided with Archbishop Makarios, the President of Cyprus, in his feud with the island's three Bishops who decided to unfrock him.

title: Saigon May Release Thieu Foe, an AntiCommunist, to Vietcong
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 11The case of Tran Ngoc Chau, whose imprisonment by the Saigon Government in 1970 caught world attention, now turns on the question of whether he will be turned over to the Vietcong or set free.

title: A Plague on Both...
description: Whenever they get the opportunity in byelections these days, British voters send the message loud and clear: they are disillusioned as never before with both major parties and frustrated by the twoparty system. There are fears that the disillusionment, may spread to parliamentary government itself.

title: Surtees Injured in Match
description: BOSTON, March 11Bill Surtees of Chicago was injured today while defending his United States open racquets championship against Howard Angus of England at the Boston Racquet and Tennis Club. Leading by 98 in the first game, Surtees was struck over the right eye by his opponent's racquet and was taken to a hospital for examination. The match will be rescheduled.

title: Proposed Legislative Districts For The State Senate and The Assembly
Need for Pennsy Doubted In Solving of Rail Crisis
description: The Federal official directly in charge of drafting a full and comprehensive plan for the preservation of rail transportation in the Northeast is not certain that a viable Penn Central Railroad is necessary.

title: 3 BELIEVED PACING CHIEF JUDGE RACE
description: An appellate judge from the Bronx whose public electioneering has involved sending out, on request, copies of a biographical resume, emerged yesterday as one of the three leaders in the Democratic party's complicated struggle to pick a nominee for New York State's highest judicial post  chief judge of the Court of Appeals.

title: The Ensemble in New and Newer Music
description: The end of ideology, proclaimed some years ago in international politics, has been stealing over contemporary music, too. Yesterday's New and Newer Music concert given by The Ensemble under the direction of Dennis Russell Davies at Alice Tully Hall could serve as an illustration of the almost dogmatic lack of dogmatism to be found in recent compositions.

title: Screen: 'White Sister':Sophia Loren Cast as a Nursing Nun in Cliche-Filled Tale of Hospital in Italy
description: No doubt it comes from seeing too many of the wrong old movies, but from a title like "White Sister" I expected something slightly tropical, mildly mysterious and vaguely erotic. I should have known better. There have been White Sisters on film beforetwo, in fact: Lillian Gish in 1923 and Helen Hayes in 1933and though their stories haven't much to do with Sophia Loren in the nineteen-seventies, they, like she, were nursing nuns.Expelled from her African home and duty by the revolutionary government of Libya, Sister Germana (Miss Loren) is assigned to a hospital in Italywhere, immediately, she takes charge. It is a happy-go-lucky hospital, unusual, and with two doctors, two lay nurses, two orderlies, a cook, several hundred patients, and Sophia Loren.Miss Loren controls the wards, keeps the records, tastes the food, supervises the nurses and assists in the operating room. She is without peer and without competitionexcept from one patient, Annibale Pezzi (Adriano Celentano), atheist, communist and amorous young malingerer who wants to run the hospital his way. It is immediately obvious that he and she will fall in love.Each in his own way, Annibale and Sister Germana, are forces for good. And from the combination of two such forcesat least in a movie like "White Sister"  there can come only supergood.Beyond a spell of pouting for Annibale and a bit of heartbreak for Sister Germana, there is not much relief from the goodness, though a hospital always provides emergency cases, terminal cases, hair-breadth recoveries and malpractice mortalitiesthe whole day-to-day life-and-death routine of the place to make up for real dramatic action.Annibale and Sister Germana have a momentary spiritual union maybe, but no affair. Once they hold hands and, under extenuating circumstances, they kiss (she is devout, but no prude). But the general aura of sentimental piety is never dispelled, not even by the presence of Sophia Loren.For those who feel, as I do, that if there were no cinema Sophia Loren would be sufficient reason for inventing it, "White Sister" will offer very little more than a beautiful but unanimated mask of their heroine.Adriano Celentano, a good actor (scarcely known here), is made to portray a kind of sullen rough-edge cuteness. And Fernando Rey, as the hospital's chief of staff, plays straight the quality of distinguished gentleness that he has so brilliantly parodied in the films of Luis Bunuel.Alberto Lattuada directs down for drama and up for emotion with a sometimes-appealing innocence. When a young man expires in a hospital bed to the accompaniment of violins and cellos, and a heavenly choir (I swear) just at the moment of his passing overit seems less like film than like archaeology, like unearthing the world's oldest clich, long dead but with its heart still gamely beating."White Sister" opened Saturday at the Columbia I Theater.

title: Mystery Missions
description: There should always be a clearly discernible line between the creation of public policy and the pursuit of private profit. In his comments on the activities of former Secretary of the Treasury John Connally, President Nixon showed a dismaying insensitivity to that distinction.

title: Brauna B. Eisenberg Is Married
description: SCRANTON, Pa., March 11 Miss Brauna Beth Eisenberg and Marvin Joseph Fortgang were married here this afternoon by Rabbi Max Posnansky in Temple Beth Shalom.

title: Downey, Released By China, Crosses Hong Kong Border
description: HONK KONG, Monday, March 12John T. Downey, a 42yearold American held in China since 1952 on espionage charges, was freed today and crossed the border from China into Hong Kong at 11:50 A.M.

title: Casey Urges Global Unity In All Stock Disclosures
description: WASHINGTON, March 11William J. Casey, the Undersecretary of State for Economic Affairs, called over the weekend for the establishment of uniform international standards of minimum disclosure in connection with securities offerings as a means of creating a truly international securities market.

title: TERMS ON U. S. AID TO HANOI DEPICTED
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 The White House will ask Congress to approve postwar aid to North Vietnam only if Hanoi begins living up to its part of the Paris agreement, Administration sources said this weekend.

title: Yank DH's Slump to .520 In Orioles' 100 Triumph
description: MIAMI, March 11  Thurman Munson, his mustache approaching the walrus variety, stood at the batting cage today and talked about his designation as the Yankees' designated hitter for the game with Baltimore.

title: GERMANY RAISES MARK BY 3%, JOINS FRANCE IN FLOAT
description: BRUSSELS, Monday, March 12 West Germany's Finance Minister, Helmut Schmidt, an nounced early today that the mark would be revalued up ward by 3 per cent when for eign exchange markets reopen March 19.

title: JUVENILE IS SEIZED IN SLAYING OF GIRL, 9
description: SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., March 11  A juvenile suspect was arrested this afternoon in the slaying of a 9yearold girl whose body was found with multiple knife wounds this morning after an allnight search. The state police, who said they had also recovered the weapon used in the killing, withheld the name of the suspect because of his age.

title: The Indians' Due
description: When the skirmishing at Wounded Knee is over, the Indian nations and the American people alike should take a hard look at a situation that has hardly been helped by the wistful reprise of an old outrage. Since the infamous massacre of 1890, the country's policy for the Indians has moved from extermination to assimilation (first through allotment of individual holdings, then through termination of Federal care) to the present unsatisfactory policy of tribal sovereignty watered down by poverty and adulterated by bureaucratic intervention.

title: Bugging Inquiry Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)H. William Shure, a New Haven lawyer and former judge advocate in the Air Force, was named today an assistant minority counsel of the special Senate committee assigned to investigate the Watergate bugging affair and related charges of political espionage. The appointment was announced by Senator Howard Baker, Republican of Tennessee, vice chair?? of the committee.

title: 2,500 Untouchables Shed Hinduism And Embrace Buddhism in Delhi Rite
description: NEW DELHI, March 11 They sat on the ground in tattered clothes and bare feet. They folded their hands, rocked forward and chanted in solemn unison.

title: Warriors Beat 76ers, 9793, As Barry Plays Decisive Role
description: PITTSBURGH, March 11 (AP) Rick Barry broke a 9393 tie, then stole an inbounds pass that produced a disputed 3point play as the Golden State Warriors defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 9793, in a National Basketball' Association game tonight.

title: Forum Bouts on Tap Tonight
description: David Vasquez of the Bronx, will face Francisco Villegas of Puerto Rico tonight in one featured 10round bout at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum. In the other bout, Edwin Viruet of the Bronx will oppose Nestor Rojas of Venezuela.

title: Minnesota Five's Loss Becomes N.I.T.'s Gain
description: The National Invitation Tournament, suffering from sagging attendance in recent years, got lucky. Minnesota, the big draw it lacked, is coming to Madison Square Garden.

title: TEXAS TORNADO TOLL RISES TO SIX DEATHS
description: HUBBARD, Tex., March 11 (AP)The death toll rose to six today from the tornado that struck this central Texas town early yesterday.

title: Montclair Greets P.O.W. With a Look Back at 1950
description: MONTCLAIR, March 11With Sousa marches, highschool cheers and the harmonies of a barbershop chorus, Montclair today welcomed a native son, Comdr. Robert B. Doremus, back after seven and a half years as a prisoner of war.

title: Exhaust Hearings to Begin
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI)  Government hearings will begin tomorrow on the auto makers' plea for a oneyear postponement of the stiff exhaust emission standard set for 1975 models. The hearings will he conducted by the Environthental Protection Agency.

title: ISLANDERS LOSE ON 2 LATE GOALS
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 11 (AP)  Danny Grant's two goals in the final minutes gave the Minnesota North Stars a 21 National Hockey League victory over the New York Islanders tonight.

title: RIGHTS UNITS PLAN NIXON OFFENSIVE
description: CHICAGO, March 11  The new civil rights movement plans to utilize the tactics of the old in a national spring offensive against the Nixon Administration's economic policies.

title: Humphrey Discloses Plan to Name Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI)  Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, while visiting the White House today, said that he would have chosen Henry A. Kissinger as his adviser on national security if he had been elected President in 1968.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Paul Delaney's recent summary in The Times of the Administration's proposed civil rights budget for fiscal year 1974 incorrectly asserted that most of the $629million increase in civil rights outlays would be concentrated on benefits for middle  class minorities rather than on the traditional areas of civil rights enforcement.

title: Eugene Bull Connor Dies at 76; Police Head Fought Integration
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 11 (AP)  Eugene Connor, the Birmingham Police Commissioner who used dogs and fire hoses to break up civil rights demonstrations in the early nineteensixties, died here yesterday. He was 75 years old.

title: Mortgage Auction Is Set
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (Reuters)  The Government National Mortgage Association announced today that it would auction $272million of 6 per cent unsubsidized mortgages on April 4. Any F.H.A.approved mortgagee is eligible to bid. A similar auction was held on March 7.

title: GREAT DANE PRIZE GOES TO KITTY K
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 11 Ch. Harldane's Kittie K, owned by Gordon and Martha Wright of Wantagh, L. I., and handled by Dan Lasky, was best of breed among the Great Danes today for the third year in a row at the Saw Mill River Kennel Club show. This competition, which drew 1,012 dogs and a crowd of 5,500 to the Westchester County Center, has no group winners nor bestofbreed award.

title: Celtics Conquer Knicks, 122  107
description: BOSTON, March 11The New York Knicks' slim chance of catching the Boston Celtics virtually disappeared this afternoon at Boston Garden in a foulfilled battle between the National Basketball Association Atlantic Division rivals.

title: Records: In Ellingtonia
description: Over the last 10 years Duke Ellington has left a growing accumulation of unreleased records behind him, a storehouse of Ellingtonia that is just beginning to seep out into the stores.

title: Survival in Britain
description: OXFORD, England  The British economy is in a period of acute crisis. After two decades of a diminished share in world trade, the last few years saw inflation accelerating to around 10 per cent per annum, combined with feebler growth and unemployment rising above the million mark. Much less well known is the acute profitability crisis which leaves British capitalismthat is, the system of production for private profitliterally struggling for survival.

title: A PROTESTANT RAID STOPPED IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 11  A group of clubwielding Protestants were stopped by the British Army at the edge of a Roman Catholic publichousing development m Newtownabbey, just north of Belfast, last night. Today two of the group of 99 were charged with carrying guns, nine with carrying other weapons and the rest were freed.

title: HOUSTON GOLF WON BY MISS WHITWORTH
description: HOUSTON, March 11 (AP)Kathy Whitworth, the career leading moneywinner on the women's pro golf tour, captured her biggest paycheck today. She shot a twounderpar 70, in the final round for 214 and a twostroke victory to win the $20,000 first prize in the $100,, 000 S&H Green Stamps golf tournament.

title: Edward Ackerman, Geographer With Carnegie Institution, Dead
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 11Edward A. Ackerman, executive officer of the Carnegie Institution, an educational and research organization, died on Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at National Airport. He was 61 years old and lived here.

title: F.B.I. Agent Shot as Indians Warn U.S.
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., March 11A Federal Bureau of Investigation agent was shot and a militant Indian was injured this afternoon when gunfire erupted at a roadblock set up to control traffic into this occupied village.

title: Mrs. Henry Ford 2d: Still Ebullient and Vivacious
description: Mrs. Henry Ford 2d recently celebrated her eighth wedding anniversary. She was back in Europe where it all began and the day marked another small victory over a lot of people who had thought there never would be a wedding and, once there was, that wouldn't last.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Orangetown (N.Y.) Public Library, which was evicted a month ago for not paying its rent, apparently has resolved its longstanding dispute with the government of the Rockland County town.

title: TV: Mostel Stars in Old Faithful, New Musical
description: The idea of an original musioal on television for Zero Mostel, an infrequent visitor to the medium, is a good one. And the first 15 minutes of Old Faithful, an hourlong program scheduled for the American Broadcasting Company tonight at 9, look promising. program scheduled for the American Broadcasting Company tonight at 9, look promising.

title: SHULTZ IN SOVIET FOR TRADE TALKS
description: MOSCOW, March 11Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz arrived here today for three days of crucial talks on the prospects of SovietAmerican trade.

title: LIGHTNIN FORGES EARLY SAIL LEAD
GAULLIST GROUP RETAINS POWER FOR FIVE YEARS
description: PARIS, March 11The Gaullistled Government won renewed fiveyear mandate in today's final round of legislative elections with a markedly stronger showing than had been expected.

title: Montclair Hails Prisoners With a Look Back to 1950
description: MONTCLAIR, March 11With Sousa marches, highschool cheers and the harmonies of a barbershop chorus, Montclair today welcomed Comdr. Robert B. Doremus, a native son, back after seven and a half years as a prisoner of war.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Paterson Fire Destroys 3 Stores

title: BEAUTY TALK
description: In Elizabeth Arden's day, those pastel pink jars were full of romance and big, dark secrets. Miss Arden's very feminine approach was that beauty was an aim a woman should devote herself to and that she needn't bother her pretty little head with the science of cosmetics.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: View Typifies Officials' Guarded but Positive Reactions to Move
description: BRUSSELS, March 12Paul A. Volcker, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said today, One ingredient of what we need has been put into place for solving the international currency crisis.

title: WILLIAM J. MONAHAN JR.
description: RAHWAY, N. J., March 12 (UPI)Inspector William J. Monahan Jr., the highestranking uniformed police officer of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, died yesterday. He was 48 years old.

title: Frankie Frisch Dies
description: Frankie Frisch, a member of baseball's Hall of Fame, died in Wilmington, Del., yesterday at the age of 74. He had suffered critical injuries a month ago in an automobile accident near Elkton, Md. Details, Page 42.

title: Nordiques Conquer Blazers With 3dPeriod Goals, 64
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 12 (AP)  Michel Archameault's goal early in the final period tonight gave the Quebec Nordiques a 64 victory over the Philadelphia Blazers in a world Hockey Association game.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hour's Given In Eastem Standard Time

title: Judge to Be C.A.B. Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)President Nixon intends to nominate a state judge from Oklahoma as a member of the Civil Aeronautics Board, the White House announced today. Ronald L. Ziegler, press secretary, said Lee R. West, a Democrat from Ada, Okla., would resign the judgeship he has held since 1965 to join the C.A.B.

title: Ginny May Auction Slated
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (Reuters) The Government National Mortgage Association announced today that it would auction $272million of 6 per cent unsubsidized mortgages on April 4. Any Federal Housing Authorityapproved mortgagee is eligible to bid. A similar auction was held on March 7.

title: Incentives Urged in Paper Reuse
description: The amount of waste paper made usable could be more than doubled to over 25 million tons by 1985 if the Federal Government would help industry with incentives, such as tax rebates per ton of reclaimed material, according to a study for the American Paper Institute.

title: Rev. Dr. Kent S. Knutson, President of American Lutheran Church, Dies at
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 12 (AP)The Rev. Dr. Kent Knutson, president of the Ameri can Lutheran Church diead to day, five months after he was hospitalized with a rare brair disorder. He was 48 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: The PBW Stock Exchange said yesterday it had been granted a stay against implementing a Securities and Exchange Commission rule that institutional members transact at least 80 per cent of their business with the public or unaffiliated investors.

title: FOOD TALK
description: Standard Brands has entered the egg market with a cholesterolfree substitute, a frozen product based on egg whites that the company says has a nutritional value similar to whole eggs.

title: International Air Fares To Increase 2 to 11.1%
description: Fares on most international air routes will increase from 2 to 11.1 per cent next month as a result of the devaluation of the dollar, the International Air Transport Association said yesterday.

title: U.N. Unit Accuses The North Koreans Of 2 DMZ Killings
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, March 12The United Nations command accused North Korea today of killing two South Korean soldiers and wounding another last Wednesday in the first serious shooting incident in the Korean demilitarized zone since September of 1971.

title: Gunman Reported Slain By Soldiers in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Tuesday, March 13 (AP)British troops said they shot a gunman to death early today, and a 16yearold Protestant youth died of wounds he received in a bomb blast earlier this month.

title: PENTAGON TO PUSH FOR MINORITY JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 Secretary of Defense Elliot L. Richardson expressed shock today at the absence of women and representatives of minority groups in top civilian jobs in the Army and other services. He ordered an immediate effort to change the situation.

title: Amex and OTC Stocks Drop Slightly
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market finished slightly lower yesterday in continued slow trading.

title: GIANTS' TV ISSUE STIRS OPPOSITION
description: A Representative from WestChester County and the president of a Hartford television Station said yesterday they would protest if the New York Giants planned a television blackout of any games they Might play at the Yale Bowl in New Haven.

title: Five Democrats Will Vie In Primary for Chief Judge
description: ALBANY, March 12A fivecandidate fight for the Democratic nomination for New York State's highest judicial post, Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, emerged from an indecisive designating convention here today.

title: TV: Stewart as Lawyer
description: Good writing, sure playing and smooth, lowkeyed direction mesh effectively in Hawkins on Murder, one of the better made  for  TV movies, carefully formfitted to James Stewart. As a top criminal lawyer defending a young California heiress on a triplemurder charge, the actor fares much better in this oneshot appearance than in his situation comedy series that nosedived.

title: Japanese and Spanish Dancers Seen
description: Creative tensions both between and within cultures marked several programs over the weekend, as Saeko Ichinohe and Company appeared at Japan House Sunday and Z and J appeared at the Cunningham Studio Friday evening.

title: Moscow Exhibit Gains
description: CHICAGO, March 12 (Reuters)More than 70 American companies that provide equipment and services for the oil and gas industries have signed contracts to participate as exhibitors in the NeftaGaz Expo in '73 in Moscow Oct. 23 to 31, Martin C. Dwyer, Inc., and the Welt International Corporation, organizers of the exposition, reported today.

title: Attempt to Widen Canarsie Boycott Of Schools Fails
description: A boycott by white parents of eight schools in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn went into, its eighth day yesterday as Canarse parents attempted, without apparent success, to widen the protest to two schools in the Gravesend area.

title: MILTON MARX
description: Milton Marx, a portrait painter, watercolorist and the theatrical caricaturist for the former Newark News, died, Sunday at his home, 209 East 56th Street. His age was 75.

title: French Vote: Show of Stability
description: PARIS, March 12  The French election yesterday has brought a certain relief and a degree of dissatisfaction for every party concerned.

title: CAMBODIANS YIELD TOWNS ON HIGHWAY
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 12 (AP)Government troops under intense Communist pressure withdrew from two towns 20 miles south of Phnom Penh today despite heavy American bombing support, according to reports from the field.

title: U.S. Again Blocks Roads
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., March 12Armed Federal officers reestablished roadblocks on all roads leading into this occupied village this afternoon, thus again sealing militant Indians inside the area they now proclaim the Independent Oglala Sioux Nation.

title: RAIL LABOR PACT WITH 14 UNIONS IS REPORTED NEAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The railroads and 14 unions are on the verge of signing a new 18month nationwide labor contract, union and industry officials reported today. They said it would be the first time in memory that a national rail contract had been reached without strikes or other disruptions.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SWINGING SCHOLARS From 1 to 6 this afternoon, Philharmonic Hall, Broadway and 65th Street, will be as full of msuic as it could possibly be. All for free. This is the prologue to tomorrow's statewide Music in Our Schools Day. Today, it will be celebrated by taking student music makers out of the schools and employing them, on all four levels of the hall, as well as in the hall itself.

title: Miss Shultz, Teacher, Is Bride
description: HONOLULU, March 12Miss Elizabeth Shultz, a teacher at the Maili Elementary School in Wainae, was married here yesterday to Capt. Jerald S. Takesono of the Air Force Dental Corps.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: NEWS DISPUTE CUTS AN EDITION OF PAPER
description: A dispute over a delivery driver's work assignment at The Daily News last night led to a work stoppage that prevented the distribution of 65,000 copies of the newspaper's early edition in Manhattan and the Bronx.

title: Chess: The UpandDown Ruy Lopez Now Is Enjoying Up Status
description: The Ruy Lopez, named after the Spanish bishop who analyzed some of its principal variations in his Libra del Ajedrez in 1561, holds the field today over all other open games. That was not always true.

title: HEARINGS STARTED ON ACUPUNCTURE
description: ELIZABETH, March 12 A state legislative committee began hearings today on the prospect of licensing the practice of acupuncture.

title: CHASE OFFER SET TO DIAL FINANCIAl
description: The Dial Financial Corpora. tion announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to be acquired by the Chase Man. hattan Corporation.

title: Basketball Ratings
description: The top 20 with points figured on a 201816141210987654321 basis (firstplace votes in parentheses) and wonlost records and total points:

title: Downey Captured on a ColdWar Day
description: John Thomas Downey, who returned to the United States yesterday after 20 years as a prisoner of the Chinese Communists, was shot down on a day when the Korean war was still raging and the outlook for a truce was clouded by disputes over the issue of prisoners of war.

title: YIELDS ADVANCE IN BOND MARKETS
description: Interest climbed acrosstheboard again yesterday as the economic advance continued to make heavy demands on the money market, and bond buyers remained on the sidelines, awaiting still higher returns on longterm securities. Not much optimism was heard in Wall Street that bond rates would soon turn down, despite some dramatic upward adjustments in recent weeks. The capital markets remain highly sensitive to the issue of inflation and may be expected to react to any events which may have a bearing on future price increases or strength of the economic recovery, Merrill Lynch said in its latest bond letter. We continue to believe that longterm yields remain in a rising trend, it concluded.

title: ELECTRONICS GROUP SETS 9POINT PACT
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The $30billion electronics industry, long divided over foreign trade, announced agreement today on a ninepoint set of principles aimed at fairer world trade conditions and no new restrictions on investment abroad by United States companies.

title: Leonard Will Quit Post In Justice Department
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (APP)Jerris Leonard, head of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, will quit his job Wednesday.

title: MANILA STRESSES REFUGEES' PLIGHT
description: MANILA, March 12  As Government troops and Moslem dissidents clashed for a 12th day in the southern Philippines today, a Cabinet Minister said that 742,000 civilians were running from the fighting, looking for food.

title: Fond Farewell to the Fordham Flash
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12After five weeks of battling against insuperable odds, toughfibered Frank Frisch finally succumbed today to the crippling injuries of his automobile smashup. The world of sports has to be desolated by the news, and I am more deeply grieved than most because the old Fordham Flash was not only my first sports idol but also my close personal friend. I placed him on a pedestal even before I knew him, and the better I got to know him the higher that pedestal kept mounting. He may have been a shorttempered firebrand on the ball field, but off it he was an utter delight, a genuine funnyman with an outrageous sense of humor. When I was a small boy in short pants, I had many opportunities to introduce myself to the great Frank Frisch. I didn't have the nerve. I was too awed by him. I thought of that episode about a dozen or so years ago when my young daughter, Kathy, answered the phone at home. She looked a little bewildered as she handed it to me.

title: Brown Trial Is Told Weapons Don't Give Usable Fingerprints
description: A police expert testifying at the trial of H. Rap Brown said yesterday that it was virtually impossible to obtain usable fingerprints from firearms.

title: Senate Unit May Summon Nixon Aide
description: WASHINGTON, March 12James O. Eastland, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said today that he would vote to call a White House counsel, John W. Dean 3d, as a witness in the committee's hearings on the nomination of L. Patrick Gray 3d as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: PERONIST ELECTED ARGENTINE CHIEF, LOUSE REPORTS
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 12The military Government tonight declared Dr. Hector J. Campora, the handpicked presidential candidate of former dictator Juan Domingo Peron, as the victor in Sunday's national elections.

title: Cahill to Nominate Two for High Court
description: TRENTON, March 12  Governor Cahill announced this evening that he would nominate his personal counsel, Pierre Garven, and State Superior Court Judge Mark A. Sullivan as associate justices of the New Jersey State Supreme Court.

title: Wood, Field and Stream,
description: There is a movement afoot in America to make a sojourn in the outdoors resemble a fraternal organization's annual summer outing, and those willing to be caught in swirling crosscurrents of humanity at the New York Coliseum last Sunday could see what new products have been created to achieve this end.

title: Music: Vocal Virtuosos of France
description: The avowed aim of the Marcel Couraud Vocal Group is to explore the outer limits of musical and physiological possibilities in the human voice. And it does do that. Sunday night's concert of contemporary music at Alice Tully Hall under Mr. Couraud's direction, the group's debut here, demonstrated what can be done by any conductor who has been able to round up a dozen phenomenally flexible voices and has the talent to push them into uncharted regions of accuracy and pitch refinement.

title: Maine Senate Votes Repeal Of Poll Tax on Adult Males
description: AUGUSTA, Me., March 12The Maine Senate today gave final approval, 26 to 2, to bill that would repeal the $3 poll tax on adult males, a law that has been on the books since 1845.

title: Mrs. Harry Brandt Dead; Theater Executive's Widow
description: Mrs. Helen Satenstein Brandt widow of Harry Brandt, theater chain executive, died Sunday at the home of her son, Richard of 941 Park Avenue, while on a visit from Miami Beach, where she had been living. She was 68 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 13, 1973

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Baraka Discusses Politics as an Art
description: Seeing A Recent Killing, his 1964 play, on stage regently in its New Federal Theater production left Imamu Amiri Baraka (LeRoi Jones) with mixed feelings. It was like looking in a trunk, he said. A lot of stuff I had forgotten came out. It was about a period in my life in 1954 and 195520 years ago, two times removed.

title: Indictment Charges Use of Public Aides For Work on Home
description: TRENTON, March 12 (AP)  The Attorney General's office today announced the indictment of Andrew Ferenz, director of the Delaware River Port Authority Bridge, and two other officials on charges they had conspired to use authority labor and materials for construction at Mr. Ferenz's home.

title: Downey Back Home To Visit His Mother
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., March 12After more than 20 years as a prisoner in China, John Thomas Downey came home tonight to be at the bedside of his critically ill mother, in a hospital here. He was freed by China this morning and crossed the border into Hong Kong.

title: Haker Victor in Giant Slalom; First World Cup Race in Japan
description: NAEBA, Japan, March 12 (AP)Erik Haker of Norway won today the first World Cup ski race held in Japan, a giant slalom, while David Zwilling of Austria, by placing fifth, closed in on Gustavo Thoeni of Italy, the series leader, who was disqualified.

title: Kasko, Denied DH in Own Park, Lashes Out at InterLeague Rule
TAX BILL BY JUNE IS GOAL OF MILLS
description: WASHINGTON, March 12Chairman Wilbur D. Mills of the House Ways and Means Committee hopes to have a taxreform bill completed by June 15 and will not interrupt the committee's work on taxes to turn to trade legislation unless some kind of international economic emergency requires it.

title: Raskind, Miller Advance In U.S. Maccabiah Tennis
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., March 12Favorites led the way today at the start of a tournament for positions on the United States tennis team for the World Maccabiah Games in Israel this summer.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: There is a movement afoot in America to make a sojourn in the outdoors resemble a fraternal organization's annual summer outing, and those willing to be caught in swirling crosscurrents of humanity at the New York Coliseum last Sunday could see what new products have been created to achieve this end.

title: Float Toward Stability
description: WASHINGTON, March 12Although floating Commor Market national currencies will add some surface uncertainty in international dealings for Americans, in another sense the decision is likely to mean less uncertainty.

title: Citibank Says Emphasis Remains on Growth Issues
description: The First National City Bank said yesterday that although it sold a number of quality growth stocks last year from the pension funds and personal trusts it administers, it continued to emphasize large quality growth issues.

title: Relief Units Held More Alert to Fraud
description: State Welfare InspectorGeneral George F. Berlinger yesterday reported a marked increase in the antifraud activity of local welfare departments since his agency started in September, 1971.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: CLASS B YACHTS SAIL FOR JAMAICA
description: MIAMI, March 12Nineteen Class B boats began the pursuit of the 39foot sloop Lightnin at noon today when the second of three fleets sailed in the 811mile MiamiMontego Bay (Jamaica) yacht race.

title: The Enigmatic Master of France
description: PARIS, March 12Georges. Jean Raymond Pompidou, with his Boris Karloff eye. brows, his fleshy nose ark his unusual last name, which still makes some Frenchmen giggle, is pictured by acquaintances as a jolly good fellow. He likes the company of poets, painters and writers and very expensive people such as the Rothschilds, for whom he once worked. There are others who say, yes, he is a bon vivant, he likes good food and wine, but he is not truly gregarious. It is exactly the reverse, someone who has been watching him for years commented. He confides in no one. There is not a man who reveals himself less.

title: Fear of the Reds
description: A Socialist editor probably came as close as anyone to explaining the unexpectedly easy victory of the ruling Gaullist coalition in France's National Assembly election with the remark: People really are discontentedeven Pompidou had said thatbut they are afraid of the Reds.

title: SATELLITE PLANNED FOR LINK TO ALASKA
description: RCA Global Communications, Inc., and RCA Alaska Communications, Inc., filed yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission for authority to build and operate an interim communications satelite by Aug. 1. The $7.4million domestic network would use the Telesat Canada satellite tied in with five earth stations to provide voice, message and TV traffic between both coasts and Alaska.

title: EUGENE L. BRISACH, SERVED STATE COURT
description: Former Justice Eugene Brisach of the State Supreme Court died Saturday at the United Presbyterian Residence in Woodbury, L.Y. His age was 89.

title: Mangalam Chacko Is Dead; Aide at the U.N. Was 57
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 12Mangalam E. Chacko, director and deputy to the Under Secretary General for Political and Security Council Affairs, ciked this morning of a heart attack at his home in Mount Vernon. He was 57 years old.

title: Assembly Passes Bill to Save 150,000 Wetlands Acres
description: ALBANY, March 12  The Assembly unanimously passed today a tidal wetlands bill designed to protect and preserve about 150,000 acres of wetlands, mostly on Long Island, which still have value for wildlife.

title: Wall for Manhattan
description: There is urgent need for some consciousnessraising about the city's waterfront. New York's most magnificent resource and amenity is being systematically blocked offboth visually and practicallyfrom the life of city.

title: NIXON SAYS AIDES WILL NOT TESTIFY BEFORE CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 In a policy statement on the use of executive privilege, President Nixon said today that members and former members of his personal staff would decline to make any formal appearances before Congressional committees.

title: DaytonHudson to Sell Unit
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 12 (UPI)  The DaytonHudson Corporation said today It planned to get out of the catalogue showroom business: The company said it felt the catalogue showroom business was incompatible with the company's departmentstore operations because it was growing so fast it was necessary to go all out in it very rapidly or get out. DaytonHudson said it would sell its threeunit Sibley Catalogue Showroom division.

title: Europe's Technicians in a Job Scramble
description: PARIS, March 9Unemployment among the highly qualifiedwhat the British call the Ph.D. dolequeue syndrome is becoming a serious social problem in Western Europe, as it has been in the United States for some time, as European industry prepares for the more intense competition of the enlarged Common Market.

title: N.I.T.'s Luck of the Draw Sets Favorites Apart
description: The National Invitation Tournament draw was set up before Minnesota and North Carolina were added to the 16team field. A spot in the upper bracket and one in the lower bracket was left for the Big Ten and Atlantic Coast Conference representatives. They happened to be Minnesota and North Carolina, named yesterday No. 10 and No. 11, respectively, in the final Associated Press basketball poll.

title: U.S. ASSERTS HANOI STILL INFILTRATES
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 The Defense Department confirmed reports today that North Vietnam has continued some infiltration of weapons, ammunition and military personel South across the demilitarized zone and along the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos.

title: PERONIST ELECTED ARGENTINE CHIEF, LANUESE REPORTS
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 12The military Government tonight declared Dr. Hctor J. Campora, the handpicked Presidential candidate of former dictator Juan Domingo Pern, as the victor in Sunday's national elections.

title: Rabe Protests Pirated Version Of Sticks and Bones in Moscow
description: David Rabe, author of the controversial antiwar drama Sticks and Bones, has bitterly protested a pirated Soviet production of his play that is having a successful run in Moscow.

title: The Good Neighbor
description: The Red Cross is humanity's bridge, a link connecting people of different countries and arching over separations of time and distance. In a world of human problems  wars, national disasters, poverty, sickness, illiteracy, misuse of drugs, pollution224 million persons of all ages, races, social strata, nationalities and political persuasions come together in a universal cause under the symbols of the Red Cross, the Red Crescent and the Red Lion and Sun.

title: Israeli Is Slain in Cyprus; Arab Thought to Be Killer
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 12 (Reuters)A 59yearold Israeli was shot to death by a young man in a Nicosia hotel today, the police reported. A warrant has been issued for the arrest of the man, believed to be a Jordanian Arab student.

title: 2 FOR HIGH COURT PICKED BY CAHILL
description: TRENTON, March 12  Governor Cahill announced this evening that he would nominate his personal counsel, Pierre Garven, and State Superior Court Judge Mark A. Sullivan as associate justices of the New Jersey State Supreme Court.

title: 4 in Family Slain In Suburban Home; Son, 18, Is Charged
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 12 (AP)Four members of a family were found slain today at their Abington Township home in Montgomery County. The police identified the victims as Alex Davenport, 55 years old; his wife, Rowilla, 50, and their two sons, Peter S., 12, and Edwin Drew, 14.

title: The Strange Case of the Traveling Vase
description: The arguments about the Euphronios vase have multiplied so foggily that the basic issue is hardly visible any more. It might, be useful therefore to consider a popular myth shared some collectors, museum trustees and directors which, like most such, hides human desires of a rather pedestrian kind. The myth is used to explain a certain posture of some American museums today, the last bastions of overt, selfconfessed imperialism in the world. Just as in the 19th century some Americans believed that, because of their superior mentality and mechanics, they had a mandate to possess the West and the Philippines and sectors of China, so today it is felt by some trustees that they have a mandate to possess and trade art, the last transferrable national entity, now that people cannot any more be colonized or countries concessionized.

title: JABBAR NETS 34 IN BUCK VICTORY
description: MILWAUKEE, March 12 (Ar)  Kareem AbdulJabbar had 34 points and 23 rebounds tonight to lead Milwaukee to a 12695 victory over Phoenix in a National Basketball Association game.

title: SHOP TALK
description: It all began with a shirt. A leather shirt that Doug Thomas wanted to buy for himself against the wishes of his wife, Lynn, who thought she could make one just as good herself and proceeded to do so.

title: NIXON SAYS AIDES WILL NOT TESTIFY BEFORE CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 In a policy statement on the use of executive privilege, President Nixon said today that members and former members of his personal staff would decline to make any formal appearances before Congressional committees.

title: Earth Week Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)  President Nixon proclaimed the week beginning April 8 as Earth Week and the week beginning May 13 as Small Business Week.

title: Playing to the Fear Of Crime
description: President Nixon's radio speech on law and order problems was the most depressing utterance of a man who has given us many. This was not so much because of its concrete proposals, bad as some of them were, but because it continued, and from the highest level, the usual American political response to the fear of crime rather than to the hard fact of crime itself.

title: Frankie Frisch, 74, Dead; Baseball's Fordham Flash
description: Frankie Frisch, who went from the Fordham campus to the Baseball Hall of Fame as one of the game's greatest second basemen, died yesterday in Wilmington, Del., a month after he was critically injured in an automobile accident. He was 74 years old.

title: At Rug Auctions, WalltoWall People
description: Sunday after Sunday they roll out their carpets and pack in the crowds. Some people come expecting to pay a trifle for some oriental rug treasure. Others come prepared to invest, or to be entertained, win a door prize, compare prices, spot shills, sneer or jeer.

title: Legislative Districts
description: The caption on the map that appeared on Page 35 in Monday's New Jersey edition of The New York Times omitted the information that one State Senator and two Assemblymen would be elected to represent each of the proposed legislative districts.

title: Scribner Plans to Take Terminal Leave April 1
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has reportedly tol?? the Board of Education he will comply with the board's request that he go on vacation April 1 as a prelude to leaving office on June 30.

title: Europe's Technicians in a Job Scramble
description: PARIS, March 9Unemployment among the highly qualifiedwhat the British call the, Ph.D. dolequeue syndrome is becoming a serious social problem in Western Europe, as it has been in the United States for some time, as European industry prepares for the more intense competition of the enlarged Common Market.

title: Nine Held in Harlem Raid On Drug Cutting Factory
description: Anticrime section policemen yesterday raided a Harlem apartment allegedly used as a cutting factory for narcotics and arrested six men and three women.

title: ExPostal Official Sentenced
description: SYRACUSE, March 12 (AP)The former postmistress of the Tompkins County community of McLean, accused of misappropriating $6,096 between July, 1971, and July, 1972, in postal funds, drew a sixmonth suspended jail term and two years' probation today in United States District Court. Marietta W. Miller, 39 years old, received the sentence from Judge Edmund Port. She had pleaded guilty to one count of a fourcount indictment Jan. 8.

title: Many Midwest Officials Voice Concern After Briefing on RevenueSharing Plans
description: CHICAGO, March 12Concerned representatives of six Midwestern states and 14 cities met here today for a briefing by Federal officials on President Nixon's latest budget proposals.

title: LINDSAY TO NAME A NEW TAX CHIEF
description: Mayor Lindsay expects to name a new head of the city's Tax Commission within a week to replace Norman A Levy, who was indicted last week on charges of fixing parking tickets and who has taken an unpaid leave of absence.

title: BERMUDA PRESSES HUNT IN MURDERS
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 12  The Government of this British colony extended its emergency powers today in an attempt to speed a solution of the murders of the Governor and his aide Saturday night.

title: Woman to Go to Saigon As Spokesman for U.S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 12 (AP)The post of senior United States military, information officer in Vietnam, held by a succession of generals and colonels for the last decade, is soon to be filled by a civilian woman.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Two OffBroadway hits have announced plans to move to Broadway. Because of increasing ticket demand, the Negro Ensemble Company is transferring its production of Joseph A. Walker's The River Niger from the St. Marks Playhouse to the Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street, on March 27. The switch, which will bring no substantial increase in ticket prices, should not be construed as a departure from the company's established activities as a nonprofit producing institution, according to Douglas Turner Ward, artistic director.

title: East Harlem Story Is Told With a Soul and Latin Beat
description: Starting this morning at 10 o'clock, the eagerly innovative Museum of the City of New York will present an allnew Soul & Latin Show in a gallery that has plenty of room for dancing, if the mood should seize you.

title: Lenders Are Facing New Accountability For Escrow Funds
description: TRENTON, March 12There are distinct probabilities that a study of the way lending institutions handle taxescrow accounts on home mortgages will lead to tighter regulation, State Banking Commissioner Richard F. Schaub said today.

title: Kentucky State Is Upset By Valdosta in N.A.I.A.
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 12 (UPI)  Kentucky State, a threetime champion, was buried under a barrage of free throws in the final six minutes tonight and upset, 9081, by Valdosta (Ga.) State in the first round of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball tournament. Secondseeded Augustana (Ill.) defeated Hanover (Ind.) in the second night game.

title: DEPOSIT RATE DOWN FOR SAVINGS BANKS
description: The flow of new deposits into mutual savings banks dropped sharply in February from the record levels posted in the same month last year, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.

title: Man Who Doesn't Bet Gets Tax Bill on Payoff
description: A 32yearold patrolman has been hit with a $1,380 tax bill that Albany says he owes on offtrack betting winnings, but he says he never bet on any horse races in his life.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: LINCROFT, N. J., March 12Do you want to be a tennis pro? The pay could be $300 to $400 a week, the hours of your own making and the work yearround, thanks to the continued boom in the sport.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: EXCHANGE MEMBERS DISCUSSING MERGERS
description: Coenen, Murray & Co., Inc., and Jesup & Lamont, both member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, are discussing the possibility of merger.

title: Notes on People
description: A number of foreign government officials were seen yesterday in places where they are rarely seen, if ever. Premier Mehmet Shehu of Albania, for example, was in a hotel in Rome after a flight from Tirana. Italian officials said the Premier's stay was a private matter and that he was moving on to Paris for reasons that did not concern Italy.

title: Scheduled Soviet Credit Put Off by Export Bank
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (Reuters)The scheduled first ExportImport Bank credit to the Soviet Union has been postponed, a bank spokesman said today.

title: Market Remains Quiet; Money Talks Watched
description: The stock market remained stalled in slow trading yesterday, despite evidence of substantial progress in the negotions in Europe to resolve the currency crisis.

title: New Process for Nickel
description: A new process to extract nickel from oxide and solicate type ores and from lowgrade sulfide concentrates was announced yesterday by the Republic Steel Corporation. The new process provides 92 per cent nickel recovery, compared to the current 70 to 90 per cent obtained from existing procedure, Republic said.

title: F.T.C. Plans Ad Suit Charging Deception by Makers of Aspirin
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 The Federal Trade Commission laid the groundwork today for projected litigation over allegedly deceptive advertisements for Anacin, Bayer Aspirin, Bufferin, Excedrin and other pain killers.

title: Equity Financing
description: U R S Systems Corporation reported yesterday cancellation of previously announced plans for a registered secondary offering of between 300,000 and 500,000 common shares on behalf of a group of its larger stockholders, citing depressed prices in the current market. The company's stock, traded on the American Stock Exchange, closed at 6, up .

title: CONTRACTS CLIMB IN BEEF AND HOGS
description: Live beef cattle and live hog prices rose sharply yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, setting new records for the April deliveries and auguring higher prices for housewives.

title: WEST SIDE KEEPS VIGIL OVER PUPILS
description: The schools on the West Side continued their vigilance over young children yesterday following last week's homosexual murder of a 10yearold boy on West 106th Street.

title: Magee, His Handcuffs Removed, Testifies Quietly
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 12 Ruchell Magee, whose behavior has disrupted courtrooms on dozens of occasions, testified quietly today at his trial here on charges that he kidnapped and murdered a judge on Aug. 7, 1970.

title: Tennessee Jumper Dies
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 12 (AP)Tony Wilson, a University of Tennessee athlete who held the Southeastern Conference high jump record of 7 feet 1 inches, died today of an apparent cerebral hemorrhage. He was a brother of the singer, Nancy Wilson.

title: VILLEGAS AND VIRUET WIN BOUTS AT FORUM
description: Outboxing his opponent almost all the way and outslugging him at the end, Francisco Villegas of Camito, Puerto Rico, scored a unanimous 10round decision over Davey Vasquez before a crowd of 1,563 in the Felt Forum last night.

title: Raiders Triumph, 8 to 7, In Game Without Penalty
description: In a theateroftheabsurd contest that had so many goals there wasn't time to call any penalties. The New York Raiders last night scored with 50 seconds remaining to gain an 87 victory over the Chicago Cougars.

title: Thou Shalt Not Kill
description: President Nixon has called on Congress to defeat crime in America by restoring the death penalty. The appeal appears based on a theory as questionable as the proverbial promise to fight fire with, fire. Even were moral considerations to be put aside, judicial murder happens not to be a particularly effective way to accomplish the desired end.

title: Frankie Frisch Dies
description: Frankie Frisch, a member of baseball's Hall of Fame, died in Wilmington, Del., yesterday at the age of 74. He had suffered critical injuries a month ago in an automobile accident near Elkton, Md. Details, Page 42.

title: NASTASE, TIRIAC WIN AT CHARLESTON NET
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 12 (AP)Topseeded Die Nastase of Rumania downed John Cooper of Australia and Ion Tiriac of Rumania upset Paul Gerken of East Norwalk, Conn., in the first round of the national indoor tennis championships tonight.

title: New Books
description: Martha, by Nathan A. Shiff, M.D (Lyle Stuart, Secaucus, N.J. $5.95). The author's love for his wife.

title: Vetrano Wins Backing of G.O.P. For Executive in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 12Edward N. Vetrano, the County Clerk of Westchester, won the Republican designation tonight to run for County Executive.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Department of Air Resources yesterday proposed a regulation for the city noise code that would cut down on the blare of horns by requiring the installation socalled citycountry horns in all new vehicles sold in the city in 1974 and thereafter.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Phoenix Suns, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. (TelevisionChannel E (cable), 7:30 P.M.) (RadioWNBC, 7:30 P.M.)

title: Sports News Briefs
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 12 (AP)A pair of San Francisco fighters found themselves in the middle of a minor riot tonight when one was disqualified for fouling and the other was tossed out of the ring after joining the melee.

title: Two Confirmed by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI)The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Alexander P. Butterfield as head of the Federal Aviation Administration and Robert W. Long as an Assistant Agriculture Secretary. Both nominations were approved by voice vote without dissent.

title: Hanoi Aide in Peking
description: HONG KONG, March 12 (UPI) Foreign Minister Nguyen Duy Trinh of North Vietnam held talks in Peking yesterday with his Chinese counterpart, Chi Pengfei, according to Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency. Mr. Trinh stopped in Peking on his way home after attending the international conference on Vietnam in Paris.

title: TV: Reasoner Report Creates Image for A.B.C.
description: In the last few years, the American Broadcasting Company has been steadily stragthening Its position in relation to the other two networks. It is still third in the overall ratings game, behind the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company, but no longer a poor third. The result, in the complicated world of TV economics, has been an effort to improve the operations of A.B.C. News.

title: Samples of Water In Miami Beach Fail A Test for Bacteria
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 12 (Reuters)Residents and tourists in Miami Beach were told today that they must boil water before drinking it for at least two more daysuntil the bacteria count in the water system is below the danger level.

title: ConsenttoWed Law For Males Is Upheld
description: A State Supreme Court justice upheld yesterday the law that requires parental consent for the marriage of males from 18 to 21 years of age.

title: Conservatives Pick Biaggi As Candidate for Mayor
description: Leaders of the Conservative party endorsed Representative Mario Biaggi for Mayor last night, thereby virtually insuring the Bronx Democrat a place on the November ballot even if he loses the Democratic primary.

title: Stage: Porter's Worst
description: Old musicals are like old winethey do not always keep. Not that Cole Porter's You Never Know, which opened at the Eastside Playhouse last night, was remarkably successful the first time around. In 1938, with Clifton Webb, Libby Holman and Lupe Velez, it mustered only 78 performances and those were the good old days.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: May I commit on the recent tragedy in Khartoum? The articulated motives for the promised executions of the assassins are two: that justice should be done, and that future similar acts will be thereby deterred. The justice motive is clearly questionable. There are some undeniable parallels to be drawn between the Khartoum atrocity and the Mylai massacre, terror bombing in Indochina and other U.S. crimes against civilians in Vietnam. All were part of a national policy (and the Palestinian guerrillas consider themselves nationalists above all else) with national agents using the weapons each felt would best further policy objectives. Both, in pursuit of the cause, did violence to the innocent in shocking ways, though our own agents were much less discriminating.

title: City's Housing Chief Lists Remedy for Agency's Ills
description: Improved rentcontrol administration, a streamlined bureaucracy, and tightened fiscal procedures to combat abuses are cited by Andrew P. Kerr as some of the important reforms he has put into effect since taking over as chief of the city's scandalridden Housing and Development Administration four months ago.

title: 4 LAW VIOLATIONS BY G.O.P. HINTED
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The General Accounting Office said today that President Nixon's reelection campaign committee had apparently violated Federal election laws at least four times in its handling of a $200,000 cash contribution by Robert L. Vesco, a New Jersey financier.

title: 10 Killed as Teachers Clash With Troops in Cambodia
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 12 (Reuters)Ten people were killed and about 40 wounded when a demonstration by striking teachers in Southern Cambodia turned into a gun battle, military sources said today.

title: CLASS B YACHTS SAIL FOR JAMAICA
description: MIAMI, March 12Nineteen Class B boats began the pursuit of the 39foot sloop Lightnin at noon today when the second of three fleets sailed in the 811mile MiamiMontego Bay (Jamaica) yacht race.

title: COMMUNISTS SEEK ITALIAN CATHOLICS
description: ROME, March 12The Communist party announced a nationwide drive today to enlist churchgoing Roman Catholics for its rank and file.

title: Philco Cuts Power For Refrigeration
description: The PhilcoFord Corporation yesterday introduced a new line of refrigeratorfreezers that it, said uses 30 to 50 per cent less electricity than competi tors' or previous Philco models.

title: ANTIDEROSEDRIVE APPARENTLY FAILS
description: TRENTON, March 12New Jersey Democratic leaders reported here today that a liberal drive to stop Senator Ralph C. DeRose from winning the party's nomination for Governor had foundered, and that the Essex County conservative Democrat was now regarded as the leading contender in the June 5 primary.

title: MAFIA FIGURE GETS 5YEAR SENTENCE
description: Aniello Dellacroce, described as a major figure in organized crime, was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison and fined $15,000 for incometax evasion.

title: FRANK M. BITETTO, 65, OF READER'S DIGEST
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., March 12 Frank M. Bitetto, who supervised all printing operations as vice president and director of manufacturing of the Reader's Digest Association, died in a drowning accident Saturday while in Acupulco, Mexico. He was 65 years old and a resident of Stamford, Conn.

title: Floating Together
description: The decision of West Germany, France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Denmark to float their currencies jointly against the dollar, when foreignexchange markets open next Monday, was the right response to the protracted monetary crisis. Given the massive amounts of highly volatile capital in private hands and the anxiety and uncertainty that have been evident in recent weeks, it would have simply invited resumption of the frenzied speculation to have reopened the currency markets with fixed exchange rates.

title: City Now Willing to Sell Land in Broad Channel
description: At the instigation of John E. Zuccotti, the new chairman of the City Planning Commission, the Lindsay administration has reversed itself and now is willing to let 1,200 families of Broad Channel Island buy from the city the land on which they have lived for two and three generations.

title: Excerpts From President's Statement
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 Following are excerpts from a statement issued today by President Nixon on his use of executive privilege:

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: PHILIP EVERGOOD, ARTIST, 71 IS DEAD
description: BRIDGEWATER, Conn., March 12Philip Evergood, an artist known for social satires, died last night in a fire in the bedroom of his home here. He was 71 years old. His wife, Julia, suffered from smoke inhalation, but was reported in satisfactory condition.

title: Bill Would Speed Illicit Drugs' Disposal
description: ALBANY, March 12Assemblyman John E. Kingston, the Republican majority leader of the Assembly, today introduced legislation that would speed the destruction of seized narcotics to avert situations such as have occurred in New York City, where 398 pounds of drugs, with a streetsale value of $73million, have been stolen from the Police Department.

title: But Total Uncertainty Over Outcome Causes Fall in Trading Pace
description: Leading bankers welcomed yesterday the decision of six nations of the European Economic Community to float their currencies jointly in relation to the United States dollar.

title: People in Sports: Slugger Hurt
description: Frank Robinson, the 37yearold slugger who signed a twoyear contract with the California Angels for $300,000 this spring, broke a toe yesterday while climbing into the radiotelevision booth at the Angels' Palm Springs training camp. He will be sidelined for at least three weeks. The season opens April 6.

title: Conservatives Pick Biaggi As Candidate for Mayor
description: Leaders of the Conservative party endorsed Representative Mario Biaggi for Mayor last night, thereby virtually insuring the Bronx Democrat a place on the November ballot even if he loses the Democratic primary.

title: Britain Charges 10 in London Bombings
description: LONDON, March 12Seven men and three women were charged tonight with conspiracy to cause the explosions that rocked London last Thursday.

title: People and Business
description: The presidents of five energy industry associationsnatural gas, oil, nuclear, coal and electric utilities  said yesterday in a joint statement that the United States has enough resources to meet its foreseeable energy needs. The development of the country's badly needed energy resources has been discouraged by a lack or coherent national energy policies, they declared.

title: Velasquez in the Right Place 2 Times at Big A
description: Jorge Velasquez picked up a mount in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, and proceeded to score a thrilling victory. Substituting for Angel Santiago, the leading rider at the meeting, who was ill, Velasquez accepted the assignment on Sigmund Sommer's 5yearold gelding, Suitor.

title: Steel Production Rose 0.1% in Week To 2,923,000 Tons
description: Steel production for the week ended March 10 continued to move upward and reached 2,923,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was 0.1 per cent higher than the 2,919,000 tons poured a week earlier, The trade association's weekly production index rose to 119,8 from 119.6 in the week ended March 3.

title: Recital
description: Very rarely does an unheralded singer appear in Carnegie Recital Hall who can stand comparison with international superstars. On the basis of her concert Sunday night, Berenice Bramson can match talents with any soprano recitalist before the public today.

title: Beauty's Only Ether Deep
description: WASHINGTON, March 12Because of the miracle of cosmetic surgery, people are now spending a lot of time trying to decide what to look like. Following are just a few of the options:

title: Boycott Continues at School in Newark
description: NEWARK, March 12James Mosselle, the teacher whose transfer from Vailsburg High School more than a month ago touched off a boycott by white students, returned to the school today, but the boycott continued.

title: Yankee Stadium Director Loses Use of His City Car
description: Don Evans, the city's acting director of Yankee Stadium, was deprived yesterday of access to city automobiles for one month, after he was found to have used his city car without authorization. The restriction was announced by Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton, after an inquiry.

title: BERMUDA PRESSES HUNT IN MURDERS
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 12  The Government of this British colony extended its emergency powers today in an attempt to speed a solution of the murders of the Governor and his aide Saturday night.

title: Advertising: Singling Out Singles
description: Discovering in an almanac that the population of single adults in the United States had soared to 37 million in 1970 from 16 million in 1955 while the number of divorced persons, widows and widowers had also increased, was what really convinced Hy Steirman to get moving on an idea he's had for a while a magazine for the unmarried set.

title: Bridge: 2 Entries Lead a Field of 30 Into Men's Team Event Finals
description: ST. LOUIS., March 12Teams from the South and the Midwest led 30 expert teams into the final stages the men's team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here at the ChasePark Plaza Hotel this afternoon. All the New York representatives trailed badly.

title: G.M. ASKS DELAY ON '75 STANDARDS
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 The General Motors Corporation bluntly told top officials of the Environmental Protection Agency at public hearing today that it could not comply with the 1975 limitations on two auto pollutants set by Congress in the Clean Air Act of 1970, and urged a oneyear delay in the standards.

title: Durocher Breaks Up Briefing Of Players on New Contract
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 12  Leo Durocher threw a wrench into baseball's labor relations today by pulling his Houston Astros out of a meeting with Marvin Miller, executive director of the Major League Players' Association.

title: 4 HELD IN NASSAU IN U.S. DRUG CASE
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 12The arrest of two Canadian men and two women from California last Friday night on charges of possession of Mexi can heroin was announced today by the Nassau County District Attorney and an assistant United States attorney.

title: 9 FOOD PLACES FAIL HEALTH INSPECTION
description: The City's Health Department has listed nine more restaurants and other food establishments that failed a second healthcode inspection. They were given dates for their third and final inspection, by which time they must correct violations or face closing orders.

title: A Bumpy Road at RollsRoyce
description: PARIS, March 9One of the biggest employment shocks in Britain came when RollsRoyce, which had the reputation for being a place where you worked for life, went bankrupt in February, 1971. Despite a resuscitation effort, 4,300 people were dismissed, including 1,000 on the technical staff.

title: National Gallery Relabels Some Art
description: The National Gallery of Art in Washington has recently reattributed nearly 40 of its major paintings and sculptures by old masters, it was learned yesterday. The reattributions include works formerly ascribed to such artists as Titian, Piero della Francesca, Vermeer, Rembrandt, Mantegna, Durer and Velazquez and are now attributed to followers of these artists.

title: O.E.O. Plans to Close 10 Regional Offices by April 28
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 The dismantling of the Office of Economic Opportunity moved forward today as Howard Phillips, the acting director, told all employes that the agency's 10 regional offices should be prepared to close by April 28.

title: Peterson's Debut: 2 Runs, No Comments
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 12  Fritz Peterson stood on the mound at Municipal Stadium today with two purposes  to pitch his first three innings of the spring and to listen for comments about him and his marital situation.

title: U.S. Again Blocks Roads To Isolate Wounded Knee
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., March 12Armed Federal officers reestablished roadblocks on all roads leading into this occupied village this afternoon, thus again sealing militant Indians inside the area they now proclaim the Independent Oglala Sioux Nation.

title: Dana Corp. Increases Earnings and Sales
Phillips Trial Put Off
description: The second murder trial for William Phillips, who testified at the Knapp Commission hearings on police corruption, was postponed yesterday until Sept. 5 because Mr. Phillips' chief lawyer, F. Lee Bailey, will not be available until the end of summer. The first trial for the 33yearold former policeman ended in a hung jury. He is accused of the murder of a pimp and prostitute.

title: 3 Seized in Capital In Stennis Shooting
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 The metropolitan police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced tonight the arrest of three men in the Jan. 30 robbery and shooting of Senator John C. Stennis of Mississippi.

title: Downey Back Home To Visit His Mother
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., March 12After more than 20 years as a prisoner in China, John Thomas Downey came home tonight to be at the bedside of his critically ill mother, in a hospital here. He was freed by China this morning and crossed the border into Hong Kong.

title: SUDAN TO PRESS FOR INDICTMENTS
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 12The threeman judiciary commission interrogating the members of the Black September guerrilla team that killed two American diplomats and a Belgian has decided to seek in indictment on four charges including premeditated murder, a Governmentcontrolled newspaper said today.

title: GUNMAN SHOOTS ONE AT AD AGENCY HERE
description: An assistant cashier at the J. Walter Thompson advedtising agency was wounded slightly yesterday by an apparent robber who fled emptyhanded from the seventh floor of the company's headquarters at 420 Lexington Avenue, at 43d Street.

title: Yankee Stadium Director Loses Use of His City Car
description: Don Evans, the city's acting director of Yankee Stadium, was deprived yesterday of access to city automobiles for one month, after he was found to have used his city car without authorization. The restriction was announced by Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton, after an inquiry.

title: Gulf Western Draws New Rebuffon A. & P. Bid
description: Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., yesterday received another setback in its quest to buy a 19 per cent interest in the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company as the Federal Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld a preliminary injunction enjoining a tender offer.

title: 6 DEAD AND 7 MISSING IN EAST CHICAGO FIRE
description: EAST CHICAGO, Ind., March 12 (UPI)Six persons were killed today when a fire destroyed a tenement building in the city's Indiana Harbor district. Seven persons were missing and feared dead.

title: Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge Marks 20 Years of Bird Watching
description: The first time Herbert Johnson stood in the dry, sunbaked sand and struggling beach grass at the edge of Jamaica Bay 20 years ago he decided he was probably facing the greatest professional challenge in his life.

title: Son of Adm. McCain On List of Prisoners Due to Be Released
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 12 (AP)A Navy pilot among the American prisoners to be released Wednesday is the son of the admiral who directed some of the heaviest bombing raids over North Vietnam.

title: DEMOCRATS LOSE NASSAU NOMINEE
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 12The nominating convention of the Nassau Democratic party, which was scheduled for tomorrow night, was postponed today to next Monday because of the unexpected withdrawal of the Democrats' candidate for County Executive and the reluctance of other party members to seek the post.

title: DEBUSSCHERE OUT FOR. KNICKS GAME
description: After every Knick home game, coach Red Holzman goes through the ritual of asking Dr. Andrew J. Patterson, the team doctor, Is everything all right?

title: Yields on Treasury Bills Rise at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, March 12Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: ALMA NORTH WINS SPRINT AT BOWIE
description: BOWIE, Md., March 12 (AP) Alma North, a 5yearold mare, captured the $23,550 Conniver Handicap today, the final day of the meeting at Bowie Race Course.

title: ELLSBERG JURORS HEAR SCHLISINGER
description: LOS ANGELES, March 12Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. and John Kenneth Galbraith testified for the defense today in the Pentagon papers trial.

title: Breakfast Cereal Manufacturers Defend Use of Sugar
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 Executives from two of the nation's largest food processors defended sugary breakfast cereals today, as being good for children's nutrition.

title: Soil Erosion Control Is a Victim of Shifting Priorities
description: TROY, Mo. The good farms around here lose three to five tons of soil an acre each year. We consider that tolerable. But a lot lose more than that. I was on a farm recently that was losing about 200 tons an acre. I figure that if we can hold the loss to about three tons a year, it will take 300 years to lose the topsoil we're now farming.

title: MULZOFF RESIGNS; SPURNS NEW PACT FROM ST. JOHN'S
description: Frank Mulzoff resigned yesterday as St. John's basketball coach two days after his team had lost to Pennsylvania, 6261, in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: State's Marital Consent Law Is Upheld
description: A State Supreme Court Justice upheld yesterday the law that requires parental consent for the marriage of males from 18 to 21 years of age.

title: Goalies on LastPlace Teams Endure Similar Sad Fortunes
description: It is half a continent from Bloomington, Minn., to Oakland, Calif. But two beleaguered goalies for lastplace teams suffered the same fates in two different. National League games on Sunday night.

title: CLOSING STAY URGED ON HOBOKEN OFFICES
description: TRENTON, March 12 (AP)Assemblyman John Horn, the Minority Leader, said today that he had asked the State Labor and Industry Department to reverse an order that would close theh Hoboken employment security office on March 31.

title: Austrians to Float Schilling
description: VIENNA, March 12 (AP)Austrian Finance Minister Hannes Androsch and national bank president Hans Kloss said today that Austria planned no upward revaluation of the schilling, but rather a floating of the currency against the dollar for the time being.

title: Hanoi Gives U.S. List of 108 P.O.W.'s to Be Released Tomorrow
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Tuesday, March 13The United States announced last nigh that it had received from the North Vietnamese a list of 107 American military prisoners of war and one civilian who are to be released in Hanoi tomorrow.

title: 2 I.T.U. OFFICIALS TO AID TALKS HERE
description: Bertram A. Powers, president of Typographical Union No. said yesterday that the president of the International Typographical Union, John J. Pilch, was sending in two international representatives the week of March 25 to assist in New York newspaper negotiations.

title: Gunman Says He Balked on Yablonskis
description: ERIE, Pa., March 12A gunman hired to kill Joseph A. Yablonski testified here today that he had backed out of the murder plot when he was told to kill the other members of the Yablonski family who later died in a killing that the State of Pennsylvania has called a labor assassination.

title: 2 British and 2 American Plays Will Vie for Tonys
description: Two American and two British plays were nominated yesterday in the bestplay category of the annual Antoinette Perry Awards (Tonys). Selected were The Sunshine Boys by Neil Simon and That Championship Season by Jason Miller, and the British imports, Butley, by Simon Gray and The Changing Room by David Storey.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge, the world's largest municipal sanctuary, will mark its 20th anniversary this summer. Last year it had about 100,000 visitors, most of them interested in birdwatching and enjoying an outdoor stroll in an unspoiled natural area.

title: Disciplinarian Back at School But Newark Boycott Continues
