description: NEWARK, March 12James Mosselle, the teacher whose transfer from Vailsburg High School more than a month ago touched off a boycott by white students, returned to the school today, but the boycott continued.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 13, 1973 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ARMAMENTS TALKS RESUME IN GENEVA
description: GENEVA, March 12The second round of negotiations aimed at limiting American and Soviet strategic nuclear armaments was resumed here today after a recess that began Dec. 21.

title: Mrs. Nixon's Aide to Leave
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI)Mrs. Charles Stewart, Mrs. Richard Nixon's press secretary, said today she would leave the White House later this month to work in the Cultural Affairs and Educational Division of the State Department.

title: Deborah Skinner Wed in London
description: LONDON, March 12Miss Deborah Skinner, daughter of Dr. Burrhus F. Skinner, the Harvard psychologist, was married here Saturday to Barry Gordon Buzan of Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: Books of The Times
description: If the dozens of women who collaborated in writing this book are rightand it really impossible for a man to understand what it is like to be a womanthen probably shouldn't be reviewing Our Bodies, Ourselves: A Book by and for Women, by the Boston Women's Health Book Collective. But I am doing so anyway, for several reasons: first, because the book looked useful and I wanted an excuse to read it carefully, and second, because those members of the movement I respect have often argued that women's liberation means men's liberation, and it is an argument I am willing to try on.

title: Seoul Assembly Meets
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 12The pew National Assembly convened its first session today. Former Premier Chung Il Kwon, a retired general who commanded the South Korean Army during the Korean war, was elected its Speaker. He Is a member of the Democratic Republican party headed by President Park Chung Hee.

title: Malaysia Quits Asia Group, Saying It Has Done Nothing
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 12 (AP)Malaysia announced today that she was withdrawing from the Asian and Pacific Council because it had not done anything.

title: Northern California Quake
description: EUREKA, Calif., March 12 (UPI)A moderate earthquake rolled across much of northern California early today. The quake rattled windows and crockery in the coastal city of Eureka and as far inland as Redding, but the auhtorities said that no casualties or serious damage had been reported. The University of California seismological station at Berkeley registered the tremor at 4.5 on the Richter scale.

title: RAIL LINE URGED FOR ALASKA'S OIL
description: WASHINGTON, March 12David Barrett, the Premier of British Columbia, proposed here today that oil and natural gas from Alaska's North. Slope be delivered to the United States by rail, not pipeline.

title: Bill Would Speed Illicit Drugs' Disposal
description: ALBANY, March 12Assemblyman John E. Kingston, the Republican majority leader of the Assembly, today introduced legislation that would speed the destruction of seized narcotics to avert situations such as have occurred in New York City, where 398 pounds of drugs, with a streetsale value of $73million, have been stolen from the Police Department.

title: Haker Victor in Giant Slalom; First World Cup Race in Japan
description: NAEBA, Japan, Tuesday, March 13 (UPI)Danielle DeBernard of France won the women's slalom today in the first World Cup ski races held in Japan. She had an aggregate time of one minute 29.90 seconds.

title: National Gallery Relabels Some Art
description: The National Gallery of Art in Washington has recently reattributed nearly 40 of its major paintings and, sculptures by old masters, it was learned yesterday. The reattributions include works formerly ascribed to such artists as Titian, Piero della Francesca, Vermeer, Rembrandt, Mantegna, Drer and Velazquez and are now attributed to followers of these artists.

title: E. E. C.'s Monetary Text
description: BRUSSELS, March 12 (Reuters)Following is the text of the statement by the Council of Finance Ministers of the European Economic Community after their emergency meeting on the monetary crisis:

title: PSYCHOSURGERY SUIT BEGINS IN MIDWEST
description: DETROIT, March 12. (AP)A threejudge panel in Wayne County Circuit Court opened hearings today to determine whether a mental patient has the right to decide to have potentially dangerous brain surgery offering prospects of a cure.

title: RAIL LABOR PACT WITH 14 UNIONS IS REPORTED NEAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The railroads and 14 unions are on the verge of signing new 18month nationwide labor contract, union and industry officials reported today. They said it would be the first time in memory that a national rail contract had been reached without strikes or other disruptions.

title: Agreement Cancels TreeCutting Rights In Maine State Park
description: AUGUSTA, Mc., March 12 (AP)  Maine environmentalists won what they consider a major victory today with the signing of an outofcourt cash settlement that saved a forest in Baxter State Park from a paper company's chain saws.

title: SPECIALTY STEEL TO RISE IN PRICE
description: Allegheny Ludlum Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it planned to raise prices on certain of its flat rolled specialty steel products by a range of 5 per cent to 10 per cent, beginning with shipments May 1. The products have numerous end uses in the consumer, commercial and industrial fields. Allegheny Ludlum said that the price of stainless steel would be increased by an average of less than 7 per cent which the company stressed would be still below the 1970 and 1971 base levels established under Phase 2 and Phase 3. Stainless strip prices will be increased by about 6 cent.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: More than 500 members of the East Orange Education refused to teach again yesterday.

title: City Weeding Out Old, Unsafe Cabs; 79 Barred in Day
description: The Taxi and Limousine Commission yesterday began a campaign to sweep unsafe and unclean licensed taxis and livery vehicles off the streets of the city. By 5 P.M. 79 cabs had been found in violation.

title: GERMAN EXPORTS IN RISING DEMO
description: BONN, March 12A high Government source said to night that Finance Minister Helmut Schmidt had offered a 3 per cent upward revaluation of the mark at the weekend Brussels monetary conference because it would benefit West Germany's domestic and foreign interests.

title: Caravan to Aid Indians
description: BILLINGS, Mont., March 13 (UPI)A caravan loaded with more than two tons of food and medical supplies has passed through Montana, headed for Wounded Knee, S. D. Steve Robideau, of Seattle said that the caravan has intended to let the Indians thereknow that many people of all races support what they are doing. Representatives from several Indian tribes and black, white and Chicano communities are in the caravan.

title: Mayor of Albany Accused Of Balking State Inquiry
description: The State Commission of nvestigation accused Mayor Erastus Corning 2d of Albany yesterday of attempting to deay and obstruct its investigation of allegations of corruption ??n the Albany Police Department.

title: London Article on Degeneration of New York Stirs Outcry Here
description: The front  page tabloid headline, in 1inch type beneath the logo Daily News New York's Picture Newspaper, proclaims: THUGS, MUGS, DRUGS CITY IN TERROR.

title: Five Cities in Running
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)  The yearold National Center for State Courts has reduced to five the list of cities that may eventually be its permanent home. They are Williamsburg and Alexandria, Va., Salt Lake City, Philadelphia and Denver.

title: Stacy Harris, 54, Actor On Radio, Stage and TV
description: HOLLYWOOD, March 13 (AP) Stacy Harris, a character actor who played the part of Leslie Harrington on television's Return to Peyton Place, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 54 years old.

title: 20Year Term Halved In BombThreat Case
description: A Beacon, N. Y., shoe merchant, tentatively sentenced last Nov. 10 to 20 years in prison for bomb threats to the liner Queen Elizabeth 2 and American Airlines, was given a final 10year sentence in Federal Court yesterday.

title: LAKERS WRAP UP DIVISION HONORS
description: BUFFALO, March 13 (AP)Wilt Chamberlain tied his season high with 25 points and grabbed 23 rebounds as the Los Angeles Lakers, the defending National Basketball Association champions, clinched their third straight Pacific Division title, beating the Buffalo Braves, 121112, tonight.

title: Brooklyn Pastor and 2 Others Accused of Defrauding H. R. A
description: Nicholas Scoppetta, the city's Commissioner of Investigation, announced yesterday the arrests of three persons  the head of a Brooklyn daycare center, a welfare recipient and a Department of Social Services typist  on charges of grand larceny in three separate cases. They involved a total of $47,000 in funds from the Human Resources Administration.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Major changes in the operation of horse racing in New York State are expected to be recommended to Governor Rockefeller tomorrow by the Delafield Commission.

title: BIG MEAT PACKER ACCUSED OF BRIBES
description: Iowa Beef Processors, Inc., the nation's largest beef company, and the cochairman of its board of directors were indicted yesterday on charges of having conspired to bribe union, and supermarket officials, to sell the company's products here.

title: Rider Suspended 5 Years; Battery Found in Whip
description: BALTIMORE, March 13 (AP)Kenneth Pichette, a jockey from Warren, Mich. was suspended for five years by the Maryland Racing Commission today after being found guilty of having a battery in his whip before a race at Bowie Race Course.

title: Campora Demands Peron Be Present at Oath Taking
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 13Dr. Hctor J. Cmpora, Presidentelect of Argentina, said today that he would shortly visit his mentor, the former President and dictator Juan Domingo Pern, in Madrid.

title: STATE SEEKS LAW ON BIRTH CONTROL
description: ALBANY, March 13The State Social Services Commissioner, Abe Lavine, said today that his department was seeking legislation that would permit the sale of contraceptives to persons under 16 years of age and that would mandate that local social welfare districts offer full familyplannirg services.

title: BIG MEAT PACKER ACCUSED OF BRIBES
description: Iowa Beef Processors, Inc., the nation's largest beef company, and the cochairman of its board of directors were indicted yesterday on charges of having conspired to bribe union and supermarket officials to sell the company's products here.

title: Tempest in a Cuppa Tea
description: SYDNEY, Australia Australia intends to renegotiate certain details of its joint base agreements with the United States but accepts all the responsibilities of the 1951 ANZUS alliance. Moreover, despite pressure from extreme leftist members of the ruling Labor party, Prime Minister Gough Whitlam sternly refuses to reveal any security secrets involving American installations here. He intends to stand by military commitments inherited from previous regimes.

title: KUWAITI IS QUOTED ON OIL AS WEAPON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 13 The Emir of Kuwait was quoted today as having pledged that his country would use its oil wealth as a weapon when the zero hour for the Arab battle against Israel came.

title: Jean Yazinsky Dies at 81, Ballet Dancer and Teacher
description: OXFORD, Conn., March 13Jean Yazvinsky, a ballet dancer, and teacher who headed his own ballet school in New York from 1944 to his retirement in 1960, died Sunday in Griffin Hospital in nearby Derby. He was 81 years old.

title: Downey Is Doubtful His Imprisonment Benefited Anybody
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., March 13John T. Downey reflected today on his long imprisonment in China and said it had cost him a great part of his life, apparently for naught.

title: Press Photographers Showing PrizeWinning Pictures of '72
description: The New York Press Photographers Association announced yesterday the winners in its 37th annual competition in conjunction with an exhibition of these prizewinning photographs of 1972 at The Mill at Burlington House, Avenue of the Americas and 54th Street.

title: Mrs. Marjorie Campbell, Worked for the Retarded
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., March 13  Mrs. Marjorie Goetze Campbell, president of the board of governors of the Mansfield Training School, a 1,500bed school for mentally retarded, died yesterday at the Middlebury Convalescent Home. She was 70 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Senator Raymond H. Bateman, a Somerset Republican; announced yesterday the formation of a committee to urge Governor Cahill to seek reelection. Mr. Bateman, also announced that he had decided to seek reelection to his Somerset County Senate seat.

title: Red Smith
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 13Behind the batting cage, Ron Swoboda said to Ralph Houk: Keeping the ball low is the most important thing for an outfielder? They call Swoboda Rocky, short for Rock Head, and it is a bum rap. There isn't a more sincere or more thoughtful player in baseball, or one who strives more conscientiously to improve himself. He is getting ready for his ninth season in the majors and he must have been familiar with the cutoff play as an undergraduate at Maryland. Yet he is not ashamed to be asking questions still, taking refresher courses, reminding himself that when he fields a hit with a runner in scoring position he must aim his throw at the chest of the cutoff man, who will have stationed himself on a line between the outfielder and the plate. If there is a play at home, the cutoff man lets the throw go through; otherwise, he catches it to prevent the hitter from taking second base.

title: Music: Ax's Piano Debut
description: A young pianist with the hardtoforget name of Emanuel Ax has one thing going for him before he plays a note. But brand identification, as advertising men term it, helps in the long run only if the product delivers, and Mr. Ax's recital at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night fortunately carried the stamp of quality.

title: Ford and Chrysler Support Plea For Delay in '75 Emission Rules
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation aligned themselves today with the General Motors Corporation in asking the Environmental Protection Agency to suspend for one year the 1975 Federal limitations on auto exhaust emissions of carbon moxoxide and hydrocarbons.

title: Norman Silberdick Dies; Accounting Firm Partner
description: Norman Silberdick, a founder and managing partner of the certified public accounting firm of Silberdick & Peritz, 350 Fifth Avenue, died Monday of an aortic aneurysm in Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 64 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A massive research project on the cause of welfare dependency is being conducted by New York City in an attempt to find major policy alternatives for reform.

title: U.S. Planes Pick Up 168 Freed Prisoners From Hanoi
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippities, Wednesday, March 14Imp third phase of American prisonerofwar releases began, today in Hanoi.

title: Symphony Is Off Arts Center Schedule
description: TRENTON, March 13The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, an apparent victim of what has been called a cultural wasteland in this state, will not appear this year at the Garden State Arts Centers.

title: Boyle Is Implicated By Yablonski Killer
description: ERIE, Pa., March 13  One of the convicted killers of Joseph A. Yablonski, the reformist leader in the United Mine Workers who was shot to death with his wife and laughter in 1969, made a dramatic courtroom confession here today that indirectly implicated W. A. Boyle, the ousted union president, in the murder plot.

title: GENERAL BATTERY SOUGHT FOR CASH
description: Northwest Industries, Inc., and the General Battery Corporation jointly announced yesterday that they have entered into discussions looking toward a cash tender offer by North west Industries for all of General Battery common stock. General Battery, headquartered in Reading, Pa., has about 2.34 million common shares outstanding. Trading in General Battery on the New York Stock Exchange was stopped after the announcement at 12:43 P.M. when the issue was up 2 at 27. Trading resumed shortly before the close and the issue finished up 4 at 29. Based on the closing price of the issue, the transaction would be valued at $67.86million.

title: SYRIA SAYS CHARTER WINS 97.6% OF VOTE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 13 (AP)Syria's first permanent Constitution since 1961 was endorsed by 97.6 per cent of the voters in a national referendum that ended early today, the Syrian Government announced.

title: Drugs Are Seized By U.S., Mexico; 100 Arrests Made
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Federal Government announced today the seizure of more than 24 tons of marijuana and 9.3 pounds of heroin as well as the arrest of more than 100 persons in a recent fiveweek drug enforcement operation in cooperation with Mexican officials along the ArizonaMexico border.

title: AID FOR AGED WINS BIG HOUSE MARGIN
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The House, in a strong rebuff to President Nixon, approved today a bill on aid to the elderly that the White House has said would be vetoed.

title: Biaggi Enters Race And Attacks Bosses
description: Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic mayoral nomination yesterday and opened his campaign with an attack on Democratic bosses, a traditional issue of liberal Democrats.

title: COMMUNISTS RAID CAMBODIAN TOWN
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 13 (Reuters)Communist forces attacked a roadside village on Cambodia's main southern highway early today after forcing Government troops to evacuate the nearby district town of Chambak, the military command reported.

title: Cornell and Yale Triumph In Polo Tourney Openers
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 13Cornell defeated Harvard, 1715, with two lastminute goals, and Yale vanquished Texas A. and M., 245, tonight in the opening round of the national intercollegiate indoor polo tournament. Peter Ambrus, Yale captain, scored 13 goals.

title: EverLoyal Peronist
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 13 The constant theme in the political life of Dr. Hector J. Cmpora, Argentina's Presidentelect, has been subservience to former President ana dictator Juan Domingo Perlin. Throughout the campaign that finally netted him the presidency in Sunday's election, Dr. Campora, a dentist and veteran politician, emphasized his servitude to the old master. The early posters showed his relaxed, smiling face above a simple slogan, Loyalty. By the time the campaign ended, his image had practically disappeared from posters that displayed Mr. Perlin alongside the catchy phrase, Cmpora in Perlin in power.

title: Revenue Sharing for Education Could, Cost New York Millions
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Nixon Administration's revenuesharing proposal for education would make drastic changes in the way Federal aid is allocated to schools with disadvantaged children and could cost New York and otherlarge states millions of dollars, according to an Administration document.

title: Slayings Said to Follow Son's Clash With Father
description: ABINGTON, Pa., March 13 (UPI)The police said today that an 18yearold suburban Philadelphia youth had bludgeoned to death his parents and two brothers following what may have been a disagreement with his father over the length of his hair and over his grades in college.

title: Letters Thank Nixon For P.O.W. Release
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)White House officials said today that President Nixon had received more than 100,000 letters commending him for winning the freedom of American prisoners of war.

title: INQUIRY IS ASKED ON FOOD INCREASES
description: NEWARK, March 13  The Burlington County Consumer Affairs Department asked the District Economic Stabilization Board here today to investigate what it contends are unconscionable price increases posted by 10 major retail food chains.

title: Indian Council Acts to Oust Outsiders
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., March 13 The Pine Ridge Tribal Council moving to reestablish its authority over the reservation, adopted tonight a resolution to remove from the reservation all nonOglala Sioux who have come to the area to support militant Indians occupying Wounded Knee.

title: Tim Buck, 82, Former Leader Of Canadian Communists, Dies
description: TORONTO, March 13 (Canadian Press)  Tim Buck, retired leader of the Communist party of Canada, died Sunday in Cuernavaca, Mexico, the party's national office announced today. He was 82 years old.

title: Woman, 80, Dies in Fire; Boy, 5, Burned in 2d Blaze
description: An 80yearold woman identified as Ernestha Goodman died yesterday in a fire apparently caused by a cigarette she was smoking in bed in her apartment at 75 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

title: JAPAN TO SUPPORT JOINT EUROPE FLOAT
description: TOKYO, March 13 (Reuters) Japan will support the joint float of six Common Market currencies against the United States dollar when finance ministers of the Western world's main trading nations meet in Paris Friday.

title: Downey Is Doubtful His imprisonment Benefited Anybody
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., March 13John T. Downey reflected today on his long imprisonment in China and said it had cost him a great part of his life, apparently for naught.

title: Bourse Reopens in Paris
description: PARIS, March 13 (UPI)The, Bourse, or stock exchange, reopened here today after a fourday strike by employes. Traders said the legislative election victory by the majority Gaullist party and the joint European currency float against the dollar fueled a moderate increase in share values, especially in those sectors that might have been nationalized had the leftwing alliance won the elecons.

title: College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: Confident, Buoyant State University Turns 25
description: When the State University's campus in Stony Brook, L. I., was being built in the early nineteensixties, the plans did not show where the campus paths should go. The planners had decided to wait and see what routes the students themselves would choose. Afterwards, they laid out the network of paved pathways over the students' muddy tracks.

title: CON ED CONFIDENT ON POWER SUPPLY
description: The chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that the supply of electricity this summer will probably be the best we've had in the last three or four summers.

title: Bridge: At 76, a St. Louis Champion Again Wins National Title
description: ST. LOUIS March 13The oldest man ever to win a major national title broke his own record at the American Contract Bridge League's spring nationals here last night. Seventysixyearold John Simon, a St. Louis financier, successfully defended the men's team championship in a starstudded field.

title: Advertising: Cars Honk 3 Ways
description: Automobile advertising comes in three varieties. There's the advertising from the manufacturer; it tries to sell the product by playing up its features and engineering and that sort of thing. Then there's the advertising from dealer associations; this frequently does the same thing but includes more local flavor. Finally, there's individual dealer's advertising, which lays out his specific deals.

title: W. Indies Cricketers Tally 391 in Reply to Australians
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, March 13 (Reuters).  The West Indies led Australia by 67 runs on first innings with a total of 391, then claimed one wicket for 84 before the close on the fourth day of the second test cricket match today.

title: State Issues Warning On PetTurtle Danger
description: TRENTON, March 13 (UPI)  Turtles contaminated with salmonella are being sold in New Jersey illegally, the State Health Department said today.

title: NixonCongress Battle
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The President and Congress are headed once again for an impasse over executive privilege the unwritten doctrine under which the executive branch has kept secrets from the legislative branch since 1796.

title: Canarsie Attendance Rises As Boycott Enters 9th Day
description: Pupil attendance in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn showed a small improvement yesterday as a white parents' boycott of the area's eight elementary and junior high schools went into the ninth day.

title: Revenue Sharing for Education Could Cost New York Millions
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Nixon Administration's revenuesharing proposal for education would make drastic changes in the way Federal aid is allocated to schools with disadvantaged children and could cost New York and other large states millions of dollars, according to an Administration document.

title: Two Killed in Ulster Violence; A Youth
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Mardi 13 (UPI)  A British Army patrol shot and killed an armed man in Belfast today and a soldier died in a landmine ambush near Northern Ireland's border with the Irish Republic, army spokesmen reported.

title: AUTO PRODUCTION SEEN AT RECORD
description: DETROIT, March 13 The United States auto industry is increasing production schedules to keep pace with record sales and as a result it appears the 1973 model run will be at a new high of at least 9.4 million cars.

title: 20YEAR TERM GIVEN IN KILLING OF DRIVER
description: A Bronx man found guilty in January of the fatal shooting of a parttime driver for The New York Times and the wounding of another parttime driver was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to up to 20 years in prison.

title: Body of Missing Girl, 8, Found in Shaft in Harlem
description: The body of an 8yearold Harlem girl, missing since Sunday, was found in a narrow shaft behind her home yesterday in a spot that had been searched Monday and found to be empty of all but trash and garbage.

title: PACT WITH JAPHAN URGED IN MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, March 13 (AP)A Soviet spokesman said today that it was high time to sign a World War II peace treaty with Japan but added that much depends on Japan's approach to this problem.

title: Con Ed Sure of Supply
description: Consolidated Edison expects its supply of electricity for the summer to be the best in three or four years, Charles F. Luce, chairinan, said yesterday. He predicted rate increases of 8 to 10 per cent a year for five years if the present inflation continued. Details on Page 55.

title: Miller, Raskind Victors In U.S. Maccabiah Tennis
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., March 13Jeff Miller of Scotch Plains, N. J., the topseeded player, gained the third round of the qualifying tennis tournament for the Maccabiah Games in Israel at the Kutsher's Country Club indoor courts today.

title: Strike Ended in Maine
description: CARIBOU, Maine, March 13 (AP)Employes of American Kitchen Foods, Inc., returned to their jobs today after voting to end a weeklong strike over layoffs at the potato processing plant.

title: Foreign Policy Association Names 10 New Directors
description: The board of directors of the Foreign Policy Association has elected 10 additional members to join 65 scholars, lawyers, businessmen and civic leaders in guiding the national nonpartisan organization.

title: Senate Panel Calls Dean In a Challenge to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Senate Judiciary Commit. tee, in a direct challenge to President Nixon, voted unanimously today to call his chief legal counsel, John W. Dean 3d, as a witness at its hearings on the nomination of L. Patrick Gray 3d to become director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Hungarian Member Of Control Unit Gets Asylum in Australia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 13 (AP)A 22yearold Hungarian Army sergeant serving with the International Commission of Control and Supervision defected here over the weekend and has been granted asylum by Australia.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ON THE BRINK The Texas blind salamander is on his way to extinction mainly because too many people arc collecting him. The brown pelican, native of the South, is threatened with the past tense because its eggs have become too thinshelled (something associated with DDT in food fishes). The sad litany of endangered species goes on and on, graphically and absorbingly described in photo, film and text at the twofloor Kodak Gallery, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 13d Street (2626170).

title: Boyle Is Implicated By Yablonski Killer
description: ERIE, Pa., March 13  One of the convicted killers of Joseph A. Yablonski, the reformist leader in the United Mine Workers who was shot to death with his wife and daughter in 1969, made a dramatic courtroom confession here today that indirectly implicated W. A. Boyle, the ousted union president, in the murder plot.

title: Syracuse Pastor Sentenced
description: SYRACUSE, March 13 (AP) A minister was sentenced to five years' probation today for misappropriating $754 in funds meant for an antipoverty program he headed. The minister, the Rev. Forrest Adams, pastor of the Tucker Missionary Baptist Church, pleaded guilty previously to thirddegree grand larceny.

title: EXPARKWAY CHIEF GETS 3YEAR TERM
description: TRENTON, March 13  D. Louis Tonti, former executive director of the New Jersey Highway Authority, was sentenced today to three years in jail and fined $10,000 for conspiring to extort $120,000 from Business concerns between 1965 and 1971.

title: MusicinSchools Bands Fill Lincoln Center Air
description: Lincoln Center was awash In an interview, the music in children, music and sunshine yesterday as thousands of children from schools in New York City and Long Island gathered to perform as part of a Music in Our Schools Day Exposition.

title: BRUINS CONQUER ISLANDERS, 3 TO 0, GAIN ON RANGERS
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 13 Two and a half hours of hard work against the Boston Bruins tonight added up to zero for the Islanders as they lost, gamely, 30.

title: F.D.A. Issues Rules for Foods' Labeling
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Food and Drug Administration issued today a set of final rules and tentative proposals that are intended to take the mystery out of the contents of food packages.

title: Leary on Trial in California
description: SAN LUIS Obispo, Calif., March 13 (UPI)Timothy Leary, who wandered as a fugitive for nearly three years in an unsuccessful search for asylum, went on trial today on a charge of escaping from a State prision. Leary, who was serving a term for marijuana possession, escaped from the then minmumsecurity California Men's Colony near here in 1970 and fled to North Africa, Europe and Asia before being arrested two months ago in Afghanistan by a United States nacotics agent.

title: 1919 Hit Opens BrandNew Theater
description: A show that grandmother loved half a century ago opened last night in Broadway's newest theater.

title: NANA MOUSKOURI LINGUIST IN SONG
description: Since limy Belafonte introduced Nana Mouskouri to the United States in the midsixties, the strikinglooking Greek singer, whose dark  rimmed glasses have become her visual trademark, has built steadily on the strong foundation of her pure  toned, richly colored voice. Mr. Belafonte was in the audience that filled Carnegie Hall on Monday night to hear the latest rounding out of Miss Mouskouri's talents.

title: BRITISH SOCCER
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Thousands of Vietnam Veterans on Welfare Here
description: It's got the longest lines in the world, the former Special Forces sergeant recalled.

title: PEPSICO BLOCKED ON RHEINGOLD BID
description: The United States Court of Appeals here issued an order yesterday blocking Pepsico Inc., from exercising control over the Rheingold Corporation, pending a decision on an application for an injunction by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: It Is Newton's New Law: The Tide Has to Go Up
description: There is room at the top for taco successful athletic programs at Alabama.

title: TaxExempt Yields Up
description: The market for taxexempt bonds, faced with the prospect of absorbing nearly $2billion of new offerings over the next month, continued yesterday to make sharp upward adjustments in yields.

title: Mayor of Albany Accused of Attempt to Obstruct State Investigation of Police
description: The State Commission of Investigation accused Mayor Erastus Corning 2d of Albany yesterday of attempting to delay and obstruct its investigation of allegations of corruption in the Albany Police Department.

title: Secretariat Will Drill Today for Bay Shore
description: Secretariat, last season's Horse of the Year, is scheduled to work at Belmont Park this morning at 7:30.

title: Farmers Said to Plan Record Acreage in '73
description: American farmers intend to plant another record number of acres this year in grains and soybeans key ingredients of tomorrow's meals.

title: Notes on People
description: Gov. Ronald Reagan of California discussed his political future and his fondness for jelly beans. Of politics, the Governor said he would not run for the Senate next year. Mr. Reagan's decision was expected, as was his failure to rule out for himself another bid for the Republican Presidential nomination. I personally am not attracted by the idea of participating in a legislative body after holding executive office, said Mr. Reagan, now in his second term as Governor.

title: Dare to Be Great Losers Are Reimbursed in Jersey
description: TRENTON, March 13Checks totaling $696,700 were mailed today to 515 New Jersey residents who lost money investing in the Dare to Be Great merchandising scheme devised by Glen W. Turner.

title: Blues' Caron Stops Sabre Sextet, 20, Making 23 Saves
description: ST. LOUIS, March 13 (UN) Phil Roberto and Floyd Thomson scored tonight to give the St. Louis Blues a 20 triumph and extend the Buffalo Sabres' victoryless streak to five games.

title: Two Life Stories An Ego Trip, Or a Glimpse at a Generation?
description: Some people might think it is the supreme ego trip, this unusual art exhibit called Judy and Adrienne. For there, lining the white basement walls of the art gallery, are hundreds of mementoes from the private lives of two Manhattan artists who grew up together in New Rochelle: Judy Levy, 27 years old, and Adrienne Lan26.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., March 13Sports record books are rewritten annually and great names fade into oblivion with each edition. It's called progress, ringing out the old and bringing in the young.

title: It Is Newton's New Law: The Tide Has to Go Up
description: There is room at the top for two successful athletic programs at Alabama.

title: Bank America Will Enter The Insurance Business
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the parent company of the nation's largest bank the $41billion Bank of America, San Francisco, announced yesterday they planned to enter the insurance business.

title: The Medina: Glory and Shame of Tunis
description: TUNIS, March 1Cold and rain have been the lot of this Mediterranean city this winter and nowhere has the weather been more painfully felt than in the ancient quarter where thousands of families huddle in unheated rooms.

title: ORVIN ANDREWS, 84, LED DAY PUBLISHING
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 13Orvin Granville Andrews, president of the Day Publishing Company in New London, Conn., and a newspaper executive for 59 years, died here today. He was 84 years old.

title: Volvo Agrees to Halt Ads Carrying Unproved Claims
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)The Volvo Corporation of America, accused of unfair and deceptive advertising by the Federal Trade Commission, agreed today to refrain from saying, without reasonable proof, that its cars were more economical than others.

title: GRAEBNER, NASTASE ADVANCE IN TENNIS
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va. March 13 (AP)Clark Graebner of New York wore down West Germany's Meiler for a 76, 57, 63 victory in the quarterfinals of a $15,000 tennis Tournament tonight.

title: Biaggi Enters Race And Attacks Bosses
description: Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic mayoral nomination yesterday and opened his campaign with an attack on Democratic bosses, a traditional issue of liberal Democrats.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Senate Panel Calls Dean In a Challenge to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Senate Judiciary Committee, in a direct challenge to President Nixon, voted unanimously today to call his chief legal counsel, John W. Dean 3d, as a witness at its hearings on the nomination of L. Patrick Gray 3d to become director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Ford Recalls 8,000 Trucks In Check of Brake Hoses
description: DETROIT, March 13 (UPI)The Ford Motor Company announced today that it had begun recalling nearly 8,000 light trucks in an attempt to find about 250 that have defective brake hoses that could result in a partial loss of brake power.

title: Capitalism, for Better or Worse
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Three questions deserve hardheaded and unflinching investigation:

title: Tokyo Commuters Go On a Rampage
description: TOKYO, March 13Frustrated Japanese commuters protested a slowdown in service today by going on a rampage.

title: Bomb Used in Suicide
description: EUREKA, Calif., March 13 (UPI)An unemployed electrician, Clarence Arthur Deyo, 50 years old, Tulelake, Calif., committed suicide by blowing himself up with a dynamite bomb, police reported yesterday.

title: People in Sports: Ice Cubes Tumble Olga
description: The Soviet coaches blame it on ice cubes. Olga Korbut, the tiny Olympic gymnastics champion, suffering from a severe head cold, was unable to perform with five teammates in Buffalo on Monday night. Instead, the 4foot10inch, 83pounder watched from the stands for a short time and then retired to the dressing room. The coaches don't like the girls to cool their drinks with ice cubes, said an interpreter. Olga drank a lot of juice on Saturday, in Houston, and used ice cubes. That might have started the cold. The 17yearold girl, last of the team to be introduced, drew a tremendous ovation. During the 20 minutes, she sat in the stands, she used a couple of dozen tissues. She's constantly crying, said the interpreter, not because she's unhappy but because of the cold.

title: Sailor Freed of Charges
description: SAN DIEGO, March 13 (AP) The Navy said today that it had dropped riot and assault charges against Apprentice Seaman James M. Allen of Steubenville, Ohio, who had been jailed since a disturbance aboard the carrier Kitty Hawk in October. The charges were dismissed because witnesses were unable to identify Seaman Allen as an assailant, a spokesman said.

title: Durocher Fined by League; No Way I'll Pay, He Says
description: COCOA, Fla., March 13 (AP)Manager Leo Durocher of the Houston Astros was fined $250 today by the National League president, Chub Feeney, for interfering with his team's meeting yesterday with Marvin Miller and Durocher responded by threatening to resign and take the matter to court.

title: Equity Financing
description: A public offering of 1.5 million common shares of the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation at $54.50 a share was announced yesterday by Dillon Read & Co. The company's stock closed at 54, up , on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Tonti Sentenced to 3 Years and Fined $10,000 on Parkway Extortion Charge
description: TRENTON, March 13D. Louis Tonti, farmer executive director of the New Jersey Highway Authority, was sentented today to three years in jail and fined $10,000 for conspiring to extort $120,000 from business concerns between 1965 and 1971.

title: FRENCH ELECTION SPURS U.S. CLAIM
description: WASHINGTON. March 9Administration officials said today that they hoped that the French Government, fresh from a new election victory, would start positive action on the fiveyearold claim for compensation for costs arising from the eviction of United States forces from France in 19661967.

title: Mr. Nixon's Principles And Practices
description: It is a common habit of most people to proclaim great principles when it suits their purposes, and to evade or ignore them when it doesn't, and President Nixon's definition of the privileges of his office and his White House staff is only the latest illustration of the habit.

title: TV: College Reunion Leads to Eternal Triangle
description: Tonight's Wednesday Movie of the Week on the American Broadcasting Company network, from 8:30 to 10, is called Class of '63. Filmed primarily at the University of Southern California, the story uses a 10year class reunion to concoct a dramatic plot around little Mickey Swerner (Cliff Gorman), his wife, Louise (Joan Hackett), and Joe Hart (James Brolin), the big lug she still loves after all these years.

title: G.O.P., Liberals Weight A Deal to Back Wagner
description: Robert F. Wagner, who from 1954 to 1966 served three terms as Democratic Mayor of New York, would be given the Republican and Liberal lines for the job this year In a delicate deal that politicians were trying to stitch together last night.

title: B. B. WALKER'S LOSS PUT AT $7,6MILLION
description: An accounting firm has determined that the B. B. Walker Company of Asheboro, N. C., sustained a loss of about $7.6million in commodity trading accounts handled by Bartlette B. Walker, the company's founder and chairman who committed suicide last week.

title: Whitehead Bill Sets Localism As Criterion for Station License
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)The White House today proposed legislation that had been in the works since last year to increase the terms of broadcast licenses from three to five years and to establish as the chief criterion for renewal whether a television or radio station is substantially attuned to the needs and interests of its local public.

title: Plea for Buffalo Inquiry Upsets Assembly Session
description: ALBANY, March 13  The State Assembly's plan for a quiet day of ceremonies honoring West Point generals and themselves veered into uproar today as a black Democrat kept insisting that they take note of racial friction at a Buffalo high school.

title: ONDINE TAKES UP LIGHTNIN PURSUIT
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 13  With Ondine and Buccaneer leading the way, 13 big Class A yachts began pur; suing Lightnin today in the, 811mile, MiamiMontego Bay race.

title: Edwards Is Nominated For High Health Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  President Nixon today nominated Dr. Charles C. Edwards to be the Assistant Secretary for Health in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: TWO SUSPECTS LOSE CAB RACE TO POLICE
description: Two suspected bank robbers were arrested yesterday by a police lieutenant who pursued them in a taxi after its driver rejected the robbers' efforts to enlist his services in a purported escape attempt.

title: Average Gains 6.32
description: The stock market continued to chug along in low gear yesterday in the absence of any major news breaks from the European monetary front.

title: Business Briefs
description: S.E.C. to Ask Rehearing on PBW Stay

title: Yanks See Allen's Work Ethic
description: FOR't LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 13A fourhour bus ride brought the Chicago White Sox to Fort Lauderdale Stadium just before noon today and Dick Allen was on the bus.

title: Met Will Sing Its First Troyens in Fall
description: The Metropolitan Opera will perform Berlioz's Les Troyens for the first time in its history on Oct. 22. That and other plans for next season, which will open on Sept. 17 and include six new productions; were disclosed yesterday at a press conference in the opera house by Schuler Chapin, acting general manager, and Rafael Kubelik, music director.

title: ALLAN C. GEORGE, ACCOUNTANT, DIES
description: HIGHLAND BEACH, Fla., March 13Allan C. George, the last of the five founding partners of Harris, Kerr, Forster & Co., certified public accountants, died yesterday. He was 69 years old and had lived in Darien, Conn., until he retired in 1970.

title: State DrugLaws Panel Gives Alternative to Rockefeller Plan
description: The Temporary State Commission to Evaluate the Drug Laws yesterday released its promised alternative to Governor Rockefeller's proposed legislation to heighten penalties for drug traffickers.

title: Backus Bout Called Off
description: PARIS, March 13 (Reuters)A scheduled April 9 welterweight fight between the European champion, Roger Menetrey of France, and the former world champion, Billy Backus of Syracuse, N. Y., has been called off because Menetrey is due to meet the world champion, Jose Napoles, June 23, the promoters said today.

title: BLAZERS TRIUMPH OVER AEROS BY 43
description: PHILADELPHIA; March 13 (AP) John McKenzie scored the winning goal with 4 seconds left in the second period tonight as the Philadelphia Blazers beat the Houston Aeros, 43, in a World Hockey Association game.

title: The Schools Need You
description: The purpose of school decentralization was to make the schools more responsive to the people. Ultimately the goal of such responsiveness can only be achieved if the people themselves are willing to assume new responsibilities. Thus, May 1, the date of the second citywide elections of members to the 32 community school boards, will be a crucial test of the citizen involvement necessary to give decentralization meaning.

title: N.C.R. Announces an Order For 11,000 Cash Registers
description: The National Cash Register Company announced yesterday a $60million order from Montgomery Ward for 11,000 electronic cash registers and the International Business Machines Corporation announced its smallest System/370 machine, the model 115.

title: Music: Mahler Interpreted by Giulini
description: PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA. With Rafael Orozco, Plano. Conducted by Carlo Marla Giulini. As Philharmonic Hall.

title: CARMINE GALLONE ITALIAN FILM MAKER
description: FRASCATI, Italy, March 13 (UPI)Carmine Gallone, director of nearly 100 films over 48year period, died of bronchial pneumonia here Sunday. He was 87 years old.

title: SUBPOENAS LINKED TO GUN PURCHASE
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Justice Department disclosed today that the reason it had subpoenaed and then jailed dive New Yorkers of Irish descent in Texas was that it had ?? information about the purchase of Mexican weapons for shipment to Northern Ireland.

title: Mays and Staub Swing, But Dodgers Trip Mets
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13  Willie Mays and Rusty Staub made their first appearances of the spring for the New York Mets today, and so did Henry Gaylon Matthew Webb, a rookie pitcher who needed one out to heat the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: MRS. MICHAEL ADDISON
description: Mrs. Viola G. Addison, widow Michael Addison, a former member of the New York Stock Sxchange, died Monday at her tome, 1016 Fifth Ave. Her age was 78.

title: Korvette to Open Store In Flushing Late in 1973
description: The Korvette departmentstore chain announced that it would open its first new store in the metropolitan area since 1967 in the Flushing section of Queens late this year. The new store, now under construction, will be a twostory, 135,000 square unit occupying a square block on Kissena Boulevard.

title: Aagh, Splut, Cough, Hack
description: DETROITSamuel Johnson observed that the scoundrel's last refuge is to wrap the flag around himself. Nowadays, instead of the flag, the vision of a beautiful environment is used.

title: Conviction of Dowdy For Bribery Upset, But Perjury Stands
description: RICHMOND, March 13 (AP) A Federal appeals court reversed today the conspiracy and bribery convictions against former Representative John Dowdy, Democrat of Texas, and left it up to the Government to decide whether he should face a new trial.

title: Stability in a Time of Crisis
description: What happened to Armageddon suddenly? During the recent weeks of international monetary upheaval, many prophetsfriends of gold, friends of fixed exchange rates, foes of John Maynard Keynes and foes of Milton Friedmanwere moaning, This is the end of civilization as we have known it. But when the Bretton Woods systein of fixedexchange rates finally collapsed and the healthiest members of the European Common Market decided to stop spending massive quantities of their money to prevent further devaluation of the dollarand instead to float their currencies against the dollarwhat happened? The dollar strengthened, the price of gold fell and the securities markets rallied.

title: CITY CENTER CUTS FUNDS TO JOFFREY
description: The City Center of Music and Drama, facing a continuing financial crisis, has decide?? to reduce its annual support of the City Center Jaffrey Balle?? from $380,000 to $75,000, with an additional $65,000 to be given as an advance agains?? independent fundraising efforts of the Joffrey Ballet. As a result of the cutback, which will begin after the curren season, the Joffrey, a repertory company, will be forced to shorten its 197374 New York season perhaps by as much as half.

title: Frederick Hasler, Banker, Dies; Headed Pan American Society
description: Frederick E. Hasler, chairman of the Continental Bank & Trust Company from 1941 to its merger with what is now the Chemical Bank in 1948, died Monday at his home in Washington Depot, Conn. He was 91 years old.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: People and Business
description: Taking a stand opposite to that of most labor leaders, Joseph P. Tonelli, president of the United Paperworkers Union, called yesterday for defeat of the BurkeHartke bill, which would restrict imports and foreign investments by American companies.

title: Bermuda Asks Surrender of Handguns
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 13The police called on all inhabitants of this British Colony today to turn in their handguns as part of the investigation of the murder of the Governor and his aide last Saturday night.

title: May Potato Futures Overcome Early Losses in Lively Session
description: May potato futures, which dropped the daily permissible limit of 35 points on Monday, lost another 35 points yesterday in early trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract fell from 8.50 cents a pound to 8.15.

title: Dutch Liberal Will Head European Parliament
description: STRASBOURG, France, March 13 (AP)Cornelis Berkhouwer, a Dutch liberal, was elected president today of the enlarged European Parliament, the assembly of the European Economic Community, or Common Market.

title: Nixon's StripMining Bill Defended and Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, March 13State and Federal officials agreed today on the urgent need for laws to control strip mining as four days of hearings on proposed laws began before the Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee.

title: G.O.P. Liberals Weigh A Deal to Back Wagner
description: Robert F. Wagner, who from 1954 to 1966 served three terms as Democratic Mayor of New York, would be given the Republican and Liberal lines for the job this year in a delicate deal that politicians were trying to stitch together last night.

title: President for WUI Unit
description: Rosario P. Romanelli, 43 years old, has been named president of Western Union International, Inc., it was announced yesterday. A lawyer and an engineer, he has been with Western Union International and its predecessor compay for 16 years. His appointent follows regulatory approval of a new corporate structure whereby Western Union International becomes the principal subsidiary of newly formed parent organization named WUI, Inc.

title: SANTE FORLANO
description: Sante Forlano, a fashion photographer whose work was well known in national women's magazines, died of a heart attack Monday at his home, 327 Lexington Ave. His age was 49.

title: Campora Demands Peron Be Present at Oath Taking
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 13Dr. Hector J. Campora, Presidentelect of Argentina, said today that he would shortly visit his mentor, the former President and dictator Juan Domingo Pern in Madrid.

title: Foster Parents Win Back Boy, 7, As A gency Is Told to Return Him
description: A 7yearold boy, who was removed from his foster parents' home in New Jersey by a representative of a Catholic Charities agency, was ordered returned to that home by a State Supreme Court justice yesterday.

title: Atkins Diet: A Revolution That Has Medical Society Up in Arms
description: The Medical Society of the County of New York yesterday denounced Dr. Robert C. Atkins' revolutionary nocarbohydrate diet as unscientific, unbalanced and potentially dangerous, especially to persons prone to kidney disease, heart disease and gout.

title: REAL CEASEFIRE APPEARS ELUSIVE AS U.S. ENDS ROLE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 13With the final scheduled American withdrawal from Vietnam only two weeks away, there is still little prospect of a true ceasefire as both the Communists and the South Vietnamese continue to violate many of the basic provisions of the Paris peace agreement.

title: Miss Debernard Wins Slalom in Japan
description: NAEBA, Japan, March 13 (AP)  Daniele Debernard of France outsped Austria's favored Annemarie Proell in two daring descents today and won the women's slalom in the World Cup skiing competition.

title: Triumph for Peron
description: At the age of 77, and more than seventeen years after the armed forces ended his authoritarianstyle regime by throwing him out of the country, Juan Domingo Per6n has won a disconcerting if spectacular victory in Argentina. He has also posed a difficult problem for the present military rulers, who not only blackballed him as a presidential candidate in Argentina's first general election in a decade but refused even to let him come home for the campaign.

title: Amex, OTC Edge Up
description: Advances and declines were almost evenly divided yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and overthecounter market in continued light trading.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In commenting on the National Academy of Sciences' study of autos mobile emissions, The Times (editorial Feb. 22) incompletely quotes pollutioncontrol costs from President Handler's covering letter to Congress and E.P.A. The Times further notes that Handler's letter and the report afford some inadvertent justification for a year's delay in imposition of emission standards in 1975 and 1976, as has been urged by the automobile manufacturers. A careful reading of both report and letter would lead to different conclusions.

title: Campus Offices Bombed
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., March 13 (UPI)A bomb destroyed 40 offices in the third and fourth floors of the social studies building at the University of Puerto Rico's suburban Rio Piedras campus last night. No one was injured. The campus has been embroiled in a dispute between the university administration and students advocating Puerto Rico's independence from the United States.

title: DOLLAR ADVANCES AS COLD WEAKENS
description: PARIS, March 13The dollar strengthened and the gold price fell in European financial centers today, but traders said that while current trends were encouraging, it was still too early to conclude that the latest monetary crisis was over.

title: Industry Officials Stress Scope of Energy Crisis
description: ABILENE, Tex., March 13 The top brass of the nation's largest oil and gas companies came to West Texas today to expound upon the energy crisis.

title: Mrs. Farkas Gave Most of Gift to Nixon Fund After Election
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Dr. Ruth Lewis Farkas, wife of the founder of Alexander's department stores in New York and President Nixon's choice to be Ambassador to Luxembourg, said today that she gave the bulk of her $300,000 contribution to the Nixon campaign after the election was over.

title: Thousands of Vietnam Veterans on Welfare Here
description: It's got the longest lines in the world, the former Special Forces sergeant recalled.

title: Books of The Times
description: GIRLS AT WAR AND OTHER STORIES. By Chinua Achebe. 129 pages. Doubleday. $5.95.

title: The Great Oil Port Dispute
description: TRENTON, March 13Many influential Republican leaders here believe that Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. has bought himself a political disaster in his confrontation with Governor Cahill over a proposal for a deepwater oil port in coastal waters off New Jersey. In a statement submitted in Washington last month to the Senate subcommittee on air and water pollution Mr. Sandman, Republican of Cape May, and an announced candidate for the nomination for Governor, said he was opposed to the construction of a large oil port off Cape May. But he proposed the construction of one in Raritan Bay in northern New Jersey, where, he said, the environment has already been destroy by oil refineries.

title: ISRAELIS WILL BUY MORE JENS IN U.S.; TOTAL IS PUT AT 48
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Nixon Administration has agreed to sell Israel four squadrons of combat jets and to help the Israelis set up production of an advanced jet fighter of their own design.

title: Suit Asks Department of Labor to Halt Alleged Peonage in Mental Institutions
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Two national organizations and three mental patients sued the Department of Labor today to end what the plaintiffs called widespread peonage in mental institutions.

title: R. H. Macy & Co. Establishes Records in Earnings and Sales
Shortages of Some Foods Reported in Soviet Areas
description: MOSCOW, March 13 (Reuters)  Shortages of butter, potatoes and other foods have hit several provincial areas of the Soviet Union and local authorities have introduced restrictions on sales, Soviet and diplomatic sources said today.

title: 12 Are Top Contenders In USAC Driving Race
description: Good racing, as they say in the racing business, is when you don't know who will win. The observation is especially valid now because at least a dozen drivers are rated strong possibilities to win the 1973 championship of the United States Auto Club, The USAC season opens this Saturday afternoon with a 150mile race for a purse of $50,000 at FasTrack international Speedway (formerly Phoenix International) near Phoenix, Ariz. The cast of characters includes six drivers who have topped 200 miles an hour in preseason testing at Texas International and Ontario Motor Speedways, plus two or three sandbaggers who can pass 200 any time they want to.

title: George A. Locke, Inventor And Bell System Researcher
description: GLEN HEAD, L.I., March 13. George A. Locke, holder of, 56 patents for inventions, mostly in the teleprinter and teletypewriter fields during his 50 years with the Bell System, died yesterday at his home, 2 Ashley Place. He was 79 years old.

title: Mays and Staub Swing, But Dodgers Trip Mets
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13  Willie Mays and Rusty Staub made their first appearances of the spring for the New York Mets today, and so did Henry Gaylon Matthew Webb, a rookie pitcher who needed one out to heat the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: A VARIANCE IS GIVEN FOR 2 MORE STORIES
description: The city's Board of Standards and Appeals rejected pleas yesterday by the Planning Commission and a local planning board and granted a zoning variance to the developer of an apartment house on Third Ave nue.

title: 3 ARE ARRAIGNED IN STENNIS ATTACK
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Three young men arrested last night were arraigned today in the robbery and shooting of Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi.

title: Bids to Cut Assessments Ruled Open to Public View
description: The city's Corporation Counsel said yesterday that all applications by property owners for reduction of their realestatetax assessments and the notes of the assessors were open to public inspection.

title: Israel Will Allow an Arab University on West Bank
description: TEL AVIV, March 13Israel today approved establishment of a Palestinian Arab university on the West Bank of the Jordan River.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 14, 1973

title: Executive CoverUp
description: When President Nixon at a news conference on January 31 promised a precise statement concerning the use of executive privilege, he assured reporters: The general attitude I have is to be as liberal as possible in terms of making people available to testify before Congress, and we are not going to use executive privilege as a shield for conversations that might be just embarrassing to us.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: ISRAELIS WILL BUY MORE JETS IN U.S.; TOTAL IS PUT AT 48
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Nixon Administration has agreed to sell Israel four squadrons of combat jets and to help the Israelis set up production of an advanced jet fighter of their own design.

title: Philippines Gives Toll in 2 Weeks of Fighting With Moslem Rebels
description: COTABATO, the Philippines, March 13 (AP)Military authorities said today that at least 187 Moslem rebels, 30 Government soldiers and 27 civilians had been killed in two weeks' fighting here in the southern Philippines.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Records: Resilient Banjo
description: Courtesy of the film Deliverance, the banjo is currently being heard over the airwaves of the nationproof yet again of the resilience of this instrument with an African name and origin that has been one of the main props of American folk music for about 200 years.

title: CANADA AIDE URGES MOVING OIL BY RAIL
description: WASHINGTON, March 13David Barrett, the premier of British Columbia, suggested today that a United States decision to support a railroad to carry oil and gas from Alaska might improve the likelihood that Ottawa would permit additional exports of Canadian oil and natural gas to this country.

title: Oil Executive Slain
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) Jay Edward Morgan, 43 years old, an executive for the Continental Oil Company, here on a business trip, was shot and killed early today in an apparent robbery, the police said.

title: Panel Splits on Whether Press Is Periled by Federal Criticism
description: Representatives of news media and government expressed widely divergent views here last night on whether freedom of the press was threatened by Nixon Administration criticism of newspapers and television networks.

title: Lon Not to Dissolve Parliament and Call For New Elections
description: PHNOM PENH, Wednesday, March 14 (Reuters)President Lon Nol of Cambodia will shortly dissolve Parliament and hold new general elections, it was officially announced here today.

title: More Cheese Imports Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)Representative Hugh L. Carey, Democrat of Brooklyn, asked today that President Nixon raise the import quota on cheese from 128 million pounds to 250 million pounds to avoid a rise in the price of domestic cheeses.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Samara Prepares to Buck the N.C.A.A.
description: Fred Samara, one of the country's top collegiate track and field athletes, may defy the National Collegiate Athletic Association and compete in the United StatesSoviet Union indoor dual meet Friday night in Richmond.

title: Widow, 55, Opts for Jail To Bar a Fine of $1,145
description: BELVIDERE, March 13A 55yearold widow from Hackettstown has just completed her sixth day in virtual solitary confinement at the Warren County Jail here for refusing to pay a $1,145 fine.

title: CHAPARRALS BOW TO STARS, 131118
description: DALLAS, March 13 (AP)Zelmo Beaty scored 26 points in 28 minutes to lead the Utah Stars to a 131118 victory over the Dallas Chaparrals tonight in American Basketball Association action.

title: Mysterious Prisoner Is Said to Be a Texan ExG.I.
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)Bobbyd Joe Keesee's sister said today that he walked out of her home in Albuquerque, N. M., in May, 1970, for not over an hour to get his car repaired. Their next meeting will come when the latest group of war prisoiaers freed by North Vietnam arrives home.

title: Big Board Reports Drop In February Margin Debt
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday a decline of $200million in margin debt during February in the customer accounts of its member firms. This equaled the January decline. It brought margin debt down to a total of $7.5billion, as compared with the record $7.9billion at the end of December.

title: Yanks See Allen's Work Ethic
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 13A fourhour bus ride brought the Chicago White Sox to Fort Lauderdale Stadium just before noon today and Dick Allen was on the bus.

title: Theater: Irene Bustles Merrily and Relentlessly
description: There is probably a market for Irene, the almostnew musical comedy that opened the completely new Minskoff Theater last night, and I sincerely hope it finds it. One can only admire so much energy and effort.

title: REAL CEASEPIKE APPEARS ELUSIVE AS U.S. ENDS ROLE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 13With the final scheduled. American withdrawal from Vietnam only two weeks away, there is still little prospect of a true ceasefire as both the Communists and the South Vietnamese continue to violate many of the basic provisions of the Paris peace agreement.

title: 10.7% Package Accepted By Unions in Rail Industry
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The railroads reached agreement with the rail unions today on a new 18month contract that would raise wages by 4 per cent and fringe benefits by 6.7 per cent for more than 500,000 workers.

title: CITY STUDY SEEKS WELFARE REMEDY
description: A massive research project has been under way in the city administration for nearly nine months on causes of welfare dependency, proposing to find major policy alternatives for the reform of the welfare system and its related institutions.

title: Backus Bout Called Off
description: PARIS, March 13 (Reuters)A scheduled April 9 welterweight fight between the European champion, Roger Menetrey of France, and the former world champion, Billy Backus of Syracuse, N. Y., has been called off because Menetrey is due to meet the world champion, Jos Napoles, June 23, the promoters said today.

title: Jockey Making It Despite Language Bar
description: Nice going, kid, Preston King said to Kelly Castaneda yesterday after the third race at Aqueduct.

title: Benelux Currency Parities Are Retained
description: Several European governments took further action yesterday in the continuing shakeout of the international monetary crisis.

title: Dare to Be Great Losers Are Reimbursed in Jersey
description: TRENTON, March 13 Checks totaling $696,700 were mailed today to 515 New Jersey residents who lost money investing in the Dare to Be Great merchandising scheme devised by Glen W. Turner.

title: City Planners Act to Uplift Area of Convention Center
description: John E. Zuccotti, chairman of the City Planning Commission, yesterday announced a sixpoint plan designed to win the support of the Clinton community for the proposed convention center along the Hudson River between 43d and 47th Streets.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 55yearold widow from Hackettstown, N. J., yesterday spent her sixth day in Warren County Jail for refusing to pay a $1,145 fine that stems from her refusal to allow sewer pipes crossing her property to be hooked to the town sewer line.

title: HUGH S. COYLE DEAD; EXSTATE JUSTICE, 68
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 13Hugh S. Coyle, a State Supreme Court Justice until his retirement three years ago, died Saturday in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 68 years old and had been residing and practicing law in Woodstock, Vt.

title: Vote on Turkish President In Parliament Inconclusive
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 13 The election of a new President of Turkey by Parliament produced a conflict today between the choice of the army, Geh. Faruk Gurler, and two candidates representing political parties.

title: Alleged Narcotics Leader In Brooklyn Area Seized
description: A smalltown South Carolinian, who, the police said, betame a major distributor of heroin in the metropolitan New York area, was arrested yesterday on an indictment charging that he sold. $9million worth of the drug annually.

title: HERBERT KENT
description: Herbert Kent, a British actor who made his debut in this country in 1912 in a musical comedy, Pomander Walk, died yesterday at a nursing home. He was 96 years old and lived at 1000 Madison Avenue with his wife, the former Ada Clarke, who was known on the stage as Ada Kent.

title: SUIT IS DISMISSED AGAINST FAIRCHILD
description: An action brought by Motorola, Inc., against the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation in 1968 was dismissed yesterday by Judge William H. Copple, United States judge for the District of Arizona, according to a spokesman for Fairchild Camera.

title: New Day on the Rails?
description: For decades labor relations on the nation's railroads have been a morass in which interunion rivalries and management ineptitude combined to preserve featherbedding, push up operating costs and force frequent Congressional intervention to halt paralyzing strikes. Government came to play such a dominant role in the entire process that collective bargaining all but atrophied.

title: Knicks Victors; Reed Scores 28
description: Even though Dave DeBusschere and Phil Jackson were not available, the Knicks were strong and scrappy enough to down the Phoenix Suns last night, 115111.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Galbraith Heard as Ellsberg Witness
description: LOS ANGELES, March 13John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard economics professor, defined at the Pentagon papers trial today what in his view would constitute damage to the national defense.

title: TEACHERS WILL END NEW HAVEN STRIKE
description: NEW HAVEN, March 13 (AP) Members of the New Haven Federation of Teachers voted overwhelmingly tonight to accept a judge's recommendation that they end a sevenday strike and allow contract negotiations to resume.

title: U.C.L.A. Opens Bid for Title Tonight
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 14 The University of California, Los Angeles, opens the defense of its National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship tomorrow night hoping to go on to a record seventh straight title and ninth in 10 years.

title: HUSSEIN SPARES 17 PALESTINIANS
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 14 King Hussein announced today that he had commuted the death sentences passed against Mohammed Daoud Odeh, a leader of Al Fatah, the main Palestinian guerrilla organization, and 16 of his colleagues.

title: Senate Unit Backs Bill On Dollar Devaluation
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (Reuters)The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the Nixon Administration's legislation to devalue the dollar, clearing the way for final Senate approval.

title: Foster Children Week Set
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)President Nixon issued today a proclamation marking April 8 as the start of National Action for Foster Children Week and urged all Americans to volunteer their talents, energies and compassion for such children.

title: U.N. Panel Sits in Panama Today
description: PANAMA, March 14  Last Sunday, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera was having lunch in a remote village in northwest Panama after having spent several hours listening to cattlemen there complain of drought.

title: ART TROVE SEIZED BY ITALIAN POLICE
description: ROME, March 14The Italian customs police reported yesterday that they had seized 63 hitherto unknown ancient Etruscan objects in a private home at Capodimonte, 54 miles northwest of Rome.

title: Senate Confirms 5 for Jobs In the Department of Housing
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)  The Senate confirmed today the nominations of Floyd H. Hyde as Under Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and of H. R. Crawford, Sol Mosher and Michael H. Moskow as assistant secretaries.

title: Courtaulds, Ltd., Planning Irish SyntheticFiber Plant
description: Courtaulds, Ltd., the large British fiber and chemical company, announced plans yesterday to establish a $60million syntheticfiber plant in Letterkenny, County Donegal, Ireland.

title: Alleged Gallo Aide Held in Mob Killing
description: Robert Bongiovi, an alleged gunman who was with Joseph Gallo the night he was assassinated last April, was charged yesterday with a murder that the police said might have links to the Gallo killing.

title: U.S.Aided Coops Dedicated in Harlem
description: Amid popping balloons and speeches by government officials, an $11million, federally aided housing  rehabilitation project was dedicated in Harlem yesterday, and the first of nearly 400 families who will live there moved in.

title: S.E.C. Doubts Crisis in Investments
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission published new data yesterday showing that the crisis in the investment company businesswith redemptions of shares far exceeding sales  is nowhere near as severe as it has been painted by Wall Street.

title: House Swears in Alaskan
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)Don Young, a Republican, was sworn in today as Alaska's only member of the House. He succeeds Nick Begich, a Democrat, who was officially declared dead after disappearing on an airplane flight with Hale Boggs of Lonisiana.

title: TV Review
description: How about a toneddown The French Connection setup as a television series? Judging by Mr. Inside/Mr. Outside, a 90minute pilot feature for a projected serial, why not? It was shown last night on the National Broadcasting Company. Phil D'Antoni, who produced the awardwinning movie, was credited as executive producer.

title: NIXON CRIME PLAN SENT TO CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, March 14President Nixon, asserting that the only way to attack crime effectively is without pity, urged Congress today to revise the entire criminal code in way that, in many cases, would increase penalties and reduce the discretion of Federal judges in imposing sentences.

title: Insurance Concern Elects
description: The election of Frank E. Sullivan as executive vice president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company was announced yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Ambulance Aids Heart Victims

title: Nixon Asks New Sentencing System for Capital Crimes
description: WASHINGTON, March 14President Nixon's plan to revive the death penalty seeks to circumvent the Supreme Court's opposition to capital punishment by establishing a novel, system for sentencing Federal criminals.

title: Cambodia Planning Legislative Election As a Peace Move
description: PHNOM PENH, March 14 (Reuters)  President Lon Nol today ordered Government officials to prepare for a general election to replace the sixmonthold National Assembly.

title: CANADIENS DOWN RED WINGS BY 5??
description: DETROIT, March 14 (AP)The Montreal Canadiens score?? three goals in the third perio?? and defeated the Detroit Re?? Wings, 53, tonight in a Nation?? Hockey League East Division contest at Olympia Stadium.

title: TRUCKERMAFIA LINK DROPPED BY POLICE
description: The Police Department has retracted an allegation it made last fall that a midtown trucking concern was connected to the Mafia.

title: HOUSE HOLDS UP CODE OF EVIDENCE
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 The House voted overwhelmingly today to postpone indefinitely the imposition of the Supreme Court's controversial new rules of evidence for the Federal court systems.

title: Bergen G.O.P. Insurgents To Subpoena Party Chiefs
description: HACKENSACK, March 14A lawyer representing insurgent Republicans told a Superior Court judge today that he intended to call the present and three former chairmen of the powerful Bergen County Republican Committee as witness in an effort to prove the state's primary election laws unconstitutional.

title: State Names a Mediator In Cemetery Dispute Here
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, announced yesterday that he had designated Hugh Sheridan as a special state mediator to deal with the continuing threat of a cemetery strike.

title: Stage: Yiddish Play With a Gimmick
description: Since Yiddish musical comedy is as traditional as, say, knishes, an uptodate, inspirationaladded ingredient like a popular TV commercial wouldn't hurt, right? Well, Try It, You'll Like It, which was served up last night at the Mayfair by Jacob Jacobs, who has been around almost as long as knishes, is a tasty dish if you like familiar fare.

title: DA CAM PLAYERS OFFER SIX WORKS
description: The Da Capo Chamber Players believe that contemporary music deserves a second hearing. Too often works are given more or less prestigious premieres and then disappear forlornly back into their composers' desk drawers; the Da Capo Players fish them out again.

title: Only One Company Entered Guilty Plea In IllegalSkins Case
description: A Federal Government office has retracted a statement that 32 defendants had pleaded guilty to illegal trafficking in animal skins.

title: Vietnam: No End In Sight
description: Ceasefire or no ceasefire, fighting is continuing in South Vietnam, with both sides violating the rules almost at will, and with the North Vietnamese by all accounts sending in men and equipment in large quantities. American officials, who for weeks maintained a determined optimism, are now conceding that at least lowlevel combat is likely to continue.

title: New Barracks: Lg. Lux. Apt., Sep. Bath, Pvcy. Gt'd
description: The Army's drive to attract and hold bachelor and spinster soldiers for an allvolunteer force will include new living quarters resembling a cross between Hollywood's idea of an Ivy League dormitory and those genteel garden apartments that line suburban highways, their doors surmounted by phony coats of arms and names like Camelot.

title: 10 Killed in Attack On Pagoda in Delta
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 15 (Reuters) Terrorists threw grenades into a crowded Buddhist pagoda in a Mekong Delta village, shortly after last midnight, killing 10 persons and wounding 88, military sources said.

title: Mission to Moscow
description: Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz's justconcluded visit to Moscow was so hastily arranged that his hosts there were unable even to welcome him with proper diplomatic protocol. Mr. Shultz, who is President Nixon's chief economic adviser, went to Moscow in the midst a continuing major international monetary crisis. Both facts testify to the importance of his mission.

title: State Program to Aid Crime Victims Reaches Only a Few of Those Eligible
description: It was 11 A.M. on Livingston Street in Brooklyn, and Samuel Kantor, a 55yearold milkman on his day off, was carrying his son's typewriter to the shop for repair.

title: 200A Troublesome Age
description: WASHINGTON, March 14In rooms of Federal green, planners are already planning ways to celebrate the Republic's 200th anniversary in 1976. They are searching for historical events suitable for reenactment. Reenactment is the staple of official celebration. Remember the 1960's?
