Reenactments of Civil War battles often seemed as inescapable as street muggers. Driving serenely through the countryside, we were always being screamed at for getting in the way of the Battle of Bull Run, the siege of Vicksburg.

title: STUDY FINDS FACTOR OF CYSTIC FIBROSIS
description: University of Texas researchers reported yesterday the isolation of a unique factor from the blood of patients with cystic fibrosis.

title: MARKET PURSUES INDECISIVE PATH
U.S. Relaxes Blockade at Wounded Knee, but Storm Hampers New Parleys
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., March 14The Federal Government eased the blockade of Wounded Knee today and agreed to allow food, fuel and medicine in as a spring blizzard roared into the area, closing roads throughout the southeast corner of the state.

title: Widow of Fats Waller Dies
description: Mrs. Anita R. Waller, widow of Thomas (Fats) Waller, the jazz pianist, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at ner home, 17030 130th Avenue, Jamaica, Queens. She leaves her son, Maurice, also jazz pianist, and six grandchildren.

title: 4 Bomb Explosions Rock 2 Port Cities on Cyprus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 14 (AP)The port cities of Limassol and Famagusta were shaken by four bomb explosions tonight, three directed against the homes of police officers in Limassol.

title: BenGurion Leaves Hospital
description: TEL AVIV, March 14 (AP)David BenGurion, Israel's elder statesman, was released from a hospital today after suffering chest pains. The 86yearold former Premier, taken to a hospital yesterday, improved during the night, his doctors said.

title: State TakeOver of OTB Proposed
description: ALBANY, March 14Senate Majority Leader Warren M. Anderson proposed today that the state take over New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation and severely restrict the kinds of bets it could accept.

title: COUNSEL TO NIXON TELLS SENATE UNIT HE WON'T TESTIFY
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 John W. Dean 3d, President Nixon's chief legal counsel, declined today an invitation to appear before the Senate Judiciary Committee in connection with the nomination of L. Patrick Gray 3d, Mr. Nixon's choice to become director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Percentage Gains
description: Stocks with the largest percentage gains on the American Stock Exchange yesterday:

title: Racially Tense High School Shut For 2d Straight Day in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, March 14Kensington High School here was closed today for the second day in a row as groups of students milled about the hallways and refused to go to classes.

title: New U.S. Plan Would Allow Byproducts in Frankfurters
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)In a move to help stabilize meat prices, the Agriculture Department, proposed today to allow continued use of byproducts such as pork snouts, goat tongues and hog lips in frankfurters.

title: NETS BOW TO Q'S AT HOME, 10898
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 14 The San Diego Conquistadors, battling to wrest fourth place and a playoff spot in the American Basketball Association's Western Division, defeated the New York Nets, 10898, before 8,264 fans at Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: U. S. EASES CURES ON PAKISTAN ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The United States relaxed its total embargo on arms shipments to India and Pakistan today, thus permitting the Pakistanis to receive some 300 armored personnel carriers, spare parts for previously supplied arms and some nonlethal military equipment.

title: NIXON PLANS SALES FROM STOCKPILES
description: WASHINGTON, March 14President Nixon has decided to sell large amounts of metals and other commodities from the nation's strategic stockpile in an effort to drive down soaring prices, it was learned from authoritative Administration officials tonight.

title: City Study Says Drop in Addicts In Jail Reflects Easing of Crime.
description: The Health Services Administration released a study yester day that contends that the sharp decline in the percentage of addicts seeking detoxification in city detention facilities reflects an overall easing of addictcommitted crime in the city.

title: FERDINAND M. BISSELL
description: SANTURCE, P.R., March 14 Ferdinand M. Bissell, a retired vice president of the Banco Popular de Puerto Rico, died Friday in a San Juan nursing home. He was 68 years old.

title: U.S. Renews Withdrawal From Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 14 (AP)  The United States temporarily resumed troop withdrawals from South Vietnam today to match the release of 108 American prisoners by North Vietnam, the American command announced.

title: Bill Is Introduced in House To Abolish Death Penalty
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)Representative Robert F. Drinan, Democrat of Massachusetts, introduced today a bill that would abolish the death penalty under Federal law.

title: Modern Museum Takes a New View
description: For anyone who can remember its opening exhibition in 1929, it is hard to believe that the Museum of Modern Art is a hoary 44 years, old. The realization comes more easily, however, during a visit to The Paintintt and Sculpture Collection: New Perspective, which opened to the public yesterday. The surprise shifts direction; it is no longer a matter of disbelieving the 44 years, but of wondering how a collection of such quality could have been assembled in so relatively short a time, even by an institution that had everything going for it, as the museum did for about three decades after, its founding.

title: NIXON CRIME PLAN SENT TO CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, March 14President Nixon, asserting that the only way to attack crime effectively is without pity, urged Congress today to revise the entire criminal code in a way that, in many cases, would increase penalties and reduce the discretion of Federal judges in imposing sentences.

title: LEBANESE TRADERS VEXING LIBERIANS
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  The former Liberian Minister of Information and Tourism, G. Henry Andrews, implied in a letter some weeks ago that the Lebanese business community here, said to dominate the nation's retail trade and from 15 to 20 per cent of the economy, could be put out of the country just as Asians were evicted from Uganda last year.

title: Senate Approves the Use Of Road Funds for Transit
description: Washington, March 14The Senate, following its tenseest legislative debate of the year, voted today to allow urban areas to spend their share of Federal highway money to build rapid rail systems.

title: O.E.O., First on the One Hand, Then on the Other
description: WASHINGTONIn the President's radio address on human resources, he spelled out three criteria to be applied in reaching decisions regarding Federal activities in the socialprogram area.

title: Ross Hunter's Version of 'Lost Horizon' Opens:The Cast
description: To a small boy in 1937, Frank Capra's film adaptation of James Hilton's "Lost Horizon" did not seem as naive as it did the last time I saw it, four or five years ago, but it remains an example of romantic Hollywood filmmaking at its best. It has the style of Ronald Colman, the wit of Robert Riskin (its screenwriter) and its sets, costumes and special effects are superb. In those days, there was virtually no place or thing that could not be reproduced bigger than life on any Hollywood backlot.One can even accept the Capra film's rather smug, ostrichlike attitudes toward world problems, if only as a souvenir of the decade that gave us, among other things, the Reichstag fire, Munich and World War II. Shangri-La  Hilton's secret Tibetan valley where poverty, illness and age are unknown and the only excesses are those of moderation  is an almost perfect expression of the wishes of a very specific time  one that is long-since past, at least to me.Not so to Ross Hunter, the producer ("Airport," "Imitation of Life," "Magnificent Obsession") who has devoted a lot of his career to trying to preserve the glamour that once was Hollywood's by ransacking its old movies. With his updated, musicalized remake of "Lost Horizon," which opened yesterday at Loews State I and the Tower East Theaters, Hunter persists in his mad if harmless mission with the fanaticism of someone trying to build sandcastles at the water's edge.This "Lost Horizon," with Peter Finch at the head of a not-quite-all-star cast, is a big, stale marshmallow, notable, perhaps, in that most of it was filmed in and around Hollywood at what is reported to have been a rather large budget. Money apparently doesn't go very far in Hollywood these days, for the film, in addition to packing all of the dramatic punch of a Moral Re-Armament pamphlet, is surprisingly tacky in appearance.When we aren't seeing the magical valley of Shangri-La in long-shot as something painted through trick photography, we see it in close-up as a couple of seedy backlot sets, one of which, the High Lama's palace, looks like Pickfair remodelled as a motel. The old Hollywood craftsmanship is as dead as the arch attitudes and philosophizing of Larry Kramer's screenplay, which replays most of the memorable moments of the original film, with sometimes hilarious results."I am Chang," says John Gielgud, his eyes slightly taped for an Oriental effect, but you are not meant to snicker. "Can this be the skin of a 100-year-old woman?" asks 20-year-old Olivia Hussey who plays the remarkably well-preserved Maria, whom we all wait to turn into an ancient peanut once she goes beyond the Shangri-La pass.The most hilarious moments, however, are the original contributions of Hunter, Charles Jarrott, his director, and Hermes Pan, who choreographed some of the great Astaire-Rogers musicals but is out of his element here.With the exception of Bobby Van, who plays a second-rate comic who is hijacked to Shangri-La along with Finch, the British diplomat, nobody in the film can dance very well, not the chorus boys (featured in a pricelessly ill-suited number celebrating the joys of fatherhood) nor poor Sally Kellerman, who plays a Newsweek correspondent fed up with life. It's extraordinary how Miss Kellerman successfully maintains her appeal even while failing as a singer and dancer. Dancer? What she does is try to keep time.The second-rate auspices just about destroys everyone in the film, with the possible exceptions of Finch, Van and Michael York. Liv Ullmann, who is the world's most beautiful woman when photographed by Ingmar Bergman, is stiff and uncomfortable as a Shangri-La school mistress. Charles Boyer, as the High Lama, dressed in a sheet, looks like the ghost of Hamlet's father emerging from a steam-bath. And how long has it been since you've seen the soul of a dying man depart through a window? You'll see it again here.The music written by Burt Bacharach is often pleasant, but it's too sophisticated for both the movie and the lyrics, written by Hal David. The lyrics, when not silly, have a way of attracting attention to the ersatz nature of the entire enterprise. "Look inside yourself," Miss Ullmann sings to Finch, "that's where the truth always lies." The conjunction of truth and lies hardly seems accidental in a film that sets out to recall a kind of filmmaking now lost, but succeeds only in denting pleasant memories.

title: JAMES P. MAHER
description: James P. Maher, a former financial writer, editor and Wall Street broker, died yesterday at Brooklyn Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 345 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: State Drug Panel's Plan For Penalties Is Praised
description: ALBANY, March 14 state commission's proposed alternative to Governor Rockefeller's pending legislation dealing with narcotics traffickers was generally praised today by leading Republicans here who are seeking tougher drug laws but who have problems with the Governor's plan.

title: Dog's Bite Must Be as Good as His Bark
description: All dogs can be obedience trained and can be taught to be watchdogs, but to become a security animal is something else, Joseph DeCosta, an instructor, told Dog Fanciers Club members at their luncheon in the Hotel McAIpin yesterday.

title: BRONX WIDOW FOUND DEAD IN HER BATHTUB
description: A 69  year  old widow was found dead yesterday in the bathtub of her apartment in the Clasons Point section of the Bronx. The police said she was fully clothed and her mouth was gagged and they tentatively termed the death a homicide.

title: IRISH BRANDY, 31, AQUEDUCT VICTOR
description: Irish Brandy of the JoeMar Stable had the benefit of a frontrunning ride under Kelly Castaneda in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, and took the sevenfurlong event by two lengths over Leo Fink's Pat Intent.

title: MRS. WILLIAM H. WILLIS
description: ARMONK, N.Y., March 14Mrs. Elizabeth K. Willis, the widow of William H. Willis, who headed the executive recruiting concern in New York bearing his name, died Monday. She was 75 years old.

title: Equity Financing
description: Middle South Utilities, Inc., directors accepted yesterday a bid of $22.116 a share for four million shares of new common stock from a group of underwriters headed by Kidder, Peabody. The underwriting group will offer the stock to the public 22 a share.

title: INQUIRY CONTINUES INTO DEATH OF GIRL
description: The police continued yesterday their investigation of the circumstances surrounding the death of Felicia Bruce, the 8yearold girl found dead Tuesday, two days after she left her home at 277 West 117th Street on an errand.

title: Connor, S.I. Borough President, Quits G.O.P. to Run as Democrat
description: Robert T. Connor, Borough President of Staten Island and a lifelong Republican, switched to the Democratic party yesterday, and announced that he would seek its nomination for reelection.

title: Jersey Issues Maps Contesting Private Rights to Riparian Land
description: TRENTON, March 14 The slate today unveiled the first of a series of tidalflow maps that will form the basis for challenges to private ownership of property in sections of Newark, Elizabeth, Hoboken and other cities and towns.

title: Resigning G.O.P. Aide Prods the White House
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 Representative Bob Wilson of California, stepping down as chairman of the Republipan Congressionat Campaign Committee, said today that his party's fortunes in the 1974 elections would largely depend on White House support.

title: 7 FOOD PLACES FAIL HEALTH INSPECTION
description: Gordon Chase, the city's Health Services Administrator announced yesterday the names of seven more foot establishments that he said had violated the Health Code. Unless the violations are cleared up by a third and final inspection, the establishments face the possibility of being closed.

title: BILL ON NEWSMEN FRUSTRATES ERVIN
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, expressed frustration today as he listened to proposals to restrict and to widen his bill to protect the rights of newsmen.

title: Lerman Freydberg, 70, Dies; Headed Plastics Concern
description: Herman M. Freydberg, a retired plastics manufacturer who was a former president of the Westchester County Golf Association, died Monday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. His age was 70.

title: Markson 67, Leaving Garden Boxing Post
description: After having promoted more than 2,000 boxing cards in 40 years, Harry Markson will retire March 31 as president of Madison Square Garden Boxing, Inc.

title: China Releases Two Airmen, The Last Americans She Held
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, March 15The last two American pilots held by China were released today and crossed the border into Hong Kong.

title: Italy Is Said to Consider Letting Floating Lira Decline Farther
description: ROME, March 14The Government today held consultations on monetary strategy amid indications that the lira exchange rate might be allowed to drop substantially lower than it has already in the month it has been floating.

title: Dollar Up, Gold Down
description: Since March of 1968, there have been two prices goldthe official price set by governments and the freemarket price set by traders and speculators. The official price of gold, following the second devaluation of the dollar, is now $42.22 an ounce. Only three weeks ago, when confidence in the dollarand other paper currencieswas plummeting, the freemarket price of gold soared to $95 an ounce, an alltime peak.

title: LITTON DIVESTITURE IS ORDERED BY F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission yesterday ordered Litton Industries, Inc., to divest itself of TriumphAdler, a WestGerMan typewriter manufacturer acquired by Litton in 1969.

title: ELMER A. GREENHALL
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., March 14Elmer A. Greenhall, a manufacturer of men's belts and braces, died here yesterday. He was 72 years old and formerly lived in Springfield, N.J.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: TV: C.B.S. Applause Glitters at Its Musical Best
description: Applause is the stagemusical version of All About Eve, the brittle, bitchy film classic starring Bette Davis. Applause is not a classic. It is a loud and brassy Broadway musical, at its best when starring Lauren Bacall. Its best can be seen tonight, from 9 to 11 on the Columbia Broadcasting System, in a special TV adaptation taped in London, where Miss Bacall and the play are currently having a stage run.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Growing Sport
description: One measure of the burgeoning popularity of fly fishing was the nearcapacity crowd attending the 11th annual meeting and dinner of the Theodore Gordon Flyfishers held last weekend at the Marriott Essex House in Manhattan.

title: INVENTORY TOTAL ROSE IN JANUARY
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 Total business inventories rose in January by the largest amount since the current economic expansion began, but sales rose even faster, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Music
description: Although Nell Rankin has made numerous concert appearances here in her long career, she is best known now for her appearances with the Metropolitan Opera, of which she has been a member since 1951.

title: Biharis of Bangladesh Subsist in Ghettos of Despair
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, March 9Bewildered and terrified, the Biharis of Bangladesh are huddled in tents at packed camps around cities and ports. They are dispossessed.

title: Archer, ExQueens Prosecutor, Gets 3 Years for Taking Bribe
description: Norman D. Archer was sentenced to a threeyear prison term yesterday for accepting a bribe to fix a criminal case while he was a chief assistant district attorney in Queens.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, March 14 (Reuters)Japan had a surplus of $890million in her balance of payments for February, mainly because an international currency crisis prompted a large influx of dollars, the Finance Ministry announced today. The February surplus contrasted to a deficit of $607million in January and a surplus of $661million in February, 1972.

title: Cochran Is on Prowl for SkiRace Talent
description: RUTLAND, Vt., March 14 Gordon (Mickey) Cochran, the father of skiing's four flying Cochrans, was a close observer of the national college ski championships at nearby Middlebury last weekend. He kept peering at the plunging collegians in the slalom and downhill races as if all were potential Olympic stars. You never know, he said. Good racers are not easy to come by in this country where school work takes priority over ski training. And it's training that makes ski racers outstanding. Remember, when we race against Europeans, we're competing against people raised on skins.

title: Alou Brothers Each a Hit in Yankee Debut
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 14Mrs. Virginia Rojas Alou never wanted her sons to become baseball players. She wanted them instead to go to college. She wanted a doctor in the family, Matty Alou said.

title: NIXON PLANS SALES FROM STOCKPILES TO REDUCE PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, March 14President Nixon has decided to sell large amounts of metals and other commodities from the nation's strategic stockpile in an effort to drive down soaring prices, it was learned from authoritative Administration officials tonight.

title: Judge Denies H.E.W. Stay of His Order To End School Bias
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)Judge John H. Pratt of United StatesDistrict Court denied today a Government motion for a stay of his ruling that the Department of Health, Education and Welfare must promptly enforce desegregation in hundreds of schools in 17 Southern and, border states.

title: Court Reinstates 2 Indictments For Perjury Dismissed by Culkin
description: The dismissal last year by State Supreme Court Justice Gerald P. Culkin of perjury indictments against two retired policemen was reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division.

title: Slaying of Yablonskis Portrayed As a Panicky Action of Burglars
description: ERIE, Pa., March 14  The defense sought today to portray the slaying of Joseph A. Yablonski, the United Mine Workers reform leader who was shot to death with his wife and daughter in 1969, as a bungled burglary in which the gunmen panicked and slaughtered a family.

title: Screen: Vivid 'Soleil-O':Mel Hondo Makes Dramatic Outcry in Film Debut About Blacks in France
description: "Soleil-O," which opened yesterday at the Olympia Theater, is sharply direct about some of the darkness that has enveloped immigrant, African blacks in France, particularly in Paris.In his first film, the young, black Mauritanian stage actor-director Mel Hondo makes a pitiable and often dramatic outcry even if his dramatization of injustices is open-ended and inconclusive.Mr. Hondo is presenting the sad, frustrating existences of his black brother workers in an alien country through the experiences of one educated, gentle immigrant from Mauritania.While his obvious anger seems biased on occasion, he is meticulous in stressing that white employers and other citizens are fearful of the ever-increasing numbers of black people in France, who were "only a handful" in 1946 and are in the hundreds of thousands now.If he is elliptical in his use of symbolism and a stream-of-consciousness approach, his total portrait, like the film, is stark black-and-white. A white entrepreneur blandly outlines the need for work aptitude tests to the tall, bearded, young hero at the beginning of his quest for a better life in Paris.But the civil, religious and educational principles inculcated in African blacks by French colonialists are, however, of little help in qualifying them for jobs in present-day Paris.The anomaly of people adrift is projected through the cold attitude of wary employers (and union leaders), menial jobs, lack of housing and varied forms of racism. Mr. Hondo, it must be underlined, also is unsparing in his view of black officials in their own country who, it says here, are merely giving the expatriates little but official doubletalk.One assumes that behind all the symbols, Mr. Hondo is looking for salvation that might come from the precepts of Malcolm X and other black revolutionaries whose portraits we glimpse toward the end of his film.Mr. Hondo and Robert Liensol, who plays the leading role forcefully and naturally, and the others in his cast of blacks and whites (simply listed by their proper names), have not solved the problem or come up with a prospective solution to it.But they and, particularly, Mr. Hondo, whose imagery tends to be arty and disjointed, have given us a drama that remains disturbingly vivid.

title: LOCAL ELECTIONS ARE SET IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 14Ulster will hold local government elections on May 30, under a new system of proportional representation, it was announced here today by the British Secretary of State, William Whitelaw. The elections will be the first since 1967.

title: New Air Fee Approved
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized the nation's airlines yesterday to add 34 cents to the cost of each airline flight to defray the cost of airport searches ordered by the White House to deter hijackers. Page 85.

title: SHULTZ ASSURES SOVIET ON TRADE
description: MOSCOW, March 14  The United States Secretary of the Treasury, George P. Shultz today assured Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, that President Nixon was determined to overcome Congressional opposition to an easing of trade with the Soviet Union.

title: Personal Finance
description: Refunds are up and so are incometax filings in comparison with a year ago.

title: SHOW RECALLS ERA OF BLACK DANCERS
description: The fact that many black vaudeville dancers were also comedy dancers who became known as nondancing comedians on Broadway and television can make one forget what good dancers they were. Or still are. Tuesday night's program at Town Hall by the Mura Dehn Traditional Jazz Dance Theater served as a useful and very pleasurable reminder.

title: Rates in Credit Markets Advance on Broad Front
description: Interest rates pressed higher along a broad front again yesterday as the market for fixedincome securities continued its quiet, but persistent deterioration. Sonic signs of relative stability appeared in the market for taxexempts, the hardest hit sector of late, but the group that won a large State of Washington issue Tuesday was considering a bid late in the day that would raise the original yield by roughly 10 basis points, or onetenth of a percentage point. The money market, meanwhile, worked higher in rate, partly reflecting more pressures from the approach today of the quarterly taxpayment date for corporations.

title: Chess:
description: The battle between MateinTwo Dillon of the romantic, sacrificial school and Inchalong Cassidy, the positional wonder, is by no means the lopsided affair it sometimes appears to be.

title: ELLSBERG JURORS BRIEFED ON SPYING
description: LOS ANGELES, March 14The jury in the Pentagon papers trial continued its education today in how the United States gathers intelligence.

title: South Africa Will Ease Segregation for Graham
description: DURBAN, South Africa, March March 14 (AP)South Africa's racial segregation policy will he modiefied for the Rev. Billy Graham's appearance in Durban Saturday.

title: Bomb Threat Delays Flight
description: BOSTON, March 14 (AP)A Trans World Airlines flight to Athens was diverted to Boston early today after a bomb threat was made at the airline's New York office. The flight way delayed at Boston's Logan Airport for four and a half hours.

title: J. STEELE GOW
description: PITTSBURGH, March 14J. Steele Gow, retired executive director of the Falk Foundation, died yesterday in PresbyterianUniversity Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: BACKING SAID TO RISE ON DEFENSE OUTLAYS
description: The number of persons who feel that too much is being spent for the national defense has declined to 42 per cent from the 50 per cent figure recorded two years ago, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: Transit Strike Put Off
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 14 (UPI Approximately 400,000 Philadelphia area commuters received a reprieve today with postponement of a threatened strike that would halt all bus, trolley and subway service. Local 243, Transport Workers Union, scheduled to walk out at midnight in a wage contract dispute with the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority, extended the strike deadline until midnight Sunday.

title: Andre Repond, Psychiatrist, Headed World Health Unit
description: MONTHEY, Switzerland, March 13 (Reuters)Dr. Andre Repond, a psychiatrist and for mer president of the World Federation for Mental Healtb, died last night. He was 87 years old.

title: Alleged Gallo Aide Held in Mob Killing
description: Robert Bongiovi, an alleged gunman who was with Joseph Gallo the night he was assassinated last April, was charged yesterday with a murder that the police said might have links to the Gallo killing.

title: U. S. EASES CURES ON PAKISTAN ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The United States relaxed its total embargo on arms shipments to India and Pakistan today, thus permitting the Pakistanis to receive some 300 armored personnel carriers, spare parts for previously supplied arms and some nonlethal, military equipment.

title: 2 JAPANESE URGE INVESTMENT RISE
description: Two Japanese executives warned here yesterday that Japan's efforts to restrict exports could give only temporary, partial help in reducing the American trade deficit with their country. In 1973 this deficit topped $4billion.

title: Roosa Faults Attempting Quick Monetary Solution
description: Robert V. Roosa, Under Secretary of the Treasury for monetary affairs in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations and one of the world's leading students of international monetary affairs, warned yesterday against attempts to find a quick solution to the present world findncial crisis.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Mrs. Roger Yaseen tossed her curly red hair and announced that the short ruffled lavender chiffon dress she was modeling looks like the 1940's and the 1890's at the same time.

title: GRAEBNER UPSETS NASTASE IN 3 SETS
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 14 (AP)Thirdseeded Clark Graebner of New York overcame loss of the first set in a tiebreaker to upset topseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania, 67, 63, 64, in the $15,000 National indoor open tennis championship.

title: Out at Wounded Knee
description: A heavy snowstorm has apparently had the salutary effect of damping down the tensions at Wounded Knee that earlier in the week threatened a new armed confrontation as Department of Justice agents sought a way to reduce the rebellion in that remote Indian settlement in South Dakota. The 200 or so members of the militant American Indian Movement, having declared themselves an independent nation at war with the United States, must be regarded as insurrectionists, however quixotic their uprising. Yet no official in his right mind can want to employ the armed might of this country to subdue a tiny band of men engaged in a symbolic war against a nation that has, in fact, broken its treaties with them, decimated their people and reduced their entire race to wretched remnant.

title: Power and Molloy quintets Advance to C.H.S.A.A. Final
description: In Catholic High School Athletic Association semifinal games played last night at Fordham University, Power downed All Hallows, 6249, and Molloy beat Holy Cross. 4945, before a capacity crowd of 3,470.

title: 3 Injured in Plane Crash
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 14 (UPI)A singleengine Cessna plane crashed late yesterday About a mile from the Westchester County Airport. Three persons were injured. The three were reported in fair condition at Greenwich Hospital. They were identifed as John Place, 51, years old of Rye, N.Y. the pilot; Barbara Sandes, 18, of the state of Washington, and James Bengston, 28, of Costa Mesa, Calif., Roth passengers.

title: GORMAN DEFEATS DIBBS BY 76, 64
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 14 (AP)Tom Gorman of Seattle defeated Eddie Dibbs of Miami, 76, 64, and kept alive his bid for the $5,000 first prize in the Caracas roundrobin international tennis tournament today.

title: LeisureSpending So Much Is Taking the Fun Out of It
description: When you asked them why they lived in New York, they'd tell you: the opera, the array of restaurants, the movies, the Knicks. But now even these New York lovers, accustomed to such a rich diet of divertissements, are being forced to take an uncomfortable look at what it costs to have fun.

title: F.B.I. Nets 6 in Hijacking Of Goods Worth $150,000
description: NEWARK, March 14 (AP)Six persons were arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation today in the hijacking of truckloads of television sets, radios, coats, digital clocks and stainlesssteel flatware.

title: Ad for Job to $20,000 Results in a Consent Order
description: Hundreds of women responded to a classified advertisement for an administrative assistant to a president paying to $20,000 a year. But Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz charged that at least 24 of the women hired by Universal Administrators, a management service at 200 Park Avenue, were hired and placed in other jobsand never paid.

title: Greek Universities Reopen
description: ATHENS, March 14 (AP)Greek universities, closed for a week after confrontations last month between students and police, reopened peacefully today. The student disturbances represented the first widespread challenge to Greece's sixyearold military Government.

title: Distillers Corporation Net Up 10.5% in Quarter
description: Distillers CorporationSeagrams, Ltd., the world's largest distiller, increased earnings in the quarter and halfyear ended Jan. 31 by more than 10.5 per cent from the yearearlier periods, the company reported yesterday. Sales in both periods set records, the company said.

title: Strongman of the Sudan Gaafar alNimeiry
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 14During the night of May 25, 1969, the Premier of the Sudan, Mohammed Ahmed Mahgoub, was awakened by his wife who told him that a military coup was taking place against him.

title: Nixon Praises Drug Agents Who Helped Convict Ricord
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)  President Nixon today praised the narcotics agents who were instrumental in the conviction of a heroin smuggler who Mr. Nixon said had brought enough drugs into the United States to affect the lives of more persons than were killed in Vietnam

title: Bonn's Moue From Dollar as a Measure Signals MoneyPolicy Shift
description: BONN, March 14West Germany moved away from the United States dollar as its monetary measuring stick for the mark today and indicated that it expected Washington to acknowledge this step in a new arrangement to support the American currency.

title: Notes on People
description: In an unusual announcement, the Society of Jesus said in Rome that its General, the Very Rev. Pedro Arrupe, had apologized to a close aide of Pope Paul VI for a letter written by an English Jesuit. The letter, published in The Observer in London last Sunday, was written by the Most Rev. Peter Hebblethwaite. It said, in part, that the Papal aide, the Most Rev. Giovanni Benelli, was concerned with prestige and pomposity when many are trying to make the church a simpler, more fraternal place.

title: CONTRACEPTIVE AIR FOLLOWS ABORTIONS
description: Of the 7,299 women who received abortions last year at the 22d Street Center of Planned Parenthood of New York, 86 per cent accepted medically approved or prescribed birthcontrol method afterward, the organization announced yesterday.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: ELISHA WALKER JR.
description: Elisha Walker Jr., a financier, died yesterday of a sudden illness in Acapulco, Mexico, according to word received by relatives here. He was 62 years old and lived at 870 United Nations Plaza.

title: Chilean Crash Toll at 45
description: ANTOFAGASTA, Chile, March 14 (UPI)The toll in Chile's worst traffic accident rose to 45 today with the deaths of 10 more persons. The accident occurred Monday night when a bus smashed headon into another bus.

title: 5th Senate Bill Introduced On Northeast Rail Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 1(AP)Senator William Saxbe, Republican of Ohio, proposed today that the Government nationalize seven financially ailing railroads in the. Northeast. His bill is the fifth introduced this session on the rail crisis.

title: Business Records
description: Wednesday, March 14, 1973

title: Senators for Capital Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, proposed today a constitutional amendment that would give the District of Columbia full voting representation in Congress  two Senators and probably two Representatives.

title: COSGRAVE TAKES HELM IN DUBLIN
description: DUBLIN, March 14  Liam Cosgrave, leader of the coalition that won the general election of Feb. 28, took office today as Prime Minister of Ireland.

title: ISRAEL OFFERS KING POWER OVER SHRINES
description: TEL AVIV, March 14Premier Golda Meir today offered King Hussein of Jordan guardianship over the Islamic holy places in the Old City of Jerusalem.

title: TURKS IN IMPASSE ON NEW PRESIDENT
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 14 Turkish politicians and leaders of the armed forces backed off from a confrontation today as Parliament postponed until Friday the election of a new national president.

title: TWO MORE CLUBS ENDORSE BEDILLO
description: Representative Herman Badillo, who lost the New Democratic Coalition endorsement to Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, announced yesterday that two more coalition clubs had voted to support his own candidacy.

title: P.O.W. Commander Among 108 Freed
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, March 14North Vietnam released 108 more American prisoners of war today, including the officer who had acted as commander of prisoners captured in the North.

title: Olin and BASF Wyandotte Announce Price Increases
description: The Olin Corporation and the BASF Wyandotte Corporation announced yesterday that they would raise prices for chlorine and caustic soda by $5 a ton. Spot delivery prices go into effect immediately for Olin, and April 1 for BASF Wyandotte.

title: California Man Indicted In Shooting Deaths of 10
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., March 14 (AP)  The Santa Cruz County grand jury indicted Herbert W. Mullin, 25 years old, for murder today in the shooting deaths of 10 persons here.

title: Industry Leaders Assail Strip Mining Control Bills
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Leaders of the nation's mining industry said today that they opposed both strip mining trol bills currently under study by the Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee.

title: Executives on Tour Get Doomsday View Of City in 1980's
description: Otto Preminger, the film director; William S. Beinecke, the S. & H. greenstamps' king, and C. K. McClatchy, vice president of The Sacramento Bee, found themselves on the prow of a sludge cargo ship on the East River yesterday, listening to a doomsday description of how New York City would run out of places to put its garbage by the midnineteeneighties

title: People and Business
description: William W. Scranton, former Governor of Pennsylvania, rejoined Northeastern National Bank of Pennsylvania yesterday, this time as chairman of the board.

title: Mr. Hogan's Declaration
description: In his more than three decades as District Attorney Manhattan, Frank S. Hogan has made that formerly scandalridden office a beacon of quality for lawenforcement agencies all over the country. Politics has been banished in staff appointments and in handling cases. Graduates of the Hogan school rank high Federal, state and local agencies as well as in prestigious private law firms.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Pupil attendance in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn showed its biggest oneday gain yesterday since white parents began boycotting the area's eight schools on March 1 to protest the busingin of children from another community. Officials of Community School District 18, which includes Canarsie, said 1,694 pupils showed up for classes yesterday, 173 more than on Tuesday. However, 8,042 pupils were absent at the eight schools.

title: EDUCATORS SEEK TO ENJOIN AGENCY
description: A nonprofit organization of educators filed suit in a Federal court in Washington yesterday against the newest Government agency, the National Institute of Education, charging that it has been functioning illegally.

title: SOVIET RASTERS TOP RUSSIAN CHESS EVENT
description: MOSCOW March 14 (AP)Soviet chess masters, led by Mikhail Tal, a former world champion, captured the first six places in the international tournament in Talkinn that ended today.

title: Hungarian on Truce Unit Has Emigrated to Australia
description: CANBERRA, Australia, March 14 (Reuters)  A member of the Hungarian delegation helping to supervise the ceasefire in South Vietnam arrived in Sydney today from Saigon as an immigrant, it was announced here.

title: Texas Voters Reject Bond Issue For Trinity River Canal Project
description: FORT WORTH, March 14 A solid majority of the voters in the 17 Texas counties of the Trinity River basin rejected yesterday a property tax needed to support $150million in site preparation bonds for a canal on the river.

title: Teacher Strike Sentences Cut for Two in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 14 (AP)The judge who sentenced two leaders of the Philadelphia Federation of Teachers to jail for defying his order to end a strike reduced their sentences today after refusing to free them.

title: METROLINER IS HIT BY ANOTHER TRAIN
description: TUXEDO, Md., March 14 (UPI)A train carrying railroad workmen struck the rear of a stopped New YorktoWashington Metroliner outside Washington today, injuring 12 persons. It was the first major accident for the highspeed passenger train since it began operations four years ago.

title: Senate Approves the Use Of Road Funds for Transit
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The Senate, following its most tense legislative debate of the year, voted today to allow urban areas to spend their share of Federal highway money to build rapid rail systems.

title: Brooklyn G.O.P. Opposes Coalition Race for Wagner
description: Governor Rockefeller's attempt to forge a RepublicanLiberal coalition behind former Mayor Robert F. Wagner ran into a revolt yesterday by the Republican organization in Brooklyn, and as a resuit, the delicate negotiations, could be undone.

title: Muskie Battles Aides Of President to Draw
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine and three members of President Nixon's Cabinet waged a miniature version of the battle of the budget today on Capitol Hill. Nobody won.

title: Two Movie Stars Tell Arizona Inquest Of the Night Business Manager Died
description: GILA BEND, Ariz., March 19 Two movie stars, Burt Reynolds and Sarah Miles, testified at an inquest held in Arizona's desert country today that they knew nothing about a head wound found by the police on the body of David A. Whiting, Miss Miles's business manager, on Feb. 11, the day Mr. Whiting died.

title: HUSSEIN SPARES 17 PALESTINIANS
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 14 King Hussein announced today that he had commuted the death sentences passed against Mohammed Daoud Odeh, a leader of Al Fatah, the main Palestinian guerrilla organization, and 16 of his colleagues.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Mackell Charges Nadjari Is Lawless and Sadistic
description: District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens denounced Deputy Attorney General Maurice H. Nadjari yesterday as lawless and as a petty and irascible wouldbe prosecutor who had sadistically abused witnesses called to testify before his grand juries.

title: U.S. in the U.N. Dock
description: The agenda for the extraordinary session of the United Nations Security Council, opening today in Panama, is consideration of measures for the maintenance and strengthening of international peace and security in Latin America in conformity with the provisions and principles of the Charter. The fact is that Panama maneuvered to get the meeting there as part of its drive to gain control over the Canal and Canal Zone from the United States.

title: CHARLES H. FOSTE
description: SYOSSET, L.I., March 14Charles H. Foster, a manufacturer's representative for precisionmachine parts, died yesterday at his home, 236 Berry Hill Road. He was 61 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: The Screen: 'Fear Is the Key' Arrives:The Poor Man's .007 Is at the DeMille
description: An action movie that generally manages to deliver some action and is almost always as good as it pretends to be (however modest its pretensions) must be allowed some excellence by its own scale of values. That is the scale, the only proper scale, to apply to Michael Tuchner's "Fear Is the Key," a minor, rather satisfying entertainment that opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.It is based on an Alistair MacLean novel, and like "Puppet on a Chain," the last Alistair MacLean novel seen on film here, it has a little of the look and something of the feel of a James Bond thrillerbut cheaper, more threadbare, with fewer gadgets and more nerve.This doesn't necessarily make for better movies, but it should make for different expectations. People seem to wear the same clothes all through the film. They chase economy cars, shoot from smaller arsenals. And sometimes second best, like virtue, is its own reward.So the film seems to need its locationsthe flat Louisiana coastline, the offshore oilfields, the sumptuous rain-swept mansion (this last shot in England)for use rather than just for exotic appeal. There is a car chase, ingenious, obligatory, overlong and rather dull, but there are also the tidal swamps, the mostly empty roads receding into a distance that make up in atmospheric emotion for what the story lacks in sense.The story, an incredible intrigue enacted by one John Talbot (Barry Newman) to revenge the murder of his wife and child and at the same time make the world safe for Western monetary systems, is sufficient for the movie but not for critical examination. It is enough that it provides some dangerous encounters and the particular kind of good-guy heroics that have become trade.Barry Newman's stock in No matter where he is courting danger ("The Salzburg Connection," "Vanishing Point") Newman always seems vaguely out of place. I've about decided that "out of place" is really where he belongs, and that he is not so much the hero as a fantasist (city-bred, nice Jewish boy, good-looking though a trifle cross-eyed) seeking heroism.When he goes "Aaargh," near suffocation underwater in the film's climax, he is almost pure comic book  which is already a kind of sophistication, though perhaps not so intended. It is in terms of such comic-book sophistication that he meets the villain, Vyland (John Vernon), and will one day court the heroine, Sarah Ruthven (Suzy Kendall), waiting for him topsides with her oil-rich dad.We never really put away childish things, and when we pick them up from time to time it may be well that we can do it with games as gracefully innocuous as "Fear Is the Key."

title: Nixon Aides Plan a Statement To Avert Inflation Psychology
description: WASHINGTON, March 14In an effort to avert a revival of inflationary psychology, the Administration plans to issue next week a statement outlining the probable course of farm and retail food prices for the rest of 1973, informed sources disclosed today.

title: Title Polo Resumes Tonight
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 14The University of Connecticut, the defending champion, meets Yale and the University of Virginia plays Cornell tomorrow night in the semifinal round of the National Intercollegiate indoor polo tournament at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club. Yale had won the title five consecutive years, a record, before being eliminated in the semifinal last year.

title: World Hockey Association Scoring
OTTAWA IS COOL TO OIL PROPOSAL
description: OTTAWA, March 14  The Federal Government reacted politely, but coolly today to the $4billion plan proposed yesterday by Premier David Barrett of British Columbia to transport Alaska oil and gas by rail to markets in the United States.

title: 2 Port Authority MassTransit Bills Pass in Senate but Stall in Assembly
description: ALBANY, March 14The Senate narrowly approved two bill; today providing for $650million mass  transportation construction program by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, but the Republican leadership in the Assembly failed to muster enough votes for final passage by the Legislature.

title: Lindsay Capital Budget Cut $80Million
description: The Board of Estimate and the City Council's Finance Committee, in separate closed sessions yesterday, cut $80million of requests by Mayor Lindsay from the capital budget and haggled about inserting $80million of their own items instead.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Bridge: 64 Teams Are Competing In Vanderbilt Championship
description: ST. LOUIS, March 14The Vanderbilt knockout team championship, the premier event of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, when into full gear here this afternoon, with 64 teams competing, 10 of which survived preliminary round matches yesterday.

title: MORE FUNDS SEEN FOR SOCIAL USE
description: WASHINGTON, March Responding to mounting tests, the Nixon Administration backed down at least part today from earlier plans trim Federal outlays for and local social services.

title: Defendant Admits Extortion In GambinoKidnap Case
description: John E. Kilcullen, a 42yearold bartender, interrupted his trial in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to plead guilty to extortion in the kidnaping of Emanuel Gambino, a nephew of Carlo Gambino, the reputed Mafia leader.

title: Court Backs Con Ed On Storm King Plan
description: The State's Court of Appeals cleared a major barrier for the Storm King power plant yesterday when it upheld in a unanimous ruling the state's decision that the plant would not endanger water quality standards.

title: MICHAEL G. PHIPPS, POLO STAR, WAS 63
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., March 14Michael G. Phipps, one of the outstanding polo players of his day, died of a heart attack last night at his home here. He was 63 years old.

title: Recital
description: The string bass is generally seen traveling in herds, grazing at the edges of the orchestra, but occasionally one breaks away like a rogue elephant and charges off on its own. Such a rebel instrument turned up at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, in the hands of a young virtuoso named Richard Fredrickson.

title: At Purim, They'll Eat Haman's Hat
description: PURDY'S CORNER, N.Y.Hamantaschen are plentiful now in this upper Westchester community, where a motherdaughter team has just finished baking more than a gross of the threecornered pastries in preparation for the Jewish holiday of Purim this Sunday.

title: Season's Series Squared by the Hawks
description: CHICAGO, March 14The New York Rangers got a lesson in how to play hockey in losing to the Black Hawks, 42, at Chicago Stadium tonight and Gene Carr got a lesson in boxing from Keith Magnuson.

title: JACOB S. SIEFMAN
description: SURFSIDE, Fla., March 14Jacob S. Siefman, a certified public accountant and an executive of Stalite Dental Products Company in Hialeah, died today in Mount Sinai Hospital, Miami Beach. He was 69 years old.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: AN EXBROKER OWES $12.5MILLION TAXES
description: A former stock broker, now fugitive from justice, has been notified that he owes the Government more than $12.5million in back taxes.

title: Airlines Authorized to Charge 34 Cents for Hijacking Searches
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized the nation's airlines yesterday to add 34 cents to the cost of each trip to defray the expense of antihijacking airport searches ordered by the White House.

title: Miami Beach Water Supply Declared Safe for Drinking
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 14 (AP)Miami Beach's water supply was declared free of contamination today, and health officials said drinking water need no longer be boiled.

title: Connor, S.I. Borough President, Quits G.O.P. to Run as Democrat
description: Robert T. Connor, Borough President of Staten Island and a lifelong Republican, switched to the Democratic party yesterday, and announced that he would seek its nomination for reelection.

title: Health Food Industry Sues The F.D.A. for $500Million
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)The health food industry has filed a $500million damage suit against the Government, charging that attempts to regulate the business have resulted in abuse, harassment and economic hardship.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: HOUSE BUILDING Last season the Theater Development Fund, which was founded to help commercial theater gain audiences by subsidizing audiences, started a special project to build up houses and coffers of Off Off Broadway Theaters. If you are a union member, student, teacher, clergyman, senior citizen or person involved in certain community activities, you are perhaps eligible to benefit from it.

title: Ban on Striker Aid Sought
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)  The United States Chamber of Commerce urged Congress today to prohibit grants of Government food stamps to strikers. Otto F. Wenzler, labor relations manager for the chamber, told a Senate Agriculture Committee that misuse of the food stamp program by allowing strikers to get stamps had become one of the main threats to the stability of our collective bargaining Process.

title: CATTLE FUTURES CONTINUE TO RISE
Sudan's Leader, Under Pressure, Supported by Army and South
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 14The political threat posed to the regime of Maj. Gen. Gaafar alNimeiry by the guerrilla attack on the Saudi Arabian Embassy and the murder of three diplomats has turned out to be less severe than originally expected.

title: WILLIAM J. M'CABE
description: HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., March 14William J. McCabe, editor and publisher of The Rockland County Times since 1940, died at work this evening, apparently of a heart attack. He was 64 years old and lived here.

title: Arthur Daley
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., March 14Gussie Busch is the contented owner of a contented ball club this year, his 20th as head man of the St. Louis Cardinals. He treated his ballplayers as if each were a Stan Musial, his longtime pet and deservedly so. No one was cut in salary, many were raised and the Redbirds were the first to have all contracts signed.

title: MERGER BILL TO GO TO CONGRESS TODAY
description: A bill that would permit the National and American Basketball Associations to merge and would free players from reserveclause restrictions is to be introduced today in Washington by Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, with the cosponsorship of Senator Marlow Cook, Republican of Kentucky, and Senator Frank Moss, Democrat of Utah.

title: New Air Fee Approved
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized the nation's airlines yesterday to add 34 cents to the cost of each airline flight to defray the cost of airport searches ordered by the White House to deter hijackers. Page 85.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: This Administration, not, I am sure, through either ignorance or stupidity but through a combination of both, is beginning to dismantle one of the glories of postWorld War II American history.

title: Minority Not Invited
description: ASHBY, Mass., March 14 (AP)Yesterday's annual town meeting voted 148 to 79 against inviting members of minority groups into town.

title: CELTICS SUBDUE BULLETS 111107
description: BOSTON, March 14 (AP)John Havlicek scored 4 points in the final 15 seconds tonight and the Boston Celtics clinched a tie for the championship of the National Basketball Association's Atlantic Division with a 111107 victory over the Baltimore Bullets.

title: VETERANS BID CITY MEET THEIR NEEDS
description: A line of Vietnamera veterans, some symbolically clad in castoff military clothing, filed before the City Commission on Human Rights yesterday to relate their experiences with unemployment, a lack of drug rehabilitation and public indifference.

title: People in Sports: Kraft Takes Rhode Island Post
description: Looking for new challenges, Jack Kraft of Villanova accepted a fouryear contract yesterday as basketball coach at the University of Rhode Island.

title: YACHT HITS REEF IN MONTEGO RACE
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 14  The 30foot sloop Delphini became the first casualty of the MiamiMontego Bay yacht race last night when it struck a reef off the northeast point of Cat Island in Bahamian waters.

title: Riese Seeking Schrafft's Units
description: More than 20 of the 35 Schrafft's restaurants, first established in New York in 1906, may be acquired soon by a restaurant organization largely known to the public only through the names of a number of New York restaurants it owns.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 15, 1973

title: Miss Blackburn Captures Junior Title Downhill Race
description: WHITE PASS, Wash., March 14 (UPI)Gail Blackburn, an 18yearold from Brunswick, Me., won the girls' downhill race at the North American junior alpine ski championships today.

title: COUNSEL TO NIXON TELLS SENATE UNIT HE WON'T TESTIFY
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 John W. Dean 3d, President Nixon's chief legal counsel, declined today an invitation to appear before the Senate Judiciary Committee in connection with the nomination of L. Patrick Gray 3d, Mr. Nixon's choice to become director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Books of The Times
description: TO PEKINGAND BEYOND. A Report on the New Asia. By Harrison E. Salisbury. 308 pages. Illustrated. Quadrangle. $7.95.

title: MRS. B. B. ATTERBURY
description: LA MADERA, N.M., March 14Mrs. Ruth Rand Atterbury, wife of Boudinot B. Atterbury, a retired investment banker of New York, died Sunday in an automobile accident in Espanola. She was 78 years old and had homes here and in Manhasset, L. I.

title: STOCKS ARE DOWN ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market finished slightly lower yesterday in slow trading as investors apparently awaited developments in the international monetary crisis.

title: ROBBERY SUSPECT, 13, IS TRIED IN MUGGING
description: BUFFALO, March 14A 13yearold suspect in the armed robbery of a branch bank here went on trial today in Family Court on a separate robbery charge involving a street mugging that netted $11.

title: FRANCIS A. KENNEY
description: Francis A. Kenney, manager of transportation for the Sulphur Export Corporation, an affiliate of Texas Gulf, Inc., died on Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, in So Paulo, Brazil. He was 46 years old and lived in East Brunswick, N. J.

title: Trojans Swallow Frustration on Way to N.L.T.
description: Being No. 2 in the Pacific8 Conference has meant few rewards for Southern California's basketball team.

title: C.W. POST FACULTYMEETS ON DISPUTE
description: GREENVALE, L. I., March 14 Most of the faculty members of the C. W. Post Center of Long Island University suspended classes for three hours today to attend a meeting dealing with problems of salary demands, tenure and productivity.

title: Kuniyoshi Paintings Set Auction Marks
description: A triumphal comeback for American artists in eclipse for and three decades was marked last night in an auction sale offering part of the Edith G. Halpert collection at Sotheby Parke Bernet, 980 Madison Avenue.

title: U.S. OFFSHORE OIL SENT TO MIDWEST
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The Government has begun to allocate some of its own offshore oil, socalled royalty oil, to refiners in the Middle West in an effort to avert a shortage of diesel fuel on the farm. Such a shortage could nudge farm prices upward, officials fear.

title: American Motors Urges Delay on Pollution Rules
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)American Motors, the smallest of the major auto makers, aligned itself today with its bigger competitors in telling the Government it could not meet the 1975 auto pollution standards.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Coach Gravely Hurt in Crash

title: 4 Senators Seek to Oust Head of O.E.O.
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 Four Democratic Senators filed a lawsuit today seeking the removal of Howard J. Phillips as acting director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, contending that he is serving illegaily without Senate confirmation.

title: U.S. HOLDS 9 CUBANS RESCUED FROM BOAT
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 Nine Cubans rescued from sinking Cuban fishing boat are being held in protective and friendly custody in Key West, Fla., by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: NEW HAVEN TEACHERS RETURN TO CLASSES
description: NEW HAVEN, March 14Publicschool teachers in New Haven went back to the classrooms today, suspending their weekandaday walkout to allow negotiations to resume.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 15, 1973

title: New Sergeant Major Of the Army Is Named
description: WASHINGTON, March (AP)Sgt. Maj. Leon L. Autreve was named today become the Army's top noncommissioned officer.

title: George Bell, ExNixon Aide For Nongovernment Units
description: WASHINGTON, March 14George T. Bell, a former special assistant to President Nixon, died last night in his home here following a long illness.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 14On the one side there is Janet Youngholm, a Princeton sophomore, who wants to play men's intercollegiate football at Princeton next fall. She is serious. I love sports. I've never played football but the game has a certain grace and beauty which attract me.

title: Brooklyn G.O.P. Opposes Coalition Race for Wagner
description: Governor Rockefeller's attempt to forge a RepublicanLiberal coalition behind former Mayor Robert F. Wagner ran into a revolt yesterday by the Republican organization in Brooklyn, and as a re sult, the delicate negotiations could be undone.

title: Plan to Speed Abortion Services Urged
description: The president of the Rockefeller Foundation called upon government agencies and the public and private health sector yesterday to share the responsibility of making safe and humane abortions available to women throughout the country regardless of their ability to pay.

title: Metropolitan Appoints a Panel To Review Museum Policies
description: Dodglas Dillon, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said yesterday that the Metropolitan's board of trustees at its meeting on Tuesday had appointed a special committee of its members to review museum policies and procedures.

title: GROCER SHOT DEAD IN QUEENS HOLDUP
description: The owner of a grocery store in Jackson Heights, Queens, was shot to death last night when he tried to resist three holdup men.

title: McGovern Urges Congress To Create Own Budget Unit
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, called on Congress today to create its own Office of Budget and Management.

title: 5to1 Triumph Creates Tie for Third
description: Struggling for a berth in the World Hockey Association playoffs, the Raiders struck early and late last night for a 51 rout over the Houston Aeros.

title: 500 Differ Sharply On Yorkville Plans And School Needs
description: Some 500 residents of Yorkville disagreed sharply and loudly at a public hearing last night over proposals for the construction of housing, park land and schools on a fiveacre plot at 90th Street and the East River.

title: Boy, 7, Is Reunited With Jersey Foster Family, Ending a Court Battle Over Custody
description: There were smiles and hugs and a few tears  as Jerry Pectle was reunited yesterday with the the foster family that had cared for him for five of his seven years.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: 5% of Food Concerns Fail Inspection

title: Coffee Sees Democratic Defeat If One of His Rivals Is Nominated
description: TRENTON, March 14 Richard J. Coffee declared here this eveningthat the nomination of any of his major opponents for Governor could be a disaster for the Democratic party in the November elections.

title: WIDOW MAY SUCCEED BERMUDA GOVERNOR
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 14 (Reuters)The Bermuda government will ask Britain to appoint Lady Sharpies as governor of this colony to replace her husband Sir Richard Sharpies, who was shot to death Saturday, according to reliable sources close to the Bermuda cabinet.

title: Merrill Lynch and 2 Others Plan Holding Companies
description: Three major brokerage concerns announced plans yesterday to form holding companies in the first moves of this kind for member firms of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Frick Planning to Raze Widener Town House
description: The Frick Collection, one of the country's most distinguished art museums, is planning to tear down an adjoining Louis XVstyle town house on East 70th Street despite the protests of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: M'ME URGES DELAY IN MRS. FARKAS VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)confirmation of Mrs. George L. Farkas as Ambassador to Luxembourg encountered a snag today when Senator Gale McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, called for a delay by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in voting on the nomination.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The ElectroOptical division of the Kollmorgen Cbrporation has been awarded a $17.8million contract by the Naval Ship Systems Command for the production of submarine periscope systems, the company announced yesterday.

title: 102 Youth Corps Camps To Be Open This Summer
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The Department of the Interior and the Department of Agriculture announced plans today to operate 102 Youth Conservation Corps camps this summer.

title: Advertising: A Show in Moscow
description: Some 6,000 chief executives of companies that manufacture medical electronics and medical equipment will soon be receiving invitations to exhibit at a Moscow trade show in September.

title: NoiseControl Laws Are Urged for State
description: TRENTON, March 14  The state was urged today to begin immediately to draw up regulations fixing acceptable levels of noise for industry, transportation and other sources of sound pollution.

title: Foster Boy, 7, Is Reunited With a Happy Mancuso Family
description: There were smiles and hugsand a few tearsas Jerry Pectle was reunited yesterday with the foster family that had cared for him for five of his seven years.

title: METS ARE VICTORS OVER TIGERS AGAIN
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14The New York Mets broke a fourgame losing streak today with a 64 victory over the Detroit Tigers, the only team they have beaten in the first week of springtime exhibition games.

title: RIGHTS PLAN FOES CALLED DEVIOUS
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The chief Congressional sponsor of the equal rights amendment to the Constitution said today that opponents of the amendment were trying to use their opposition as a means of building a rightwing political organization among women.

title: Leary Trial Under Way
description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., March 14 (UPI)Testimony began today in the trial of Timothy Leary on charges of escaping from prison after a jury of 11 women and one man was selected. The first witness for the state was Lee Hansen, records officer at the California Men's Colony prison near here, who testified that Leary was brought to the facility March 18, 1970, and disappeared the following Sept. 12.

title: Goldin Again Enters Race For Controller Nomination
description: A sixcandidate field shaped up yesterday for the Democratic nomination for City Controller, a job more powerful than its unromantic public image might suggest.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Dancers to Honor Dorothy Alexander

title: FACULTY ASSAILS RIDER PRESIDENT
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, March 14 (AP)The faculty of Rider College voted today to censure the college president, Frank Elliott, in a strongly worded statement expressing a lack of confidence in the Elliott administration.

title: Court Backs Con Ed On Storm King Plan
description: The State's Court of Appeals cleared a major barrier for the Storm King power Plant yesterday when it upheld in a unanimous ruling the state's decision that the plant would not endanger water quality standards.

title: Suharto Agrees to Serve A 2d Term in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 14 (UPI)  President Suharto accepted nomination today to serve as President for a second term and agreed to the nomination of the Sultan of Jogjakarta, Hamengkubuwono, as vice president.

title: HEARINGS OPEN ON NEW CENTER
description: In a session that ran well into the night, the City Planning Commission heard testimony yesterday for and against the convention center scheduled for the Hudson River waterfront between 43d and 47th Streets.

title: CHARGES TRIMMED IN RAP BROWN CASE
description: As the H. Rap Brown trial ended its ninth week yesterday, State Supreme Court Justice Arnold G. Fraiman threw out several sections of the 24count indictment against the black militant and three codefendants.

title: Trenton Community Paper Is Upheld Against Charge It Is Public Nuisance
description: TRENTON, March 15  A city magistrate dismissed disorderly charges against a small, labororiented community newspaper here today, declaring that the paper's constitutional right to a free press overrode police charges that its distribution on the streets was a public nuisance.fendants were represented by Albert Barklay Jr. of Princeton, a volunteer lawyer connected with the New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 16, 1973

title: 7 IN CHINATOWN HEED IN EXTORTION
description: Seven members of what the police called a youthful Chinese extortion gang were taken into custody yesterday by policemen n a stakeout as they allegedly accepted money from one of their victims.

title: SANTA SUSANA STAKE WON BY BELLE MARIE
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 15 (UPI)Belle Marie, the evenmoney favorite, won the $54,300 Santa Susana stakes by five lengths over Tallahto today at Santa Anita.

title: Red Smith
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 15The men who hammered out baseball's threeyear peace treaty put too much time and effort into the job to let one man's arrogance and another's stupidity ruin it all. Otherwise, Leo Durocher, the practically peerless leader of the Houston Astros, and Spec Richardson, the Houston general manager, might be taking bows for one of the clumsiest efforts at sabotage this side of Watergate. As soon as Chub Feeney, the National League president, heard about it, he slapped a $250 fine on Durocher, who was last heard screaming that he would quit baseball sooner than pay up, Jimmy the Greek's odds on this one are not immediately available, but anybody who wants to bet on Leo can get action here.

title: The Screen
description: Mark Twain's The Adventures of Tom Sawyer is not the great American novel that The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn is, but it is the great American book for boys, especially those who grow up in a rural Middle West where one has to manufacture the kind of local history and folklore that boys in the East, South and Far West take for granted.

title: One Killed and 24 Injured In a Crash on the L.I.R.R.
description: LAKE RONKONKOMA, L.I., March 15One woman was killed tonight and 24 people were injured, three of them critically, when a Long Island passenger train smashed into a halted freight train here shortlybefore 9 P.M.

title: JERSEY MAY GET POWER RATIONING
description: TRENTON, March 15New Jersey homeowners, businesses and industries face the rationing of electric power within three years unless some method of controlling demand or increasing energy sources is found, according to William E. Ozzard, president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

title: Kitty Hawk Sailor Fined
description: SAN DIEGO, March 15 (AP)  Seaman Apprentice John L. Rowe, convicted of assault and rioting aboard the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk, has been fined $700 and reduced one pay grade. A fiveman courtmartial board rejected yesterday the urging of Navy prosecutors that he be given a brig sentence and a badconduct discharge.

title: KOOSMAN STRONG IN 5INNING STINT
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., March 15 Jerry Koosman continued his comeback bid for a spot in the Mets' starting rotation today by pitching five strong innings against the Dodgers and starting a fourrun fifth inning that enabled him to gain credit for a 65 victory.

title: Miller's 6UnderPar 66Leads Golf by a Stroke
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 15 (AP)Johnny Miller conquered the pressure of playing head to head with Jack Nicklaus, scored a sixunderpar 66 and took the firstround lead today in the $130,000 Greater Jacksonville open golf tournament.

title: Out of Monetary Crisis, a Revived European Emphasis on Unity
description: PARIS, March 15Although problems of fundamental importance remain, the recently renewed monetary crisis has provoked tangible changes in European and Atlantic relations. It seems to have been a turning point.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in EasternStandard Time

title: WAGNER PLEDGE A YES OR NO SOON
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner promised yesterday to announce no later than early next week whether he would run for his old office this year on the Republican and Liberal linesand dropped a hint that he would insist on his own terms.

title: TAIPEI RESTRAINS 2 CAMPUS GROUPS
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 15Government officials say that the army's security agency has uncovered small secret organizations sympathetic to the Chinese Communists on two university campuses.

title: Canadian Official Is in Saigon to Assess Truce Group
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 15The Canadian Minister of External Affairs, Mitchell W. Sharp, arrived today on the first leg of an inspection trip to decide whether Canada should continue participation in the International Commission of Control and Supervision, the fournation body charged with keeping the peace in Vietnam.

title: A Vietcong General Assesses U.S. Soldier
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 15  Lieut. Gen Tran Van Tra, the chief Vietcong delegate to the truce commission, said tonight that Americans were good soldiers, but they fought the wrong war.

title: Yale Seen as out of Bounds, So Giants Try Princeton
description: Continuing a frustrating search for a place to play their home games this season and next, the Giants have stepped up negotiations with Princeton University for possible use of Palmer Stadium because television and political problems have all but eliminated Yale University's Yale Bowl. Princeton, however, appears to be a reluctant possible landlord.

title: REPORT TO THE PEOPLE OF NEW YORK CITY AND WESTCHESTER COUNTY
description: For Con Edison 1973 is a milestone. It is the 150th anniversary of the founding of our corporate ancestor, the New York Gas Light Co., which in 1823 was chartered to provide gas service to lower Manhattan.

title: INDIA ENDS IMPORT OF U.S. SORGHUM
description: NEW DELHI, March 15 India has stopped further purchases of sorghum grain from the United States because of the sad experience in which poisonous seeds were found in a shipment of the grain, an official of the Food Ministry said here today.

title: Music
description: Your average disk jockey, With the endless circle of programing the same top 40 hit recordings that marks much of today's radio music, is probably suffering some kind of identity crisis, reduced as he is to a disembodied voice relating time, temperature and traffic conditions in the Holland Tunnel. His aim is to achieve glamour statusmove up the rungs and be called an air personality.

title: State May Have to Impose Restrictions on Use of Cars
description: TRENTON, March 15New Jersey may have to impose restrictions on automobile use unless it revises its proposed automotive pollution levels to meet standards required by the Federal Government by 1975, Federal and state environmental officials warned today.

title: GEORGE SCHOETTLE
description: George H. Schoettle, who had been a teacher of music in the pity school system for 50 years at his retirement in 1958, died Wednesday at his home, 134.02 59th Avenue in Flushing, Queens. He was 84 years old.

title: $2.2Billion Approved for Capital Projects in City
description: The City Council and the Board of Estimate yesterday passed a record $2.24billion capital budget for 197374 and Mayor Lindsay immediately approved it.

title: IceSkating Rinks to Close
description: The city's five outdoor iceskating rinks will close for the season on Sunday. The rinks are the Mullaly in Mullaly Park, the Bronx, the Prospect Park, Brooklyn, and the Staten Island War Memorial in Clove Lakes Park.

title: Department Trial of Prison Aide Opens
description: A Correction Department guard captain went on departmental trial yesterday on charges stemming from an investigation into the alleged sale of paroles to inmates at Rikers Island.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Fliptop Hazard
description: The Adolph CoorsBrewing Company of Golden, Colo., may soon lay to rest the ubiquitous and environmentally hazardous fliptop of a beverage can.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Mrs. N. C. Wyeth, 86, Dead; Widow, Mother of Artists
description: CHADDS FORD, Pa., March 15 (AP)Carolyn Bockius Wyeth, widow of the artist N. C. Wyeth and mother of Andrew Wyeth, one of America's best known painters, died today of a heart attack. She was 86 years old.

title: 2 Youths Hurl Paint At Soviet Envoy Here
description: Two youths splattered a Soviet diplomat with red paint last night as was walking on East 72d Street, the police said. They added that the diplomat was uninjured, He was identified as Germon Kosenkov, second secretary to the Soviet Mission at the United Nations.

title: Vietnam Aid
description: Neither those who favor it nor those who oppose yet know precisely what postwar aid to Indochina means. The Nixon Administration is hesitating to make any public proposals until it determines whether the terms of the ceasefire are going to become effective, and certainly until after all the American prisoners of war are safely out of North Vietnamese custody. But the forces of public opinion are already at work on Congress, in the form of mail by the truckload, and each elected representative will soon face some tricky decisions.

title: DASH TO HIGHLIGHT 11. S.SOVIET MEET
description: The United States and the Soviet Union will stage their second annual indoor track and field meet tonight in the Richmond Coliseum.

title: Massachusetts Jail Guards Balk
description: WALPOLE, Mass., March 15 About 120 guards assigned to the morning and afternoon shifts at the state's maximum security prison here refused to work today and were suspended for five days without pay.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on March 15 were:

title: NIXON SUGGESTS HIGHCOURT RULING ON REFUSING DATA
description: WASHINGTON, March 15President Nixon suggested today at a news conference that the time may have come for the Supreme Court to decide the extent of a President's right to withhold information from Congress.

title: Friars, Maryland Gain Eastern Final
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., March 15 Providence and Maryland exploited the fast break for short spurts to beat Pennsylvania and Syracuse, respectively, tonight and move to the East Regional final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: The Convention Center
description: The proposed Convention Center is the key to one the most potentially dynamic development areas of Manhattan: the midtown West Side.

title: Capitalism, for Better or Worse
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.A naive simplistic view of the internal social struggles shaping the emergence of small Asiatic country from its colonial past caused the United States to pay a colossal price in treasure, human lives and immoral standing throughout the civilized world.
