Now, an equally simplistic view of conflicting forces that constantly shape and reshape our own society prompts the Nixon Administration to embark on a program of domestic policies for which this country will have to pay a still higher price in diminished material wellbeing, retarded social progress and waning selfrespect.

title: Publisher of Times Intervenes In Subpoena of Reporter's Files
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 The New York Times, through its publisher, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, has asserted ownership of the notes and files of one of its reporters, subpoenaed by the Committee for the Reelection of the President.

title: Ulster Opposition Protests the Arrest Of One of Its Aides
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 15  An Opposition member of the deactivated Northern Ireland Parliament, Patrick O'Hanlon, 28 years old, was arrested by the British Army in Newry today and accused of throwing stones at soldiers.

title: HOUSE PANEL TOLD OF MUSEUM WOES
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Officials of the Smithsonian Institution told a House Appropriations subcommittee today that construction claims against the controversial Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden might increase the cost of the building by $4.6million.

title: Little AllAmerica
description: FIRST TEAM

title: Schumann and Pleven Quit
description: PARIS, March 15 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann and Justice Minister Ren Pleven today resigned from the French government following their loss of their parliamentary seats in Sunday's runoff election.

title: CORPORATE PROFITS SHOW AN INCREASE
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (Reuters)Pretax book profits of corporations rose $6.2billion in the fourth quarter of 1972 to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $101.9billion, the commerce Department reported today.

title: Two More Bodies Found
description: BAILEY'S CROSSROADS, Va., March 15 (UPI)  Workers found two more bodies today in the wreckage caused two weeks ago when a giant crane fell on a high rise building and demolished it. The death toll is now 10.

title: LINDSAY DEFENDS 8 YEARS IN OFFICE
description: In his first appearance in Harlem since he announced last Wednesday that he would not seek reelection, Mayor Lindsay told a meeting of 200 that he wished he had done more during his eight years in office but that the housing, education and crime situations were better than they were before he took office.

title: Ethyl Corp. Seeks 2 Million Shares Of Bangor Punta
description: The Bangor Punta Corporation, a diversified holding company, announced yesterday that it had received an offer from the Ethyl Corporation to purchase 2 million shares of Bangor Punta's newly issued common stock at $15.50 a share, for a total consideration of $31million. David W. Wallace, president and chief executive officer of Bangor Punta, said a meeting of Bangor Punta's board was scheduled for early next week to consider the offer. Mr. Wallace added that he favored the offer since it would infuse new equity capital into the company.

title: Actress Sues Playboy
description: LOS ANGELES, March 15 (AP)  Joey Heatherton, the actress, has sued Playboy magazine for $2million, charging that the publication invaded her privacy and unlawfully used a photograph showing her partly nude. She said that the photo, appeared in last December's issue and was from a shot in the motion picture Bluebeard.

title: GRIVAS MEN ATTACK CYPRUS POLICE POSTS
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 5 (AP)  The guerrilla underground ended a fiveweek truce during the night, blowing up two police stations and throwing bombs at the homes of seven policemen.

title: One Killed and 26 Injured In a Crash on the L. I. R. R.
description: LAKE RONKONKOMA, L.I., March 15 One woman was killed and at least 26 persons injured, one critically, as a fourcar Long Island Rail Road passenger train overshot the station here and smashed into parked freight locomotive in staging yard.

title: Panama's Chief Denounces U.S. and Warns of Violent Changes
description: PANAMA, March 15  Panama today denounced the United States presence in the Canal Zone as neocolonialism and warned that if peaceful change was not permitted in Latin America, Latins would be forced to carry out violent changes.

title: Plan Evokes Amusement, Nervousness and Anger Among Traders
description: President Nixon's stated intention to sell a part of the nation's stockpiles of strategic commodities evoked amusement in the cash metals market, nervousness among speculators in materials for future delivery and anger among producers of the affected items.

title: JAPAN'S ASIA PLAN IS MERELY AN IDEA
description: TOKYO, March 15The official spokesman for Japan's Foreign Ministry said today that a proposal by Premier Kakuei Tanaka for a new Asian peace organization was a suggestion without any substance behind it yet.

title: Parade on 5th Ave. Set For Vietnam Veterans
description: A parade on Fifth Avenue to honor veterans of the Vietnam war will be held Saturday, March 31, it was announced yesterday by the Home With Honor Committee, which is sponsoring the event.

title: STATE TAKEOVER OF OFFTRACK BETS IS URGED IN STUDY
description: A study group appointed by Governor Rockefeller recommended yesterday that the state take over and sharply limit the activities of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation on the ground that OTB may kill the horse racing industry in the state.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Antitrust Suit Names 3 Automakers

title: U.S. Dollar Weakens Nestle Role Seen
description: PARIS, March 15The dollar weakened today after strengthening earlier in the week, but the reason had less to do with the international monetary crisis than with a single company's need for dollars.

title: SHIVER DISCLOSES 66 POVERTY PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI)Sargent Shriver made public today a plan for ending poverty in the United States that he said he had given to President Johnson in 1966. Mr. Shriver said the plan had become a casualty of the war in Vietnam.

title: U.S. Plane Picks Up 32 Prisoners From Vietcong
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Friday, March 16 (AP)A United States Air Force hospital plane took off from Hanoi today with 32 American prisoners of war freed by the Vietcong.

title: President Reported Planning to Bolster Swaps, or Currency Borrowings
description: BONN, March 15West German Chancellor Willy Brandt disclosed today that President Nixon had told him the United States would contribute to an international compromise to support the dollar.

title: Graebner Upset in Final At National Indoor Net
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., March 15 (AP)  Jurgen Fassbender dropped the first set 46, but stormed back to take the next two sets, 61, 64, against Clark Graebner to win the $3,000 singles prize in the National Indoor open tennis championships.

title: 2 Jordanians Are Arrested In France With Explosives
description: LYONS, France, March 15 (AP)The French police arrested two men with, Jordanian passports today in a car with 35 pounds of plastic explosive. The two were quoted as saying they were on their way for bomb attack on the Jordanian Embassy.

title: The AmuckRunners
description: JERUSALEMThe executioners of Khartoum are of the same mental make as the assassins in the streets of Belfast. They are not alone in the world. They are part of the new international amuckrunners disguised as freedomfighters, presented by perverted publicity as glamorous guerrillas, idolized by a disoriented community of alienated adolescents.

title: Executives on Tour Revise View And Report Favorably on City
description: A group of top executives from television, radio and outofstate newspapers ended a whirlwind tour of city officials and agencies yesterday, sitting around a table in Gracie Mansion and conveying favorable comments to the Mayor.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: AUDIO WITH VISION Radio station WBAI is going to capitalize on television this weekend. The listening medium is harnessing the looking medium for a video benefit to raise funds for WBAI. The benefit, at Automation House, 49 East 68th Street, will fill the building's three floors with a plethora of videotape equipment, shows and artists for three days. It starts tonight, from 8 to 10, and continues tomorrow and Sunday from noon to 10.

title: Notes on People
description: The Soviet Union has urged that the Nobel Peace Prize be given to President Tito of Yugoslavia. An article in Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, said the chairman of the Soviet Peace Committee, Nikolai Tikhonov, has written to the Nobel Committee, endorsing Western European support for the Yugoslav President.

title: STATE ACTS TO SHUT METHADONE CLINIC
description: A methadone maintenance clinic has changed a peaceful and highly respectable Yorkville neighborhood into a community of fear, according to Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: MET AND LOUVRE PURCHASE IVORY
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art signed a contract yesterday with the Louvre in Paris for the purchase of a medieval ivory comb. The purchase is believed to mark the first time in history that two of the world's greatest museums have bought a work of art for joint ownership.

title: STATE TAKEOVER OF OFFTRACK BETS IS URGED IN STUDY
description: A study group appointed by Governor Rockefeller recommended yesterday that the state take over and sharply limit the activities of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation on the ground that OTB may kill the horse racing industry in the state.

title: JACKSON PRESSES FOR SOVIET SHIFT
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Senator Henry M. Jackson, supported by 73 other Senators, today reopened a Congressional drive to block a trade agreement with the Soviet Union until Moscow reduces its exit fees so that Jews and others can freely emigrate.

title: St. Louis and the Future of a Famed Railroad Terminal
description: ST. LOUIS, March 15The late Irvin S. Cobb is said to have described Union Station of St. Louis as one of the two ugliest structures created by man, the other being the derby hat.

title: Dr. Jan Librach, 69, Dies; Led Polish Arts Institute
description: Dr. Jan Librach, executive director of the Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences in America, author and former Polish diplomat, died Wednesday at his home here. His age was 69.

title: New Face for Racing
description: The Delafield Commission report issued yesterday doesn't promise any winners for New York's horseplayers, but it does promise them a pew deal. After years of legislative indifference, neglect and contempt, ontrack handicappers may benefit from the respectful backtothe  track message contained in the report. Better (and less expensive) days appear in store for those who find the intriguefilled dream world of the racetrack a pleasant way to relax. This means doctors and lawyers and scholars and pensioners and business people, as well as the socalled dregs of society sometimes associated with horseplaying.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Fulbright's Panel, Too, Seeks Dean Testimony
description: WASHINGTON. March 15John W. Dean 3d, the White House legal counsel who declined yesterday to appear before the Senate Judiciary Committee, has also been invited to testily before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. But the reasons for the two invitations appear to be opposite.

title: San Juan Freight Comes In
description: WESTBURY, L. I., March 15 San Juan Freight, driven by George Phalen, led from the start tonight and posted a 1length triumph over Chester Great in the featured $6,000 trot at Roosevelt Raceway. He returned $16.20, $5.40 and $3.20 for $2 across the board.

title: INDIANA TOPPLES MARQUETTE, 7569
description: NASHVILLE, March 15 (AP) Indiana, sparked by Steve Downing and John Ritter, defeated Marquette, 7569, tonight and advanced to the final of the National Collegiate Mideast Regional basketball tournament.

title: Chief of S.E.C.Asks Changesfor Public
description: The new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday called for important changes in the operations of the nation's stock exchanges to provide better investment opportunities for the public.

title: PRESIDENT WARNS HANOI NOT TO MOVE EQUIPMENT SOUTH
description: WASHINGTON, March 15President Nixon voiced concern today about the movement of North Vietnamese militaiy equipment toward South Vietnam and said Hanoi should not lightly disregard his words.

title: Women's Rights Amendment Wins Connecticut Ratification
description: HARTFORD, March 15The Connecticut Senate, which never got to a vote on the women's rights Constitutional amendment last year because the House rejected the proposal, ratified the amendment today, 27 to 9.

title: The Screen
description: Satyajit Ray's Days and Nights, in the Forest began a commercial engagement yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room, at 60th Street. The Indianmade import was previously shown here once as an entry in the New York Film Festival in 1970. A review by Howard Thompson deemed the feature a rare, wistful movie that somehow proves it's good to be alive.

title: Report Defends G.M. Officials In Testimony on Corvair Safety
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff released today a study of one facet of the Corvair controversy concluding that General Motors Executives had not misled a Congressional investigation in 1966 as Ralph Nader had charged.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Manette van Hamel is a happy woman these days. Her husband, Diederik, retired last fall as the Netherlands Consul General in New York and that means she finally has found enough time to devote to her sculpturetowear jewelry.

title: Dispute Blocks Delivery Of Times in Boston Area
description: BOSTON, March 15 (AP)News Distributors, Inc., and Local 259 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters signed tonight a new contract that cleared the way for regular delivery of The New York Times and The Christian Science Monitor in the Boston area, a spokesman for the distributor said.

title: BOSTON MUSEUM NAMES DIRECTOR
description: BOSTON, March 15The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston today formally announced the appointment of Merrill C. Rueppel as its new director. Mr. Rueppel, who is 47 years old, is director of the Dallas Museum of Fine Arts.

title: Looking Up Down Under
description: SYDNEY, Australia  During its brief history Australia swung from total dependence on Britain to heavy reliance on America. Now it is starting an experiment with independent nationalism. But it is less likely than imagined by some enthusiasts that pseudoisolationist move can long endure for, from its birth, this country has been sharply influenced by faroff events.

title: President Rejects Curbs On Prices Paid Farmers
description: WASHINGTON, March 15President Nixon emphatically rejected today the idea of putting controls on prices paid to farmers for their products, including meat.

title: Elliott Roosevelt's Book Is Disavowed by Family
description: Four children of Franklin D. Roosevelt, in a statement made public yesterday, disassociated themselves completely from a book written by their brother, Elliott Roosevelt, which says that their father was intimate with a secretary, Marguerite (Missy) LeHand when he was married to Eleanor Roosevelt.

title: Treasury Investigates Possible Lead Dumping
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 The Government disclosed today another example of the ancient saying that the left hand knoweth not what the right hand is doing.

title: Dow Down by 9.03 Points; Trading Relatively Light
description: A spate of selling moved into the stock market yesterday and sent prices tumbling in relatively light trading.

title: Toll in Mekong Pagoda Blast Put at 17 Dead, 80 Hurt
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 15 (AP)A predawn service in a Buddhist pagoda in the Mekong Delta was shattered today by a series of explosions that killed at least 17 people and wounded more than 80.

title: Rivera Back at WABC After Censorship Dispute
description: Geraldo Rivera, the lawyerturnednewsman who has attained star status in local television, returned to WABCTV's nightly Eyewitness News show last night after the settlement of what he called a censorship dispute with his employers.

title: Fireman Builds Better Lock Opener But Board Slams Door on Sale to City
description: A 36yearold Fire Department lieutenant who invented a device that can open most locked doors within a minute, and who has sold his device to more than 100 cities, cannot sell it to New York City because he is a city employe.

title: Books of The Times
description: WE HAVE ALL GONE AWAY. By Curtis Harnack. 188 pages. Doubleday. $6.95.

title: $1.5Billion Given Colleges
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI)  Four million gifts by private individuals and groups raised $1.5billion for 1,080 United States colleges and universities during 197071, the American Council on Education said today.

title: $500,000 to Be Given N.Y.U. Medical Center
description: More than half a million dollars was raised for the New York University Medical Center last night at a dinner at which the hosts were Mrs. Arthur D. Leidesdorf, who was Miss Israel in 1960, and Dr. James M. Hester, president of N.Y.U.

title: ELISBERG TRIAL HEARS SORENSEN
description: LOS ANGELES, March 15Theodore C. Sorensen, counsel to former President Kennedy, told the Pentagon papers trial today that when he left the White House he took with him many Government documents.The implication was that he then used those documents as material for the books he wrote about the Kennedy years and for articles he wrote on foreign affairs.

title: Sullivan on Broadway
description: Ed Sullivan's Broadway is a flashy, splintery tribute to both Mr. Sullivan and Broadway, due for beaming at 8:30 tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, MARCH 16, 1973
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Strip Mine Damage Attributed to Lack of Planning
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Spokesmen for environmental protection groups told the Senate Interior Committee today that the strip mining of coal in the United States, which a Govemment study has estimated is damaging 4,650 acres a week, would not have become a problem if there had been proper planning.

title: Excerpts From Racing Report
description: Following are some of the major extracts from text of Delafield Commission report.

title: Five Years Later, My Lai Is a No Man's Town, Silent and Unsafe
description: MY LAI 4, South Vietnam, March 15 (AP)This no man's town is too quiet.

title: Government Maintains Silence on DetailsSqueals Expected
description: WASHINGTON, March 15President Nixon said today he had determined that it will be safe for the United States to very substantially reduce the Government's stockpiles of metals and other supposedly strategic materials and added that we are going to go forward and do that.

title: Women's Rights Amendment Wins Connecticut Ratification
description: HARTFORD, March 15The Connecticut Senate, which never got to a vote on the women's rights Constitutional amendment last year because the House rejected the proposal, ratified the amendment today, 27 to 9.

title: Cambodia Says Her Troops Gain South of Capital
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 15 (Reuters)The Cambodian command announced today that Government forces had managed to push the front line south of the capital to a point 18 miles from the city.

title: Bar Group Appoints a Panel To Study News Shield Laws
description: CHICAGO, March 15 (AP)The American Bar Association has appointed a panel to study newsmen's shield laws and to consider its policy on the issue.

title: LABOR WANTS UNIT ON INDUSTRY KEPT
description: ALBANY, March 15Representatives of business and labor sharply criticized today the Governor's proposal to abolish the State Board of Standards and Appeals and empower the State Industrial Commissioner to promulgate and enforce safe ty and health standards for industry.

title: 2 SEIZED IN BRONX IN NIGHT ATTACKS
description: The Bronx police arrested two men last night who they said had terrorized as many as 15 households in the Sounndview area over the last five months in predawn burglaries.

title: Sea Bird, Leading Sire, Dies at French Stud Farm
description: ALENCON, Prance, March 15 (AP)Sea Bird, who swept the 1965 horse racing season in Europe with victories in the Epsom Derby and Prix de l'Are de Triomphe and went on to become a leading sire, died of an intestinal blockage at a stud farm in Western France today.

title: Equity Financing
description: Multimedia, Inc., said yesterday it intends to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of 500,000 shares of its common stock, of which 100,000 shares will be sold by the company and the remainder by present stockholders.

title: The Gentleman From Virginia
description: It seldom happens in these hairy youthful days that anybody chooses a wise old gentleman for a critical job, but President Nixon has done it again by picking David Kirkpatrick Este Bruce of Virginia to be the first official U.S. representative to the Communist Government of China.

title: BISHOP FEDDERS, 59, SERVED PERU INDIANS
description: The Most Rev. Edward L. Fedders, a Maryknoil missioner from Covington, Ky., died of a heart attack Sunday as he conducted mass in Pomata, a small community in the Juli prelature of Peru. He was 59 years old and had served in Peru for 29 years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your March 3 issue President Nixon is reported as comparing opposition to American reconstruction assistance to Hanoi with postWorld War II opposition to aid to Germany and Japan, while Flora Lewis gives reasons for Hanoi's ruling out an inters nationalized aid mechanism.

title: Sandman Repeats Opposition to Oil Port in Ocean
description: TRENTON, March 15Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., in an attempt to clarify an earlier statement, repeated his opposition today to the construction of a deep water oil port proposed by the Army Corps of Engineers off the New Jersey coast.

title: Supreme Court Studies Key Environment Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 Lower Federal courts have had many cases involving the threeyearold National Environmental Policy Act. Now case that has reached the Su preme Court bears on two is sues so important that the outcome could decide the future effectiveness of the act.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Westchester Democrats Top Slate With DelBello
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 15Westchester County Democrats tonight designated Mayor Alfred B. DelBello of Yonkers to run for County Executive.

title: F.B.I. Agent Slain in Battle With Bank Theft Suspect
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 15 (UPI)An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation pursued a suspected bank robber and his girlfriend into an apartment complex today and was mortally wounded in a gunfight.

title: Senate Democrats Call on Nixon To Cut Back Troops Overseas
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Senate Democrats today overwhelmingly approved a resolution urging. President Nixon to bring home many of the 600,000 United States servicemen stationed around the world.

title: Index of Commodity Prices Shows Increase for Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 148.9 from 148.4 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 114.2 on March 14, 1972.

title: Manila Reports Foreign Aid to Rebels
description: MANILA, Friday, March 16The Philippines has notified its allies in the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations that the renewed Moslem rebellion in its southern island of Mindanao is being assisted by foreigntrained troops bearing foreignmade arms.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: Las Vegas, Nev.  Lonnie Bennett, 180 pounds, Los Angeles, knocked out Fred Wallace, 180, Dallas, 1 round.

title: David Bruce, 75, Selected To Head Office in Peking
description: WASHINGTON, March 15President Nixon announced today that he had recalled Ambassador David K. E. Bruce from retirement to head a United States liaison office in Peking.

title: Meager Snowfall in the City Yields Budget Windfall
description: The unusually mild winter has proved to be a windfall for the government officials who pay the bills for snow removal. But for skiers and the people who sell ski equipment, it has been a disaster.

title: Stuffed Bass Dish For Weekend Chef
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: BASIC TAX SHIFTS LOOM FOR BANKS
description: WASHINGTON, March 15A radically altered system for taxing commercial banks, savings banks and savings and loan associations is undergoing final review by top Administration policymakers before being proposed to Congress, probably in a few weeks.

title: Man Killed in Tornado
description: NASHVILLE, March 15 (AP)  One man was killed and three persons were injured when a tornado raked across the northern section of White County in Eastern Tennessee early today. Most of the state was hit by severe thunderstorms and heavy rains. Power lines wer reported down, one school system was closed and homes in lowlying areas were flooded.

title: U.S. and Soviet Blamed For Lagging Arms Talks
description: GENEVA, March 15Eight nonaligned members of the disarmament conference here protested sharply today to the United States and the Soviet Union over the absence of tangible progress.

title: Records
description: Dacapo, a branch of the German Electrola label, has come forth recently with a threerecord set of Bruno Walter's Mozart performances from the nineteenthirties (IC14750178/80M, $17.94). The price is a bit steep, espedaily when compared with such domestic reissue labels as Seraphim, Odyssey and Victrola, and it is all the higher now that import distributors have been forced by the dollar's devaluation to raise their prices.

title: Cahill's MassTransit Bill To Be Introduced Monday
description: TRENTON, March 15Governor Cahill's bill that would create, a New Jersey Transit Authority empowered to use surplus tollroad revenues for masstransportation programs will be introduced when the Legislature returns Monday.

title: Halpert Art Collection Brings $3.6Million
description: The auction of the personal and gallery collection of American paintings and sculpture of the late Edith G. Halpert ended yesterday with receipts of $3,670,675, a total that has art dealers and collectors agog over the prospect of a significant new market in several decades of American art following World War I.

title: A LIE IS ADMITTED IN YABLONSKI CASE
description: ERIE, Pa., March 15 (AP)The prosecution began calling union organizers and pensioned miners to the stand today in an attempt to link the United Mine Workers and the defeated union president, W. A. Boyle, to what the prosecution contends was payoff money for the Yablonski murders.

title: Scribner Names Aide As Interim Chancellor
description: Dr. Harvey B. Scribner has designated Deputy Chancellor Irving Anker to be Acting Chancellor of the city school system when he begins his forced vacation on April 1.

title: Cardinal Fights Abortions
description: ST. LOUIS, March 15, (AP)John Cardinal Carberry, Archbishop of St. Louis, pledged $20,000 yesterday in support of a fight against liberalized abortion laws, Cardinal Carberry announced the contribution at an organization meeting of the Archdiocesan Pro Life Committee.

title: Island Paradise
description: The sedate and prosperous British colony of Bermuda, sunlit islands in the Atlantic favored by nature, tourists and wealthy expatriates, is one of the last places in the world that one might expect the kind of mad political violence that has afflicted much of the rest of mankind lately.

title: Iraqi Linked to Black September Is Sought in BombPlanting Here
description: A Federal warrant was issued yesterday for a 27yearold citizen of Iraq suspected of being a member of the Black September terrorist organization and charged with planting a bomb in an automobile parked next to the El Al Israeli Airlines terminal warehouse at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Heinz Ullstein Dies at 80; German Book Publisher
description: BERLIN, March 15 (UPI)Heinz Ullstein, a member of the third generation of Germany's Ullstein bookpublishing family, died today after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Bache Profits in Sharp Decline; Inflationary Pressures Cited
description: Bache & Co., Inc., citing tremendous inflationary pressures on its business, reported yesterday a substantial profit decline for its latest fiscal year.

title: Envoy to Peking
description: I thought it was very important to appoint a man of great stature to this position, President Nixon said yesterday, explaining why he had picked David K. E. Bruce to head the first United States liaison mission to Peking. The words underlined and confirmed the general conclusion reached earlier when it was reported that Henry kissinger and Premier Chou Enlai had agreed to exchange personnel: in effect, the United States and the Chinese Peoples' Republic are resuming diplomatic relations in all but the most formal sense. Mr. Bruce will be except for a few legalismsthe first United States Ambassador to Mao Tsetung's China.

title: Show Marks Hirschfeld's 50 Years at Drawing Board
description: He sits and swivels, cranks himself higher and lower, sometimes even lowers the back rest and reclines. In an old barber chair transported to the top floor of his brownstone, Al Hirschfeld is master of all he surveys on 95th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Of the 348 teams that started play in the New Jersey high school basketball tournament, only 14 remaineight public school teams and six parochial school squads.

title: Eight May Face CourtsMartial For Antiwar Roles as P.O.W.'s
description: WASHINGTON, March 15At least eight of the enlisted men scheduled to return early tomorrow from Hanoi are known to be bitter critics of the Vietnam war whose refusal to participate in camp life in North Vietnam provoked deep hostility among their fellow prisoners, according to military sources.

title: Ford Fund Denies Suggesting C.I.A. Train Police
description: The president of the Ford Foundation has denied an assertion by the Central Intelligence Agency that New York City policemen were trained the agency at the suggestion of the foundation.

title: President Rejects Curbs On Prices Paid Farmers
description: WASHINGTON, March 15President Nixon emphatically rejected today the idea of putting controls on prices paid to farmers for their products, including meat.

title: Wayward Air Brought Mildness
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)Two huge rivers of air flowed capriciously astray this winter. The result, according to government weathermen, was snow in the South, frequent mild temperatures in the North and other unseasonal weather in the nation.

title: Korean Delegates Disagree On Steps Toward Reunion
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 15 (UPI)South and North Korea, meeting for the first time this year in talks aimed at eventual reunification of their two countries, disagreed today on how to start the way to a single Korea.

title: SENATORS RETAIN TRUCK, US LIMITS
description: WASHINGTON, March 15The Senate, by wide margins, rejected efforts today to repeal the present limits on the size and weight of trucks and buses that use the Interstate system.

title: People and Business
description: H. Ross Perot, the Texas millionaire who, with some associates, controls the stock brokerage house of duPont Glore Forgan, Inc., drew some astonished gasps yesterday at the New York Society of Security Analysts when he disclosed the headline of another in a series of studiously homespun ads that he has reportedly designed himself.

title: U.S. Aide Leaves Wounded Knee To Talk With Officials in Capital
description: PINE RIDGE, S.D., March 15 The chief Federal negotiator trying to end the Indians' occupation of Wounded Knee suddenly left for Washington today to confer with officials of the Justice and Interior Departments. He is expected to return here tomorrow.

title: Judge Dissatisfied in Film Death Case
description: GILA BEND, Ariz., March 15 Justice of the Peace Mulford Winsor 4th said today that there were a lot of unanswered questions about the death last Feb. 11 of David A. Whiting, business manager for the actress Sarah Miles.

title: Deal for the Independence Off
description: Plans to have the 30,000ton Independence return to cruise service in June have been canceled by American Export Lines and Wall Street Cruises, Inc. The 21yearold liner has been laid up in Baltimore since 1959. The canceled contract had called for the new owner to pay $1.1million in cash, take over $1.4million mortgage and pay American Export Lines 1 per cent of gross revenues until 1976.

title: British Petroleum's Quarterly Net Up
description: The British Petroleum Company, Ltd. increased its quarterly profit for the first time in more than a year in the final quarter, reflecting a recovery in prices and general improvement in demand, the company reported yesterday. Net income for all of 1972, however, was less than half that of the year before, the report added.

title: BUCKLEY PROPOSES PROGRAM ON ENERGY
description: Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, has proposed a fourpoint program to deal with the nation's energy crisis.

title: SAVINGS DROP CITED BY HOME LOAN BANK
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (Reuters)The Federal Home Loan Bank board said today net new savings received in February were $1.6billion compared with $2.7billion in February, 1972, a decline of $1.1billion. This was the smallest inflow, on a seasonally adjusted basis, since the fall of 1970.

title: Marilyn Cochran Victor in Cup Slalom
description: NAEBA, Japan, March 15, (AP)  Marilyn Cochran of Richmond, Vt., tossed aside caution on a steep run and won the women's giant slalom, and JeanNoel Augert of France scored an impressive triumph on the men's slalom course in World Cup races today.

title: Market Place: Warrants Key On Penn Dixie
description: There is rarely a sure thing in the market, but a special situation often comes close. That's why some sophisticated investors are now looking at a situation involving the shares of Continental Steel.

title: Council Passes Bill on Posting Of Prices of Prescription Drugs
description: The City Council approved yesterday without dissent a bill to require pharmacies to post prices of prescription drugsa move consumer activists feel could save families with heavy medicine costs hundreds of dollars a year.

title: Unit Studying Eminent Domain Urges New Uniform Procedure
description: ALBANY, March 15A state commission studying eminent domain today recommended a new uniform procedure to aid property owners whose land is seized for public purposes and to eliminate the present maze of conflicting procedures that work to a property owner's detriment.

title: Reducing the Stockpile
description: To check rising industrial prices, the President has decided to sell large quantities of metals and other commodities out of the Government's strategic stockpile. As Mr. Nixon noted in his press conference yesterday, there are going to be some squealsalleging damage to national securityfrom those who produce and sell to the stockpile, but the President rightly insists that the Government's hoards can be safely reduced to support the fight against inflation. The White House has billed the move as a peace dividend. It would be wise to screen the entire defense budget in the light of the same concept.

title: People in Sports: Ewbank Looks at Fields
description: Weeb Ewbank, coach and general manager of the New York Jets, went shopping yesterday for a permanent inseason practice field for his football team. He was shown a possible site on the grounds of the Nassau County water pollution control plant in South Oyster Bay by Ralph Caso, county executive.

title: In City Opera Cenci, Production Is Star of the Show
description: With the exception of a few mutants such as Martha and L'Elisir d' Amore, operas are infamous for the enthusiasm with which they explore the dark underside of the human soul (if you will allow so blurbwriterly an expression). Beatrix Cenci, the third of Alberto Ginastera's operas to be staged by the New York City Opera, closely resembles his others in that regard. The Argentine composer's work, which had its premiere in Washington last season with Julius Rudel conducting and Gerald Freedman as director, made its new York debut on Wednesday night in essentially the same production.

title: FED PUMPS FUNDS TO MONEY MARKET
description: The Federal Reserve System pumped more than $1billion into the money market this week in an apparent attempt to stabilize shortterm interest rates, the central bank's weekly statement showed yesterday.

title: PRESIDENT WARNS HANOI NOT TO MOVE EQUIPMENT SOUTH
description: WASHINGTON, March 15President Nixon voiced concern today about the movement of North Vietnamese military equipment toward South Vietnam and said Hanoi should not lightly disregard his words.

title: Advertising: Eye on the Eyeball
description: Elliot Young is the kind of fellow who really keeps his eye on the ball, or rather on the eyeball.

title: Man Killed in Tornado
description: NASHVILLE, March 15 (AP)  One man was killed and three persons were injured when a tornado raked across the northern section of White County in Eastern Tennessee early today. Most of the state was hit by severe thunderstorms and heavy rains. Power lines wer reported down, one school system was closed and homes in lowlying areas were flooded.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: OSLO, March 15 (AP)Tim Caldwell of Putney, Vt., turned in the best performance by an American in the Holmenkollen Festival today since John Bower won the Nordic combination in 1968. He finished second to George Zipfel of West Germany in the 15kilometer race.

title: HOWARD H. AIKE, BUILT COMPUTER
description: Dr. Howard Hathaway Aiken, who in the late nineteenthirties conceived the design for the world's first largescale computer, the Mark I, in cooperation with engineers of the International Business Machines Corporation, died in his sleep early Wednesday on a visit to St. Louis. He was 73 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Bridge: New York Team Is Trailing In 3dRound Touring Play
description: ST. LOUIS, March 15A famous New York team was in trouble this afternoon in the third round of the Vanderbilt knockout team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: Force on Monetary Scene: Oil Money From Mideast
description: PARIS, March 15  A new force has arisen on the monetary scene  the power of oil money in North Africa and the Middle East.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Following is the transcript of President Nixon's news conference today as issued by the White House:

title: BOOKSELLERS LOSE OBSCENITY APPEAL
description: ALBANY, March 15  The Court of Appeals upheld today the constitutionality of the penal law providing that a person who sells obscene material in the course of his business is presumed to do so with knowledge of its content or character.

title: Vatican Aide Backs Sharing of Finds
description: ROME, March 15A Vatican scholar came out today against what he termed Italy's archeological patriotism and suggested that it should be made easier for foreign institutions to acquire legally and display ancient treasures dug up in this country.

title: Two More Bodies Found
description: BAILEY'S CROSSROADS, Va., March 15 (UPI)  Workers found two more bodies today in the wreckage caused two weeks ago when a giant crane fell on a high rise building and demolished it. The death toll is now 10.

title: Mother of Kidnapped Baby Seeks New Life
description: Since the kidnapping of her 5dayold son by a hammerwielding assailant at noon on Jan. 3 in Harlem, Nanny Lee Armstrong, has moved to a new home in Brooklyn.

title: The Place Looks GreatBut the Food Is Another Matter
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: Stage: WellMeaning Brother Gorski
description: Unions and their problems are the subject matter of Emanuel Fried's Brother Gorski, which opened last night at the Astor Place Theater. It was wellmeaning but excessively heavygoing. Mr. Fried's heart is in the right place, but his playwriting isn't.

title: The U.S. Liaison Chief for Peking
description: The five Presidents of United States since World War II might have found difficult to agree on a number of things, especially the conduct of foreign fairs. But when it came the selection of a man to trusted with a critical job, all five chose David Kirkpatrick Este Bruce, who has become this country's senior diplomat despite repeated efforts to retire. After long and distinguished career that included the posts of Ambassador to France, West Germany and Britain, Mr. Bruce retired in 1969.

title: David Bruce, 75, Selected To Head Office in Peking
description: WASHINGTON, March 15President Nixon announced today that he had recalled Ambassador David K. E. Bruce from retirement to head a United States liaison office in Peking.

title: Slave Labor Camp for Migrants Charged in Florida, 2 Seized
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., March 15 (AP)  Two men were arrested today on charges of operating what the police called a slave labor camp for 27 migrant farm workers.

title: Rider President Defends His Actions on Tenure
description: CHICAGO, March 15  Dr. Frank N. Elliott, the president of Rider College, said today that faculty members who voted yesterday to censure him in a dispute on tenure were not aware that they, themselves had set the rules.

title: 144 Chagall Panels Burn In French Workshop Fire
description: BIOT, France, March 15, ReutersFire has destroyed 144 decorative panels by the painter Marc Chagall in this Riviera village, the police reported today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Leaders of New York City's highereducation community attacked proposals to impose tuition at the City University of New York as an unfair double tax on city residents that would hasten the departure of the middleclass and lead to racial antagonisms here. The proposal was made by Governor Rockefeller's Task force on Financing Higher Education.

title: Robins Favor Wins by Nose, Pays $29
description: To most of the 17,663 fans at Aqueduct yesterday, the reports of the Delafield Commission might have been relegated to the couldn'tcareless category. Random questioning throughout most of the vast stands brought forth answers such as, Oh, is it out yet, or when is the new law going into effect, when there were any answers at all. In most cases, though, the interrogations were brushed off, politely, but brushed off, just the same.

title: Couture Copies: No Signs of Madness
description: Obviously, the Paris couture has given up its flirtation with the jeans and Tshirt crowd. Instead of such things as tiedyes and patches, there are honesttogoodness real clothes. Coats instead of ponchos and blankets. Dresses, alone and with jackets. Even bona fide suits.

title: STOCKS OFF AGAIN ON NAMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market continued to decline yesterday in light trading.

title: YANKS TOP TWINS FOR 4TH STRAIGHT
description: FT. LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 15The Yankees won their fourth straight game here tonight, defeating the Minnesota Twins, 60, before 3,670 fans. The shutout, first of the spring for the Yanks, brought their exhibition wonlost record to 72.

title: YearRound D.S.T. Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI)Senators Claiborne Pell and John O. Pastore, both Rhode Island Democrats, proposed today that daylight saving time be observed the year round. They introduced a bill to do this and said it would help reduce crime, cut traffic accidents and lessen demands on electric power. An extra hour of daylight during the evening in the winter will help curb all these problems, Mr. Pell said.

title: Weinberger Calls Off Plan To Distribute Abortion Film
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI)Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, has killed a department plan to distribute to public schools and colleges a controversial film advocating legalized abortion, it was learned today.

title: TV: Mario Thomas, Lily Tomlin Shine
description: It has been a good week for women on television. Last night, Lauren Bacall. Tonight, Mario Thomas and Lily Tomlin.

title: Plane Birth Brings Charge
description: CLEVELAND, March 15 (UPI)  A Southern University coed who gave birth to a baby on an airliner was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on an attempted murder charge resulting from the birth. The authorities said that Betty J. Anderson of Garyville, La., had admitted abandoning the newborn girl in the washroom of a United Air Lines plane at Youngstown (Ohio) Municipal Airport Feb. 19. Miss Anderson had given birth unnoticed during a flight from Washington, D.C. The baby was rescued from a washroom fixture by airline employes and the mother was later traced with the aid of a passenger list.

title: WEINSTEIN SEEKS LIBERAL SUPPORT
description: Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein, one of three candidates designated by the Democrats to run for chief judge of the state, is going after the Liberal party nomination, despite an agree ment between Liberal party, leaders and Republicans that calls for Judge Charles D. Breitel to be the candidate of the two parties.

title: Chic Young, Creator of Blondie, Dead
description: Chic Young, creator of the comic strip Blondie, died Wednesday night of a pulmonary embolism at the Apollo Medical Center in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 72 years old and had been in ill health for some time, remaining near his home in Clearwater, Fla.

title: CLASS A GAINING IN MONTEGO RACE
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 15  With breeies freshening and skippers gambling, the Class A fleet began accelerating today on close reaches in the MiamiMontego Bay yacht race.

title: PLAN FOR TUITION AT CITY U. SCORED
description: The City University chancellor, Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, warned yesterday that if the City University followed the recommendations of a state task force and began charging tuition, the flight of middleclass families from the city would accelerate and racial antagonisms would deepen.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Films

title: FARMERS INCREASE THEIR CROP PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)  Farmers intend to plant 17.2 per cent more corn and 14.5 per cent more soybeans this year, crops that figure heavily in the Nixon Administration's strategy to curb the rise in food prices, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: BLAST DEMOLISHES AN OFFTRACKPARLOR
description: An explosion of unknown origin last midnight leveled an Offtrack Betting Corporation parlor and a Strauss autosupply store on Jamaica Avenue in Quens Village. No injuries were reported.

title: BRUINS BEAT SABRES, TIE RANGERS FOR 2D
description: BUFFALO, March 15 (UPI)Thirdperiod goals by Carol Vadnais, Phil Esposito and Bobby Orr sparked the Boston Bruins to a 41 National Hockey League victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight.

title: NIXON GIVES VIEW ON PAKISTAN ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 15President Nixon today defended the resumption of arms sales to Pakistan as the fulfillment of contractual commitments made before the IndiaPakistan war of 1971.

title: Shortterm Interest Rates Show a Rise
description: Shortterm interest rates took another leap upward yesterday as the banking system continued to mobilize funds to meet soaring demands upon it.

title: JACK FRIEDMAN
description: Jack Friedman, senior partner in the accounting firm of Friedman, Alpren & Green, died Wednesday in New York University Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 325 West End Avenue, and in Miami Beach and Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: NIXON SUGGESTS HIGH COURT RULING ON REFUSING DATA
description: WASHINGTON, March 15President Nixon suggested today at a news conference that the time may have come for the Supreme Court to decide the extent of a President's right to withhold information from Congress.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Tom C. Clark, retired Supreme Court Justice, told the Citizens' Conference on the Courts last night that unification of the courts in New York State was long overdue, and that court reform was too big a job to be accomplished by lawyers and judges alone. Mr. Clark, who spending his retirement sitting in the Federal courts and crusading for court reform, spoke at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel at a dinner session of a twoday conference of 100 representatives of 39 New York civic and philanthropic organizations. The groups have formed a coalition for court reform.

title: Mrs. Hogg Is Married To Bruce B. Dayton
description: ORONO, Minn. March 15 Mrs. Virginia Minn., of New Brighton, a marriage counselor, was married here this afternoon to Bruce B. Dayton, board chairman of the DaytonHudson Corporation, a department store chain and real estate conglomerate with outlets in 30 states.

title: New York City Offtrack Betting
description: CURRENT FACTS AND FIGURES

title: Schumann and Pleven Quit
description: PARIS, March 15 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann and Justice Minister Rene Pleven today resigned from the French government following their loss of their parliamentary seats in Sunday's runoff election.

title: Merck Sets Record Outlay
description: Merck & Co., Inc., said yesterday that it plans to spend a record $88million for research and development this year, or 10 per cent more than the $79.6million spent in 1972.

title: Bridge:
description: ST. LOUIS, March 15A famous New York team was in trouble this afternoon in the third round of the Vanderbilt knockout team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: Raiders Lose to Sharksin Finale Here
description: A tired band of Raiders was easy prey for the Los Angele Sharks last night. The New Yorkers bowed, 62 and, unwittingly, took a step in soling their playoff dilemma.

title: U.S. Considering Plan to Speed Closings of Losing Rail Routes
description: WASHINGTON, March 15The Nixon Administration is considering a plan to expedite widespread abandonment of moneylosing Northeastern rail routes, including many of the Penn Central.

title: G.O.P. DISSIDENTS LOSE BERGEN SUIT
description: HACKENSACK, March 15Superior Court Judge James I. Toscano upheld today the constitutionality of a section of the state's primary election law that had been challenged by insurgent Bergen County Republicans.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: New Director Named By Education Group
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  The National Education Association announced yesterday the appointment of Terry E. Herndon, executive director of its Michigan affiliate, as executive secretary of the national organization.

title: ARTHUR WRIGHT
description: SPRINGFIELD, Vt., March 15 AP)Arthur Wright, former nanaging editor of The TimesReporter, published here and in Bellows Falls, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 53 years old.

title: Eight May Face CourtsMartial For Antiwar Roles as P.O.W.'s
description: WASHINGTON, March 15At least eight of the enlisted men scheduled to return early tomorrow from Hanoi are known to be bitter critics of the Vietnam war whose refusal to participate in camp life in North Vietnam provoked deep hostility among their fellow prisoners, according to military sources.

title: U.S. Considering Plan to Speed Closings of Losing Rail Routes
description: WASHINGTON, March 15The Nixon Administration is considering a plan to expedite widespread abandonment of moneylosing Northeastern rail routes, including many of the Penn Central.

title: Jersey Said to Face Electricity Rationing
description: TRENTON, March 15New Jersey faces rationing of electric power within three years unless some method of controlling demand or increasing energy sources is found, William E. Ozzard, president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, warned today.

title: Health Center in AllBlack Mississippi Town Again in Dispute and May Lose U.S. Funds
description: WASHINGTON, March 15The comprehensive health center of Mound Bayou, an allblack town in Mississippi, is in trouble again and faces a cutoff of Federal funds.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Kolton, at Panel in Senate, Firm on Fixed Rate
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 The head of the New York Stock Exchange urged Congress today to require that brokerdealer commissions be determined by competitive negotiations and that members of all national securities exchanges be required to execute only public orders.

title: $212BILLION VOTED FOR CITY PROJECTS
description: The City Council and the Board of Estimate yesterday adopted a record $2.24billion capital budget for 197374 and Mayor Lindsay immediately approved it.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES HALT DOWNTURN
description: The threeday downthelimit declines in soybeans futures came to an end yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Elliott Roosevelt's Book Is Disavowed by Family
description: Four children or Franklin D Roosevelt, in a statement made public yesterday, disassociatec themselves completely fron a book written by their brother Elliott Roosevelt, which says that their father was intimate with a secretary, Marguerite (Missy) LeHand when he was remarried to Eleanor Roosevelt.

title: N. Y. U. Trio Gains RoundRobin Final In National Fencing
description: BALTIMORE, March 15Twelve schools qualified all three of their fencers today for the final round of the National Collegiate championships at Johns Hopkins University. In all, 72 competitors, 24 in each of the three weapons epee, foil and sober, advanced to the roundrobin to be held tomorrow and Saturday.

title: Business Briefs
description: GENEVA, March 15 (AP)The United States formally presented its claims for compensation of trade losses in Britain, Denmark and Ireland to the European Common Market today. Herbert Propps, assistant special trade representative of President Nixon, raised the United States demands in the first of a series of meetings with the European Economic Community to renegotiate its external tariffs after the admission of the three countries.

title: CLASS A GAINING IN MONTEGO RACE
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 15  With breezes freshening and skippers gambling, the Class A fleet began accelerating today on close reaches in the MiamiMontego Bay yacht race.

title: CONGRESS VOTES BILL FACING VETO
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 The new Congress cleared the way today for its first legislative confrontation with President Nixon by giving final approval to a bill that the White House has said would be vetoed.

title: Health Technician Accepts An Apology From Steingut
description: ALBANY, March 15The Albany Medical Center has announced that a female health technician who said she had been subjected to physical annoyance two weeks ago by four Democratic Assemblymen undergoing free heart tests had accepted an apology on their behalf from Stanley Steingut of Brooklyn, Democratic minority leader.

title: L. V. KLEINW ACHTER, AUSTRIAN DIPLOMAT
description: Ludwig V. Kleinwchter, who was Austrian Ambassador to the United States in 195152, capping a foreignservice career of more than 40 years, died Monday in Vienna. His age was 91.

title: DENVER ADVANCES IN N.C.A.A. HOCKEY
description: BOSTON, March 15 (AP) Pete McNab scored three goals and had three assists today in leading Denver University to a 104 victory over Boston College and a berth in the finals of the National Collegiate) hockey tournament at Boston Garden.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Nearly four years ago. Tom Young, the basketball coach at American University, peered through the gloom of a lighted playground in Washington, D. C., at a skinny youngster off by himself. The pickup games had ended. The courts were deserted. But in the summer humidity, the teenager, whom Young had recruited, had been alone for half an hour, jumping and tapping a basketball against a backboard with his right hand, then with his left. Young wandered over to where Kermit Washington was practicing. What are you doing? the coach asked. I just read Bill Russell's book, the teenager said. He did this as a kid50 taps with his right hand, 50 with his left. It's a good drill, the coach agreed. In earlier years, Kermit Washington watched Elgin Baylor perform on the D.C. playgrounds. People pointed him out, he says now.

title: CHOU AIDE EXPECTED TO BE SENT TO U.S.
description: PEKING, March 16The appointment yesterday of David K. E. Bruce to head a United States liaison office here has strengthened speculation that Mr. Bruce's counterpart in Washington will be Chang Wenchin, one of Premier Chou Enlai's principal foreignpolicy advisers.

title: Industrial Output Up Sharply; Housing Starts Are Off Slightly
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Industrial production rose strongly again in February and housing starts continued at a high level, Government reports disclosed today.

title: Albano Spuns Wagner
description: Vincent F. Albano, the Republican leader in Manhattan, has joined in the opposition to former Mayor Robert F. Wagner as the RepublicanLiberal nominee for Mayor. Mr. Albino declared that he would fight for a Republican rather than for Mr. Wagner as the candidate. Page 15.

title: Secret Material Removed After Blast
description: A military police detail yeserday removed classified maerial to a Government instaliaion after an explosion and fire tad demolished three commercial buildings in Queens Village.

title: HARRY LEITHROSS, LANDSCAPE PAINTER
description: NEW HOPE, Pa., March 16Harry LeithRoss, an artist in oil and watercolors noted for his landscapes, died yesterday in a nursing home at Pinesville. His age was 87 and he had lived here almost 40 years.

title: BUILDUP BY HANOI REPORTED IN AREA NORTH OF SAIGON
description: TAY NINH, South Vietnam, March 16South, Vietnamese and American officials say that Communist forces are ?? in a major buildup of supplies and military equipment in tiffs critical border province northwest of Saigon.

title: College Title Polo Tonight
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 16Connecticut and Virginia will play for the National Collegiate indoor polo championship tomorrow night at the Ox Ridge. Hunt Club.

title: Administration Asks More Aid to Amtrak And Route Cutback
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Nixon Administration urged Congress today to authorize $300million in new Federal loan guarantees to finance continued rehabilitation of the nation's passenger train system.

title: ENERGY CRISIS PLAN OFFERED BY JACKSON
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)A 10year plan to increase the nation's fuel supplies and give private industry a bigger stake in solving the energy crisis was proposed today by Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington.

title: Business Records BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDING
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Penn Ties N. Y. U. After Second Day In National Fencing
description: BALTIMORE, March 16A surprising performance by the University of Pennsylvania's saberman, Bill Hamlin, who captured 10 of his 12 bouts today, enabled the Quakers to tie New York University for the team lead after the second round of the National Collegiate fencing championships.

title: In Wee Small Hours, Yanks Sign Lyle
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 16It was shortly after midnight, and Sparky Lyle and Lee MacPhail were an hour into their third meeting of the day and Lyle was ready to leave.See you in the morning, Lyle told the Yankee general manager.

title: Even Good People Are Losing Heart
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.No area of American life needs firmer commitment today than the constitutional promise of equal opportunity, especially for those Americans, mainly colored, who suffer injustice, or for whom the American, promise seems to be still empty words. The majority of the world's people today are colored, net white. Their greatest hope in American ideals, cannot be justified if they see Amiricans, colored like themselves, enjoying only secondclass citizenship. Power they can easily discern in America. Equality is what convinces them that it is our moral leadership that they should follow.

title: Equal Teaching Time Urged
description: ATLANTA, March 16 (UPI)In an effort to let school children hear both sides of the question, the State Senate voted yesterday to forbid the teaching of evolution in Georgia schools without equal time to the Biblical approach to the creation of life.

title: WINE TALK
description: Wine tastings are fashionable these days. They have replaced, the cocktail party in some circles and they have become a smash fundraising event (Come to a wine tasting for George McGovern)

title: Commodity Study Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (Reuters)Representative William R. Cotter, Democrat of Connecticut, has asked the General Accounting Office to investigate the impact of speculation in the commodity exchanges on rapidly rising food prices. The G.A.O. is the independent watchdog agency for Congress.

title: New Widow Wins $1Million
description: PITTSBURGH, March 16 (UPI)Mrs. Elizabeth M. Nock, 59 years old, won $1million in the Pennsylvania lottery yesterday, two days after her husband was buried.

title: Administration Asks More Aid to Amtrak And Route Cutback
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Nixon Administration urged Congress today to authorize $300million in new Federal loan guarantees to finance continued rehabilitation of the nation's passenger train system.

title: GROVER C. WASHABAUGH
description: NEW CASTLE, Pa., March 16 (UPI)Grover C. Washabaugh, athletic director at Westminster College for 24 years and its basketball coach from 1937 to 1955, died yesterday at Jameson Memorial Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: Secretariat Faces Five Rivals Today
description: The Meadow Stable's Secretariat, worth $6,080,000 according to the terms of his recent syndication, will make his first start of the season today.

title: Big Board Seat Price Is Lowest in a Decade
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that a seat sold at $125,000, the lowest price paid for a membership in more than a decade.

title: Rules for Registering For School Elections
description: All permanent registered voters are eligible to vote in community school board elections, on May 1. In addition, parents with children enrolled in city public primary schools may register as parent voters in the districts where their children are enrolledwhether or not they are already permanently registered voters. But they may vote in only one place.

title: Bermuda Governor And Aide Buried; Killers Still Sought
description: ST. GEORGE, Bermuda, March 16  Sir Richard Sharpies, the murdered Governor of Bernitida, was buried in this tiny former capital of Bermuda today.

title: TV TOWN MEETING IS SET FOR TODAY
description: Should lowincome public housing projects be built in middleclass neighborhoods?

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: EDUCATION OFFICE PACES F.B.I. CHECK
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)The acting Commissioner of Education, John R. Ottina, said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was investigating some contracts awarded, by the Office of Education.

title: Mideast Peace Voyage Began by Abie Nathan
description: A ship captained by Abie Nathan, the former Israeli jet fighter pilot turned peace activist, left here yesterday for the Middle East with. Mr. Nathan's proclaimed goal of creating a people's dialogue to end the violence between Arabs and Jews.

title: New York CocaCola to Move Half Its Executives to Jersey
description: The CocaCola Bottling Cornpany of New York announced yesterday that, half of its executives would move their corporate offices and staffs to Hackensack, N. J., in June.

title: MRS. CHESTER LASELL
description: BOCA GRANDE, Fla., March 16Mrs. Ruth Drake Lasell, the wife of Chester H. Lasell, a partner in Morgan Stanley & Co., investment house at 140 Brodway, New York, died yesterday at her home here. She was 62 years old and lived also in Greenwich, Conn.

title: BRUINS TRIUMPH OVER WINGS, 54
description: DETROIT, March 16 (AP)Doug Roberts scored in the final minute to give the Boston Bruins a 54 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: Slide Rule in Hand, Mrs. Knauer Tries To Aid Consumers
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 Mrs. Virginia Knauer, the President's special assistant for consumer affairs, today issued at Mr. Nixon's behest the Administration's battle plan for saving money on food.

title: SAIGON'S PRISONERS SAID TO FAKE ILLS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 16 (AP) A team of American doctors two years ago examined 116 South Vietnamese political prisoners who said they were paralyzed because of maltreatment and concluded that all of them were either faking or were victims of hysteria, according to United States sources.

title: SENATE CONSIDERS STRIP MINING BILL
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)A fourday hearing belore the Senate Interior. Committee on strip mining reclamation legislation ended today With conservationists urging strict Federal controls and mining industry representatives recommending standards that would not restrict production.

title: Harpsichord and Brass
description: Much contemporary music has been written for the harpsichord since that sedate instrument's restoration to favor early in this century, but a lot of it puts one in mind of the nuns in old Bing Crosby movies who prove what uptodate folks they are by playing baseball. The harpsichord tries to be a good sport, too, but one usually is embarrassed at the coyness of it all.

title: MUGGER ASSESSED 15YEAR SENTENCE
description: A Supreme Court Justice in Manhattan, James S. Leff, sentenced Supreme Court Justice in Manhattan, James J. Leff, sen tenced a man convicted of assault and robbery to a maximum term of 15 years in prison yesterday after criticizing the leniency with which other judges had dealt with the man's past crimes.

title: COLBERT, GRAHAM SHARE GOLF LEAD
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 16 (AP)Jim Colbert got birdies on the last two holesone with a 40foot putt front off the greenfor a 65 today and a share of the secondround lead with Lou Graham in the $130,000 Greater Jacksonvixe open golf tournament.

title: FLORENCE THORNE OF A. F. L. IS DEAD
description: WASHINGTON, March 12Florence Calvert Thorne, for many years director of research of the American Federation of Labor, died today. She was 95 years old.

title: The Good Buys List
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Department of Agriculture lists good buys for this month and next Besides being good buys, foods marked with X are also on the plentiful list.

title: A NearTwin of Queens Official Is Charged With Molesting Girls
description: A 29yearold postman seized last night on suspicion of sexually abusing a dozen or more teenage girls was described by the police as nearly a twin of a Queens assistant district attorney who has been accused of similar sex crimes.

title: College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: Education, Higher
description: Governor Rockefeller's proposal of mandatory life imprisonment for those trafficking in drugs may, to the untutored eye, seem Draconian. It offers, rather, an occasion for imagination and innovative planning.

title: WHITE HOUSE ENDS GRAY'S DATA OFFER
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI)The Administration has rescinded the offer by L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to open the F.B.I.'s files on the Watergate case to all members of the Senate, Congressional sources said today.

title: SCHWEITZER HAILS MONETARY RESULTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 16PierrePaul Schweitzer, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said today that the Paris monetary meeting, and the European decisions preceding it, have made a constructive contribution to the restoration of orderly conditions in exchange markets.

title: POOR CONDITIONS AT ALPINE SKIING
description: KINGFIELD, Me., March 16 The threeday Eastern Alpine championships bekan on an abbreviated note on Sugarloaf Mountain today. Because of melting snow, race officials staged a tworun slalom instead of the originally scheduled downhill event.

title: Mrs. Nixon is 61
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI)Mrs. Richard M. Nixon dedicated a wildlife center in suburban Virginia today, her 61st birthday, and said that her real celebration would come tomorrow night At a family St. Patrick's Day dinner at the White House. We always celebrats on March 17, she told reporters.

title: Steelers' Tackle, Holmes, Arrested in Ohio Manhunt
description: SALEM, Ohio, March 16 (AP)  Sheriff's deputies and the Ohio State Patrol arrested a man whom they identified as the Pittsburgh Steelers' defensive tackle, Ernest Holmes, after a manhunt today in which a helicopter pilot was shot and wounded.

title: Scientists Translate the Bronx Cheer, etc.
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 16  Giving tongue to thought is common. What Prof. W. John Smith has done is give thought to tongue, and he has decided what we mean when we show it.

title: Miki Sets Lift Record
description: MOSCOW, March 16 (AP)Kodzi Mild of Japan broke his world featherweight record today by snatching 255 pounds in an international weightlifting competition, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency. Mild bettered by 2 pounds the best previous effort for a lifter in the 125pound class.

title: EQUAL RIGHTS VOTE NOW IN QUESTION
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Nebraska Legislature's vote to rescind support of the equal rights amendment barring discrimination based on sex may not have had any effect on its chances for ratification.

title: Art: Blakelock's Diminutive Paintings
description: If Albert Blakelock (18471919) had been just a little better as a painter, his life could have supplied the raw material for an American legend similar to Vincent Van Gogh's. A physician's son, he was seduced, from studies for the medical profession by the lure of painting, and thereafter experienced the hard times and neglect that are primary requisites for an artbiography candidate. In addition, Blakelock's typical. landscapes were moody, literally moonstruck affairs, and, to cap it all, his privations led to what was then called a nervous breakdown and Confinement in institutions from 1899 to 1916. For a couple of years after his release, his paintings sold well and he was even elected to the National Academy. But everything came too late for him. He was recommitted in 1918 and died in confinement the following year.

title: Bridge: New York Teams Challenge in Vanderbilt Cup Matches
description: ST. LOUIS, March 16Teams led by New York experts faced hard battles in seven of the eight Vanderbilt Cup matches that began here this afternoon at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: Argentines Give Peron a Triumph but Are Split on What's to Come
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 16 A few weeks, before the elections here, a senior Argentine diplomat mulled over the prospects of a new Peronist government during a leisurely lunch at an outdoor restaurant.

title: Burlington Line Approves Study on Milwaukee Road
description: Burlington Northern, Inc., said yesterday it was prepared to enter a joint feasibility study with the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad on the Milwaukee Road's request to merge into the Burlington Northern.

title: WHITE ROUSE ENDS GRAY'S DATA OFFER
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI)The Administration has rescinded the offer by. L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to open the F.B.I.'s files on the Watergate case to all members of the Senate, Congressional sources said today.

title: British Trainmen End Strikes Pending Negotiations Monday
description: LONDON, March 16Leaders of the locomotive engineers' union voted narrowly tonight to suspend the strikes and slowdowns, that have disrupted Britain's railway services.

title: Albano Joins G.O.P. Opposition To Choosing Wagner for Mayor
description: Republican resistance to a RepublicanLiberal nomination of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner for the mayoralty spread yesterday as Vincent F. Albano of Manhattan, the party's senior county leader in the city, declared that he would fight for a Republican rather than Mr. Wagner as the candidate for mayor.

title: Lightnin First Into Montego Bay After 5Day Sail From Miami
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 16  Ted Turner's yacht, Lightnin, unheard from for almost two days, crossed the finish line first tonight in the 811mile MiamitoMontego Bay race. The 39foot Class C sloop finished at 10:47, New York time, completing the course in 5 days 10 hours 47 minutes 36 seconds.

title: STOCKS ARE DOWN ON AMEX AND OTC;News of Monetary Pact Has Little Effect Trading Off
description: News of the monetary agreement in Paris did not prevent prices on the American Stock exchange and on the overthecounter market from finishing lower yesterday in light trading.

title: KOCH, VAN DILLEN LOSE IN CARACAS
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 16 (AP)Upsets continued in the $15,000 Altamira international tennis championships today. Zeljko Franulovic of Yugoslavia upset Tomas Koch of Brazil, 64, 76, and Francois Jauffret of France surprised Erik Van Dillen of San Mateo, Calif., 62, 76.

title: 2 Senators Avert a Touchy Vote About Long Island Sound Bridge
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 A bit of lastminute cooperation yesterday between New York and Connecticut Senators allowed New York's two Senators to escape having to cast a politically difficult vote on the proposed bridge across Long Island Sound between. Rye, N. Y., and Oyster Bay, L. I. According to their aides New Yorks SenatorsJacob, K. Javits, a Republican, and James L. Buckley, a ConservativeRepublican  have not taken a position on the bridge, which is avidly sought by Governor Rockefeller but strongly opposed by many Long Island and Westchester County residents.

title: U.S. AND 13 OTHERS ADOPT MEASURES ON DOLLAR CRISIS
description: PARIS, March 16The United States and 13 other major trading, nations agreed today on a loosely formulated package of measures designed to ease the problem Of excess dollars abroad and to assure the reopening of official currency dealings under orderly conditions on Mondity.

title: Back Stairs
description: To the Editor: After reading F. R. Buckley's masterservant apologia, Human Reward, OpEd March 6, I would like to know how he feels about the Institution of Slavery.

title: Australian Police Raid Offices Of the Nation's Secret Service
description: SYDNEY, Australia, March 16 (AP)Commonwealth policemen raided the headquarters of the nation's secret service, the Sepurity Intelligence Organization, in Melbourne today.

title: 3 Extra Days to Register ordered in School Voting
description: Federal District Judge Charles E. Stewart ordered the Board of Elections yesterday to extend its inschool voter registration drive for three more days, following complaints that bilingual registration forms were not being provided in many schools.

title: Market Place: British Wooing Conglomerates
description: The tender by Britishowned Triumph American, Inc., for control of the General Host Corporation announced on Thursday marks the beginning of what sorne observers believe will be a rush by British companies to acquire control of assetrich American companies whose shares are selling at depressed prices.

title: High School Notes
description: Every year, the Bronx High School of Science leads the city in the number of Regents Scholarship winners, and this year wasn't any different. At least 539 seniors about three fourths of its graduating classwill have the state scholarships, which are worth between $600 for one year and $1,000 for four years at a college within New York State.

title: City to Lose Some Offices Of CocaCola of New York
description: The CocaCola Bottling Company of New York announced yesterday that half of its executives would moye their corprate offices and staffs to Hackensack, N. J., in June.

title: TWO PRIESTS HELD IN THEFT OF BOOKS
description: NEW HAVEN, March 16Two men who described themselves as unfrocked Byzantine priests were indicted in Federal District Court here today on charges that for years they stole ancient books, atlases and manuscripts from Yale Library to sell to rarebook dealers in New York and Chicago.

title: SEOUL READY TO TALK TO CHINA ON OIL CLAIM
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 16The South Korean Government declared today that it was willing to negotiate with Peking on jurisdiction over offshore oil exploration in the Yellow Sea and the East China Sea.

title: Administration Officials Oppose Call for an Overseas Troop Cut
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Nixon Administration today strongly opposed a call endorsed by Senate Democrats yesterday for a substantial reduction in military forces abroad.

title: Girl Runner, 14, Leads U.S. Women to Victory
description: RICHMOND, March 16Robin Campbell wowed 'em tonight, and no international debutante could have enjoyed a more satisfying comingout party.
