description: WASHINGTON, March 16  bit of lastminute cooperation yesterday between New York and Connecticut Senators allowed New York's two Senators to escape haying to cast a politically difficult vote on the proposed bridge across Long Island Sound between Rye, N. Y., and Oyster Bay, L. I. According to their aides, New York's SenatorsJacob K. Javits, a Republican, and James L. Buckley, a ConservativeRepublican  have not taken a position on the bridge, which is avidly sought by Governor Rockefeller but has apparently been blocked by the Department of the Interior. It has also been strongly opposed by many Long Island and Westchester residents.

title: Parade Today
description: The 24th annual St. Patrick's Day Parade will begin today at noon. The marchers will step off at 44th Street and move up Fifth Avenue, turning east at, 86th Street and disbanding at Third Avenue. The parade route will be closed to traffic, but major crosstown streets will be opened to vehicles periodically. Normal parking regulations will be in effect elsewhere.

title: U.S. Suit Accuses Chicago Of Bias in Fire Department
description: CHICAGO, March 16 (UPI) The United States Justice Department charged the Chicago Fire Department yesterday with discriminatory hiring and promotion practices.

title: City Opens Drive to Stop State TakeOver of OTB
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city was undertaking an intensive lobbying effort in Albany and across the state to fight the Delafield Commission's proposal that the state take over the city's offtrack betting operations.

title: Pacers Top Nets, 9889, For 9th Straight Victory
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 16The Indiana Pacers extended their longest winning streak of the season to nine games tonight by turning back the New York Nets, 9889. They climbed within 3 games of the Utah Stars in the battle for first place in the American Basketball Association's West Division.

title: Use of Laser Writing Speeds Transmissions
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  Engineers at Bell, Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N. J., have patented a method by which a full newspaper page can be transmitted from a distant point and recorded on microfilm in four seconds. The procedure involves laser writing. Patent 3,720,784 was granted this week to Dan Maydan, Melvin I. Cohen and Robert E. Kerwin for the process and apparatus.

title: THUY IS SCORNFUL OF NIXON THREAT
description: PARIS, March 16 (AP)Xuan Thuy, head of the North Vietnamese delegation to the Paris peace talks, today brushed aside warnings by President Nixon about North Vietnamese troop and equipment infiltrations into the South in violation of the peace agreement.

title: SKI INFORMATION
description: Roundtheclock Information is available at Ellis Ski Information Center.

title: JOHN D. M'KENZE, ETAS OFFICIAL
description: John D. MacKenzie, former board chairman and president of the American Smelting and Refining Company, died yesterday in Rochester, Minn. He was 75 years old and had lived in Naples, Fla., since his retirement in 1963 after 43 years with the company.

title: Prison Seems Calm In Face of Walkout By Walpole Guards
description: WALPOLE, Mass., March 16 A work stoppage by at least 150 guards at the states maximum security prison continued for a second day today with no negotiations between correcItions officials and the guards' union and no apparent signs of tension or disorder inside.

title: As Others See Us
description: LONDON, March 16Mayor Lindsay and his aides are angry because The London Sunday Times surveyed New York City and found conditions there hopeless, intolerable and inhuman. The conclusion was outrageous, said the Mayoi. His press secretary, Tom Morgan; a tan with a sense of humor, added, It's a gross insult to the city.

title: INQUIRY IS BEGUN IN L.I.R.R. WRECK
description: LAKE RONKONKOMA, L. I., March 16Investigators from the Long Island Rail Road and the Interstate Commerce Commission began dismantling the four cars and two engines of the passenger train that crashed last night into a standing freight locoinotive here, killing one woman and injuring 26 other persons.

title: SIX HERE CHARGED IN THEFT OF PAPERS
description: Six men, five of them employed by The Daily News, were arrested yesterday and accused of the weekly theft of hundreds of Sunday papers published by The News and The New York Times.

title: CHRISCRAFT WINS APPEALS TO COURT
description: The lengthy legal contest for control of the Piper Aircraft Corporation of Lock Haven, Pa., resulted yesterday in a Court of Appeals ruling here that the Bangor Punta Corporation should pay damages to ChrisCraft Industries.

title: The Screen: 5 Documentaries by Ricky Leacock
description: The extraordinary growth of television in the nineteenfifties and the concurrent development (mostly, by independent film makers) of lightweight camera and sound equipment, changed not only the fortunes of a number of documentary film makers but also the look and sound of their films. Instructive, bossy voiceever narration became increasingly rare as the films came to speak for themselves, through their subjects'It's called Cinma vrit aoroad, direct cinema here.

title: BUILDUP BY HANOI REPORTED IN AREA
description: TAY NINH, South Vietnam, March 16South Vietnaniese and American official's say that Communist forces are engaged in a major buildup of supplies and military equipment in this critical border province northwest of Saigon.Minh trail.

title: Y.M.C.A. Aide Is, Aquitted In Slaying of Indian Leader
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif., March 16 (AP)A Y.M.C.A. camp manager was found not guilty today in the shooting death of Richard Oakes, an Indian leader.

title: BULLETS CONQUER CELTICS BY 10397
description: BALTIMORE, March 16 (UPI) Elvin Hayes scored 29 points tonight as the Baltimore Bullets ended the Boston Celtics' eighttame winning streak with a convincing 103.97 National Basketball Association victory.

title: Funny, You Don't Look Irish
description: WESTPORT, Conn.For one bright year of my childhood I was pure, unadulterated Irish. Later I was to discover that the Americanborn Currys, Devlins and McGoverns of my smalltown Pennsylvania neighborhood qualified as more Irish than I, though I was born in Dublin, because I was Jewish, too. Evidently one diluted the other, and neither was a state of grace in that time or place. But for that shining year I Was five, and back with my mother in Ireland where I belonged. I wanted to stay forever.

title: Mrs. Chadwick Wed
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn., March 16Mrs. Betty Ives Chadwick widow of Arthur Chadwick of Weston, was married here this afternoon to Herbert C. Gstalder. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Shea in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church. Before his retirement Mr. Gstalder was general manager in the Scarsdale, N.Y., regional office of OwensIllinois, Inc., packaging manufacturers. His first wife, the former Mary Jane McDonald of Syracuse, died.

title: People in Sports: Mileti Expands
description: Nick Mileti, who owns the Cleveland Indians of the American League, the Cavaliers of the National Basketball Association and the Crusaders of the World Hockey Association, is continuing to branch out.

title: Queen Opens New London Bridge
description: LONDON, March 16Queen Elizabeth II opened a new London Bridge today, the third in almost, a thousand years. The second one, unable to sustain modern traffic, was pulled down, shipped piece by piece to the United States and rebuilt in Arizona.

title: BEATEN DETECTIVE MAINTAINS COVER
description: A detective was reported yesterday to have been badly, beaten by men he had under suriveillance as suspected of heroin dealers, and kept silent so he would not blow his cover.

description: PARIS, March, 16 (Reuters) Following Is the text of the communiqu issued after the 14nation monetary meeting in Paris today:

description: NEW HAVEN, March 16Two men who described themselves as unfrocked Byzantine priests were indicted in Federal District Court here today on charges that for years they stole ancient books, atlases and manuscripts from Yale Library to sell to rarebook dealers in New York and Chicago.

description: Watching Robert Joffrey's ballet Companyis rather like obseriing an endangered species. Since the City Center is withdrawing most of its support from the company There no longer seems any pointcalling it the City Center Jeffrey Ballet.

description: NEWARK. March 16A law firm specializing in workmen's compensation claims returned to Federal District Court today to seek a contemptofcourt citation against the State Commission of Investigation and several of its officials.

description: MILLINOCKET, Me., March 16 John F. Ward, a former Speaker of the Maine House of Representatives and a former president of the State Senate, died today at the Millinocket Community Hospital. He was 68 years old.

description: Frederick W. Van Duyne Jr., an investment consultant; died, apparently of a heart attack, on Wednesday in Sanibel, Fla. He was 69 years old And lived also. In West Falrnouth, Mass.

title: One Dies as Car Hits Truck

The accident occurred about noon at the intersection of Rocky Point Road and Bailey Roadhere. The woman was identified as Anna Kokinelis of Hallock Landing Road.

Wagner for the mayoralty spread yesterday as Vincent Albano of Manhattan, the party's senior county leader in the city, declared that he would fight for a Republican rather than Mr. Wagner as the candidate for mayor.

The AC's stand for Andr and Coquelin, his wife. What's more, the A is supposed to be strong and mannish, the C gracefully curved and feminine.

title: Chronology of Money Crisis
description: January, 1973The events that were building toward the biggest monetary crisis since the realignment of international currencies in December, 1971, began during January when Italy, bothered by a weakening lira, decided on a twotier currency market. The ensuing flight of dollars from Italy to Switzerland caused Swiss authorities to float the franc which in turn sent dollars surging into West Germany.

description: WASHINGTON, March 16PierrePaul Schweitzer, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said today that the Paris monetary meeting, and the European decisions preceding it, have made a constructive contribution to the restoration of orderly conditions in exchange markets.

title: POOR CONDITIONS AT ALPINS SKIING
AlmaTadema's Victorians in Togas
description: Along with antimacassars and the Aspidistra, the paintings of Sir Lawrence AlmaTadema of the Royal Academy were, a fixture of Victorian life. His obsessively detailed pictures of life in Imperial Rome, recaptured for the benefit of imperialist England were vastly popular with Victorian society. But since the artist's death in 1913, his reputationexcept for devotees of camp  has been buried as deep as an ancient artifact.

C., March 16  Shortly after Indiana turned in the first big upset of the 55th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament last night by beating Marquette, 7569, in the second round at Nashville, the University of San Francisco, contributed the second surprise. The Dons eliminated Long Beach State, 7767, in Los Angeles.

description: DUBLINCuriously for the land of Joyce, Yeats and Beckett, apart from some graffiti on Belfast wallsIs there a life before death? and a crop of jokes, there has been little memorable writing about the Northern Irish conflict.

description: The price of shortterm mone continued to soar yesterday, with the sharp upward movemeat of recent weeks accelerated by reportslater deniedthat the United States had agreed to foster higher interest rates in this country as partof an international financial package negotiated in Europe.

title: Brennan Calls 10.7% Rise In Rail Pact Reasonable
description: WASHINGTON March 16Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan hailed today the recently negotiated 18month national railroad labor contract, saying its 10.7 per cent increase in wages and benefits far over 500,000 workers in 15 unions will fall within reasonable guidelines.

title: Notes on People
description: Mrs. Edward F. Cox, the former Tricia Nixon, entered Georgetown University Hospital in Washington yesterday afternoon for a diagnostic procedure, the White House announced. The 27yearold elder, daughter of President and Mrs. Nixon was said to be under the care of Dr. Walter Tkach, a White House physician. The hospital said the diagnostic procedure normally lasted between 48 and 72 hours and that Mrs. Cox had been admitted by appointment, not in emergency conditions. The hospital said the President had not accompanied her, but declined to who had.

title: Kandinsky Drawings Feature of Show
description: Wassily Kandinsky, the Russian painter who spent many of his most creative years as an expatriate in Germany and France, is generally regarded as one of the originators of modern abstract art. Sometime around 191213the exact date is still a matter of debate among art historians  Kandinsky produced the first of his abstract Improvisations and Compositions, which, though obviously based on landscape motifs, carried the design of expressionist painting into the realm of the nonobjective.

title: Prairie Landmark Ruined
description: FREEDOM, Okla., March 16 (UPI)Chimney Rock, a towering limestone landmark that rose hundreds of feet and guided pioneers across the Oklahoma prairie, lay crumbled at the bottom of Cimarron River Canyon today, apparently the victim of time and recent high winds. It apparently was blown over in recent weeks but this was not discovered until recently.

title: Canada's Voice Abroad Mitchell William Sharp
description: OTTAWA, March 16EarHer this season Mitchell William Sharp, Canadian Speretary of State for External Affairs, appeared as a piano soloist with the Toronto Symphony Orchestra.

title: Rain or Shine, Irish Will March Today
description: With considerable help from their friends; the Irish will march up Fifth Avenue today in the 211th annual St. Patrick's Day Parade.

title: SAIGON RESUMING LOCAL ELECTIONS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 16The South Vietnamese Government will hold new nationwide elections for village councils, reversing a ban put into effect last May during the Communists' spring offensive, a Government spokesman announced today.

title: The Screen: 'Vault of Horror' Opens:The Cast
description: If there is, as I believe, a natural hierarchy in horror films  then to the top rises the vampire movie, and at the very bottom creeps the scary omnibus vignette film, especially the scary vignette film with comic undertones. An example of the last, "The Vault of Horror," opened yesterday at three local theaters.Actually, "The Vault of Horror" contains a brief vampire story, called "Midnight Mess" (that title happens to be the cleverest thing in the movie), that makes the mistake of equating vampirism with sustenance rather than sex. The hero of "Midnight Mess" (Daniel Massey), a thorough rotter who becomes dinner before his tale is done, meets each night with four other gentlemen to recount the dream, so he thinks, of his own violent demise.The others do likewise with miseries ranging from burial alive to a fatal rage for order. Everyone pretty much deserves his death (I'm not sure about Terry-Thomas who merely wants his house kept neat), and everyone gets it through one of those ironic twists of fate so dear to the soul of 10th-rate mystery fiction.Several distinguished performers  Anna Massey, Michael Craig, Dawn Addams, Glynis Johns, among others  appear in the film, and none is ever quite so bad as the material warrants.Except for the tacky optical effects in an episode called "This Trick'll Kill You," where you can see the invisible wires supporting an unsupported vertical Indian rope, the film displays a surface proficiency that keeps suggesting better things. The director, Roy Ward Baker ("A Night to Remember," "Five Million Years to Earth"), has made good movies in the past. But toward "The Vault of Horror" he displays a reticence approaching fastidiousness, which may be the cover for a well-concealed but very honorable distaste.

title: 20,101 SEE FINALS IN GOLDEN GLOVES
description: Although they had to wait until the program was almost over before witnessing their first knockout victory, the capacity crowd of 20,101 that showed up last night for the finals of the 47th New York Golden Gloves didn't seem to mind.

Well, you might drop in at the exhibition at the Hallmark Gallery, downstairs in the big greetingcard store, 720 Fifth Avenue, at 56th Street (5829130). The show, through May 12, is Forty Shades of Green: The Republic of Ireland.

title: Classroom Soldiers

The measure, which is sponsored by Senator Leon Giuffreda, Republican of Suffolk County, is even more objectionable than a similar one introduced, and narrowly defeated, two years ago. While the earlier effort introduce military training into the schools was satisfied with the R.O.T.C. as an afterclass activity, the new proposal would conduct such courses as electives in regular school time against academic credit.

title: Prices of Stocks Retreat After a Brief Rally Fizzles
description: The stock market kept a nervous eye on the negotiations to resolve the monetary crisis in Paris yesterday and lost ground in moderate trading.

title: U.S. Blocks All State Plans On RyeOyster Bay Bridge
description: The Federal Government has blocked all routes officially proposed by New York State for the controversial bridge from Rye, N. Y., to Oyster. Bay, L. I., on the ground that they would traverse a national wildlife refuge.

title: Camden 28 Jury Asks 5 Questions, Through Trial Jude, About F.B.I.
description: CAMDEN, N. J., March 16In a highly unusual move, the jurors in the Camden 28 draftraid trial submitted to the judge today a list of questions they wanted answered about policies and procedures of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: BRENNAN PRAISES 10.7% RAIL ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON March 16Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan hailed today the recently negotiated 18month national railroad labor confract, saying its 10.7 per cent increase in wages and benefits for over 500,000 workers in 15 unions will fall within reasonable guidelines.

title: Widow Protesting Fine Free Pending Plea
description: HACKETTSTOWN, N. J., March 16Mrs. Anne Souders, who became a celebrated center of controversy after going to jail rather than pay what she considered an unfair fine, was released today after appealing for a new trial.

title: STATE PLANS CLAIMS TO MORE TIDAL LAND
description: BUENA, March 16 (UPI) The New Jersey Department, of Environmental Protection, which earlier this week claimed 1,200 acres of the Hackensack Meadowlands, announced today that future claims would be, more extensive.

title: 2 Times Reporters Cited By the Firefighters' Union
description: Judy Klemesrud and David Bird, reporters for The New York Times, were among the winners in the Uniformed Firefighters Association's annual Media Awards Contest, announced yesterday.

title: Dining Out in jersey
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: Hanoi Pledges Search for Missing G.I.'s
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 16 (AP)The editor of North Vietnam's chief newspaper said today that his Government was not hiding any American prisoners and that a search would be started for all the missing and dead as soon as this was possible.

title: MARCOS RECEIVES AN AMNESTY PLAN
description: MANILA, March 16  President Ferdinand E. Marcos met today with several Moslem officials, who proposed a formula for settling the rebellion in four large provinces in southern Mindanao.

title: The Amish Have a Place in the Florida Sun, Too
description: SARASOTA, Fla.The old man squinted down the long shuffleboard court at the cluster of his opponent's disks in scoring positions at the other end.

title: Truth on Tax Reform
description: A moderate reform of the tax laws would correct weaknesses that benefit only the very wealthy and would end privileges granted to certain corporations. Such a reform could be achieved without increasing the taxes paid by the ordinary citizen and would bring in additional Federal revenue of upward of $10 billion. That extra revenue would provide Congress and the country with an alternative to President Nixon's socially regressive budget.

title: Music: Berk Premiere
description: What is a pot that has everything in it? That favorite crosswordpuzzle word: olla. Luciano Berio's Concerto for Two Pianos and Orchestra is an olla. It had its premiere on Thursday night with the New York Philharmonic conducted by Pierre Boulez. It also came to being through Philharmonic auspices as a commission from the society.

title: New Widow Wins $1Million
description: PITTSBURGH, March 16 (UPI)Mrs. Elizabeth M. Nock, 59 years old, won $1million in the Pennsylvania lottery yesterday, two days after her husband was buried.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Will Christian Brothers Academy win its third consecutive state title?

title: KUZMA N. GALITSKY, SOVIET GENERAL
description: MOSCOW, March 16Gen. Kuzma N. Galitsky, former commander of Soviet troops in Poland, died Tuesday in Mos. cow after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: Moyers to Address College
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., March 16 (AP)Bill D. Moyers, television commentator and former Presidential aide, will be the commencement speaker at Virgina Polytechnic Institte on June 9, university officials announced, today.

title: ODDENINO'S OFFER IS MADE BY RANK
description: Merger News

title: Senators Resume Secrecy
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI)  The Senate Finance Committee resumed today its usual practice of meeting in secrecy to draft legislation after giving open sessions short but unproductive trial yesterday. The chairman, Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, said the meeting had to be closed because not enough members attended to form a quorum and without a quorum no vote could be taken on whether to open the meeting.

title: BEAUTIFUL. STORIES FROIM TOM T. HALL
description: Amazingly, Thursday's Carnegie Hall concert by Tom T. Hall, a country singer and song writer who has been around for eight years, was also his first appearance in New York. How the city's supposedly aware promoters and assorted music world wheelerdealers could miss out on this major musical talent is a sad reflection on all concerned.

title: City Opens Drive to Stop State TakeOver of OTB
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city was undertaking an intensive lobbying effort in Albany and across the state to fight the Delafield Commission's proposal that the state take over the city's offtrack betting operations.

title: ASSOCIATED PRESS SHIFTS TOP EDITORS
description: The appointment of Louis D. Boccardi, 35 years old, as executive editor of The Associated Press in control of all news operations was announced yesterday by Wes Gallagher, president and general manager. The post of executive editor has been vacant since the retirement of Alan J. Gould in 1963.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI)  Two contracts total ing more than $31million have been awarded to the electric boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation for over hauling nuclear submarines.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Board of Higher Education voted yesterday to establish New Jersey's first public school of architecture. It will be administered by the Newark College Engineering.

title: CANADA IS URGED BY THIEU TO STAY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 16  President Nguyen Van Thieu strongly urged Can ada today to remain a member of the International Commission of Control 04 Supervision.

title: Bum Bet
description: The recommendations of Governor Rockefeller's study commission on offtrack betting have a fundamental illogic. Its report does show that offtrack betting has hurt attendance at race tracks, to their considerable detriment. But it offers no persuasive reason for believing that a state takeover of such legalized betting would be better in this respect than continued city operation.

title: Superchiet Cars Derailed
description: NEWTON, Kan., March 16 (UPI)  Two cars of Amtrak's ChicagotoLos Angeles SuperchiefEl Capitan derailed west of town today. No one was injured. The baggage car and the Pullman, which left the tracks four miles west of Newton, were at the end of the train. Damage to the tracks and the cars was reported to be minor.

title: CORNELL LOSES, 65, IN HOCKEY TOURNEY
description: BOSTON, March 16 (UPI)Dana Talafous scored a goal with 33 seconds left in a suddendeath overtime to give Wisconsin a 65 victory over Cornell in a semifinal game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey playoff tonight.

title: 4 STATES IN SOUTH STRUCK BY FLOODS
description: GREENWOOD, Miss., March 16 (UPI) Torrential spring rains caused widespread flooding in Mississippi and three other Southern states today, forcing hundreds from their homes, triggering mud and rock slides and snarling commerce.

title: Witness Says Yablonski Was Slain for Alleged Ties to Coal Company
description: ERIE, Pa., March 16 (UPI)The gobetween in the killings of Joseph A. Yablonski and his wife and daughter testified today that he was told that Mr. Yablonski had to be killed because he had sold, out the United Mine Workers to the nation's largest coal company.

title: Wall St. Banker Plans New Swiss Careers
description: Henri L. Froy, a 62yearold investment banker at Abraham & Co., Inc., who is trading Wall Street for Switzerland on April 1, will start two new careers in the process.

title: EDUCATION OFFICE FACES EEL CHECK
description: WASHINGTON, Match 16 (AP)The acting Commissioner of Education, John R. Ottina, said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was investigating some contracts awarded by the Office of Education.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Entries
BALLOT POSITION CITED AT TRIAL
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., March 16I just thought it would be like following St. Peter and the Pope into heaven.

title: British Bill Rates Decline
description: LONDON, March 16 (Reuters)  The average rate at today's tender of British Treasury bills fell to 8.0972 per cent front 8.2244 per cent. The Bank of England kept its minimum lending rate at 8.75 per cent.

title: 76ERS MARK FOR SETBACKS
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 17 (AP)  Elvin Hayes scored a career high of 43 points and blocked two shots in the last two minutes tonight to, lead the Baltimore Bullets to a 120Ilk National. Basketball Association victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Puerto Rico Judges Curbed
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 17 (UPI)The Puerto Rico Supreme Court has ordered island judges to stop telling juries that prosecution witnesses should be presumed to be telling the truth. Associate Justice Carlos V. Davila said Wednesday that the prevailing practice prejudiced the assumption of innocence of an accused person in a trial.

title: Bring Bade the Worn Out Lilacs
description: 1 This year, in early spring, cut the old lilac to the ground, or cut out old stems leaving vigorous growth for building a new plant.

title: 15 NEWSMEN GIVEN CONSERVATION PRIZE
description: The ScrippsHoward Foundation has awarded a total of $10,000 in prizes to 15 newspapermen and women in the 1972 Edward 3. Meeman Conservation Awards, the foundation president, Matt Meyer, announced yesterday.
