description: A car manufactured in the Soviet Union will be shown for the first time in the United States at the 17th International Automobile Show, which opens April 7 at the New York Coliseum,

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Criminals At Large
description: Many first novels contain autobiographical elements. Ted Allheury was a British counterintelligence officer bring World War II. His first novel, A CHOICE OF ENEMIES (St; Martin's, $6.50), is all about counterintelligence and the not so cold war. James Martin is a police sergeant in a city in Ohio. His first novel, THE 95 FILE (Simon & Schuster, $6.95), is all about police work in a city in Ohio.

title: AROUND THE
description: Use dormant oil sprays to kill scale and overwintering insects.... Paint fences.... Have mower serviced and sharpened.... Spread lime on lawn if the grass is dry enough for treading upon.

title: Sloop Lightnin Is Likely Victor At Montego Bay
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 17  Ted Turner spent much of today at the Montego Bay Yacht Club, looking out at the Caribbean for boats that never appeared on the horizon.

title: Nixon's Justice
description: WASHINGTONWe are going to have a crime problem as long as we are willing to put up with it, President Nixon warned the nation last week, and most Americans are not willing to put up with it any longer.

title: Gardens
description: EACH spring a pair of Baltimore orioles nest in a tall tree at the edge of our lawn. To make sure we will not be deprived of these I wonderful Caterpillardevourers, I keep the suet basket supplied for a week or two after we hear their first cheery whistle in early May. As further insurance, I permit a wild grapevine to climb up into one tree at the woods edge. (Orioles consider wild grapes a treat.) And, year after year, they never fail to return to us. We have counted as many as seven flashing orangeandblack bodies around the suet basket at once.

title: Kenneth Clark's revolutionary slogan: Just teach them to read!
description: In the 19 years since Kenneth Clark's study of the baneful effects of segregation was cited in the Supreme Court's 1954 school desegregation decision, no committee concerned with the integration and improvement of New York City's schools has been complete without him. In his undeviating view, the two goals of good schooling and an integrated society go together, and he has often found himself doing battle with black separatists as well as with white segregationists  and, lately, with white liberals who do not share his ideas.

title: Assistant District Attorney Cleared of Sex Crimes Will Get His Job Back
description: District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens said yesterday that a member of his staff who had been accused of sex crimes would be reinstated as the result of the arrest of a man who strongly resembled him and who had confessed to the crimes.

title: TIGERS TURN BACK KAN, STATE, 9272
description: HOUSTON, March 17 (UPI)Larry Finch scored 32 points and put on a dazzling ballhandling exhibition today to lead Memphis State to a 9272 victory over Kansas State and a berth in the semifinals of the National Collegiate basketball tournament for the first time in the school's history.

title: HADDONFIELD FIVE IS JERSEY VICTOR
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 17 Tom Betley and Kevin Eastman led Haddonfield High to the Group I championship of the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association basketball tournament today as they scored 50 points in a 7667 triumph over Orange High.

title: VIETCONG REJECT CHARGES BY NIXON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 17The chief Vietcong delegate to the truce commission today rejetted as groundless charges by President Nixon that the Communists were infiltrating large quantities of men and weapons into South Vietnam in violation of the ceasefire.

title: 3 TIED FOR LEAD IN WOMEN'S GOLF
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 (AP)Shelley Hamlin, the firstround leader in the $25,000 Orange Blossom Classic golf tournament, dropped to a 75 today and wound up in a threeway tie for the lead going into today's final round.

title: MOSCOW AMENDS LAW ON COPYRIGHT
description: MOSCOW, March 17  The Soviet Union has amended its copyright law in an evident attempt to curb the unauthorized outflow of dissident literature.

title: For the WelltoDo Woman, a Place to Ski and Get a Divorce
description: SUIT VALLEY, Idaho (AP)  The welltodo woman with a yen for freedom has discovered Sun Valley as a place to ski and split, a resort where it's almost as easy to break up a marriage in the courts as it is to break a leg on the slopes.

title: The Wine of Absurdity
description: The word absurd has most insistently recurred in the Vituperations against our modern society and in the philosophers' attempts to analyze the sources of today's discontent. For half a century and especially since World War II, the French have recurringly idolized that adjective used as a noun, bestowing a capital A upon it, and developing a whole philosophy around it. To some it has appeared as a symbol of abdication and despair. Others have hailed the sarcastic denunciation of the absurdity in our politics, in our wars, in our economic and ethical lives as a sign of hope in an improved society, which might hopefully turn out to be better attuned to our aspirations as individuals refusing to be dehumanized.

title: Thoughts out of ChinaII Doing it yourself
description: Americans and Russians, French and British, Germans and Italians, and many more, have been vastly surprised and considerably upset by what has happened in Asia in the last two decades. In brief, the centuriesold pattern of a world economically and technologically dominated by Western societies has been smashed to smithereens. The most dramatic development has been the rapid transformation of Japan's ruined, partly handicraft postwar economy into a giant, hightechnical economy. Even today, moreover, with the example of Japan dramatically there to alert us, few have noticed how often impressive results seem to ensue whenever any unit of Asian society ultimately rooted in the ancient Chinese culture begins to do business in a fully modern way. Yet that lesson is abundantly plain from the examples of Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan and formerly impoverished South Korea, and it should also become plain in South Vietnam, if the South Vietnamese ever get the chance to do business in comparative peace.

title: SPANISH DOUBTFUL OF REFORM MOVES
description: MADRID, March 17  Twice in a little over two months the highest authorities of Spain have hinted forthcoming changes in their authoritarian rule.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Sprinklered Risks

title: LATE LEAP SURGE SINKS RANGERS, 7 5
description: TORONTO, March 17The New York Rangers, who needed a victory to regain a secondplace tie with Boston in the National Hockey League's East Division, frittered away a 41 firstperiod lead tonight and then lost to Toronto, 75.

title: Movies
description: FRED WILLIAMSON'S only hero, other than himself, is Muhammad (I'm the greatest) Ali, and it figures. Fred, you see, is very sure of himself. The 35yearold actor has reason to be. First, there are his face and physique, which look as though they were chiseled to order in heaven by Michelangelo for some customer who had requested The Perfect Man. (The only imperfections are two small scars on his forehead, souvenirs of his 10 years as a pro football jock)

title: And a viewed Manhattan
description: They are a very relaxed couple, most comfortable with their shoes off, John Saladino, the designer, says. They wanted beautiful space  not beautiful furnishings. They didn't want to be tied down to possessions. This contemporaryminded pair were the Kenneth Williamsons, who had been drawn to a twobedroom apartment in a new Brooklyn Heights highrise by its view of the island of Manhattan, glistening in the sun by day and glittering like a million jewels by night. Saladino interpreted the Williamsons' wishes by redesigning the space into a landscape for living. It has curves (a conversation platform, a bar enclosed in a well) that add another dimension to the standard apartment rectangles; sweeps of mirror and stainless steel that extend the magnificent view, and a color scheme of plum, berry red, taupe and sepia that provides an earthy warmth and an emotional lift. There was no need for the objects and art that usually form a counterpoint to the neoBauhaus clich of all white space, the designer points out. The result is elegant, simple, warm  and utterly comfortable. A place to come home and put your feet up.

title: Sandra Bushnell to Be Wed June 1
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 17Mr. and Mrs. Clarence W. Bushnell of Bridgeport and South Yarmouth, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Lynn Bushnell, to Lieut. Comdr. Lawrence E. Ronan, U.S.N., son of Mrs. Henry Sikele and Frank Ronan, both of Detroit.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Spring Finery to Bloom Early
description: Emboldened by the exceptionally mild winter with its record rainfall, the floral population of Long Island promises to be bedecked in pring finery as much as two weeks earlier than usual this year.

title: Elissa Bennett Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Bennett. of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elissa Jean Bennett, to Robert C. Bernius, son of Mrs. Charles Bernius of Floral Park, L.I. and the late Mr. Bernius. The prospective bridegroom, an assistant district attorney in Kings County, graduated from Brown University and the Yale Law School. His fiance is a junidr at Elmira College.

title: Suffolk Elections on Tuesday
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.,Voters in Sag Harbor will choose a Mayor Tuesday, ending a campaign fought over the future of the Whaling; Festival and tax increases.

title: Elizabeth A. Fougner to Marry in August
description: MANHASSET, L. I., March 17Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Fougner have announced the engagement of Mr. Fougner's daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Fougner, to Arthur Sherwood Hillhouse 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hillhouse of Colts Neck, N. J. An August wedding is planned.

title: Black Politicians Meet on Candidates
description: The Council of Black Elected Officials jumped into the jockeying for citywide offices yesterday with the first of a series of screening sessions of candidates who are seeking its endorsement for Mayor, Controller and City Council President.

title: New York Schools
description: From any vantage point, the New York City public school systemthe biggest in the nation  is a gigantic enterprise. It has an annual operating budget in excess of $1.6billion, 113,000 employes (including 60,000 teachers) and nearly 1.2 million pupils who attend classes in 1,000 school buildings.

title: Camera World
description: THE Germain. School of Photography, 225 Broadway, will conduct two basic courses in photography that will meet on Saturdays for ten 3hour sessions. The first will be Basic Small Camera (35mm and 214) Techniques, and it will meet Saturday mornings from 9:30 to 12:30. The second will be Basic Darkroom Techniques and it will meet Saturday afternoons from 1:30 to 4:30. Each course will cost $100. Those interested can write the school (New York, N.Y. 10007), or call (212) WO 44550.

title: In the Light of History
description: The English historian J. H. Plumb, whose scholarly specialty is the 18th century, comes about as close to being an 18thcentury intellectual in the breadth of his interests as is humanly possible in our 20thcentury age of specialization. Anyone who doubts this fact will be quickly persuaded by this collection of his recent essays.

title: Latest Nixon heat
description: WASHINGTON, March 17In his press conference the other day, President Nixon confirmed that the North Vietnamese had been sending heavy military equipment into South Vietnam in violation of the truce agree meat, and he issued what could only be regarded as a threat of U.S. retaliation if these violations continued.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Familiar ingredients are here: birth of the cantor's son, sometime in the 1880's in a Lithuanian FiddlerontheRoof shtetl; the family's hazardous emigration to Washington; the breakaway of a teenage Jewish hellion into the vaudevilleminstrel world at the century's turn; his garish success in routine Shubert extravaganzas that somehow turned into ideal vehicles for the great singing clown; his brief career in Jazz Singer talkies; finally his fast decline before his death in 1950. Mr. Freedland, an uninspired profiler, labors grimly on the Janus faces of his subject: the peerless commedia dell arte genius, and the boring offstage hambone crippled all his life by what Robert Sherwood once called elephantiasis of the ego. Both faces are blurred by the heavy brushstrokes.

title: MacPhail Move No Aid to Houk
description: When the Yankees invoked the renewal option clause of the contracts Of Fritz Peterson and Sparky Lyle (who has since signed), it recalled the controversy Ralph Houk created in trying to sign Jim Bouton eight years ago.

title: A fan's notes: Sutherland, Horne, Sills, Nilsson, Price, Farrell
description: The relationship between opera singers and composers has always been uneasily symbiotic at best. They need each other just as, say, the pilot fish needs the shark, or the mold needs the cheese. There is, nonetheless, a continual tugofwar going on between singers and composers, and it has become clear in recent years that singers are once again, as at many moments in music's past, winning the tug. It may be that the comparative scarcity of composers who enjoy writing for the voice and who understand how to do it has helped resuscitate the bel canto era's showiest music and thus restored singers to the godlike prominence they enjoyed in older times. But whatever the explanations, the singer once more rules the opera most.

title: 4 County G.O.P. Chiefs Assail Proposed Alliance With Wagner
description: Four of the city's five Republican county leaders yesterday spoke out strongly against the proposed G.O.P. nomination of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner for his old job.

title: Village Elections on Tuesday
POINT OF VIEW
description: How to evaluate the effectiveness of efforts to improve society of to assess the side effects of economic activities has become a subject of major interest in many corporate board rooms and Government agencies.

title: L.I. Population Is Still on Rise
description: MINEOLA, L. I.The population of Nassau and Suf folk Counties grew last year at more than twice the rate of the national rate to a bicounty total of 2,661,321, the Long Island Lighting Company reported in its annual population survey last week.

title: The greatest poet of the 19th century
description: For the generation between the two world wars, Tennyson was the laureate of the long, shallow sleep of Victoria's reign. One thinks of James Joyce's Alfred Lawn Tennyson or of the dimwitted bard of W. H. Auden's epigram: He had the finest ear, perhaps, of any English poet; he was also undoubtedly the stupidest. These caricatures of Tennyson now strike us as curiosities in the history of criticism, signs of a profound misapprehension of the poet and of his age. Tennyson, of course, remains what he has always beenone of the supreme poets in our languagebut our response to what he wrote is changing radically. In place of the decorous rhymester we have begun to recognize the great symbolist poet, the precursor of Yeats and Eliot, the troubled prophet of Apocalypse who foresaw in King Arthur's last dim weird battle of the West the long of the 20th century.

title: Disks Pass Tapes Video Derby
description: Is RCA going to beat out C.B.S. again? Will Zenith come up with a competing system? What about Sony? Will it be tape or disks? What will the speed be? Will the systems be compatible?

title: Contributions
description: WASHINGTONFour months after the Nixon landslide, money is still moving in and out of the President's Reelection Campaign Committee. But it is not the record, amountnearly $50million collected, nearly $5million left overthat keeps the issue in the headlines. The intriguing questions are: Why did the committee recently return $655,000 to three big contributors? Why, long after the election was over and the giant surplus was wellknown, did an additional. $246,000 dribble into the Nixon treasury in January and February?

title: 11 Primary Races Form for AtLarge Council Posts
description: Eleven primary contests have already, developed for 10 CouncilmenatLarge seats to be decided this year. Assemblymen, a former Supreme Court Justice and other state office holders are trying to unseat all but one of the incumbents at City Hall.

title: ExChief of Price Unit Returning to Old Job
description: DALLAS, March 17 (AP)Dr. C. Jackson Grayson, former head of the nowdefunct Phase 2 Price Commission, will return to Southern Methodist University April 1.

title: Old Tools Restore 1790 Home
description: WATER MILL, L. I.Adjacent to the mill from which this village takes Its name is a rambling Colonial structure that served as the miller's home until the 20th century. The only thing new about the house is that for the last 10 years, a miller has once again been in residence, but this time the miller is a woman.

title: The Case for Congress
description: The power of Congress to appropriate money and ultimately to control how that money is spent is the foundation of all legislative power. In the evolution of selfgovernment, fierce battles were fought in England between the House of Commons and the king to determine financial control. In this country, Congressional supremacy on fiscal matters is clearly set forth in the Constitution and in the Federalist papers.

title: MISTERY DISEASE KILLS MIAMI FISH
description: MIAMI, March 17Thousands of fish have been killed by a mysterious disease slowly spreading from a point in Biscayne Bay, about 20 miles south of downtown Miami.

title: Leaving the Public Holding the Bag
description: THE current editorial outcry against assaults by the Nixon Administration on influential newspapers and their reporters and on television news and public affairs programs has largely ignored the interests of a third party, one which has the greatest stake of all in how news is interpreted and disseminatedthe public.

title: Music: Visiting Bamberg Orchestra
description: As ensembles come and go in Carnegie Hairs perpetual International Festival of Visiting Orchestras, one sometimes gets the feeling, that they have all been assembled on the same production line and that there are no significant differences to distinguish one from another.

title: Domestic Noble Savages
description: American writers and readers in a new mood of cultural pluralism and communalism have turned to Indian matters with great enthusiasm. No longer can it be truthfully said, as it was only 10 years ago, that Indian books sell mainly to children and a few academic cases of arrested development. The standard compilation by Charles J. Kappler of Indian Treaties 17781833 published in 19Q4, can be reprinted at a very high price (Interland Publishing, 799 Broadway, New York, N.Y. $67.50) for the many schools, libraries, lawyers, scholars and political activists, Indian and nonIndian, who now really need the reference work. Volumes whose real content is otherwise are touted by publishers and authors as part of the newlypopular genre of Indian protest books.

title: Paul Connolly to Wed Miss Horgan
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., March 17Miss Geraldine Horgan and Paul Brian Connolly will be married July 14 in New York.

title: Numismatics
description: THIS session of Congress seems to be offering real reason to hope for enactment of a Federal law to protect collectors against fraud. Past efforts to obtain legislation prohibiting the manefacture and sale of unmarked replicasusually failed to get beyond the billintroduction stage. Now there are two Hobby Protection bills pending before a subcommittee of the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce. They have already been the subject of an open hearing and qualified observers say that the bills have a good chance of being reported the full committee.

title: Bridge
description: Those who are puzzled by the term doubledummy, vihich simply refers to the development of the play that would be expected if all the players could see all the cards, may find enlightenment in the diagrammed deal. But first try a fourpart test.

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: FRIDAY'S PLAYOFF GAMES

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Permits for play on most of the city's 522 tennis courts will go on sale tomorrow at the Parks Administration's five borough offices for the season beginning April 7 and ending Nov. 25. The offices will be open, weekdays from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. and, through June 30, on Saturdays from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M.

title: L.I. Farms See Little Help State Plan
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I.A New York State law designed togive farmers a tax break may have little impact on the current move to save Long Island's rapidly diminishing agricultural industry.

title: 19 in Pennsylvania Are Indicted In Claims for Federal Flood Aid
description: SCRANTON, Pa., March 17 An investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation has resulted in 19 indictments against individuals, mostly from the WilkesBarre area, who obtained various forms of flood assistance from the Federal Government after the tropical storm Agnes hit that area last June.

title: Recordings
description: THE silent departure of Leopold Stokowski from American musical life after over 60 years is, or should be, a sobering event. Colorful, controversial, innovative, seem like paltry adjectives to describe Stokowski's contributions to our musical awareness over three generationsthe list of major 20thcentury works that he introduced, the orahestras he trained, his recordings, the uniqueness of his musical personality all add up to an incalculable legacy that cannot possibly be described here.

title: Suddenly in Bucharest There's Snow and Confusion
description: BUCHAREST, March 17 Last year in midMarch flowers were sprouting in Bucharest, sidewalk cafes were beginning to reappear, and some fortunate people were heading off to nearby lakes for weekend sunbathing. But now, this Balkan capital is reeling from its worst snowfall in two decades.

title: Paterson Minorities Get Voice on WPAT
description: PATERSON  Listeners to WPAT are finding that something has been added to the station's usual diet of walltowall, middleoftheroad music with a dash of news. On Sundays, the station is presenting an hour and a half of state and local news and a bit of music in the morning and a twohour telephone and talk show in the evening. And during the week, WPAT is including special reports on Paterson in its morning news broadcasts.

title: Stamps
description: THE United Nations, moving on what is for the organization a new front in the battle against the evils that beset mankind, is buttressing a campaign against drug abuse with a new issue of commemoratives coming out on April 13.

title: Democrats in Senate Plan Budget to Counter Nixon's
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Senate Democrats, fighting to gain the initiative in the spending dispute between the President and Congress, are preparing their own budget for the 1974 fiscal year.

title: 16 Elections Set for Westchester on tuesday
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 17Controversies over land development, taxes and other local issues mark 16 contested village elections in Westchester County this Tuesday. Party control is at stake in 12 of the villages, including all five in which the Democrats now have a majority on the Village Bolds of Trustees.

title: Presidential Issues
description: WASHINGTONCongress and the President had been sparring for months over such weighty matters as control of the public purse and the use of war powers. Last week they were slugging it out over a littleunderstood and seemingly mundane issue called executive privilege.

title: Lili DarvasA Movie Star Is Born at 70
description: Do you know Lili Darvas? a woman of the local Hungarian colony once asked another. No, wasthe excited reply, but I'm the best friend of her worst enemy!

title: SHOP TALK
description: EAST HANOVER  You can live happily without ever owning a single original sculpture. But when a fine, small piece Of art fashioned from wood, metal or stone is available for little more than the cost of two cartons of cigarettes the temptation to buy it is often too great to resist.

title: In Cold Print: Where Books Go When They Die
description: Avery Gorman, author of the very funny novel, Oh God, is the only writer I know who ever rejected a rejection slip. We are sorry to inform you, he wrote The New Yorker, that your rejection slip does not meet our editorial needs. I thought of Avery the other day when I talked with John Nelson, PrenticeHall's subsidiaryrights man, who had just dictated a formletter to 40 PrenticeHall authors, informing them that their books were about to be remaindered and if they wished to purchase any or all at cost, they should act now.

title: 2 Brothers Are Accused Of Murders of 2 Men Here
description: Two brothers were charged yesterday with murdering two persons and injuring three others in a fight in a Washington Heights apartment building, the police reported.

title: Opera: New Faces in Roserikavalier
description: There, were many new faces in the season's first Rosenkavalier at the Metropolitan  Opera, on Friday night, and the two prettiest were those of Yvonne Minton of Octavian and Judith Biegen as Sophie. Miss Minton, the Australian mezzo, was making her debut with the company, and Miss Biegen was singing her first Sophie on any stage. The conductor, Christoph von Dohnanyi; Also was new; he has appeared previously at the Met, but never in this Strauss opera.

title: Cards Errors Are Costly
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17What will it take for the Mets to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates for the Easterr championship? Tom Seaver asked today, echoing the big question of spring training here. It'll take a maximum effort by our regulars and especially by our pitchersnothing less.

title: Miss Scott Plans Bridal
description: WESTON, Mass., March 17 Miss Margaret Anne Scott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis D. Scott, plans to be married to Peter Kley Wittman of North White Plains, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Franz Wittman of Ambler, Pa.

title: Argentine Election Allegiance
description: That Will

title: GUILFORD CAPTURES N.A.I.A. TITLE, 9996
description: KANSAS CITY, March 17 (AP)Guilford, N. C., had to rally twice to beat MarylandEastern Shore, 9996, tonight and win the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball championship.

title: A Quiet Prelude to the Commuting Day
description: To make the 7:27 to New York City comfortably, I get up at 6 A.M. By comfortably I mean having time to park, buy The Times and still be first in line on the station platform at a point where, I have calculated, the train door will stop. Even though it is 12 miles from my home in Weston to the Westport station and the suburban traffic is brutally urban in its density, I do not need an hour and 27 minutes for the mechanical necessities.

title: Home, Repair Clinic
description: Questions from readers about home repair problems should be addressed to: Home. Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N. Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered in this column.

title: CERVANTES STOPS LOCCHE IN TENTH
description: MARACAY, Venezuela, March 17 (AP)Antonio Cervantes retained his World Boxing Association junior welterweight title with a technical knockout over Nicolino Locche of Argentina tonight. A crowd of 10,000 watched the bout.

title: Oral Roberts to Be Speaker At Hall of Fame Ceremony
description: Oral Roberts, the evangelist, will deliver the main address April 26 when Elmer Ripley, Dolph Schayes, Bruce Drake, Dutch Lonborg and the late John Beckman will be inducted into the National Basketball Hall of Fame at Springfield, Mass.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONFor a case historyof all that can go wrong with a major military weapon contract, nothing quite compares with the story of Tomcat, the carrierbased fighter that seems to have nine lives, each one progressively more expensive. Its rescue this month, by means of a deal between the Navy and the Grumman Aerospace Corp., was only the latest such episode.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: A record number of apartment completions in the country is predicted for 1973 although starts will decline from a record last year, according to the Advance Mortgage Corporation.

title: Kerr on The Tooth of Crime
description: YOU are free to move as you wish during the playing of Sam Shepard's The Tooth of Crime at the Performing Garage down on Wooster Street, either trailing the actors closely as they rove in and on and about Jerry Rojo's bridgework structure supported by pylons and pocked with open spaces or keeping your distance by climbing, to ropedoff balcony platforms where you can let your feet dangle over the arena. There are no fixed audience positions and, on the night I attended, the audience did dissolve, billow, reform freely as the action shifted turf, sometimes settling itself on stage properties that had to be quickly vacated when headlong performers charged at them.

title: Politicians Take Strategic Stand at Parade, in Annual Maneuver
description: Politicians equally familiar at a fiesta or a bar mitzvah infused the St. Patrick's Day parade yesterday with their own peculiar sort of blarney.

title: CATHY CARR WINS 2 SWIM CROWNS
description: MOSCOW, Idaho, March 17 (AP)Records fell in all five swimming events at the national women's collegiate swimming and diving championships last night at the University of Idaho. Two of the records were set by the Olympic gold medalist, Cathy Carr of the University of New Mexico.

title: A's Reported Trading Blue to Rangers
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 17  Speculation arose anew today over a trade that would make Vida Blue a Texas Ranger in the next few days.

title: Coliseum Bars Raiders Seeking Playoff Dates
description: In a hardline action, Nassau County refused yesterday to let the New York Raiders of the World Hockey Association play in the Nassau Coliseum.

title: U. of Arkansas Gets Its First Black Coach
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (UPI)  The University of Arkansas confirmed today that it had hired its first black coach. He is Frank Falks, a football assistant, who was formerly offensive line coach at Kansas State.

title: Rugg Installed as Chief Of Power Squadrons
description: The United States Power Squadrons installed David A. Rugg of Middletown, N. J., as District 4 Commander yesterday at the annual meeting in Newark. District 4 is composed of 15 squadrons, of which four are from the city and 11 from northern and central New Jersey.

title: Condos Get Foothold on Long Island...
description: CORAM, L. I.Condominiums are sprouting in the fertile soil et central Long lsland, and their developersfresh from a roasting in the field of rental apartmentssay they are the suburban housing of the future.

title: The Region
description: Governor Rockefeller, Alex Rose and the folks who gave you Republican John Lindsay to turn the city around in 1965  after 12 years of Democrat Robert F. Wagner  last week offered up their mayoral candidate for 1973: Robert F. Wagner.

title: U.N.Names French Diplomat To Head Bangladesh Relief
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 17  Francis Lacoste, former French Ambassador to Belgium, has been appointed special representative of the Secretary General and will become the director of the relief office in Bangladesh. His appointment becomes effective April 1.

title: Notes: Hawaii Hotel Probe
description: STATE investigation has been undertaken in Hawaii into what may be one of the worst cases of hotel overbooking on record. It took place in Honolulu during the long Lincoln's and Washington's Birthday weekends. Thousands of tourists with reserved rooms arrived to find the rooms occupied, and in an emergency appeal, Hawaiian homeowners were asked to put up 500 visitors for whom no other space was available.

title: Land Cost Imperils Park Plan In Suffolk
description: MONTAUK, L.I.The price of some 1,000 acres of prime, virgin park land at land's end here that Suffolk County wants to acquire has nearly doubled in the last year, according to appraisals obtained by Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein.

title: Hias Elects a President
description: The election of Carl Glick, investment broker, as president of United Hias Service, the worldwide Jewish immigration agency, was announced last night.

title: Mission to Moscow
description: MOSCOWThe talks with the Russians, Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz told Western correspondents here last Wednesday, were serious, professional ... I tried to explain the nature of the problem as we see it ... the character of the American political process involving interaction between the President and Congress.

title: Susan Feldman Plans June Bridal
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., March 17Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Feldman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Feldman, to Richand Mark Greene, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul T. Greene of Kings Point.

title: Troy Sees Opportunity In Lindsay Withdrawal
description: On March 7, in the Blue Room of City Hall, Mayor Lindsay, dapper in a gray suit, blue shirt and red tie, told a jostling, videolighted press: I will not seek a third term.

title: Hankinson, Manakas Head AllIvy Basketball Squad
description: Princeton, N.J., March 17 Phil Hankinson of Pennsylvania and Ted Manakas of Princeton were unanimously named to the allIvy League basketball team today by the league's eight coaches.

title: The Amnesty of John David Herndon
description: In his several articles on amnesty over the past two years James Reston Jr. has made a special effort to illuminate the case of the military deserter. The Amnesty of John David Herndon is essentially a commissioned work in that cause, done at the suggestion of Safe Return, an American group aiding exiled servicemen and draft resisters. The original design called for Reston to chronicle the return from France of one testcase deserter, who would hopefully receive a fullscale courtmartial at which he could offer a Nuremberg defense of his refusal to accept reassignment to Vietnam.

title: Robert Lawson
description: Illustrators may be treated as artists and their output as works of art. Few illustrators, of course, are worthy to be discussed at this level. In such a domain only a Goya is qualified to participate. Most illustrators and this includes very good ones indeed, must be regarded as craftsmen. Whatever the degree of their skill, these craftsmen also vary in their ability to depict character. Briefly, an illustration is to be regarded first for its merit as a picture, second for the skill required to make it, last for the quality of the depiction of persons and things in the text.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Maryland recently became the first state to ban the use of lead shot while waterfowling.

title: Many people, one at a time
description: Any Auden poem is a miscellany; Auden's form is the miscellany. A few years ago he published his Commonplace Book: odd things that had caught his eye, alphabetically arranged. The alphabet confers a look of order, but so whimsically does spelling render phoneme and phoneme encompass designation that you never knew what you'd find on the next page.

title: New and Recommended
description: GRAVITY'S RAINBOW, by Thomas Pynchon. (Viking, $15; paper, $4.95.) This apocalyptic comedy by the author of V. takes off on V2 rockets, paranoia, the love of death and modern historyone the longest, most difficult, most ambitious American novels in years.

title: CRISIS IN 2 STATES IRKS MRS. GANDHI
description: NEW DELHI, March 17Political turmoil in two Indian states has jolted the Government and thwarted Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's efforts cement her power across nation.

title: ACROSTIC PUZZLE
description: Guess the words defined below and write them over their numbered dashes. Then transfer each letter to the correspondingly numbered square in the pattern. Black squares Indicate word endings. The filled pattern will contain a quotation reading from left to right. The first letters of the guessed words will form an acrostic giving author's name and title of work.

title: A n Expert on Taxes Accuses Ehrlichman Of Demagoguery
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Philip M. Stern, a philanthropist and tax expert, charged this week that it was sheer demagoguery to argue that the only tax reforms that would raise large amounts of money are those that would hurt the average taxpayer.

title: Dance
description: THIS Thursday, the City Center Joffrey Ballet will present the first American performance of Parade, a 56yearold ballet whose reputation as the landmark modernist ballet rests primarily upon the reputation of its creators: Pablo Picasso, Jean Cocteau, Erik Satie and Leonide Massine.

title: The Changing Room: Something Like Magic . . .
description: FOLLOWING, David Storey's mysterious and ultimately mesmerizing The Changing Room is like watching the evolution of life on the planet, The evolution and then the disappearance. The play is about a room, a space, an initial void. Four moldering green wallsmore fungus than paintframe an emptiness, into which the first sluglike forms of life move hesitantly. A feeble attendant, whose face has sourly congealed about the fear in his eyes, pushes a broom into the waiting world, brushing dust before him, pausing to put down towels for the more vigorous animals who will follow him.

title: Colbert Gains 2Shot Edge at 206
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 17 (AP)  Jim Colbert, who holed a long sand shot for an eagle 3, at the fourth hole, carded a 71 today and gained a twostroke lead after the third round of the $130,000 Greater Jacksonville open golf tournament.

title: BLACK STUDENTS GET SCHOLARSHIP
description: EVANSTON, Ill., March 17The names of 347 black high school students who have won scholarships awarded by the National Achievement Scholarship Program for Outstanding Negro Students have been announced by Edward C. Smith, president of the National Merit Scholarship Corporation.

title: Riparian Rights
description: TRENTON  Thousands of homeowners and hundreds of businesses in more than a dozen northern New Jersey communities were threatened last week when the state served notice it is at last ready to stake its claim on all riparian land whose title had devolved upon the state from the Crown of England.

title: How to Explain the Flood of Realist Art?
description: SOMETHING like a realist revival has lately become such a conspicuous phenomenon in American painting that by now it needs, as they say, no introduction. It is an accomplished fact whose dimensions seem larger every time one pauses to measure them. Having noted the fact, one is left with the task of trying to make some sense of it, a task made difficult by a confusing variety of general modes and individual styles. Some of these modes and styles are apparently traditionminded and some are apparently novel, butthough brash PhotoRealism has gotten the most publicitynone seems clearly dominant.

title: Suharto Dedicates Building
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 17 (AP)President Suharto has dedicated a 17story building in honor of veterans of Indonesia's struggle for independence from Dutch rule between 1945 and 1949. The $3.6million building was opened this week.

title: HERBERT STRAUSS, AD OFFICIAL, DIES
description: Herbert D. Strauss, senior executive officer of Grey Advertising, Inc., died of a heart attack yesterday in his apartment in St. Thomas, Virgin Islands. He was 63 years old and also had a home here.

title: Antiques: Princeton Show
description: PRINCETON  Antique dealers from as far away as Illinois, Ohio and New Hampshire will take part in the annual Princeton Antiques Show opening Wednesday with a 6 to 9 P.M. preview.

title: Where the Trolleys Stop
description: When in Vienna, do as the Viennese do: get out at the trolley's last stop and walk in the woods. See Page 3. And to learn where the Viennese walk, see Page 11.

title: The Americanization of Sony
description: The Sony Corporation, long regarded by many people as the epitome of the Japanese export success story, is going multinational.

title: Jail Terms Deplete Ranks of Hell's Angels
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 17 The Hell's Angels, the motorcycle gang whose violence satisfying their appetites once spread terror in this state, have fallen on hard times.

title: If I Were a Nell, I'd Be Singing
description: WHAT the dickens do you do after you've done a musical version of Mark Twain's Tom Sawyer? Simpleyou do a musical version of Charles Dickens's The Old Curiosity Shop. That's why Readers Digest, which branched out into moviemaking with the tuneful Tom now at the Music Hall, is preparing to put Little Nell and her dear old Grandaddy through their musical paces.

title: Assembly of Bishops Urges Defense of Human Rights in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 15 Brazil's bishops, in their strongest and most detailed declaration of human rights, have denounced various types of discrimination in this country and the limitation on basic freedoms here.

title: Sanguillen Excels in Field
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. March 17The Pittsburgh Pirates put their new right fielder. on display against the Yankees today and he promptly resembled the old one.

title: Democrats Pick Aide
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)Representative Ralph H. Metcalfe, Democrat of Illinois, has been elected secretary of the Democratic Study Groups, a group of 165 liberal Democratic House members. He said that the group will continue to keep the liberal members of the Congress informed and mobilized as to the most effective manner to influence legislation which will be coming before the Congress.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  Notwithstanding suggestions to the contrary, the work ethic is alive and very well indeed in the United States. The reason: It has been receiving large doses of the best of all possible tonicsjobs. With the economy now in full stride after recovering from the recession that hit bottom in November, 1970; the helpwanted sign is rapidly replacing the padlocked plant gate.

title: Miss Bennett To Be Bride
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 17  Miss Maureen Bridget Elizabeth Bennett and Capt. Frederic Edward Joseph Helbig, Medical Corps, U.S.A., will be married May 26 in St. Joseph's Raman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Rand Study Predicts Gains From Cable Television
description: The Rand Corporation, in research study undertaken for the National Science Flundation, has concluded that in time, cable television May Influence the way we, live as, radically as the automobile and the telephone have done.

title: Daughter for the Aliens
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth H. Allen of Darien, Conn., last Sunday in St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford. Mrs. Allen is the former Miss Linda Aaronson. The child, whose father is a program administrator on the corporate staff of the International Business Machines Corporation, is named Katherine Elizabeth.

title: CITY BRIDGE PLAYERS SUFFER A REVERSAL
description: ST. LOUIS, March 17  A team of New York bridge experts suffered a remarkable reversal of fortune in the Vanderbilt Cup contest here yesterday.

title: HiFi
description: PIERRE BOULEZ loves it for its definition of polyphonic textures. Leonard Bernstein says, God bless it, if it will revive the sales of classical records, and the interest in good music on records. But Lorin Maazel speaks darkly of frustrated engineers who haven't the talent to be conductors themselves and who like to twirl knobs and play god.

title: Consumers Mobilizing for a War on Food Prices
description: RIVER EDGE  Women throughout the state are eagerly joining a loosely knit confederation dedicated to lowering food prices.

title: Gethin Betters Lap Record In Formula 5000 Victory
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, March 17 (Reuters)  Peter Gethin of Britain posted a runaway victory in the opening auto race of the Rothman's Formula 5,000 European championship series today.

title: MYAKKA PRINCE WINS PACING SERIES FINAL
description: WESTBURY, L. I., March 17 Myakka Prince won the $25,000 final of the Spring Pacing Series by threequarters of a length tonight in 2:02, 2/5 at Roosevelt Raceway. Buddy Gilmour drove the 5yearold bay gelding.

title: Peter Watt Fiance Of Abby Naitove
description: HANOVER, N. H., March 17Dr. Arthur Naitove, associate professor of surgery at the Dartmbuth Medical School, and Mrs. Naitove have amounted the engagement of their daughter, Miss Abby Naitove, to Peter Stuart Watt, son of Squadron Leader W. W. Watt, R.A.F., retired, and Mrs.. Watt of Peterborough, England. The wedding is planned for August in Fulmer, England.

title: Welkind: Help Comes First
description: CHESTER Things have calmed down a bit at the Welkind Neurological Hospital, but the staff of the 32bed institution on a quiet Chester hillside is still Winking from the glare of sudden recent nationwide publicity.

title: Turkish Election.
description: ANKARAThe Turkish armed forces are good at military intelligence, but they don't know much about political intelligence, said a member of the Grand National Assembly (Parliament) last week. The observation seemed to go to the root of the governmental crisis that mounted swiftly in the past five days to a tense political impasse.

title: Quadruplets in Illinois Die; Were Born Prematurely
description: JOLIET, Ill., March 17 (AP) Three remaining quadruplets born to a Joliet couple died this morning of respiratory problems.

title: DR. HALSEY L. RAFFMAN
description: Dr. Halsey L. Raffman, a dentist who patented several Xray accessories, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived here and in Palm Beach.

title: French ElectionA Vote forModerateChange
description: PARISAfter the sometimes harsh election campaign, French politicians settled down last week to a surprisingly easy consensus on what the country wants and how to go about providing it.

title: The Company and the Union
description: When asked in 1898 what labor wanted, Samuel Gompers answered, More. That succinct philosophy expressed the then universal desire to participate in the American dream of affluence and abundance. It is a philosophy that still dominates the American labor movement. For with few exceptions, the major industrial unions today are concerned exclusively with dollars and cents. They neglect worker health and safety as well as the critical, emerging issue of the nature of the workplacethe problem of meaningless, dreary, repetitive work.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The recent advent of environmentalism in the United States has often brought about a negative reaction from corporate management. But in some companies it has created a new breed of corporate officer whose function is to deal solely with environmentalcontrol issues.

title: Inquiry on Horse Roundup Ends; Cruelty Complaint Is Weighed
description: BOISE, Idaho, March 17A twoweek Federal investigation of the controversial February roundup of a herd of about 40 horses on public lands in the rugged Lemhi Mountains has been completed and sent to Washington.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE DOLLAR eased slightly after six Common Market countries floated their currencies jointly. West Germany is pegging the mark to Special Drawing Rights, each equivalent to 888871 grams of gold, although the mark will continue to be quoted against the dollar.... Gold in London closed at $82.75 vs. $82.87 a week earlier.... Foreignexchange markets will reopen tomorrow.

title: Canada's Foreign Secretary Says CeaseFire in Laos Renews Hopes for Peace
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 17 Mitchell W. Sharp, Canada's Secretary for External Affairs, said today that the ceasefire signed here last month, had kindled renewed expectations for peace in Laos.

title: Experts on Power Schooled on Safety
description: CRANFORD  In the last 10 years, more than 5,000 electricians and electrical engineers from every state in the nation and from 45 foreign countries have spent a week or two here learning about preventive medicine for sophisticated electrical systems.

title: Girl Scouts Learning Karate
description: HUNTINGTON STATION, L. I.A group of Girl Scouts here, who share with their male counterparts the motto Be Prepared, are learning karate from a Suffolk County policeman.

title: MEDICAL SOLUTION RECALLED IN INQUIRY
description: MILWAUKEE, March 17 The Federal Food and Drug Administration has disclosed that Cutter Laboratories of Berkeley, Calif., is recalling 6,463 bottles of an intravenous solution manufactured at the company's plant in Chattanooga, Tenn.

title: Art
description: AMONG the abstract painters whose work nowadays commands a special attention, one of the most accomplished is Agnes Martin. Although highly regarded by critics and collectors of diverse commitments, her paintings have somehow failed to ignite that spark of ideological fervor that seems a necessary ingreshent, if not to the making of firstrate art, at least to the making of a firstrate reputation. Thus, the recent exhibition organized by Suzanne Delehanty at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia will not be coming to New York. It is now en route to California, where it will be seen at the Pasadena Art Museum from April 3 to May 27.

title: Elizabeth Burke Bride in Captial Of Lewis I. Dale
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 Miss Elizabeth Gordon Burke and Lewis Ingram Dale, staff assistants in the White House personnel office, were married here this afternoon in St. David's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Luther Miller Jr.

title: Delhi's Wedding Season Proceeds Unabated Despite Handicaps
description: NEW DELHI  The wedding season has invaded Delhi. Caravans of swaying kerosene lamps nightly light the roads, leading grooms, on jeweled mares to their brides.

title: Son to Mrs. Messinger
description: A son was born March 8 to Mr. and Mrs. Barry W. Messinger at Beth Israel Hospital here. The child has been named. Samuel Edward. Mrs. Messinger is the former Lynda Langfeld of Washington. Mr. Messinger is assistant legislative counsel for the Motion Picture Association of America.

title: Women Play Big Roles In Bronx K. C. Show
description: Women's Lib has reached the Bronxthat is the Bronx Kennel Club. After 59 years, there is a woman president, Mrs. Debbie Lynn Bowden.

title: Mary Munsche Fiancee of G. H. Stanton
description: ?? for Biatran orpnans flown to the Ivory Coast during the Nigerian war. There she met her fianc, who was in Africa with the Peace Corps.

title: Hanoi Hilton Cells Clear of P.O.W.'s 1st Time in 8 Years
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 17Pieces of dirty prison clothes, a pile of wellread books, some graffiti and memories were all that was left today, of American war prisoners at the Hanoi Hilton.

title: Learning to Love. Floating Rates
description: LONDONLess than two years ago it was, an article of faith of the United States Administration that the dollar could not be devalued.

title: In the Land of the Fumaroles and Williwaws
description: THE Valley of Ten Thousand Smokes up north in cold Alaska was one of the hottest places on earth when Robert Fiske Griggs discovered it in 1916. It was so spectacular he was afraid no one would believe his story. He had found a valley 20 miles in length blowing scalding steam hundreds of feet into the, air from hundreds of thousands of vents. The ground was so hot a man could make a new vent, or fumarole, simply by poking a hole in the earth. He could cook his food just by burying the pot.

title: Sentence Is an Essay
description: MIDDLEBORO, Mass., March 17 (AP)Gary Henderson of Taunton, who allegedly called several policemen pigs at a Middleboro night club, was ordered Tuesday by a District Court judge to write a 500word essay on the duties of a police officer.

title: Bill Asks Abolition Of Fixed Milk Floor
description: TRENTON  A bill that would eliminate the pricesetting powers of the state Division of Dairy Industry will be ready for study by members of the Legislature when they return to work tomorrow.

title: Beryllium Dust Bitterest Issue in Pennsylvania Strike
description: HAZLETON, Pa.  Labor stag is nothing new to this aging coal town, set like a lusterless stone in the filigree of playedout mines and coalstripped valleys in the northern reaches of Appalchic. Like most of the other towns in coal country, Hazleton has had its share of trouble and its men have grown grudgingly accustomed to fear of death and disaster.

title: David Bruce Maxwell Marries Miss Kathryn Anne Winkhaus
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., March 17  Miss Kathryn Anne Winkhaus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Theodore Winkhaus, was married here this afternoon to David Bruce Maxwell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Douglas Maxwell of Glen Head. The ceremony was performed in St. John's of Lattingtowrl Episcopal Church, by the Rev. Howard M. Lowell, the rector.

title: New Boss Has Angels' Blessing
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 17 (AP)Bobby Winklesspent 280 hours during the winter writing and organizing a 70page playbook for the California Angels.

title: Black Becomes Judge
description: BOSTON, March 17, (AP) David S. Nelson, a black leader from Boston's Roxbury section, took the oath as a. Superior Court associate justice Thursday before an overflow gathering in the House chamber. He had been an assistant attorney general, in charge of the consumer protection division.

title: Merle Haggard Sings At Mrs. Nixon's Party
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)With a backdrop of the American flag, Merle Haggard, the country, singer, dedicated a poem to Mrs. Richard M. Nixon as she celebrated her 61st birthday on St. Patrick's Day in the White House.

title: Some Soviet Provinces Report Food Shortages
description: MOSCOW, March 17Scattered disruptions in the supply of bread and potatoes and other essentials are being reported from Soviet provincial areas.

title: RUDY TURCOTTE IS WINNER, TOO
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., March 17 (AP)  East Acres' Alma North took the lead down the stretch and won the 22d running of the $25,400 Betsy Ross Stokes for fillies and mares at Garden State Park today.

title: Monticello Seeking Delay In April 12 Track Opening
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., March 17  Leon Greenberg, president of Monticello Raceway, has asked the State Harness Racing Commission to postpone the scheduled April 12 opening of the harness track because of a dispute with a union representing parimutuel clerks, cashiers and other track workers.

title: Arthur Daley
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17The saddest words Ted Simmons ever heard on a baseball diamond were spoken in somewhat kindly fashion by Doug Harvey, the umpire. They were directed at the then 18yearold Simmons, a rookie catcher for the St. Louis Cardinals, in his first time at bat in the big leagues.

title: Susan McNeily Plans Nuptials
description: TENAFLY, N. J., March 17 Mr. and Mrs. Peter W. G. McNeily have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan M. McNeily to Bradley P. Craig, son of Mrs. W. Emerson Craig of Longmeadow, Mass., and the late Mr. Craig.

title: Heroin hunger may not a mugger make
description: Nelson A. Rockefeller, like a lot of ordinary citizens, appears to believe that most of the muggings and other violent crimes on the streets of New Yqrk are committed by heroin addicts. Tens of thousands of innocent victims, the Governor recently told the solons of Albany, are robbed, mugged and murdered by those addicted who have to get money to support their habit. The Governor was defending his controversial proposal to lock up drug pushers and violent addicts for lifea proposal so controversial that 67 per cent of the 1,549 Americans who were asked about it by the Gallup poll thought it was a fine idea.

title: Brustein in London
description: ANY description of English theater today would have to take notice of how firmly rooted it is in a tradition of social realismby which I mean a preoccupation with the politics, morals, and manners of middleor workingclass life, treated with attention to surface authenticity.

title: OTB Bettors Like Status Quo
description: What is the reaction from people who would be most affected to the Delafield Commission report on horse racing in New York State?

title: Things Questions, People
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Here are some lists. Each is material for a trenchant, even devastating newspaper column at grips with the intensest kind of reality. This is the chance for you, reader, An exercise that lazy mind. Find out what it is to be your own columnist. After studying each list, mentally compose your own columns as suggested by the material.

title: Horse Show Course Designer To Speak at Forum Tomorrow
description: The Professional Horsemen's Association will hold its annual forum tomorrow night at the Belmont Plaza Hotel with Mrs. Pam Canuthem of England the featured speaker. Mrs. Carruthers, probably the best known course designer in Europe, will lead an open discussion on her specialty after she finishes her talk. Mrs. Carruthers, who won the American Horse Shows Association course design competition in 1971, has designed courses for the National Horse Show here for the past five years.

title: Highway Fund
description: WASHINGTONOn the surface, the Senate debate last week concerned $850milliona paltry sum in an $18billion, threeyear highway construction bill. But the issue was really the shape of the Government's transportation policy for many years to come, and that was what brought a herd of lobbyists and some careful political maneuvering to the back rooms of the Capitol.

title: EAST BLOG EASING CURBS ON TRAVEL
description: MUNICH, West Germany, March 16  Any Westerner working in Eastern Europe quickly learns that travel to the West is a major preoccupation. He also discovers that the Communist authorities are slowly and cautiously giving in to this increasing demand, though maintaining strict controls.

title: A Dire Threat of Famine
description: NEW DELHI  The rains did not come plentifully enough last summer and India waits anxiously for the next monsoon season, June to September. A bad monsoon this year means famine, a Western farm expert here said.

title: Legs Snake OutDance Eplodes
description: YOU can call the City Center Joffrey Ballet modish, and many people do, especially those perhaps snobbishly inclined, but it is also possibly more alert and responsive to the immediate needs of the New York ballet audience than any other of our dance companies. This is certainly not the same as saying that it is the best. But perhaps case could be thade for it being the most brashly lively.

title: Niagara Mohawk Seeking A Rise in Electric Rates
description: SYRACUSE, March 17 (UPI) The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation has asked the Public Service Commission for an electric rate increase totaling more than $35million a year.

title: Asia's Poor: Miiizons in Despair
description: Following is the first of a series of articles on the impact of development programs in southern Asia.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 125 bookstores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Seventh Avenue manufacturers and, other apparel producers will find themselves in a serious price squeeze this summer and fall as a result of the rising costs and growing shortage of fibers and fabrics.

title: Artists in Schools Prove a Success
description: TRENTONIn more than 100 schools throughout New Jersey, students are learnTing about the world of art from the people who create it.

title: The Legislature: Round Two
description: TRENTON  After spending three weeks in recess while the Joint Legislative Appropriations Committee reviewed Governor Cahill's proposed $2.4billion budget and a bipartisan state apportionment commission redistricted its seats, the Legislature returns here tomorrow to take up a number of highly controversial measures in what promises to be one of the stormiest election years in New Jersey's political history.

title: Wounded Knee and all that
description: To most nonIndian Americans, the Indian occupation and destruction of the Bureau of Indian Affairs Building in Washington, D. C., last November, and in recent weeks the seizure of 11 hostages and the succeeding dramatic events at Wounded Knee, S. D., the kidnapping of the city's mayor and shootout at Gallup, N. M., the burning of the courthouse at Custer, S. D., and the scatteredbut spreadingrash of similar violent confrontations between Indians and whites in different parts of the country have been shockers.

title: A CORRECTION
description: That 10 cent map of Prospect Park and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden mentioned in Every Prospect Pleases, and Only Man Is Vile (Travel Section, March 4) costs not 10 cents but $1. The problem was an editing error, not inflation, but Patti Hagan, author of the article, recommends the map even at the higher price.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Within recent weeks 12.5 million American homes received an all  advertising magazine called Shopper's Voice. In the fall another 12.5 million will also receive it.

title: Mrs. Mainwaring Wed
description: GLEN COVE, L. L, March 17Mrs. Wilma Case Mainwaring and Robert Charles Canavello were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride, The Rev. W. Cameron Allan of the First Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony. The couple's first marriages ended in divorce. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. William Van Rensselaer Case of Glen Cove and the late Mr. Case. Her husband is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Delmonico Canavello. His greatgreatgrandfather, Peter Delmonico, was a founder of Delmonico's restaurant in York.

title: Kyle a Hockey Captain
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 17 Clay Kyle of Philadelphia has been elected captain of Princeton's 197374 hockey team.

title: News Summary and Index
description: United States intelligence officials in Saigon said yesterday that the Communists had more war supplies in South Vietnam than before their offensive last year, but that their combat units were far below fighting strength. They believe it unlikely that the Communists would attempt a major drive in the immediate future, but are concerned that the large buildup in military equipment could produce a significant increase in the level of fighting. The South Vietnamese are damn nervous about all this stuff sitting right there in front of them, one official said. [Page 1, Column 4.]

title: Kinsella from Rome to convert the Irish
description: Incredible as it may seem, there are more Christians on this planet today than there are Chinese; and in their hectic history of schisms, sects and dogmas, it is the Chinese whom the Christians most resemble. The Roman Catholics, comprising the mandarin class, look to their Italianate Chairman in Rome for directives and guidance and still believe in a kind of spiritual Middle Kingdom. One could go further: revisionist bishops struggle against progressive curates and splinter groups; cadres of the faithful urge priests to toss aside their dogcollars and lead ecclesiastical singsongs; nuns hemlines are rising; congregations are as exercised about oilspills and urban problems as they used to be about hell. Hope has replaced faith, and miracles are now something of an embarrassment, like those trusses and surgical apparatus that used to be so solemnly displayed in Canadian cathedrals for the encouragement of crippled pilgrims. It won't be long before Peter De Vries is proven right and some imaginative young cleric makes divorce a sacrament.

title: RIGHTS VINATION CHARGED IN SUIT
description: A truck driver who served four months in jail for failing to make courtordered payments to his estranged wife and six children has lost a legal battle, but he may have won reconciliation with his family.

title: Planning and Zoning Boards at Odds
description: Basic differences between the city's zoning appeals board and the City Planning Commission show little sign of abating despite the recent appointment of new chairmen in both agencies.

title: Dave Anderson
description: When he left his office every night, he took the subway to his Flatbush home, where he listened to Beethoven or read.

title: Reading Scores Decline In the City Schools Again
C.H.S.A.A. Title at Stake
description: Power Memorial Academy and Archbishop Molloy, two schools noted for providing, colleges with outstanding basketball talent, meet today at Fordham University for the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship. The 4 P.M. game will be preceded by freshman and junior varsity championship games.

title: Maples Are Called a Nuisance
description: MAYWOOD  A Hackensack landscape architect is conducting a heated oneman campaign against use of the maple as a shade tree.

title: Kissinger Is in Acapulco
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, March 17 (AP)  Henry A. Kissinger, national security adviser to President Nixon, arrived at this Pacific resort port today for a twoweek vacation. He traveled from Washington aboard a United States Air Force plane.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
Tickets for Tennis Event At Felt Forum Go on Sale
description: Tickets are on sale at the Madison Square Garden Center box office for the Lady Gotham women's tennis tournament to be held in the Felt Forum March 28 through April 1.

title: WINDTEX SCORES AT GULFSTREAM
description: MIAMI, March 17 (AP)Saul Epstein's Windtex, ridden by John Rotz, upset favored Dubassoff and won the first division of the $30,000added Canadian Turf Handicap by a neck today at Gulfstream Park.

title: Aaron May Catch Ruth, But Not Displace Him
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. March 17 (UPI)Hank Aaron knows the record he has spent a lifetime pursuing may never be entirely his own.

title: Roberta Books And Jay Negin Plan Marriage
description: NEWTON CENTRE, Mass., March 17Mr. and Mrs. Leonand Book's have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roberta Paula Books, to Jay Stanley Negin of New York.

title: Sheriffs Ask Legislation to End Erosion of Powers
description: TRENTONThe 21 county sheriffs in New Jersey, angered because they believe their law enforcement duties are being eroded and encroached upon by other agencies, are demanding legislation to clearly define their roles.

title: Merchandise Mart Is Proposed For Old Garden Site on 49th St.
description: A group of investors is studying the possibility of constructing a merchandise mart on the site of the old Madison Square Garden at Eighth Avenue and 49th Street.

title: Disputed Drug Is Restudied for Use in Geriatrics
description: WASHINGTON March 17American scientists have reopened study of an old drug that has been dismissed by, some as nothing more than a local anesthetic with a jetset reputation and extravagantly praised by others as a chemical foundation of youth.

title: Some Facts on. Fertilizers
description: CLAIMS and counter claims for particular brands and kinds of fertilizers for the home garden are common. They usually are not informative. Instead their appeal is often emotional and directed to untounded prejudices and fads.

title: 20 DIE IN BOMBING AiMED AT LON NOL
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 17A Cambodian Air Force captain stole a plane today and bombed the presidential palace in what was reported to be an attempt to kill President Lon Nol.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 17United States intelligence officials said today that the Communists now had more war supplies in South Vietnam than they had before their big offensive last year, but that their combat units were far below fighting strength.

description: MANASQUAN  A vivid picturepostcard chronicle of the New Jersey shore has been compiled by a collector here who started out to buy antique milk glass four years ago and found history in shoeboxes.

title: RAIDERS DEFEATED BY COUGARS, 6 TO 3
description: CHICAGO, March 17 (AP)Bob Sicinski scored his 24th and 25th goals of the year leading the Chicago Cougars to a 63 victory over the New York Raiders in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

title: Patricia Wells Is Betrothed
description: Miss Patricia Nadia Wells of New York plans to be married May 12 to Colin Williams at the home of the prospective bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Denis Williams of Alderley Edge, England.

title: State to Check All Rx's in Antidrug Move
description: ALBANY, March 11A new law mandating a computerized review of the drug presonibing activities of the state's 25,000 physicians is scheduled to go into effect next month over the objections of the state medical society.

title: WISCONSIN VICTOR IN N.C.A.A. HOCKEY
description: BOSTON, March 17 (UPI) Dean Talafous broke a 22 tie with his third clutch goal in two games tonight to help the University of Wisconsin win its first National College Athletic Association hockey championship, 42, over the favorite and a fivetime champion.

title: William E. Ward, President Of Family Bolt and Nut firm
description: Wiiam E. Ward, president and chief executive officer of the Russell, urdsall & Ward Bolt & Nut Company, died of a heart attack Friday night at his home in Greenwich, Conn. His age was 60.

title: State Floral Show Blooms in Morris
description: MORRISTOWN  The fragrance of flowers and the colors of spring greeted visitors to the Morristown National Guard Armory yesterday when the New Jersey Flower and Garden Show opened.

title: HEARING WILL GET LETTERS TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Lawyers for A. Ernest Fitzgerald have released five letters indicating that confidential information about his case that had been sent to the White House may have been improperly turned over to the Air Force.

title: To Many, Tiny Archibald Is Big. Man
description: His mother calls him Tiny and his coach calls him the kid. He is a sparrow among eagles, a scrawny 160pounder in a 6foot1inch frame, Even his ribs stock out. He is the roadrunner in the cartoon who goes beepbeeping under and around the legs of anybody who gets in his way on the way to 2 points.

title: Black Fraternity Pledged to SelfHelp
description: There was a time when we were a closed, snobbish club, emulating in many ways the white student fraternities, said the vice president of Gamma Iota Lambda. It's different for us today. As black people, we can't afford the luxury. of having purely funoriented clubs.

title: Television
description: WHEN Joseph Papp's production of David Rabe's Sticks and Bones was postponed indefinitely from the evening of March 9, on the Columbia Broadcasting System, the debate for and against the decision was quickly drawn along predictable and obvious lines. On the surface, the issues lend themselves to immediate clarity.

description: The first rentaltocondominium, conversion of a highrise apartment structure in the city has produced an example of New York's latest housing phenomenon, the half and half building.

title: BELGRADE ATTACK ON U.S. HEIGHTENS
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 17  A Yugoslav campaign against United States influences sharpened this week with new criticism of American diplomats, an attack on the Voice of America, disruption of an American film show and denunciation of news publications in the United States.

title: Go on Sale Wednesday Go on Sales Wednesday
description: The sale of tickets for the first five Knicks playoff games at Madison Square Garden will be held on Wednesday.

title: Thriving O'Hare City Reflects Economic Power of Big Airports
description: CHICAGO, March 17When the Illinois Veterans of Foreign Wars last held their convention in Chicago, the 7,000 members stayed in this city's famed Loop area and marched proudly down State Street in their traditional patriotic parade.

description: APPLICATIONBy Jean J. Davison

title: Reports to Congress Criticize Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 Five studies critical of a variety of Federal transportation subsidies were released today by the Congressional Joint Economic Committee.

title: Turkey Season Ahead For Sullivan County
description: Sullivan County's second spring turkey season will run from May 7 to 18. Officials of the State Department of Environmental Conservation estimate that there are more than 1,000 birds in the county that have propagated from the original 30 in 196667.

title: UMass, N. Carolina Reach Quarterfinals
description: A team effort on offense and defense helped the University of Massachusetts overcome a 35point performance by John Brown of Missouri and led the Minutemen to a 7871 victory in an openinground ocntest of the 36th annual National Invitation Tournament last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: IMSA Set To Make It. In Big Time
description: The highflying International Motor Sports Association, which really zoomed last season after a relatively slow start, is about to make the big time. The club has been accepted in principle for membership in the Automobile Competition Committee for the United States known as ACCUS), the Am can arm of the Federation Internationale de l'Automobile (F.I.A.). The final decision on the time of the actual seating will be made at a meeting of ACCUS later this spring.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Shortly after World War II the Government began building a stockpile of strategic and critical materialsmore than 70 of themthat might be in short supply, in case of another war. Last week, spurred by rising prices of metals and some other nonfarm commodities, President Nixon decided the whole idea was a bit absurd and that most of the stockpile should be sold.

title: There is Still. Another Irelandin Britain
description: LONDON, March 17The St. Patrick's Day parade was canceled for the second year running, but six fullscale St. Patrick's Day banquets were held in London alone.

title: Cousteau? Hippo, Hippo, Hooray!
description: SEVERAL Cousteaus ago one on seals, as I rememberI swore never to look at another one of those exercises in selfadvertisement that pass under the general title, The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau. Because of my peculiar passion for the hippopotamus, I was sucked in again recently by Hippo! That exclamation point should have been a warning to me, but, hoping to the last that there would be some real footage on the behavior of the hippopotamus in its natural habitat, I sat through the entire hour, chafing from shot to shot.

title: New & Novel
description: Douglas Reeman is not going to run out of subject matter as long as there is some naval vessel  sail, steam or gasoline  whose story remains to be told. This one charts the course of the Royal Navy's Motor torpedo boat, a perishable speed boat as expendable as the American version used in the Pacific war. The men who command and crew these craft are for the most part young examateurs, like Lieut. Clive Royce, a 23yearold who gets his baptism of fire as First Officer on MTB 1991. The torpedo boats and gunboats of Royce's flotilla are charged with attacking enemy shipping and protecting their own convoys off the North Sea coast, and Mr. Reeman's novel consists of one desperate sortie after another. The war at sea is all the plot the book needs, but as additional seasoning there is a regular Navy type C.O. whose notions are at odds with the more flexible attitudes of Royce and his mates. And a WREN who is willing to wait at the jetty for her hero. Vintage carnage.

description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Aid for Handicapped Pupils
description: Parents and educators of the city's 80,000 handicapped schoolchildren are looking hopefully toward a new program in Queens where, what, they regard as some of the most promising concepts are being put into practice.

title: Miss Robbins Married
description: Miss Constance Robbins of New York and Henry W. M. Geuther of Jacksonville, Fla., were married here yesterday evening by Rabbi Nathan Perilman in his study. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Hank L. Robbins of New York and Monterey, Mass., and Mr. and Mrs. Henry Geuther of Jacksonville.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Jet Skids Off Runway
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 17 (UPI)An Eaatern Airlines 727 jet carrying 89 passengers from, San Juan, P. R., slid off a runway and came to rest in a field last night, but no one was injured.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The mail has just brought me Mr. [Barnard] Collier's wellcolored portrait (To tame the monster: A most Galbraithian economist, Feb. 18), and I naturally wouldn't dream of deleting any of his warts. But could I correct a few matters before they get into the obituaries, about which I'm becoming increasingly sensitive? I did support George McGovern, morally, oratorically and even financially, to the bitter end. Not even George knows whether that helped or hurt. My wife had $1,800 in hand or in prospect when we were married. In those days, before Mr. Nixon's economists who view me with such doubt took charge of the dollar, $1,800 was something. But it was hardly a fortune. Since then our asset position has improved, but for an economist that should be elementary. I settled upon Gstaad as a place to write some 18 years ago, well before it became fashionable. Maybe that is why it became fashionable, but this seems unlikely. I'd like to think I didn't come all that recently to a decent break for women. Gloria Steinem might even confirm that I encouraged her. Mr. Okun, whom I had previously considered a nice but rather harmless man, says that I write popular fiction about economics. This I also would wish to deny. But I am troubled by his charge. Mr. Okun was one of those who principally helped L. B. J. disguise the fiscal effects of the Vietnam war, so on fiction he stands as an expert.

title: Playoff Dates Are Listed For NetsCougars Series
description: Tentative dates for New York Nets playoff games have been set. On the premise that the Nets, now in fourth place, will meet the Carolina Cougars, now in first place, in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division firstround fourofsevengame series, the dates are:

title: Photography
description: MILITANT feminists can now relax. At least, they can relax if they think that two wrongslnake a right. Because photographers are now exploiting men as well as women by transforming them into sex objects.

title: Wellington
description: The Duke of Wellington's death in 1852 engendered many of the same feelings among his contemporaries that Churchill's was to evoke over a century later.
