description: WASHINGTON, March 18Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., the chairman of a special Senate committee investigating the Watergate bugging case, said today that White House aides who invoked executive privilege to keep from testifying on the matter should be found in contempt of Congress.

title: Miss Goolagong Beats Miss Wade For Indoor Title
description: HINGHAM, Mass., March 18 (AP)Evonne Goolagong, the 21yearold Australian, avenged defeats in her two previous tournaments by beating Virginia Wade of Britain, 64, 64, in the final of the $20,000 women's national indoor tennis championship today.

title: Mrs. Fisher Remarries
description: HARRISON, N. Y., March 18  Mrs. Lillian Fisher of White Plains, widow of Kenneth P. Fisher, was married here this afternoon to Monroe Gutner of Scarsdale. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony at Temple EmanuEl. Mr. Gutner, whose first wife died, is a member of the American Stock Exchange.

title: Rangers Chase the Blues With 31 Garden Triumph
description: The New York Rangers averted a lost weekend last night in Madison Square Garden by beating the St. Louis Blues, 31, in a hotly contested National Hockey League match.

title: Soccer Results
description: GERMANAMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Reds Invite ExPOW To Throw First Ball
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 18 (UPI)A former prisoner of war will throw out the first ball at major league baseball's opening game April 5, officials at Wright Patterson Air Force Base said today.

title: ARABS AND ISRAEL VYING IN SENEGAL
description: DAKAR, Senegal, March 11 The West African nation of Senegal, a pivotal country in black African politics, has become a focal point of the ArabIsraeli contest for support in, black African countries.

title: Amer. Hockey League
description: SATURDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Ford Foundation Aid
description: The Ford Foundation has decided to continue its aid to developing countries for the next decade, its annual report disclosed yesterday. The report also showed the foundation had gained a return of 18.1 per cent on its portfolio of stocks. Details, Page 2. The City Center of Music and Drama said that it would receive an interestfree loan of $1million from the foundation. Page 46.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The head of the New York branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Carl D. Lawrence, said his organization was still awaiting an answer to its demand for a full grand jury investigation into the fatal shooting of Patrolman Irving Wright two weeks ago today. Patrolman Wright, who was black, off duty and wearing civilian clothes, was killed by two white fellow policemen who mistook him for a robber while he was pursuing a holdup man.

title: A Relaxed Roberta Flack Sings Program Wtih BigBand Backup
description: Roberta Flack's climb to her current success can be measured by the number of musicians she uses. On Saturday at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum she used not only her usual quintet but also had grafted on to it a massed big band that included many of New York's topechelon recording studio musicians. Some (such as the bass player Ray Brown) were even imported from the West Coast.

title: MUSICIANS' GROUP PLANS JAZZ FETE
description: The degree to which New York will become jazz city for 10 days this summer was made plainer yesterday when the New York Musicians Organization outlined its plans for The Five Boroughs Jazz Festival, from June 29 through July 8.

title: Colbert, Despite 6 Bogeys, Cards 73, Wins by Stroke
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 18 (UPI)Jimmy Colbert, surviving six bogeys, shot a oneoverpar 73 today and scored a onestroke victory in the $130,000 Jacksonville open.

title: Jersey City's Irish Salute St. Patrick In Their Customary Belated Tribute
description: JERSEY CITY, March 18  The will factor overcame the chill factor as thousands marched here today in a white St. Patrick's Day celebration.

title: INDIANS SET FIRE TO U.S. PROPOSAL
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., March 18  Insurgent Indians. holding this tiny village publicly burned today a detailed Government proposal aimed at settling the armed confrontation. However, they agreed to continue negotiations with Government officials.

title: Jersey Gave U.S. $1.47 For Every $1 in 1972 Aid
description: TRENTON, March 18  For every dollar received in direct Federal aid last year, New Jerseyans paid, Federal taxes of $1.47, the fourth highest total in the country, the New Jersey Taxpayers Association reported today.

title: Nixon Seeking to Abolish Insanity Defense in Crime
description: WASHINGTON, March 18In a move certain to provoke controversy in legal circles, President Nixon will ask Congress to abolish insanity as a defense against murder and related Federal crimes such as treason and kidnapping.

title: BLAZERS TOPPLE KNICKS BY 9996
MORE BUS SERVICE IS URGED TO HELP POOR GET TO JOBS
description: In a cityordered study of how improved transportation might help poor people, the Regional Plan Association proposed yesterday that 15 bussystem extensions be instituted to connect lowincome areas to nearby manufacturing districts.

title: Ford Foundation Aid
description: The Ford Foundation has decided to continue its aid to developing countries for the next decade, its annual report disclosed yesterday. The report also showed the foundation had gained a return of, 18.1 per cent on its portfolio of stocks. Details, Page 2. The City Center of Music and Drama said that it would receive an interestfree loan of $1million from the foundation. Page 46.

title: Iran Plans Agreement
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 18 (Reuters)A new 20year oil agreement will he concluded between Iran and the Western oil consortium operating here after their current deal is mutually declared null and void on Wednesday, reliable oil sources said today. Premier Amir Abbas Hoveida officially announced last night, as had been reported, that Iran would take over all installations from the Western consortium, consisting of British, French, Dutch and American oil companies.

title: BURNHAM, DREXEL PLAN CONSOLIDATION
description: Burham & Co. and Drexel Firestone, Inc., announced over the weekend that their consolidation into Drexel Burnham & Co. would become effective today. The new investment banking and brokerage concern will have capital in excess of $50million.

title: Capitalism, for Better or Worse
description: CHICAGOIn our society (it's the only one I've experienced, so I cannot speak for any other), the razor of necessity cuts close. You must make a buck to survive the day. You must work to make a buck. The job is often a chore, rarely a delight. No matter how demeaning the task, no matter how it dulls the senses or breaks the spirit, one must work or else. Lately there has been a questioning of this work ethic, especially by the young. Strangely enough, it has touched off profound grievances in others, hitherto silent and anonymous.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, MARCH 19, 1973

title: Man and Beast
description: The joint venture of a city zoo and the government of an African state to improve a water supply system would be unique in any case. But what gives genuine significance to the agreement recently signed by the New York Zoological Society and the Government of Kenya is its recognition of the needs of human beings and animals alike and its effort to serve both without injury to either.

title: Ford Foundation to Continue Aid To Nations for Next Decade
description: The Ford Foundation, after reviewing its $50millionayear program of assistance to the poorer countries of the world, has decided to continue its developmental efforts in the next decade.

title: Personal Finance
description: Sewer servicethe ancient technique of some process servers who throw summonses away without delivering themhas long been illegal almost everywhere.

title: Fiat Signs Deal to Construct 230Million Plant in Brazil
description: Giovanni Agnelli, chairman of Fiat, S.p.A., of Turin, Italy's largest manufacturer of automotive products, signed an agreement last week with Rondon Pacheco, governor of the Brazilian State of Minas Gerais, to build a $230million automotive plant at Belohorizonti, Brazil. The plant will have a capacity of 190,000 Fiat 127 model cars and will be completed within three years.

title: Eastern Hockey League
description: SATURDAY'S PLAYOFF GAMES

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation proposed new rules that would require companies burying radioactive wastes in the state to obtain a permit to do so. The rules, which are subject to a hearing April 16, are the first formal spellingout of powers the department inherited from the Health Department when it was created in 1970.

title: 3Way Resemblance Is Seen in Sex Case; City Worker Is Held
description: A rape suspect resembling a Queens prosecutor charged with sex crimes is now thought by Brooklyn authorities to resemble still another man arrested on sexoffense charges in January.

title: WORKER RESCUED FROM A GAS TANK
description: A critically injured steamfitter, trapped after a 60foot plunge into a narrow shaft formed by the double walls of a huge gas tank under construction in Queens, was rescued by a police emergency squad early yesterday after nearly four hours of dramatic maneuvering to reach him.

title: Ervin Suggests Penalizing Aides of Nixon Who Balk
description: WASHINGTON, March 18Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., the chairman of a special Senate committee investigating the Watergate bugging case, said today that White House aides who invoiced executive privilege to keep from testifying on the matter should be found in contempt of Congress.

title: For a CountryDance Expert, 82, It All Began With the Old Mole
description: At 82 years of age, Miss May Gadd admits to a special fondness for the Morpeth Rant and the Step Stately. But it was the Old Mole that turned her on to her life's work.

title: Red Smith
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 18Almost four weeks ago Jimmy Ellis was up in Orlando, not to savor the enchantments of Walt Disney World but to give a facial to one Pretty Boy Feldstein, a former saloon bouncer from Toronto. He left Pretty Boy for dead in the second round. Two weeks ago Ellis boxed Charles (Emperor) Harris in Miami Beach. The Emperor wore pants of red crushed velvet that came clear down below the knee to protect against floor burns. At 1:48 of the first round he lit on the imperial britches and did not get up. Less than two weeks hence Ellis will take on three heavyweights in Savannah, Ga., going two rounds or less with each One is Jimmy Lee Nixon, a hot amateur unbeaten in 30 bouts. A fortnight later Ellis will be in Huntington, W. Va., fighting Joe Harris of Cincinnati for the Green Acres Retarded Children's Home. Harris has boxed people like Terry Daniels and Ron Stander, which clearly qualifies him as party of the second part im another onerounder.

title: U.S. Said to Consider Placing Rabbi in Moscow
description: Spiritual leaders of the three major faiths said yesterday that the State Department had under serious consideration the appointment of an American rabbi for the United States Embassy in Moscow.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
MRS. JOHN J. LAMLA
description: Mrs. Lillian Livingston Lamula, wife of John J. Lamula, a stockbroker and former State Assemblyman and Republican district leader in Manhattan, died of cancer on Saturday in Memorial Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived at 15 West 12th Street. A brother, Joel Livingston, also survives.

title: State's Claim on Tidelands Imperils Many Businesses
description: HOBOKEN, March 18If the state is serious about this thing, Hoboken will be a prairie, said Andrew Colabella, president of a paper recycling business he located a few years ago in an old tidal marsh in the northwestern part of the city.

title: 3 G.O.P. LEADERS OPPOSE WAGNER
description: Three of the city's five Republican leaders greeted Governor Rockefeller's warm endorsement of their old political foe, Robert F. Wagner, with vows to fight, predictions of open rebellion and denunciations bordering on the furious.

title: TWO ARE KILLED IN IRISH VIOLENCE
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 18 (UPI)  Ten bombings, 25 shootings and a landmine explosion killed at least two persons in the last 24 hours.

title: Biaggi Tells His Listeners: I, Too, Have Worked Hard
description: At the Northeast Regular Democratic Club in Bayside, Queens, one night last week, Representative Mario Biaggi was talking about crime. Only a few years ago, he was saying, law and order were dirty words among liberals, coded language for antiblack attitudes.

title: ROCKEFELLER CALLS WAGNER THE MAN TO LEAD THE CITY
description: Governor Rockefeller endorsed former Mayor Robert F. Wagner yesterday as a man who can lead and heal this city, and politicians said that his statement sealed the deal that would give Mr. Wagner the Republican and Liberal lines for Mayor in this year's election.

title: Marcos Says Mindanao Revolt Is Ebbing
description: MANILA, March 18 (AP)President Ferdinand E. Marcos says that the insurgency in the southern Philippine island of Mindanao has been virtually crushed and that the insurgents are on the run.

title: Judge Relaxes Security Rules As Charlotte School Strife Ebbs
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., March 18With racial violence abate ed, officials of the Charlotte Mecklenburg County schools have dismissed most of the offduty policemen hired to patrol the schools, and a superior court judge lifted an injunction banning weapons and outsiders from school grounds.

title: That Light Snowfall Set Records in State
description: Yesterday's light blanket of snow in New Jersey was recorded as one of the record snowfalls of the year, although it melted quickly in the larger cities.

title: JOHN H. SQUIRES
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., March 18 John H. Squires, who retired in 1959 as an assistant vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, died this morning at Williamsport Hospital at the age of 73.

title: BUS STRIKE NEARS END IN HARTFORD
description: HARTFORD, March 18  A limited settlement in the 114day Connecticut bus strike was neared tonight following agreeInent by the Connecticut Company and the Amalgamated Transit Union on a new twoyear contract.

title: How to Honor Hizzoner? Daley Watchers Respond
description: CHICAGO, March 18 Hundreds of persons have busied themselves for countless hours here in recent weeks on a project that even the Cook County Democratic machine has not yet undertaken  devising an appropriate monument to Mayor Richard J. Daley.

title: G.O.P. Warns of Tax Rise Without Nixon Budget Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI)Taxes could go up 15 per cent by 1975 unless President Nixon's controversial budget cuts are made, the Republican National Committee said today.

title: Crisis Of the Old Order
description: When human reason and reasonableness fail to break the grip of wornout ideas and decadent institutions, history sometimes does the job by producing an unbearable crisis.

title: Tributes Delay Parade
description: BOSTON, March 18 (AP)The traditional St. Patrick's Day parade lasted longer than usual in South Boston today as many of the estimated total of 200,000 spectators broke through the lines and rushed into the street to kiss the ring of the honorary parade marshal, Humberto Cardinal Medeiros, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston.

title: N.H.L. WOULD BUY SEALS, FINLEY SAYS
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 18 (AP)Charles O. Finley, owner of the California Golden Seals, confirmed today that the National Hockey League board of governors had expressed willingness last week to purchase the franchise here.

title: Conner Conquers Schofield In Congressional Cup Sailoff
description: LONG BEACH, Calif March 18 (UPI)Dennis Conner of San Diego found fresh wind after trailing at the start, then went on to defeat Henry Schofield of the. Long Beach Yacht Club yesterday in the first suddendeath sailoff for the Congressional Cup match race series championship.

title: Navajo Wins by Length
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 18 (AP) Navajo, one of the favorites, won the $20,000 Louisiana Derby. Trial today by a length at the Fair Grounds. He returned $19.80, $5.80 and $3.60. His time for the mile and 40 yards was 1:40.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 18A 1963 journal on all sports described gymnastics as lacking in crowd appeal and consequently given little publicity. Have you looked lately?

title: Irving Chin Wins Backing For a Manhattan Judgeship
description: Irving S. K. Chin, a member of the City Commission on Human Rights, has been endorsed for the Civil Court bench by the Committee to Reform Judicial Selections.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Four New Jersey Representatives, saying there was no need for a change of leadership in the state, have endorsed Governor Cahill for a second term. A statement of endorsement was signed by Peter H. B. Frelinghuysen, Edwin B. Forsythe, Matthew J. Rinaldo and Joseph J. MaraZiti. The two other Representatives, John E. Hunt and William B. Widnell, were not approached for an endorsement, according to State Senator Raymond H. Bateman, cochairman the Cahill for Governor committee.

title: MOLLOY QUINTET WINS TITLE, 6361
description: James Gooch, a senior from the Rosedale section of Queens, scored 21 points rind grabbed 15 rebounds to lead Archbishop Molloy to a 6361 upset victory over Power Memorial in the 45th annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball championships before a crowd of 3,470 at Fordham yesterday.

title: Shifts in Federal Aid Alarm New South
description: ATLANTA, March 18  The Nixon Administration's current and proposed cutbacks in social services, coupled with rising doubts about the distribution and efficacy of revenuesharing funds, have generated confusion and suspicion in the South, where nearly half the nation's poor and blacks live.

title: PROVIDENCE LOOKS TO BRUIN REMATCH
description: Ernie DiGregorio, as confident as he is accurate, said, There was no one on Mary land who was going to really stop me from scoring.

title: Screen: 'Two People,' or 8 Hours to Kill in Paris:Peter Fonda Is Cast as Returning Deserter
description: "There's no time. There's no time for any of this.""Almost eight hours. Some people don't ever have eight hours."And so together they begin to waste those eight hours hand and hand, strolling down the dark and deserted boulevards past all the tourist attractions of Paris. Pausing before Notre Dame she grows bitterly philosophical: "By the time you get out, that may have become a parking edifice!" But eventually they do get to bed, and, through a night of blurred-focus passion, they make love. And if she does not say "I never knew it could be like this," it is perhaps only because she could never be heard over the welling up of the music  the music that follows them everywhere on plucked and bowed strings and sounds nothing like so much as total submission to the last three bars of the "Summer of '42" theme.They have come to Parishe, she and the background musicfrom Marrakesh, and they are bound for New York. They are the central elements in Robert Wise's "Two People," a very silly movie that opened yesterday at the Baronet Theater. He is Evan Bonner, high-principled Vietnam war deserter returning home to face the music (not this music, some other music). She is Deirdre McCluskey, high-fashion model and daughter of a West Virginia coal miner (what else?), returning home to her little illegitimate son, to at least $100,000 a year and to a life that has lost its meaning. Naturally, they fall in love.I am tempted to hang the movie with quotations from its dialogue  which would be unfair. It is really equally bad in all departments. It may even be most aggressively awful when its people stop talking and take the train from Marrakesh to Casablance or the plane from Casablanca to Paris (first class all the way) or just watch the streets from their hotel rooms. There has never been such appreciation for the poetry of Paris traffic patterns, and in general the esthetic program behind "Two People" seems to be: When in doubt, travel.Estelle Parsons plays a supporting role as a fashion editor accompanying Deirdre, and, though conventionally brittle, her performance comes closer to suggesting two sides to a person than does any other characterization, in the movie. As Deirdre, Lindsay Wagner, a newcomer, is pretty and solemn. But a tendency for her facial expressions to disintegrate into grimaces (perhaps occasioned by the lines she must speak) makes it difficult to accept her quality. Peter Fonda, as Evan Bonner, seems greatly withdrawn to some inward meditationa strategy, I believe, not of performance but of self-defense.Separate units are credited with filming in North Africa, in Paris and in New York City. But "Two People" is remarkably of a piecenot with the consistency of a movie director like Robert Wise, but rather with the consistency of something cooked up from the same package of synthetic soup.

title: City Plans Suit to Keep Poverty Programs Alive
description: New York City is preparing a Federal suit to keep the Federal antipoverty program in effect and to prevent the Nixon Administration from dismantling of the Office of Economic Opportunity.

title: Prison Talks Lagging
description: BOSTON, March 18 (AP) No significant progress was reported today in negotiations between the state Correction Department and the guards union at Walpole state prison, Guards walked out Wednesday in protest over conditions at the maximum security prison, which they say lacks adequate meaures for protection of the guards.

title: Credit Markets Watching 2 Giant LongTerm Issues.
description: Cashladen institutional investorsbuyers of the bulk of new bond issueshave turned much of their attention this month toward two giant financings scheduled for offering this week.

title: Hispanic Students Continue Boycott At Montclair State
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, March 18 (UPI)Seventeen Puerto Rican students demonstrated peacefully outside Montclair State College for the third consecutive day today demanding the resignation of a Cuban toucher.

title: Boy, 7, and Woman Die in Fire on Lower East Side
description: A woman and a 7yearold boy believed to be her grandson were burned to death yesterday morning in a fouralarm fire that burned out of control for more than two hours in a fivestory brick tenement on the lower East Side.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 19, 1973

title: Peter Serkin's Quartet Makes Chamber Debut
description: Fred Sherry, Ida Kavafian, Richard Stoltzman and, of course, Peter Serkin are all wellknown names on this city's chambermusic circuit, and they have now banded together to form a group. They don't have a name for it yetMr. Stoltzman suggested ingenuously that the audience think up some suggestions yesterday afternoon during the very, very long Messiaen Quartet for the End of Time. Bookings have been arranged already for next season, with plans to bring in guest artists as the occasions require.

title: Iris Lerner Bride of Steven R. Lapidus
description: Miss Iris R. Lerner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Newton Lerner of New York and Cedarhurst, L. I., was married here yesterday eveto Steven R. Lapidus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold Lapidus of Woodmere, L. I.

title: Taxi Poll on Mayoralty Finds Beame Leading
description: Taxi News, the industry's newspaper, will announce in this week's issue that its informal poll shows City Controller Abraham D. Beanie to be the present leader in the mayoral campaign.

title: Dollar Is Strong as Tokyo Market Opens
description: TOKYO, Monday, March 19The dollar was surprisingly strong in heavy trading this morning, on the Tokyo ForeignExchange Market, the first major market to reopen after the twoweek suspension in trading during international monetary negotiations.

title: Every Birth in Asia Limits Hope
description: KAMAN, IndiaThere are about 47,000 more people on earth today than there were yesterday. By the end of the week there will be nearly 1.5 million more.

title: Fund Cut Curtails Joffrey's Fall Season
description: Faced with an 80 per cent reduction in subsidy from the City Center of Music and Drama as well as a previously undisclosed requirement from the center that it raise its ticket prices, the City Center Joffrey Ballet has decided to shorten its fall season here from six to four weeks. It has also dropped plans at this time for a season in the spring of 1974.

title: Records: Wellstood jazz
description: Dick Wellstood's problem may be that be is simultaneously too broad, in his view of the jazz piano and too easily pigeonholed in any of several categories. Between the breadth of his personal view and the narrowness of those who expect only one thing from him, Mr. Wellstood manages to offendmany of those who might be his fans. And, if he has overlooked any of those who are not offended by the scope of his Music, he can hit a few more with the acid wit of the liner notes he writes for his occasional records.

title: McCormack Is Appointed
description: BOSTON, March 18 (AP)Continental Wingate Company, which specializes in housing rehabilitation has announced appointment of Edward J. McCormack Jr., former Massachusetts attorney general, as senior vice president and a director.

title: Bridge: How Bud Reinhold's TeamOvercame 69Point Deficit
description: ST. LOUIS, March 18 Only one New York group remained in contention in the Vanderbilt knockout team championship when the semifinal stage began here this afternoon.

title: Dollar Is Strong as Tokyo Market Opens
description: TOKYO, Monday, March 19The dollar was surprisingly strong in heavy trading this morning on the Tokyo ForeignExchange Market, the first major market to reopen after the twoweek suspension in trading during international monetary negotiations.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Carter, Miss Susslin Win Eastern Slalom Titles
description: KINGFIELD, Me., March 18Peter Carter, a Harvard Law School student with a big red beard, scored the most important victory of his long skiracing career today in a snowstorm at Sugar Loaf Mountain.

title: Killings in Bermuda Reflect Winds of Change Touching Vacation Paradise
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 18This lovely island of moderation has usually managed to escape most of the world's miseries. Warmed in the winter by the Gulf Stream, cooled in the summer by ocean breezes, Bermuda has no snakes or tropical fevers, no income tax or skyscrapers.

title: BLACKS COMPLAIN OF MEDIA TO F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, March 18The Federal Communications Commission for the first time has met with a group of 40 blacks who voiced their complaints against the commission and the broadcast industry.

title: MORE BUS SERVICE IS URGED TO HELP POOR GET TO JOBS
description: In a cityordered study of how improved transportation might help poor people, the Regional Plan Association proposed yesterday that 15 bussystem extensions be instituted to connect lowincome areas to nearby manufacturing districts.

title: Crimes Decline
description: Inexact as they may be, the figures showing an overall decline of 18 per cent in levels of crime in New York City last year seem substantial enough to withstand serious challenge. Corroborating sources of information tend to bear out the police statistics and encourage the belief that present anticrime efforts are having an impact.

title: School Prayer Bills Ready
description: BOSTON, March 18 (AP)Three bills that would allow the celebration of religious holidays, voluntary prayer and enforced periods of silent prayer or meditation in Massachusetts public schools go before the House tomorrow.

title: Education Group Suspends Harvard Unit With Women
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass, March 18 (UPI)The Harvard University Graduate School of Education has been suspended from Phi Delia Kappa, the world's largest professional education society, for allowing women to join the Harvard chapter, the university said today.

title: LON NOL ORDERS STERN MEASURES
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 18President Lon Not ordered a series of stern measures today after an ap parent attempt to assassinate him in a bombing raid on the presidential palace.

title: Ohio Amtrak Wreck Kills One, Hurts 19
description: EAST PALESTINE, Ohio, March 18 (AP)One man was killed and at least 19 persons were injured today when five cars of Amtrak's Broadway Limited, carrying 167 passengers, left the track in a heavy snowstorm.

title: PROVED RESERVES OF OIL AND GAS OFF
description: WASHINGTON, March 18Proved reserves of crude oil and natural gas fell again in 1972, the industry reported today.

title: 2 Charged With Harassing Police at a Purim Fete
description: Two youths were arrested on charges of harassing the police yesterday while celebrating the Purim festival in a Hasidic neighborhood in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: U.S. DECISION ON TIN REPORTED BY BOLIVIA
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 18 (AP)Bolivia has received assurances that the United States will not damage the Bolivian economy by sale of strategic tin reserves, Foreign Minister Mario Gutierrez announced this weekend.

title: CHRISTIAN BROTHERS, BISHOP EUSTACE WIN
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 18 A spectacular performance by Bishop Eustace and the third straight state title for Christian Brothers Academy highlighted the parochial school finals of the New Jersey state high school basketball tournament today at Princeton's Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: Anderson Asserts I.T.T. Data Contradict Mitchell Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)  Jack Anderson, the columnist, reported today that he had obtained summaries of confidential International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation documents that he said contradicted sworn testimony by former Attorney General John N. Mitchell last year to the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: LIGHTNIN VICTOR IN MONTEGO RACE
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 18Ted Turner, the world oceanracing champion, had two reasons today to pop the champagne corks.

title: RELAY MARKS FALL IN WOMEN'S SWIM
description: MOSCOW, Idaho, March 18 (UPI)Records fell in both relay finals last night at the national women's collegiate swimming and diving chainpionships at the University of Idaho natatorium.

title: Abortion Clinics Here Face Nationwide Competition and Uncertain Future
description: One of Manhattan's 12 nonhospital abortion clinics, geared to a capacity of 750 patients a week, is down to an average of 380. If we go below 300, they've got us in trouble financially, a spokesman said.

title: Gambia Revalues Dalasi
description: BATHHURST, The Gambia, March 18 (AgenceFrance Presse)The Gambia revalued cur rency today by 20 per cent. There are now four Dalasis, the local currency, to the pound instead of five. The Government decision, announced by the radio, comes into force at midnight tonight.

title: Watch and Wait
description: LONDON, March 18The stories from Washington about alleged North Vietnamese infiltration southward in violation of the truce terms have had a wellorchestrated quality. First reports of the movement of men and arms were leaked. Then the Pentagon officially endorsed the field reports. Finally the President spoke gravely of them at his press conference.

title: Royal Dutch Scores on L.I.
description: ST. JAMES, L.I., March 18Royal Dutch, owned and ridden by Phebe Phillips of New York, won the intermediate jumper, championship today at the Hollandia Farm horse show. The aged bay gelding won two of the three classes to score 10 points. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Cousins's Dutch Tide, Hollandia Farm's Double Dutch and Old Mill Farm's Moon Spree finished in a threeway tie for reserve honors with 5 points each.

title: Regina Foley Bride Of William Groman
description: Miss Regina Ann Foley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Foley Jr. of Clifton, N. J., was married here yesterday morning to William Carl Groman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Groman of Flushing, Queens.

title: Dreyfus Reports Decline In Earnings Before Charge
description: The Dreyfus Corporation, major mutualfund management concern, announced yesterday that its earnings in 1972 had totaled $5.04million, or $1.90 share, before an extraordinary charge of $4.45million, or $1.68 a share. In 1971 Dreyfus earned $5.6million, or $2.10 a share.

title: J. Cooper Graham Jr., 72, An Officer of Grolier, Inc.
description: J. Cooper Graham Jr., a vice president and director of Grolier, Inc., publishers of educational and reference works, died yesterday at his home in Baltimore. He was 72 years old.

title: 11 Die, 43 Hurt in Canada In PileUp of 32 Vehicles
description: BARRIE, Ontario, March 19 (UPI)  Eleven persons were killed and 43 others injured in one of Canada's worst highway accidents, a fiery chainreaction crash that involved 32 vehicles, the police said today.

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Disaster Aid Sought
description: ALBANY, March 19Governor Rockefeller urged President Nixon today to designate six upstate counties as disaster areas and see that all possible Federal assistance be made available to these counties. The six counties along the shores of Lake Ontario and Lake Erie, which have been subjected to extensive flooding in recent days because of high winds and wave action, are Jefferson, Monroe, Niagara, Orleans, Oswego and Wayne.

title: Rule Change Aids Soccer Offense
description: The United States and Canadian soccer associations and the World governing body of the sport have granted the North American Soccer League permission to change the traditional offside rule, reducing the area in which it is in effect.

title: Bank Profits and Officer Pay Up in '72
description: Profits of the nation's largest banks were generally higher during 1972, and, reflecting this fact, the managers of some of these institutions received sharp increases in their total pay last year.

title: People and Business
description: Norman Barker Jr. has been named chairman of the United California Bank, which, with 249 branches, is California's fifth largest bank. The 50yearold banker, who has been associated with U.C.B., a subsidiary of the Western Bancorporation, for 16 years, has been its chief executive officer since 1971.

title: Cambodia Seizes Many as Subversives
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 19Arrests and interrogations continued today while state security groups pursued what a high official called the dismantling of subversive networks in Phnom Penh.

title: Epstein Says the A's Have It
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 19  Contrary to almost daily rumors this spring, Vida Blue was not in the Texas Rangers' camp today. Mike Epstein, on the other hand, was.

title: Rap Brown Won't Testify; Final Witness Contested
description: H. Rap Brown, the black militant charged with armed robbery and attempted murder here, will not take the witness stand, his attorneys said yesterday.

title: Bridge: Miracle Team Led by Reinhold And Aces Gain Vanderbilt Final
description: ST LOUIS, Mo., March 19The final of the 1973 Vanderbilt Cup began here this afternoon with the world champion Aces facing a miracle quintet headed by Bud Reinhold of Highland Park, Ill. Both teams had survived desperately close semifinal battles that ended in the early hours this morning.

title: Use of Midwives Revived in California
description: POINT REYES STATION, Calif., March 19Birth is too important to be left to obstetricians, said Dr. Michael Whitt shortly before interviewing a couple who came to seek his help in having their baby at home.

title: Personal Income Jumped $8.3Billion in February
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)National personal income jumped by $8.3billion last month, mainly because of another sizable increase in private payrolls and a rise in social security benefits, the Government said today.

title: Steel Output at Record on 1.8% Weekly Advance
description: Steel production of 2,977,000 net tons in the week ended March 17 was the highest for Many week in history, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: A jury heeded the urgings of prosecution and defense lawyers and found a.25yearold Vietnam veteran not guilty by reason of insanity of the killing of a Roman Catholic priest in 1971. The jury ordered the defendant held in a state psychiatric hospital.

title: The Theater: Thoughts
description: A biographical musical that just about sums up. Thoughts, which opened at night at the Theater de Lys. The biography is black and Southern  a young musician born in Alabama in (I presume, for this is what it says in the show) 1944, and living, quite happily, in New York. It is the story of a black Southern childhood, adolescence and maturity. It is interesting and touching. You feel that a man has the courage to tell the truth about himself.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PHOTOFLASH If you've ever wondered how news photographer spends his time, you can find out by dropping in at the Mill at Burlington House, 1345 Avenue of the Americas, at 54th Street. In the lobbies at each end of the mill and in the display windows facing the street are more than 70 pictures, prizewinners of the 37th annual competition of the New York Press Photographers Association.

title: Everyone Blames U.S. for Food Prices
description: An array of Congressmen, localgovernment officials and supermarket executives met yesterday to talk about, rising food prices and wound up agreeing, more or less, that it is all the Federal Government's fault.

title: The Stage: Dr. MaGico
description: Saturday night at La MaMa  the PlayHouse of the Ridiculous's new musical extravaganza, The Magic Show of Dr. MaGico, is 30 minutes late. The large crowd in the tiny lobbysuburbanites as well as New Yorkersis becoming patient.

title: COX, CREALEY WIN IN VIRGINIA TENNIS
description: MERRIFIELD, Va., March 19 (UPI)  Rural seeded Mark Cox of England and eighthseeded Dick Crealey of Australia won opening,  round matches' in the: Union Trust tennis tournament today.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Everybody Watches Everybody in East Europe, but Nobody Really Notices
description: WARSAW, March 11  As Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, was driven out to Prague's military airport on visit early last year, he might have noticed the crowds thinning as the motorcade reached the edge of the capital.

title: Mars Exploration by Robots Foreseen by Soviet Scientist
description: MOSCOW, March 19 (UPI) Sovietmade robots will be rolling across the surface of Mars in the near future, conducting experiments that are beyond the capability of human explorers, a leading space scientist said today.

title: Bench's Recovery Touches All Bases
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 19 (AP) Johnny Bench, who had surgery last Dec. 11 to remove a benign lesion on his right lung, displayed his mostvaluableplayer form today by hitting his first home run of the spring.

title: A.A.U. Won't Let 5 Go to So. Africa
description: Requests by five top United States track and field athletes for travel permits and visas to compete in a multinational sports competition in South Africa starting Friday have drawn mounting opposition.

title: 28% of SubCabinet Jobs Vacant 2 Months After the Inauguration
description: WASHINGTON, March 19Two months after President Nixon's inauguration for a second term, more than a quarter of the major subCabinet positions in his Administration remain to be filled.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York University and the City University Construction Fund yesterday set a price of $62million for N.Y.U:'s Bronx campus, which is being bought by the City University agency for future use by Bronx Community College.

title: Union Carbide Rights Award Cancel
description: At a special meeting of its board of directors late yesterday afternoon, the New York Urban League rescinded its decision to give one of its annual Frederick Douglass awards to the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: Cahill Vetoes Shield Bill For the Press as Extreme
description: TRENTON, March 19  A controversial legislative measure that would have given reporters in New Jersey the legal privilege to refuse to disclose any news information to an investigative body was vetoed here today by Governor Cahill.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 9The New Jersey high school basketball tournament is over. However, one question lingers: Which team is the best. Bishop Eustace Prep of Pennsauken or Christian Brother Academy of Lincroft?

title: High Court, Acts to Hurry Appeal on Alaska Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI)  The Supreme Court acted today, to speed an appeal of a lower court ruling that is blocking construction of the transAlaskan pipeline, described by the petroleum industry as a vitl step toward alleviating the nation's fuel shortage.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: University of Palestine
description: The establishment of a Palestinian Arab university on the Jordan West Bank is an important step toward channeling Palestinian national aspirations into more constructive pursuits than the bitterness and terrorism which have preoccupied them for so long.

title: The Jobless and Their Problems Jam Asian Cities
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Pitung's fever was two days old when his stomach pains started. He lifted himself off his cardboard sleeping mat, across the dirt floor and out the cloth door of his friend's bambooframed cardboard shanty to the edge of the canal five feet away. There, as mosquitoes swarmed In the damp predawn darkness, he vomited. Then he returned to his mat and, his friend said, he shook uncontrollably.

title: SOME BIG BANKS LIFT PRIME RATE TO 6% FROM 6
description: A group of major banks, led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, increased their prime lending rates yesterday by onehalf of a percentage point to 6 per cent, thus provoking a new confrontation between the Nixon Administration and the banking industry.

title: A Graduate Program Sets Out to Find History's Women
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y. When I tell my friends I'm getting my master's in women's history, most of them say: Oh, you're dredging up Elizabeth the First, Anne Hoblitzeller said with a grimace. They forget that through all of history, women have always been there. Where were they and what were they doing? That's what we're trying to find out

title: Walton's Head Unturned by Pros
SPECIALBID IDEA DISLIKED BY ELDER
description: Lee Elder of Washington asserted yesterday he wanted no favors in the form of a special invitation from the Masters golf tournament, to which a black player has never been invited.

title: LimousineTaxi Owners Decry City Policy Toward Gypsy Cabs
description: Leaders of the city's licensed nonmedallion taxi industry said yesterday that they would turn their licenses back to the Taxi and Limousine Commission if the city made no concerted effort to take gypsy cabs off the streets in the next two weeks.

title: Arthur Daley
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 19Probably no city in the country yearns for a pro football franchise with as much undisguised ardor as does Tampa. A handsome stadium glistens emptily in the bright sunshine. Eager supporters pray every night that the proper heavenly guidance descends on Pete Rozelle. Meanwhile, everyone waits. But it is not completely passive waiting. They nudge a little.

title: Rutgers and Manhattan Eliminated From N.I.T.
description: Glenn Garrett, the lowest season scorer on the starting five and the most unlikely player to take the last shot of the game, scored on a desperation 20foot jumper at the buzzer last night that gave Alabama an 8786 victory over Manhattan.

title: New Haven Averts 2d Teacher Strike With a Pact on Pay
description: NEW HAVEN, Match 19On the eve of a threatened second walkout, the New Haven Teachers Federation and the Board of Education agreed tentatively today on a new contract.

title: Senate Finance Unit Votes Equalization Tax Extension
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI)  The Senate Finance Committee voted today to extend the interest equalization tax until April 1, 1975.

title: Luna Incognita
description: The scientists who gathered at Houston for the fourth annual Lunar Science Conference recently had far more factual information about the moon than has ever before been available. They had the preliminary results from the rocks returned by Apollo 17, as well as the conclusions of more extended research on the discoveries of earlier Apollo manned vehicles and on the knowledge gained by Soviet unmanned rockets to the moon.

title: PILOTS WITH DOWNEY DIED IN CRASH IN '52
description: WASHINGTON, March 19The State Department said today that two American pilots who flew John Downey and Richard Fecteau into China in 1952 died when the plane crashed during the mission.

title: STEIN IS DISPUTED ON BANK SURPLUSES
description: The state's Superintendent of Banks and a spokesman for the mutual savings banks in the state disputed yesterday a proposal by Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein that the banks' surplus funds, which he said amounted to about $3.5billion, be put to new uses.

title: ExInmates Sing The Blues
description: Good for President Nixon, that in spite of his hardline views on crime he would have the great Merle Haggard as the primary entertainer at a White House dinner. Merle Haggard is an a exoffender (car theft, bad checks, armed, robbery) but he also happens to bone of the foremost performing artists in America today, a, singer and songwriter whose art transcends the country musk context in which he works: Some of us may not be as enamoured as Mr. Nixon of the Haggard patriotic hits, Okie From Muskogee and Welkin' on the Fightin' Side of Me, but they can easily be tolerated in exchange for such songs as Every Fool. Has a Rainbow or I Take, a Lot of Pride in What I Am.

title: RECAPITALIZATION OF MOPAC BACKED
description: A plan of recapitalization, under which the Mississippi River Corporation would become the undisputed controlling stockholder of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, was approved here yesterday by Federal District Judge Eward Weinfeld.

title: Diamonds Linked to Blasts From Within Earth
description: An accumulation of evidence is now believed to show that diamonds are brought to the surface by rocketlike eruptions that pierce the entire crust of the earth and roar into the air at supersonic speed  comparable, perhaps, to the noise of 1,000 supersonic transports.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Parents who wish to give their teenage boys an understanding of wilderness living, but who do not have the time or talent to do it themselves, would do well to consider one of the camps established for that purpose.

title: ROBERT STAUB
description: Robert Staub, a dealer who had a large collection of rare records, particularly of piano music, died last Tuesday of a heart ailment in Paris. He was 50 years old and lived here.

title: Murphy Should Stay
description: When Police Commissioner Patrick Murphy returned to New York City a little over two years ago, it was grim and depressing time both for the Police Department and the city as a whole. Rumors of a massive scandal swirled about the department in which, he had first served years earlier as a beat patrolman in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn. An entire city was gripped in an escalating fear of crime..

title: TV: WarCongress vs. President
description: From 10 to 11 last night on the Columbia Broadcasting System, Dan Rather, C.B.S. News White House correspondent, and Roger Mudd, Congressional correspondent, presided over a well organized review of The Long WarCongress vs. the President. The subject does not lend itself to visual excitement. Mired in constitutional complexities, it requires talking heads, a format that still gets many TV newsmen nervous, despite the fact that the result depends entirely on which heads are talking about what.

title: 14 FOOD PLACES HERE GET HEALTH NOTICES
description: Gordon Chase, the Health Services Administrator, yesterday issued a list of 14 foodprocessing establishments that have been cited for violations of the Health Code.

title: GERMANY TO STUDY STEEL STOCK RISE
description: BONN, March 19The West German Government called today for an investigation into stockmarket activity related to a merger of two German steel companiesAugust Thyssen and Rheinstahlwhich would create the largest steel producer in Western Europe.

title: Notes on People
description: About to be cast ashore after two and a half years of the sailor's life, David Eisenhower seemed a little at sea about his future. Admitting that life in the Navy had made me restless, the lieutenant junior grade and Presidential soninlaw said: Now I'm trying to plan for my future. I'm 25 years old and my life's been very structured up to this point. I have to set my course in the next three weeks.

title: CITY LOSES SUIT ON HOUSING COURT
description: In an unusual suit, in which top judicial officials had sued the city, the Lindsay administration was ordered in State Supreme Court yesterday to provide funds for the city's new Housing Court, which is supposed to begin functioning On April, 1.

title: Stocks Off Sharply On Amex, OTC; Tight Money Seen
description: News of an increase in the prime rate by some major banks sent prices down sharply yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 20, 1973 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Chess: The Game's Not Won Until The Other Side Cries Uncle!
description: One of the most difficult tasks in chess is winning a won game, and when it comes to telling theonethatgotaway stories, chessplayers make fishermen sound tonguetied.

title: Voice of Clarion Power
description: During the nineteenthirties at the Metropolitan Opera, Wagner was the king of composers, thanks to a group of great sopranos  Frida Leider, Maria Mueller, Kirsten Flagstad and Grete Stckgold among themand one tenor. The tenor was, of course, Lauritz Melchior. There were other tenors who relieved him in the Wagnerian roles, but they were to him what a relief pitcher in those days was to Lefty Grove. It was Melchior, who, season in and season out, could be depended upon to thrill audiences in the most demanding tenor roles of the literature  the Heldentenor roles of Siegfried and Tristan especially. Wagner asks his singers to blast through a formidable orchestration without ever giving the feeling of blasting: and to bring serious musicianship to those roles; and to uphold the ideal of the Gesamtkunstwerkthe union of music and drama to create a unique synthesis. Melchior upheld this ideal better than any Wagnerian tenor of his time.

title: 12 MORE P. O. W.'S LAND AT M'GUIRE
description: McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N. J., March 19 Ten military servicemen and two civilians, all former Vietnam war prisoners, arrived here by transport plane shortly after 3 P.M. today.

title: Philadelphia Transit Delay Linked to Contract Talks
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 19 (UPI)Service on the heavily traveled Broad Street subway and, on most surface routes operated by the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority was halted for 35 minutes today at the start of the morning rush hour.

title: MURPHY TO LEAVE BEFORE YEAR ENDS
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that he would not serve beyond the end of Mayor Lindsay's term, which expires Dec. 31, 1973.

title: Court Bars Student Ouster Over Obscenity in Press
description: WASHINGTON, March 19State university officials cannot shut off the dissemination of offensive ideas by expelling a student who circulates them in print, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: F.T.C. SHIFTS VIEW ON RULE MAKING
description: WASHINGTON, March 19The Federal Trade Commission, in a change of position, informed Congress today that it did not want legislation affirming its rulemaking powers, at least for the time being.

title: Refinery Workers Strike
description: MARCUS HOOK, Pa., March 19 (AP)Approximately 1,700 workers struck the Sun Oil Company refinery at Marcus Hook today after voting yesterday to reject a new twoyear contract.

title: ...Government of the (White) People
description: Our TV sets show us desperate men entrenched on a prairie hilltop, clutching Molotov cocktails, defying the forces of law and order. Wrapped in flopping blankets, painted for war, they glower at the viewer over the sights of their hunting rifles.

title: PLANS BEGUN TO END REGION HEALTH UNITS
description: WASHINGTON, March 19Many of the Regional Medical Programs ordered out of existence by the Administration in Washington have already submitted their phaseout plans although Congress has not yet agreed to ending them.

title: Sears Operating Net Rises By 12% on 9.7% Sales Gain
SHOP TALK
description: Take away that light box devised by Earl M. Reiback as the roof of his $8,500 modem bed and what's left? Aside from the hole, there's a stainless steel fourposter and a saving of $7,500.

title: City Charges A.&P. Continues to Ignore Promises on Sales
description: A survey of A. & P. supermarkets in four boroughs has led to charges by the Department of Consumer Affairs that the food chain has committed more than 300 violations of a 1972 agreement in which it had promised to have sale items properly priced and to have them available.

title: Sandman Scores Structure Of Bergen Primary Ballot
description: HACKENSACK, March 19Representative Charles W. sandman Jr., an avowed candidate for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, contended today that the way the Bergen County primary ballot was structured had worked to the detriment of his candidacy four years ago.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, March 19Daily index numbers and spot primary market commodity prices March 6, 1973 to March 13, 1973.

title: Peking Audience Warm To London Philharmonic
description: PEKING, Tuesday, March 20The first Western symphonic orchestra ever to play in China received an enthusiastic reception from an audience here last nightespecially when it threw a dash of Chinese revolutionary music into its repertory of European classics.

title: Dollar Upin Calm Trading; Markets Reopen in Europe
description: PARIS, March 19The dollar moved sharply higher against the key European currencies early today when official foreignexchange trading resumed after a 17day shutdown. Later in the day the dollar retreated, still closing with a net gain on the day.

title: U.S. ASKING RULES ON MINING OF SEA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19The United States proposed today, that temporary regulations be established to cover undersea mining of minerals until a United Nations seabed treaty goes into effrect.

title: Decreases of 8% to 18% Are Also Reported for Print Paper
description: Price reductions ranging from 8 per cent to 18 per cent for its most popular sizes of amateur color negative film and for print paper were announced yesterday by the Eastman Kodak Company.

title: Sun Oil Says It Will Pay 25c per Barrel More for Oklahoma Crude
description: The Sun Oil Company announced yesterday a 25cent rise in the price it pays for Oklahoma crude oil as momentum appeared to build for industrywide price increases.

title: Paley, C.B.S. Chairman, Personally Vetoed Showing of Sticks and Bones
description: William S. Paley, board chairman of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., personally vetoed the showing Sticks and Bones a biting drama about a blinded Vietnam veteran's homecoming, on the C.B.S.TV network as scheduled for March 9, it was learned yesterday.

title: INTEREST LAGGING FOR SCHOOL VOTE
description: Excuse me, are you registered?

title: He Pedals for Pennies
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia There are about 100,000 pedicabs in Jakarta, most owned in fleets by wealthy people who rent them out for 100 to 125 rupiahs (25 to 30 cents) for 12 hours.

title: Connecticut Plans Raid To Get City Businesses
description: HARTFORD, March 19 Gov. Thomas J. Meskill announced today that he would lead a team of high state officials and corporate executives on a recruiting raid into New York City next month to persuade business and industries to move to Connecticut.

title: HARM TO CHICANOS IS LAID TO SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, March 19Public schools and teachers in the Southwest favor white students in classroom discussions and thus seriously hinder educational opportunity for MexicanAmerican students, the United States Civil Rights Commission said today.

title: 14th Body Recovered
description: FAIRFAX, Va., March 19 (AP)Crews have found the body of Nabil S. Ramia, 21 years old, of Arlington, completing their search for the 14 known dead in the March 2 collapse of a partly constructed apartment building at Baileys Crossroads.

title: Judge Is Letting Defendants Use LookAlikes to Test Witnesses
description: In what has turned into an unusual experiment on possible mistakes in identification in criminal cases, Criminal Court Judge Benjamin Altman has allowed defense counsel to bring lookalikes into hearings for a courtroom lineup to verify whether complainants can identify suspects.

title: STAY IS GRANTED ON TAX RECORDS
description: Four Manhattan realestate concerns won a temporary stay in State Supreme Court yesterday against a, move by the city to disclose their financial statements in connection with their applications for reductions in their propertytax assessments.

title: Wheaton to Raise Tuition
description: NORTON, Mass., March 19 (AP)Wheaton College will increase tuition lees by $350 year next September, raising the yearly fee for tuition, room, board and student fees to $4,530, college officials announced today. Wheaton, private college for women, has an enrollment of 1,175.

title: Limon Dancers Stir Soviet Memories
description: MOSCOW, March 19The Jos Limn Dance Company of New York brought an unusual art form to Moscow this weekend, and its distinctive brand of interpretive dance evoked mixed initial reaction among Soviet viewers.

title: Americans to Be at Soviet Consoles in Space Mission
description: HOUSTON, March 19Soviet space officials have agreed that, for the 1975 joint mission between American and Soviet astronauts, American flight controllers will be allowed at the consoles of the Soviet control center on the basis of technical necessity.

title: Rhodesia Begins the Trial Of Journalist in Private
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 19Peter Niesewand, a 29yearold freelance journalist, went on trial here today, accused of violating Rhodesia's Official Secrets Act.

title: DEMOCRATS PICK CASO'S OPPONENT
description: FRANKLIN SQUARE, L. I., March 19  The Democratic County Committee tonight named William J. Deeley Jr., 54yearold Merrick lawyer, as the candidate for County Executive in the November elections.

title: DATE SET IN TRIAL ON BRAIN SURGERY
description: DETROIT, March 19 (UPI)A three judge panel of the Wayne County Circuit Court has set March 27 for the start of arguments on the legality of experimental brain surgery on involuntarily held mental patients.

title: WENDELL PIGMAN, LEGISLATIVE AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, March 19Wendell H. Pigman, a Congressional aide who helped in reshaping the United States policy toward the use of chemical and biological warfare weapons, died yesterday in the Veterans Hospital here. His age was 42. He had been using an artificial kidney machine for five years.

title: ASHE ADVANCES, BEATS EL SHAFEI
description: MERRIFIELD, Va., March 19 (UPI)  Arthur Ashe, seeded fifth, defeated Ismail et Shafei of Egypt tonight in the Union Trust Tennis Classic, 63, 67, 60.

title: JAIL GUARDS GIVEN STRIKE INJUNCTION
description: BOSTON, March 19  The State Department of Correddons won a temporary injunction State Supreme Court today ordereing Walpole State Prison guards to end a fiveday work stoppage.

title: 6 HIGH NIXON AIDES LINKED TO ACCORD BY US WITH L.T.T.
description: WASHINGTON, March 19A House subcommittee made public today documents purporting to show that at least six previously unnamed highranking officials of the Nixon Administration were involved in a successful attempt to persuade the Justice Department to settle its antitrust suits against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation on terms acceptable to the company.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In EasternStandard Time

title: Realty Agent Penalized in Sex Bias Case
description: TRENTON, March 19The State Supreme Court today upheld the power of the Division on Civil Rights to assess pain and suffering penalties against persons or corporations adjudged guilty of discrimination.

title: Air Controllers Get An Accord With U.S. On Contract Terms
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)Tentative agreement was announced today on the first labor contract between the Federal Government and the union representing 15,000 air traffic controllers throughout the United States.

title: Dollar Up in Calm Trading; Markets Reopen in Europe
description: PARIS, March 19The dollar moved sharply higher against the key European currencies early today when official foreignexchange trading resumed after a 17day shutdown. Later in the day the dollar retreated, still closing with a net gain on the day.

title: Nixon's Education RevenueSharing Bill Gets Hostile Reception in House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 19The Nixon Administration officially disclosed its longawaited and highly controversial bill for education revenue sharing on Capitol Hill today and got a largely hostile reaction to virtually every part of it.

title: Judge Is Letting Defendants Use LookAlikes to Test Witnesses
description: In what has turned into an unusual experiment on possible mistakes in identification in criminal cases, Criminal Court Judge Benjamin Altman has allowed defense counsel to bring lookalikes into hearings for a courtroom lineup to verify whether complainants can identify suspects.

title: People in Sports: Bids Go Up
description: Chris Dundee, a Miami boxing promoter, has offered. $1million to George Fore man to defend his heavyweight title against Jimmy Ellis in the Miami Beach Convention Hall in. May or June. Dundee, who earlier had offered Foreman $500,000 and then $600,000, raised his price in a telegram to Dick Sadler, Foreman's manager.

title: TransAtlantic Air Fares Likely to Rise Under Pact
description: Prospects of a fare cut this year on regularly scheduled transAtlantic flights virtually disappeared yesterday.

title: The Jobless and Their Problems Jam Asian Cities
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Pitung's fever was two days old when his stomach pains started. He lifted himself off his cardboard sleeping mat, across the dirt floor and out the cloth door of his friend's bambooframed cardboard shanty to the edge of the canal five feet away. There, as mosquitoes swarmed in the damp predawn darkness, he vomited. Then he returned to his mat and, his friend said, he shook uncontrollably.

title: $650Million Transit Deal Defeated Again in Albany
description: ALBANY, March 19For the second week in a row, the Republican leadership in the Assembly failed to round up enough votes for Governor Rockefeller's bill granting final approval of a $650million bistate transit package, including an express rail spur from Manhattan to Kennedy Airport.

title: U.N.'s Toulouseautrec Goes Home
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19After 25 years, Claude Bottiau, painter, designer of United Nations stamps and caricaturist of the world's great, has left the staff and gone home to France.

title: HONDA DEVELOPS EMISSION SYSTEM
description: WASHINGTON, March 19The Honda Motor Company of Japan said today that it had developed an auto pollutioncontrol system for conventional piston engines that would meet the 1975 American emission standards for two major pollutants  hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide.

title: Stocks Plunge as Banks Raise Prime Rate
description: The stock market plunged sharply yesterday after a group of major banks posted an increase in their prime lending rates and caused Wall Street to shift its focus from the European currency exchanges to the domestic economy.

title: Compensation Law Slated for Study At Public Hearings
description: NEWARK, March 19 (AP)A lawyer for the State Commission of Investigation said today the commission would soon begin public hearings on alleged abuses in the Workmen's Compensation System.

title: Night in Midtown, Through the Eyes of Anticrime Team
description: The three policemen were watching, crouched in their car, and every so often moaning about the ineptitude of the burglar across the street. He had just put one garbage can on top of another and used them to climb to a secondstory window. Then he had fallen off the garbage cans.

title: U.S. BARS ASYLUM FOR TWO CUBANS
description: WASHINGTON, March 19Citing the spirit of the recentCuban  American agreement against hijacking, the United States has refused to grant asylum to two Cuban fishermen who briefly seized control of their nineman fishing boat at sea.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Mother Greets Marine, Once Identified as Dead
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif. March 19Mrs. Mildred A. Ridgeway of Houston wept again today for her eldest son, but this time her tears were for joy over his return from five years of Vietcong imprisonment.

title: MISSISSIPPI FLOODS ISOLATE COLUMBUS
description: Water from the flooded Tombigbee River left Columbus, Miss., a virtual island yesterday as rivers swollen by the weekend's torrential rains crested on the day before the start of spring.

title: Lindsay Signs Bill Requiring Licenses In Massage Parlors
description: Mayor Lindsay signed into law yesterday a bill intended to wipe out sex from massage parlors. At the same time, enforcement officials geared to cope with anticipated subterfuges to keep prostitution going under the guise of other types of legal businesses.

title: G.I. IMPERSONATOR ENTERS GUILTY PLEA
description: BALTIMORE;, March 19 (AP) Thomas E. Southerland pleaded guilty today to four counts of possessing false military identification and leave papers in a case that the Government had contended earlier involved heroin smuggling.

title: Wounded Knee
description: VISIT WOUNDED KNEE The billboard said Way back at the main highway. And now half the world has got the message.

title: 50 Killed by Gas Explosions At Mine in Northeast India
description: NEW DELHI, March, 19At least 50 coal miners were reported killed last night in a series of underground gas explosions near the town of Dhanbad in the state of Bihar, 150 miles northwest of Calcutta.

title: Vietnam Accord on U. S Missing Is Due
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 19 (AP)The United States, North and South Metnam and the Vietcong were reported near agreement today On a combined search for ericans and. American dead unaccounted for in Vietnam. A United States spokesman said that the operation was expected to take years.

title: TV: Flawed Red Pony
description: Television has come up with such a beautifully produced version of John Steinbeck's The Red Pony that one dramatic flaw, sustained for two hours (with commercials), cannot be dismissed. The program was shown Sunday night over the National Broadcasting Company network.

title: Demanding Works Sang in 1st Recital By Sherrill Milnes
description: Sherrill Milnes has never been one stint, and by generously plying his ample voice over the last decade In the world's opera houses he has become today's leading baritone in the Italian repertory. And rightly so, because his basic vocal endowment is a prodigious one. Mr. Milnes was in Philharmonic Halle Sunday afternoon for his first New York recital, again in a typically expansive mood with a long, demanding program.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: High Officials of Saigon and Vietcong Open Talks in Paris on Political Future
description: PARIS, March 19  The rival South Vietnamese admirdstrations opened negotiations on the political future of their country here today, seven weeks after procilamation of the ceasefire.

title: KESSLER'S CONCERT IS TINAYRE TRIBUTE
description: Paul Kessler, tenor and former student of Yves Tinayre, presented a concert in tribute to the late French singermusicologist Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. Mr. Kessler devoted most of the first half if his program to medieval, Renaissance and baroque pieces researched by his teacher, and to the extent that it recalled Tinayre's cultivated artistry, and reintroduced us to some of the neglected masterworks in the Tinayre library, it was an important event.

title: Business Briefs
description: The consent order of the International Controls Corporation, which last week severed the company from a massive fraud suit by the Securities and Exchange Commission, yesterday cleared the way for the reinstatement of a New York law firm that had been disqualified in the case.

title: 3 SWASTIKAS DAUBED ON GREEK SYNAGOGUE
description: ATHENS, March 19  Three swastikas were daubed on the main Athens synagogue with black shoe polish today in the first incident of its kind in eight years here.

title: Soviet Waives Its exit Tax For Five Leaving for Israel
description: MOSCOW, March 19The Soviet authorities waived emigration taxes for at least five educated Jews today in what appeared to be the start of an effort to appease American Congressional opposition to an easing of trade with the Soviet Union.

title: Hitchhiker Takes Car
description: MILTON, Mass., March 19 (AP)Two young women who picked up a male hitchhiker in Boston were found nude in the Blue Hill Reservation yesterday. They told the police that the hitchhiker robbed them, took their clothes and drove away with their car.

title: POLAND ACTS TO PUT MRS. RYAN ON TRIAL
description: WARSAW, March 19 (Reuters)Poland has asked the United States to extradite Hermine BraunsteinerRyan for trial for her alleged activities as a former Nazi concentration camp guard.

title: 28% of SubCabinet Jobs Vacant 2 Months After the Inauguration
description: WASHINGTON, March 19Two months after President Nixon's inauguration for a secand term, more than a quarter of the major subCabinet positions in his Administration remain to be filled.

title: G.M. Chief Sees No Need For Auto Strike This Year

description: The PBW Stock Exchange won a minor skirmish yesterday in its court battle against a Securities and Exchange Commission rule that institutional members transact at least 80 per cent of their business with the public or unaffiliated investors.

title: Soviet Waives Its Exit Tax For Five Leaving for Israel
description: MOSCOW, March 19The Soviet authorities waived emigration taxes for at least five educated Jews today what appeared to be the start of an effort to appease American Congressional opposition to an easing of trade with the Soviet Union.

description: WASHINGTON, March 19State university officials cannot shut off the dissemination of offensive ideas, by expelling, a student who circulates them print, the, Supreme Court, ruled today.

description: PINE. RIDGE, S. D., March 19Oglala Sioux tribesmen in opposition to the tribal council chairman, Richard Wilson, began proceedings today that could lead to the overthrow of his government.

description: WASHINGTON, March 19  Yields on United States threemonth Treasury bills today rose to their highest level since Sept. 4, 1970. Sixmonth bill rates hit their highest level since June 22, 1970.

title: Protecting the Aged
description: Only one aspect of welfare reform survived in Congress last year the estublishment of a guaranteed Federal floor under income for the needy aged, blind and disabled. In most areas that Congressional decision will be of great immediate benefit to relief recipients in all three categories; but in this city and state it will mean hardship for many thousands of elderly and infirm persons unless corrective action is taken at this session of the Legislature.

title: Open Budget
description: The struggle between President Nixon and Congress over the content of the budget has directed attention to a longstanding Congressional weakness. The House and Senate lack a regular system for viewing the budget as a total entity.

title: Cumberland Director Named
description: Inder Persaud, a former director of hospitals in Guyana, South America, was named yesterday as the $31,000ayear executive director of Cumberland Hospital, a cityowned institution in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. Mr. Persaud began his career in New York's municipal hospital system in 1967 as acting administrator of Morrisania Hospital in the Bronx. He moved to Cumberland in 1968 as associate executive director,

description: WASHINGTON, March 19 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

description: TRENTON, March 19With members, voicing outrage and indignation that such an action would be necessary, the State Senate voted 34to0 today to levy a special tax on companies that leave the state and deprive their workers of pension benefits.

title: Table Shows Pattern Of Dollar's Strength
description: LONDON, March 19 (AP) The following table shows what one United States dollar would buy on foreign currency markets at the close today, last Friday and on March 1, when the latest monetary crisis began:

title: JAMES GANG OFFERS AN EXCITING ROCK
description: Hearing a band like the James Gang makes one regret the demise of the dance concert. A good portion of the audience at Carnegie Hall Sunday Bight apparently regretted it, too, so much so that they ended the evening dancing in the aisles.

description: Second Division

title: Holzman Gets a Surprise: He Ranks 4th in Victories
description: Red Holzman, coach and general manager of the New York Knicks, is so selfeffacing that it will come as a shock to his followers  as it did to him  that he ranks fourth in victories as a coach in the National Basketball Association's history.
