description: *N. A.Not available.

title: 19 REPUBLICANS CRITICAL ON ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 19Fourteen House Republicans charged today that the Nixon Administration, with its bargaining chip approach of threatening deployment of new weapons, could be impeding progress toward further agreements with the Soviet Union on limiting strategic nuclear weapons.

title: Miss Louise Mettler Married To Christopher F. Davenport
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 19  Miss Louise Mettler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Wyckoff Mettler Jr., of Welaunee Plantation here, was married this afternoon to Christopher Frederick Davenport, son of Mr.. and Mrs. Frederick M. Davenport of New York.

title: INJUNCTION ASKED BY GENERAL HOST
description: The General Host Corporation filed suit yesterday in Federal Court here in an effort to block a tender offer by Triumph American, Inc., for General Host shares.

title: Congress Clears Measure To Delay Court Revision
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)The Senate completed Congressional action today on a bill providing that changes in rules of evidence for Federal courts will not be effective until approved by Congress.

title: Dollar Is Higher Than Expected to Tokyo
description: TOKYO, March 19 The value of the dollar was higher than expected in Tokyo foreignexchange trading today. This was the first full day of trading since the market was closed more than two weeks ago because of the currency crisis.

title: 6 HIGH NIXON AIDES LINKED TO ACCORD BY U.S. WITH I.T.T.
description: WASHINGTON, March 19A House subcommittee made public today documents purporting to show that at least six previously unnamed highranking officials of the Nixon Administration were involved in a successful attempt to persuade the Justice Department to settle its antitrust suits against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation on terms acceptable to the company.

title: New York Youths Win in Science
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 A 16yearold Colorado high school senior, who came to this country from India with his family 10 years ago, was awarded a $10,000 scholarship here tonight in the 32d annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search.

title: Kuhn Says He's Appalled By KekichPeterson Case
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 19  Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn touched off a skirmish with the New York Yankees today when he said he was appalled at the exchange of families by two Yankee pitchers.

title: ' Painters Painting' Explores the Art Scene Here
description: In the past, Emile de Antonio has made some fine documentaries, including "Point of Order" and "Millhouse," each a scathing, highly biased attack against someone or something. His newest film, "Painters Painting," represents a change of mood. It's a great big, cheerfully uncritical hug of a movie about a subject he adores, the contemporary New York art scene and the people who make it hustle.Watching it is like being at a cocktail party. Robert Rauschenberg is there. Andy Warhol is there (with Brigit Berlin taking Polaroid snaps of him). Jasper Johns is there. As are Barnett Newman and Henry Geldzahler and Kenneth Noland and Frank Stella and Larry Poons. Robert Scull and Ethel are there, looking pleased and modest and just slightly uncomfortable, as if waiting for the next attack by the Philistines who refer to him as the taxi tycoon when he is really the Lorenzo di Medici of pop.The movie is mistitled. It should be called "Painters Talking." Although we do see Larry Poons ripping a large color-filled canvas off his studio floor, and although we see old still pictures of the late Jackson Pollock at work, most of the movie is devoted to the painters talking about themselves and their work.A few make sense: Jasper Johns, Willem de Kooning, Andy Warhol (at least, he smiles a lot and looks genuinely modest). At one place or another, some basic points are made about the various trends in American art that followed abstract expressionism. Much of it, however, is cocktail party conversation. Says Barnett Newman: "Esthetics are for me what ornithology is for birds.",Mr. Rauschenberg says that to be an abstract expressionist one had to have time to feel sorry for oneself. He doesn't and didn't. Mr. Stella says that the kind of contemporary painting he represents is designed, among other things, to keep the viewer from "reading" the painting, and to make it difficult for critics to describe and thus difficult to carry out their function.A lot of "Painters Painting" is funny (intentionally), some of it is boring (unintentionally) and a great deal of it is somewhat less informative than is absolutely necessary. Hilton Kramer, art editor of The New York Times, is given rather short shrift when he tries to trace the European roots of American abstract expressionism. In the festive context of the rest of the film, his attempt amounts to a social mistake.I would assume that Mr. de Antonio has some opinions (not entirely favorable) about the parts played in the New York scene by various art dealers and curators. You wouldn't know it from "Painters Painting." It all looks like a warm, lovable rat race, even though one in which the stakes can be tremendous. Leo Castelli, the dealer, smiles benignly as he tells of the Jasper Johns that was bought for $2,000 and could be sold today for $200,000.Mr. de Antonio has been an observer of the scene for years, and is obviously as fond of the artists as he is fascinated by their work, which has been beautifully photographed in color and black and white by Ed Emshwiller, who is a first-class film maker in his own right."Painters Painting," which opened yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, looks great. Like so much contemporary painting, however, it involves too much talk.

title: Krislin Wins Aqueduct Feature
description: Rallying from last place while rounding into the stretch, Harold Snyder's Krislin triumphed in the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday. Jacinto Vasquez was on the winner, who carried 112 pounds and covered the six furlongs in1:11 4/5. The runnerup in the field of five was Rafael Escudero's Supper Show. Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Lucky Payday was third.

title: TransAtlantic Air Fares Likely to Rise Under Pact
description: Prospects of a fare cut this year on regularly scheduled transAtlantic flights virtually disappeared yesterday.

title: LIBERALS CHOOSE WAGNER AS PART OF 2PARTY DEAL
description: Liberal party leaders last night designated Robert F. Wagner for Mayor, the first move in an agreement between Governor Rockefeller and the Liberals to give Mr. Wagner RepublicanLiberal endorsement.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: PROCACCINO SEEKS CONTROLLER POST
description: Because he is too poor to run for Mayor again, Mario A. Procaccino said yesterday, he will run as the populist candidate for the Controller's job that he held from 1966 through 1969.

title: LIBERALS CHOOSE WAGNER AS PART OF 2PARTY DEAL
description: Liberal party leaders last night designated Robert F. Wagner for Mayor, the first move an agreement between Governor Rockefeller and the Liberals to give Mr. Wagner RepublicanLiberal endorsement.

title: AIR TRAFFIC STRIKE IS ENDED IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, Tuesday, March 20 (Reuters)  France's striking air traffic controllers today decided to resume work following a monthlong walkout. A rapid return to normal flight conditions was expected.

title: Vernal Equinox Today Brings Start of Spring
description: Spring will arrive here officially at 1:13 P.M. today with the vernal equinox, the time when the sun crosses the equator into the Northern Hemisphere, and day and night are the same length.

title: 2 Sides of Dan Wagoner Seen in Dance Premiere
description: There are two Dan Wagon ers, one earthy and folk orlented and the other meditative and given to abstract dance patterns, and it is impossible to tell which side of Mr. Wagoner's personality will shape any given, dance. In his performance Friday evening at Westbeth, both elements were strongly present in the premiere of his new work, Changing, Your Mind.

title: Mayor Hails His Reime A s Pioneer in Productivity
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday told the first conference on productivity in government that the pioneer work done in this field by other cities, by states and to stay and would be copied byother cities, by states and even the Federal Government.

title: Frenchman Is Recalled for Canal Pact And as the Benedict Arnold of Panama
description: PANAMA, March 19BunauVarilla? He sold this country out fora platter of lentils, said Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, the leader of Panama, in an interview the other day.

title: CANADIAN RETURNS PROM VIETNAM TRIP
description: OTTAWA, March 19Returning from a sixday visit to Indochina, Mitchell, W. Sharp, Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, promised a very quick decision today on the issue of keeping Canadian observers on the International Commission of Control and Supervision.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Motion picture rights to The Sunshine Boys, Neil Simon's hit play at the Broadhurst Theater, have been acquired by Columbia Piotures and Rastar Productions, headed by Ray Stark, in what a spokesman for Rastar said could develop into the highest price ever paid for a play. Mr. Simon will write the film script of his comedy, which deals with a pair of fanious old vaudevillians, portrayed onstage by Jack Albertson and Sara Levene. Columbia plans to release the film version during the 197475 season.

title: Top Secret Label Discounted By a Witness at Ellsberg Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, March 19An expert on the system of classifying information told the jury in the Pentagon papers trial today that the label top secret on a document would be given little weight by a foreign country because the United States Government had ruined the integrity of the classification system.

title: Cahill Vetoes Shield Bill For the Press as Extreme
description: TRENTON, March 19  A controversial legislative measure that would have given reporters in New Jersey the legal privilege to refuse to disclose any news information to an investigative body was vetoed here today by Governor Cahill.

title: Music: A Protean Man
description: It might be argued that this music season has produced more imaginatively planned, more carefully rehearsed and more splendidly played concerts than the one Michael Tilson Thomas conducted for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center on Sunday evening in Alice Tully Hall. But it would have been hard to persuade this listener of any such thing after the program, which involved Mr. Thomas not only as conductor but also as pianist and actor. All this, in his debut with the society.

title: MARCH SOYBEANS DECLINE SHARPLY
description: March  delivery soybeans after setting a record of $7 a bushel several weeks ago, turned sharply downward yesterday and closed at $6, a drop of 32 cents. Daily price limits do not apply to the spot month.

title: For Jakarta Poor, Trash Means Money
description: JAKARTA, IndonesiaThe people in the kampong, or hamlet, along the canal where Pitung died make their living by picking through the trash bins of the wealthy residents of Menteng, Jakarta's prosperous residential section, which begins on the other side of the railroad tracks.

title: Kelley to Coach at Yale
description: MEADVILLE, Pa., March 19 (AP)  David Kelley has resigned as assistant football and tennis coach at Allegheny College to accept a position as an assistant football coach at Yale University,

title: Green's Distinctive Soul Singing Avoids Reliance on Microphone
description: In an age when many singers ghost, have to have their lips removed from the microphone by surgical means, the soul singer Al Green is unusual. For some of the time Sunday evening at Philharmonic Hall, he avoided the instrument, walking past it, backing off and sidling up to it, all the while Singing in his distinctive soul style.

title: Ancorp National to File Under Bankruptcy Law
description: Ancorp National Services, Inc., formerly the American News Company, will file today for an arrangement with creditors under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York.

title: Final French Vote Lineup
description: PARIS, March 19 (AP)The reelection of a centrist Reform Movement deputy in the French territory of Polynesia put the final lineup of the new aNtional Assembly at 262 seats for the Gaullists against 177 for the combined Socialist and Communist coalition, 30 for the Reform Movement and 21 scattered noparty rightists.

description: ACROSS

title: Senate Backs Secrecy on Data From Business to Cost Council
description: WASHINGTON, March 19The Senate rejected today a proposal to require big corporations to make public detailed information about products, costs and profits that they must report to the Cost of Living Council.

title: 2 Brothers, Owners of Nevele, Draw 5 Years for Tax Evasion
description: Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon yesterday sentenced two brothers who own a major Catskills hotel to fiveyear prison terms for incometax evasion and castigated them as greedy millionaires who were no better than a common thief.

title: Raiders Will Go to Court To Obtain Coliseum Dates
description: Declaring there is a protective climate surrounding the Islanders at the Nassau Coliseum at the expense of the taxpayers, a lawyer for the New York Raiders said yesterday he would go to, court today to force the Coliseum to grant playoff dates to the World Hockey Association team.

title: Boise Cascade Completes Reorganization of Debts
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation, the forestproducts company that went through an acquisition binge in the nineteensixties and just recently completed a divestiture program, announced yesterday that it had completed a re structuring of its loan agreements.

title: OHIO TAX LAWYER NAMED I.R.S. CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, March 19Donald C. Alexander, a 51yearold Cincinnati tax lawyer, was named by President Nixon today to be Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

title: PATTERN IS MIXED FOR BOND TRADING
description: The credit markets turned in a throughly mixed performance yesterday, with interest rates on both money and bonds showing no clearcut trend.

title: SOME BIG BANKS LIFT PRIME RATE TO 6% FROM 6
description: A group of major banks, led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, increased their prime lending rates yesterday by onehalf of a percentage point to 6 per cent, thus provoking a new confrontation between the Nixon Administration and the banking industry.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 19 (AP)Shane Gould of Australia set a United States record in the 1,650yard freestyle last night, finishing in 16 minutes 36.65 seconds as the threeday Southern California swimming championships ended. The 16yearold, who is training in Los Altos, Calif., beat the previous best of 16:54.6 by Debbie Meyer of Sacramento in 1970. Miss Gould was more than half a minute ahead of the secondplace finisher, Keena Rothhammer of the Santa Clara Swim Club.

title: Mailers Step Up Contract Talks With Publishers of 3 City Dailies
description: Mailers Union No, 6 intensified negotiations yesterday with the city's three major newspapers In an effort to reap an early contract agreement.

title: Advertising: TV Scramble Due
description: The three television networks will be announcing soon their fall lineup and the nation's ad agencies, with hundreds of millions of dollars of client money, are champing at the bit to buy.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In an unusual suit, in which top judicial officials sued the city, the Lindsay administration was ordered yesterday to provide $750,000 for the new Housing Court, which is supposed to reform the handling of housing cases here.

title: Driver Hits Bull and Dies
description: KENNEDY, Tex., March 19 (UPI)A deputy sheriff driving home from his small ranch struck a bull on a state highway late yesterday and died early today of injuries suffered in the accident. He was Joe P. Garza, a Karnes County law officer.

title: BREWSTER, IN DEBUT, SINGS SENSITIVELY
description: Robert Brewster is an Ameripan tenor who has studied extensively abroad as well as here. In his debut recital in fully Hall last Thursday night, the training showed in his fine, sensitive interpretations of a distinctive list of songs.

title: Byrd Scores White House Stand on Dean
description: WASHINGTON, March 19The Senate's second  ranking Democrat accused the White House today of trying to cover up involvement in the Watergate affair by invoking executive privilege to keep Presidential aides froom testifying.

title: JAIL GUARDS BACK AVER INJUNCTION
description: WALPOLE, Mass., March 19 (AP)Guards were reported showing up for the 11 o'clock shift tonight at Walpole State Prison after a state Supreme Court judge issued a backtowork order ending a strike that began last Wednesday.

title: Equity Financing
description: Uniroyal, Inc., yesterday said directors had authorized purchase of up to 750,000 common shares of the company for use in connection with certain employe benefit programs and also for possible future acquisitions. The company's stock closed at 13, tip 1 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: BULGARI DIES AT 84; A LEADING JEWELER
description: ROME, March 19Constantino Giorgio Bulgari, one of Europe's best known jewelers, died yesterday at the age of 84.

title: Lauritz Melchior Is Dead; Wagnerian Tenor Was 82
description: Lauritz Melchoir, the supreme Wagnerian tenor of his era, died Sunday of a liver tumor in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 82 years old and had lived for many years at his nearby hilltop home, The Viking, overlooking Los Angeles and the San Fernando Valley.

title: Panama's DowntoEarth Leader
description: PANAMA, March 19Perhaps the most striking first impression about Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos is that he isn't at all like his public rhetoric. He is, after all, capable of oratory militant enough and powerful enough to endear him to thousands of Panamanians and to cause apprehension among Americans who want to avoid violence over Penama's insistence that substantial steps be taken soon toward granting her full sovereignty the Canal Zone.

title: Coast Coroner Says Sarah Miles's Aide Was a Drug Victim
description: GILA BEND, Ariz., March 19 (UPI)  The Los Angeles County coroner has confirmed findings that David A. Whiting, business manager of Sarah Miles, died of an overdose of tranquilizers, Justice of the Peace Mulford Winsor 4th said today.

title: U.S BARS ASYLUM FOR TWO CUBANS
description: WASHINGTON, March 19Citing the spirit of the recent Cuban  American agreement against hijacking, the United States has refused to grant asylum to two Cuban fishermen who briefly seized control of their nineman fishing boat at sea.

title: Harvard Graduatd Students Strike Over Financial Aid
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 19 (AP)More than 150 graduate students and teaching fellows at Harvard University went on strike today to protest the university's financial aid policies.

title: TOWN TURNS OUT TO GREET A P.O.W.
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 19  Sgt, Richard Perricone's hometown gave him a rousing welcome today  something they had been waiting to do for more than six years.

title: MURPHY To LEAVE BEFORE YEAR ENDS
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that he would not serve beyond the end of Mayor Lindsay's term, which expires Dec. 31, 1973.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE COLUMBUS TREE. By Peter S., Feibleman. 472 pages. Atheneum. $8.95.

title: Roland Dorgeles, Writer, Dies; President of Goncourt Academy
description: PARIS, March 19Roland Dorgeles, author of France's most successful book on World War I and president of the Goncourt Academy for the last 17 years, died yesterday at his home. He was 86 years old.

title: NEW APPEAL SENT TO THE PATHET LAO
description: BAN NA KONG, Laos, March 19With the deadline for forming a new coalition government only four days away, the Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, has sent a third cablegram to the Pathet Lao leader, Prince Souphanouvong, appealing for an urgent settlement of remaining problems.

title: Falling in Love Even Though the Fever of Youth Is Long Gone
description: They really aren't so different from young couples, these men and women who marry late in life. While with some of the septuagenarians and octogenarians it may be a case of all passion spent (all physical passion, that is), the attitudes and adjustments are about the same as if the husbands and wives were in their twenties.

title: Assembly Passes Six TaxReform Bills
description: TRENTON, March 19  The Assembly passed a package of six taxreform bills today, ineluding a key measure that would establish a fulltime tax court, and sent the measures to the Senate.

title: HEARTY PIANO STYLE BY DIONNE WEIGERT
description: The best performance in Dionne Weigert's formal, downtown New York solo debut program Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall came at the end, with Prokofiev.'s Piano Sonata No. 7. Here Miss Weigert's hearty, extroverted style and considerable dexterity could have free rein, and the result was an energetic, often exciting account of the score.

description: SUNDAY'S GAMES

description: To the Editor: The Times has a rather consistent and alarming misunderstanding regarding the situation on the Ainercan farm today.

title: BUCKS RETAIN TITLE IN MIDWEST DIVISION
description: MADISON, Wis., March 19 (AP)  Kareem AbdulJabbar scored 27 points and Oscar Robertson 25 tonight as the Milwaukee Bucks clinched their third successive National Basketball Association Midwest Division championship with a 118.99 victory over the Detroit Pistons.

title: DR. PHILIP R. CASESA, V.A. HOSPITAL HEAD
description: Dr. Philip R. Casesa, director of the Brooklyn Veterans Administration Hospital from 1960 to 1971, died Sunday in an auto accident near Jesup, Ga. He was 63 years old and lived at 15 Shepherd Avenue, Willowbrook, S. I.

title: 2 Turkish Parties Agree to Prolong President's Term
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 19 (AP)Turkey's major political parties agreed today to extend the term of President Cevdet Sunay as a compromise solution to the militarycivilian deadlock in the presidential election in Parliament.

description: WASHINGTON, March 19  Correspondence file: Committee for the ReElection of the President, Washington, D. C. Dear Committee:

title: RANGERS WIN, 61, FOR 2DPLACE TIE
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 20The New York Rangers, playing the closechecking, positional style that Coach Emile Francis demands, defeated the Minnesota North Stars tonight, 61, in the handsome Metropolitan Sports. Center.

title: Legal Bill of $150,000 Jolts Watergate Four
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 Henry B. Rothblatt, who used to complain publicly that he was not being paid enough to repttseht the four Watergate defendants from Miami, has submitted bill to the four men for about $150,000.

title: Robert Murphy, SeaBird Expert, Dies
description: Robert Cushman Murphy, one of the world's foremost authorities on marine birds, died Monday night at his home, 16 Sound Street, Stony Brook, L.I. He was 85 years old.

title: 6 AUTO MAKERS TOLD TO PROVE AD CLAIMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)  The Federal Trade Coinmission ordered three United. States and three foreign auto makers today to prove advertising claims involving such things as trunk space, soundproof interiors and handling.

title: People in Sports: 76ers No. 1
description: The Philadelphia 76ers, the worst team in the National Basketball Association, won a coin flip with the Portland Trail Blazers yesterday for the right to pick first in the N.B.A. draft April 16, but it was not clear whom the 76ers won the right to pick.

title: Steelers' Tackle races U.S. Charges in Snipings
description: PITTSBURGH, March 20 (AP) Ernest Holmes, defensive tackle for the Pittsburgh Steelers, was faced today with Federal charges stemming from a series of highway snipings in Ohio last Friday, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported.

description: BASKETBALL

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A closedcircuit television surveillance system will be installed on a twomile stretch of the Atlantic City Boardwalk by June to help cut crime.

title: The Ulster Problem
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 20The British white paper seeks to set up a political framework within which Northern Ireland's Protestants and Roman Catholics can begin to dismantle the structure, of ambitions and fears that divide them.

title: Squibb Net Rises 13% in Quarter
Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)The Federal Trade Commission said today that it would accuse two competing airconditioner manufacturers, the General Electric Company and the Chrysler Corporation, of maintaining an illegal interlocking directorate.

title: Albany Senate Votes Free Tuition for Some Vietnam Veterans
description: ALBANY, March 20  The Senate approved legislation today providing a tuitionfree college education for Vietnam veterans who were prisoners of war or missing in action, as well as for their children and the children of servicemen who were killed in the war.

title: Seaver Yields 1 Hit in 4 Innings
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 20 The New York Mets dropped a 62 decision to the Detroit Tigers today, but the news in the Met camp took place 60 miles away at HttgginsStengel Field in St. Petersburg.

title: Public Hearings Urged on Prime Rate
description: WASHINGTON, March 20Representative Wright Patman said today the law requires that Thursday's meeting between major banks that have raised their prime lending rates and the Government's Committee on Interest and Dividends be open to the public.

title: Commerce, Chief Defends Cutbacks In Funds for Poor
description: WASHINGTON, March 20The display of anguish over President Nixon's cutbacks in some social programs comes mainly from poverty middlemen and not the poor, Secretary of Commerce Frederick B. Dent said today.

title: Stealersapos
description: PITTSBURGH, March 20 (AP) Ernest Holmes, defensive tackle for the Pittsburgh Steelers, was faced today with Federal charges stemming from a Series of highway snipings in Ohio last Friday, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported.

title: Summary and Conclusion of British Government White Paper on Northern Ireland
description: LONDON, March 20Following are the summary and conclusions in the British Government's white paper setting out its constitutional Proposals for Northern Ireland:

title: Biggest Intelligence Layoff
description: WASHINGTON, March 20James R. Schlesinger, the new Director of Central Intelligence has begun the largest personnel cutback in the history of the agency.

title: Biggest Intelligence Layoff
description: WASHINGTON, March 20James R. Schlesinger, the new Director of Central Intelligence, has begun the largest personnel cutback in the history of the agency.

title: Canada Remains Unbeaten In World Curling Tourney
description: REGINA, Saskatchewan, March. 20 (Canadian Press) The ice improved and so did the curling today in the third round of the world curling championship as Canada retained its undefeated record. The Canadians ran into tough competition before subduing the previously unbeaten French foursome, 65.

title: Today Is the Final Day To Register in Schools
description: Today is the last day the city's public primary schools will be open for inschool voter registration for the May 1 election of local School boards.

title: C.I.A.T. T. PLANS ON CHILE REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 A vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said today that a top official of the Central Intelligence Agency had agreed with the recommendations the corporation made to try to prevent the election of Salvador Allende Gossens, a Marxist, as President of Chile.

title: Matthews Still Climbing Fences
description: Incredible as it may seem, Vince Matthews still is climbing fences to train, although the competitive goals now are pots of gold, not goldplated medals.

title: A Critic Offers Views on Women's Lib
description: I have become the figure at the center of resistance to the movement, Midge Decter says wryly. Women who two years ago would have been very fierce in the face of resistance to the movement say to me, You've picked the lunatic fringe of this movement and that's not fair. But as they go on and on with that kind of conversation, you find out that they adhere to the very ideas they describe as lunatic.

title: Japanese Decide Pollution Case
description: TOKYO, March 20A Japanese, court ruled today that a major chemical company was responsible for the mercury poisoning of people in the town of Minamata, which has given its name to a debilitating disease.

title: Denim Is Wallto Wall as 16,000 Roam at Grateful Dead Concert
description: It was walltowall decayed denim as more than 16,000 members of the youth culture crowded into the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L. I., on Mondaythe final of three evening concerts featuring the Grateful Dead, one of the longest surviving and better groups to emerge from the great San Francisco rockgroupquake of the mid1960's.

title: Police Using a Computer To Hunt Heroin Thieves
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy disclosed yesterday that a special team of detectives was using a computer in its effort to track down the men who had stolen 398 pounds of heroin and cocaine from the Police Department.

title: SOVIET MINISTER ANSWERS CRITICS
description: MOSCOW, March 20A Government Minister whose department is under fire took the unusual step today of meeting with Soviet and foreign newsmen to defend himself.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Matthews Still Clinrning Fences
description: Incredible as it may seem, Vince Matthews still is climbing fences to train, although the competitive goals now are pots of gold, not goldplated medals.

title: A $65MILLION SUIT FILED AGAINST H.U.D.
description: DETROIT, March 20 (UPI) A $65million class action suit was filed today against the Department of Housing and Urban Development, alleging that the Federal agency had sold substandard, defective homes to thousands of low  income families.

title: State to Aid Counties On Alcoholic Employes
description: TRENTON, March 20 (AP) The State Department of Health announced today it had offered to help county employes with their drinking problems.

title: Mysterious Letters On Eviction Studied By U.S. and State
description: Federal and state authorities sought yesterday to determine the origin of a flood of letters addressed to Manhattan residents, warning them of the dangers of overcrowding of cities and threatening them with eviction.

title: COLUMBIA HONORS 3 NOBEL WINNERS
description: Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia University, warned yesterday that a creeping disenthusiasm for higher education was now evident nearly everywhere in American public life and was likely to have a serious impact on American science.

title: CANADA EXCHANGES VOTE FOR A MERGER
description: MONTREAL, March 20 (Reuters)  Members of the Montreal and Canadian Stock Exchanges have voted in favor of merging the two exchanges, it was announced today.

title: GENESCO REALIGNS OFFICER STRUCTURE
description: A realignment of the senior management structure of Genesco, Inc., a diversified retailing and manufacturing company, was announced yesterday by Franklin M. Jarman, chairman and chief executive officer.

title: 6,252 to Leave H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare plans to eliminate mote than 6,000 public health jobs by the middle of next year, according to a departmental planning report.

title: Fewer Troops From Hanoi Reported Starting South
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 The United States intelligence community has reported a significant reduction in the number of North Vietnamese troops and the amount of equipment that have recently entered the infiltration routes toward South Vietnam, wellplaced Administration officials said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A closedcircuit television surveillance system will installed on a twomile stretch of the Atlantic City Boardwalk by June to help cut crime.

title: The Proceedings In the V.N. Today
description: March 21, 1973

title: WIDENER MANSION GIVEN A REPRIEVE
description: The city's Department of Buildings yesterday approved  and hours later Buildings Commissioner Joseph Stein revokedan alteration permit for the contested Widener townhouse at 5 East 70th Street that called for altering the mansion by demolishing it and erecting in its place a 16foot wall.

title: Burger Activates CourtRevision Unit
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger set into motion today an accelerated highpowered study of Federal court appeals, a move that could fundamentally restructure the nation's system for delivery of justice.

title: Table Tennis Standouts Getting In the Money
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. L, March 20  Wealthier than they were a year ago, the cream of United States table tennis players is settled here to compete, in the Eastern championships, which, begin a threeday run Friday night at the State University at Farmingdale.

title: I.C.C. Member Proposes Easing of RailRate Curbs
description: A menber of the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday proposed a relaxation of the regulatory agency's tight control over ratemaking procedures to permit increases when carriers can show increased labor costs of at least 5 per cent in any year.

title: C.I.A.I.T.T.PLANS ON CHILE REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, March 20A vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said today that a top official of the Central Intelligence Agency had agreed with the recommendations the corporation made to try to prevent the election of Salvador Allende Gossens, a Marxist, as President of Chile.

title: By Arnold Whitridge
description: NEW HAVENOn the question of amnesty, one of those disagreeable questions which refuses to go away, most of us probably stand midway between Mr. Nixon's nevernever, and the extraordinary demand made by deserter and a draft evader on the OpEd page Feb. 28 for immediate and unconditional amnesty for all those who, like themselves, had defied the laws of the United States. The effect of these two letters was to make us more sympathetic with the President's categorical No, but that is not the last word on the subject either.

title: Tohill to Have Amputation
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., March 20 (AP)  Doctors annonced today that Billy Tohill, Texas Christian University's head football coach, will have his right foot amputated tomorrow The 33yearold Tohill suffered multiple injuries in a onecan traffic accident a week ago The amputation is necessary to restore circulation, doctors said.

title: Notes on People
description: Summing up his opinion of the proceedings with a proud smile, Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas witnessed the swearingin of his wife, Cathleen, as a member of the District of Columbia bar. The brief ceremony took place before a threejudge panel specially convened in the District of Columbia Court of Appeals to enable Justice Douglas to attend after the Supreme Court had recessed for the day. Mrs. Douglas has applied for a position in the United States Attorney's office. Justice Douglas said he had no idea if she would get the job.

title: Collage Show Honors Joseph Cornell
description: From 1929 until his death last December at the age of 69, the American artist Joseph Cornell lived and worked in a modest, whiteshingled house on Utopia Parkway in Flushing, Queens. Although his work was widely exhibited both here and abroadin recent years, there were notable exhibitions at both the Guggenheim and Metropolitan museums in New York and at the Documenta show in Kassel, West Germanyand his reputation was more or less established as a ciassic, his accomplishments had never met with any official recognition in the borough where he had made his home for the entire course of his artistic career.

title: Vietnam Veteran Parade Is Shifted to Broadway
description: A parade honoring returning veterans of the war in Vietnam that was originally scheduled for Fifth Avenue on March 31 will instead start at 37th Street and Broadway and move up Broadway and Central Park West to 72d Street.

title: The Dirty Float
description: And so the world is launched upon the new era of floating. To be sure, it is not a clean launch but a dirty one, with governments intervening in currency markets. But the dollar has bobbed upward in relation to most other currencies in waters that seem remarkably calm. How long will stability last? Is it conceivable that, under the pressure of the most serious monetary crisis of the postwar era, the major financial powers of the nonCommunist world have already laid the basis for a new, durable international monetary system?

title: ISLANDERS DOWN GOLDEN SEALS, 63
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 20 The New York Islanders reached a milestone in the Nassau Coliseum tonight when they won their second, straight National Hockey League game, beating the California Golden Seals, 63.

title: POLICE TEAM SEIZES A SUSPECT IN RAPE
description: A teacher's aide who was raped last November at a Harlem school identified a 17yearold youth as her assailant yesterday after the case was reopened by two detectives assigned to an experimental neighborhood police team.

title: Three Are Named To Staff of S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, March 20Lee A. Packard was named today director of the division of market regulation of the Securities and Exchange Commission in a series of staff appointments announced by G. Bradford Cook, the agency's chairman.

title: Office Dropout Revels as Clown
description: For a graduate of the Institute of Insurance Marketing at Southern Methodist University, Leon McBryde's life took a pretty drastic turn when he ran away from the 9to5 life to become what he had wanted to be since he was 8 years old, a circus clown.

title: WORD IS DELAYED
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner has decided to run for Mayor, high Republican and Liberal party sources reported yesterday.

title: PANAMA ACCUSES U.S. OVER TREATY
description: PANAMA, March 20Panama accused the United States today of attempting to maintain the status quo in the Canal Zone. The charge followed United States declaration of willingness to conclude a new Canal treaty promptly and give up a substantial part of the zone.

title: CHINA, IN U.N., BACKS DEVELOPING NATIONS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20  China made a strong attempt today to assume the leadership of the developing countries of the world in the international effort to draw a law governing the waters that cover 70 per cent of the earth's surface.

title: HARTFORD JUDGE BACKS NEWSPAPER
description: HARTFORD, March 20  A Federal judge has ruled here that the publisher of The Wallingford Post need not reveal the names of confidential sources he used in an article linking a philanthropist and dogtrack promoter with the Mafia.

title: Anarchy of Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTONSecretary of State Rogers has begun a quiet but intensive inquiry into the problem of protecting American ambassadors and their staffs in foreign capitals from the outlaws who are now terrorizing the diplomatic community.

title: N. Carolina, Irish. Advance in N.I.T.
description: Notre Dame proved last night it belongs in the National Invitation Tournament for more reasons than to sell tickets.

title: Earth Day Hails Start Of Spring
description: Spring arrived yesterday afternoon, and along with it came the first of a series of days set aside here this year to mark concern about the environment.

title: Nixon's Men: All Work and No Fills
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 One of President Nixon's aides was talking the other day about the rather drab image he and his White House colleagues seem to have with the public and the press.

title: DR. DAVID AARON SWICK
description: Dr. David Aaron Swick, an ophthalmologist who was medical director, of Yeshiva University from 1929 to 1950, died Saturday in Washington. He was 94 years old and had been living in La Plata, Md.

title: U.S. Court Voids CatchAllArticle Of Military Code
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia held as unconstitutionally vague today the socalled general article of the Uniform Code of Military Justice, which holds servicemen liable for actions to the prejudice of the good order and discipline in the armed forces.

title: U.S. Six Upsets Germans
description: MUNICH, March 20 (AP)The United States upset West Germany, 84, today in exhibition hockey in preparation for the world tournament. West Germany, a Group A competitor, beat the Group B Americans, 53, yesterday in GarmischPartenkirchen.

title: KEKICH, M'DANIEL DEFEAT REDS 10
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 20 Mike Kekich and Lindy McDaniel stopped the Cincinnati Reds on four hits today in pitching the New York Yankees to a 10 exhibition victory, their fourth straight against National League teams.

title: Parents' Tugging Breaks Arm Of Gorilla Baby at the Park Zoo
description: Patty Cake, the tiny gorilla baby that has drawn thousands to the Central Park Zoo, suffered a broken arm yesterday, either from the playfulness of her massive parents or from parental rivalry.

title: SMITH REGISTERS 82, 62 VICTORY
description: ATLANTA, March 20 (AP)Stan Smith blasted his way past Jos Edison Mandario, 62, 62, in the first round of the $50,000 Peachtree Corners international tennis tournament tonight.

title: Advertising: Some New Firsts
description: Now that the economy is moving up, manufacturers are getting back into the swing of introducing new products.

title: 6,252 to Leave H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare plans to eliminate more than 6,000 public health jobs by the middle of next year, according to a departmental planning report.

title: Bridge: After Two Years, the Aces Recapture Vanderbilt Title
description: ST. LOUIS, March 20 Early today, the Aces regained the Vanderbilt Knockout Team title that they last won two years ago, and gained confidence for the coming battle in Brazil in May, when they will try to retain their world title.

title: Trainer Claims a RooterShe's 3
description: Horses coming, squealed 3yearold Kristine King yesterday as the field in the third rate at Aqueduct jogged past the stands en route to the post.

title: Paterson College Protest Is Continued by Students
description: WAYNE, N.J., March 20For the second day today, a group of students at William Paterson College struck and demonstrated in support of faculty members who have been denied tenure or not been rehired for the fall term.

title: Quarter Net and Revenues At Records for A.T.&T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company continued its recordbreaking pace into 1973 and reported yesterday new highs in revenues and net income for the three months ended Feb. 28.

title: Rockets Deal Tams 13th Loss in a Row On 11397 Decision
description: MEMPHIS, March 20 (AP)Denver's Al Smith provided the spark near the end of the third period that helped the Rockets to a 11397 victory over the Meniphis Tams in an American Basketball Association game tonight. It was the Tams' 13th straight loss.

title: 4 More Oil Refiners Raise Price They Pay for Crude
description: The Shell Oil Company, the Phillips Petroleum Company, the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Continental Oil Company yesterday announced 25centabarrel increases in the prices they pay for crude oil.

title: Baker Wins $9,956 At Track but LosesTicket to 3 Gunmen
description: A Queens baker who won $9,956.10 at Roosevelt Raceway discovered sadly Monday night that three men who broke into his shop wearing ski masks and brandishing guns had a very hot tip: they knew all about his good luck.

title: 2 YACHT HONORS TO RUNNING TIDE
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 20The class champions of the seventh biennial MiamiMontego Bay yacht race are Lightnin, the overall and Class C winner, Aura in Class B and Running Tide in Class A.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH F. A. CUP

title: Disease Thwarts Hopes of Asia's Poor
description: TRIWUNG KIDAL, Indonesia Misty volcanoes on the horizon. Groves of banyan, bamboo and fruit trees. A dozen hues of green. A crystal blue sky with cottonpuff clouds. Beautiful maidens in brightly colored batik sarongs. Snoozing dogs, cows and goats. Naked children frolicking in a stream.

title: U.S. Six Upsets Germans
description: MUNICH, March 20 (AP)The United States upset West Germany, 84, today in exhibition hockey in preparation for the world tournament. West Germany, a Group A competitor, beat the Group B Americans, 53, yesterday in GarmischPartenkirchen.

title: Moore Hails Increase
description: The Bankers Trust Company, whose prime lending rate remains at 6 per cent, voiced strong support yesterday for the commercial banks that raised the politically sensitive basic loan rate to 6 per cent on Monday.

title: Milwaukee Road Buys Cars
description: CHICAGO, March 20 (AP)The Milwaukee Road announced today that it had ordered 500 covered hopper cars for use primarily in moving grain. The equipment will cost about $9million and will be built by the PullmanStandard division of Pullman, Inc.

title: COURT, 63, BACKS WEIGIITED VOTING
description: WASHINGTON, March 20The Supreme Court ruled today that its oneman, onevote mandate need not be observed in electing officials of specialpurpose governmental bodies.

title: Newark Detective of Many Disguises Gets a Bit Part in TV Film of His Life
description: NEWARK, March 20 (AP) David Toma has played beggar, a banker, a junkie and a junk dealer, and now someone else is playing David Toma.

title: Table Tennis Standouts Getting In the Money
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., March 20  Wealthier than they were a year ago, the cream of United States table tennis players is settled here to compete in the Eastern championships, which begin a threeday run Friday night at the State University at Farmingdale.

title: 3 Arts Leaders, Citing a Funds Crisis, Urge StepUp tionate share of Federal arts
description: Three national arts leaders told a Congressional subcommittee here yesterday that the arts in America, despite unparalleled growth in audience and earned income, are facing a serious financial crisis and urged major increases in Federal and state funding to insure their survival.

title: Dio, in Unusual Argument, Makes Bid for New Trial
description: John Dioguardi, a convicted labor racketeer known as Johnny Dio, made an unusual move for a new trial in Federal Court here yesterday because of a letter he received in prison from a member of the jury that convicted him on Jan. 26 in a stockfraud case.

title: 2 Cubans Who Fled From Fishing Boat Surrender to U.S.
description: MIAMI, March 20 (AP)Two 21yearold Cubans who were said to have commandeered a Cuban fishing boat and tried to reach Mexico were charged today with illegal entry into the United States.

title: Auto Racing Followers Facing Loss of a Treat
description: One of the great treats of auto racing is seeing a versatile driver competing in some format away from home base A. J. Foyt winning a stockcar race at Daytona, Mark Donohue winning the Indianapolis 500, Mario Andretti winning a Grand Prix. Now, if the United States Auto Club goes through with a policy just made public you'll see fewer USAC drivers in sports  car and NASCAR events and fewer outside drivers in USAC races.

title: RECORDS ARE SET BY PORK BELLIES
description: Hog and pork bellies again set record prices in futures trading yesterday as they had done on Monday.

title: STATE CHALLENGES BENEFIT FOR CHILD
description: DENVILLE, March 20  A promoter was charged today with exploiting the case of a girl who is suffering from a rare intestinal disorder to obtain money by false pretenses.

title: ELLSBERG WITNESS EXPLAINS SECRECY
description: LOS ANGELES, March 20The late Ho Chi Minh would have had to telephone the Defense Department to determine whether one of the top secret documents in the Pentagon papers trial was genuine, a defense witness testified today.

title: Alert Prosecutors
description: The recent international conference for the protection of endangered animal species owes some part of its great success to the dramatic prosecution of a major fur dealer and civil suits against 31 others here in New York. The delegates in Washington were clearly shaken by the volume of illegal trade thus disclosed, and they drew the obvious conclusion that much more stringent efforts had to be made on a worldwide basis if such threatened creatures as the spotted cats were still be saved.

title: Though Many Guess, Only Marchi Knows
description: ALBANY, March 20  Will he or won't he? Only Senator John J. Marchi knows for sure.

title: Fetver Troops From Hanoi Reported Starting South
description: WASHINGTON, March 20The United States intelligence community has reported a significant reduction in the number of North Vietnamese troops and the amount of equipment that have recently entered the infiltration routes toward South Vietnam, wellplaced Administration officials said today.

title: LAWYER RECEIVES 5 YEARS AS BRIBER
description: A prison sentece of five years was imposed yesterday on Edmund A. Rosner, a New York lawyer convicted of bribery and obstruction of justice.

title: Roberto Jr., 8, Wants That RightField Job
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20 (UPI)Mrs. Roberto Clemente, here for the announcement of her husband's election to the baseball Hall of Fame, described today some of the heartaches since her husband's death little more than 11 weeks ago.

title: SOVIET GETS LOAN FROM EXIMBANK
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (Reuters)The Government's ExportImport Bank announced today that agreement had been reached with Soviet officials providing for $202.4million in United States loans and guarantees for the purchase of American industrial equipment.

title: Philip McMaster, Physiologist, Rockefeller U. Professor, Dies
description: Dr. Philip Duryee McMaster, professor emeritus of the Rockefeller University and a wellknown physiologist and pathologist, died yesterday in Mount Kisco, N. Y. He was 81 years old and lived on River Road, Cos Cob, Conn. He also had homes in Kennebunkport, Me. and at 157 East 72d Street.

title: Rockefeller Stays Away As Top Aides Win Backing
description: ALBANY, March 20  A sixhour meeting between Governor Rockefeller's top aides and the five New York City Republican county chairmen ended tonight with a terse statement in which the chairmen backed away from their open criticism of the Governor's choice of Robert F. Wagner as a mayoral candidate and agreed to use their best efforts in his behalf.

title: People and Business
description: Cordell Hull was named managing director yesterday of a new Londonbased subsidiary of the American ExCompany. A nephew of the late Cordell Hull, who was Secretary of State under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, he will head the American Express International Development Company, Ltd., which will provide financial services to multinational companies.

title: Kleindienst Orders Gray Not to Discuss Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, March 20L. Patrick Gray 3d told Senators today that under new orders from Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst he could no longer discuss the Watergate case in defending his 10month record as acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Republicans Wrest Control in 3 Villages In Westchester as Suburbs Co to Polls
description: Republicans ousted Democrats from control of Trustee Boards in three Westchester County villages yesterday, Democrats took control from Republicans in a fourth community as voters went to polls in New York suburbs to elect local officials.

title: ISLANDERS SEEK WINNING FORMULA
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 20The New York Islanders, whose introduction into the rough and ready life of the National Hockey League has been long, hard and frustrating, could reach a milestone tonight.

title: Market Place: Fees Held Root Of Wall St. Woes
description: Talk with anyone with feel for the financial community and he is likely to tell you that Wall Street is a disaster area.

title: Iran Formally Nationalizes Her Oil Industry, Shah Says
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 20 (AP)The Shah of Iran today formally took control of the country's multibilliondollar oil industry from foreign operators.

title: WARD'S SEES A RISE OF 10% IN '73 SALES
description: Montgomery Ward & Co., the retail merchandising subsidiary of Marcor, Inc., expects a 10 per cent increase, in sales in 1973, with a Substantial profit improvement, Edward S. Donnell, president of Ward's, said at a meeting of retail analysts of the New York Society of Security Analysts here yesterday.

title: Monuments of Failure
description: DENPASAR, Indonesia  Russia's costly policy of seeking to purchase dominance in key strategic countries has been just as miserable a failure here in Indonesia, the world's fifthlargest nation, as it seems to have been in Egypt where armaments didn't manage to buy lasting political power.

title: Soviet Skater Sets Mark
description: MOSCOW, March 20 (Reuters) Tatyana Averina broke the world record in the women's 1,000meter speedskating race at Alma Ata, the official Soviet press agency, Tass, reported today. Her clocking of 1 minute 26.1 seconds cut 1.2 seconds off the world mark held by Annie Henning of the United States.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HOUSE ORGAN Back in 1914, the Aeolian Organ Company installed a huge organ, one of the largest for a private house, in 1 East 70th Street, which was then the home of the Frick family and now is home of the Frick Collection (2887700) of fine art and sculpture.

title: Riessen Beats Chanfreau, Van Dillen Ousts Fairlie
description: MERRIFIELD, Va., March 20 (UPI)Topseeded Marty Riessen defeated Jean Chanfreau of round of the Union Trust tennis tournament. The score was 63, 75.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: FLANDERS, N. J., March 20The national public links golf championship, coming to the metropolitan area for the first time since 1936, is scheduled for July 1114 at the Flanders Valley Golf Club.

title: Vietnamizing the Peace
description: Fiftyone, days after the signing of the Vietnam ceasefire agreements the two South Vietnamese sides have finally got down to talking about the political future of their land. For the first time in the long series of Vietnam conferences the common language of the participants Vietnamese. By rights, this Paris conference should be the culmination of a decade of war, the forum at which at last can be exercised the South Vietnamese people's right to selfdetermination, in the words of the truce agreements. These documents blandly declared that ninety days would be a reasonable period for the two sides to Teach agreement on their internal affairs.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: Denver 113, Memphis 97.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Rochester Pair Move Up To 5th in Upstate Bowling
description: SYRACUSE, March 20 (UPI) Ed Stewart and Jerry Crego of Rochester rolled Into fifth place in the doubles standing of the American Bowling Congress tournament today with 11,254 total. Ray Leist of Fort Wayne, Ind., moved into 10th place in singles with 661.

title: Mailers and City Newspapers Reach Tentative Pact
description: Mailers Union No. 6 became the first of 10 newspaper unions yesterday to reach agreement on a new contract with the city's three major dailies.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: MAYORS DISCUSS COMMON WORRIES
description: Satire and stark realism besame the last resort of Mayors end other city officials from all Over the country yesterday as they discussed the urban plight in the finale of a two day productivity conference, the first ever held.

title: Rockefeller Stays Away As Top Aides Win Backing
description: ALBANY, March 20A sixhour meeting between Governor Rockefeller's top aides and the five New York City Republican county chairmen ended tonight with a terse statement in which the chairmen backed away from their open criticism of the Governor's choice of Robert F. Wagner as a mayoral candidate and agreed to use their best efforts in his behalf.

title: 2 FORMER BROKERS CONVICTED OF THEFT
description: Two former officials of the MIA Securities Corporation, an overthecounter brokerage house, were found guilty yesterday in New York Supreme Court of the theft of $1million in securities from another firm.

title: Books of The TimesA Sick Humor Begins to Stir
description: THE HAWK IS DYING. By Harry Crews. 226 pages. Knopf. $5.95.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Spring arrived along with it the first of a series of days set aside this year to mark concern about the environment. Under Secretary General C. V. Narasimhan rang the United Nations peace bell to open International Earth Day.

title: Wagner in the Wings
description: Only the incredibly muddled state of the mayoral contest could account for the sudden emergence of former Mayor Wagner, for many years the city's most prominent Democrat, as a potential fusion candidate on the Republican and Liberal party lines.

title: 5 Guards Held Hostage
description: MOUNDSVILLE, W. Va., March 20 (AP)One inmate was fatally stabbed, two others were inbe and five guards were ing held hostage today at the West Virginia Penitentiary, Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. said. Tonight the Governor ordered National Guardsmen and additional state troopers to the prison.

title: Ancorp Plans to Continue Business Under Chapter XI
description: Ancorp National Services, Inc., formerly the American News Company, will continue in business and retain its properties unhampered by law suits and any other interference with its business, under orders signed yesterday by Edward J. Ryan, referee in bankruptcy.

title: Liquor Cargo Hijacked
description: A delivery truck containing 104 cases of liquor valued at $10,000 was hijacked early yesterday morning, the police reported. They said two unidentified men accosted the truck and driver at East 138th Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx. The police said that the driver of the truck, Robert Konitz, was taken by the men to 233d Street and Van Cortland Park in the Bronx, and released.

title: Sarah Vaughan at Papa After 26 Years
description: The last time Sarah Vaughan appeared at the Copacabana, which was 1947, she sang with the John Kirby Sextet. Now, returning after 26 years, she has the full Copacabana orchestra at her disposal. But although the orchestra plays her arrangements well and gives her strong support, many of her most effective moments occur when the Copa musicians sit silently, listening with obvious fascination while she sings with just her regular trio, with her own piano accompaniment or completely alone, a capella.

title: IRAQ AND KUWAIT CLASH AT BORDER
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 20 Troops from Iraq and Kuwait clashed today at the border between their two countries, and each side blamed the other for starting the shooting.

title: Insurance Chief Heads '73 United Fund Drive
description: The appointment of Milton W. Mays, president and director of the Continental Corporation and the Continental Insurance Companies, as 1973 general campaign chairman of the United Fund of Greater New York was announced yesterday by R. Manning Brown Jr., the fund chairman.

title: How Wagner's Name Came Up
description: It all began with a drink with Alex Rose about a month ago, Robert F. Wagner recalled yesterday.

title: REGULATION URGED IN HUMAN TESTING
description: Members of a citizens' panel commissioned by the Federal Government to study laws regulating medical experimentation involving humans is recommending that Congress form a National Human Investigation Board with regulatory authority for at least all federally sponsored research, which totaled $600million last year.

title: Reverse Copyright
description: When the Soviet Union announced several weeks ago that it was joining the Universal Copyright Convention, two schools of thought emerged on what the action meant. Optimists saw the Moscow move as part of a broader Soviet trend toward normalization of international relations and consequent improvement in the general atmosphere among nations. Pessimists contended, however, that the move was aimed at the very reverse of normalization, that Moscow sought primarily to use the copyright law as an additional bludgeon against its dissident writers with the aim of preventing the publication abroad of manuscripts the Soviet regime considered heretical.

title: A Hint of Scandal Focuses Attention on Cable TV
description: Late one recent Sunday evening, Andrew Heiskell, the chairman of Time Inc., idly turned the dial to Channel C, one of the two publicaccess channels of Sterling Manhattan Cable Television.

title: WhitePaper Reaction Mildly Positive
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 20The British white paper, with its complex portions of victory and defeat for each of Ulster's warring communities, drew applause from moderates and a guarded initial response from hardliners on both sides.

title: Athens Police Storm University To End SitIn by 800 Students
description: ATHENS, March 20Police. men swinging clubs stormed into the Athens University Law School today to break up a sitin by 800 students demanding greater academic liberties.

title: COURT, 63 BACKS WEIGHTED VOTING
description: WASHINGTON, March 20The Supreme Court ruled today that its oneman, onevote mandate need not be observed in electing officials of specialpurpose governmental bodies.

title: DIOCESES OPPOSE A BILL ON ALIENS
description: Representatives of five Roman Catholic dioceses in New York and New, Jersey charged yesterday that pending Federal legislation concerning illegal aliens could bring incredible suffering to hundreds of thousands of people who live in the metropolitan area.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH F. A. CUP SixthRound Replay

title: HENRY STURGIS, 81, EXBANHER, DEAD
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 20  Henry S. Sturgis, retired vice president of the First National Bank of New York, died yesterday. He was 81 years old and had lived here since 1958.

title: Oxford Lab Discovers Pottery Fakes
description: LONDON, March 20Two of four important pieces of ancient Chinese pottery submitted for testing, to an Oxford laboratory by the Freer Gallery of Art, which is part of the Smithsonian Institution of Washington, were found to be fakes.

title: Hunter Nine Open Season Against Queens on April 4
description: A 27game 1973, baseball schedule, the largest in Hunter College history, will be highlighted by a southern trip in midApril.

title: Turkey Establishes Courts To Handle Political Crimes
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 20 (AP)Constitutional changes, including establishment of state security courts to deal swiftly with political crimes, became law in Turkey today.

title: HAWKS HOLD OFF LAKERS BY 114112
description: ATLANTA, March 20 (UPI)The Atlanta Hawks nearly squandered a 7point lead in the last 42 seconds tonight but held on for a 114112 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers. The Ulcers missed an attempted lob to Wilt Chamberlain at the buzzer that might have tied the National Basketball Association game.

title: McCloskey Quits G.O.P. To Become Independent
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., March 20 (AP)Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. of California, a longtime antiwar critic, said today that he had dropped his Republican party affiliation and become an independent.

title: PLANS ANNOUNCED ON U.S. SATELLITES
description: The American Satellite Corporation and the Westar Satellite Communications System announced yesterday plans for the proposed domestic satellite communcations system. American Satellite, a subsidiary of Fairchild Industries, announced it had contracted to buy three 12transponder communications satellites from the Hughes Aircraft Company for about $25million.

title: A CIVILIAN P.O.W. REPORTED TORTURED
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, March 20 (UPI)United States hospital sources said today that North Vietnamese interrogators had tortured Bobby Joe Keesee, the civilian prisoner of war released by Hanoi last week, possibly because they thought he was a spy.

title: Clemente Is in Hall of Fame
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20Eleven weeks afterhe was killed on a mercy mission, Roberto Clemente was voted into baseball's Hall of Fame today in an extraordinary special election.

title: Nixon Aides See Lag in Food Price Rise
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 The Nixon Administration, an effort to assuage public and union irritation over high food prices, forecast today a much slower rate of increase in the second half of 1973.

title: No Article
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich.While the headsup, manly bearing of the American P.O.W.'s returning from Hanoi should command our admiration, it will be both untimely and unfair to contrast this showing with what is remembered of American behavior in the Korean P.O.W. camps some twenty years ago.

title: Yanks Wind Up Sept. 30
description: The New York baseball season ends this year on Sunday, Sept. 30 with the Yankees playing host to the Detroit Tigers.

title: Kennedy Agrees to Speak At Fete Honoring Wallace
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)  Senator Edward M. Kennedy has agreed to speak at a July 4 ceremony in Decatur, Ala., honoring Gov. George C. Wallace, the Massachusetts Democrat's office confirmed today.

title: MARK WEINBAUM, EDITOR, 82, DEAD
description: Mark Weinbaum, editor in chief since 1925 of Novoye Russkoye Slovo, a Russianlanguage daily newspaper, died Monday in Flushing (Queens) Hospital after a heart attack. He was 82 years old and lived at 14618 25th Drive, Flushing.

title: Official Works for Janitor
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP)To give a family man a day off on recent holiday, William Coblentz, San Francisco airport commissioner, worked a full shift as a janitor at the airport, including latrine duty with mop and broom.

title: SENATE APPROVES PLAN FOR RETURN OF RENT CONTROL
description: WASHINGTON, March 20The Senate approved tonight a oneyear extension of the Economic Stabilization Act including a provision that could lead to a reimposition of Federal rent controls in New York and other major cities.

title: Boyle Denies Arranging Payment to Yablonski Killers
description: ERIE, Pa., March 20W. A. Boyle, the recently defeated president of the United Mine Workers, denied today a knowing role in arranging the $15,000 union payment that the State of Pennsylvania contends the murderers of his reformist union challenger, Joseph A. Yablonski, were paid to shoot him to death in 1969.

title: TROOPERS' RAISEOF 5.5% IS URGED
description: TRENTON, March 20 (AP) A state factfinder has recommended a 5.5 per cent raise for state troopers, which would. put the top salary, including uniform allowance, at $15,607 a year.

title: CeaseFire Groups Begin Investigation of Violations
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 20  After weeks of inactivity, field teams of the International Commission of Control and Supervision have started investigating the frequent violations of the ceasefire in Vietnam.

title: MARKET VOLUME CONTINUES SLOW
description: The stock market plodded through another gloomy session yesterday as Wall Street awaited the outcome of the Nixon Administration's latest confrontation with the commercial banking community over rising interest rates.

title: INDIAN LEADER ASKS A NIXON EMISSARY
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S.D., March 20 (AP)A leader of the Indians who have held Wounded Knee for 21 days said today that the Government had not responded to a proposal that President Nixon send a representative to hear the grievances of residents of the Pine Ridge Reservation.

title: BRITISH PROPOSAL ON ULSTER OFFERS MINORITY RIGHTS
description: LONDON, March 20  The British Government today announced its longawaited plan to insure a share of political power for the Roman Catholic minority in Northern Ireland.

title: SENATE APPROVES PLAN FOR RETURN OP RENT CONTROL
description: WASHINGTON, March 20The Senate approved tonight oneyear extension of the Economic Stabilization Act including a provision that could lead to a reimposition of Federal rent controls in New York and other major cities.

title: S.E.C. Says Vesco Log Disappeared
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, which has charged Robert L. Vesco and 41 others with looting $224million from four mutual funds managed by Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., disclosed yesterday that a passenger log book that is important to its case had disappeared.

title: Secretariat 85 in Derby
description: RENO, Nev., March 20 (AP)  Secretariat, the 1972 horse of the year and a winner in his first start of 1973, is an 85 betting favorite to win the Kentucky Derby May 5.

title: Money and Capital Markets Close on Even Keel
description: The money and capital markets, under almost uninterrupted siege for several weeks, managed yesterday a second consecutive session in which they held on an even keel. Some interest rates continued to edge higher but several sectors of the market showed a broad improvement and specialists began to say guardedly that the worst might be over. One favorable sign was the successful marketing of $350  million of Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company debentures, which were described by the head underwriter as something better than 90 per cent placed upon reaching the market as 7's priced at 100.

title: Privilege Invoked for 11 Priests In Basque Dispute With Madrid
description: MADRID, March 20The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Pamplona has invoked the church's special privileges in Spain to protect 11 priests of his diocese against legal proceedings for having delivered some of the strongest public attacks in recent times on Spain's political leadership.

title: PLAYOFF DATES SET FOR KNICKS
description: The Knicks will face the Baltimore Bullets in the opening game of the semifinal round of the National Basketball Association Eastern Confrence playoffs at Madison Square Garden on March 30, Ned Irish, the Knicks' president, announced yesterday.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHTS GAMES

title: Music: poster's Texans
description: For some years, musicians of many American orchestras have been filling out evaluation forms in which the qualifications of conductors who lead them are spelled. out in blunt, sometimes embarrassing, detail. When vacancies in the music director post turn up, the computed results are offered to orchestra management for Mehl consideration. Among several recent beneficiaries of this practice is Lawrence Foster, a Los Angelesborn musician who in 1971, partly as a consequense of an orchestral vote, became music director of the Houston Symphony Orchestra. He was appointed chief guest conductor of London's Royal Philharmonic that same year.

title: Kleindienst Orders Gray Not to Discuss Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, March 20L. Patrick Gray 3d told Senators today that under new orders from Attorney General Richard G. Kleindinst he could no longer discuss the Water gate case in defending his 10month record as acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Athens Police Storm University To End SitIn by 800 Students
description: ATHENS, March 20Policemen swinging clubs stormed into the Athens University Law School today to break up a sitin by 800 students demanding greater academic liberties.

title: Cahill Says Cuts Proposed by H.E.W. Imperil the State's Services to Needy
description: TRENTON, March 20Governor Cahill warned today that the proposed changes in Federal socialservices regulations represented a crisis for New Jersey's publicwelfare program and a serious threat to the effective delivery of sound social services to needy citizens in the state.

title: Whiting Inquest Delayed
description: GILA BEND, Ariz. March 20 (AP)Completion of an inquest into the death of David A. Whiting, 26yearold business manager of Sarah Miles the actress, was delayed again today when one of the jurors was hospitalized.

title: NOW Accounts Supported By Chairman of F.D.I.C.
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (Reuters)The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Frank Wille, said today he believed the spread of negotiable, order of withdrawal, or NOW, accounts was both inevitable and in the public interest. These type of accounts, which pay interest for what are, in effect, checking accounts, are in use by mutual savings banks in Massachusetts and New Hampshire.

title: Women Activism Turns To Alternatives in Arts
description: The women's movement, which keeps local activists, so busy it has become a life= style socially as well as politically, is now inventing a counterculture of feminist alternatives in arts and letters too.

title: Equity Financing
description: CNA Income Shares, Inc., a newly formed closedend diversified management investment company, yesterday said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed initial public offering of 7 million shares. The Continental Assurance Company? a subsidiary of the CNA Financial Corporation, is the investment adviser of the company whose offering would be managed by underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation, duPont Glore Forgan, Shearson Hammill and Walston & Co.

title: DOLLAR'S COURSE MIXED IN EUROPE
description: PARIS, March 20The dollar moved against the major European currencies today with no definite trend. It was up against the West German mark and Dutch guilder but off against the British pound and the French franc.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: WORD IS DELAYED
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner has decided to run for Mayor, high Republican and Liberal party sources reported yesterday.

title: BUREAU TO SERVE WELFARE HOTELS
description: The creation of a city bureau to provide onsite services fox welfare clients living in hotels and singleroomoccupancy premises was announced yesterday by Jule M. Sugarman, Human Resources Administrator.

title: Workers in Denmark Begin Major Walkout
description: COPENHAGEN, March 21 (Reuters)  Nightshift workers throughout Denmark began walking off their job's at midnight to launch Denmark's biggest industrial conflict since 1936.

title: MORE SOVIET JEWS GET WAIVER OF TAX
description: MOSCOW, March 20 (UPI)An additional 35 Jews residing in Moscow received permission today to emigrate without paying the emigration tax. This brought to 44 the number of such waivers the Soviet Government has granted in two days, a Jewish source said.

title: Lippmann in Hospital
description: Walter Lippmann, the Pulitzer Prizewinning newspaper columnist and author, suffered a heart attack and was admitted to New York Hospital yesterday. The hospital said early this morning that Mr. Lippmann, who is 83 years old, was in satisfactory condition.

title: H.E.W. Aide Opposes Training Funds for Medical Researchers
description: WASHINGTON, March 20The Administration is convinced that direct support of the training of scientists for careers in medical research is an unnecessary and unproductive expenditure of Federal funds, a spokesman for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare told a House subcommittee today.

title: Things for Children To Do in New York
description: Films

title: COL. DAVID WOODWARD
description: BETHESDA, Md., March 20Lieut. Col. David Woodward, who retired recently from the Air Force, in which he was director of the Aircraft Operations Control Center supporting the Apollo Space System at Patrick Air Force Base in Florida, died of cancer today at the Naval Medical Center here. His age was 44.

title: Kawaida Project Is Backed by a Steelworkers Local
description: NEWARK, March 20  The leadership of one of the state's largest steelworkers union locals has endorsed the construction of the controversial Kawaida Towers housing project.

title: Red Smith
description: San Diego, cradle of California civilization and home of Archie Moore, has just added a tourist attraction to treasure trove that already included Cabrillo National Monument, the Starlight Opera, Nate Colbert and the world's largest outdoor organ. Muhammad Ali arrived yesterday to unveil his torso for West Coast eyes for the first time in a decade. Having received $10,000 for training expenses, he will live free with his retinue in the Westgate Plaza until Saturday, March 31: For a fee$200,000 he will endeavor to fight 12 rounds or less that afternoon with Ken Norton, himself possessor of the shapeliest physique this side of Michelangelo's David. It may surprise some that there are people who believe firmly that Norton will beat the former heavyweight champion of the world bugeyed. They are Ken Norton, his hypnotist, his trainer, and five partners who have been buying sirloins for the fighter since he was sprung from the Marine Corps four years ago. We are not smoking opium, Robert Biron said yesterday. We really think Ken has a great shot.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: BRITISH PROPOSAL ON ULSTER OFFERS MINORITY RIGHTS
description: LONDON, March 20The British Government today announced its longawaited plan to insure a share of political power for the Roman Catholic minority in Northern Ireland.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The New York Raiders obtained yesterday an order to show cause why they should not be granted playoff dates next month at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L. I. Federal Judge John R. Bartels ordered Nassau County and Coliseum officials to appear in Brooklyn District Court Friday to defend their action against the World Hockey Association team. The Raiders cannot play at Madison Square Garden if they make the playoffs because the. Garden will be occupied by the circus.

title: Lawsuit in Traffic Death Is Settled for $100,000
description: ROCHESTER, March 20 (AP)  A suit resulting from the traffic death of Arthur Benvenuto, district principal of Honeoye Falls Lima Central School, has been settled for $100,000. Justice Daniel E. Macken of State Supreme Court approved a compromise settlement yesterday.

title: A 27YearOld Bronx Mother Slain in Apartment House Lobby
description: A 27yearold mother, coming home from her latenight job was slain yesterday by a knifewielding assailant in the lobby of her Bronx building.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Judge Orders U.S. to Reinstate Minnesota Crop Disaster Loans
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March (AP) A Federal judge ordered the Nixon Administration today to reinstate the disaster loan program for 2,200 farmers in 15 Minnesota counties where crops were destroyed by heavy rains in the fall of 1971 and the spring of 1972.

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, MARCH 21, 1973
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Nevada Governor Sees Hughes
