description: ATLANTA, March 21The loss of Rod Selling was the price the New York Rangers had to pay for their 61 victory over the Minnesota North Stars last night at Bloomington, Minn.

title: COURT, 54, BACKS SCHOOLS IN TEXAS ON PROPERTY TAX
description: WASHINGTON, March 21The Supreme Court held today that the states could finance their public school systems in part with property taxes that provided more money and better educational facilities for pupils who lived in wealthier districts.

title: PRESIDENT OFFERS SUMMER JOB PLAN WITH FUND OPTION
description: WASHINGTON, March 21President Nixon announced today that he would make $424million available to provide 776,000 summer jobs for youths, about $3million more than the Federal Government spent for this last year.

title: Soviet Implies It Has Ended Exit Fees
description: MOSCOW, March 21Soviet authorities, in a clear bid for American Congressional approval of trade concessions from the United States, sought to convey the impression tonight that the education tax on Jewish emigrants had been lifted permanently.

title: Libyan Jets Attack U.S. Air Transport In Mediterranean
description: WASHINGTON, March 21An Air Force transport plane was shot at by two Libyan fighter planes over the eastern Mediterranean early today, the State Department announced. The plane was apparently on an electronic reconnaissance mission.

title: 18 Pupils on Bus Injured
description: KINGSTREE, S. C., March 21 (AP)At least 18 pupils were hurt today when a fertilizer truck struck a school bus broadside at a crossing on U.S. Route 52 about six miles south of Lake City, the state highway patrol reported. The school bus, with seating for 48 students, was about half filled at the time of the collision, the authorities reported.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: United States District Judge Frederick H. Lacey recommended yesterday that the United States Postal Service begin an investigation of mailorder advertising campaigns United States District Judge Frederick B. Lacey recommended yesterday that the United States Postal Service begin an investigation of emailorder advertising campaigns for bust developers, diet pills and aphrodisiacs. for bust developers, diet pills and aphrodisiacs.

title: Spring Comes to Florida: The Clues Are Everywhere
description: WEST FROSTPROOF, Fla., March 21It may not have been official until 1:13 P.M. yesterday afternoon, but spring came to this central Florida crossroads several days ago.

title: Personal Finance
description: Most working taxpayers who have been sick or disabled know that tax law permits exclusion of up to $100 a week of disability pay from taxation. This has long proved a major help to persons hospitalized or disabled for periods of time.

title: Cowl Rejects a Complaint On Upcoming N.M.U. Vote
description: A complaint by dissident.S about election procedures in the National Maritime Union has been rejected by Judge, Robert L. Carter in Federal Court here.

title: SoHo to Be Made a Landmark Area
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission announced yesterday that it was planning to designate SoHo, the lower Manhattan district noted for its postCivil War castiron fronted structures, as a historic site during the early part of summer.

title: Grumman Deficit Widens To Record on F14 Loss
Libyan Jets. Attack U.S. Air Transport In Mediterranean
description: WASHINGTON, March 21An Air Force transport plane was shot at by two Libyan fighter planes over the eastern Mediterranean early today, the State Department announced. The plane was apparently on an electronic reconnaissance mission.

title: His Reign in Augusta Stays Nicklaus From Spain
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 21 Jack Nicklaus, unhappy with his golf game, is here for the $125,000 Greater New Orleans open and to tune up for the Masters beginning April 5 at Augusta, Ga.

title: Equity Financing
description: A public offering of 725,000 common shares of Indianapolis Power & Light Company at $24.25 a share was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch and Salomon Brothers. The company's stock closed at 24, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Boards Have Wide Powers
description: The city's community school boards are responsible for the policies and operations of all elementary and junior high schools within their districts. Each district board, which must hold a monthly public meeting, hires the district superintendent and the principals, and may hire the new teachers for schools with low reading scores.

title: Blumenthal and Badillo Assail Rockefeller on Mayoral Race
description: Two liberal candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination last night assailed the plan to run Robert F. Wagner on the Republican and Liberal lines next fall.

title: 4 in Suffolk Are Charged In a LoanSharking Case
description: HAUPPAGE, L. I., March 21  Four men were arrested today and charged with operating a major loansharking ring in Suffolk County, District Attorney George J. Aspland said.

title: Thief Steals Knick Fan's Playoff Tickets as Many Who Stand and Wait Are Not Served
description: A fastbreaking thief with no mercy in his heart stole a fivegame block of Knicks, playoff tickets here yesterday from a fan who had just purchased them.

title: Western Airlines Schedules Big ReEquipment Program
description: Western Airlines announced yesterday it has undertaken the largest reequipment program in its 47year history by signing a purchase agreement for seven aircraft and an option agreement for 15 more.

title: Woman Fights Rejection For Job as a Trainman
description: The Long Island Rail Road was in for trouble when Carol Wagner was 18 years old, That was when she became interested do trains.

title: Cahill Will Seek 2d Term; Defies Foes on Corruption
description: TRENTON, March 21Goverrior Cahill announced his candidacy for reelection today with a heated call to New Jersey's voters to reject him it they believed he or his Republican administration had been corrupt.

title: Focus on Factions in Elections for 32 School Boards
description: You have to submit to vilification and abusesometimes physical abuse. You are shouted at in public meetings. You have to put in at least 20 hours a week. People on our board had problems with their families and with their employers  because the job interfered so much with their other obligations.

title: U.S. DEMANDS LIST OF P.O.W.'S IN LAOS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 22 (AP)The United States demanded today that North Vietnam supply list of American prisoners of war held in Laos and the date and place at which they will be released.

title: SAIGON ATTACKS A BESIEGED POST
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 22The Saigon military command said, yesterday that it had opened a major attack to break the siege of a small outpost surrounded by Communist troops for more than a week.

title: McCone Defends I. T. T. Chile Fund Idea
description: WASHINGTON, March 21John. A. McCone, former head of the Central Intelligence Agency and now a director of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, denied repeatedly today that a fund of $1million or more that the company had offered the United States Government for use in Chile had been intended to finance anything surreptitious.

title: Con Edison Talks Broken Off
description: Negotiators for 18,000 employes of the Consolidated Edison Company broke off contract talks yesterday, but Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, said he would try to get the two sides together again.

title: Ellis Top Punt Returner
description: Ken Ellis of Green Bay was the top punt returner in the National Football League in 1972 with a 15.4yard average, according to official statistics released yesterday.

title: A.T. & T. Sets Sale Of Comsat Shares
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday plans for divesting itself of its entire holding of 2,895,750 shares of the Communications Satellite Corporation through a public offering.

title: Zoo Here Gets a Grant For Sponge Research
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 The New York Zoological Society's Osborn Laboratories of Marine Science was awarded a $100,000 grant today for continuing research into the antibiotic potential of the common sponge.

title: Rescuer of 2 Women Commended by Nixon
description: A maintenance man at the New School for Social Research has received a letter of commendation from President Nixon for rescuing two women from an apartment house fire.

title: Gordon Rule Reinstated
description: Gordon W. Rule, the Navy procurement expert who was shifted to a minor post after assailing the appointment of Roy L. Ash to head the Office of Management and Budget, was returned to his old job yesterday. Details, Page 24.

title: Assembly Delays Adirondack Park Plans
description: ALBANY, March 21Rejecting Governor Rockefeller's appeals, the Assembly approved a bill today to defer for one year any legislative action on a plan to control development on the 3.7 million acres of private land in the Adirondack Park.

title: The Gray Hearings
description: L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, finds himself in a vulnerable position in his Senate confirmation hearings as a result of the Administration's decision to shut off further testimony about the Watergate case. Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst, acting presumably on White House orders, directed Mr. Gray to withdraw his previously expressed willingness to answer all questions and make available all F.B.I. files concerning the bureau's investigation of the Watergate scandal.

title: Court Quashes Subpoenas On Watergate Reporting
description: WASHINGTON, March 21The United States District Court for the District of Columbia blocked today efforts by President Nixon's campaign organszation to compel 10 reporters and news executives to turd over notes and other unpublished material in the Watergate case.

title: Murphy Rites on Saturday
description: A memorial service for Robert Cushman Murphy, the naturalist, who died Monday will be held Saturday at 11 A.M. at the Setauket Presbyterian Church, Main Street, Setauket, L. I. The service will be conducted in part by his son, the Rev. Dr. Amos C. Barstow Murphy, a UnitarianUniversalist clergyman. In an obituary article on Mr. Murphy in The New York Times yesterday, his son's name was given erroneously.

title: U.S. Court Calls Legality of the War A Political Issue
description: WASHINGTON, March 21A Federal appeals court here has declared that questions dealing with the legality of the Vietnam War are political issues beyond the scope of the judicial powers of the United States Constitution.

title: STUDY RELEASEDON POWER PLANT
description: ITHACA, N. Y., March 21 (AP)  A projected nuclear power plant on Cayuga Lake would slightly, but not adversely, affect the surrounding environment, according to consultants to the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation.

title: Boards Have Wide Powers
description: The city's community school boards are responsible for the policies and operations of all elementary and junior high schools within their districts. Each district board, which must hold a monthly public meeting, hires the district superintendent and the principals, and may hire the new teachers for schools with low reading, scores.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Seaway Opening Earlier
description: CLEVELAND, March 21 (AP) Officials of the St. Lawrence Seaway said yesterday that the opening of the waterway had been advanced from April 1 to March 28 because of pressure from shipping interests and warm weather. Officials said the Welland Canal connecting Lakes Erie and Ontario would also open early but that daylight navigation only would be in effect until buoys and other navigational aids were positioned.

title: 2 XRated Films Halted By a Judge as Obscene
description: FREEHOLD, March 21 (AP) Superior Court Judge Merritt Lane Jr. today declared obscene the Xrated films Deep Throat and Love For Sale, which have been playing at the Strand Theater in Keyport.

title: PARLEY ON LAOS IN NEW IMPASSE
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 22 The prospect that Communist and Government negotiators could reach agreement on forming a new provisional coalition government before the deadline tomorrow disappeared today with the de parture of the head of the Pathet Lao negotiating team.

title: I.T.T. Officials in Conflict On Purpose of Chile Fund
description: WASHINGTON, March 22A clearcut conflict in the testimony of three officials of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation emerged today as a Senate subcommittee continued its inquiry into the company's alleged attempts to prevent the election of Salvador Allende Gossens, a Marxist, as President of Chile.

title: Prices Drop Sharply on Amex And OTC as Volume Picks Up
description: With prices tumbling sharply in steppedup trading, the American Stock Exchange inflex closed yesterday at the lowest point it has been since November, 1971. The overthecounter market also continued its slide.

title: Apparel Group Fills Post
description: George Miller, president of Elegant Heir, has been elected president of the Boysapos; and Young Men's Apparel Manufacturers Association. He sueceeds Richard Frankfort, pres ident of Donmoor, Inc.

title: Out of Winner's Circle Into a Ring
description: When the bell rings, Paul Kallai, the jockey, usually is snugup on a thoroughbred's mane, hustling out of the starting gate.

title: BlockSecurity Program Is Detailed by Lindsay
description: Mayor Lindsay outlined details yesterday of his $5million blocksecurity program to finance crime prevention with the help of funds from neighborhood groups.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHTS GAMES

title: New Jersey Sports
description: CHATHAM TOWNSHIP, March 22High school distance runners who plod along River Road here are well aware that they tread in the footsteps of practitioners another, far more violent sport.

title: Business Briefs
description: CheckingAccount Interest Opposed

title: For a Right to Leave and a Right to Return
description: PARISThe Uppsala Declaration on the right to leave and the right to return can advance the cause of freedom for the human family. The U.N. Commission on Human Rights meeting in Geneva includes these rights on its agenda. They have particular meaning today for Russians (both Jews and nonJews) who are being held within national borders and people detained in other countries.

title: Red Smith
description: A gang of years ago, Cliff Roberts, who runs the Masters golf tournament in Augusta, Ga., asked a newspaperman up to his New York apartment. Over drinks he confided that he had a problem. He said the people down in Augusta had warned him that if he ever had a Negro in the Masters it would be the end of the tournament. On the day he told about this, the scores had come in from the first round of the National Open championship and two black men were among the leaders. (Their names elude memory now, but the chances are Charlie Sifford was one.) What should he do, Roberts asked, if one of them should finish among the 16 leaders in the Open and thus qualify for the Masters?

title: Race for Mayor: Confused but Traditional
description: I am a Democrat. I have always been a Democrat. I will remain a Dimocrat until I die.

title: S.E.C. to Fight Challenge To New Institutional Rule
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)The Securities and Exchange Commission will seek dismissal Monday of a court challenge to its new rule concerning institutional membership in stock exchanges, an S.E.C. spokesman said today.

title: PANEL SAYS DRUGS KILLED FIR AIDE
description: GILA BEND, Ariz., March 22  A coroner's jury ruled today that David A. Whiting, the 26yearold business manager of Sarah Miles, the English actress, had died of an overdose of drugs. But the jurors said that they were unable to determine if the drugs had been taken intentionally or accidentally.

title: DAVID ALEXANDER, TURF WRITER, DIES
description: David C. Alexander, Kentuckyborn horseracing and mystery writer, died Wednesday night in the Veterans Administration Hospital here after a long illness. He was 65 years old and lived at 143 West Fourth Street.

title: Bridge: A Kibitzer After the Game Fails to Ruffle One Player
description: Perhaps the most irritating thing that can happen to a topranked expert who has just lost a vital match by a small margin is to have a kibitzer approach him with a speech beginning, You should have made that slam by . . . and find that he is right.

title: Uris Building Negotiating The Sale of All Its Assets
description: The Uris Building Corporation, one of New York's largest realestate companies, announced yesterday that it had entered into preliminary negotiations for the sale of all its assets.

title: Mayoral Muddle
description: Far from clarifying the choice for New Yorkers in the crowded mayoral race, the circumstances under which former Mayor Wagner is being pushed into the contest serve only to make that choice muddier still.

title: RollsRoyce Motors Is for Sale to the Highest Bidder
description: LONDON, March 22Rolls Royce Motors, Ltd., maker of the luxury cars for which buyers wait up to two years, went on sale today to the highest bidder.

title: REVERSAL SOUGHT OF F.P.C. GAS MOVE
description: WASHINGTON, March 22Representative Torbert H. Macdonald, chairman of the House subcommittee with jurisdiction over natural gas legislation, asked the Federal Power Commission today to reverse a split decision in which it authorized higher prices for flowing gas on condition that the producer undertake a specified exploration program.

title: Equity Financing
description: An initial public offering of 7 million common shares of Standard & Poor's Intercapital Income Securities, Inc., a closedend, diversified management investment company, at $25.00 a share was made yesterday by underwriters managed by Dean Witter; Paine Webber; E. F. Hutton and Reynolds, Securities, Inc.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: State Panel Urges a Delay On Reviving Death Penalty
description: TRENTON, March 22The state's Capital Punishment Study Commission recommended today that legislative action on restoring the death penalty be put off until the United States Supreme Court makes final decision on its constitutionality.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: JOHN W. STERETT
description: CRANFORD, N. J., March 22 John W. Sterett, a retired assistant treasurer of the Union Carbide Corporation in New York, died yesterday in the Alexian Brothers Hospital in Elizabeth. He was 79 years old and lived here.

title: Furniss Sets U.S Record in 200Yard Medley
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 22 (AP)  Southern California's Steve Furniss set an American record tonight in the 200yard individual medley in the National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming championships.

title: ALABAMA UPSETS MINNESOTA FIVE; VA, TECH GAINS
description: Minnesota folded under the pressure down the stretch last night, went scoreless for 7 minutes and was upset by Alabama, 6965, in the quarterfinal round of the National Invitation Tournament before 17,640 at Madison Square Garden.

title: BILINGUAL BALLOT ORDERED BY COURT
description: Federal District Judge Charles E. Stewart has ordered the city's Board of Elections to print the instructions on the ballots for the May 1 elections for community school boards in both Spanish and English and to distribute them at all polling places.

title: I.T.T. Officials in Conflict On Purpose of Chile Fund
description: WASHINGTON, March 22A clearcut conflict in the testimony of three officials of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation emerged today as a Senate subcommittee continued its inquiry into the company's alleged attempts to prevent the election of Salvador Allende Gossens, a Marxist, as President of Chile.

title: Svoboda Is Swiftly Reinstalled as Czech President
description: PRAGUE, March 22  Gen. Ludvik Svoboda, the 77yearold President of Czechoslovakia, was elected today to second fiveyear term during a ceremony in a medieval hall where knights once jousted.

title: STATE ACTS TO SAVE CON EDISON TALKS
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, intervened yesterday in an effort to revive negotiations between the Consolidated Edison Company and two unions with contracts expiring at midnight March 31.

title: College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FLIGHT OF FANCY The 37th Street Hideaway is one flight up at 32 West (9478940), a nondescript small building that used to be home for someone, The Hideaway occupies the entire second floor, which, according to some, was once the apartment of John Drew, the actor, which means that he had a spacious living place even though the restaurant is in small, but comfortable, quarters.

title: William McCorry Dies at 85; Long in Yankees Front Office
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., March 22 (AP)William C. McCorry, for many years traveling secretary of the New York Yankees, died in a hospital here today. He was 85 years old.

title: N.Y.U. Increases Tuition In 6 Schools for Next Year
description: New York University announced tuition raises yesterday in six of its graduate and professional schools for next year. The university approved a $300 increase for its School of Medicine, bringing the fee to $3,000 a year; a $200 increase in the Business and Law Schools, raising those fees to $2,800 a year each, and a $500 rise in, the condensed, threeyear dentistry program, which started this year, increasing that fee to $3,500 a year. The undergraduate tuition fee will remain at $2,700 for the third year in a row.

title: Oklahoma State Five Hires Strong as Pilot for 4 Years
description: STILLWATER, Okla., March 22 (AP)Guy Strong, vowing to try to return Oklahoma State's basketball fortunes to the glory days of Hank Iba, signed a fouryear contract today as head coach at a $23,000 annual salary.

title: ADVAWE SHOWN BY MAY SOYBEANS
description: With the March soybean fucures contract out of the way, interest focused yesterday on the May delivery. It shot up the 15 cents a bushel daily limit during a wild session and then dipped to close at $5.80 a bushel, up 12 cents from Wednesday's closing price of $5.68.

title: Garelik May Seek ReElection And Run on Slate With Wagner
description: Sanford D. Garelik indicated last night that he might run for reelection as City Council President instead of Mayor, and might do so on a ticket with Robert F. Wagner.

title: Students in France Protest End to College Deferments
description: PARIS, March 22Five year to the day from the beginning of the 1968 student upheavals that finally convulsed all France by the month of May, the young are again marching in the streets by the tens of thou sands.

title: Senators Resisting Nixon on Health
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 The Administration and a Senate committee locked horns today in total disagreement over policy concerning several major health programs.

title: Fast Shuffle
description: Summer is an uneasy time for every mayor. With students released from high school, unable to find summer jobs and drifting along with older youths already unemployed, the risk is great th4 streetcorner idleness will escalate into mischief and then into bloodstained riots. For several years the Federal Government has successfully damped down this danger by providing special money to hire young people for temporary summer jobs on public projects.

title: News Summary and Index,
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 23, 1973

title: Pennsylvania Court Adopts Bar's Curbs On Pretrial News
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 22 (UPI)  The State Supreme Court, in a ruling made public today, ordered law enforcement officials to stop releasing the criminal records of suspects to the news media.

title: Cosmos 552 Launched
description: MOSCOW, March 22 (AP) The Soviet Union launched, Cosmos 552 today, the latest unmanned satellite in its secret space program, Tass reported. The Government press agency said the craft had been put into an earth orbit with a high point of 209 miles and a low point of 131 miles.

title: Bill to Ban Perilous Toys. Is Approved by Assembly
description: ALBANY, March 22  The Assembly passed and sent to the Senate today a bill aimed at protecting children from hazardous toys.

title: JACKSON IS FIRM ON SOVIET TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, March 22Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that despite some encouraging signs from Moscow, he would press forward with his legislation to bar trade concessions to the Soviet Union so long as emigration of Jews and others was restricted.

title: SECOND CONTRACTOR ACCUSED OF PEONAGE
description: MIAMI, March 22 (Reuters) A second farm labor contractor has been arrested in southern Florida on charges of keeping workers in bondage. Federal sources said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was investigating both cases.

title: JERSEY TRACK UNIT SETTLES STOCK SUIT
description: CAMDEN, N.J., March. 22 (AP) The Garden State Racing Association will have to pay up to $31.5million for an outofcourt settlement of a suit brought by a group of stockholders who sought its liquidation.

title: Federal Agencies Split on Plan To Salvage Bankrupt Railroads
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Interstate Commerce Cornmission is expected to tell Congress this weekend that Federal grants coupled with sweeping reorganization are needed to save the Penn Central and other bankrupt railroads in the Northeast.

title: British Plan Protest Strike
description: LONDON, March 22Trade unionists throughout Britain wilt strike on May 1 to protest the Governments wage freeze. The extent of the stoppage, to be left to individual unions, will vary front a day to token walkouts.

title: Farmers Dampen Hopes on Meat Prices
description: CHICAGO, March 22Midwestern cattle and hog raisers said this week that they planned only modest expansions of their herds this spring, indicating that supplies of fattened beef and pork would be only slightly larger this autumn and that retail meat prices would be little changed from today's recordhigh levels.

title: Capitalism, for Better or Worse
description: Capitalism today, as frequently in the past, is the object of strident criticism. Indeed, the variety of divergent sins placed upon its shoulders is truly remarkable. Inequitable wealth, pollution and consumer deception are the most common accusations.

title: Campora Accuses Military on Election
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 22Dr. Hctor J. Cmpora, Presidentelect of Argentina, accused the military Government today of refusing to recognize its defeat and delaying an announcement of the final results of the March 11 election here.

title: JOSEPH A. SCHIMSKI
description: Joseph A. Schimski, assistant general counsel for the Celanese Corporation, died Thursday of cancer at Memorial Hospital. His age was 64, and he lived at 390 First Avenue.

title: Crossing America In the Spring
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., March 22You cannot go across America these days without realizing that the nation is in the midst of another vast physical transformation, and without wondering where all this is leading.

title: YANKEES TROUNCE WHITE SOX, 12TO1
description: SARASOTA, Fla., March 22 The New York Yankees kept their springtime revival rolling along today with 18 hits and a 121 mauling of the Chicago White Sox.

title: Notes on People
description: Senator William Proxmire may have covered up his baldness with hair transplants, but he has bared all for The Congressional Record. Although a number of Senators print annual financial statements, the Wisconsin Democrat is the only one known to have made public his entire tax return. According to his 1972 return, as published in The Congressional Record, Senator Proxmire paid $2,758 for his hair transplant and claimed the operation as a medical expense.

title: Right to a PublicPaid Divorce Upheld for State Relief Clients
description: ALBANY, March 22  The Court of Appeals, the state's highest tribunal, ruled today that local governments had to pay certain expenses of divorce proceedings for indigent persons receiving welfare payments.

title: Kansas City Says Its Time Is Here
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. In American folklore, this is Hicktown, U. S. A., the butt of a thousand bad jokes about cowtown culture, cornfed girls and good ole boys.

title: Stock Prices Tumble to a Low for 1973
description: The stock market absorbed a relentless drubbing yesterday and closed in its broadest decline in more than 10 months. The selling appeared indiscriminate and swept through virtually all sectors.

title: DR. ATKINS IS SUED FOR $7.5MILLION
description: Dr. Robert C. Atkins, author of the, controversial bestseller Dr. Atkins' Diet Revolution, Was named yesterday as a de fendant in a $7.5million dam age suit charging that the die had led to a heart attack.

title: Met Lays Claim to a Paderewski Bust at Steinway
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is laying claim to bronze bust of Ignace Jan Paderewski, by Malvina Hoffman, which has been in the possession of Steinway & Son, the piano manufacturer, for the last 47 years.

title: DR. ARTHUR NEERGARD
description: Dr. Arthur Edwin Neergaard, a physician here for 50 years, died of a stroke Wednesday at This home, 120 East End Avenue. He was 89 years old.

title: Chief Teller Is Accused of Theft Of $1.5Million at a Bank Here
description: The man who supervises all the tellers at the Park Avenue branch of the Union Dime Savings Bank was arrested late Wednesday night and charged with stealing over a million and a half dollars from the bank's deposits.

title: HERMAN YOUNGLIEB, HEADED AD AGENCY
description: Herman Younglieb, president of A. B. Landau, Inc., a New York advertising agency, died Wednesday evening at his home, 110 Riverside Drive. He was 69 years old.

title: BIG CHICAGO BANK CUTS PRIME RATE AFTER RAISING IT
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago announced today, following a meeting at the Federal Reserve Board with Arthur F. Burns, its chairman, and other Government officials, that it would reduce its prime lending rate from 6 to 6 per cent.

title: Fire Loss Put in Millions
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 (AP)A fivealarm fire at a waterfront pier and warehouse last night destroyed from 50 to 60 automobiles and caused damage estimated in the millions of dollars, fire officials said

title: People in Sports: Here Comes Solomons' Mine
description: Jack Solomons, the British boxing promoter, said yesterday in London he had made an astounding offer to George Foreman to defend his world heavyweight championship against Muhammad Ali in London.

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Kentucky Colonels, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I., 8:05 F.M. (TelevisionChannel 10 (cable), 8 P.M. (RadioWHN, 8:05 P.M.)

title: Drug Report: Liberal LawandOrder View
description: The final report of the National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse is a long, conscious attempt to deflate some of the hysteria and, gently, expose what it perceives as the hypocrisy that Americans have invested in the drug problem. Yet, at the same time, the 481page doer ment, the fruit of two years of hearings and research, illustrates the limited options facing drug policymakers in the United States.

title: OilProducing Nations to Seek Price Rise to Offset Dollar Drop
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 22 The world's main oil producing countries decided today to seek immediate negotiations with the oil companies for higher prices to compensate for the devaluation of the United States dollar.

title: G. WILLIAM BOUTELLE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 22G. William Boutelle, assistant to the president of the American Distilling Company of New York, died, apparently of a heart attack, today at his home on Huckleberry Lane. He was 49 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE DIGGER'S GAME. By George V. Higgins. 214 pages. Knopf. $5.95.

title: Nixon Asks Wide Tariff Power
description: WASHINGTON, March 22President Nixon indicated in a report to Congress today that he would ask in his forthcoming trade legislation for almost unlimited authority to raise or lower tariffs, including outright elimination of tariffs if this can be negotiated with other countries.

title: Residents of East New York Produce Plan, for $70Million Educational Park
description: Three and a half years ago a group of Brooklyn residents ranging from militant young blacks and Puerto Ricans to conservative elderly whites got together in an unorthodox venture in community cooperation to devise a plan for meeting the educational needs of the blighted East New York area.

title: SHOP TALK
description: If you're in the market for a portrait, you can do it yourselfin needlepoint.

title: Racing Unit to Pay 31Million to Settle Stockholders' Suit
description: CAMDEN, March 22 (AP)The Garden State Racing Association will have to pay up to $31.5million for an outofcourt settlement of a suit brought by a group of stockholders who sought its liquidation.

title: BRUINS VANQUISH NORTH STARS, 53
description: BOSTON, March 22 (UPI)Johnny Bucyk scored a pair of goalshis 38th and 39thand assisted on three others tonight to power the Boston Bruins to their seventh straight triumph, a 53 decision over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: MISS GOOLAGONG IS UPSET, 63, 75
description: AKRON, Ohio, March 22 (AP) Seventeen  year  old Marita Redondo of National City, Calif., forced thirdseeded Evonne Goolagong into errors with a hard ground stroke and upset the Australian star, 63, 75, tonight and advanced to thequarterfinals of the $25,000 Akron tennis tournament.

title: U.N. UNIT AT WORK ON A LAW OF SEA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 22  Complex negotiations are under way here in an effort to lay the groundwork for a law of the sea that will govern on the waters that cover 70 per cent of the earth's surface.

title: Widow Meets Her 10th President
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  That's thrilling, said Matilde Bedford to President Nixon as she settled into his chair today.

title: PLANT PROBLEMS U.A.W. PACT ISSUE
description: DETROIT, March 22Leonard Woodcock, the president of the United Automobile Workers, told the union's bargaining convention today that problems in the plants would be major issues at the upcoming negotiations with the auto companies.

title: U.M.W. Aide Denies Union Money Went To Yablonski Killers
description: ERIE, Pa., March 22 (AP)Albert Pass, the highestranking official of the United Mine Workers Union yet charged in the Yablonski murders, testified today at the trial of one of his alleged coconspirators that legitimate union expenses had been paid with $20,000 that the Government charges financed the killings.

title: HORSES & EQUIPMENT
description: Horses & Equipment 995

title: The Theater: Lanford Wilson's HOT L BALTIMORE, Herald of a New Pattern
description: The Grand Hotel kind of play ain't what it used to be. Nor, for that matter, is your average grand hotel.. Not in Baltimore for instance, for according to Lanford Wilson the Hotel Baltimore is seedy enough to have lost an e from its marquee, and is now known as THE HOT L BALTIMORE, which is the title of Mr. Wilson's play that opened last night at the Downtown Circle in the Square on Bleecker Street.

title: DISPUTE ON LAOS THREATENS DELAY FOR LAST P.O.W.'S
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 23The FourParty Joint Military Commission failed today to break the deadlock that arose yesterday over the release of the final group of American prisoners of war.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME Milwaukee 108, Golden State 98. STANDING OF THE TEAMS EASTERN CONFERENCE

title: BIG CHICAGO BANK CUTS PRIME RATE AFTER RAISING IT
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago announced today, following a meeting at the Federal Reserve Board with Arthur F. Burns, its chairman, and other Government officials, that it would reduce its prime lending rate from 6 to 6 per cent.

title: Federal Agencies Split on Plan To Salvage Bankrupt Railroads
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Interstate Commerce Commission is expected to tell Congress this weekend that Federal grants coupled with sweeping reorganization are needed to save the Penn Central and other bankrupt railroads in the Northeast.

title: Soviet Jews Say Exit Is Still Restricted
description: MOSCOW, March 22Jewish activists mounted a campaign today to counter any impression abroad that Soviet authorities had lifted all major restrictions on emigration to Israel.

title: MISS RADIGUE GIVES A CONCERT ON TAPE
description: Eliane Radigue is a Parisian electronic composer of impeccable credentials. She studied with Pierre Schaeffer and served as Pierre Henri's assistant. Monday night she precented an 80minute, fourchannel tape at the Kitchen, 240 Mercer Street, that proved something of an exercise in the need for meditative concentration, but had its subtle rewards, too.

title: Music: Jersey Excels
description: Where the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra is, Marilyn Home is not far behind. And so when the orchestra played Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, there was Miss Horne as one of the soloists in Act II of Borodin's Prince Igor.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times errs when it states categorically in the lead editorial of March 12 that the United States does not have the power to make peace in the Middle East. . . . The public is rendered an additional disservice by the concluding implication that American capability to prevent war in the Middle East is the most that for the moment can be expected.

title: Boulez Shifts Focus at Philharmonic
description: Pierre Boulez, recently reengaged as music director of the New York Philharmonic, will shift his programing ideas next season. Instead of concentrating on two composers (this season they are Haydn and Stravinsky), the Philharmonic will spotlight three early Romantics and three late Romantics, and try to show the continuity between these clusters.

title: Registration Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)  Legislation that would permit registration for Federal elections by a simple postcard was approved today by the Senate Post Office Committee. The bill, sponsored chiefly by Senator Gale McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, would require local officials to accept voter registration by postcard up to 30 days before a Presidential or Congressional election. The measure has been opposed by the Nixon Administration.

title: Senate Unit to End Promotions Delay
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Senate Armed Services Committee agreed today to delay for one more week the pending promotions of more than 4,800 Air Force officers. This seemed to end a Senate impasse stemming from last year's hearings on the unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam.

title: HUGH BEAUMONT, PRODUCER, DEAD
description: LONDON, March 22 Hugh Beaumont, Britain's biggest theatrical producer, died at his home here today. He was 64 years old.

title: DISPUTE ON LAOS THREATENS DELAY FOR LAST P.O.W'.S
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 23A new dispute developed between the United States and the Communists yesterday over the release of the final group of American prisoners of war.

title: Stock Prices Tumble
description: Stock prices made their broadest decline in 10 months in active trading yesterday as concern about inflation, interest rates and the dollar crisis led to a selloff. The DowJones index fell 13.17 to 925.20, its lowest level of the year. Volume rose to 17.1 million shares, from 16 million on Wednesday. Page 49.

title: MELCHIOR SERVICE HELD ON THE COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, March 22Lauritz Melchior, the operatic tenor, was eulogized here today for his rare combination of artistry and humanity in a formal Danish service attended by 500 persons.

title: Weekly Factory Salaries Dropped $2.43 in January
description: The average weekly wage for factory workers in the metropolitan area dropped $2.43 to $159.17 in January from a December, 1972, level of $161.60, the Department of Labor reported yesterday.

title: TOP ISRAELI PARTY NAMES SCIENTIST
description: TEL AVIV, March 22 Ephraim Katchalski, one of Israel's bestknown scientists, was nominated by the Labor party tonight as its candidate to become Israel's fourth President. The nomination by the ruling Labor party is tantamount to election.

title: REV. R. C. BATCHELDER
description: LANCASTER, Pa., March 22 The Rev. Canon Robert C. Batchelder, who had been rector of St. James's Episcopal Church here for 20 years at his retirement in 1969, died today in a nursing home. He was 69 years old.

title: People and Business
description: Edmund W. Littlefield resigned yesterday as a director of the Chrysler Corporation, two days after the Federal Trade Commission said that his service on the boards of both Chrysler and the General Electric Company was illegal because both companies manufacture airconditioners.

title: DEAN ACCEPTS CALL TO TESTIFY ON FUND
description: WASHINGTON, March 22John W. Dean 3d, the White House counsel, who refused to discuss the Watergate case be fore Congress, accepted today a subpoena to tell what he knows about secret fundraising last spring for President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: Stainless Steel Price Dispute Looms
description: A dispute seemed to be in the making yesterday among major domestic producers of stainless steel over the prices they charge for their materials.

title: Screen
description: LOVE, directed by Karoly Makk; screen play (Hungarian with English titles) by Tibor Dery; photography Janos Toth; music by Andras Mihaly; editor, Gyorgy Sivo; produced by film, Studio 1, Budapest. An Films release. Running time: 92 vies. At the First Avenue Screening Room, First ?? 61st Street This film has not beer ??.

title: Amy Rides 2 Winners Before Proud Parents
description: Without question, the two happiest persons among the 16,058 spectators at Aqueduct yesterday were Frank and Rafaella Amy. They made quick trip up from their home in San Juan, Puerto Rico, to see their son Jose go through his paces as a jockey, and they were joyfully rewarded.

title: Senate Sends White House a Bill for Rural Water and Sewer Aid That Nixon Opposes
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Senate gave final approval today to a bill demanding that President Nixon release $120million that the Department of Agriculture has refused to spend for water and sewer systems in rural areas.

title: Russians Will Help U.S. In Drilling in Sea's Floor
description: The Soviet Union has agreed to help guide and finance the scientifically fruitful Deep Sea Drilling Project of the United States, contributing $1million annually, or about onetenth of its cost.

title: Press Club Bids Congress Pass Absolute Shield Law
description: The New York Press Club urged Congress yesterday to pass legislation that recognizes the right of newsmen absolutely to protect their confidential sources and information.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Jersey P.O.W. Says Experience Made Him a Better Man
description: Lieut. George T. Coker, of the Navy, who spent six and a half years in North Vietnamese prison camps, said here yesterday that he was a better man for his experience.

title: 3 Killed When Car Pursued by Police Crashes Into Taxi
description: A speeding motorist trying to elude the police during an early morning chase on the Upper West Side yesterday crashed into a taxicab at Broadway and 141st Street, killing three male passengers in the cab. Three other persons were injured.

title: VIOLATIONS IN SALES ARE LISTED BY CITY
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs issued yesterday a list of stores it had accused of unlawful selling practices or false advertising.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 23, 1973

title: Turkish Parliament Refuses Extension Of Term for Sunay
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 22 The Turkish National Assembly tonight rejected a constitutional amendment to postpone presidential elections until March, 1975, and to extend for two years the term of outgoing President Cevdet Sunay.

title: Phils Triumph in 10th by 43; Mets' Young Pitchers Erratic
NEW ENGLAND FIRMS PLANNING TO MERGE
description: F. S. Moseley & Co. and Estabrook & Co., Inc., two member firms of the New York Stock Exchange founded in the nineteenth century, said yesterday they had agreed in principle to merge.

title: Dennison Gets State Post
description: ALBANY, March 22 (UPI) H. Lee Dennison, former Suffolk County Executive, was named to the State Council of Environmental Advisers today by Governor Rockefeller. The post is unsalaried.

title: ExBank Official Here Accused Of Evading Taxes on $278,000
description: A former bank vice president was indicted here yesterday on charges of evading income taxes on $278,000 that he allegedly received to arrange almost $75million in loans for a major construction company.

title: Nixon Invites P.O.W.'s To White House Fete
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI)President and Mrs. Nixon have invited all United States prisoners of the Vietnam war to spend a day at the White House on May 24.

title: In New Phase of Struggle in South Vietnam, Both Sides Have Assets
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 20The long struggle for control of the South Vietnamese people is entering new and important phase, full of uncertainties and difficulties for both the Vietcong and the Government.

description: Winning numbers drawn on March 22 were:

description: Ships and aircraft searched mountainous Atlantic seas in hurricaneforce winds yesterday for 30 crewmen of 541 foot Norwegian freighter whose last radio message indicated she was foundering about 150 miles southeast of Cape May, N. J.

description: ACROSS

title: Phantom Jet Crashes
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 22 (AP)A supersonic F4 Phantom jet crashed in the ocean 50 miles southwest of here today. The crew of two ejected safely and was rescued by a helicopter.

title: JOURNALISM AWARDS ARE PRESENTED HERE
description: Fifteen persons and two television documentaries received George Polk Memorial Awards for outstanding journalistic achievement at a luncheon yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.

title: Soybean Entree
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Multiracial Plan Tabled
description: TOWNSEND, Mass., March 22 (AP)The Townsend town meeting last night tabled a resolution calling for a multiracial community here in Townsend.

title: Russians Will Help U.S. In Drilling in Sea's Floor
description: The Soviet Union has agreed to help guide and finance the scientifically fruitful Deep Sea Drilling Project of the United States, contributing $1million annually, or about onetenth of its cost.

title: Saturday Review Seeks Funds As Reports of Crisis Circulate
description: The Saturday Review, which changed ownership two years ago and split into four magazines, is experiencing financial difficulties, according to widespread reports in publishing circles.

title: DEMOCRATS GIVE LABOR KEY POSTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 22Organized labor, returning to power in the Democratic party from its neutral position in last year's Presidential campaign, won 10 of 25 vacant seats on the Democratic National Committee in nearfinal maneuvering today.

title: Injuries Force Snell to Quit Football
description: Mrs. Annie Snell can relax now, because her son, Matt, has decided not to play football anymore.

title: READER'S. DIGEST CATS LUNCH PRICE
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., March 22  The Reader's Digest, in an effort to help its 2,200 employes here cope with the rising cost of living, cut prices in the employe cafeteria this week by 20 per cent and gave everyone a raise of up to $640 a year.

title: BANK BORROWINGS SOAR AT RESERVE
description: Commercial banks borrowed more than $2.1billion from the Federal Reserve System during the week ended Wednesday, the highest such borrowings in 50 years, thus bringing new pressure on the central bank for an increase in its discount rate, which is now 5 per cent.

title: ExGuard For Nazis Held Here
description: Mrs. Hermine Braunstemer Ryan, a former guardsupervisor in Nazi death camps during World War II, was arraigned here yesterday as a fugitive from West Germany on unspecified murder charges.

title: North Texas State Picks Bell
description: DENTON, Tex., March 22 (AP)Ronnie Bell, a former North Texas player and an assistant coach at Clear Lake High School near Houston, joined the North Texas State University football coaching staff today under Coach Hayden Fry.

title: Nixon Asks Insanity Plea Curb As Congress Gets Crime Code
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)  President Nixon asked Congress today to abolish insanity as a defense in Federal crimes and to revamp the criminal code completely. The death penalty would be brought back and obscenity laws redefined.

title: Hornsby Did It First
description: Rogers Hornsby of the St. Louis Cardinals was the first major leaguer to have more than 400 total bases in a season. Hornsby had 450 in 1922.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Films

title: Rise in Cost of Living Stressed As Unions and C.E. Open Talk
description: National negotiations between the General Electric Company and two major electrical unions representing 100,000 workers began on a low key yesterday with both sides expressing optimism about reaching a peaceful settlement before their present contracts expire on May 26.

title: ARTHUR GOLDMAN
description: Arthur Goldman, former owner of the Goldman All Seasons Hotel and Golf Club in West Orange, N. J., died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Essex Fells, N. J.

title: COUGARS TURN BACK CHAPARRALS, 137117
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 22 (AP)The Carolina Cougars defeated the Dallas Chapparals, 137117, to move closer to the American Basketball Association, East Division title tonight. The Cougars, three games in front of Kentucky, need only two victories to clinch the championship.

title: Ratelle's 40th Goal Helps Rangers Defeat Flames
DETROIT POLICEMAN ACCUSED IN SLAYING
description: DETROIT, March 22 (UPI)A member of the city's police STRESS unit was arrested today on a charge of seconddegree murder.

title: QUEENS WOMEN GAIN IN BASKETBALL PLAY
description: Queens College advanced to the quarterfinals of the women's national basketball tournament last night by defeating the University of California at Riverside, 6236.

title: TaxCut Bills Pushed in Albany, Apparently to Nudge Governor
description: ALBANY, March 22  The Republican leaders of the Legisilature released two taxcut bills from committee today for possible future action in what was considered to be an attempt to pressure Governor Rockefeller into agreeing to tax cut this year.

title: Indonesian Congress Gives Suharto New 5Year Term
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 22 (Reuters)President Suharto was reelected without opposition tonight for a fiveyear, term as Indonesia's leader with an overwhelming mandate from the People's Consultative Congress.

title: ExGuard For Nazis Held Here
description: Mrs. Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan, a former guardsupervisor in Nazi death camps during World War II, was arraigned here yesterday as a fugitive from West Germany on unspecified murder charges.

title: Molasses Coats Street As Storage Tank Falls
description: BELLEVILLE, N. J., March 22 (UPI)  A 40foothigh storage tank collapsed at a Baker's Yeast factory here today, covering a residential street with three to four inches of molasses.

title: Kansas City Says Its Time Is Here
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. In American folklore, this is Hicktown, U. S. A., the butt of a thousand bad jokes about cowtown culture, cornfed girls and good ole boys.

title: Nixon Sends Aide to Harlem Ceremony for BlackOwned Building
description: President Nixon sent one of his representatives to Harlem yesterday to, announce formally that the Government would be doing $8million worth of business with a black builder and entrepreneur who embodies the ideals of selfhelp and selfdetermination that the President advocates.

title: U.N. AIDE FORESEES ENVIRONMENT FIGHTS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 22Political crises in the coming decade are likely to be set off by environmental aggression, such as one country's stealing another's rainfall, Maurice S. Strong, the head of the United Nations environmental program, said today.

title: LIVING COST UNIT LIMITS INCREASES BY MEAT PACKERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Cost of Living Council, in its latest effort to curb the surge in food prices, told all meat packers today that any increases in their costs must be passed along only on a dollarfordollar basis. It also directed the packers to pass along any decreases in costs.

title: Thyssen Unit Faces Noise Shutdown
description: BONN, March 22The August Thyssen foundry's new blast furnace in Duisburg was billed as the biggest in Europe and now, having turned out to be the loudest, as well, it faces possible shutdown.

title: China Buys 4 WesternMade Films, Including Sound of Music
description: PEKING, March 22 (Reuters) China has purchased four Westernmade films, including The Sound of Music and Tora, Tora, Tora, as a perceptible but cautious relaxation appears to be taking place in Chinese moviemaking.

title: Pentagon Papers Expert Says Disclosures Didn't Harm U.S.
description: LOS ANGELES, March 22The man who supervised the assembling of the Pentagon papers and who was responsible for their being classified top secretsensitive testified today that their disclosure was in no way injurious to the United States.

title: WAGNER INSISTS HE IS NO PUPPET
description: Bristling over charges that as a mayoral candidate he would be a puppet of Governor Rockefeller and Alex Rose, Robert F. Wagner yesterday issued a personal declaration of independence from the Governor and the Liberal party leader.

title: Why Executive Privilege Won't Kill You
description: Executive privilege is one of those subjects that is long on rhetoric and short on substance. It is not one of the central issues of our time, but merely a moderately interesting question that has attained importance largely because of other issues of conflict between the executive and the legislature.

title: Washington Is 29th State To Ratify Rights Measure
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., March 22 (AP)Washington became today the 29th state to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment.

title: Panama Says She'll Carry Fight Over Canal to the U.N. Assembly
description: PANAMA, March 22 (UPI)Panama said today she would carry her demand for control of the Canal Zone to the United Nations General Assembly despite an American veto of a similar resolution in the Security Council.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Ever since the turn of this century, when New York State's legendary Theodore Gordon set American fly fishing on its present course, practitioners of the gentle art have been aided by a series of truly excellent books on the subject.

title: Railroad Traffic Rises
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads in the latest week were estimated at 15.8 billion tonmiles, 3.2 per cent above a year ago. Carloadings in the week totaled 508,836 cars, 1.2 per cent above the 1972 level. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 11.2 per cent above last year.

title: Susan Rieger Married
description: Miss Susan Rieger and Peter R. Pouncey, dean of Columbia College, were married here Wednesday by Judge Sheldon Levy of the Civil Court in his chambers. Mrs. Pouncey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Rieger of New York and Easthampton, L. I., is an admissions officer at Columbia College, the first woman to hold that position. Mr. Pouncey, appointed dean last July, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. C. A. Pouncey of Emsworth, England.

description: NATIONAL TOURNAMENT

description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: CahillSandman Fight
description: TRENTON, March 22The Republican primary fight between Governor Cahill and Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. was adjudged here today as a clear test of whether a liberal incumbent can overcome a conservative reaction. But it is also something else. The primary could become a political brawl because Mr. Cahill has warned that he will punch anyone who questions his integrity, which is exactly what Mr. Sandman, with a little help from the Democrats, proposes to do.

description: Mayor Lindsay designated March 31 as Home With Honor Day yesterday and urged New Yorkers to join in a tribute to all members of the armed services who served in the Vietnam conflict.

title: Bill to Extend RentControl Law Assailed at Hearing
description: Amid cheers and jeers and some resounding speechmaking, landlord and tenant spokesmen yesterday assailed  for very different reasons  New York City's rentcontrol program at a City Hall hearing on a bill to extend the control law for three years.

title: Elder, on 65, Leads Golf by Two Strokes
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 22Lee Elder, center of a golfing controversy, scored a sevenunderpar 65 today to lead the $125,000 Greater New Orleans open by two strokes. The 38yearold black professional from Washington had his best round on the pro tour since the 1969 Phoenix open and was only one above the Lakewood Country Club course record.

title: Living Cost for Family of Put at $11,880 Here in 1972
description: A family of four had to spend $11,880 to live at a moderate level here last year  $790 more than in 1971, according to the Community Council of Greater New York.

title: TV: Ed Emshwiller's ScapeMales Moves Briskly
description: ScapeMates, a production of WNET/13's Television Laboratory, is a video fantasy by Ed Emshwiller, a prominent figure in experimental filmmaking. The halfhour piece, for two dancers and an electronic environment, can be seen on Channel 13 at 10:30 tonight.

description: PARIS, March 22  South Vietnamese talks looking toward a political settlement stuck today on the question of an agenda for negotiations, as Vietcong and Saigon delegates exchanged charges of grave truce violations.

description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Cost of Living Council, in its latest effort to curb the ;urge in food prices, told all neat packers today that any increases in their costs must be passed along only on a dollarfordollar basis. It also directed the packers to pass along any decreases in costs.

description: WASHINGTON; March 22 (Reuters)The Treasury Department sent draft legislation to Congress to extend until June 30, 1975, the Federal Reserve Bank's authority to purchase United States obligations directly from the Treasury.

title: Hearing Set on Anti bus Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, who is chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, announced today that hearings would start April 10 on a proposed amendment to the Constitution that would prohibit school busing for integration.

title: Service for Dr. McCracken
description: A memorial service for the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, who retired in 1967 after 21 years as minister of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122d Street, will be held in the church's nave Sunday at 2 P.M. Dr. McCracken died March 7 at sea off Bangkok while on a world cruise.

title: 30 ON SHIP FEARED LOST OFF JERSEY
description: Ships and aircraft searched mountainous Atlantic seas in hurricaneforce winds yesterday for 30 crewmen of a 541 foot Norwegian freighter whose last radio message indicated she was foundering about 150 miles southeast of Cape May, N. J.

title: Bay Ridge Republicans See Revolt on Wagner
description: Even if Governor Rockefeller succeeds in getting former Mayor Robert F. Wagner the Republican party's mayoral nomination, the Governor will face defections among local G.O.P. leaders and rankandfile members, party sources in Brooklyn said yesterday.

title: U.S. Dollar Declines Slightly In European Money Trading
description: BRUSSELS, March 22 (UPI) The United States dollar slipped slightly today on the European currency exchanges after yesterday's strong showing, but stayed close to the levels set earlier in the week.

title: Cambodia Says Sink Matak Is Guarded Only for His Protection
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 22  The Cambodian Government of President Lon Nol acknowledged today that it had taken steps to defend the security of former Premier Sisowath Sink Matak, but it denied reports that he was under house arrest.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A new controversy over the return of American prisoners of war arose yesterday, with the United States' insistence that 10 Americans held in Laos be included when the last group of prisoners is released in Hanoi this weekend. United States sources say the return of the prisoners in Laos was part of an AmericanNorth Vietnamese understanding. The Communists say the United States is introducing a newand unacceptablecondition. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Janet Serlin Wed to R. H. Garber
description: Miss Janet Serlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence D. Serlin of Bayside, Queens, and Hallandale, Fla., and Ronald H. Garber, son of Mrs. Jerome Garber of Cleveland and the late Mr. Garber, were married here last evening at the Park Lane Hotel.
