title: Chief Teller Is Accused of Theft Of $1.5Million at a Bank Here
description: The man who supervises all the tellers at the Park Avenue branch of the Union Dime Savings Bank was arrested late Wednesday night and charged with stealing over a million and a half dollars from the bank's deposits.

title: U.S. ASSERTS PLANE FLED LIBYAN JETS
description: WASHINGTON, March 22Nixon Administration officials reported today that the American military transport plane that was fired on over the Me iterranean yesterday had ignored a signal from two Libyan fighters to land and was instead taking evasive action.

title: Stock Prices Tumble
description: Stock prices made their broadest decline in 10 months in active trading yesterday as concern about inflation, interest rates and the dollar crisis led to a selloff. The DowJones index fell 13.17 to 925.20, its lowest level of the year. Volume rose to 17.1 million shares, from 16 million on Wednesday. Page 49.

title: Term in Securities Theft
description: Joseph Seiller, 48 years old, of 149 East 39th Street, has been sentenced to three years in prison for scheming to transport more than $4million worth of stolen securities to Europe.

title: Nixon Sends Aide to Harlem Ceremony for BlackOwned Building
description: President Nixon sent one of his representatives to Harlem yesterday to announce formally that the Government would be doing $8million worth of business with a black builder and entrepreneur who embodies the ideals of selfhelp and selfdetermination that the President advocates.

title: Farmers Dampen Hones on Meat Prices
description: CHICAGO, March 22Midwestern cattle and hog raisers said this week that they planned only modest expansions of their herds this spring, indicating that supplies of fattened beef and pork would be only slightly larger this autumn and that retail meat prices would be little changed from today's recordhigh levels.

title: CHINA SCORES SOVIET IAND U.S. ON FISHING
description: HONG KONG, March 22China has accused the United States and the Soviet Union of seriously undermining the world's fishery resources and wanting to preserve a position as fishing overlords free to fish anywhere at will.

title: DISCLOSURE BILL PUSHED IN SENATE
description: TRENTON, March 22  Senate leaders tried today to round up support for a compromise campaigndisclosure bill, and said that a showdown on the bill could come Monday.

title: BLINDAUTHOR AID URGED BY WRITER
description: A Canadian author, who was blinded in a tank accident Italy during World War II, appealed to countries throughout the world yesterday to give aspiring blind authors a fair chance so that we do not have to feel that no matter what we do we have lost the race before we start.

title: YANKEES TROUNCE WHITE SOX, 12 TO ??
description: SARASOTA, Fla., March 22 The New York Yankees kept their springtime revival rolling along today with 18 hits anc a 121 mauling of the Chicagc White Sox.

title: 100% FLUORIDATION URGED ON JERSEY
description: TRENTON, March 22The New Jersey Fluoridation Study Commission recommended today that the state mandate the fluoridation of all drinking water.

title: MISS EMONET, 16, WINS CUP SLALOM
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., March 22 (AP)  Patricia Emonet, a 16yearold French skier in her first season of World Cup competition, won the women's slalom today and claimed third place in the overall championship standing.

title: U.S. ASSERTS PLANE FLED LIBYAN JETS
description: WASHINGTON, March 22Nixon Administration officials reported today that the American military transport plane that was fired on over the Mediterranean yesterday had ignored a signal from two Libyan fighters to land and was instead taking evasive action.

title: 13 Restaurants to Offer BeefBoycott Discounts
description: A group of 13 New York restaurants will support the planned consumer boycott of beef products by offering a 10 per cent discount to patrons who avoid ordering beef for dinner.

title: F.B.I. NEEDS CITED AT CAMDEN TRIAL
description: CAMDEN, March 22  A prosecutor in the trial of the Camden 28 argued today that the F.B.I. had decided it was more important to keep getting information from its informer than to stop a raid on a draftboard office.

title: Leading Catholic Opposition Party in Ulster Supports the British Proposal
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 22  Northern Ireland's leading Roman Catholic opposition group, the Social Democratic and Labor party, today gave a qualified welcome to the British Government's proposals for the future of the beleaguered province.

title: Credit Markets Keep a Steady Trend
description: This week's steady performance of the credit markets continued yesterday, aided by a gathering suspicion that the Administration might impose controls on raw agricultural products in an effort to restrain inflation. Such a step was not ruled out yesterday by a top Government official and in New York the chief economist at Blyth Eastman Dillon declared we look for additional action in this area.

title: Chile's Cabinet Resigns To Facilitate Reshuffle
description: SANIAGO, Chile, March 22 (Reuters)  Chile's Cabinet resigned tonight, Interior Minister Carlos Prats Gonzolez told newsmen here.

title: Star Trek Returning to N.B.C. As a Saturday Morning Cartoon
description: Star Trek, the National Broadcasting Company television series that developed a cult of devoted followers after it went off the air several seasons ago, will be back in the N.B.C. lineup next season as an animated cartoon Saturday mornings.

title: Many Concerns Buying Own Shares
description: In these dark days on Wall Street, a welcome and substantial buying force has emergedcorporations acquiring their own shares in unprecedented amounts.

title: Department Store Sales Rise
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were estimated at $812million, up 10 per cent from the yearearlier $737million. Total retail store sales were about $9.06billion, up 13 per cent from the yearearlier $8.02billion.

title: The Biggest Nixon Shock
description: TOKYO  The real Nixon shock disturbing hitherto stable relationships between the United States and Japan is Tokyo's conviction that America is far weaker than had previously been suspected.

title: Hue, in Respite From War, Rolls Up the Barbed Wire
description: HUE, South Vietnam, March 14The barbed wire is coming down in Hue, and some people are dismantling their bunkers.

title: Rosalind Elias's Father Dies
description: LOWELL, Mass., March 23 (AP)Salem Elias, a business leader in this northern Massachusetts city and the father of the Metropolitan Opera singer Rosalind Elias, died yesterday at a hospital here. He was 91 years old. Mr. Elias was the father of 13 children, 9 of whom survive.

title: Lennon Deportable
description: Ruling that John Lennon is deportable because of a disputed 1968 drug conviction, in England, the Justice Department yesterday gave the former Beatle 60 days to leave the United States. His wife, Yoko Ono, was told that she could remain as a permanent resident. Details, Page 20.

title: Webster Sparks Whalers In Triumph Over Cougars
description: BOSTON, March 23 (UPI)Tom Webster had two goals and an assist tonight as the New England Whalers defeated the Chicago Cougars, 31, in a World Hockey Association game, The Whalers can clinch East Division crown with one more victory.

title: Equity Financing
description: Hamilton Investment Trust filed for 1.25 million units through a group led by Blyth, Eastman Dillon; Loeb, Rhoades and Bateman, Eichler.

title: FORMER SINGER GUILTY ON BRIBE
description: SANTA BARBARA,. Calif. March 23Phil Regan, 66 years old, a former singer and Hollywood actor, was found guilty today by a Santa Barbara County Superior Court jury of giving a bribe to County Supervisor Frank Frost to help expedite a multimilliondollar residentialrecreational complex on the Pacific oceanfront near here.

title: H. B. Slaybaugh, 101, Dies
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Match 23Harvey B. Slaybaugh, a retired railroad man and banker, died today at the age of 101. Mr. Slaybaugh, who spent 17 years with the New York Central Railroad in Cleveland, was also a president of the First National Bank of ArdsleyonHudson, N. Y. He leaves 3 sons, 7 grandchildren and 15 greatgrandchildren.

title: Books of The Times
description: TOWARD A RECOGNITION OP ANDROGYNY. By Carolyn G. Heilbrun. 189 pages. Knopf, $6.96.

title: M.T.A. IS SCORED ON IND FATAITY
description: Mrs. Carol Greitzer, a member of the City Council, charged yesterday that a fatal subway accident last Dec. 22 could have been caused by faulty maintenance that permitted a train to move with an open door.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: A Missing Person: Mona Lisa
description: LONDONThe first reference to A portrait of a woman by Leonardo is in the account written by Antonio de Beatis of the visit on Oct. 10, 1517, by Cardinal Louis of Aragon to Leonardo when he was living in the Manor of Clotur, near Amboise,

title: Heavy Bombing by U.S. Continues in Cambodia
description: HONOLULU, March 23 (UPI) American warplanes continued their intensified bombing throughout Cambodia today in support of government troops, the United States Pacific Forces Command said.

title: EMPLOYMENT RATE ROSE IN FEBRUARY
description: ALBANY, March 23  The State Industrial Commissioner, Louis L. Levine, said today that total employment in the state in February was 7,690,000, an increase of 25,000 over the January total and 75,000 more than in February, 1972.

title: Arms Session in Geneva
description: GENEVA, March 23 (Reuters) American and Soviet negotiators met for twoandahalf hours today amid continued secrew in the new round of talks on limiting offensive nuclear weapons. The next meeting will be on Tuesday.

title: DR. HILDA VON MISES, A STAT1STICS EXPERT
description: Dr. Hilda Geiringer von Mises, emeritus professor of mathematics at Wheaton College and the widow of Dr. Richard von Mises, engineer, mathematician and a pioneer authority on powered flight, did Thursday in Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: Alexander's Quarter Net Sharply Below 1972 Level
description: Alexander's Inc., one of the metropolitan area's largest retailers, had its third consecutive quarterly decline in earnings for the second fiscal quarter ended Feb. 10.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BANNER WEEK You don't have to be a flagwaver or even a Betsy Ross, but you are free to drop by any time today through next. Friday to make a banner of your own choosing. Where? At the Museum of Contemporary Crafts, 29 West 53d Street, daily from 11 to 6 (except tomorrow, when it starts at 1).

title: S.E.C. Reassures Big Board on Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 23G. Bradford Cook, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told a delegation from the New York Stock Exchange today that he believed they would be less worried than they are now about the commission's plans for a new central securities market once they had seen the details.

title: U.S. Aide Defends Ships Spain Shuns
description: MADRID, March 23  The United States Ambassador, Horacio Rivero Jr., a retired admiral, is caught in an embarrassing controversy here over the Spanish Navy's rejection of three muchused American warships.

title: PRESS IS OFFERED ADVICE BY CAHILL
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 23Governor Cahill told a gathering of editors and publishers today that the press must find some method of selfdiscipline if it expects government to enact broad laws shielding newsmen from being forced to testify about their sources of information.

title: Baseball Transactions AMERICAN LEAGUE
description: KANSAS CITYSent Norm Angelina, Barry Raziano, pitchers, and Tommy Harmon, catcher, to minor league complex for reassignment.

title: CLIMB CONTINUES IN SUGAR FUTURES
description: World sugar prices, strong on Thursday, rose sharply again yesterday in futures trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

title: The Met Auditions: An Exciting, Enervating Day at the Opera
description: Stephen West, a curlyhaired, bigboned bass baritone out of the Rocky Mountain region, stood at the center of the stage at the Metropolitan Opera House in a brown coffee  with  cream suit, feet spread, large hands slightly raised.

title: 2D WOMAN STRICKEN BY SOLUTION IS DEAD
description: MILWAUKEE, March 23A second person has died here of blood poisoning suffered after receiving an intravenous solution that has now been recalled by the manufacturer.

title: Dr. Max Jacobson Faces State Charges on Conduct
description: The New York State Department of Education and the Attorney General's office have served Dr. Max Jacobson with 11 charges of unprofessional conduct and fraud in the practice of medicine.

title: Cost of Body Sculpture
description: Senator William Proxmire has discovered that even admirable candor can be costly. Setting a praiseworthy example, he published his income tax return and revealed among other factsthat he had deducted as a medical expense the $2,758 cost of his muchpublicized hair transplant operation. The negative public reaction prompted a swift announcement by the Senator that he would amend his Federal and state tax returns to eliminate that deduction and pay an additional $1,000 in taxes. He publicly rejected the not unreasonable notion that, for a politician whose voter appeal in this telegenic age depends partly on his looks, the operation should be regarded as a business expense and therefore deductible.

title: Building of Soviet Pipeline Is Falling Behind Schedule
description: MOSCOW, March 21 TheSoviet press disclosed yesterday that construction of its major 1,100mile pipeline linking rich Siberian oilfields with Eastern Europe had fallen behind schedule, causing work crews to have to double their pace to meet the deadline for putting the pipeline into operation this summer.

title: 2 BRITISH SOLDIERS KILLED IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 23 (Reuters)Two British soldiers were shot to death Ian dtwo others were injured whn gunmen raided an apartment where they were attending a party in Belfast tonight.

title: Mall Stirs Downtown Minneapolis Revival
description: MINNEAPOLISIn winter, snow melts upon touching the heated pavement of the Nicollet Mall, the eightblocklong hub of the downtown shopping district, raising small clouds of steam. Even without this convenience, it is unlikely that shoppers hereinured to hard winters  would find weather an obstacle. But, increasingly, shoppers never have to go out of doors, proceeding from auto parking lots to stores, offices and hotels via a network of secondstory enclosed bridges.

title: ALFRED G. KAY
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., March 23Alfred G. Kay, a former partner in Kay Richards & Company, stockbrokers in New York, died today in West Palm Beach.

title: I. R. A. CHOOSES TO KEEP FIGHTING
description: LONDON, March 23  The militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army, in the sharpest and possibly most damaging rebuff so far to the constitutional proposals issued by Britain on Tuesday, announced tonight in Dublin that it would keep on fighting.

title: White House Backs Gray, But Senate Support Ebbs
description: WASHINGTON, March 23The White House reaffirmed today its support for. L. Patrick Gray 3d as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as indications mounted that Mr. Gray's chances of Senate confirmation were ebbing.

title: ISRAELIS DISCLOSE 1967 SINAI LOOTING
description: JERUSALEM, March 23 Millions of dollars' worth of equipment and property of Egyptian enterprises in the Sinai was looted by Israelis in the months after the June, 1967, war, according to a confidential report prepared by the Israeli State Controller.

title: Furniss, Stamm Better U.S. Swimming Marks
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 23 (AP)Steve Furniss of Southern California, Mike Stamm of Indiana and Indiana's 800yard freestyle relay team set American records tonight as the Hoosiers extended their lead in the second night of competition in the National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming and diving championships.

title: Futility in Panama
description: No one has emerged with credit from the extraordinary United Nations Security Council session in Panama City. Panama's military ruler, General Omar Torrijos, may have scored a propaganda point by forcing the United States to veto a resolution on the Canal that was supported by thirteen nations; but he must know that this bruising exercise, coupled with the report that he threatened American Ambassador John Scali with physical violence if a veto were cast, will make it more difficult to negotiate a new treaty capable of winning United States Senate approval.

title: Victim's Father calls Sentence Too Short
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 23 (AP)  Rear Mm. J .P. Moorer expressed anger today after a 17yearold sailor, who had pleaded guilty to kidnapping the admiral's daughter, received only a fouryear prison sentence.

title: FLUORIDING COST CALLED MINIMAL
description: TRENTON, March 23  One of the oldest and largest suppliers of fluoridated water in New Jersey described today the cost of adding the chemical to community water systems as minimal and indicated that it could not be considered a facfor in deciding the issue of fluoridation.

title: Reynolds Metals Elects
description: George M. Walters has been elected an executive vice president of Reynolds Metals Company. He will continue to serve as principal financial officer.

title: ANTICRIME GRANTS IN STATE CLEARED
description: The State Crime Control Planning Board, which has allocated more than $100million for crime prevention since its inception in 1968, approved $11million in funds yesterday for anticrime programs in the state.

title: ALFRED CHAPIN ROGERS
description: Alfred Chapin Rogers, who was formerly on the staff of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and had served as a librarian of the, Winterthur Museum of Wilmington, Del., died yesterday at his home in Camden, S. C. His age was 63.

title: CAIN HOLTY DIES; ABSTRACT PAINTER
description: Carl Holty, an artist whose, career spanned half a century and who retired three years ago from the faculty of Brooklyn College, died Thursday at Midtown Hospital after a short illness. He was 72 years old and lived at 327 Central Park West.

title: At Wounded Knee, Two Worlds Collide
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., March 21In a scrubby valley here in this empty, windswept plains country, a band of young Indians and their allies are dug in, armed and painted for war, while on the hillsides around them a Federal force of armor and automatic weapons stands nervously.

title: Consumer Resistance Starting To Affect Price of Food Here
ISRAELIS DISCLOSE 1967 SINAI LOOTING
description: JERUSALEM, March 23 Millions of dollars' worth of equipment and property of Egyptian enterprises in the Sinal was looted by Israelis in the months after the June, 1967, war, according to a confidential report prepared by the Israeli State Controller.

title: Congressmen Get Complaints On Mails and Add Their Own
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 Metropolitan area Senators and Representatives who generate a lot of mail themselves are beginning to bristle over rising numbers of complaints about poor mail service.

title: Dispute on P.O.W .'s Still Snags Releases
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 24The United. States and the Communists remained deadlocked today in a dispute over the release of the final group of American pris oners of war.

title: COLONELS TRIUMPH OVER NETS, 11591
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 23 The Kentucky Colonels kept their championship hopes in the East Division of the American Basketball Association alive tonight by beating the New York Nets, 11591, before 9,597 at Nassau Coliseum, a seasonhigh for a Net's game.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Lowcost housing, if not a dirty word, at least is rarely uttered in political society. There is obviously no simplistic answer, political or otherwise, to the disquieting problems of housing those unable to find reasonable shelter in the marketplace. However, a palimpsest of possibility exists which has not as yet been attempted, a measure which might well attract private enterprise  no other means being enterprising  to the task of modestrental housing: zero land cost.

title: Auto Sales Set a Record In March 11to20 Period
description: DETROIT, March 23The United States auto industry sold a record of 280,701 new cars in the March 1120 period.

title: Thoeni's Cup Lead Is Cut To 4 Points by Zwilling
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., March 23 (AP)JeanNoel Augert of France won the men's slalom today in the World Cup ski racing at Heavenly Valley as the battle between Gustavo Thoeni of Italy and David Zwilling of Austria for the season championship was forced into the final ejrent of the series, the giant slalom here tomorrow.

title: STOCKS ERRATIC; DOW SLIPS 2,49
description: The stock market stumbled through an erratic session yesterday in fairly heavy trading and closed with a modest decline after recording a sharp loss at midday.

title: Bridge:
description: New York tournamentgoers are accustomed to encountering foreign experts, visiting Manhattan for a few weeks or for longer periods. Less obviously, the converse applies, and New Yorkers serve as ambassadors to remote parts of the world, where they can demonstrate how the game is played in the bridge, capital of thethe afternoon.

title: MRS. HOWARD S. MOTT
description: TENAFLY, N. J., March 23Dorothy Colman Mott, the widow of Howard S. Mott, a banker and investment manager, died today in a nursing home in Westwood. She was 82 years old and lived here.

title: 30Foot Lava Wave Inundates Deserted Iceland Fishing Town
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, March 23 (Reuters)  Huge earthen fortifications built in the hope of saving a deserted fishing town from destruction by a volcano were thrust aside early today by the relentless flow of lava and rock.

title: Watergate Judge
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 When John Joseph Sirica was a young man struggling to put himself through Georgetown Law School, he worked as an athletic instructor at the Knights of Columbus gymnasium. He was also an amateur boxer.

title: Picasso's Cubist Images Still Dominate Parade
description: The revival of Parade is, among much else, the revival of a significant artistic episode in the career of Pablo Picasso. The good news about the City Center Joffrey Ballet's new production of this legendary ballet is that it fulfills its obligation to Picasso's contribution to this work in resplendent style. Everyone seriously interested in Picasso's art will want to see it.

title: SEARCH CONTINUES FOR MISSING SHIP
description: An air and sea search continued last night in rough seas and moderately high winds for signs of the Norwegian freighter Norse Variant and her crew.

title: 3 BIG BANKS RAISE PRIME RATE T0 6 DESPITE PRESSURE
description: Three of the nation's largest banks, acting in apparent defiance of the Nixon Administration, announced yesterday increases in their prime lending rates to 6 per cent from 6 per cent.

title: Consumer Resistance StartingTo Affect Price of Food Here
description: Consumer resistance to high food prices  especially meat prices, which have soared since the beginning of price stabiliza, tion in August, 1971is beginning to have an effect in the food market's of the New York metropolitan area.

title: Thoeni's Cup Lead Is Cut To 4 Points by Zwilling

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The reports include the following:

title: Former Pennsy Directors
description: Twenty former directors of the Penn Central Transportation Company and the estates of two other former directors have agreed, in principle to settle 18 lawsuits brought against them by scores of stockholders of the bankrupt railroad for alleged dereliction of duties to the injury of individual stockholders.

title: Wallace Sees Rest of U.S. Moving Closer to the South
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 23 (AP)Gov. George C. Wallace told about 500 applauding high school students in the Alabama House chamber today that views of other sections of the country had become closer to those in Alabama and the South.

title: 3 Leisurely Loot QueensHome After Handcuffing 2 Women
description: Three bandits handcuffed the wife and daughter of a Queens antique collector to a bathroom pipe yesterday morning and then leisurely looted their home of an estimated total of $100,000 in antique Tiffany lamps, cut glass and silver, the police said.

title: Art: Okada's Work Is Pleasure to See
description: Xenzo Okada, who has an exhibition of new work at the Betty Parsons Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, is an arttst whose paintings are a great pleasure to see but irustrating to write about. There is not much you can on down, although by standing in front of any one of the paintings you might be able to judge that this color or that, that form or this, in their relation to one another, account in part for the balance and harmony of a composition.

title: Bill Is Signed to Reinstate Death Penalty in Arkansas
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 23 (AP)Gov. Dale Bumpers signed into law today a bill to reinstate the death penalty in Arkansas.

title: PERIL TO BERGEN IS SEEN IN BOOM
description: HACKENSACK, March 23Bergen County, continuing to boom industrially, commercially and residentially, could be near a development crisis, according to environmental scientists.

title: 7 Dead, 75 InjuredIn Political ClashesIn a Pakistan City
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 23At least seven men were killed and 75 injured in armed clashes, apparently, petween rival political groups flat had assembled to observe a national holiday today.

title: Ellsberg Witness Says He Took Secret Papers Without Leave
description: LOS ANGELES, March 23Morton H. Halperin, a former Defense Department official, said today that he did not have either written or oral permission to take top secret documents with him when he left Government service.

title: People and Business
description: Representative Henry S. Reuss said yesterday that the Administration should encourage direct European and Japanese investment in American industry as the best bet for achieving balanceofpayments salvation.

title: Onion, $5, Captures Mile By 9 Lengths at Rig
description: Onion turned in one of his frontrunning efforts and maintabled the pace all the way to win decisively in a onemile race at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Case Lists His Assets For 72 at $754,872
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP)  Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of Nevi Jersay, made, public a personal financial statement Friday showing assets, of $754,872.

title: Cahill Tells Press It Needs System of SelfDiscipline
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 23 Governor Cahill told a gathering of editors and publish. era today that the press must find some method of selfdiscipline if it expects goyeminent to enact broad laws shielding newsmen from being forced to testify about their sources of information.

title: AllCruz Outfield Is Too Much for Mets
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23  The three Cruz brothers of Puerto Rico wrote a little footnote to baseball history today when they played all nine innings as the outfield for the St. Louis Cardinals and personally outscored the New. York Mets.

title: Maine Shifts Holiday
description: AUGUSTA, Me., March 23 (AP)Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis signed today legislation changing the state's observance of Veterans Day back to Nov. 11. The bill was passed earlier this week by the Legislature.

title: ClosedEnd Funds
description: Following Is a weekly listing of the net asset value of a closedend Investment fund's shares as reported by the companies through The Association of ClosedEnd Investment Companies at the close of business Friday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Appellate Division of State Superior Court ruled yesterday that the superintendent of the Essex County Hospital Center, a, county mental institution in Cedar Grove, may not bar lawyers from inspecting their clients' medical records. The court said the law pertaining to the records permitted the information to be shown to relatives, friends, physicians or lawyers if it appears that this information is to be used directly or indirectly for the benefit of the patient.

title: Whitehead Reports 3 Networks Resist Pressure to Cut Reruns
description: President Nixon's chief adviser on telecommunications has reported that the three major television networks lurk resisted White House pressure to cut down voluntarily on the number of programs they rerun.

title: Business Briefs
description: John Mosier, former board chairman of the Mosler Safe Company, was named here yesterday as one of fiye new courtappointed directors to run the International Controls Corporation of Fairfield, N. J.

title: Acquisition Bid by Triumph Is Aired Here
description: The General Host Corporation charged in Federal court here yesterday that Triumph American, Inc., was violating Federal laws in attempting to gain control of the corporation.

title: Elliott, Foiled, Will Stick to Saber Now
description: Witold Woyda, the bouncy lawyer from Poland, demonstrated the same fine form last night that enabled him to win the 1972 Olympic championship in foil by triumphing in his specialty at the opening session of the Martini and Rossi threeday fencing jamboree.

description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: A Lawyer Is Convicted Of Perjury in Dowdy Case
description: BALTIMORE, March 23 (AP) A Federal jury convicted Hugh J. McGee, a Washington lawyer, Itoday on charges of lying during a grand jury investigation of former Representative John Dowdy of Texas.

title: LAW FIRMS GIVEN AID FOR ECOLOGY
description: The Ford Foundation renewed support for public interest law, firms yesterday by awarding supplemental, twoyear grants totaling more than $700,000 to three such firms for continued work in the environmental field and for encouraging more responsive and innovative action by Federal agencies.

title: A Cleaner Hudson Seen In Comparison With '69
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., March 23Participants at the third Hudson River Symposium, which ended a twoday session here today, offered a much brighter picture of cleaning up the Hudson than they did at their last symposium four years ago.

title: Rangers Oppose Bruins Today in Boston Garden
description: Coming off a threegame winning streak in which they have limited St. Louis, Minnesota and Atlanta to one goal each, the New York. Rangers will storm Boston Garden today for a doordie game against the Bruins (2 P.M., Channel 9 and WNBC radio).

title: Notes on People
description: Having second thoughts about his second crop of hair, Senator William Proxmire has decided to amend his 1972 tax returns to eliminate claims that his hair transplant qualified as a medical expense. The Wisconsin Democrat, whose decision to print his 1972 Federal return in the Congressional Record made public his $2,758 claim said his reconsideration would cost him about $1,000 in Federal and state tax payments.

title: Nassos Daphnis's Abstract Paintings
description: The retrospective exhibition of paintings and constructions by Nassos Daphnis, at Leo Castelli's downtown gallery, 420 West Broadway, consists of 15 works, one each from the last 15 years of the artist's production. It is an impressive exhibition, which displays a consistent authority and eloquence in a very narrow range of expression.

title: Knicks' Lineups
description: AT GARDEN8 P.M.

title: Laver, Smith Gain in Atlanta Tennis
description: ATLANTA, March 23 (AP)Topranked Rod Laver struggled to a threeset triumph over Dick Stockton today, 64, 46, 75, leading the way into the semifinals of the $50,000 Peachtree Corners international tennis tournament.

title: Democrats Elect. Rep. Hays
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP)Representative Wayne L. Hays of Ohio has been. elected chairman of the Democratic Congressional Commit tee, which promotes election of Democrats to the House. He succeeds Representative Thomas P. O'Neill of Massachusetts, who became vice chairmanafter yesterday's election.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Manson Follower Is Given 30Year Prison Sentence
description: LOS ANGELES, March 24 (UPI)A follower of Charles Manson has been sentenced to 10 years to life in prison for raiding a surplus store to get guns to free him.

title: Dining Out in New jersey
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Rocket Kills 33 Refugees. In Camp in Vietnam Delta
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 23 (AP)Thirty three refugees were killed and 65 wounded early today when Communist forces fired a rocket into a resettlement camp in Chau Doc Province 95 miles southwest of here, the Saigon command reported.

title: Dr. Max Jacobson Faces State Charges on Conduct
description: The New York State Department of Education and the Attorney General's office have served Dr. Max Jacobson with 11 charges of unprofessional conduct and fraud in the practice of medicine.

title: ShanghaiTokyo Flight
description: TOKYO, March 23 (UPI)A Chinese passenger plane arrived today from Shanghai on a flight designed to pave the way for direct flights between China and Japan. Its arrival marked the first direct flight to Tokyo made by Chinese crew members.

title: U.S. Orders Lennon Out
description: The Justice Department yesterday gave John Lennon 60 days to leave the United States, ruling that he was deportable because of a disputed conviction for possession of hashish in England in 1968.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Nixon Eases Curbs On Importing of Oil
description: WASHINGTON, March 23President Nixon liberalized restrictions on oil imports today in a signal to distributors and motorists that the Administration expected a gasoline shortage this summer.

title: Dr. Frank C. Mathers, 92; Pioneer in Atomic Energy
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 23 (AP)Dr. Frank C. Mathers, whose method of fluorine production was used at Oak Ridge National Laboratories in the separation of uranium isotopes, died today. He was 92 years old.

title: SETTLEMENT SET IN TURNER CASE
description: PITTSBURGH, March 23 (UPI) Glenn W. Turner, founder of the Dare to Be Great empire, has agreed to settle nationwide litigation against him for about $5million.

title: Laver, Smith Gain in Atlanta Tennis
description: ATLANTA, March 23 (AP)Topranked Rod Laver struggled to a threeset triumph over Dick Stockton today, 64, 46, 75, leading the way into the semifinals of the $50,000 Peachtree Corners international tennis tournament.

title: REGENTS TO SEND TASK FORCE HERE ON READING SKILL
description: ALBANY, March 23  Warn ing of a critical situation, the State Board of Regents es tablished a task force today tc go to New York City and hell reverse the continued decline in reading achievement by many pupils there.

title: 7 More in G.O.P. Named In Suit Over Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI)  Federal District Judge Charles R. Richey granted the Demodatic National Committee permission today to add seven more Republican campaign officials, including James W. McCord Jr., convicted bugging conspirator, as defendants in its civil suit over the Watergate burglary.

title: Now Amtrak Locomotives
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP)Amtrak announced today that it had placed a $10.8million order for 15 highspeed electric locomotives with the General Electric Company. The National Railroad Passenger Corporation said it would use the locomotives on its electrified routes between New Haven, New York City, Washington and Harrisburg, Pa.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: GRAZ, Austria, March 23 (AP)The United States hockey team fought back from a. 40 firstperiod deficit tonight to gain a 66 tie with Yugoslavia in the Group B world tournament. The Americans, who opened the tournament yesterday with a 64 victory over Japan, gained a 55 tie on secondperiod goals by Gary Sargent and Earl Anderson, and a 66 tie on Chuck Ness's score with five minutes left.

title: Catholic Priests Group to Vote A.G.E. Shift to Peacetime Goods
description: DETROIT, March 23  The National Federation of Priestsapos; Councils voted at a fourday meeting here this week to exercise its corporate responsibility by sending a representative to the stockholders meeting of General Electric April 25 in Denver. The organization will cast its single share vote in favor of economic conversion from production of wartime to peacetime goods.

title: Queens, Immaculata Fives In Women's Tourney Final
description: Theresa Shank scored 25 points, including a tapin at the buzzer, as the defending champion, Immaculata College, beat Southern Connecticut State, 47.45, last night in the semifinals of the women's national collegiate basketball tournament at Queens College's Fitzgerald Gym.

title: BULLETS CLINCH DIVISION CROWN
description: CLEVELAND, March 23 (UPI) Wes Unseld dropped in a 15 footer with three seconds left in the game tonight as the Baltimore Bullets clinched the Central Division title in the National Basketball Association with a 106104 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: The Truth Unfolds
description: From the very beginning of the Watergate scandal, there has been a persistent attempt by the White House and the Committee for the ReElection of the President conceal how widespread this espionageandsabotage operation was and how many highly placed persons were involved. Events in recent days have done much to indicate how complex and devious this attempted coverup apparently has been.

title: Market Place: Tell Sad
description: Anyone who still needs convincing that the stock market is in bad shape need only look at the 20 most active stocks of the week.

title: F.B.I. AID IS ASKED IN BERMUDA KILLING
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 22 (AP)  The investigation into the assassination of the British Governor and his aide has spread to the United States, a Scotland Yard investigator said here today.

title: BARRY CASE IS OVER; WARRIORS KEEP HIM
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 23 (AP)A 1969 Federal Court suit over Rick Barry's basketball services ended today when a judge approved a disputed contract Barry had signed with the Golden State Warriors.

title: Stocks Off on Amex and OTC Exchange Average Is Down 0.04
description: A recovery in the last hour cerased some earlier losses yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

title: Day Cate: It's Fine for Mother, but What About the Child?
description: Andrew and his pintsized architectural cronies build a tree house in a Bronx day care center. Ellen molds clay animals at home with her mother. Who is better off?

description: EASTERN CONFERENCE

title: Jets Attacked U.S. Transport In a Libyan Restricted Zone
description: WASHINGTON, March 23The United States military plane fired on by two Libyan fighters over the Mediterranean two days ago was flying in a 100mile restricted air zone, declared by Libya but rejected by the United States, the State Department said today.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET SIGN A CLEANWATER PACT
description: MOSCOW, March 23The United States and the Soviet Union today signed an agreement for joint waterpollution studies aimed at cleaning up some of their major lakes and rivers for the enjoyment of future generations.

description: LACROSSE

title: Former Pennsy Directors Agree to Settle in 18 Suits
description: Twenty former directors of the Penn Central Transportation Company and the estates of two other former directors have agreed in principle to settle 18 lawsuits brought against them by scores of stockholders of the bankrupt railroad for alleged dereliction of duties to the injury of individual stockholders.

title: Dave Anderson
description: From the backyard of his family's ranchstyle home on a hill overlooking the city, Ernie DiGregorio can see a redbrick dorm on the Providence College campus. Almost romantically, it was the only college he ever had eyes for.

title: Olga Overshadowed
description: The magic of a tiny Soviet teenager named Olga Korbut attracted 19,694 fans to Madison Square Garden last night the largest crowd to see a gymnastic, event in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Dance: Joffrey Revives Parade, Diaghilev Work
description: On the face of it, it seemed an extraordinary idea to revive Parade. Although by reputation it was one of the most significant of the artistic collaborations of the Diaghilev Ballet, this 1917 work was little more than a historybook name. It was in the Diaghilev repertory quite briefly (it was never, given after 1926), and even then it was performed infrequently.

title: Canaletto and Brueghel Bring Record Sale Price
description: LONDON, March 23 World record auction prices were set today for paintings by Canaletto and Pieter Brueghel the younger at a $3.15million sale of Old Masters at Christie's.

title: BidTime Pressures, SmallTown Press

The Government clamps Les Whitten, Jack Anderson's aide, in jail for eight hours, and the clanking jail door is heard round the world. Pottstown Council holds a secret meeting, and when it's uncovered, the news about it is confined to Pottstown. Censorship, government controls and secrecy aren't limited to people like Anderson. The smalltown newsman is also feeling the sting.

Barnes, chairman of the board of the Alrac Corporation, Stamford, Conn., was granted Patent 3,721,652. The company has begun limited production in a pilot plant, and plans to build larger quarters next year.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 23The Saigon Government has moved several thousand people in the Central Highlands, against their will in many cases and despite strong protests from American officials.

description: LINDEN, N.J., March 23On a windy hillside here today several hundred friends and followers of Mary Mitchell gathered in a cemetery to pay their final respects to 70yearold gypsy queen.

title: Screen: Exurban Horror:A Community Takes on Army in 'The Crazies'
description: The citizens of Evans City are in a fix, but they don't know it. The Army plane that recently crashed nearby was carrying some deadly bacteria that have poisoned the water supply. The symtoms of the illness: uncontrollable giggles followed by madness and probably death.Thus begins "The Crazies," an inept science-fiction film from George A. Romero, the Pittsburgh man who established himself as the Grandma Moses of exurban horror films with "The Night of the Living Dead," a movie whose stark, primitive style has made it into a classic of low camp.Like that earlier film, "The Crazies" was shot near Pittsburgh with a bunch of actors who perform with the kind of hysterical enthusiasm I haven't seen in 30 years, not since viewing a grade-school production of "Six Who Pass While the Lentils Boil," in which one young actor fell off the stage into the orchestra pit.The film's real subject is not bacteriological weaponry, or the idiocies of the military, but the collapse of a community presented as a spectacle, prompted when the Army moves to quarantine Evans City without explaining what's wrong.The soldiers, who wear gas masks all the time (though the poison is in the water supply), shoot the citizens on sight. The citizens begin shooting soldiers on sight. Here and there, people go mad. A priest immolates himself, and the Army commander shouts: "You must get the President on the phone! We've got to get a nuclear weapon over that town!" The scientist who developed the bacteria despairs: "Jesus Christ! This is so random!" Toward the end, his beautiful lab assistant quietly asks: "Just how would you rate our chances, doctor?"The film opened yesterday at the Forum, the UA Eastside Cinema and the UA East Theater.

title: Filipino Rebels Urge Ouster of Chiefs
description: COTABATO, the Philippines, March 23  Moslem rebels fighting Government troops in this Mindanao province have demanded that old Moslem feudal leaders and provincial officials be ousted before the insurgents negotiate with President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Fire Damages Bronx School
description: A threealarm fire damaged the top floor of Public School 26 in the Bronx last night. It was discovered shortly after 8 P.M. on the top floor of the fourstory school, at Burnside Avenue and Andrews Street. There were no reports of injuries.

description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., March 21In a scrubby valley here in this empty, windswept plains country, a band of young Indians and their allies are dug in, armed and painted for war, while on the hillsides around them a Federal force of armor and automatic weapons stands nervously.

title: DR. REGINA C. KESLER
description: Dr. Regina Chanowicz Kesler, a pediatrician of Paramus, N.J., who had been on the staffs of the Hackensack (N.J.) Hospital and Valley Hospital of Ridgewood, N.J., died Monday of cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital. Her age was 44.

title: British Gas Union Votes to End Strike Over Wage Limits
description: LONDON, March 23  Gas workers voted tonight to end their token strikes and slowdowns, which were intended to gain pay increases over the limits set by the Government to halve inflation. The gas workers were the second key group in a week to abandon resistance to the pay curbs, scheduled to begin April 1. A freeze on pay increases is now in effect.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NUTLEY, N. J., March 23A flabby Boy Scoutcamp counselor complete with stopwatch in hand and baggy sweatsuit, furiously blowing a whistle while observing his inept athletes execute a routinepracticein short, everybody's stereotype image of a coach.

title: EUROPEANS REACH ACCORD ON MONEY
description: BRUSSELS, March 23  The nine finance ministers of the European Economic Community took a common position today on the parity adjustment mechanism they would like to see in any future fixedrate monetary system. That position appeared to conflict in part with plans put forward by the United States.

title: REGENTS TO SEND TASK FORCE HERE ON READING SKILL
description: ALBANY, March 23  Warning of a critical situations the State Board of Regents established a task force today to go to New York City and help reverse the continued decline in reading achievement by many pupils there.

title: 10 Hurt as Train Hits Bus
description: WILSON, N. C., March 23 (UPI)A northbound autotrain crashe dinto a stalled Seashore Lines bus at a crossing in the center of this town today, injuring 10 persons, one of them critically. The police said the train, carrying passengers and their cars from Florida to suburban Washington, D. C., was traveling about 50 miles an hour. The heavy bus was hurled more than 30 feet. Jeanette Barnes of Washington was reported in critical condition at Wilson Memorial Hospital.

title: A THREAT TO SCALI IN PANAMA REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP)John A. Scali, the United States representative to the United Nations, was told by Panamanian officials that there might be violence against him if the United States vetoed a Security Council resolution on the Panama Canal, officials said today.

description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., March 23Sabino L. Dewey, adopted son of Dr. John Dewey, the philosopher and educator, who himself had been active in vocational education, died yesterday in the Huntington Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived here.

Ehrlichman, Mr. Nixon's top domestic lieutenant, has floated Ole notion that there is no way of raising large amounts of revenue through loophole closing other than through digging into the average taxpayer's exemptions or charitable deductions and mortgage credits (sic). That is sheer demagoguery and contrary to the facts.

title: WINE TALK
description: The 1972 figures are in on wine imports. The United States imported 37 million gallons of table wines an extraordinary increase of 44 per cent over 1971. We took 10 million gallons from France, an increase of 41 per cent over the previous year; 7 million gallons from Spain, an increase of 115 per cent, and 6.5 million gallons from Italy, a boost of 38 per cent.

title: City to Press for Passage of Bill To Delay Start of Housing Court

title: We're judged by a different standard

The truth is that some of the more talented people in Hollywood were in the small band that defied the House UnAmerican Activities Committee in the late forties.

title: Cathy Finik Married To Garey J. Clemens

McGuire in St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church.
