description: What was New Jersey like in the good old dayslong before it became one of the most congested states in the country, long before its land was polluted by construction, long before some of its rivers became sewers and its air the repository for other wastes?

title: To a Locksmith  or a Burglar Locks Are Just a Few Principles
description: Ronald Stern can open just about any lock made, a talent that left him the choice of becoming either a skilled burglar or a skilled locksmith. He chose the latter.

title: Russian Named to Replace Official in Soviet Armenia
description: MOSCOW, March 23 (AP)Moscow has sent a Russian to replace an Armenian in the No. 2 Communist party post in Soviet Armenia in a further sign of concern about the local situation.

title: Police Chaplain on the job With Flock
description: MINEOLA, L. I.The Rev. J. Harry Hall, a Nassau County police chaplain, decided recently that to understand the problems of the police he had to be with them on the job, so he spends an average of one night a week riding in police cars in patrol.

title: THOERI CAPTURES WORLD CUP TITLE
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., March 24 (AP)Gustavo Thoeni of Italy won his third straight World Cup season championship today with a strong showing in the giant slalom, although Bob Cochran of the United States captured the final ski race of the season.

title: MORTON OLLENDORFF
description: Morton Ollendorff, who retired in 1965 as president of the Gotham Watch Company and then helped the American Foundation for the Blind develop a Braillewatch factory in Switzerland, died here Friday. He was 90 years old and lived at 100 West 57th Street.

title: Amtrak Buying Locomotives
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)Amtrak has announced that it has placed a $19.8million order for 15 highspeed electric locomotives with the General Electric Company.

title: Community Hopes to Keep MUSE
description: When the Brooklyn Children's Museum, which has charmed itself into the hearts of hundreds of thousands of youngsters and their parents, moves to its new location next year, its current quarters will carry on as a communityrun cultural center.

title: All That Glitters Is Henry James
description: HENRY JAMES's The Golden Bowl, published in 1904, was the last novel he completed in his lifetime, and he was perfectly right when he called it the best and richest of all his novels. His brother William, who was always amazed by timid Henry's ability to turn himself into such a dominating storyteller, was also right when he admitted that there is a brilliancy and cleanness of effect and, in this book especially, a hightoned social atmosphere, that are unique and extraordinary.

title: Dayvander Scores In Westbury Pace; Tarport Adios 3d
description: WESTBURY, L. I., March 24 (AP)Dayvander made a big rush in the middle of the track to win the $17,500 Rosedale Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: The World
description: LONDON  The British Government last week finally outlined the proposals It hopes will bring peace and stability to its scarred province of Northern Ireland. Rarely has anything been read so closely by the Roman Catholics and Protestants in Ulster whose strife has cost more than 750 lives in three and a half years.

title: Stamps
description: Now it is clear, that if the Americans buy ANY of THIS TEA, they must pay the Parliament's Duty and acknowledge their RIGHT to TAX US as often and as high as they think proper, than which nothing can be more disgraceful and injurious to a FREE PEOPLE.

title: The Subway as Studio
description: Why does an artist like to practice portraiture in the last place an artist should set up shopNew York's crowded, jouncing subways? Because all the singular faces that make up New York's ethnic pluralism are there.

title: Kison Put on Disabled List
description: BRADENTON, Fla., March 24 (UPI)Bruce Kison, a Pittsburgh Pirates' pitcher, was placed on the 21day disabled list today and will miss the opening of the season. Manager Bill Virdon said Kison, who hasn't pitched an inning this spring, was suffering with a sore right shoulder.

title: COLONELS TOP NETS AS GILMORE EXCELS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 24 (AP)The Kentucky Colonels scored a 12696 American Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets tonight.

title: Highway Death Rate in '72 Is Called Lowest in History
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)  The Highway Users Federation says that the American highway death rate in 1972 was 4.5 per 100 million miles of motor vehicle travel, the lowest in history.

title: Bronx Antipoverty Leader Dismissed After Charging His Group's Funds Were Misused
description: The leader of a Bronx antipoverty program, who had charged that his group's funds were misused for such purposes as purchase of a car, payments for traffic violations and a Christmas party, has been dismissed and his compaints are being investigated by two city agencies.

title: News of the Camera World
description: MINORITY Photographers, Inc., 155 Essex Street, New York, N.Y. 10002, is instituting a program called Operation Contact in Which participating photographers exchange 35mm contact sheets on a national and international level as a form of communication that is relevant to photographers. To participate those interested must join the organization, which calls for an initiation fee of $5 and monthly dues of $1. Members then send one contact sheet, with whatever information they feel is needed to explain it, to Minority Photographers. The organization will then forward the sheet to another participant, and will notify the member as to where it was sent. Future correspondence will then be carried on directly between the two photographers.

title: Dance Troupe Brings a Now Thing to Schools
description: HACKENSACK  Hundreds of Newark schoolchildren found out last week that Dirty Air Is Everywhere. But they weren't the first to have made this discovery.

title: The actors surprise each other and us
description: Andre Gregory's Manhattan Project began in 1968, a crucial year according to Equity figures when OffBroadway had 74 commercial shows and 91.1 per cent of all money invested was lost. To use the term showbusiness was as laughable as to call most of what passed for theater in New York a performance. The Manhattan Project is an amalgamation of stage performers seeking a new, more exciting theatrical experience and the restructuring of the economic foundations which so often stymie their kind of experimental stagecraft.

title: Discus Mark Broken
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 24 (AP)Steve Gunzel hurled the discus 195 feet 3 inches and Jeff Lough ran three miles in 13 minutes 38.6 seconds for meet records today at the 35th annual Santa Barbara Relays.

title: Vietcong Reject Charge On PostTruce Missiles
description: SAIGON, March 24 (UPI)The Vietcong rejected today United States charges of ceasefire violations, saying they had placed antiaircraft missiles in the Khe Sanh area before the Jan. 28 truce.

title: Cambodia
description: PHNOM PENHThe crisis in Cambodia deepened last week, leaving the Government teetering on the wreckage of the democratic republic it set out to create three years ago  and, the United States Air Force bombing heavily to keep the wreckage from falling into Communist hands.

title: Japan A Case Against Pollution
description: TOKYO  In the fishing town of Minamarta in southern Japan 20 years ago, cats began dancing in the streets and fell, dead, writhing in pain. Dogs and pigs went mad. Crows dropped from the sky.

title: Shala to Be Honored For Charitable Work
description: Don Shula, head coach of the Miami Dolphins, will receive the Honor Award of National Jewish Hospital April 30 in recognition of his outstanding service in civic and charitable work.

title: Toms River Engineer Fashions Plastic Bike
description: TOMS RIVERA local plastics engineer has invented a plastic bicycle that he says will substantially reduce the risk of injury and offer riders a variety of advantages not found in conventional metalalloy models.

title: Factory Will Be a Hospital
description: Construction is to begin, in the fall on the conversion of an old factory in the Bush Terminal area of Brooklyn into the new home of the Lutheran Medical Center.

title: Diamonds
description: One would hardly expect to find the essential ingredient of a martini or whisky sour inside of a diamond, but it now appears that most, if not all, natural diamonds contain trace amounts of ethyl alcohol and more abundant (though still minute) quantities of water.

title: C. F. Rodenberg Weds Susan Lyle
description: Miss Susan Rogers Lyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Jewett Lyle of Buffalo and Ridgeway, Ontario, was married here yesterday afternoon to Clinton Fitch Rodenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Brand Rodenberg of Cincinnati.

title: 3 SOLDIERS SLAIN IN BELFAST TRYST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 24Three British soldiers were killed and another critically wounded last night after two girls lured them into an ambush.

title: CAMBODIA SPURNS OFFER FOR TALKS
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 24 (Reuters)The Cambodian Government has rejected a Communist offer of negotiation that would have excluded President Lon Nol from taking part, a senior official source said here today.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Oyster Yields Defy Trend
description: PORT NORRIS  New Jersey marine experts and local oystermen estimate that the 19721973 oyster harvest from Delaware Bay was the largest in a score of years and nearly triple last season's take.

title: WITNESS'S EFFORT BRINGS NEW TRIAL
description: KEY WEST, Fla., March 24A judge here ordered a new trial this week for George Maxwell Williams, 28 years old, a Key West man who is serving a twoyear sentence in the Florida State Prison for breaking and entering.

title: Pakistan Extends Sea Zone, Objects to Soviet on Fishing
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 24President Zulfikar All Bhutto has issued a proclamation declaring that Pakistan's exclusive fishery zone would extend 50 nautical miles from the coastline instead of 12.

title: MONDALE URGING MEDICARE STAND
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that on Monday he would introduce a resolution cosponsored by a majority of the Senate, opposing the President's plans to reduce Medicare and Medicaid benefits.

title: L.I. Medical School Names Dr. Fritts As Its Chairman
description: Dr. Harry W. Fritts has been appointed chairman of the department of medicine at the medical school of the State University at Stony Brook.

title: PISTONS TRIUMPH, CLINCH 3D PLACE
description: DETROIT, March 24 (AP)The Detroit Pistons went ahead early on the shooting of Chris Ford and defeated the Kansas CityOmaha Kings, 11098, tonight to clinch third place in the National Basketball Association's Midwest Division.

title: The Nixon Dilemma
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 24On the West Coast these days, President Nixon is riding high, but even many of his strongest supporters here are troubled by the increasingly damaging evidence in the Watergate case.

title: The Heldentenor Species Died With Him
description: LAURITZ MELCHIOR lived a long and a full life, and he died full of honors, and he left his mark on singing in the twentieth century. Yet it was with a pang that one music lover heard about his death last Monday. In a way, Melchior was an integral part of the life of anybody who went to the Metropolitan Opera from 1926 to his retirement in 1950. He was there every season, singing the heroic Wagnerian rolesbig, tireless, with the unique male voice after Caruso. When he retired, many of us had the feeling that an age was over, and we were right.

title: Police Shoot Narcotics Suspect, Son of Reputed Genovese Aide
description: The police made several drug arrests in the metropolitan area Friday night and early yesterday, including one in which they said an undercover agent shot the son of a man said to be a figure in organized crime.

title: Trenton's Mayor Reflects on Move
description: TRENTON  Nine years ago, Mayor Arthur Holland moved from an allwhite neighborhood into a poor, mainly black and Puerto Rican section in downtown Trenton. His purpose, he said then, was to demonstrate that the central cities could be saved and that white families should not fear living in racially mixed neighborhoods.

title: ...And Communicate a warmth That Melts the Language Barrier
description: THERE'S a village in northern France called Aubrives. I saw Aubrives first in the late fall, just before winter, when the beech and oak trees, stately along the browning meadows, had turned to gray. It was a gray time of the year, and the sun seldom shone.

title: Major Expansion Program Planned for Primrose Farms
description: Plans are under way todevelop Primrose Farms in Somers, N. Y.which has been operating as a boarding, instructional and show stable into a complete equestrian community.

title: Harvard Given Money For a New Dormitory
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 24 (AP)Harvard University has received a $3million gift to build a new dormintory in Harvard Yard on the site of Hunt Hall.

title: Fire in Brooklyn Building
description: A fouralarm fire severely damaged a vacant factory building at 115 Fourth Avenue at Baltic Street in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, tying up traffic on Fourth Avenue for three and a half hours and casting a smoky pall over much of the downtown area Two firemen were treated on the scene for smoke inhalation. The police said they believed the fire was started by children playing in the basement of the building.

title: No Trace Found in Search For Lost Ship and Crew
description: The search for survivors of the Norwegian freighter Norse Variant continued yesterday and was aided by good weather, but no trace of the crew was found, the Coast Guard said.

title: Jordan Says Captive Concedes Al Fatah Is Black September
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 24 Jordan said today that a captured Arab guerrilla had confessed that Black September was nothing but a name that Al Fatah, the main guerrilla organization, used occasionally for its operations.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: In South Africa to attend a congress on mission and evangelism, Billy Graham lashed out last week against drug abuse and pornography in the United States and called for the strongest possible laws against rape:

title: Acupuncture Legal in Guam
description: AGANA, Guam, March 24 (UPI)Gov. Carlos G. Camacho has signed a law that legalizes the practice of acupuncture. A board of examiners to license acupuncture practicloners was created and penalties for individuals who practice without a license were set. Doctors on the island generally welcomed the law.

title: Rev. E. K. St. Clair Jr. Weds Tam Whidden
description: PITTSBURGH, March 24Miss Teresa Ann Marieta Whidden was married here this morning to the Rev. Elbert Kyle St. Claire Jr. The Episcopal ceremony was performed in the Heinz Memorial Chapel of the University of Pittsburgh by the Very Rev. St. Claire, father of the bridegroom, rector of the Church of the Advent and dean of the Brandywine Deanery in Kennett Square.

title: L.I. Historical Unit Wins Cut in Taxes
description: An application for partial exemption from real estate taxation has been granted by the city Tax Commission to the Long Island Historical Society.

title: As Wayne Grows, So Do Its Traffic Problems
description: WAYNEDespite an extraordinary growth in population in the last two decades from 12,000 to 52,000this town has managed to control its costs by the careful addition of huge shopping centers along busy highways and attractive industrial plants that are well spread out. And yet, township officials are able to point out that 35 per cent of Wayne's 27 square miles has still not been developed, an indication that there is room for expansion in both homes and industry. In recent years, there has been some resistance to full development, but now there is talk of more construction.

title: Wendy Habas Wed To L. J. Samuelson
description: Miss Wendy Habas, who is with the research department at Columbia Pictures, and Lawrence Jeffrey Samuelson, product manager for the Eastern division of the International Business Machines Corporation, were married here yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Rabbi Herbert Weiner of Maplewood, N. J., performed the ceremony.

title: A's Land Fosse in a Trade
description: CLEVELAND, March 24 (UPI)The Cleveland Indians traded a catcher, Ray Fosse, and a shortstop, Jack Heidemann, to the Oakland Athletics today for a catcher, Dave Duncan, and an outfielder, George Hendrick.

title: COUGARS TRIUMPH, CLINCH TITLE TIE
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., March 24 (AP)The Carolina Cougars defeated the Memphis Tams, 143129, today and clinched tie for first place in the American Basketball Association's East Division. It was the Tams' 15th straight loss.

title: Moneysavers
description: It is time to take a fresh look at unpainted furniture. Bleached, natural woods are replacing those chromeandglass accents that have long been popular in contemporary room design. Decoration today is moving toward the greater use of naturalsbutcherblock tables, shelves and counters; sisal and hemp matting, suedes and leathers and, especially, bleached canvas for upholstery. All counterpointed by growing plants. The trend is most noticeable among young people on limited budgets who do not use the services of interior designers. New styles and new designs have never been the strong point of unpainted furniture, but this, too, may be changing. A new wall storage system (9) designed by architect Karlis Grinbergs of Cambridge, Mass., who works with Buckminster Fuller, is a bright spot in the usual jumble of lookalike chests and bookcases. And the style range in unpainted pieces has been expanded to include such fashionable items as chairs and armoires in simple provincial designs and many of the bentwood classics. There are even lineforline reproductions of Shaker furniture, sold by mail in kit form, that retain much of the charm of the museumquality pieces they are copied from. Pricerather than qualityis still the magnet that draws people to unfinished furniture. One has to shop around. And better  constructed pieces are more costly than crude ones. Traditional designs are more expensive than simple modern ones. On the whole, though, the savings may be as much as 30 to 50 per cent over the equivalent finished piece. Furniture in kits can be a real bargain. The weekend putterer who tackles the fourposter canopy bed (7) will have a pleasing bedstead that is a copy of an antique in the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich., all ready to be topped by a fishnet canopy and spread with a patchwork quilt.

title: Calendarof Motor Sports Events
description: March 30.31South Jersey Region, Sports Car Club of America 200mile T.S.D. rally over paved roads; start at Holiday Inn, Exit One, New Jersey Turnpike. Registration: Friday 7 P.M., first car off Saturday 7:01 A.M. Information: Sue, King, registrar; phone (609)6294966.

title: Sone Notes on the Underground
description: The accompanying article and drawings examine what is, depending on the point of view, a necessity growing grimmer daily, a living metropolitan body's circulatory system, a happening, a social center, an antisocial center. Despite their generally different reactions to the subway, writer Alfred Kazin and illustrator Miriam Troop have one discovery in common. Both find, in the subway, faces suggestive of other betterknown faces, proof, perhaps, that life imitates life.

title: Connecticut's Buses Will Resume Service Tomorrow
description: HARTFORD, March 24After a winterlong strike, the buses are ready to roll in Hartford, New Haven, Stamford and 42 outlying towns on Monday.

title: Fireball Gets Brighter Here
description: A year after the acceptance of the Fireball as the official sailboat of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, the number of Fireball craft on the Sound has increased from two to 95. And when the association begins its second year of competitive racing in July, nearly 200 Fireballs are expected to participate.

title: Angela M. Uscocovich Is Bride
description: Miss Angela Maria Uscocovich and Alberto J. R. Izquierdo were married here last night at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Marcos Uscocovich of 201 East 66th Street and Bahia de Caraquez, Ecuador. Criminal Court Judge Nicholas Tsoucalas performed the ceremony.

title: Bolt Kills 6 Youths in Brazil
description: RIO DAS FLORES, Brazil, March 23 (Reuters)A bolt of lightning killed six children who sought shelter under tree at this small town in the eastern part of the state of Rio de Janeiro, the police said.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The Atlantic flyway, one of the nation's four great migratory waterfowl corridors, is brilliantly described in recent book of the same name.

title: Alimony
description: After serving 5 years and 5 months in prison for failing to pay $2,550 for temporary support for his wife and nine children, George J. Chicoine, once a prosperous home builder in Burlington, Vt., last Wednesday was released.

title: HUDSON TRIUMPHS IN GOLDEN GLOVES
description: LOWELL, Mass., March 24 (UPI)Johnny Hudson of Detroit won a split decision last night for the national Golden Gloves heavyweight championship. None of the 10 titles at stake was won by a knockout.

title: Those WellGround Noses
description: WASHINGTON, March 24A recent New York Times article on President Nixon's White House staff reports that the Nixon men work hard at their jobs.

title: Moscow's Concession
description: Soviet laws are notoriously flexible. The latest example has come recently as the Kremlin has gone to great lengths to publicize the fact that it is permitting a few Jewish families to emigrate to Israel without paying the prohibitive education tax required by Soviet law. The Kremlin has been so anxious to make this concession known that its public relations tactics have included providing television film of Jews being allowed to leave. The notorious K.G.B. tipster, Victor Louis, has even written an article for an Israeli newspaper hinting that the education tax is about to become a dead letter.

title: Kingsland Homestead Now a Museum
description: Age before beauty, the saying suggests, but at the Kingsland Homestead  a 200yearold house in Flushing dedicated officially yesterday as a museum  the two have gracefully traveled the long road through the years together.

title: Up Close, the Remote French Make LyingIn Trs Jolie...
description: OUR daughter was born in late July, 1971, in Cavaillon, a prosperous farmers' market town in southern France. A copy of her birth certificate Is on file at the American Consulate in Marseilles, another in the archives of the tiny hilltop village of Lacoste (200 registered voters) where we had rented a house from June through September. We had come to Lacoste, half an hour's bus ride from Avignon, to stay in the house of a friend for the month of May. Then we thought we would go on to Spain and the sea, but we were quickly overcome by the inertia of my condition and sheer surprise that any place in France could still be so lovely, unspoiled andin an age of alienationso friendly.

title: Down Home With Earl Scruggs
description: EARL Scruggs has been the bestknown bluegrass banjo player for years now, but recently his career has taken a special twist. For more than two decades Scruggs formed part of the Flatt and Scruggs team that made its mark on country and bluegrass circles, folk circles and even pop circles. Singer and guitarist Lester Flatt teamed with Scruggs and the Foggy Mountain Boys to make some 25 records for Columbia, and their music reached a mass audience when it was used for the TV show The Beverly Hillbillies and the movie Bonnie and Clyde.

title: Cascade Plus I.O.R. Equals Confusion
description: This is a story with a lot of initials  I. O. R., I. T. C., O.R.C. and S.O.R.C.an acronym (NAYRU), some code words (Mark II and III), a catrigged ketch and a few people named Jerry and Olin. There are other things, too, including a disappearing paragraph. It's all, pretty com plicated.

title: Antiques Center Set for Third Ave.
description: A leading antiques promoter announced last week that he planned to open in May what he described as the largest permanent outlet for antiques in the city.

title: New Soviet Names Given to Mountains And Rivers in East
description: MOSCOW, March 24  The Soviet Union has followed up its renaming of nine Siberian towns by giving Russian designations to as many as 250 rivers and mountains with Chinesesounding names in the Soviet Far East.

title: U.S. Tally of Gray Whales Off California Sets Mark
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)  The National Marine Fisheries Service said Thursday that it counted more gray whales off the California coast in the last counting period than at any time since it began the count six years ago.

title: Women Equality Groups Fighting Credit Barriers
description: A revolt against what many women and civil rights lawyers perceive to be sex discrimination in the extension of credit is gathering momentum.

title: CORRECTION
description: Ada Louise Huxtable's artide on industrial architecture in today's Arts and Leisure Section states that a news story had announced the obsolescence and eventual closing of the Ford River Rouge plant. According to the Ford Motor Company, only the Dearborn Iron Foundry within the Rouge manufacturing complex is scheduled to be closed. The Rouge complex continues in active production.

title: Speak of the Devil
description: This obscure and disturbing being really exists, said Pope Paul VI, speaking of the Devil. Belief in the Devil, a group of Catholic priests recently declared, is so essential a support of Christian faith that if this pillar is removed, then, of a certainty, the other parts of the structure will collapse.

title: Old 2102 Set to Chug Again
description: LEBANONThey fired up old No. 2102, a massive black steam locomotive, the other day and the crowd of smokeeaters on hand included a proud and enthusiastic group of Westfield teenagers.

title: Dispute Settled on Exempting LowIncome Elderly From Rent Rises
description: A yearlong dispute that the city said seriously endangered a program to exempt 65,000 lowincome households with elderly tenants from rent increases has been settled with an agreement involving the Lindsay administration, the state and the realestate industry, it was announced yesterday.

title: U.C.L.A. and Memphis State Gain Final
description: ST. LOUIS, March 24The University of California, Los Angeles, lost poise for the first time this year but snapped out of it in plenty of time to beat Indiana University, 17059 in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball chainIpionship today.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your reviewer's scathing critique of The Implosion Conspiracy, Louis Nizer's book on the Rosenberg case (superficial . . . maudlin . . . banalities), the pivotal question of honesty is posed: If Nizer were an honest writer, Robert Coover charges in effect, he would have presented all the facts, would have examined the investigative techniques of Roy Cohn, would not have avoided such crucial questions as: Was the Harry Gold hotel registration card an F.B.I. forgery?

title: I.T.T. & C.I:A.
description: WASHINGTONWhen Salvador Allende Gossen was elected President of Chile in 1970 on a Marxist program, the Nixon Administration appeared to accept the need for calm if hardheaded adjustment to a regrettable development. It was not long, however, before charges began to fly in Santiago of behindthescenes American pressure to undermine the Allende regime. A question arose: Was the power of the United States Government and United States corporations being wielded covertly in a modern version of the old policies of dollar diplomacy and the big stick?

title: A Chinese Farmer Plans a Restaurant
description: FLEMINGTON  William Wing is a Chinese farmer who loves the good earth. So much so, In fact, that he has devoted the last 25 years to growing the special vegetables used by Chinese restaurants in the New JerseyNew York area.

title: Please, How Do I Get Out of Here?
description: HITLER II 115. When It Comes To Women They Come To Me. JOE 1, 137. JOE SUPERSTAR 124. Jesus Mary Save Souls! POLLO 13$. LITTLE ACE 143. PECO 123. SNAKE 140. PICK UP ON THIS. Moses 99. KEITH 152. RANG no LOVE CHILD 91.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  With much of the country angry about rising food prices and the high cost of living, there is in the air the possibility that consumerism will become a mass movement of untold economic and political power.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: E.P.A. Officials Named
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency has appointed four divisions directors in its Office of Pesticide Programs. They are Leonard R. Axelrod, criteria and evaluation; William S. Murray, technical services; John V. Osmun, operations, and John B. Ritch Jr., acting director, registrations.

title: Close Vote In Suffolk Ends Reign Of Mayor
description: YAPHANK, L. I.A recount it the Suffolk County Board of Elections confirmed here Thursday that Thomas H. Kost, a Democrat, defeated Lindenhurst Mayor Charles J. Cowan, a R'epubiican, by three votes in Tuesday's election.

title: What's Opened In the Theater?
description: SEESAW, a musical based on William Gibson's play Two for the Seesaw, with music by Cy Coleman, book by Michael Bennett and lyrics by Dorothy Fields, got five favorable reviews (Watts, Post; Gottfried, Women's Wear; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Glover, AP; Sanders, ABCTV) and seven mixed reviews (Barnes, Times; Watt, News; Wallach, Newsday; Gaver, UPI; Harris, CBSTV; Klein, WNEWTV; Bookspan, WPIXTV).

title: Tennis Boom Helps Pros
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I. Tennis has become one of the leading, yearround sports in Nassau County, and part of the credit for the racquet boom belongs to the Eastern Professional Tennis Association.

title: Really, This Jargon Is Getting Out of Hand
description: A garden, I read the other day, is now a personalized, recreational ecounit. This presumably means we'll have to start calling a spade a manually operated recreational ecounit maintenance tool.

title: Motorola Fills Two Posts
description: Richard A. Kraft and Robert C. Warren have been named vice presidents of Motorola, Inc. Mr. Kraft will be in charge of product development including planning, design and engineering of all consumer electronics products. Mr. Warren will be in charge of all marketing, sales and merchandising of consumer electronics products as vice president of marketing.

title: Prefontaine Sets American Record For SixMile Run
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., March 24 (AP)  Steve Prefontaine, running all by himself, bettered the American record in the sixmile run today with a clocking of 27 minutes 9.4 seconds.

title: Boy, 13, Wins Fight On Price of Paint For Model Planes
description: WASHINGTON, March 24John Malachowsky, a 13yearold builder of model rockets, and the Federal Government have won a split decision in their litigation co force a price reduction on the hobby paint that John used for model rockets.

title: James Arthur Stanton Marries Lisa Albrecht
description: ROANOKE, Va., March 24  Miss Lisa Albrecht was married here this afternoon to James Arthur Stanton. The Rev. William R. Klein performed the ceremony in the Second Presbyterian Church.

title: Woman Marathon Runner Piling Up Trophies
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I. Each time that Nina Kuscsik ran around the block she felt that the neighbors were snickering and saying: Here she comes again.

title: William Lewis Sings Role Of Don Jose in Carmen
description: Since Don Jos is an especially strong character in the Met's GenteleIgesz staging of Carmen, any new tenor to the production has his work cut out for him. William Lewis assumed the role Friday night, and he gave a generally credible, conscientious performance.

title: Teacher, Engaged
description: Donaldson is a research analyst with the Massachusetts Department of Public Health, division of alcoholism, and is working toward a Ph.D. in sociology at Boston College.

title: Child to the Sorensens
description: A daughter was born Thursday to Mr. and Mrs. Theodore C. Sorensen of New York in the LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Sorensen is the former Miss Gillian Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Martin of Grand Rapids, Mich. Her husband, former special counsel to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, is a partner in the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. The child has been named Juliet Suzanne.

title: Man Injured in Auto Accident Is Awarded $897,000 by Jury
description: A man who bought a used rental car that was sold to him as a demonstrator model and which he was later seriously injured and his wife killed, has received an award of $897,000 from a State Supreme Court jury last week.

title: World News Briefs
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, March 24 (UPI)The Uganda radio said today that Tanzania had moved fresh troops toward her border with Uganda today, after an unsuccessful invasion by a 3,500man force yesterday. Uganda armed forces were ordered on full alert status, the radio added.

title: U.S. Court Approves Housing At Air Base
description: WESTHAMPTON, L. I.After almost four years of standing empty, the housing at what used to be the United States Air Base here will finally be occupied.

title: Medicine
description: Mrs. Dorothy Berger, the wife of a Bronx delicatessen manager, recently gave birth to her fifth child in New York Hospital. The baby was delivered not by a doctor, but by a woman who had become an old friend the hospital's first nursemidwife, Diane Tose.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Miss Moora Engaged
description: MEDFORD LAKES, N. J., March 24Mrs. Robert L. Moora has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Kathleen Alison Moora, to Thomas Edward Bryant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Omar Bryant of Knox, Me. The future bride is a daughter also of the late Mr. Moora, a former editor of The New York Herald Tribune and later a public relations executive with RCA.

title: Dance: Live Dragon
description: Two years ago at a concert that did not attract much notice, Nancy Meehan made a very notable debut as a choreographer. It is always satisfying to spot a winner at first glance, and Wednesday night at Kaufmann Concert Hall, the Nancy Meehan Dance Company presentedin whatwas only the second concert here of its existencean absolutely wonderful work called Live Dragon.

title: Mailbox: On Entering Masters
description: To The Editor: A story in the Times (March 18) about the demands of Herman Badillo and Edward Koch, Congressmen from New York, that black golfers be allowed admittance to the prestigious Masters Golf tournament at Augusta, Ga., correctly pointed out that there are only two requirements for getting into the Masters, neither of which is being white. The way to get in is to win a professional tournament or by finishing in the top 16 in the National Open.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Nassau Democrats Show Unusual Unity
description: FRANKLIN SQUARE, L.I.,  Something strange occurred at the Nassau County Democratic committee nominating convention here last week: Instead of chaos there was calm; instead of factionalism there was unity; and instead of disruptions, there was order.

title: TWO MAJOR BANKS TRIM NINE RATE
description: Two more major banks, one in New York and the other in Philadelphia, bowed to the Nixon Administration yesterday and reduced their prime lending rates to 6 per cent from 6 per cent.

title: Somerset to Open a Courtroom in a Renovated Church
description: SOMERVILLE  Somerset County's sorely needed fourth courtroom, which is scheduled to open May 1, will be situated in a renovated church building next to the County Courthouse.

title: Elizabeth Crayhon Wed
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., March 24  Miss Elizabeth Ann Crayhon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Crayhon, was married here at noon today to Robert Arthur Goosk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles V. Goosk of Oceanside.. The Rev. Donald C. Latham performed the ceremony at Ascension Episcopal Church. The bride's father is the day editor of National Teletype Setter Service, United Press International.

title: The Way West Looks Bright for Merged Railway
description: DEVILS LAKE, N.D Dawn on the Empire Builder comes a little after Devils Lake. The sun overtakes the famed passenger train 811 miles and 16, hours out of Chicago, revealing in the cold light of day a treeless, rolling lunar landscape.

title: U.S. and Cuba A Tale Of Two Fishermen
description: WASHINGTONNot so long ago the two Cuban fishermen would have been greeted in the United States as brave escapees from Communist dictatorship. They had pulled a gun on the other crew members of their nineman fishing boat and set sail for Mexico and freedom. After losing their way, they gave themselves up to their captain, but en route home the boat ran out of fuel off the Florida coast and was towed into Key West March 12 by the Coast Guard. The two hijackers, it was revealed last week, asked for asylum in the United States.

title: Canoe Clubs Stirring Bigger Ripples
description: In the Paerdegat. Basin at the foot of Avenue N in Brooklyn, the Sebago Canoe Club's pennants were snapping smartly as a sign of the club's 40th anniversary. The members were out in force, sanding, caulking, varnishing and painting their little craft while a landfill operation for grading the dock area was going on.

title: WEST COAST SCOUT VICTOR IN FLORIDA
Child to the Bergners
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Alfred P. Bergner of Bethesda, Md., on March 3 in the George Washington University Hospital in Washington. Mrs. Bergner, the former Miss Jane Hilary Cohen.

title: Sandman Sues to Curb Arbitrary Name Listings on Ballots
description: NEWARKRepresentative Charles W. Sandman Jr. thinks that one reason he lost a close primary election race to Governor Cahill four years ago is that his name was placed in poor positions on the ballot.

title: Fire in Brooklyn Building
description: A fouralarm fire severely damaged a vacant factory building at 115 Fourth Avenue at Baltic Street in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, tying up traffic on Fourth Avenue for three and a half hours and casting a smoky pall over much of the downtown area Two firemen were treated on the scene for smoke inhalations The police said they believed the fire was started by children playing in the basement of the building.

title: Knockabouting Fire Island
description: Take a 30yearold Cape Cod Knockabout, without auxiliary motor or selfbailing capacity, set aside two days in midsummer for a spree on the sea, and you'll be amazed what sailing exploits you can capture just an hour from the heart of the city.

title: How Pirandello Became Pirandellian (And Other Things)
description: WAS Luigi Pirandello a Fascist, as he, himself said he was? The question is as pointless as trying to establish whether Dostoevski was really a black reactionary at heart, or Pirandello's contemporary, Rudyard Kipling, an imperialist racist. Authors are rarely what they believe themselves to be but always what other people think they are. This kind of personal question may, however, be worth asking in the case of the rare old writers who are still alive many years after their deaths.

title: Methaqualone to Be Placed Under a Strict State Law
description: ALBANY, March 24 (AP)Methaqualonesold as Quaalude, Sopor, Optimil, Somnafac, Parest and Dimethacolwill be subject to strict new controls effective April 1, it was announced by Dr. Hollis S. Ingraham, the State Health Commissioner.

title: The Openings Of the Week
description: ECHOESTomorrow, Bijou, 7. A play by N. Richard Nash. Starring David Selby, Lynn Milgrim and Paul Tripp.

title: Lewis, ExMet, Named Coach by the Cardinals
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24 (UPI)  The St. Louis Cardinals named today their first black coach, Johnny Lewis, who played for the Cardinals, the New York Mets and the San Diego Padres.

title: ANTIU.S. FEELING RISES IN GERMANY
description: BONN, March 24 (AP) An unusual number of antiAmerican incidents in West Germany in recent days has added to the problems between the two countries and has revealed an ugly American image of the G.I. among a small but growing number of Germans, once among the most solidly proAmerican allies.

title: Dyeing For a Pumpout
description: During last summer's boating season, according to the newsletter of the Federated Boatmen of New Jersey, a New York boatman had his holding tank pumped out at one of the New York pumping stations. Before he started the pumping, he secretly inserted a dye into his holding tank.

title: HotDog Skiing: New Twist
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 24Radicalism in sports is on display here this weekend at the national freestyle skiing championships, an event that embraces visual feats challenging the retina, physical feats challenging physics, and competitors challenging authority, Olympia, the high price of lift tickets and the rigidity of slalom gales.

title: Weston No. 1 Rink Gains Curling Final at Darien
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 24A Massachusetts rink and one from Canada reached the final round of the Nutmeg Curling Club's 10th annual Golden Handle Trophy International Mixed bonspiel today and will play a 10end match at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow at the Country Club of Darien.

title: Christiane Fabricant
description: Mr. and Mrs. Boris Fabricant of Paris and Montreal, France, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christiane Franoise Fabricant, to William Howard Donaldson, son of Mrs. Fred M. Parker of Watertown and Cape Vincent, N.Y., and the late Howard B. Donaldson. A summer wedding in France is planned.

title: A Grosz Show in Princeton
description: PRINCETON  In Berlin during the hectic, disillusioned days of the Weimar Republic, George Grosz was one of the principal exponents of a biting, sardonic form of artistic expression known as Die Neue Sachlichkeit  the new objectivity. Ruthlessly, he portrayed the city's greedy, corpulent businessmen, smug housewives, placid, voluptuous prostitutes and supercilious Army officers.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE CHAIRMAN of the Federal Reserve Board, Dr. Arthur F. Burns, gave his blessing to the idea of dual prime rates by banks for different categories of business. The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago was the first bank to reduce a recently announced rate of 6 per cent to 6 per cent after the Committee on Interest and Dividends said the rise by several banks was not justified at this time.

title: State Unit, Citing Chaos, Scores City's Welfare Aid
description: A state commission charged yesterday that unparalleled chaos existed in the city's delivery of social services to welfare clients, in part because of a plethora of legislative and administrative changes imposed in recent years.

title: Week's Music Offers Didjeridu Sextet
description: The didjeridu is a wind instrument of the Australian Aboriginals that looks like nothing so much as a tree branch that has been hollowed out by termites. That, in fact, is exactly what the didjeridu is, and what it does is emit a hollow, foghornish drone.

title: Nassau Library Seeks Funds
description: GARDEN CITYThe Nassau Library System would gain $155,000 under Governor Rockefeller's proposed budget, but its director says that is not enough.

title: David Heal to Marry Miss Leslee L. Smith
description: PITTSBURGH, March 24Mr. and Mrs. Norman Ralph Smith have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leslee Lenore Smith, to David Gordon Heal, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Edward Heal of Elizabeth, N.J. The wedding is planned for April 28.

title: News of the Rialto
description: AMID the hullaballoo attending Joseph Papp's projected arrival as a member of the Lincoln Center establishmenthis New York Shakespeare Festival will become a constituent of the 65th Street Street complex in the fall, if funding proves availableit may not be amiss to remind the leader's loyal legions that there will be a Shakespeare Festival in Central Park this summer.

title: Dr. Ivan Soubbotitch, 79, Dies; A Professor at New York Law
description: Dr. Ivan Soubbotitch; a professor at the New York Law School who had long been with the law firm of Coudert Brothers, died Friday of a heart attack in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 1045 Park Avenue.

title: 8 Years Out of Gracie Mansion, Wagner Insists City Is Governable
description: Now 62 years old and eight years removed from the mayoral power he held for 12 years, Robert F. Wagner hunched forward in his elegant midtown law office and talked in the deliberate, almost nervously halting way he had always talked, about the Wagner era at City Hall and about his curious relationship with Governor Rockefeller, which seems to be leading him to another bid for the mayoralty. And, Mr. Wagner insisted, as he always had, that New York City was governable.

title: Miss Kellner Fiancee Of Albertos Benveniste
description: Mr. and Mrs. Warren Kellner have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mis Michele Leslie Kellner, to Albertos Benveniste, son of Mrs. and Mrs. Simy Benveniste of Salonika, Greece. A Dec. 15 wedding is planned.

title: G. I. Legends of Vitnam, Some Even True
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 24 (AP)Can it really be that somewhere in South Vietnam the Vietcong are running a mobile snack bar, stolen from the Americans, complete with popcorn popper and ice cream machine?

title: Boulez at the Philharmonic
description: Pierre Boulez has turned the New York music scene upside down. Even before he took over as music director of the New York Philharmonic in September, 1971, his reputation as the champion of unfamiliar contemporary music had preceded him. A priori, he made masses of enemies. A host of others have since joined the ranks. So the groans were perhaps heartier than the hurrahs when it was announced last November (about 11 months after the fact) that the 48yearold Frenchman's contract had been extended three years to run through the 197677 season.

title: Brooklyn Parkway Decision In Dispute
description: The decision of the Board of Estimate last Thursday to approve a $965,000 project to repave and beautify nearly a mile and a half of Eastern Parkway, in Brooklyn, brought up a subject that has disturbed Brooklynites for a long time.

title: Headliners
description: Campaign workers closest to Mrs. Hale Boggs find it difficult to explain why she ran to succeed her husband as Congressman from Louisiana. She says she never really made the decision, it was just something that everybody expected her to do, says Pat Mahoney, who worked as Mr. Boggs's secretary for 10 years. Corinne Boggs, 57, declared her candidacy for the seat three months after her husband disappeared on an airplane flight over Alaska last Oct. 16. She had plenty of political savvy gained in campaigns for her husband, and she quickly picked up endorsements from the political leaders in her district. Last month she won a fivecandidate Democratic primary easily, and last week, in a special election, she overwhelmed her Republican opponent, attorney Robert E. Lee, by a fourtoone margin.

title: OMBUDSMAN PLAN
description: Governor Rockefeller has moved to limit sharply the powers of a 127yearold prison reform group that recently announced its intention of establishing an ombudsman for inmates in the state's correctional institutions.

title: AROUND THE
description: Turn over the compost pile.... Watch seedlings indoors to be sure they are not drying out; turn daily to keep them straight (they bend toward the light). . . . Last call to feed shade and fruit trees.... Spray elms for elm bark beetle control.... Sow hardy vegetables oditdoors.

title: The Bowie Boom
description: BRITISH rock and roll, for all its other occasional other virtues, has always been a generational phenomenon, tied to youth and particularly British youth. Not that Americans can't enjoy it, even Americans past the cutoff point of 25. But the rock bands that continue to emerge from the British Isles generally start with a distinct sense of themselves as part of a subculture alienated from the rest of the world by class, drugs, superior perceptions and, above all age.

title: Canada Expected to Keep Her Truce Force in Vietnam
description: OTTAWA, March 24While its official position is not expected to be announced until Tuesday, the Canadian Government has laid virtually all the groundwork for an announcement that the 290 Canadian observers will stay on duty in South Vietnam.

title: The New Corrosion
description: The 1950's had their scandalsof five percenters seeking Government contracts for their clients; of a gift freezer accepted by President Truman's military aide; of a vicuna coat given to President Eisenhower's special assistant. Even though these incidents have a quaintly oldfashioned ring today, they aroused the American public at the timeperhaps excessively.

title: Auto Emissions
description: DETROITHalted assembly lines. . . cars that cost hundreds of dollars more but run poorly and burn more fuel . . . a dislocated auto industry. That was the grim scenario pictured by the Big Four automakers at hearings two weeks ago before the Environmental Protection Agencya vision of the havoc that could result from their efforts to meet Federal air pollution standards for 1975.

title: Bobick Ready for Pro Debut
description: Duane Bobick still remembers the phone call, as if it happened yesterday, not last August.

title: Being a Pro Is a Lot of Fun
description: Olga Korbut has departed, a Russian hummingbird in white tights who made America flip too, a gymnastic master of sport of international class, a 17yearold representative of the Soviet armed forces although She is only 4 feet 11 inches and 84 pounds. Now, into the Felt Forum for the Lady Gotham Classic tennis tournament, will come America's version of the teenage heroine  Chris Evert, the tanned blonde who resembles a cute poodle on parade, a touring pro at 18, a high school senior who will earn at least $100,000 this year in prize money and business deals although she has turned down more financial temptations than she has accepted.

title: Cost of Food Battle Of the Checkout Counter
description: WASHINGTONIs Phase 3 a failure? Concern for its future was widespread last week in the wake of a report that consumer prices had soared by 0.8 per cent in Februarythe largest rise since the Korean Warand that supermarket prices alone leaped by 2.4 per cent.

title: GOLF FINAL MINED BY MISS BLALOCK
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 24 (UPI)Jane Blalock continued her mastery of the St. Lucie Sinners course today and led 16 survivors into tomorrow's final round of medal play of the $100,000 Sears women's golf tourney with a 5 and 4 victory over Mrs. Kathy Cornelius.

title: Latest Entry in Song Contest Not Music to Everyone's Ears
description: TRENTONThere is little likelihood that New Jersey's newest songwriting team ever will be mistaken for Rodgers & Hart. The composers Frank DeBenedetto and John Prato, both of Passaic, and they have produced the latest candidate for the state's official song.

title: Admiral Kidd vs. Mister Rule
description: When Ogden Corp., the company that owns the giant Avondale Shipyard in Louisiana, ran into trouble because of a suspiciously low bid on a Navy destroyer contract a few years ago, it did what other military contractors have often done: It demanded more money from the Government. At a highlevel meeting in the office of then Under Secretary of the Navy John Warner, the company's chairman submitted a letter drafted by its Washington lawyer (himself a former General Counsel of the Navy). The company, the letter said, was neither willing nor able to put up more money toward delivery of the destroyers. Therefore, it was incumbent on the Department of the Navy to come up with the needed cash or the shipyard would simply stop work. When the company officials had been asked to leave the room, the admiral in charge of shipbuilding told Warner the contractor's demand for an extra $10million on the spot and $4million soon afterward was reasonable and ought to be paid. There seemed to be general agreement. But then a ruddy, expensively but conservatively dressed civilian interrupted. Admiral, he said, over my dead body will you reform that contract and give them $10million. This is the goddamnedest thing I ever heard of, a contractor coming in and throwing a piece of paper on the table and saying that to the Navy.

title: F.B.I. Boston Post Filled
description: BOSTON, March 24 (AP)James O. Newpher, 55 years old, has been named to succeed the late James L. Handley as special agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's regional office here. He currently holds a similar post in Denver.

title: Unwilling gladiator of a modern male state
description: To the Editor: The accusation by Betty Friedan that lesbians are man  haters is surpassed in effect only perhaps by the womanhating exhibited by Friedan herself. Within the broad spectrum of political theory and practice which characterizes feminism in 1973, Betty Friedan stands at the most conservative and peripheral point, and her constituency among feminists has declined proportionately as the movement has extended its vision from reformism to revolutionary social change and has increased its numbers through consciousness of and relevance to the oppression of working class, Third World and lesbian women. Friedan's prediction in McCall's last summer of sexual McCarthyism, of sexist reaction to women's militancy, has come true: and in fact she has fulfilled her prophecy by becoming the prime reactionary voice.

title: Annual Memo: Barnacles Adhere
description: After a winter of keeping your boat stored away, it is a good idea to make sure the vessel is in seaworthy shape before putting it in water. The Marine Department of OwensCorning Fiberglas Corporation is frequently asked to give advice on boat upkeep. Here are some of the more commonly asked questions and answers:

title: U.S. AUTHORS ASK A BAR TO SOVIET
description: The Authors League of America has urged Congressional action to prevent the Soviet Government from using the American courts to enforce its claim to copyright control over the works of Soviet authors.

title: Community's Wrath May Block Privately Run Methadone Clinic
description: The angry reaction of the community may block the plan for a supermarket owner to turn over the second floor of his store building at the southeast corner of Broadway and 104th Street to a privately operated methadone clinic.

title: Pro Baltimore
description: To THE EDITOR: TEPHEN E. RUBIN'S article about Peter Herman Adler's career requires some comment, inasmuch as it unjustly slights the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra. It states, In 1959 Adler went to Baltimore to become chief of its orchestra, remaining until 1967, a period which he considers a low point in his career because his attempt to improve the ensemble failed.

title: Jersey Toll Evasion Down
description: WOODBRIDGE, N. J., March 24 (UPI)The New Jersey Highway Authority announced, today that stricter enforcement and new warning signs at toll gates had decreased the number of motorists slipping through the gates without paying. Motorists arrested as toll evaders are tried in municipal courts and face a maximum fine of $200 and 30 days' imprisonment.

title: PUZZLES
description: READING MATTERBy A. J. Santora

title: Martin Captures Jump Title
description: BANFF, Alberta, March 24 (AP)Jerry Martin of Minneapolis was outdisanced on both jumps but compiled the winning point total today in the North American ski jumping championships. Martin had 213.7 points. Scott Clayton of Denver had the longest jump, 253 feet.

title: I.C.C. Seeks Rail Aid Plan With 1% Levy on Freight
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Interstate Commerce Commission, in a report to Congress, proposed today the restructuring of railroads in the Northeast into a Federal aid railway system with Government grants funded through a generas 1 per cent tax on freight transportation.

title: Mother To Miltie
description: RING LARDNER Jr. and Ingo Preminger, the writer and producer behind the wildly popular Korean war comedy, M*A*S*H, will next focus on a contemporary battle. They have acquired The WhoreMother, Shaun Herron's new novel about a 21yearold member of the Irish Republican Army who becomes disillusioned and tries to escape the violence and brutality that surround him. Among those aidingor hinderinghim in his effort to flee are a passionate widow, a young American girl and a number of hardbitten patriots who are convinced their fight is the good fight.

title: Collision Over the Cost of Money
description: The Nixon Administration confronted the nation's bankers over the cost of money last week and the shock waves from the collision sent a tremor through the financial community.

title: Rudel Looks Ahead
description: IT may be something of an exaggeration to say that Julius Rudel is a oneman interlocking directorate or that the footlights never dim on his operatic empire. And then again it may not. He is director of the New York City Opera, music director of the Kennedy Center in Washington and music director of the Caramoor Festival in Katonah, N. Y,, all of which produce opera in a large or small way. He is music adviser for Wolf Trap Farm, the summer festival just outside of Washington, and he has an informal relationship with the Opera Society of Washington (it performs at the Kennedy Center), the Los Angeles Music Center Opera Association (it sponsors the City Opera's annual Los Angeles season) and the Cincinnati Summer Opera (it has used Corbett Foundationfinanced productions that originated at the City Opera because the foundation is in Cincinnati). He is also board chairman of the National Opera Institute, which finances opera projects and singers. The important aspect of spreading myself all over the place, Rudel said the other day in announcing his City Opera plans for next season, is the crossfertilization of opera ideas and productions that it allows. Our current production of The Coronation of Poppea came from Caramoor. Beatrix Cenci originated with the Opera Society in Washington.

title: Vietnam
description: SAIGONThe pattern was becoming a familiar one: an allegedly flagrant violation of the ceasefire, a challenge to the peacekeeping machinery to take some action  and paralysis.

title: Deborah Davis And a Teacher Wed in Jersey
description: SHEWSBURY, N. J., March 24  Miss Deborah Strong Davis and Michael L. Friedmann were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Shippen Davis Jr., by Mayor Robert C. Lawrence 3d. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Leo Friedmann of New York.

title: Few Surprises in Elections in Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L.I.Few issues stirred sufficient excitement to produce many surprises in last Tuesday's village elections in Nassau County. In 15 contests no incumbent mayor was unseated and only three incumbent trustees were defeated.

title: Bronx Girl, 17, and Five Others Are Stabbed to Death in the City
description: An argument among three teenagers in a Bronx tavern early yesterday led to the fatal stabbing of a 17yearold girl and the wounding of her boyfriend.

title: Monet Is Given to Princeton
description: PRINCETONWhen Claude Monet took a fancy to a particular landscape, he stuck with it. One of his favorite views was his own garden in Giverny, not too far from Paris and he painted it again and again.

title: Lawrence Is Getting Annie
description: LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP Annie Oakley, who is better known for her skill with a gun than as an apostle of togetherness, is being called on to establish a closer relationship between parents and teachers at the Lawrence Intermediate School. Not that there is actually any particular difficulty between the two groups at this school.

title: Soul Mate Is First In Aqueduct Sprint
description: With Braulio Baeza steering her into the lead at the outset, Soul Mate carried the colors of Robert Dodderidge to a smashOg victory in the $27,350 Correction Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Carol Minturn Collins Engaged To Livingston Ludlow Biddle 4th
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bradley Isham Collins of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Minturn Collins, to Livingston Ludlow Biddle 4th, son of Mr. Biddle Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Washington, and the late Mrs. Biddle. A June wedding has been planned.

title: NEW LAND ACQUIRED AT WILDLIFE REFUGE
description: SCARBOROUGH, Me., March 24  The Rachel Carson National Wildlife Refuge will soon be increased by 45.6 acres of marshland and upland being acquired here by the United States Bureau of Sport Fisheries and Wildlife.

title: Medich, Pitching Way to M.D., Learns as Yankees Are Beaten
description: MIAMI, March 24If this spring were like any of the past few in the life of George Medich, the budding doctor would be studying anesthesiology, pediatrics, psychiatry, orthopedics and neurology. But it isn't, so the budding pitcher is studying fastballs, sliders and curves Instead.

title: Tompkins Park Center Is Opened
description: A $1.5million recreation and cultural center opened Friday in Tompkins Park, in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Arthur Daley
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 24As excitement mounted in the homestretch showdown last season, Johnny Bench and Joe Morgan of the Cincinnati Reds were at opposite extremes in advocating candidates for the most valuable player trophy in the National League. Bench kept insisting the only logical choice was, Morgan, while Morgan's preference was Bench.

title: F. B. I. Chief: Tattletale Gray
description: WASHINGTONThe White House was insisting publicly that L. Patrick Gray 3d continued to enjoy the President's undiminished support, but in private some Nixon Administration officials were said to be referring to him as tattletale Gray.

title: HOME FURNISHINGS
description: Order now  we'll let you know the price when we deliver it.

title: Tomec C. Smith Becomes Fiance Of Jean Mason
description: KEY LARGO, Fla., March 24Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Warner Mason have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Ellen Mason, to Tomec Colburne Smith, son of Mrs. Olga Tomec Smith and Paul Shaw Smith, both of Princeton, N. J. An April 28 wedding is planned.

title: 3 WALPOLE GUARDS FACE QUESTIONING
description: WALPOLE, Mass., March 24 (AP)Correction Commissioner John O. Boone ordered three Walpole State Prison guards tonight to submit detailed reports of an incident in which the officers are allegedly involved in the beating of an inmate.

title: The Digger's Game
description: George V. Higgins won't like the way reviewers are going to scrawl genre all over his new novel. He told an interviewer he doesn't think he's writing crime stories. He says he's writing about people, a number of whom have a tendency to break the law. He's right. But most reviewers are unredeemable pigeonholers, and there is probably no way to stop them from winging The Digger's Game toward the slots marked Crime Novel and Underworld Fiction. (His own publisher is already guilty.) This categorizing is unfortunate, for Higgins has done more than write a fast, gripping story about Boston's underworld. He has created in the Digger a deeply touching character who can make you weep with laughter and with sorrow and, one way or another, would

title: Economy
description: WASHINGTON For almost two months, Richard Nixon has been sending State of the Union messages and accompanying legislation to Congress, calling for some of the most sweeping national changes proposed by a President in the last four decades. In virtually every case, Mr. Nixon has provided a moral or philosophical rationale for his decisionbut central to his total program is an economic justification.

title: COLUMBIA CREW SWEEPS 3 RACE
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. March 24Columbia swept three events in which it was tered in the fourth annual Deering Cup regatta today on Orchard Beach Lagoon.

title: In Spring Thoughts Turn to Artichokes
description: Artichokes, plump and petaled, are frequently in produce bins, but infrequently in balanced budgets. The exception is in the spring when the abundance of artichokes usually depresses the price and also assures freshness.

title: Texas Tornado Hits Wall Street
description: H. Ross Perot, the computer millionaire who controls duPont Glore Forgan, Inc., the country's third largest stock brokerage house, has hit Wall Street with the force of a Texas tornado.

title: Seafari Finds Beauty Beneath Surface
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. A converted 57foot ChrisCraft Constellation has embarked on her new role as mother ship for the ultimate in scubadiving adventure.

title: A gallery of hurt animals and people
description: Welcome to a festival of mangled animals, tortured sexuality and innocence betrayed. During a large part of this novel, the title hawk is being trained by Harry Crews's hero, a 43yearold Georgia boy named George Gattling. The training involves the bird's being trapped, starved, tethered and fairly well driven mad until it understands what George requires of it: submission so total that its master can release it from restraint and be onthespot witness as it approaches and kills its prey, thus vicariously participating in the freedom of same. (Instead of George really living himself, right?) Other, similar scenes surround this training: small, helpless animals are variously mutilated; their long suffering is lovingly detailed; the pace of their deaths is recorded.

title: Coast Guard Asks Public to Advise on L.I. Drawbridge Changes
description: The United States Coast Guard is asking for public comments on proposed changes in its regulations governing the operation of nine Long Island drawbridges to cut down on summer traffic jams to South Shore beaches and long waits for boaters.

title: Elizabeth Mumford To Marry in August
description: DOVER, Mass., March 24 Mr. and Mrs. George Saltonstall Mumford Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Herrick Mumford, to Richard Hoyt Forshay Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Forshay of Setauket, L. I. An August wedding is planned.

title: 2,897 Objects in Orbit
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, March 24 (UPI)The Aerospace Defense Command said this week that 2,897 manmade objects were currently orbiting the earth. The command said the United States had 1,978 objects in space followed by the Soviet Union with 834.

title: East German Sextet Downs Swiss in World Tourney, 85
description: GRAZ, Austria, March 24 (UPI)  East Germany beat Switzerland, 85, in the world B ice hockey championships today underlining its reputation as top favorite of the tournament.

title: DAVID HILL, 70, LED PITTSBURGH GLASS
description: PITTSBURGH, March 24 (AP) David Garrett Hill, former chairman of the board of PPG Industries, died today at MageeWomens Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: DAVID A. GREGG 2D, AIDED HANDICAPPED
description: NASHUA, N. H., March 24David A. Gregg 2d, former vice president of the Crotched Mountain Rehabilitation Center for the physically handicapped at Greenfield, which had been founded by his father, Harry A. Gregg, died Thursday. He was 65 years old and lived in Wilton Center.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Every political movement must at some point deal with those who may have been among its originators, but beyond whom it has now grown. There should be some way the Women's Movement can recognize Betty Friedan's contribution and respect it, while gently but firmly dismissing her current irrelevant and pathetic demands that we all go backward. Friedan's magazine article (Up from the kitchen floor, March 4) contained scurrilous and vituperative attacks on lesbian feminists, deliberate misrepresentations of the radical feminist wing (more than half the Movement), and insensitive blindness to the needs and demands of Third World women, many of whom are now forming Black, Chicano, Puerto Rican and Native American radical feminist group in the United States.

title: Miss Priscilla Christman to Wed
description: CHICAGO, March 24Mr. and Mrs. Robert Harvey Christman have announced the engagement of their daughter., Miss Priscilla Phillips Christman, to William Kellogg Newbury, son of Mr. and Mrs. Egbert S. Newbury Jr. of Concord, Mass. A June 16 wedding is planned.

title: Miss Barnum Has Nuptials
description: NOROTON, Conn., March 24Miss Wendy Claire Barnum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard N. Barnum Jr. of Darien, was married here this afternoon to Richard Neal Hokin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Hokin of Chicago. The Rev. Dr. Lawrence MacColl Horton performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Noroton Presbyterian Church.

title: Great Neck Symphony Troubled By Success
description: The Great Neck Symphony is in the paradoxical positon of determining whether at can survive its success.

title: G. L. Stables to Wed Miss Wright
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 24 Miss Bonnie Wright, cochairman of the Ox Ridge Horse Show, and George Leslie Stables, a management consultant in Woodside and Danville, Calif., will be married June 23 in Darien.

title: Nixon Urges Aid for Vietnam Veterans
description: MIAMI, March 24President Nixon issued a 1,200word statement today praising the 2.5 million Vietnam veterans and urging Americans to offer them respect and opportunities and saying that in every area of Government concern, we are now doing more than we have ever done for discharged servicemen.

title: COURT DELAY CUT IN NASSAU COUNT
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 24Despite substantial increases in most types of litigation, the courts in Nassau County have been able to decrease the call endar delays, Justice Thomas P Farley, administrative judge Nassau County, said this week on releasing his 1972 report or the work of the courts.

title: 25 at Upsala Are Staging A Marathon For WFMU
description: EAST ORANGE  More than 25 Upsala College students and friends are manning microphones and telephones 24 hours a day in an attempt to raise $10,000 for the college's FM radio station, WFMU.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The expert on Navy procurement, in the eyes of some, had made three serious mistakes last December testifying before a Congressional committee when he: (I) assailed the appointment of Roy L. Ash as head of the Office of Management and Budget in the White House; (2) offered the view that, because of the Ash appointment, President Eisenhower, who had warned against the militaryindustrial complex, must be twitching in his grave; (3) bluntly demanded a tougher policy to force manufacturers to abide by contracts (Mr. Ash, as head of Litton Industries, had been involved in hundreds of millions of dollars in contract disputes with the Navy). The day after this testimony by Gordon W. Rule, Adm. Isaac C. Kidd Jr., chief of the Naval Matriel Command, asked Mr. Rule to resign. Mr. Rule refused and was shifted to a minor post. But last week Admiral Kidd returned him to his old job. Said the Navy: the minor assignment had been completed. Said Mr. Rule:

title: Photography
description: LUCIEN AIGNER, photojournalist, whose contemporaries and friends have included Alfred Eisenstadt, Erich Salomon and Robert Cape, is having a partial retrospective at the Contemporary Arts Gallery in N.Y.U.'s Loeb Student Center on Washington Square South.

title: The Hollywood 10 recalled
description: A few weeks ago, David Rintels, a Hollywood screenwriter in his late 30's, turned in his script about a blacklisted writer to his agent. A secretary in her 50's read it and dissolved into tears, while a secretary in her 20's said, I like it, but there's one thing I don't understand. Why didn't he just name the names and go back to work?

title: Alternating Current
description: The perception of distance can be a tricky problem. Here is Octavio Paz, a Mexican writer of striking gifts and postures, virtuoso of several genres, at home with French surrealism, American poetry, German romanticism, Marxist polemic. He seems very much the modernist writer as we have come to know him in the 20th century: sophisticated, mercurial, ambitious, selfdramatizing. A familiar type, a splendid instance.

title: Pamela Jordan Engaged to Officer
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 24Mrs. William Edward Jordan has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Pamela Smith Jordan, to Lieut. William Christian Conkle, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen J. Conkle of Toledo, Ohio, where Mr. Conkle is a senior partner in the law firm of Bugbee & Conkle.

description: Were it not for the good performance of so many pupils in Queens, the averages on the citywide reading tests, which were recently disclosed, would have been even lower than they were.
