title: News Summary and Index
CRICKET TEST HALTS AS FANS BURN STAND
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 24 (Reuters)The third and final cricket test between Pakistan and England here had to be abandoned 40 minutes early on its opening day today when demonstrative spectators set fire to a stand.

title: A Top Jewish Scientist Who Tried to Leave Soviet Finds Life Drastically Changed
description: MOSCOW, March 24 (AP)Dr. Benjamin G. Levich was once near the top of the Soviet establishment as a corresponding member of the Academy of Sciences. But a year ago his world began to collapse.

title: Ken Maynard of Westerns Dies
description: HOLLYWOOD, March 24 (UPI)Ken Maynard, the whitehatted cowboy hero of some 300 Western movies, died yesterday at the age of 77.

title: Center for Elderly Widening Its Vistas
description: JERSEY CITY  The 3yearold boy and the. 103yearold man who pass in the corridor of the Jewish Hospital and Rehabilitation Center of New Jersey here are both profiting from its expanded facilities.

title: RACES UNDER WAY IN WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 24The two minor parties in Westchester County are presenting major problems as the Democratic and Republican campaigns for County Executive and other offices get under way.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: President Nixon's impoundment of funds invades a peculiarly Congressional province. Two bills, one sponsored by Senator Ervin, another by Representative Mahon, are designed to restrain him (editorial March 18). The situation is serious generally. Despite constitutionally shared powers, the President has monopolized warmaking and foreign affairs. It's about time Congress got its back up.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 125 bookstores in 64 communities of the United figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive apnearances.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Heavy selling swept through the stock market last week in response to fresh indications of inflation in the domestic economy and deteriorating relations between the Nixon Administration and the commercialbanking community.

title: A scholarcritic who doesn't write for scholarcritics
description: The title of this volume of essays has been chosen with the insight of a poet  not that all poets have it. Horace Gregory's deepest concern is to perceive the most gifted writers, even those who rebel against their worlds, as profoundly reflecting the milieu in which they live, at the same time that they vibrate with meaning for readers of whatever period. This aim demands a sane knowledge of both past and present, and a sensitive responsiveness to the varieties of human thought and feeling; and the first thing to be said about these essays is that they triumphantly surmount these not easily satisfied demands.

title: Mexico Clinches Davis Cup Victory, Will Oppose U.S.
description: MEXICO CITY, March 24 (AP)Mexico clinched its North American Zone Davis Cup tennis semifinal series with Colombia today, winning the doubles for a 30 advantage.

title: IMMACULATA WOMEN RETAIN TITLE, 5952
description: Immaculata (Pa.) College repeated as the women's national college basketball champion by defeating Queens College, 5952, at Queens yesterday.

title: Notre Dame and Virginia Tech Score Upsets in N.I.T. Semifinals
description: Notre Dame's young basketball team grew up to the final of the National Invitation Tournament yesterday.

title: Seawater Anyone?
description: QUESTION: Is it safe to drink salt water? If so, in what quantities and in what proportions to fresh water? K.H., New York.

title: Yanks Quiet on That Issue
description: With seasonticket sales running 50 percent ahead last year, the New York Yankees are trying hard to avoid further controversy over the case of their familyswapping pitchers.

title: PORSCHE IS FIRST IN 12HOUR EVENT
description: SEBRING, Fla., March 24 (AP)  Peter Gregg, Hurley Haywood and Dr. David Helmick, a Florida physician, drove a swift little PorscheCarrera to victory tonight in the 23d Sebring 12hour sports car race.

title: Francis B. Shepard Is Fiance Of Miss Susan Wells Donnell
description: ST. LOUIS, March 24Miss Susan Wells Donnell and Francis Burritt Shepard of New York, members of the Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd., will be married here in June.

title: Will the Paris Opera Become the Greatest?
description: PARIS. AT the end of 1972, the Paris Opera, within living memory a byword for artistic obscurantism, technical backwardness and an administrative system of Byzantine complexity, shut its doors. On January 1, 1973, Rolf Liebermann, for fourteen years Intendant of the Hamburg State Opera, took command for three years.

title: Tenure for College Teachers Supported
description: A national commission formed to study the muchcriticized system of tenure for college and university teachers concludes in a report made public yesterday that the system needs major overhaul but is still better than any alternative.

title: CALABRIA GETTING U.S.TYPE COLLEGE
description: COSENZA, Italy, March 22In this remote corner of the deep south, close to the wild Sila Mountains, Italy's first Americantype college campus is taking shape.

title: DR. EDWARD A. GRECO
description: CAPE ELIZABETH, Me., March 24Dr. Edward A. Greco, a Portland cardiologist and a founder of the Maine Heart Association, died at his home here yesterday. He was 72 years old.

title: Islam Is Spreading Quickly Among the Black Africans and Growing as a Force for Political Change
description: KANO, Nigeria (AP)Under a scorching African sun, 50,000 kneeling Moslems bow toward Mecca, their heads touching the red dirt, in praise of God.

title: Air Fares
description: I'd like to announce the cheapest regular fare ever, said Robert Morley, the British actor, his oval face beaming from a January fullpage advertisement of the British Overseas Airways Corporation. There was some fine print at the bottom of the page but the reader could hardly escape the impression that lower air fares across the Atlantic were on the way.

title: Christopher Isherwood: No Parades
description: I am a camera with its shutter open, quite passive, recording, not thinking. Recording the man shaving at the window opposite and the woman in the kimono washing her hair. Some day, all this will have to be developed, carefully printed, fixed.

title: U.S. and Panama
description: PANAMA CITYThe United States found itself virtually alone on the Panama Canal issue last week and had to resort to the veto, only its third in United Nations history.

title: Mets Drop Sixth in Row By Bowing to Phils, 62
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., March 24Felix Milian, the 29yearold second baseman for the New York Mets, wore eyeglasses today for the first time and promptly hit a single, double and home run off Steve Carlton, probably the best pitcher in baseball.

title: Truman Library Popular
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., March, 24 (AP)The death of former President Truman in December aaprently has created a new interest by the public in the Truman Library here. Library officials report a 14fold increase in the number of visitors to the library since Mr. Truman's death.

title: Court Voids Luxury Unit Overlooking The Hudson
description: NORTH BERGENA Hudson County Superior Court judge has barred temporarily the construction of a controversial $100million luxury apartment complex that was initially scheduled to be built this spring.

title: CELTICS SET BACK KNICKS BY 108103 ON 2DHALF SURGE
description: The New York Knicks finished a successful season on an unsuccessful note at Madison Square Garden last night, losing to the Boston Celtics, 108103, after being thoroughly outhustled and outplayed in the second half.

title: Roanoke Island, 121, Wins by Head in Hoover Handicap
description: BALTIMORE, March 24Roanoke Island surged to the front in the final strides today to score by a head in the $28,650 J. Edgar Hoover Handicap before a crowd of 18,435 at Pimlico Race Course. Overlooked in the betting Roanoke Island paid $25.80 for $2 to win.

title: LEO NADEL
description: Leo Nadel, a distributor for Standard Oil (Indiana) and the American Oil Company in the metropolitan area until his retirement in 1954, died Friday in Miami Beach, where he lived. His age was 85.

title: Paperwork For A.K.C. Is Ending
description: It was American Kennel Club Day on March 2 at the symposium sponsored by Dog Lovers Digest magazine at the New York Hilton. After a few welcoming words by John A. Lafore Jr., the A.K.C. president, John Man= deville took over as program coordinator, and speeches were heard by eight of the organization's ganization's executives. Leonand B. Brumby Jr., senior vice president, stressed education and ethics, which he said provided the key to the fuof the sport.

title: The Cruise Of the Arctic Star
description: It's time to think back to Ishmael in Moby Dick who pauses to Consider the sea ... the land ... and ... a strange analogy to something in yourself. It's time to recall Caleb in Scott O'Dell's own The Dark Canoe who advises a seaman to Speak up . . . Unloose thy tongue ... Thoughts unsaid clutter the mind and do in time make it bilious. Yet it is no Ishmael, no Ahab in pursuit of the white whale, no Caleb, but O'Dell himself, as captain of a boat bound for Alaska, who is in command of this cruise up the West Coast, circa today.

title: Wedding on Aug. 4 For Raimi Olonoff
description: LIDO BEACH, L.I., March 24Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Olonoff have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Raimi H. Olonoff, to Richard Slater, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Slater of Armonk, N.Y.

title: Last Dance Wins Stakes
description: LINCOLN, R.I., March 24 (AP) Last Dance won the Watch Hill Handicap at Lincoln Downs today, covering the five furlongs in 594.5 seconds and returning $5.40 straight.

title: No NewStadium Woes for Bills
description: While the Giants cast about for a place to play this season and next, their dismayed fans can imagine the future by relating to the Buffalo Bills' new stadium. The Bills will open the 80,000seat facility in suburban Orchard Park, N.Y., on Aug. 17 when they play the Washington Redskins in a preseason game. The magnificent stadium, publicly financed, will have taken only 14 months to complete, provided it is ready for the Washington game.

title: Jessie Potter Engaged
description: GLADWYNE, Pa., March 24Miss Jessie Hayt Potter and James Burke Kingston plan to be married in June. Miss Potter is a daughter of John Rust Potter of Miami Beach, Fla., and Mrs. John Febiger Spahr of Gladwyne and is a granddaughter of the late Ernest Martin Hopkins, 11th president of Dartmouth College. Mr. Kingston is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Joseph Kingston of West Hartford, Conn

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Letters: Disney World Defended
description: To THE EDITOR: Fred Ferretti's recent evaluation of Disney World struck mostly discordant tones in my home. Apparently, Mr. Ferretti objects to the artificiality of animals, beaches and even the Disney characters themselves in Orlando. While I. confess that I found it a bit disconcerting to view Mission Control guided by a lifesized, plastic director and his staff of automated technicians, neither this artifice nor the plastic hippopotamuses disturbed our children ages and 3.

title: Chicken Dinners on Road
description: BOISE CITY, Okla., March 24 (UPI)  A semitrailer overturned on a sleetcovered highway in western Oklahoma today, dumping 40,000 pounds of dressed chicken onto the pavement.

title: Looking for Trouble? Look for Hal Holbrook
description: HAL HOLBROOK says he doesn't go looking for trouble, and that may be true. On the other hand, one could also say that, where television is concerned, he has demonstrated an uncanny knack for knowing where to stand and wait for trouble to stroll by. I look for things that are good, he says. Usually when they're good they're different, and that's trouble. You see, the only thing left to do on television is to stir up trouble, to be controversial. But television is so meek that to be real is to be controversial. Once in a while you get a script that's worth doing.

title: The real villain in heart disease
description: The first thing you notice in Dr. Campbell Moses's office is that picture on the wall. It shows photographs of eight tubes, like sections of white rubber hose, cut open and stretched out so you can see the inside. The one on the left has a clear, smooth inner surface. The second contains a few barely discernible streaks. In the third, you see a sprinkling of tiny, inconspicuous white lumps, looking like so many seed pearls set into the lining. Each successive tube has more and larger growths; by number five they begin to take on a pinkish tinge and the terrain is growing progressively rougher. Number eight looks like a craterstrewn landscape, with angry red protrusions covering much of the surface.

title: Swimmer Flees East Berlin
description: BERLIN, March 24 (AP)A 36yearold East Berlin man escaped to West Berlin this afternoon by swimming across the Spree River apparently uninjured despite a hail of bullets fired at him. The escape took place just after 3 p.m. on a warm summerlike day. The man was not identified.

title: GARDEN/HOME PLANT & FIXUP
description: THERE is much, talk of freedom these days, happy talk as a rejoicing nation sees its POW's released. Though nature has no recordable voice, it, too, is talking freedom, a dynamic release from winter to spring. With persistence, the tulip pushes up leaves to display its flower. The dormant lawn slowly greens. Buds swell and swell to open new leaves. The birds, back again, whistle merry tunes while they house hunt. The days are longer, skies are bluer, rains are gentler and the sun is warm.

title: Stars beyond the firmament
description: Last month, American television showed a two part movie called Divorce: HisDivorce: Hers starring Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor as a married couple breaking up. The movie was immediately attacked by the critics as middle brow and commercial, but it was also an example of what has become, whether they like it or not, a staple BurtonTaylor acting diet; a film created mainly as a vehicle for them, one more way to package and market  for the tax man, for a whim, for some need often quite irrelevant to the picture these stars who are now so big that they are more important than any script, however good or bad. Such preeminence is growing rare in the modern world of film, and the Burtons at love or war are about the last of their kind. What kind of life does such rarefied celebrity status give them? They permitted a glimpse to an outsider during the filming of Divorce: HisDivorce: Hers:

title: X Plus ? Equals Price Tag for Used Boat
description: While the virtues of buying a used car remain dubious, many experienced boatmen will only consider a used oras the saying goes  previously owned boat.

title: Practical Guide To Good Lawnsmanship
description: GOOD deal of time, effort and money (not necessarily in that order) are spent on estalishing and maintaining home lawns oftentimes unnecessarily, because the home gardener does not have a reasonably clear understanding of the basic needs of grass plants.

description: NORFOLK, Va., March 24 (AP)  The Black Panther party has announced plans to establish a people's police patrol in Norfolk using an armed, armored van truck and a battalion of unarmed foot patrolmen.

description: FICTION

title: Dance: Killing the Joffrey With Alibis
description: IT has been fairly wellknown for two or three weeks now that the Joffrey Ballet was in financial difficulty through the abrupt curtailment of its support from the City Center of Music and Drama, Inc.

title: Israel Reports on Exchange Of Fire and Grenade Attack
description: TEL AVIV, March 24 (UPI)The Israeli military command reported an exchange of gunfire today across the Lebanese border in the north and an Arabguerrilla grenade attack on an army patrol in the occupied Gaza Strip in the south. No casualties or damage were reported in either incident.

title: Snead Captures Passing Honors
description: Norm Snead of the New York Giants led the National Football League in passing in 1972, according to official statistics released yesterday.

description: REGINA, Saskatchewan, March 24 (Canadian Press)Sweden took the world curling championship from Canada today, taking a 65 extraend decision in the final game.

description: Small Hope Bay Lodge is not a slick, fancy resort. It's a small, unique world of its own, tucked away in a corner of Andros Island, one of the few places left where you can really get away and spread a little space around yourself.

description: KIFUGCQ. Mere jabberwocky, you think? Not to a true connoisseur of the Scrabble Crossword Game. Within seconds he can translate sikh nonsense into quick,and 20 points.

description: CEDARHURST, L. I. Cedarhurst has its own museum shop  without a museum.

title: CORRECTION
description: Ada Louise Huxtable's article on industrial architecture in today's Arts and Leisure Section states that a news story had announced the obsolescence and eventual closing of the Ford River Rouge plant., According to the Ford Motor Company, only the Dearborn Iron Foundry within the Rouge manufacturing complex is scheduled to be closed. The Rouge complex continues in active production.

title: 3Day Week Is Spreading in Southern Textile Mills
description: ROANOKE, Ala., March 24. James Brown, a 23yearold loom fixer in the old Handley textile mill here, is sold on a threeday work week. For him, it is a way out of the textile mill.

title: Hospital Unit Names Aide
description: CHICAGO, March 24 (AP)William T. Robinson, president of the Massachusetts Hospital Association, has been named a vice president of the American Hospital Association effective July 1.

description: The Soviet naval squadron in the Mediterranean has been raised to a strength from 55 to 60 ships, including a new guidedmissile cruiser, according to qualified sources in the Defense Department.

title: Indiana Signs Knight For Another 5 Years
description: ST. LOUIS, March 24Bobby Knight became one of the 10 highestpaid college basketball coaches this week when he agreed to another five years with Indiana University at a salary of about $28,500 a year. His current contract had two more years to go.

title: LAVER AND SMITH REACH NET FINAL
description: ATLANTA, March 24 (AP)Rod Laver and Stan Smith, the two top seeded players in the $50,000 Peachtree Corners international tennis tourney, each scored decisive victories today in semifinalround action. They will meet in the final tomorrow.

title: Pop
description: WHEN Dion and the Belmonts recorded in the late fifties, no one knew that rock and roll was here to stay, but anyone who in 1973 dismisses it as a passing fad must be living at the North Pole. During the same years the music wedded its beat and life style to pop culture, divorce struck many of the biggest groups. Recently, two unglued groups decided to try it together one more time. Their two new albums, Reunion by Dion and the Belmonts (Warner Bros. BS 2664) and Byrds (Asylum SD 5058) underline the changes rock underwent from those halcyon gum  chewing days of its childhood to the stormy placard  carrying days of its adolescence. Sweet innocence turned into painful awareness.

title: Insanity Defense
description: Ever since our ancestral common law emerged out of the darkness of its early barbaric) days, it has been a posgtaiete of Western civilization that the taking of a life by the hand of an insane person is not murder.

title: Confessions of a Klostersphile
description: KLOSTERS, Switzerland. In the last paragraph of Joyce's story The Dead, there is the line, Snow was general all over Ireland. The line is freighted with sorrow and is a fitting coda for a story about loss and age in a sad country. But obviously Joyce was no skier. The snow is general today all over Switzerland and there is jubilation in every face and the Gruezis with which the Swiss greet each other ring out like sleigh bells.

title: Gentry Knocks Out a Few About the Mets
description: When he was a Met, Gary Gentry was never at a loss for an opinion when asked about anything. Now that he no longer is a Met, he still has opinions, including many about the Mets:

title: Architect to Marry Barbara Schulman
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 Miss Barbara Ann Schulman, who is in her second year at the Columbia University School of Architecture, plans to be married here in July to Homer Preston Crum Jr., an architect with the Atlanta firm of Thompson, Ventulett & Stainback.

title: L.I. Woman Found Slain In Trinidad Hilton Room
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, March 24 (Reuters)A young American woman was found slain in her room at the Trinidad Hilton Hotel yesterday.

title: Or One Season Ticket
description: NEW HAVEN, March 24 (AP) Maybe we'll, let the Giants use the Bowl, wrote Yale secretary Henry Chauncey, Jr., in a waggish comment in the April issue of Yale's alumni magazine on the New York Giants' search for a home field, in return for one quarterback, two defensive backs and three future draft choices.

title: A.I.A. Awards
description: The American Institute of Architects has anounced the recipients of 12 awards to be presented at its 105th annual convention May 7 to 10 in San Francisco.

title: Javits Asks Parley on NATO Crisis
description: PARIS, March 24Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, called today for a toplevel Western meeting soon to avert a serious crisis that he said was threatening to drive North Altantic allies apart.

title: A Country Twang Hits the City
description: BITS and pieces of the country sound have been creeping into the mainstream of urban American popular music for about nine years. Ever since the Byrds first started using electrified folk and country instrumental styles and vocal harmonies (around 1964), and from the time the pedal steel guitar and fiddle became regular components of many rock bands, it has become respectable to have a Nashville twang in your music. In 1969 Bob Dylan gave the Southern influence an additional push north with his album, Nashville Skyline. Currently, radio and television commercials are just dripping with the sounds and voices of the Grand Ole Opry's top performers, and movies such as Deliverance are using bluegrass tunes as the basis for their scores (Bonnie and Clyde did the same thing a few years back).*Recent indications around New York City also point to a rapidly increasing interest in country music. As Peter McCabe recently pointed out in these pages, radio station WEN is devoting all of its music programming to country. The first appearance at Max's Kansas City by a major, Nashville artist, Waylon Jennings, brought long lines of people for most of the shows. Tom T. Hall has been to Carnegie Hall. George Jones and Tammy Wynette have made their New York debuts at Philharmonic Hall. And Bill Monroe and the Bluegrass Boys attracted close to 2,000 paying customers in the course of a twoday stop in the city.

title: Hearing Is Scheduled By Council This Week
description: Following are open meetings scheduled this week by City Council committees in the Council Committee Room at City Hall:

title: Art School Still Dream As Funds Stay Scarce
description: TRENTONBy dint of dedication and solid groundwork, friends of the arts in New Jersey got their elected representatives here to enact a law declaring that the State Legislature hereby establishes a school for the professional training of students having exceptional talent in the performing and visual arts.

title: '72 POLLUTION LAW BESET BY DELAYS
description: LOS ANGELES. March 24Federal officials acknowledged informally this week that implementation of the Water Poilotion Control Act of 1972 was proceeding considerably more slowly than Congress contemplated.

title: Barnes: I Asked The Coach to Let Me Go Back In
description: ST. LOUIS, March 24 (UPI) At first, Marvin Barnes didn't think it was anything serious at all.

title: Couple Fight Threat To 225YearOld Home
description: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP Many of the problems faced by people who want to preserve, as well as live in, historic homes can be found here in Seven Chimneys, a 225yearold house.

description: The people who have been expert for years in the recovery of stolen autos and the prevention of such thefts have taken a hard look at the boat theft problem and find it ominous.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Thousands at Food Warehouse Get It Wholesale
description: Lashed by everrising food prices and lured by the venerable New York cry I can get it for you wholesale, thousands of families stood in line yesterday as a Queens wholesale food supplier opened its doors to the public.

title: 210 HELD IN SOUTH REFUSE TO RETURN TO NORTH VIETNAM
description: BIEN HOA, South Vietnam, Sunday, March 25  More than 200 Communistside prisoners, most of them reported to be North Vietnamese, refused repatriation today in the biggest mass defection since the Vietnam peace agreement was signed Jan. 27.

title: TRIAL IN BOMBING IN WISCONSIN SET
description: MADISON, Wis., March 24Karleton Lewis Armstronghometown boy, former Boy Scout and onetime crewcut highschoolerstrode into a heavily guarded Dane County Circuit Court here last Tuesday, afternoon, raised his right fist in a power to the people salute, and sat down with his lawyer at the defendant's table.

title: Mixing of MindAltering Drugs Rises as Spread of Heroin Addiction Slows
description: Across the United States the spread of heroin addictior appears to have slowed significantly. Indeed, in some places heroin use seems to have leveled off or even dropped.

title: Turkey
description: In the uneasy balance maintained in Turkey between the civilians, who retain the outward forms of Parliamentary responsibility, and the military, who are in ultimate control, a crucial role has been played by the President. As President or chief of state since the military coup of 1971, Cevdet Sunay, a former commander of the armed forces, has been acting as arbiter between the generals and the political parties.

title: Marjorie F. Merritt, Teacher, Bride of Blake W. Robinson
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 25 Miss Marjorie Fox Merritt and Blake Willcox Robinson were married this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of St. MartinsintheFields in Chestnut Hill by the Rev. W. Benjamin Holmes.

title: SHOP TALK
description: TOTOWAComes spring cleaning, and a lot of household walls will get either a new coat of paint or a new layer of paper. All this makes the people at Best Brothers happy, for the concern not only manufactures a washable paint, which it sells for $5.98 a gallon, but also sells wall coverings.

title: Mrs. Cucchiaro Has Son
description: A son was born March 9 to Mr. and Mrs. Martin Cucchiaro of the Bronx at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. The child has been named Ronald David.

title: Pornography often borrows the trappings of art
description: The pages are smooth and creamy. The illustrations of soft, sumptuous female flesh start on the cover and carry out the book's title, Woman as Sex Object. Its 250 pictures show women fat and thin, free and corseted, for our delectation: 19th century pornography, the 20thcentury pinup and slipped in between is the erotic high art that is the book's justification. Pornography and erotic art stem from the same root: the nude as slave goddess, seen by men as a triumph, a queen, a challenge, something to be conquered. Erotica lived off privacy. Erotica is now going public, and in this book art and the women's movement serve as a publishing gimmick.

title: Islanders Top Flyers, 32, For 3d Straight Victory
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 24 Ed Westfall slapped in a shot from about 10 feet out at 12:03 of the third period to give the New York Islanders a 32 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers in a National Hockey League game before a standing room crwd of 14,665 at the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: 2 Fissures Cause Bergen Tremors
description: MAHWAH  Less than a month ago, on Feb. 28 to be exact, this Bergen County town and the surrounding communities of Waldwick, Wyckoff, Oakland and Franklin Lakes were shaken by earth tremors that passsed through en route from Philadelphia to Plattsburgh, N.Y. It was a mild quake and caused little damage, less as it passed northward.

title: Bruins Top Rangers, 30; Plante, 44, Stars in Goal
description: BOSTON, March 24There's a lot of ham in Jacques Plante. Skating off the ice of Boston Garden this afternoon, the 44yearold goaltender of the Boston Bruins raised both arms and acknowledged, with repeated bows, the ovation of more than 15,000 shrieking Boston fans. arms and acknowledged, with repeated bows, the ovation of more than 15,000 shrieking Boston fans.

title: Total of 5,427 Acres Shut
description: TRENTON  With onequarter of its shellfish waters condemned and another 25 per cent threatened with similar condemnation, state environmentalprotection officials warned this weekend that New Jersey's coastal waterways faced a waterpollutibn crisis and that things most likely would get worse before they got better.

title: AustraliaVatican Tie Set
description: ROME, March 24The Holy See and Australia have decided to establish diplomatic relations at an ambassadorial level, the Vatican announced today.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A good idea well executedthe dual biography of Pope Leo X and Martin Luther. Charles Mee, editor of Horizon magazine, retells the familiar story of the tight, agonized Luther, his inability to bend to Rome, his nailing of the 95 theses to the church door in Wittenberg, which effectively began the Reformation. What readers won't know so well is the personal object of Luther's discontent, Leo X, son of Lorenzo de Medici, patron of the arts and pleasureloving sophisticate. With an artful alternation of their stories until the two men clash, Mr. Mee has produced a highly readable piece of popular history. He makes his preference for the smiling Leo and sunny. Italy over dour Luther and chilly Germany quite acceptable.

title: 300YearOld Statue Missing in Santa Fe
description: SANTA FE, N. M., March 24A statue that has played a significant role in religious services in New Mexico for three centuries is missing from the chapel of St. Francis Cathedral in this city.

title: The Satanic Mill
description: The story is set in 17thcentury Germany during the period of the Thirty Years War. Krabat, a 14yearold Wendish beggar, is enticed by a voice in a dream to a mysterious mill, which is really a school for black magic. In three years he learns how to turn himself into a crow, to make a well run dry, to read minds. There are 11 other boys in the school. The master's face is as white as a sheet. He has a black patch over his left eye, and he studies his craft from the Book of Necromancy which is chained to the table in front of him. Exactly what the mill is grinding is not clear to the very end. The things lying around the bin floor looked like pebbles at first sight; a second glance showed Krabat that they were teeth teeth and splinters of bone.

title: Lie Detector Tests Ordered In Police Loss of $4,000
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., March 24New Mexico State District Judge James A. Maloney has issued an order requiring a former Albuquerque police chief and five members of the city police department to submit to polygraph tests in connection with the disappearance of $4,000 taken from an arrested Chicano leader.

title: CHART GIVES DATA ON POLICE WAGES
description: Senior police captains here now make more than $31,000 a year, sergeants about $20,000 and patrolmen with five years' experience more than $16,000, according to a recently circulated department salary chart.

title: Historic Sites Registered With the State
description: TRENTONFollowing is a list of historic sites in New Jersey registered with the State Office of Historic Sites and most with the National Register of Historic Places (asterisks mark those sites that are not listed in the Federal register):

title: Criminals At Large
description: The American private eye, immortalized by Hammett, refined by Chandler, brought to its zenith by Macdonald, bears with it certain conventions. The private eye does not have much money. He is essentially a loner. He is tough and competent, but he is also lonely, cynical, feels sorry for himself, has a life as seamy as the cases he investigates. And so we come to Bill Pronzini's THE VANISHED (Random, $4.95) and Michael Z. Lewin's THE WAY WE DIE NOW (Putnam's, $5.95), both private eye novels, both adhering very conventions.

title: Architecture
Wanted: Loggers
description: Predicted log contests, long believed the exclusive sport of mathematical whizzes on their comfortable cruisers, are ripe for a comeback in New York waters, according to Eastern Cruiser Association officials.

title: S. L. Simons Fiance Of Suzanne I. Sklar
description: SHREVEPORT, La., March 24  Mr. and Mrs. Albert Sklar have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Irene Sklar, to Stephen Lloyd Simons, son of Alexander Simons of New York and St. Petersburg, Fla., and Mrs. Theodore P. Rosenfeld of New York and Palm Beach, Fla. The wedding will take place here June 30.

title: Golfers Weigh Elder Case in Rainout
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 24Golfers who earn their livelihood on the pro circuit have been talking more about the Lee Elder case during the Greater New Orleans Open than of the short putts they've been missing for birdies.

title: Classic Faces in Transit
L.I. Parklands Facing Neglect
description: BABYLON, L. I., March 1For the first time, the Long Island State Park Commission has found itself with an overabundance of sprawling new park land  some dramatic, untouched wilderness preserves many times largkr than Central Park  but with none of the funds to develop or protect them.

title: Walking the Dead Diamond River
description: Anyone who writes for magazines on all manner of topics with regular, predictable brilliance, as Edward Hoagland does, invents a personality, a talisman of a hero who says, I walked, I saw, with a comeliness unknown to most pedestrians. This I is usually up to everything he may encounter in this dizzyingly overabundant world.

title: Fifteen thousand hours on the alto sax
description: The most successful composers betweenwars were New York City boys like Aaron Copland and George Gershwin, and Roy E. Harris of Utah, who applied symphonic methods to jazz and translated this folk art into music.

title: ALL HANDS ON DECK!
description: The question is an innocent one: I just bought a brand new boat. Now what do I do? It's not a dumb question, either, for everyone should ask himself something like that at the beginning of a new boating season even if the boat isn't new. And this year it is an especially good question.

title: 750 Selected Policemen Will Get Shotguns Under Compromise Reached by Department and P.B.A.
description: Shotguns will be made available to 750 specially trained patrolmen who are assigned to drive radio cars for sergeants and lieutenants to help combat ambush attacks.

title: A Summer Home Produces PAINPeople Arriving In Numbers
description: There is one aspect to owning a summer home that is rarely discussed at all, and when it is mentioned always gets more than its share of discretion. This is the phenomenon that I have come to think of as the Pain syndromePeople arriving in numbers.

title: English Is Steadily Overtaking French in Lebanon as the Second Language
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 24 It is easy to see in Lebanon's capital that English is overtaking French as the second language in this predominantly Arabicspeaking country.

title: BUREAU OF MINES FACES FUND DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, March 24A dispute over the acceptance of corporate favors by the Government's top mine safety enforcer, Donald P. Schlick, is threatening Congressional approval of the $137million budget, request of the Bureau of Mines, a Senate aide said today.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE mood of the country seems to be speeding back toward the discouragement that prevailed in the summer of 1971, before the Nixon Administration finally capitulated to widespread demands for an economiccontrols program.

title: Looking for April
description: Now is the time to look, listen, smell and feel, if you would know what time of year it is. The calendar can give you only an approximation, something by which remember birthdays and anniversaries and Internal Revenue deadlines.

title: A Good, Tuneful Time With 'Tom': Tom Sawyer'
description: MARK TWAIN once described "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer" as "simply a hymn, put into prose form to give it a worldly air." The new musical version, adapted by Robert B. and Richard M. Sherman, who also wrote the score together, may be just a little too worldly for some people. About half of the songs supplied by the Sherman brothers mightwith different lyrics and orchestrationshave turned up in any number of other, considerably inferior Sherman musicals from "Mary Poppins" to "Charlotte's Web." The small, ageless boy who plays TomJohnny Whitakeris a TV veteran, as well as a Disney graduate, and it shows. He looks right, but he has a practically Merman-like drive to please and the mannerisms of someone trying to time his actions to match a canned laughtrack.Yet with all of the worldliness of this "Tom Sawyer," there remains the memory of a perfect innocence that is very much the sense of Twain's "The Adventures of Tom "Sawyer." It's a memory prompted more by longing than by fact, and it's very much a part of the Hollywood movie tradition from which "Tom Sawyer" is derived. Carry that tradition back far enough and you'll run into the earliest Our Gang comedies, which were never about the way childhood ever was, but the way Mack Sennett and his gang knew that it should have been.Most of the movies that have come out of this tradition, and most of the child actors who became stars in them, have been awful. It is to the credit of the Sherman brothers and Don Taylor, who directed "Tom Saywer," that they've made a film that manages to evoke the fears, joys, triumphs and disasters of childhood within a tradition that usually deals in forced anthropomorphosis, insisting that children act like small-scale humans with hormone deficiencies.There have been few intelligent American films about childhoodcertainly nothing on the order of Vigo's "Zero de Conduit" or Truffaut's "The 400 Blows" or even Reed's "The Fallen Idol," and there have been few performances by children in American films to match those in any number of European films. Offhand, I can think of only Richie Andrusco in Morris Engel's "Little Fugitive" and isolated moments of Margaret O'Brien in Vincente Minnelli's "Meet Me in St. Louis." It's not that European children are naturally better actors, nor that European directors are better at directing children. Rather it has to do with the fantasy-feeding function (then as well as now) of American films aimed at mass audiences, as opposed to the more idiosyncratic aims of the better European directors, who probably sent their children to see American films on Saturday afternoons.Twain's "Tom Sawyer," as marvelous as it is, is essentially Saturday afteroon fiction, at least compared to "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," which was published in 1884, eight light-years after the appearance of "Tom Sawyer." The two novels share authorship and character names, but fundamentally they have little else in common. "Tom Sawyer" is a timeless lark in a Hannibal, Missouri, remembered as Eden but called St. Petersburg. Tom is, at heart, a rather impossible little superman masquerading as a normal boy who plays hookey, beats up boys who wear clean clothes, tells small lies at his own convenience, worships women as creatures from another planet, captures villains and, generally, goes from triumph to triumph, improving a world that isn't so terrible to start with.The Huck Finn of the later novel is someone who barely survives, and the novel itself is an adventure in a world of greed, hunger, violence and arbitrary cruelty, in which even the buffoonery is never as innocent as it seems. To enjoy what the Shermans and Mr. Taylor have accomplished in "Tom Sawyer" is to remember that they weren't making "Huckleberry Finn," but a kind of pageant glorifying an idealized time (boyhood) and place (the American Middle West in the first half of the 19th century). This they do with such immense verve and great high spirits that they effectively transform a tradition without ever breaking with it.The look of the production has a lot to do with the film's success. Mr. Taylor shot the film entirely on location in Missouri, mostly in and around the village of Arrow Rock, which serves as Hannibal, and on the Missouri River, which doubles nicely as the Mississippi. Everything is a little bigger, brighter, more colorful than life, but that's the way a pageant should be. Houses are roomy and spotless (the only shabby thing is the fence Tom must whitewash). Trees are perfect for climbing and the weather remains ideal. It is such a lovely spot that it doesn't seem at all odd that people might express themselves in song, nor that the big holiday picnicwhich precedes the cave confrontation of Injun Joe with Tom and Becky Thatchershould turn into a huge, exuberant production number. By golly, it really would have been good to be alive then!With the exception of Joshua Hill Lewis, who plays Tom's tattle-tale Cousin Sid with a very funny, pudgy sort of pushiness, all of the younger actors give standard though never horrid performances. The old folk, however, are fine, including Celeste Holm as Aunt Polly, Warren Oates as Muff Potter, and Lucille Benson as the Widow Douglas, the foolish lady whose mission in life becomes the reformation of Huck Finn.Although the Shermans' screenplay eliminates most of Twain's philosophizing about Tom's not-too-deeply hidden virtues, it retains the identify of Injun Joe, played by Kunu Hank, as "that murderin' half-breed."Twain was full of all kinds of prejudices that today would be insupportable, but Injun Joe, the outcast, is not one of them. He is a man with an evil heart, and that's all there is to it, though the film does make a case for how he got that way. Mostly, the people in the film are exactly the way they are because God made them so."Tom Sawyer" has little truck with psychological complexities and contradictions. It is as direct an expression of faith as "Rock of Ages," which the Hannibal citizensin one of the film's best momentssing at Tom and Huck's funeral with a little more gusto than the apparent grief of the occasion should properly allow.

title: BRONZE HILL, 501, VICTOR IN SWEEPS
description: DONCASTER, England, March 24 (AP)Bronze Hill, 501 shot who had to survive draw to get into the race, won the Lincoln Handicap today at Doncaster.

title: Sharyn Smith Will Be Bride
description: State Supreme Court Justice Francis X. Smith, a former president of the City Council, and Mrs. Smith of Flushing, Queens, and Oyster Bay, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sharyn Anne Smith, to Lawrence Chapman Tondel, an associate in the New York law firm of Brown, Wood, Fuller, Caldwell & Ivey.

title: If at First ...
description: It took some doing, but Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, the Nobel Prizewinning novelist; is finally free to marry the woman with whom he's been living for three years. It's the latest turn in a long, twisting matrimonial road for the 55yearold writer. In 1945, he married Natalya Reshetovskaya, but when he was sent to prison camp, they were divorced by mutual consentwhich is permitted in the Soviet Union. Miss Reshetovskaya married another man, but divorced him and remarried Mr. Solzhenitsyn after he was freed in 1956. Fourteen years later the author wanted out again, but this time his wife resisted. So he went to court. No luck, despite numerous appeals. Last week, however, friends of the author reported that his wife had given in to his pleas and that the couple had obtained their second divorce by mutual consent. Now Mr. Solzhenitsyn can marry Natalya Svetlovawho has borne him two sons.

title: Stability in Superconductivity Hinted in Crystals Discovery
description: A property of certain metals and allays whereby, at extremely low temperature, they lose all resistance to electricity has been found to occur, in a fluctuating manner, in organic crystals at temperatures three times higher than those required for such superconduction in the alloys.

title: Friday's Fights
description: Geneva  Roger Menetarey, Trance, nutpointed Arthur Kettles, Philadelphia, 10 rounds, heavyweights.

title: LAWYERS OF POOR SCORED IN REPORT
description: William J. vanden Heuvel chairman of the New York Board of Correction, made pubIic last week a report analyzing what the board contends are the shortcomings of the courtappointed lawyers here am detailing the obstacles that impede the Legal Aid Society from adequately representing indigent defendants.

title: Women's Lib? Mexican Town Knows It Well
description: TEHUANTEPEC, MexicoYes, our women know about that women's liberation business in the United States. But they are not very much interested in it. You see, they were liberated long before American women thought up the idea.

title: A Job fora Clown
description: One perplexing episode in the running conflict between the Nixon Administration and the media has centered on Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent Daniel Schorr.. A frequent critic of Administration policies, Mr. Schorr last year discovered that he was being investigated by the F.B.I. Officials said it had been initiated because Mr. Schorr was being considered for a Government job, supposedly in connection with the environment.

title: Seeking a basis for more productive schools
description: Disenchantment  measured, documented, uncynical  is the work of these two useful books. Together they cast a cold eye on the two major enthusiasms in American education today. Solidly rooted in personal experience andinformed by broad research, they produce the singular excitement of reading some truth about a subject usually distorted by geewhiz journalism or obfuscating professional jargon. The authors seek a more solid basis for our hope to make schools more decent and productive.

title: K.G.B. IS REPORTED TO SEE SAKHAROY
description: MOSCOW, March 24  For the first time the Soviet secret police have called in Andrei D. Sakharov, the nuclear physicist and humanrights campaigner, and criticized him for his rights activities, unofficial sources disclosed today.

title: Two Doctors Here Known to Users as Sources of Amphetamines
description: Two New York area physicians, Dr. Robert Freymann and Dr. John M. Bishop, have become widely known among users of amphetamines as regular sources of the powerful stimulant.

title: Miss Steiner Bride of Robert Jackson
description: Miss K. Julianne Steiner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sebastian Steiner of Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Rawlings Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Jackson of Arlington, N.J.

title: 2 SOUGHT IN SLAYING CAUGHT IN CAB THEFT
description: Two men being sought in the fatal shooting of a Brooklyn bar patron were caught early yesterday morning when they attempted to steal a taxicab from an offduty policeman and an offduay fireman, the police said.

title: Is This Tiger Dangerous?
description: SAVE the Tiger is the kind of preachy, pessimistic social drama that used to be considered boxoffice poison, and almost every studio had turned it down before Paramount decided to gamble on the script. The gamble has paid off; Save the Tiger looks like one of the first commercial successes of 1973. Audiences seem to sit still for the soulsearching speeches, and it would be pleasant to report that this film's success represents a new maturity in the moviegoing public. In truth, the movie is as muddled and chickenhearted as most Hollywood problem pictures. Then why has it caught on? What accounts for its mass appeal?

title: Lisa Wairath Daniel R. Fast Are Betrothed
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 24Miss Lisa Ann Wairath, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Walrath of Greenwich, and Daniel Raymond Fast, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Fast of Fostoria, Ohio, plan to be married on June 9 in the First United Methodist Church.

title: Stahr Aims to Upgrade Quality of Net Officials
description: A new deal is in sight for tennis umpires and linesmen, those oftenmaligned servants of the game, with the appointment of Jack Stahr as chairman of the United States Lawn Tennis Association's umpire committee.

title: All New Brunswick Is a School for 55 OnceFrustrated Youths
description: NEW BRUNSWICK A commitment by Rutgers University and the city's Board of Education gave New Brunswick its first openclassroom school this month.The new facility, Gibbons School, where 55 former New Brunswick High School students are enrolled, is housed in a yellow wooden building on the Douglass College campus.

title: Prisoner Scheduled For Psychosurgery Ruled Illegally Held
description: DETROIT, March 24 (UPI)A threejudge county court panel ruled yesterday that a man committed to a state mental hospital 18 years ago on rape and murder charges was being held unconstitutionally under a special criminal psychopath law.

title: Forgetting Elena
description: Was it Wilkie Collins who wrote the first detective novel? I'm inclined to think detective fiction may be older, the oldest vehicle for the novel, the necessary form. Who exactly is Tom Jones; what is Mr. Rochester's secret; what sort of fellow can this Osmond be? These are mysteries to be solved, and their solutions, chapter by chapter, generate novels. It is the reader who plays private investigator throughout  as in fact he does in the standard detective novel  sifting through the author's clues and relishing the evidence. As he grows more wily, his first question, What

title: Easy Upkeep Shrubs
description: SHRUBS that take care of themselves are especially valuable if they also contribute summer beauty.

title: Abdication of Edward VIII Preserved a Coin Tradition
description: LONDON March 24 (AP) The abdication of Edward VIII not only preserved British traditions of royal marriage. It also preserved an orderly alteration of royal profiles on British coins, the Royal Mint disclosed this week.

title: Giants Drub Angels 144, as Four Are Ejected After Two Brawls in Fourth
MADISON AVE.
description: William Burnett Benton, Yale '21, worked a year for the National Cash Register Company and was then told by his strongwilled mother  a school teacher  to enroll in the Harvard Law School. But for the first time in his young life, he defied her by entering instead the world of advertising.

title: Mary Ann Tomeo Wed
description: DIX HILLS, L. I., March 24Miss Mary Ann Tomeo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Tomeo of East Northport, was married here this afternoon to Richard DiLoreto Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. DiLoreto of Locust Valley. The Rev. James J. Hannon performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church.

title: D.F. Judah Weds Joanne P. DuBois
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., March 24  In the Chevy Chase Presbyterian Church this afternoon, Miss Joanne Pederson DuBois, daughter of Mrs. Armand B. DuBois, was married to Douglas Fraser Judah, son of Mr. and Mrs. Park W. Judah of Ridgewood, N. J.

title: Hebrew School Gives Hope to Disabled
description: The new 20footlong mural at the Hebrew Academy for Special Children depicts the faces of children who for one reason or another cannot do what other children do.

title: BRUCE ELLIOTT, MYSTERY WRITER
description: Bruce Elliott, an author and magazine editor, died Wednesday in St. Vincent's Hospital of injuries received in an automobile accident. He was 58 years old, and lived at 79 Barrow Street.

title: Models of New Bus Will Tour Nation to Test Public Reaction
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The first radical new bus design since 1959 is in the scalemodel stage, and three versions are ready for a nationwide tour in May to test public reaction.

title: Illegal Aliens
description: At 8 o'clock one crisp morning last week, a dozen Federal agents raided a seedy hotel in the Jackson Heights section of Queens and demanded identification papers from 15 occupants. The guestsfrom Colombia, Argentina, Jamaica and Ecuadorcould produce no valid documents. They were arrested; nearly all will eventually be deported.

title: U.S. Freeze Curbs Rehabilitation Plan
description: The efforts of some banks in the city to salvage their mortgages on financially troubled apartment buildings through rehabilitation and resale have been undercut by the Federal moratorium on housing subsidies.

title: Two Agencies Define Roles In Handling Nuclear Material
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)  The Department of Transportation and the Atomic Energy Commission gave the details of their roles in the transporation of radioactive materials in a memorandum of understanding signed this week.

title: Feminist Paper for Women Is a Success
description: DOVERA quarterly newspaper staffed entirely by women volunteers is helping to raise the consciousness levels of both sexei Called New Directions for Women in New Jersey, it is said to be the country's first statewide feminist newspaper.

title: Despite Misgivings, Offices Go Up in Greenwich
description: GREENWICH, Conn.This affluent community has abandoned its notrespassing attitude toward corporate invaders, and the pace of office construction in its central business district has quickened over the last year.

title: Professor Asserts U. of Penn Ouster Is a Political Move
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 24An assistant philosophy professor at the University of Pennsylvania says that a recent university decision to dismiss him was a result of his political activities at the school over the last three years.

title: China Studies Mystery of Acupuncture
description: Scientists in China are conducting vigorous research to determine why acupuncture anesthesia apparently works in many surgical cases.

title: Toledo Vote on Amendment Blocks Convention Center
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, March 24Plans for a proposed convention center in this city on Lake Erie suffered a severe setback as the result of Tuesday's special election on a charter amendment that put a $7.5million limit on the city council's spending authority for capital improvements.

title: How Long Must A Pizza Waiter Wait? Very Long
description: HOLLYWOOD. THE name can not be real. That's what Hollywood said a year ago when you asked about Frederic Forrest. That, and who?

title: A Yen for Protection
description: FUCHU, JapanThe giddy rise in value of the Japanese yen at the expense of the American dollat is bound to diminish the size of the umbrella the United States extends over this country under their mutual security treaty.

title: Women's Preliminaries Start Today in Tennis
description: The Three preliminary rounds for the Lady Gotham Classic tennis tournament will be playing starting today at the Port Washington (L.I.) Tennis Academy. The $30,000 event, part of the United States Lawn Tennis Association's women's prize money circuit, is scheduled for The Felt Forum March 28 through April 1.

title: Towns Fighting Fuel Lines and Tanks
description: Municipalities throughout New Jersey are voicing strong opposition to the construction of petrochemical facilitiesor at least insisting on careful safeguards for their communitiesas the result of the gas storagetank explosion on Staten Island last month that killed 40 men.

title: 2 RABBIS ASSAIL QUOTA SYSTEM
description: Two leaders of American Orthodox Judaism have assailed what they call a quota system for employment, charging it results in a new polarization jeopardizing the economic and political status of Jews and white middleclass people generally.

title: Travel Notes: On Foreign Visitors
description: THERE'S no question, says Charles Gillett, executive vice president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, that we have had shortcomings in serving foreignlanguage visitors. But the service will improve as the need for it increases.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The current debate over the direction of United States trade policy has provoked strong statements from the various sides.

title: The Kurosawas and Godards of Tomorrow?
description: TAKAHIRO TAMURA, as a man returning to the land of his childhood, clutches his mother's skull in Toichiro Narushima's Time Within Memory. The Japanese film, to be shown at the Museum of Modern Art next Sunday and on Monday, April 2, is part of the New Directors/New Films series of 9 programs sponsored by the museum and the Film Society of Lincoln Center. The series; highly praised last year for introducing provocative new works to American moviegoers, will get under way Friday with Kodou, a Senegalese film, and Helen, Queen of the Nautch, Girls, a 30minute feature from India. The closing attraction  on April 9 and 10,  will be Czechoslovakia's The Cremator, a black comedy about Nazism.

title: No Amenities at Fire Island School
description: OCEAN BEACH, L. I.The playground is a sand lot, the gym is stored in a wall, the cafeteria is a hallway and the boiler room is where the principal holds his conferences.

title: Bid Minh Says 3d Force is Main Hope for Peace
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 24Gen. Duong Van Minh said today that only third force could guarantee the spirit of reconcilation and concord called for by the Paris ceasefire agreements.

title: A Motel Suite That Rents for $1 a Minute
description: GAITHERSBURG, Md.  Late one stormy night last fall two weary professors from the Newark College of Engineering in New Jersey pulled into the packed parking lot of the Holiday Inn here with a busload of graduate students. The professors, John Mihalasky and Richard M. Jacobs, dashed inside through freezing, pelting rain to claim the group's reservations. The desk clerk had difficulty finding enough rooms for the 15 students, and once the students were taken care of the professors found themselves being escorted upstairs personally by the assistant manageror, as the Holiday Inn chain calls him, the assistant innkeeper. Surely they were on their way to some broom closet, the professors thought, and the management man was along to try to override their objections. But when the key turned in the door of their accommodations, the professors stepped into the plushest, most expensive motel suite in the entire United States: the eighth  floor Presidential Suite that normally rents for $1,400that's right, $1,400a night.

title: Seesaw  A Dove Of a Show
description: IN what may be the nuttiestand maybe just plain funniestnumber I have ever seen in a musical, dancer Tommy Tune of Seesaw uses his supple heron's legs to summon on stage a chorus in blue top hats and a vast mantle of balloons, spins them about stage in a crackthewhip exuberance that makes them seem lighter than their lighterthanair clothing, climbs a staircase made of balloons beneath a chandelier made of balloons, and, in his irrepressible idiocy, keeps calling for ever bigger and bigger finishes. The finishes finally get so big that the floor seems kneedeep confetti, whereupon Mr. Tune is handed a broom from the wings and ordered to clean the whole thing up. He is still very happy as he sweeps that last litter, and the last lone dancer, away.

title: Some Frank Talk On the Rol of Earthkeeping
description: ANYONE starting this spring for the first time on the delightful project of gardening should go outdoors and sit quietly in an open, natural place and just think about what As there. A garden can be much more than our inherited view of it as a squared, walled place just for plants.

title: Major Power Events of 1973
description: March

title: L.I. Medical School Names Dr. Fritts As Its Chairman
description: Dr. Harry W. Fritts has been appointed chairman of the department of medicine at the medical school of the State University at Stony Brook.

title: Architecture: Washington Never Slept Here
description: MINE is a generation caught between the automobile and the air age; we are the survivors of the last luxury trains and transAtlantic liners. We have experienced revolution and, certainly, history. And so perhaps I attach more cosmic significance to a recent news item that the Ford River Rouge plant is headed for closing and demolition than those who never knew about its unparalleled impact on industry, labor, the construction art and 20thcentury life style.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Loral Corporation, a manufacturer of electronic systems and plastic packaging, has returned its headquarters to Manhattan after a sixyear stay in Scarsdale.

title: Home for Elderly Planned
description: A fundraising campaign is under way to finance the construction of this $7million building in Totowa, N.J. The facility, St. Joseph's Home for the Elderly, will contain 250 beds, a recreation deck, a chapel and an auditorium. The home will be operated by the Little Sisters of the Poor, a Roman Catholic order. The structure is to be built by the J. R. Stevenson Corporation of Hempstead, L.I. The building, on a sevenacre site bounded by Cumberland Avenue, Feliner Place and Shepherd's. Lane, will replace two outdated facilitiesSt. Theresa's Home for the Aged in Paterson and the St. Rose of Lima Home for the Aged in Newark.

title: COMMUNISTS MAKE NEW P.O.W DEMAND
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, March 25A new attempt to break the deadlock over the release of the last American prisoners of war yesterday succeeded only in producing new Communist demands.

title: Education
description: Library people traditionally have kept a low profile. But now we're alarmed and we feel compelled to speak out.

title: Gossip about moments of acute embarrassment
description: Sophy Burnham's book alleges widespread corruption and fraud in the New York art world in a highly emotional tract that nonetheless raises some pertinent and disturb ing public issues  as the increasingly savage controversy over the Metropolitan Museum's deaccessioning policies confirms. It seems that the radical critique of the Establishment has caught up with the art world, and with a vengeance.

title: Susan Dietz Bride Of J. G. Milmoe Jr.
description: Miss Susan Deitz and J. Gregory Milmoe Jr. son of Mr. and Mrs. Miimoe of White Plains, were married here yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Deitz.

title: Guard and Reserve Help Communities
description: TEANECK  When Paul DeGise, an insurance man who lives in Wyckoff, prepares for weekly attendance at the National Guard Armory he dresses in sports clothes and hangs a referee's whistle around his neck.

title: WAGNER ASSURED OF G.O.P. SUPPORT IN MAYORAL RACE
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner was assured of the Republican designation for his old office, which he held three terms as a Democrat, when the Queens and Bronx G.O.P. organizations backed him yesterday by wide margins.

title: Queens Housewives Fill $1,000 Gap in Park Plan
description: A campaign to get $1,000 for a key project in the development of Yellowstone Park in Forest Hills, Queens, was completed last week through the efforts of 20 housewives and mothers.

title: Battista Hat in New Ring
description: ALBANYVito P. Battista took a deep puff on his everpresent huge cigar, blew out a stream of smoke, hunched over his desk and said: Here I am, up here five years voting for their lousy bills. I'm simply being used up here. I want to get the hell out of here.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: Cost of Money
description: WASHINGTONA group of seven large banks last Monday raised the prime interest rate they charge their most creditworthy business customers precipitating a clash with the Government and, in particular, with Arthur F. Burns, Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.As the week ended, the prime rate situation was confused and unsettledsome banks had made reductions as a result of Government pressure, while others had refused. But what was clear was that the Government's role in trying to guide interest rates in Phase continued to be ambivalent. And the ambivalence had importance not only at home; it might also effect the position of the newly floating dollar abroad.

title: Via Front Door or Back, a New Audience for Oriental Art
description: NOT YET having had a chance to visit mainland China, either before or after the revolution, I can't say whether or not the Chinese are as interested in Chinese art by which I mean the art of old Chinaas New Yorkers are. But there are currently two Chinese exhibitions in town, Ceramics in the Liao Dynasty at the China Institute, 125 East 65th Street, and Chu Ta: Selected Paintings and Calligraphy, at the New York Cultural Center on Columbus Circle, that I suspect will find at least as appreciative an audience here as they would at home. The first, which consists of 60 ancient pots, bottles, dishes, and other vessels, demands a response to pure form as the sculptural aspect of useful objects, which 20th  century Americans have reached through the back door of abstract sculpture. Abstract painting bears a similar relationship to the second, which has to do with a mid17thcentury artist who may or may not have been a madman, but at least put on a pretty good act as an eccentric.

title: A LoveHate Story
description: When a man boards his boat, he looks forward to matching his skill and strength against the sea. But, unless he is the rare sailor who takes an entirely monastic view of life, he will also have a female to contend with, be she wife or girlfriend.

title: COURT DELAY CUT IN NASSAU COUNTY
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 24Despite substantial increases most types of litigation, the courts in Nassau County hay been able to decrease the cal endar delays, Justice Thomas Farley, administrative judge Nassau County, said this weel on releasing his 1972 report a the work of the courts.

title: SLOWDOWN FOUND IN PAY INCREASES
description: Pay increases slowed down last year in key professional, administrative and technical occupations to average 5.5 per cent in New York State and 6.7 per cent in New York City, the regional Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics has reported.

title: Lindsay Signs Bill Limiting Big Tanks For Storage of Gas
description: Mayor Lindsay signed a bill into law yesterday that prohibits the construction of liquefied  natural  gas storage tanks the size of the one that exploded on Staten Island last month, killing 40 workmen.

title: DAVID GOLUB
description: David Golub, a former vice president in the creditclearing department of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., and a former director of the Petrie Stores Corporation, died Friday in Hallandale, Fla., where he had made his home since his retirement two years ago. He was 78 years old and formerly lived in the Bronx.

title: Miss Westlund Plans to Wed
description: WEST HAVEN, Conn., March 24Mr. and Mrs. Earl Emanuel Westlund of West Haven have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shelley Ann Westlund, to Ralph Wallace Wolffe. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Burns Wolffe of Higganum.

title: Connecticut College, Now Coed, Debates Whether Men Are Taking over
description: NEW LONDON, Conn. There is an argument among students here that in the four years since Connecticut Collage began admitting male undergraduates, the men have been quietly taking over powerful positions of leadership on campus and dominating the class rooms.

title: FUCHSBERG GRANTED PETITIONS HEARING
description: Jacob D. Fuchsberg, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for chief judge of the State Court of Appeals, has won a hearing next Wednesday in Federal District Court on his request for an extension in the period to gather nominating petitions for the June 4 primary.

title: Outboard Marine Starts a Kind of Rotary Club
description: It's smoother and simpler and quieter. It's faster and more powerful. It's the first Americanbuilt outboard motor powered by rotary combustion, and, its creators say, it's the most powerful outboard ever built.

title: Dance: Merce Cunningham and Four of His Events
description: When is a performance not a performance? When it is an event? Well, in any case, Merce Cunningham and his Dance Company are calling their current series of performances Event No. 65, Event No. 66, Event No. 67 and Event No. 68. It appears that the company started calling some performances events in 1964, and these present four are 65, 66, 67 and 68 in chronological sequence.

title: What the boundary between fiction and journalism feels like
description: All along the scale from Moby Dick to the Bugs Bunny factory, American imaginations have worked for more than a century at the Republic's craft, the arraying of particulars. No ideas but in things, said William Carlos Williams, sensing that, like the view through a scanning electron microscope, our very sense of reality was growing ever more particulate. The corresponding artform is the purposeful miscellany, like the list of names Fitzgerald put into The Great Gatsby, allegedly copied from notes on an old timetable.

title: INDIANA RETAINS SWIMMING TITLE
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 24 (AP)Gary Hall of Indiana captured the 200yard butterfly and three of his teammates placed in the event tonight as the mighty Hoosiers clinched their sixth consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming and diving championship.

title: Hog Quarantines Lifted
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)  Federal quarantines for the control of hog cholera have been eliminated in all areas of the United States, only the second time for total cancellation since the restrictions became a part of the Federalstate disease program in 1969, the Agriculture Department says.

title: Upper Michigan Hopes to Be Site of Project Sanguine
description: HOUGHTON, Mich., March 24  Project Sanguine, the Navy's proposed facility fof emergency radio communication with its nuclear submarine fleet, may eventually settle, in part or totally, in Michigan's Upper Peninsula.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONIn an abrupt explosive move, a principal Watergate figure last week announced that he was ready to talk about hitherto hidden details of the caseand that he had a good deal to say about such matters as perjury and political pressure. The implications for the Government and the Nixon Administration ap. peared dangerous.

title: The Kertuffel family of Poop's Peak
description: Where does the Kertuffel family live?

title: SALLY STARK SINGS AT SOERABAJA CLUB
description: Before Sally Stark joined the cast of the daily TV soap opera Love of Life two and a half years ago, she was one of the sparkling elements in that OffBroadway, spoof of nineteenthirties film musicals, Dames At Sea. The bright jauntiness of her delivery of that show's parody songs and the strong vocal qualities she showed then give a tremendous lift to her current venture into supperclub singing at the Soerabaja, Lexington Avenue at 74th Street.

title: Television
description: CLAY T. WHITEHEAD is the director of the Office of Telecommunications Policy. While Whitehead has attracted a generous share of attention in the past couple of years, the OTP remains, curiously enough, in the publicity shadows. What is it? Why was it created? What is its relationship to the Federal Communications Commission?

title: And Why No Avard for...?
description: Memo to the producers of the Tony Awards Show:

title: British Jobless Rate Down
description: LONDON, March 24 (UPI)Unemployment in Britain dropped to the lowest level in more than two years this month. The Department of Employment said that the jobless total fell by 35,624 from February to March to a total of 717,669, or 3.1 per cent of the population.

title: Booth Newspapers Gains Parade Publications, Inc
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 24 (UPI)Booth Newspapers Inc. has completed the acquisition of Parade Publications Inc. for 902,128 shares of common stock.

title: U.S. and Russia
description: MOSCOWIt was the third act of the drama, and it opened predictably enough.

title: BOO JUDGED BEST AT BRONX EVENT
description: Of the 116 breeds in the American Kennel Club stud book last year, only 41 otter hounds were registered, putting it No. 110 on the list.

title: Brooklyn Fire Salvage Corps Gives Members OnJob Civil Service Training
description: The alarm came over the radio in the Brooklyn headquarters of Fire Salvage Corps No. 1, and within minutes the unit's bright red vehicle was speeding down Eastern Parkway to a tenement fire on the edge of the BedfordStuyvesant section.

title: ExGovernor's Son Seized
description: BRUNSWICK, Ga., March 24 (UPI)  Carl Edward Sanders Jr., 19 years old, the son of former Gov. Carl Sanders, was arrested early today and charged with possession of marijuana. Mr. Sanders, who listed his employer as the the Village Apartments in Athens and his home address as Atlanta, was released on bond totaling more than $1,000.

title: T.W. Buek to Wed Jeri Whittington
description: CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ind., March 24  Miss Jeri Jo Whittington and Thomas Welles Buek plan to be married in May. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Whittington, parents of the future bride, whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Buek of Darien, Conn.

title: One Boat Show That Never Ends
description: The long wait for that annual boat show has been virtually eliminated by an enterprising Long Island boat dealer, who has established a yearround mariner's mart with a complete stock of the latest model boats ranging from small outboards to fullscale cabin cruisers.

title: Mr. Gray Confirms The Doubts
description: From the day he was nominated to be the permanent director of the F.B.I., there have been two fundamental objections to L. Patrick Gray 3d. Eight days of testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee have only confirmed those doubts.

title: New &Novel
description: We'll have to do something about science, the President said. It's getting out of hand. By the time the Chief Executive reaches this conclusion, the technological depravity implicit in our civilization is one step from the ultimate paradox: annihilation through enlightenment. Nothis is not another doomsday novel founded on pop science. Rather, it is a metaphysical mindstretcher examining the future of materialism.

title: McCord Expected by His Lawyer to Tell Judge Sirica Everything He Knows
description: WASHINGTON, March 24An attorney for James W. McCord Jr. said today he expected the convicted Watergate conspirator to tell a Federal judge everything he knows about the politically sensitive case.

title: Miss Deutsch Fiancee Of Steven Zimmerman
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. 1. March 24Dr. and Mrs. Henry J. Deutsch have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Robin Linda Deutsch, to Steven Elliot Zimmerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Zimmerman of Hewlett.

title: Eileen Foley Plans Wedding on Aug. 11
description: QUOGUE, L.I., March 24Miss Eileen Margaret Foley plans to be married here Aug. 11 to Walter James Sciamonte, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Sciamonte of St. Catherines, Ontario. Their engagement has been announced by Mrs. John M. Foley, mother of the future bride.

title: School Taxes
description: WASHINGTON  The question before the Supreme Court last week: Is a school financing system based in part on property taxes unconstitutional? The Court's answer: No.

title: State and Local Tax Return
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)State and local government increased their tax take in 1972 by 14 per cent, or nearly $14billion, the Commerce Department has reported. Property taxes, at $44billion, took the biggest slice of the local taxpayer's dollar last year but individual and corporate income taxes increased at the fastest rate. Over all, state and local governments collected $114.6billion in taxes in 1972, compared with $100.7billion in 1971.

title: T. A. Feinstein Fiance of Wendy Honig
description: WORCESTER, Mass., March 24Mr. and Mrs. John Honig have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Elizabeth Honig, to Theodore Albert Feinstein. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Feinstein of Cheltenham, Pa.

title: Hospital Reoffers Alcoholism Clinic
description: MONTCLAIR  Mountainside Hospital will repeat this week an Alcoholism Detection Clinic that it instituted last May as a highlight of its ongoing program to aid alcoholics.

title: 2 Churches in Italy Looted Of 16thCentury Paintings
description: ROME, March 24Two 16thcentury paintings were stolen from two parish churches in northeastern Italy last night.

title: Hatchery Predicts a Bumper '73 Crop for State's Anglers
description: HACKETTSTOWN  When New Jersey's troutfishing season opens on April 7, the state's 190,000 licensed anglers are likely to be hauling in many species produced at the Charles O. Hayford State Fish Hatchery.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article On Land Once Toscanini's, Disharmony Is Heard [March 4] described the consternation of many of the affluent owners of nearby homes over the construction of the SalanterAkibaRiverdale Academy.

title: PATRICK, BROWN WIN HORSE SHOW EVENTS
description: NORTH SALEM, N. Y., March 24Mike Patrick of Glastonbury, Conn., and Buddy Brown of South Salem, N. Y., two of the leading younger riders, shared honors today at the opening session of the twoday The Hill Horse Show. All junior events were run today.

title: 1,000 Labor Leaders Going to London for 5Day Conference
description: More than 1,000 labor leaders and trustees of union pension and welfare funds are flying to London this weekend for a fiveday conference about pensions and the delivery of health services.

title: Miss O'Neill Flans Bridal
description: RYE, N. Y., March 24Mr. and Mrs. James Day O'Neill have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Ann Louise O'Neill, to Robert Anthony Mulderrig Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mulderrig of Mamaroneck. The couple plan to marry here Oct. 6 in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: Israeli Pupils Given More Favorable View of Jesus
description: TEL AVIV, March 24Israeli teenagers are getting a more favorable picture of Jesus in historystudies.

title: 1930's Boeings End Regular Asia Nuns
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 24A species or airliner regarded by aviation historians as one of the most elegant and advanced ever built seems to be facing final extinction as the Indochina war sputters to an end.

title: Blast Cause Described
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, March 24 (UPI)The State Department of Public Safety said this week an accidental gas explosion was responsible for a Feb. 2 blast in Eagle Grove that took 13 lives. But the cause of the explosion Is not known.

title: What's at the Movies?
