description: THE THIEF WHO CAME TO DINNER, directed by Bud Yorkin from a screenplay by Walter Hill and starring Ryan O'Neal and Jacqueline Bisset, got 3 favorable reviews (Vincent Canby, Times; Archer Winsten, Post; Joseph Gelmis, Newsday), 6 mixed (Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Molly Haskell, Village Voice; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; Donald J. Mayerson, Cue; Arthur Knight, Saturday Review; Jay Cocks, Time) and 9 negative (Kathleen Carroll, News; Rex Reed, News; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Leonard Harris, WCBSTV; Gene Shalit, NBC; Charles Michener, Newsweek; Pauline Kael, New Yorker; Judith Crist, New York.

title: The Horseless Carriage Means Trouble
description: The invention of the automobile has introduced upon the public roads of the country a novel and not altogether welcome guest. Although barely ten years since it first made its appearance, it has already conquered an important position in the domain of travel. Indeed, its great power, speed and weight have made it a veritable king of the highway, before whom we are all invited to prostrate ourselves. Though admitted to the use of the roads, in common with other vehicles, certain restrictions have been found necessary to curb its masterful and dominating influence.

title: the traveler's world
description: MIAMIForty miles due west of here on the Tamiami Trail (U.S. 41), Everglades National Park's northern boundary butts up against the highway for about eight miles, and in just about the middle of this stretch there is a sign indicating the Shark Valley entrance to the park. It is a modest sign, and thousands of motorists race by it every day without noticing its invitation to the tramway tour seven miles deep into the park. The kiss is theirs; to the 200 tourists who do stop daily to visit Shark Valley's observation tower on the guided twohour nature tour, this is as exciting a bit of Sightseeing as the nature lover will find in all of Florida.

title: Miss Pistrang Plans Nuptials
description: HAWORTH. N. 3., March 24Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Pistrang have announced that their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Jane Pistrang, and David Drury Mullins will be married April 14. The future bridegroom is the son ot Mr. and Mrs. John M. Mullins of Demarest.

title: The Bestof82 Round Is Over
description: The popular observation that the real season of the National Basketball Association will begin only when the championship playoffs start Friday is truer this year than it has ever been.

title: Poor Automobile Fuel Economy Is Linked to Pollution Controls
description: DETROIT, March 24  The American motorist is beginning, to pay the price of the nation's effort to clean its air. And a good part of the price, ironically, is poor fuel economy hundreds of millions of galIons of extra gasoline are needed to power cars because of pollution controls, and at a time of national fuel shortage.

title: Tempering of A Steel Man
description: PITTSBURGH  Every morning when Richard P. Simmons walks into the office he occupies as president of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation a 15page computer report is on his desk.

title: Thieves' Market
description: Prices were risingafter all the New York Metropolitan Museum had reportedly paid $1million for an ancient vase, and bid $3.5million for a statue, both supposedly originating in Italyso the prospects for a quick cash killing were good. So good in fact that Italy's recurrent problem of art theft and smuggling got out of hand in recent days. Within 48 hours, Italian papers reported recovery by police of 68 ancient. Etruscan relics, stolen by grave robbers; the seizure by customs officers of eight valuable paintings, including one attributed to Raphael, which a French citizen was trying to smuggle out of Italy; and the theft from an isolated village church of a painting by Tiepolo valued at more than $1million.

title: Home Improvement
description: To help catch up on the backlog of unanswered questions, the entire Home Improvement column this week is again being devoted to Questions and Answers. Many of these pose questions that are similar to those asked by other readers whose actual letters may not be published here, but who, nevertheless, will find their answers below. Readers sending in questions about home repair problems should address them to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered on this page.

title: Van Alen and Dunn Capture Court Tennis Doubles Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 24The local team of James L. Van Alen 2d and Jimmy Dunn won the United States amateurprofessional handicap court ten is doubles championship today by defeating George Plimpton and Eddle Noll of New York, 65, 65, 36, 64, at the Racquet Club.

title: France's New Train Trackage Will Extend 125 M.P.H. Runs
description: A track rebuilding project now under way in France will permit passenger train speeds of 125 miles an hour over more than threequarters of the 360mile ParistoBordeaux run.

title: N.B.A. LineUps
description: AT SEATTLE

title: A sanctuary of male innocence
description: Like all of Horatio Alger's stories, this novel has a great deal of the marvelous about it. By one of those freak chances which give an Alger plot its air of wonder, Silas Snobden's Office Boy remained unpublished as a book during the author's lifetime, hidden as a serial in The Argosy, a boys' magazine of the eighties and nineties. Ralph Gardner, an Alger collector and biographer who has performed a rescue worthy of an Alger hero, explains in his preface that the story appeared under a pseudonym, Arthur Lee Putnam, thereby somehow getting lost in the shuffle from serial to book. And therein is the miracle, not Gardner's discovery of the mistake, but the mistake itself, like unearthing a case of Scotch in W. C. Fields's basement.

title: Sails: Where the Action Is
description: If some character in a waterfront bar says that he dropped the halfbra, no need to raise an eyebrow  even if he goes on to talk of topless and bikinis. He is probably more sailing nut than sex maniac.

title: MRS. C. L. LAWRANCE
description: Mrs. Margaret Dix Lawrance, author of Rosemary for Remembrance, an autobiography in verse, and a former trustee of the Museum of the City of New York, died yesterday at the age of 82.

title: Bridge
description: A number of heads of state, including the late President Eisenhower and several kings and queens of the threedimensional variety, have been bridge enthusiasts. Two of them have a major place in the legend and literature of the game. One was the Emir of Afghanistan, Amanullah II, who had to abdicate in 1929 because his Moslem subjects disapproved, among other things, of his playing cards, which showed the human form. The other was the Emperor BaoDai of Annam, who became the hero of the unique deal shown in the diagram.

title: Expanded Olympics Set Up for Disabled
description: TRENTON  Handicapped children will compete in special statesponsored Olympic games beginning next month.

title: Takes All Five Matches as Only Americans Gain Final Round at New York A.C.
description: Brooke Makler, the Penn senior who won the National Collegiate foil title last Saturday in Baltimore, captured the International Martini & Rossi pe event last night.

title: Carnesecca Returning To Coach at St. John's
description: Lou Carnesecc'a, general manager and coach of the New York Nets, is returning to coach St. John's basketball team, as was expected.

title: Idle Suffolk Factory to become a Business Park
description: BAY SHORE, L.I.  The plant that housed the Stratos division of the Fairchild Hiller Corporation is getting a new lease on life after having been idle for two years. The plant on Orinoco Drive here has been purchased by the Bay Shore Business Park Corporation, which plans to bring in a number of small businesses to lessen the impact of the loss of 500 jobs formerly provided by Stratos in the production of airconditioning equipment for aircraft.

title: Garrett Road, $13.20, Wins In Stretch at Fair Grounds
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 24 (AP)  Garrett Road stayed close to the lead during the early stages, then took over in the stretch run today to win the $20,000 Spring Fiesta Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

title: Canteen Hostesses Recall War Days
description: Someone once figured out that the volunteer hostesses at the American Theater Wing's Stage Door Canteen danced more than 10 million miles during World War II.

title: New School In Newark To Train Architects
description: NEWARK  Newark College of Engineering is getting down to the mechanics of preparing to open the first public School of Architecture in New Jersey.

title: BOSPORUS BRIDGE NEAR COMPLETION
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey March 24 When the last steel road section was welded into place yesterday, the major step in the first road link across the Bosporus since Darius's pontoon bridge in 500 B.C. was complete.

title: REPUTED MOB BOSS IS CITED IN HAWAII
description: HONOLULU, March 24Six alleged crime syndicate figures will be arraigned in United States District Court here Monday, including Wilford K. Pulawa, 37 years old, who is the reputed boss of the Hawaii underworld.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: (ALEX) GRONER: (THE HISTORY OF) AMERICAN BUSINESS (& INDUSTRY)  Generations of Yankee shipbuilders had learned how to desi n snip fast, clean lines, as well as maximum utilization of sail. The culmination of their art came in the fabled clipper ships,... a logical outgrowth of the packet era.

title: Auto Tax Is Urged for Houston Transit
description: HOUSTON, March 24 Mayor Louie Welch has proposed an exhaust emissions tests, based on engine displacement, to pay the local share of the city's proposed $145billion rapid transit system of elevated and subway trains and exclusive freeway lanes for buses.

title: Morenholz Helps Ox Ridge Beat Toronto in Polo, 1310
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 24Al Marenholz scored six goals to lead the Ox Ridge Hunt Club's polo team to a 1310 victory over the Toronto Polo Club today.

title: From a Pink A to a Violet Z
description: THE late Auguste Herbin was one of the more notable figures to emerge from that rabbitwarren of the modern movement, the Bateau Lavoir. The Bateau, sonamed because of its resemblance to a Seine laundry boat, was the battered hulk of a building in Montmartre, which, in the early years of the century, housed such celebrated figtires as Picasso, Juan Gris, the poet Max Jacob, as well as a number of lesser lights in the Parisian vanguard. It was there that Picasso painted the Demoiselles d'Avignon, the picture that initiated the Cubist revolution; and it was there that the nowfamous Rousseau Banquet, a raucous tribute to the painter Henri Rousseau, was held.

title: BUREAU OF MINES FACES FUND DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, March 24A dispute over the acceptance of corporate favors by the Government's top mine safety enforcer, Donald P. Schlick, is threatening Congressional approval of the $137million budget request of the Bureau of Mines, a Senate aide said today.

title: Computerized Signals Installed in Brooklyn
description: A computerized traffic signal system along the 3.5mile length of Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn went into permanent operation last week.

title: Reading
description: In a recent speech, Herman LaFontaine, the head of bilingual education for the New York City public schools, expressed some widely shared reservations about standardized tests. Taking liberties with Hamlet's popular soliloquy, Mr. LaFontaine said:

title: Mrs. Britton Wed in West
description: DENVER, March 24Mrs. Carola Britton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Britton, was married here this afternoon to Walter I. Tenney Jr. of New York, a vice president of the Price Paper Corporation there. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Tenney of Palm Springs, Calif., and Grover.

title: Rockland Area Opposes Widening of 3.4 Miles on Route 9W
description: PIERMONT, N. Y.  Area residents, fearful that construction on Route 9W is going to lead to more trucks pounding through their Hudson River communities, have brought a legal challenge to the State Department of Transportation.

title: Miss Benedict Sets Nuptials
description: The engagement of Miss Barbara Ann Benedict to Mitchell Shelton Weeks has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William John Benedict of New York and Weston, Vt. Mr. Weeks is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Shelton Weeks of Greenwich, Conn., and East Dorset, Vt. The wedding is planned for June.

title: The Almost World
description: I admired Hans Koningsberger's touchingly ambivalent novel The Revolutionary; but now that Koning has dropped two syllables from his name (for his antiwarmovement friends my name was too long for them), he has lost his complexity. The Almost World, a casually knitted account of Koning's travels and insights in Holland, Indonesia, the Philippines, Haiti, Cuba and the United States, includes a meditation on prostitution that ends with the zinger, The largest number of [prostitutes] right now is seen on television: men and women . . . bought to make us, with lies, buy things we don't need.... The book gets in several attacks against Cadillacs, and more against the white capitalist in his . . goddamn automobile or private plane, with his goddamn pretty wife in her goddamn white muslin or Courreges pants suit.

title: Child to Mrs. Bepler
description: A daughter was born March 6 to Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Edward Bepler at the New York Lying In Hospital. The child has been named Bettina Bradley.

title: President Nominates a Council To Shape Educational Policies
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 24 (AP)President Nixon today named 15 nominees for new National Council on Education Research.

title: Dollar Crisis Puts Driver In the Shop
description: Last season Pete Hamilton, a blond Yankee who had made it big in Dixie stockcar racing, was rated one of the eight best drivers on the circuit. Yet he could not get a decent ride because sponsorship money, has been drying up. In 1972 he had a disastrous season, with engine failures in four of the five races he was able to run. So now, at the age of 30, Pete Hamilton is setting up shop as a sort of elder statesman of stockcar racing, helping other drivers prepare their racers while working on a comeback program in Grand National racing. His appearance in next Sunday's Atlanta 500 is part of that program.

title: DeeDee Bridgewater Is Singing at Sam's
description: DeeDee Bridgewater is working as a single at Sam's Jazz Upstairs, Second Avenue at 64th Street, where she appears Fridays and Saturdays, backed by a trio. Alone, this dazzling singer has opportunities to stretch out in ways that she could not within the limitations imposed when she sings with a band.

title: Son to the Eugene Finks
description: A son was born on March 8 in Mount Sinai Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Eugene R. Fink of Riverdale, the Bronx. The child has been named Zachary Evan. Mrs. Fink is the former Miss Sheila Boodish of West Orange, N. J. Mr. Fink is an administrative executive at the corporate headquarters of National Kinney Corporation in New York.

title: Chess: Attack Can Be More Potent As Illusion Than as Reality
description: Dr. Max Euwe remarked, after he lost the return world championship match he granted Alexander Alekhine in 1937, that one of his failings had been his inability to discriminate between his opponent's moments of genuinely inspired brilliancy and his moments of bluffing.

title: Institute for Advanced Study Meets to Resolve Its Governance
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 24  Trustees and professors of the Institute for Advanced Study met here today to seek a resolution of the institute's crisis of governance.

title: The East End Hotel for Women Is Opening Its Doors to Men April
description: The East End Hotel for Women, founded in 1911 as a safe home away from home for working girls and operated like a girls dormitory, will admit its first male tenants April 9.

title: Rebecca Caruba: Food, Wine Expert
description: MAPLEWOODThere are probably some New Jersey gourmets to whom Julia Child is merely a televised Rebecca Caruba.

title: Calendar Of Horse Show Events
description: TodayThe Hill, Route 124, North Salem, N.Y. Regular, maiden, amateurowner and green working hunters; open and limit jumpers. 8:30 A.M.

title: Tristate Area BirthRate Drop Called Aid to Orderly Housing
description: A drop in the birth rate may yield unexpected opportunities to organize the growth of the metropolitan area into population centers, avoiding the urban sprawl of growth in the nineteensixties, the Regional Plan Association said yesterday.

title: Big Spruce Wins by 10 Lengths on Coast as 15 Cougar II Runs 3d
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 24 (AP)Elmendorf's Big Spruce charged from the outside at the head of the stretch today and ran away from heavily favored Cougar II and 501 Cicero's Court for a 10length victory in the $111,800 San Luis Rey Stakes at Santa Anita Park.

title: The Clocks Of Columbus
description: It is amusing, said Trollope about his first important job, to watch how a passion will grow upon a man. During those two years it was the ambition of my life to cover the country with rural lettercarriers. This combination of passionate commitment and awareness of the passion's incongruity with its object is what distinguishes comic poets whether gentle ones like Trollope or anguished ones like Swift  from merely funny men.

title: Miss Edna Rubin Bride of Lawyer
description: Miss Edna Rubin, daughter of Mrs. Jacob A. Rubin of New York and the late Dr. Rubin, was married here last night to Alexander Sussman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman R. Sussman of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein performed the ceremony in the Fifth Avenue Synagogue.

title: 2 Concerns Cited for Hiring Veterans
description: The big problem of Vietnamera veterans is the lack of interest by, businesses and the public in their difficulties in finding jobs, some heads of government agencies devoted to veterans affairs have said.

title: Soviet Executive Suite In Need of Secretaries
description: MOSCOW, March 24  A campaign appears to be under way in the Soviet Union to give greater prestige to the secretary.

title: IT'S HARD TO BEAT SYSTEM IN POLAND
description: WARSAW, March 11  A Western expert employed by the Polish Government left Warsaw for several days last week to pick up a car he had purchased in West Germany. This left the office car and driver at his wife's disposal, but she preferred to rent one of her own.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONPeriodically, over the last 20 years or so, the United States has become involved in international incidents arising out of the elintelectronic intelligence missions that are performed by American reconnaissance ships and planes along the coasts and borders of other countries.

title: Prosecutors Await Proof of Misdeeds By Wagner Forces
description: Three prosecutors, responding to Lindsay administration suggestions that shady political dealings are afoot in the mayoral race, said yesterday that they would welcome any evidence of wrongdoing by state officials promoting Robert F. Wagner as a possible RepublicanLiberal candidate.

title: Calendar of Dog Show Events
description: Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey all breed, Paterson Armory, 475 Market Street, Paterson, N. J.; 1,200 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Maurer: Lost and Found
description: MORE than 40 years have passed since that terrible day in August, 1932, when, at the age of 65. the American painter Alfred H. Maurer hanged himself in his father's house on West 43d Street. For some 40 years preceding that grim denouement, Maurer had been an artist of steady dedication and remarkable intelligence remarkable, too, for the courage with which he had turned his back on an early success in order to align his art with the imperatives of modernism.

title: Numismatics
description: THE fourday 17th annual Metropolitan New York Numismatic Convention, one of the premier events of the year in the East, will open Thursday at 1 P.M. in the Barbizon Plaza Hotel, 101 West 58th Street. The dealer bourse and exhibit area will remain open to the public until 10 P.M. The hours on Friday are from 10 A.M.. to 10 P.M., on Saturday from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. (except that the exhibit area will remain open until 11 P.M.) and on Sunday from 10 to 4.

title: Scull Applies His Artistic Flair to Fleet of 135 Cabs
description: A decade ago, Robert Scull was Mr. Big in the Pop art world. With his wife, Ethel, he was the discoverer, sponsor and friend of some of the famous names of the period, some of whom became permanent fixtures in the art worldAndy Warhol, Jasper Johns, Claes Oldenberg and Robert Morris were just a few of the artists who became famous under the Sculls' patronage.

title: FISH DEATHS TIED TO FLORIDA ALGAE
description: MIAMI, March 24Blue green algae have been identified by scientists as the cause of a mysterious disease that has killed, and is still sporadically killing, thousands of fish in one area of Biscayne Bay, about 20 miles south of here.

title: Gnomes of Araby
description: The recent monetary crisis may not have been brought MI solely by an attack of international speculators, as President Nixon explained it, but an extraordinary stockpile of rootless dollars was certainly standing ready to take advantage of quick profits in the monetary adjustments. This is the rising pool of dollar reserves in the Middle Eastern oilproducing countries, a relatively new factor in international monetary management that is bound to grow dramatically in size and disruptive potential for the decade to come. It is one of the most awesome side effects of the socalled energy crisis.

title: WALL STREET
description: One of the unsung miracles of modern medicine has been taking place on Wall Street lately. Leading drug and pharmaceutical shares have proved largely immune so far, at least  to the plague bedeviling most of the stock market.

title: KILLY TAKES SLALOM FOR PRO SKIING LEAD
description: STEAMBOAT SPRINGS, Colo., March 24 (AP)  JeanClaude Killy, the former Olympic star from France, won the giant slalom today and took the overan lead in the $40,000 Benson Band Hedges skiing Grand Prix. Killy, 29 years old, the twotime world champion and winner of three gold medals in the 1968 Olympics, beat Dan Mooney in the last heat.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: More than 500 filled St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Congers, N. Y., yesterday morning for a folk mass commemorate the deaths of five Nyack High School students one year ago when their school bus was struck by Penn Central freight train.

title: Lunokhod 2 Is Parked
description: MOSCOW, March 23 (Reuters)The Soviet Union's remotecontrolled moon Rover, Lunokhod 2, stood parked today for the onset of the lunar night after a busy explorations session at the Lemonnier Crater. TThe rover, which would remain parked until lunar daybreeak on April 8, has covered nearly 16 miles since it was landed on the moon Jan. 16. It spent the latest lunar day (the equivalent to 14 earth days) roaming over the crater's rim and heading for a boulderstrewn area in the eastern part of the crater.

title: For a spring weekend
description: This family heirloom recipe for pizza rustica (or country pie) is a far cry from the familiar pizza. It's more like a meat pie. An Italian meat pie.

title: The Old Man
description: Truman Nelson has a penchant for writing about historical subjects with the immediacy of the novelist, and some of his books are fiction rather than fact. But this one, though it is impatient with the conventions of scholarly annotation, depends largely on historical sources to present John Brown and his primal mission in Virginia.

title: Mine Union Official Disputes Boyle's Testimony
description: ERIE, Pa., March 24 (UPI)The head of District 19 of the United Mine Workers contradicted today the testimony of W. A. Boyle and two former union officials charged in the Yablonski slayings.

title: The Region
description: A man who can lead and heal this city, was the verdict rendered by Governor Rockefeller last week as he took a onetime Democratic foe, former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, to his bosom as his Republican candidate for Mayor.

title: A C.U.N.Y. RALLY ENDS IN WALKOUT
description: A meeting of 400 students called by the City University Student Senate to plan a protest against state proposals affecting the university ended yesterday after all but about 75 black and Hispanic students and their supporters walked out.

title: Laotian Village Puts Poppies to Torch
description: BAN NA KONG, Laos, March 19Tribal women wearing their best silver jewelry stood in rigid formation, American and Laotian flags fluttered bravely, and a village headman put the torch to a huge pile of dried poppies representing about 356 pounds of raw opium.

title: Cheeks Karate Victor
description: Albert Cheeks, a 21yearold heavyweight from the Ki Whang Kim Institute in Silver Springs, Md., won the grand championship of the annual AllAmerican open karate tournament yesterday at Madison Square Garden. He defeated Michael Warren, a teammate, who is a lightweight, 21, before a crowd of 5,000.

title: GREEKS UNCOVER WAIL PAINTINGS
description: ATHENS, March 25The full drama of a punitive expedition by the Aegean fleet against a hostile Libyan city some 3,500 years ago has been revealed in a strip of miniature wall paintings found on the island of Thera, according to a leading Greek archeologist.

title: New Traffic Chief
description: In two decades with the Police Department, Benjamin Ward has been a patrolman, a juvenile aid specialist, a detective, a legal counsel, head of the Civilian Complaint Review Board, deputy commissioner in charge of trials and, for the last two years, deputy commissioner in charge of community affairs. For all this varied experience, he had occasion yesterday to recall that back in 1951 he spent his first two weeks on the job waving whitegloved hands on First Avenue, performing the duties of a traffic patrolman. Appointed by Mayor Lindsay yesterday as the city's next Traffic ComMr. Ward said:

title: 5 Die in Brazil Flood
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 25 (AP)Flooding caused by heavy rainfall has forced 10,000 people out of their homes in Minas Gerais State west of Rio, the police said today. They said at least five persons were killed when their makeshift houses collapsed.

title: Books of The Times
description: A HOT PROPERTY. By Judy Feiffer. 171 pages. Random House. $5.95.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: 3D OF JAILS IN SURVEY HAVE NO PHYSICIANS
description: CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) Nearly onethird of the jails responding to a national medical survey have no physicians available to provide care to inmates.

title: Moon Robot Totals 17 Miles
description: MOSCOW, March 25 (UPI)The Lunokhod 2 moon robot has covered 17 miles on the lunar surface since it landed on the Sea of Serenity Jan. 16, the Commpnist party newspaper, Pravda, said today.

title: Nicklaus Wins Playoff; Elder Ties for 6th Place
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 25 Jack Nicklaus sank a 4foot birdie putt at the second extra hole of a suddendeath playoff to defeat Miller Barber and win the Greater New Orleans open golf tournament today.

title: Word Expert's Preferences Pronounced
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.Dr. Henry Bosley Woolf is editor in charge of dictionaries for the G. & C. Merriam Company here, and his preferences are pronounced.

description: Twenty  nine natural gas companies in 20 Eastern states are planning a joint search for natural gas along the Atlantic Coast.

title: Woman Held in Slaying
description: A Jackson Heights, Queens, woman was arrested early yesterday on homicide charges after, the police said, she stabbed her boyfriend with kitchen knife during an argument in his home. The woman, Martha Diaz, 22 years old, of 3440 92d Street, was booked after the death of Jose Parra, 29, of 8411 Elmhurst Avenue, Jackson Heights.

title: COUGARS BEAT Q'S AND CLINCH TITLE
description: SAN DIEGO, March 25 (AP) The Carolina Cougars won their first American Basketball Association title tonight with an easy 124113 victory over the San Diego Conquistadors. The triumph clinched the Eastern Division championship.

title: Bill by Patman Sets Freeze On All Prices for 60 Days
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (Reuters)A 60day freeze on all prices and interest rates was proposed today by a group of Democratic Representatives.

title: 6 Porsches Place Among Top 10 at Sebring
description: SEBRING, Fla., March 25 (UPI)The durability of the Porsche over rugged longdistance courses proved itself again yesterday with the victory of a yellow Porsche Carrera in the SebringCamel 12hour endurance race.

title: Rain Curtails Mets' Hunt For Two More Pitchers
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25Rain swept the Gulf Coast of Florida today, wiping out exhibition baseball over a wide area and disrupting the talent search for the New York Mets' pitching staff.

title: Carl Christiah Mose Dies; Sculptor and Art Teacher
description: NEW WINDSOR, Md., March 25 (AP)Carl Christian Mose, sculptor and art teacher, died yesterday of a heart attack at his farm home near here. He was 70 years old.

title: Woman Held as Planes Are Fired On Upstate
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y., March 25 A 53yearold woman was charged yesterday with firing a rifle at airliners using Stewart Airport to practice takeoffs and landings.

title: Music: Rita Streich Sings Lieder
description: Although you might not think so to scan the weekly concert announcements, genuine lieder recitals come along about as often as undefaced subway cars. Rita Streich's recital at Town Hall yesterday proved to be the genuine articlein fact, nearly perfect of its kind, within the limits of the soprano's light lyric voice and blithe temperament.

title: Douglas to Get $2Million In Group W 5Year Pact

title: Expert Restores Her Kitchen to Authentic Colonial
description: Perhaps the greatest magnet for viewers of a colonial house is the ancient kitchen, primitively picturesque and evocative of a romantic past. In its own time, it was the hardwon lifeline to survival that many newcomers to these shores failed to reach.

title: Boy, 13, Accused of Arson
description: A 13yearold Far Rockaway, Queens, youth was arrested on charges of juvenile delinquency seconddegree arsonSaturday night and accused of setting a twoalarm fire that heavily damaged four of 10 stores in a row at 202210 Beach 26 Street, Far Rockaway. The boy, whose name the police withheld because of his age, was released in his parents' custody pending a hearing in juvenile court.

title: River Vale Scores Sewage Dumping
description: RIVER VALE, March 25This could be the Wounded Knee of New Jersey, said Murray Goodman, leader of townwide protest against the dumping of raw sewage from seven communities into an open manole near a residential street.

title: Capitalism, for Better or Worse Somehow, It Has Overcome
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.There is little warrant for the belief that we know the laws of history well enough to make projections of any great reliability. Most of the turning points of history, great and small, were surprises to both their participants and. the analysts of the day, whatever their doctrine.

title: Work to Rule
description: The Pentagon, the civil service and the nation will better off now that Gordon W. Rule has won his battle to return to his sensitive post as overseer of Navy procurement programs. For three months he was the victim of a benighted attempt to oust and muzzle a toughminded senior expert who dared to criticize high Administration officials and policies in his area specialty.

title: CONSUMER SURVEY DISCLOSES CAUTION
description: Consumers are confident about the current state of the economy, but have turned less optimistic about future business and employment conditions. This is the consensus of a nationwide survey of 10,000 families in January and February, the Conference Board reported.

title: Optimistic Memphis State Faces U.C.L.A. Tonight

LOUIS, March 25Some loud and happy Memphis State fans, the members of the Memphis team, and their poach, Gene Bartow, are the only persons capable of imagining a Memphis State victory over the University of California, Los Angeles, in the final of the National Collegiate basketball tournament tomorrow night.

title: Looters Impede Scholars Studying Maya Mystery
description: FLORES, Guatemala  The magnificent remains of the ancient Maya Indian civilization, a culture that attained astonishing intellectual and artistic heights as Europe sank into the Middle Ages, are being systematically decimated by looters to feed the growing art markets in the United States and Europe.

title: In Paris, Spring Means Antics in the Gardens . . .
description: PARIS, March 25If twit is enough to make a tradition, there is another annul sign that spring has surely come to Paris.

description: New York State enrollment figures for the June primaries, announced yesterday, by Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo, show Democratic registrations topping Republican by, more than one million4,226,604 to 3,201,059for the first time.

title: NAVY BASE HOLDS RACIAL SEMINARS
description: SAN DIEGO, March 25Of course we have problems, said Capt. H. R. Bivin without the slightest hesitation. But we recognize them, we're doing something.

title: Red Smith

Fox, 45, said from his home in Chambersburg, Pa.: I've just had it, living out of a suitcase. I'm at the point where I can retire, and I will. This year I plan to take things easy.

title: Chase and Franklin Roll Back Rates

title: Airport Rail Link Called Peril to Trees
description: Building a section of the ManhattanKennedy International Airport rail link through Forest Park in Queens will require the removal of 184 trees, some of them 40 feet tall and 200 years old.

title: One Vote per $100
description: The principle of oneman, onevote, which was among the great pronouncements of the Supreme Court under Chief Justice Earl Warren, has just been diluted for the second time under his successor. Having recently modified the rule in the election of state legislators, the Court has now made an outright exception in voting for members of limited and specialpurpose governmental bodies. Specifically, last week's ruling concerned the boards of directors of a California water district and a Wyoming watershed improvement authority, but might just as easily apply to Sewer and fire districts in counties within the metropolitan area.

title: Bridge: Swedish Barometer' Enlivens A Duplicate Event in Teaneck
description: The Bergen Bridge Center in Teaneck, N. J., last week strengthened its claim to be considered the most enterprising metropolitan  area club by organizing a Danish evening. This did not refer to the nature of the refreshments, and might more properly have been called a Swedish evening, since the principal ingredient was a Swedish barometer.

title: THEODORE GOETZ OF NEWS CHAIN, 68

He was 68 years old, lived at 105 Greenacres Avenue in Scarsdale and had been spending the winter in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Raiders Lose, 84, Drop to 5th; Jets' Hull Gets His 100th Point
News Summary and Index MONDAY, MARCH 26, 1973
description: International

title: SENATOR ASSAILS REPORT ON WHEAT
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, said today that a confidential Justice Department report on grain dealings with the Soviet Union contained no reference to an alleged industry statement to the Federal Bureau of Investigation that appeared to contradict testimony by the Secretary of Agriculture.

title: U.S. BARS PULLOUT UNTIL ALL P.O.W.'S HAVE BEEN FREED
description: MIAMI, March 25President Nixon said today that he had ordered United States forces to stay in South Vietnam until all American prisoners of war have been released.

title: Pollution Officials Are Certain Los Angeles Can't Cut Traffic
description: LOS ANGELES, March 25 Three weeks of public hearings have convinced Federal air pollution officials that there is no possibility of imposing a big reduction in Los Angeles Basin auto traffic to clean up the air.

title: SeaGrant Program Gives State Advice About Marine Resources
description: ALBANY, March 25New York State neglected its coastal resources for so long, a recent study said, that its waterways fell into evil ways as depositories for the refuse of an otherwise busy economy.

title: SACRED WORKS SUNG BY WHEATON CHOIR
description: The Wheaton College Concert Choir is into the third week of its Eastern tour, and at Town Hall Saturday night, the 47 young singers presented an attractively varied program of sacred anthems and songs. Wheaton, not to be confused with the similarly named women's college in Norton, Mass., is a fundamentalist Bible College (most famous alumnus: Billy Graham), in a suburb of Chicago and devoted to the ideals of evangelical Christian faith and practice.

title: Iraq Frees Iranian Airmen
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 25 (AP)Three Iranian Air Force men who strayed into Iraq in a helicopter Jan. 10 when taking food and medical supplies to snowbound villagers were released today and returned to Teheran.

title: Body of 2d of 2 Fishermen Who Drowned Is Found
description: EAST MORICHES, L. I. March 25The Suffolk County police this morning recovered the body of the second of two fishermen Who drowned yesterday afternbon when their 16foot dory capsized in the ocean, off Moriches Inlet.

title: Screen: A New Truffaut: Such a Gorgeous Kid Like Me' Arrives
description: When Stanislas Previne (Andre Dussolier), a conventionally shy young sociollogist, arrives at the prison to gather material for his thesis, "Criminal Women," the matron tries to dissuade him from interviewing Camille Bliss. Instead, the matron suggests that he talk to the inmate who cut her men victims into pieces or to the inmate who strangled men with one hand. Stanislas persists, and the haughty matron says of Camille: "She's just a tramp."The matron's absolutely right. Camille (Bernadette Lafont) is brassy, vulgar, talks in clichs, is not strikingly pretty and not in the first bloom of youth, but she possesses several other qualities that drive some men wild.Like poor tubercular Mildred in "Of Human Bondage," Camille is so intensely self-absorbed that the selfishness amounts to a sexual challenge. Most important, perhaps, Camille has a smashing figure, one that seems to have little relation to the bird-brain that directs it, a figure that looks particularly great in slips and unbuttoned blouses and is seemingly impervious to assaults by men or time.Franois Truffaut's newest comedy, "Such a Gorgeous Kid Like Me," is the story of Camille's wild rise to fame and fortune as a singing star of absolutely no talent, in a world that cares less for performance onstage than for achievements off. Camille's rue to success is littered with corpses, including those of her father and her mother-in-law and one marvelously manic suitor (Charles Denner), a rat exterminator who had known from the age of 9 what he wanted to be.Camille doesn't consider herself a murderer. She just sets up situations that can if she's lucky  result in certain disadvantages to others."Such a Gorgeous Kid Like Me" is a very curious and disappointing movie. It has wit, but it's not very funny. It is too schematically predictable ever to be surprising except in minor details. Its woefully comic attitude toward the triumph of second-rateness is not of an especially interesting order. Nor, I suspect, does it come naturally to Truffaut, whose films  even the so-called failures like "The Soft Skin," "The Bride Wore Black" and "Mississippi Mermaid"  posses a poetic complexity seldom achieved by other directors' successes.In the entire film, there are just two scenes that are worthy of anything in his earlier films: a moment that is almost shocking in its suggestion of recognizable feeling, when Stanislas takes his leave of Camille in prison, where he's been taping her story and falling in love with her, and another, purely comic moment toward the end when a scholarly 10-year-old film director refuses to let strangers look at his unedited "rushes."I have such admiration for Truffaut's intelligence that I can't believe that perhaps what I take to be failures in "Such a Gorgeous Kid like Me" might not be his purposeful decisions. Bernadette Lafont, who was in Truffaut's first short film, "Les Mistons," is a singularly uninteresting actress. She's sort of horsy and loud, incapable of anything resembling a small gesture. But then (I think to myself), perhaps that is just the quality he wantedin order to make Camille's triumph that much more grotesque.The decision may be intellectually correct, but it squashes the comedy, which is not especially inventive to start with. It also puts a burden on the actors who play Camille's victims, only one of whom, Denner, catches the exuberant spirit of the piece, which is too often simply frenzied. One of Truffaut's great talents, especially evident in "Shoot the Piano Player" and "Stolen Kisses," is his way of parsing any mood into its components of comedy, tragedy, put-on and poetry. "Such a Gorgeous Kid Like Me" is a single comic mood, repeated with variations, shrilly.

title: Miss Mervyn Adams Married To M. Robert Seldon, Engineer
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., March 25Miss Mervyn Winston Adams of New York, daughter of Mrs. Robert McCormick Adams of Chicago and the late Mr. Adams, was married here this afternoon to M. Robert Seldon of Ontario, Calif., son of Mrs. Mark Seldon of Miami Beach and the late Mr. Seldon. Justice of the Peace Paul H. Smith Jr. of Eastport performed the ceremony at the bride's summer home.

title: British Draw Icelandic Fire
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, March 25 (AP)An Icelandic gunboat fired over the bow of a British ctrawler today inside the 50mile offshore sea limit set by this country, the Icelandic coast guard reported. An Icelandic spokesman said the trawler Brucella, fishing off the island of Surtsey near the 12mile limit that Britain recognizes, attempted to ram a patrol boat after being ordered outside the 50mile limit.

title: Rome Newspapers Report Embassy Phones Tapped
description: ROME, March 25 (AP)The telephones of some Eastern European and Middle Eastern embassies in Rome were tapped in Italy's widening wiretapping scandal, newspapers reported today.

title: Hollis Leach Bride of Eugene Sunshine
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 25Miss Hollis Adrienne Leach and Eugene Samuel Sunshine, graduates of Northwestern University, were married here this afternoon at the Greenwich Country club by Justice of the Peace Sheldon T. Coleman Jr.

title: 3 Church Groups Deplore Planned Social Fund Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)  Spokesmen for three national church groups voiced what they called serious misgivings today over proposed fund cuts for social programs in President Nixon's budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: FARM FOOD PRICES UP 25% IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, March 25A market basket of foods from United States farms cost the typical family 2.5 per cent more last month than in January, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

title: Marbletown Contests Metropolitan's Ownership of 1702 Town Seal
description: MARBLETOWN, N. Y.And now, the case of the Marbletown seal.

title: Va. Tech Wins N.I.T.
description: A 20foot jump shot by Bobby Stevens in the last second of overtime yesterday gave Virginia Tech a 9291 victory over Notre Dame in the final of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden. Page 57.

title: Whoever Runs It, F.B.I. Faces Problem of Political Control
description: WASHINGTON, March 25For 48 years under J. Edgar Hoover, the Federal Bureau of Investigation was above politicsnot unpolitical; as Mr. Hoover's intimates now confirm in fresh detail, but so nearly sovereign that it dominated relations with Attorneys General, Congress and sometimes Presidents. And then, after Mr. Hoover's death last May, there was L. Patrick Gray 3d.

title: Exhibition Baseball
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: SMITH SETS BACK LAVER BY 63, 64
description: ATLANTA, March 25 (AP)Stan Smith, bidding to become the king of pro tennis, beat topseeded Rod Laver, 63, 64, today and captured the $10,000 first prize in the World Champsionship Tennis's $50,000 Peachtree Corners tournament.

title: ARTHUR ROUS
description: Arthur Rous, president of the Federal Carton Corporation and senior vice president of the GrandCity Container Corporation, died of a heart attack Saturday at La Guardia Airport, on his way to a meeting of the directors of the Paperboard Packaging Council in Chicago. He was 66 years old and lived at 235 Lincoln Street, Englewood, N.J., and in Tannerville, N.Y.

title: BLACKS GET ADVICE ON GAINING POWER
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, March 25 (AP)Basil A. Patterson, the vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, says the formation of a national black political structure with state and local organizations would be a positive move toward gaining political power for blacks.

title: Winzenreid Takes 1:48.7 HalfMile In Meet on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, March 25 (AP)Mark Winzenried ran a fast half  mile, Al Feuerbach made an auspicious shot  put debut outdoors and the U.C.L.A. 440 relay team blazed to a 40second, clocking today in the Bruins' Meet of Champions.

title: Jewel Thieves Cut Off Thousands of Alarms in a $100,000 Robbery
description: A team of thieves immobilized several thousand burglar alarms in lower Manhattan by cutting cables yesterday and then burglarized a jewelry firm at 15 Maiden Lane of diamonds and rings valued at more than $100,000.

title: Sales Rose 14.4% During February At Chain Stores
description: The nation's chain stores and catalog houses continued to chalk up sizable gains in the (sales volume during February, according to a survey of The Times completed over the weekend.

title: Rangers Lose to Stars, Trail Bruins by 4 Points
description: Despite a frantic final 40 minutes played with desperation, the Rangers lost last night to the Minnesota North Stars, 21, and buried themselves deeper into third glace.

title: Pro Track Finds Trouble Appears at Every Turn
description: A new professional track and field tour began officially last Saturday night in Los Angeles, but some of the old predicaments of the amateur circuit still prevailed.

title: Brazil, Aided by Lottery, Forges Booming Auto Industry
description: SAO BERNARDO do CAMPO, Brazil, March 25Fifteen years ago, Brazil's production of automobiles was zero. Today Brazil has the largest automotive industry in Latin America and ranks eighth in the world.

title: Philippine Guerrillas Forge a Formidable Movement
description: ZAMBOANGA, the Philippines, March 25The young leaders of the rebellious Moslems in the southern islands of the Philippines have forged what appears to be a cohesive and disciplined guerrilla movement that Government forces have been unable to challenge seriously after a month of widespread fighting.

title: Miss Yablonka Married
description: VERONA, N. J., March 25  Miss Roberta Yablonka, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Yablonka of Paterson, was married here this afternoon to Arthur Karl Hirshman of East Orange. He is the son of Mrs. Elsie Hirshman of Brooklyn. Rabbi Harry Bornstein performed the ceremony at the Richfield caterers.

title: Day Schools Deplored by Head Of American Jewish Congress
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The head of the American Jewish Congress charged today that Jewish communal organizations were failing to meet their primary responsibility of providing American Jews with a basic Jewish education and a deep sense of identification with the Jewish people.

title: Drivers Warned on Tires
description: WASHINGTON, March 25, (UPI)The Tire Industry Safety Council reminded American drivers yesterday that it was time to remove studded snow tires.

title: Argentina Defeats Brazil In Davis Cup Zone Tennis
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 25 (AP)Argentina clinched the South American Zone Davis Cup tennis series against Brazil today when Julian Ganzabal, defeated Jorge Lehman, 108, 75, 64.

title: Strong Steel Demand Seen
description: CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 25 (AP)A strong domestic steel demand and the possibility of lower imports this year could stretch the nations raw steel capacity to full measure, according to Industry Week magazine. Steel producers have estimated the ceiling at about 155 million net tons of raw steel a year, a pace that has been approached during March, the magazine said.

title: State Sponsors Seminar on White Collar Crime
description: TRENTON, March 25  The state will begin training local and county law enforcement officials this week to be able to recognize and investigate white collar crime.

title: EGYPT'S PREMIER IS SAID TO RESIGN
description: CAIRO, March 25Informed political sources said today that Premier Aziz Sidky resigned yesterday after 14 months in office to enable President Anwar elSadat to take personal charge of the Governments daytoday operations.

title: JOINT UNIT BACKS SPENDING CEILING SOUGHT BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Democrats and Republicans on the Congressional Joint Economic Committee agreed unanimously today with President Nixon that total. Government spending in the next fiscal year should be held at $268billion, though the Democrats said Congress should make major reallocations with the Administration's proposed expenditure total.

title: CYPRUS REPORTS PLOT ON MAKARIOS
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 25 Cypriote officials said today that they had uncovered a plan to overthrow the Government of Archbishop Makarios next Sunday.

title: Doctors Find Clots Follow Heart Attacks
description: STOCKHOLM, March 25 Three Swedish doctors have made a surprising discovery that challenges the basic medical concepts of the relationship between blood clots and heart attacks.

title: Fidelity: Is It Nothing More Than an OldFashioned Concept?
description: I have been faithful to thee, Cynaral in my, fashion.

title: BUDGET PASSAGE IS DUE THIS WEEK
description: ALBANY, March 25A new budget for the 197374 state fiscal year, beginning next Sunday, is scheduled to be passed by the Legislature this week, with the Republican leaders of both houses recommending that Governor Rockefeller's spending plan of $8.89billion be trimmed by $120million.

title: Mansfield and Albert: Key Men in Struggle With Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Carl Albert rapped the metal handle of a letter opener against his left palm. He fer rowed his brow. He declared that it was bad enough for Piesident Nixon to refuse to follow Congressional directions on spending, bad enough for the White House to withhold information from the Senate.

title: Peronist Leaves for Rome
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 25 (UPI)Presidentelect Hctor J. Cempora left today for Rome to consult on the new Argentine Government and Peronist policy with former President Juan D. Pern.

title: Energy Experts Foresee World Strains
description: PARIS, March 25A major study by energy experts of the world's largest industrial countries pictures a decade ahead of growing dependence on Middle East and African oil sources, with rising prices and political risks overhanging needed supply. The report says close cooperation among consumer countries is an absolute need.

title: Chase and Franklin Roll Back Rates
description: Two more banks capitulated to the wishes of the Administration yesterday by rolling back interest charges on loans to large corporations.

title: Argentina Defeats Brazil In Davis Cup Zone Tennis
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 25 (AP)Argentina clinched the South American Zone Davis Cup tennis series against Brazil today when Julian Ganzabal defeated Jorge Lehman, 108, 7.5, 64.

title: NEW TEACHERS UNION ELECTS SHANKER NO. 2
description: MONTREAL, March 25 (AP) Thomas Hobart of Buffalo was elected president of the infant New York State United Teachers union today, and Albert Shanker was elected executive vice president at the Union's first convention.

title: McCord Tells Senate Unit Of New Watergate Names
description: WASHINGTON, March 25James W. McCord Jr. has provided Senate investigators with the names of participants in the Watergate conspiracy who have escaped prosecution, it was announced today.

title: Miss Lubin Is Wed To David J. Finkel
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 25  Miss Madelon Lubin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Lubin, was married here this afternoon to David J. Finkel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Finkel of London. Rabbi Bernard Schachtel performed the ceremony at the Lubin home.

title: Championship Season Wins Tony
description: That Championship Season, the longrunning drama by Jason Miller that originally opened off Broadway, last night won honors as the best play of the season in the Broadway theater's 27th annual Tony Awards, presented at the Imperial Theater.

title: Garelik: Former Policeman And a Different Politician
description: Sanford D. Garelik is campaigning, listening to an old man who is full of grievances and a sense of having been dealt with badly. Sandy, the old man is saying, what can I do? The city is killing me.

title: Iowa Publisher Named
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa, March 25 (AP)Tom L. Williams has been named publisher of the Times  Democrat newspaper, David K. Gottlieb, president of Lee Enterprises Inc., said yesterday. Mr. Williams, who has been the newspaper's general manager, succeeds Henry B. Hook, who retires April 1 after 21 years as publisher.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PLAY IT AGAIN, WOLFGANG! The Mozarteum Orchestra of Salzburg is in something of a rut; for more than a century it's been playing nothing but Mozart. The 45piece ensemble calls itself the only truly Mozart orchestra in the world (and who is to dispute it?). Fortunately, Mozart composed enough to keep a repertory going easily.

title: Movement on MIRV's
description: LONDONThe Russians are really interested. That is the word beginning to be heard from some men concerned with the problem of nuclear arms control. They are talking about serious Soviet interest in negotiating limitations on MIRV's.

title: Intimidation of the Media Seen by Nicholas Johnson
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., March 25 (UPI)A member of the Federal Communications Commission, Nicholas Johnson, accused the Nixon Administration yester of trying to intimidate the press because they want the media to repeat, not report.

title: Police Issue a Photo Likeness Of Slayer of West Side Boy, 10
description: Detectives have issued a composite photographic likeness of a man sought in connection with the sexual mutilation and murder of 10yearold Luis Ortiz on the Upper West Side on March 7.

title: TSCHUDI CAPTURES COLORADO SLALOM
description: STEAMBOAT SPRINGS, Colo., March 25 (UPI)Otto Tschudi won the slalom and $2,500 today in the $20,000 Bonnie BellFrontier Airlines ski event.

title: Vietnam P.O.W. Snag Continues, but U.S. Aides Are Confident of Solution
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 26The dispute over the release of the last American prisoners of war remained deadlocked yesterday, but United States officials privately expressed confidence that it would be resolved by Wednesday's deadline for the final pullout of American troops.

title: VIETNAM TRUCE AIDE WOUNDED BY SNIPER
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 25 (AP)An Indonesian member of the International Commission of Control and Supervision was seriously wounded tonight when a sniper fired on the jeep in which he was riding in the Mekong Delta city of Can Tho, commission sources said.

description: Before Ray Noble came to the United States and became so enmeshed in American show business that he wound up as an Englishaccented stooge on the Charlie McCarthy radio program, he led an English studio band that produced what seemed at the time to be the greatest pop records of the period. Forty years later, they still stand as the best body of dance band arrangements, performances and (in technical terms) recordings of the dance band era between World War I and Warld War II, occasionally matched but never surpassed by Glenn Miller

description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)Thallium sulfate, a dangerous poison banned from household use seven years ago, is still being sold in household formulations, the Environmental Protection Agency warned today.

description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 25 (AP)Joseph Kennedy 3d, eldest son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was reported in satisfactory condition at a hospital here today after suffering chest, skull and neck injuries in an automobile accident.

title: Dance: Merce Cunningham Stumbles
description: Merce Cunningham's fullevening ballet Canfield has a knack for making news. When it had its premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1969, there was some kind of electricians' strike (or people very like electricians  possibly stagehands) and the work had to be danced to silence. It has never since had it so good.

title: Adirondack Deadline
description: The Adirondacks suffered a wound, though not quite a mortal one, when the Assembly voted last week to postpone the Adirondack Park Agency's plan for controlling development of private lands within the park's boundaries. The year's delay can and should be beaten back in the Senate. If it is not, the last hope is a veto by Governor Rockefeller, who has vigorously opposed any such delay as a transparent attempt to kill this whole plan for saving the state's unique treasure.

Mr. Stewart said the state had paid for the trip so the officials could discuss gambling interests and plans with Mr. Hughes. But Mr. Hughes under the law will be assessed the cost.

description: Deescalation, if not elimination, of the Indochina war leaves at least two areas of recent conflict and unresolved grievances to challenge President Nixon's aspirations for a generation of peace  the Middle East and South Asia.

description: PITTSBURGH, March 25E. Miles Wilson, news editor of The Pittsburgh PostGazette unitil his retirement last June, died yesterday in Shadyside Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: Last Chance for Fairness
description: The Constitution, by its silence on the matter, has relegated the responsibility for education to the states. From this interpretation that education is not a fundamental right guaranteed by the Constitution has now come a Supreme Court decision upholding the right of states to let their public schools be financed largely through property taxes.

title: 16 YANKEE HITS TOP ORIOLES, 102
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 25  Everything they hit today was a base hit, Doyle Alexander, a Baltimore pitcher, said. I think they coulda come up without a bat and got a hit.

title: DOBERMAN TAKES TOP JERSEY PRIZE
description: PATERSON, N. J., March 25 Persistence paid off today, when Mrs. Marilyn Meshirer's Doberman pinscher, Ch. Peri's Prince Temujin was named best of 1,195 dogs at the 30th annual Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey show in the Paterson Armory.

title: Gray Liked in His Adopted Town
description: STONINGTON, Conn., March 25One of the favorite gathering places on Saturday afternoons here is Keane's News Shop on Water Street. The old men of the village like to stand and gossip outside, while other citizens prefer to talk to the owner, Frank Keane, as they wait for the afternoon papers to arrive. Yesterday, Mr. Keane, like nearly everybody else in Stonington, was talking about Louis Patrick Gray 3d, who, he recalled, used to drop in often to pick up a paper when he was a yearround resident of the town. That was before he moved to Washington in 1968.

title: Shipwrecked Sailor Saved After 3Day Ordeal at Sea
description: A 23yearold Norwegian seaman, the only survivor so far of the 30man crew of a freighter that sank in lashing seas off Cape May, N. J., on Thursday, was saved from the Atlantic yesterday after he had drifted three days and 120 miles alone on a life raft.

title: Toll Evasion Declines On Garden State Pkwy.
description: WOODBRIDGE, March 25 (AP)  Garden State Parkway officials say they have succeeded in cracking down on motorists who fail to pay tolls at unmanned exactchange lanes.

title: UGANDA REPORTED TO ACQUIRE ARMOR
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, March 25  Usually reliable sources in Uganda say that Uganda has purchased 80 French armored personnel carriers to be equipped with surfacetosurface missiles.

title: The Screen:Lelouch's Sly 'Money' Is a Clever Satire
description: Claude Lelouch's "Money, Money, Money" is such a bright, clever comedy-satire that the writer-director can be forgiven toward the end, when he almost beats the horse  his joke  to death. This is a sly, funny picture, but nothing like Lelouch's lyrical "A Man and a Woman"whose sessiness and visual punctuation of slapstick outride patches of arid blandness and a fade-out when he simply pelts us with his point.It goes like this. Why shouldn't present-day pirates, banding together in Paris, pluck profit from a chaotic society jangling with ideologies, causes and trends? Materialism, spelled money, is at the root, and this is what the five knaves go after, with brash success and a few ironic snags.The first part of the picture is the most freshly inventive, with the blithe crooks converging, careening around in cars (Mack Sennett-style), heisting a corporation safe (in the neatest trick of the year) and kidnapping a pop singer, then an ambassador.This last stunt, overlapping a plane hijacking, involves the men with a bearded South American revolutionary, whose ideals are acutely hitched to the value of a dollar. This is the sharpest section but blandness sets in until Lelouch whisks the story and tone into broad, breezy comedy. The ending is a nimble surprise. If only Lelouch had let go.Technically, the movie is first-rate. As the brazen, carefree culprits, Lino Ventura, Charles Denner, Jacques Brel (toothsomely alive and well), Charles Grard and Aldo Maccione are amusing indeed. So is most of the new, subtitled import at the Paris Theater.

description: The number of individual shareowners last year registered its first decline in more than two decadesdropping by 800,000.

title: Sudan Leader in London
description: LONDON, March 25 (AP)President Gaafar alNimery of the Sudan arrived in London today for a fiveday official visit.

title: Stevens Savors NetCutting Ceremony
description: The instant the lastsecond shot went cleanly through the net, the Virginia Tech cheerleaders and followers burst onto the. Madison Square Garden floor and lifted Bobby Stevens, their little blond hero, onto their shoulders.

title: Bergen County Is Letting ExAddicts Receive Methadone From Pharmacies
description: BERGENFIELD, N. J., March 25Cindy, 23 years old, entered Browning's Pharmacy here one day last week, walked to the rear prescription area and said good morning to Walter Browning, the owner.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: ANGOLANS VOTING ON NEW ASSEMBLY
description: LUANDA, Angola, March 25 (Reuters)  Voting was under way in Angola today for a new legislative assembly. There was little fanfare, no great entihusiasm and some bewilderment.

title: POLICE KILL MAN DURING AN ARREST
description: A man who was said to be interfering with the apprehension of a larceny suspect in lower Manhattan was shot and killed by a patrolman early yesterday, the police reported.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The label on the little girls' clothes reads Cambridge Fashion Designs LondonParisFlemington, N. J. And the clothes are as intriguing as the label:

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Will Knicks Be Playoff Ready?
description: A season that began five months ago with several unanswered questions ended for the New York Knicks Saturday night with only one real question left: can they regain in the playoffs, which will start Friday, the sharpness and cohesion that characterize their best moments?

title: McCord Tells Senate Unit Of New W atergate Names
description: WASHINGTON, March 25James W. McCord Jr. has provided Senate investigators with the names of participants in the Watergate conspiracy who have escaped prosecution, it was announced today.

title: Disengagement at Hand
description: The coming week is to mark a turning point in Vietnam as momentous as the declaration of ceasefire two months ago. By Wednesday all American prisoners war are supposed to be released from captivity in North Vietnam. And, for the first time in a decade, there are to be no more United States military personnel on duty with the South Vietnamese armed forces.

title: Movie Idol Leads Sharp Attack On Government of Indian State
description: MADRAS, India, March 22The broad, leafy streets of this southern capital are pulsing with noisy outdoor rallies in the morning, party political meetings in the afternoon and mass processions in the evening.

title: A Lighthearted Thieu Romps at Farm Show
description: CAN THO, South Vietnam, March 26With the enthusiasm of a farmer trying out a new tractor, President Nguyen Van Thieu bounded through an Americanstyle agricultural exhibition here today in the heart of South Vietnam's rich rice lands.

title: Woman Golfer Goodwill Envoy
description: It's all very well to characterize her as the Lee Trevino of the women golf pros, but Jocelyne Bourassa, who has progressed from FrenchCanadian amateur athlete of the year to rookie of the year on the 1972 tour of the Ladies Professional Golf Association, aspires to more than a wellballyhooed career as a player.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Four major performers have agreed to star in as many forthcoming Broadway productions this year.

title: M'CORD REJECTED LENIENCY OFFERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The chief prosecutor in the Watergate trial disclosed tonight that James W. McCord Jr., one of those convicted, had twice turned down Government offers of reduced charges in return for telling what he knew about the case.

title: DAVID L. LOEW DIES; MOVIE PRODUCER, 75
description: LOS ANGELES, March 26David L. Loew, a retired film producer, died yesterday in University of California at Los Angeles Memorial Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: Another Olga to Assume Spotlight at the Forum
description: There seems no end to the wave of outstanding athletes from the Soviet Union who are touring the United States these days.

title: THRIFT GROUPS TRIM MORTGAGE SPENDING
description: The nation's savings and loan associations trimmed their mortgage lending during February in the face of a slowdown in their inflow of new deposits, the United States Savings and Loan League said yesterday.

title: Shocked McLain Pat On Waivers by Braves
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26Denny McLain, who once earned $200,000 a year from baseball and other enterprises, was placed on the market tonight by the Atlanta Braves for the waiver price of $1. If nobody claims him within six days, he will become a free agent.

title: FINAL 148 P.O.W.'S WILL BE RELEASED IN NEXT TWO DAYS
description: MIAMI, March 26The White House announced today that agreement had been reached to complete by Thursday the release of the last of the United States prisoners of war in Indochina and the withdrawal of the remaining American combat forces from South Vietnam.

title: Forest Hills Project Rising, But the Controversy Lingers
description: The foundations of the longdelayed lowincome housing project in Forest Hills have begun to peep out of the muddy ground on 108th Street like spring buds, part mystery and part promise.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GROWTH This is a big day for the Negro Ensemble Company, which was born under modest circumstances only a halfdozen years ago. There are two big events taking place in its, life tonight. For one, at 6:45, the company opens in Joseph A. Walker's The River Niger on Broadway, where it has not been before. The run at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street (2453430), which will, after, opening, have an 8 P.M. curtain, brings the play uptown from the company's downtown headquarters, where it has had a successful go. This is the first black ensemble, and one with a black backstage staff, too, to come to Broadway in several decades.

title: Saigon Peace Candidate Released After 5 Years
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 26  Truong Dinh Dzu, a peace candidate in the 1967 presidential election, was released from jail today after nearly five years in which he was one of South Vietnam's hestknown political prisoners.

title: 343 Cardiac Pacemakers Are Recalled for a Defect
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)  Medtronic, Inc., announced today that it had recalled 343 external cardiac pacemakers with a defective design that could have interfered with the lifegiving electrical stimulus to heart patients.

title: State Unit Urges City To Shut Down Civil Jail
description: ALBANY, March 26The State Commission of Correction again urged New York City today to shut down the Civil Jail at 434 West 37th Street because of unsafe and unsanitary conditions.

title: Houses Pets Include a 9001b. Elephant
description: GILLETTE, N.J., March 26I wanted an elephant for so long that when we finally got her, I hardly talked to my husband and children for weeks, Elizabeth Hammond said, fending off the gentle nuzzlings of her 11monthold, 900pound pet. I spent every minute with the elephant. It was almost embarrassing. I'm surprised my family didn't walk out.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Norton Company announced yesterday that it had signed two contracts worth about $2.5million with a Soviet Government agency providing for the construction by the Soviet Union of a pulpstone manufacturing plant and for export of pulpstones to that country. The contract covers Norton technology, machinery and equipment to produce advanced pulpstones to the Soviet Union.

title: City Tax Records Rived Apparent Discrepancies
description: Tax Commission records disclosed by the city show apparent discrepancies involving substantial reductions taxassessment valuation granted last year to two of midtown's, largest new skyscrapers:

title: GEORGE ROSIER
description: George Rosier, senior partner in the law firm of Hellerstein, Rosier & Rernbar, died of heart attack yesterday while Oh vacation in Scottsdale, Ariz: He was 64 years old and lived at 3 East 71st Street.

title: Con Ed Said to Pressure City to Buy Electricity
description: A former city commissioner charged yesterday that Consolidated Edison put pressure on the City of New York to abandon the generating of electricity from waste methane gas at its sewage plants and buy its power from the utility instead.

title: 6 YANK PITCHERS CUT, 3 SPOTS OPEN
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 26Proving again that it's not what a player shows a manager in spring training but what the manager is looking for that counts, the Yankees cut six pitchers today. Three had allowed a total of only two earned runs in 19 exhibition innings.

title: L.I. Woman Was Strangled
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, March 26 (Reuters)A Boston College student, Deborah Kraskey, who was found dead in a closet at a luxury hotel here, had been strangled, according to a Postmortem examination. Miss Kraskey, 23 years old, of Huntington, L. I., had been gagged and stabbed when she was found in the closet a day after she had checked into the Trinidad Hilton. Her father is an Eastern Airlines pilot.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: MARCHI WILL SEEK G.O.P. NOMINATION; LEADERS BACK HIM
description: State Senator John J. Marchi announced yesterday his candidacy for the Republican mayoral nomination and several hours later was endorsed by the New York State G.O.P. chairman and the five Republican county leaders in the city.

title: Marriage and Pregnancy Curbs On WAC Enlistees Are Eased
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Army has canceled several restrictions on the marriage and pregnancy status of women who want to join the Women's Army Corps.

title: Menninger Scores Jail as Futile Curb To Crime by Youths
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Angrily calling the jail just as much an anachronism as slavery was, Dr. Karl Menninger, the psychiatrist and author, told a Senate hearing today that the way to reduce juvenile delinquency was through prevention rather than punishment.

title: Stage: A Crisp Macbeth
description: The CSC Repertory Theater, an enterprising unit in Greenwich Village, has Milted Macbeth on like a glove: There's no strutting, potturing or bloodthirsty bellowing down at 89 West Third Street. This is a crisp, headon production whose tightened, authoritative concept means business and misses little of the Bard.

title: HitandRun Driver Here Kills 1 Man and Injures Another
description: A man was killed and his brother seriously injured by a hitandrun driver early yesterday at Lexington Avenue and 97th Street. The police said there were indications that the two men were crossing the intersection diagonally and that the car, described by witnesses as a blue sedan, was driving at excessive speed.

title: People in Sports: Walton's Plea;
description: Bill Walton, the University of California, Los Angeles, center who is everybody's selection as college basketball player of the year, is reported to have drafted a letter to President Nixon, asking him to intervene so that Walton and other collegiate nonseniors may play for the United States in the forthcoming basketball series against the Soviet Union.

title: Wooden Hails Members Of Bruins' Walton Gang
description: ST. LOUIS, March 25 (AP)When we were going against the kind of defense we faced we'd have been foolish not to go to him with the ball, Coach John Wooden of the University of California, Los Angeles, said last night after the basketball team won another national title.

title: Mrs. Boggs Gets House Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)The House voted today to enlarge the Banking Committee by one seat to make room for Mrs. Corinne Boggs, who will be sworn in as a House member tomorrow to succeed her late husband, Hale Boggs, who was majority leader. The socalled committee on committees voted to assign Mrs. Boggs to the key Banking Committee post, despite Democratic vacancies on four other House panels. The House approved the new committee seat by voice vote without debate.

title: Islanders' LineUp
Fiat '72 Net $28Million; Depreciation Not Included
description: TURIN, Italy, March 26 (AP) Fiat, Italy's biggest private company and one of Europe's major car makers, announced today net earnings of $28million for 1972.

title: Cambodia Regime Seizes Opportunity To Tighten Its Grip and Curb Its Foes
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 23  The Government of President Lon Nol has taken advantage of two violent incidents that occurred on March 17 to neutralize its internal opposition and consolidate its absolute power.

title: SENATORS BRIEFED ON M'CORD TALKS; NIXON BACKS DEAN
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Senate's special committee on the Watergate conspiracy met privately today to hear a synopsis of two long interviews its staff held last week with James W. McCord Jr.

title: Extortion of $40,000 In RealEstate Deal Laid to Hof stra Aide
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 26A former assistant president and assistant to the dean of students at Hofstra University surrendered today on two charges of grand larceny in the alleged extortion of $40,000 in a realestate deal involving the university.

title: PhaseOut of O.E.O. Scored at Hearings
description: A new word was coined yesterday at the House Subcommittee on Equal Opportunity hearings at 26 Federal Plaza on the proposed dismantling of the Office of Eco nomic Opportunity.

title: The Theater World Pays Its Tributes
description: Following are some of the tributes paid yesterday to Sir Nol Coward by leaders in the world of theater:

title: Frederick Matthaei Sr. Dies; Detroit Industrialist Was 80
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 26 (AP)Frederick C. Matthaei Sr., Detroit industrialist, philanthropist and sportsman, died yesterday in University Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: Denver Bank Is Insolvent
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)Acting Comptroller of the Currency Justin T. Watson announced today that the Skyline National Bank of Denver has been declared insolvent and ordered closed. Skyline National had deposits of approximately $6million. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was named receiver for the bank.

title: Stilling Drug Hysteria
description: The National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse has just issued a carefully documented final report that is sweeping in scope and fully reflective of twoyear effort to dig into the difficult area of excessive drug use in modern society. The report's major contribution is to substitute a calm appraisal for the nation's lingering hysteria about drugs, especially in regard to their use by the young. It is perhaps a measure of this hysteria that the report found it necessary to reassure Americans that the drug problem will not collapse our society.

title: House Pets Include 900Pound Elephant, Snakes, Etc.
description: GILLETTE, March 26I wanted an elephant for so long that when we finally got her, I hardly talked to my husband and children for weeks, Elizabeth Hammond said, fending off the gentle nuzzlings of her 11monthold, 900pound pet. I spent every minute with the elephant. It was almost embarrassing. I'm surprised my family didn't walk out.

title: MARCHI WILL SEEK G.O.P. NOMINATION; LEADERS BACK HIM
description: State Senator John J. Marchi announced yesterday his candidacy for the Republican mayoral nomination and several hours later was endorsed by the New York State G.O.P. chairman and the five Republicans, county leaders in the city.

title: SENATORS BRIEFED ON M'CORD TALKS; NIXON SACKS DEAN
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Senate's special committee on the Watergate conspiracy met privately today to hear a synopsis of two long interviews its staff held last week with James W. McCord Jr.

title: 12 Million Will Receive Increase in Food Stamps
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)  The Agriculture Department announced today that 12 million needy persons in the Government's food stamp prograrn would get an increase amounting to 3.6 per cent or $4 per month for a family of four. But the new allowances, effective July 1, will be less beneficial to families with incomes at the upper end of the poverty scale.

title: ISRAEL IMPRISONS SIX FOR TREASON
description: TEL AVIV, March 26An Israeli Arab and a Jew who were key figures in a Syriansponsored spy and sabotage ring were sentenced to 17 years imprisonment for treason by the Haifa District Court today.

title: Advertising Carvel TV Sundae
description: Those of you who have become fans or Thomas Carvel through his radio commercials will be pleased and happy to learn that he may soon be promoting his franchise icecream chain on TV as well.

title: U.C.L.A. Wins 70th Title in Row
