description: ST. LOUIS, March 26Bill Walton put on one of the greatest performances in college basketball tournament history tonight leading his University of California, Los Angeles team to its seventh straight National Collegiate Athletic Association championship.

title: Saigon and Vietcong Again Fail To Agree on Agenda for Parley
description: PARIS, March 26Vietcong and Saigon delegations met today for about two hours but failed for the third time to agree on an agenda for negotiations leading to national elections in South Vietnam.

title: GasStorage Tank Called Threat to Sports Complex
description: RUTHERFORD, March 26A citizens coalition called today for a halt in construction of the sports complex in the Hackensack Meadows until the building, of a huge and dangerous liquidgas storage tank nearby is stopped.

title: Blue Accepts, A's Pact After Talk With Finley
description: PHOENIX, March 25 (AP) Vida Blue, Ooakland A's pitcher, is reported to have signed a contract for an undisclosed amount today.

title: City Tax Records on Two Skyscrapers Granted Major Tax Reductions Show Apparent Discrepancies
description: Tax Commission records disclosed by the city show apparent discrepancies involving substantial reductions in taxassessment valuation granted last year to two of midtown's largest new skyscrapers.

title: Survivor Says Seas Quickly Engulfed Freighter
description: The only known survivor of a Norwegian freighter that foundered in an Atlantic storm last Thursday was quoted by the Coast Guard yesterday as having said his vessel went down only five minutes after the order was given to abandon, ship.

title: The Wagner Decision
description: The basic decency that has always characterized former Mayor Wagner was reflected in his decision to dissociate himself from the maneuvering that was supposed to deliver him the Republican mayoral nomination.

title: Ellsberg Trial in Recess
description: LOS ANGELES, March 26The Pentagon papers trial of Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. will resume in United States District Court here to morrow. It was in a oneday recess today to allow the judge to do othercourt work and because Leonard I. Weinglass, one of the defense attorneys, had to appear in Chicago for pretrial hearing on a contempt of court charge growing out of the Chicago Seven trial. Mr. Weinglass was a defense attorney in that case.

title: Daitch Official Denies Guilt In Beef Conspiracy Case
description: An official of a New York City supermarket chain pleaded not guilty yesterday to Federal charges of conspiring to bribe meat buyers and labor officials to overcome resistance to boxed beef shipped from Nebraska and Iowa to the New York area.

title: Dance: Three Programs
description: The poetic leanness of Merce Cunningham's new Changing Steps was mixed with his fluttery, humorous Solo and Borst Park in Event No. 68 Sunday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Despite momentary felicities, the event was exhausting to watch and eventually selfdestructive.

title: Women on the Campaign Trail: No Longer Just Serving Coffee
description: Hours after the birth of a son, Bonnie Lobel was back on the telephone, campaigning from her hospital bed for Herman Badillo. She had been working at Badillo headquarters until two days before the birth.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Norton Company announced yesterday that it had signed two contracts worth about $2.5million with a Soviet Government agency providing for the construction by the Soviet Union of a pulpstone manufacturing plant and for export of pulpstones to that country. The contract covers Norton technology, machinery and equipment to produce advanced pulpstones in the Soviet Union.

title: Union Asks Seat on Board
description: AKRON, Ohio, March 26 (AP) The United Rubber Workers has proposed that the General Tire and Rubber Company appoint a union member to the company's board of directors. A company spokesman said he thought it was unlikely the company would agree to the idea.

title: Supreme Court Spurns Appeal by Hulan Jack
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 The United States Supreme Court today declined to hear an appeal of the conspiracy convictions of former New York State Assemblyman Hulan E. Jack and a Harlem union official, L. Joseph Overton and Jack, who was still in office at the time, were found guilty by a Federal District Court jury last year of conspiring in a shakedown scheme to force Harlem grocers into pushing the products of a food promotion company headed by Jack.

title: Cloud Stirs Fire Alarm
description: CHICAGO, March 26 (UPI)A low hanging cloud shrouded the 100story John Hancock Center early today, resulting in an alarm that brought 20 pieces of firefighting equipment and 100 firemen to the skyscraper. Fire officials said the alarm was sounded when the lowhanging, brown cloud of vapor was taken for smoke.

title: Sir Noel Coward, Playwright, Dies at 73
description: Sir Nol Coward, whose light sharp wit had enlivened the English, stage for half a century as actor, playwright, songwriter, composer and director, died of a heart attack as he was preparing to have morning coffee yesterday in his villa, Blue Harbor, on the north coast of Jamaica in the West Indies. He was 73 years op.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 27, 1973

title: British Soccer Results
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Writers Elect Radding
description: ST. LOUIS, March 26 (AP)Jerry Radding of The Springfield, (Mass.) Union, was elected president of the United States Basketball Writers Association today.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In The Times of Feb. 26, Walter Levy, a leading oil economist, urged U. S. initiative to create and coordinate a common approach on energy matters by major oil importing countries against the whipsawing by oil producing countries working through the Organization of Oil Producing Countries.

title: HANOI CONCLUDING A PHASE IN TRUCE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 27  A North Vietnamese spokesman said last night that his country intended to withdraw its delegation to the FourParty Joint Military Commission in South Vietnam by the end of the week.

title: Mrs. Charles F. Darlington, Civic Leader, Is Dead
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., March 26  Mrs. Alice Nelson Benning Darlington, who was active for many years in the Society of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center and the Metropolitan Opera Guild in New York, died Saturday of cancer in Northern Westchester Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived on Charles Road.Mrs. Darlington was the wife of Charles Francis Darlington, a former executive of the Mobil Oil Corporation and Ambassador to Gabon from 1961 to 1965. With her husband, Mrs. Darlington was coauthor of African Betrayal, an account of their in Gabon.From 1968 to 1971, Mrs. Darlington was managing director of the Metropolitan Opera Guild and at her death was a member of its executive committee. She had been a member of the guild's board since 1954 and had served as chairman of its executive and education committees.

title: Amtrak Buying Locomotives
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)Amtrack announced today the purchase of 15 highspeed locomotives from General Electric at a cost of $10million.

title: TV Review
description: Strictly as entertainment, television shows constructed around awards ceremonies follow a rather predictable pattern. The Grammys for music are usually the, worst. The Topys for theater are generally the best.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Drop at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Governmen's weekly competitiev sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: JOINTTAPE PLANS ENCOUNTER DELAY
description: Plans for a combined stock tape, considered a key element in the muchdiscussed central market system designed to give investors better access to the nation's stock exchanges, have run into controversy and delays.

title: MALAVE SCORES KNOCKOUT IN 6TH
description: Edwin (Chu Chu) Malave landed a bellringing left to the head and knocked out Percy Hayles of Kingston, Jamaica in 39 seconds of the sixth round before a partisan crowd of 2,276 in the Felt Forum last night.

title: BANKS BOW TO U.S. ON 6% LOAN RATE
description: After a week of dispute with the Nixon Administration, the nation's bankers managed yesterday to put through a general increase in the prime, or minimum, rate on loans to large corporations to 6 per cent from 6 per cent.

title: Metropolitan Briefs.
description: New York University's School of Engineering will be merged with the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute to form a new engineering school.

title: Survivor Says Seas Quickly Engulfed Freighter
description: The only known survivor of a Norwegian freighter that foundered in an Atlantic storm last Thursday was quoted by the Coast Guard yesterday as having said his vessel went down only five minutes after the order was given to abandon ship.

title: Rhodesia Planning Enclaves for Blacks Like South Africa's
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 26  The Rhodesian Government took the first step today toward the establishment of Bantustans, semiautonomous tribal regions on the South African pattern.

title: DRYSDALE UPSETS DIBLEY IN TWO SETS
description: ST. LOUIS, March 25 (AP)Unseeded Cliff Drysdale of South Africa sprang a major upset tonight when he edged Colin Dibley of Australia 64, 7.6, in a firstround match of the $50,000 Holton Tennis Classic.

title: Slater, Walker Will Seek Stock of Franklin Stores
description: The Franklin Stores Corporation and Slater, Walker of American, Ltd., said yesterday a tentative agreement had been reached whereby Slater and a number of its associates would make a tender offer for 65 per cent of Franklin's common stock at $21 a share. Franklie's principal shareholders and management said they would tender their shares.

title: Traffic in Looted Maya Art Is Diverse and Profitable
description: MERIDA, MexicoThe priceless art treasures extracted from the ruins of the Maya and other preColumbian civilizations make their way to the American and European art markets along, a chain that involves a bizarre assortment of characters.

title: Boston Ace Sets Record For Scoring
description: Making it look easy, Phil Esposito has become the first man in National Hockey League history to turn in three straight 50goal seasons. The Boston Bruins' big gunner, who shoots the puck more than anyone else in the game, has 51 goals, thanks to a twogoal night against the Buffalo Sabres on Sunday. He has 122 points, 25 more than the Philadelphia Flyers' Bobby Clarke, the leading candidate for most valuable player.

title: Production of Steel At a Record Pace In the Latest Week
description: Steel production continued its recordbreaking pace through the week ended March 24, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: SOFT ROCK IS TREND FOR PAUL WILLIAMS
description: Generational differences faded away at Paul Williams' concert Sunday night at Tully Hall. An actor and songwriter (often in collaboration with Roger Nicols) for such as Tom Jones, Andy Williams, Dionne Warwicke, Johnny Mathis, Three Dog Night, Bobby Sherman and the Carpenters, Mr. Williams presents a repertory that reflects the variety suggested by that list. One might loosely describe it as soft rock, but the softness is such that the links to musical comedy and the whole tradition of Tin Pan Alley seem paramount. Mr. Williams has a nice, serviceable voice and an engaging if rather theatrical stage manner. His arrangementsfor a rock/cabaret quintet and string quartet obbligatosounded deft and discreetly lush. All in all, a pleasantly entertaining hourandaquarter.

title: Stocks, in Late Rebound, Advance 5.19 to 927.90
description: After seven declining sessions in a row, the stock market reversed itself late yesterday afternoon and closed with a fairly strong advance in moderate trading.

title: MAY 1 TARGET IS SET BY U.S AND MARKET
description: GENEVA, March 26  The United States and the European Economic Community hope to complete by May 1 their preliminary examination of Washington's request for trade concessions because of damage it has cited resulting from the enlargement of the Common Market.

title: Clements Bids Grumman Raise Efficiency to Get Orders for F14
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Deputy Defense Secretary William P. Clements said today that the Grumman Corporation would have to make some real significant changes in its internal management if the company expected additional orders for the Navy's F14 fighter.

title: HighSchool R.O.T.C. Measure Is Defeated, 7066, in Assembly
description: ALBANY, March 26  The Assembly defeated a controversial bill tonight that would have permitted local school boards to establish reserve officers training courses for highschool youths.

title: U.S. Executives to Form Group for Chinese Trade
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 A highlevel group of American business executives has decided  under United States Government auspices  to form a special organization to promote American trade with China.

title: 2 Are Seized With Hashish
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 26 (UPI)The United States Customs Service announced today the arrest of two Pakistani nationals and the seizure of 80 pounds of hashish valued at $360,000. Edward T. Coyne, chief customs service officer in Philadelphia, said that Ahmed Jan, a 26yearold deck officer on the German freighter Falkensels, and Abdul Roue, 32, who was found to be an alien illegally living in Brooklyn, were arrested yesterday.

title: Second Ave. Bank Robbed
description: A 6foot, 5inch bank robber wearing a dark trench coat and armed with a small handgun held up the branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank at 2065 Second Avenue at East 105th Street yesterday and escaped with more than $1,000. The police say the robber entered the bank shortly before 1 P.M. and handed a note to a teller. The teller gave the bandit between $1,000 and $2,500, and he ran from the bank.

title: DEAN PHONE CALL TO GRAY VERIFIED
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 The White House acknowledged today that John W. Dean 3d, President Nixon's counsel, had asked L. Patrick Gray. 3d, the acting F.B.I. director, to correct his allegation that Mr. Dean probably lied to Federal agents investigating the Watergate Case.

title: Athens Students Agree to Talks With University Aides
description: ATHENS, March 26Athens University students ended an eightweek strike today and agreed to designate spokesmen to negotiate their grievances with university authorities.

title: Canada's Trade Surplus Declined During February
description: OTTAWA, March 26 (Reuters)Canada's trade balance with all countries dropped $35.2million in February to $125.1million, Canada Statistics reported today.

title: Proposed Rules on Discrimination in Fund Sharing Held Inadequate
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Representatives of minority tions charged today that the Government's proposed regulalions for preventing discriminafirm in programs financed by revenue sharing were inadequate.

title: Percy Says U.S. Is on Brink of a Major Breakthrough in Attempt to Change Ideas on Work
description: The United States is on the brink of a major breakthrough in the effort to change our ideas about work, Senator Charles H. Percy said here yesterday in a speech to the National Conference on the Changing Work Ethic.

title: ExMine Union Aide Guilty In Murder of 3 Yablonskis
description: ERIE, Pa., March 26William J. Prater, a former organizer for the United Mine Workers, was convicted of firstdegree murder tonight in the 1969 slayings of Joseph A. Yablonski,, mine union reform leader, and his wife and daughter.

title: Wagner Denies That Marchi's Plans Played a Part in Decision on G.O.P.
description: What happened during the fourandahalf hours between the time that Robert F. Wagner, with carefully gauged public irritation, dismissed some Republican leaders as peanut politicians and the hastily distributed statement in which he ruled himself out of the Republican primary?

title: George Sisler Dies at 80
description: George Sister, a member of the baseball Hall of Fame, died yesterday at St. Mary's Health Center in Richmond, Mo. Sisler, 80 years old, had been hospitalized for more than a week. An account of his life appears on Page 50.

title: H.E.W. to Aid Children With Career Choices
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced plans today to show portions of an animated film series on career choices on the Captain Kangaroo television program for young children Monday, Wednesday and Friday from April 2 through May 7.

title: Court Bars Review of Harvard Professor's Contempt Citation
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Supreme Court declined today to review the contempt citation of a Harvard professor who had refused to answer grand jury questions because he believed a scholar had the right to keep confidential the sources of his information.

title: Santa Fe to Expand
description: Santa Fe Industries, Inc., plans capital expenditures this year of about $200million, up 67 per cent from the $119.7million spent in 1972, according to the annual report. The spending program will cover $145million for the company's railroad subsidiary, the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway.

title: MEAT CONTRACTS SHOW DOWNTURN
description: The consumer won several battles vicariously in the futures trading markets yesterday. Consumer resistance to high meat prices apparently influenced some selling in beef cattle, live hogs and pork bellies yesterday.

title: Wheeling, Dealing At N.I.T.
description: The atmosphere of the National Invitation Tournament is becoming more and more like a highpressure market place where college basketball scholarships are up for grabs, coaches are jobhunting and agents and pro scouts are in almost constant negotiations. Never did the flesh peddling appear more flagrant than in the N.I.T. that ended Sunday.

title: Wet Skiers Elevate Lowly Garbage Bag
description: KINGFIELD, Me. What's new in skiing apparel? Garbage bags. Those green or sandcolored polyethylene bags that cost about 10 cents each may well put a drier approach on skiing.

title: Chess: Development Rules Can Bend, But Break at Your Own Risk
description: Rules for development in chess are designed primarily for beginners. They substitute a stock, ultraroutine strategy for the genuine article in order not to interfere with the neophyte's proper preoccupation with keeping the attack and defense paths of the pieces clear in his mind.

title: 2 IN HEROIN PLOT RECEIVE 30 YEARS
description: Maximum sentences of 30 years in prison were meted out yesterday to two overseas Chinese who Were convicted of a scheme to smuggle heroin into this country from Southeast Asia.

title: PEPSICO SOVIET UNIT SET FOR NOVEMBER
description: Donald M. Kendall, chairman of Pepsico, Inc., said yesterday that the softdrink company would open its plant in the Soviet Union in late November.

title: Republican Leader in Illinois Is Held on Fraud Charge
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 21 (UPI)  State Representative William D. Cox was arrested today by Federal agents, and charged with swindling the state out of $17,000 for undone secretarial work and filing false Federal income tax returns in furtherance of this scheme.

title: Rail Crisis Drawing Variety of Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 A variety of plans for solving the plight of railroads have been offered, the most recent of which was nationalization, which was proposed by Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio. Other major proposals are as follows:

title: State Moves to Bar Sale of PapTest Kit Through Mail Order
description: An advertisement in magazines says: Millions of women find it easier to face cancer of the cervix than face a Pap test in a doctor's office.

title: PREY'S LIED SINGING RICHLY SATISFYING
description: For vocal beauty, a fresh interpretational point of view and musical sensitivity, Hermann Prey has few rivals as an exponent of the German lied. His program at Tully Hall late Sunday afternoon was devoted to Schubert and was a richly satisfying experience from first note to last.

title: U.S. Executives to Form Group for Chinese Trade
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 A highlevel group of American business executives has decided  under United States Government auspices  to form a special organization to promote American trade with China.

title: Wheeling, Dealing At N.I.T.
description: The atmosphere of the National Invitation Tournament is becoming more and more like a highpressure market place where college basketball scholarships are up for grabs, coaches are jobhunting and agents and pro scouts are in almost constant negotiations. Never did the flesh peddling appear more flagrant than in the N.I.T. that ended Sunday.

title: FOOD PRICE RISES LINKED TO DEMAND
description: The middlemen in the food industrythe wholesalers, distributors and shipperstold a Congressional hearing here yesterday that food prices were skyrocketing because demand continued to increase while, in many cases, supplies had been diminished.

title: Wynette and Jones Present, in Songs, Flavor of Nashville
description: Not many people knew it, perhaps, but Sunday in New York was. Country Music Day, officially declared so by Mayor Lindsay. The reason for the accolade was the Philharmonic Hall appearance of the Tammy WynetteGeorge Jones Show, the first in a Country in New York series.

title: MAY I TARGET IS SET BY U.S. AND MARKET
description: GENEVA, March 26  The United States and the European Economic Community hope to complete by May 1 their preliminary examination of Washington's request for trade concessions because of damage it has cited resulting from the enlargement of the Common Market.

title: FINAL 148 P.O.W.'S WILL BE RELEASED IN NEXT TWO DAYS
description: MIAMI, March 26 The White House announced today that agreement had been reached to complete by Thursday the release of the last of the United States prisoners of war in Indochina and the with drawal of the remaining American combat forces from South Vietnam.

title: MISS ENGDAHL BEST IN SOFT PIANO MUSIC
description: If a program could be constructed entirely out of slow movements, Lenore Engdahl might be just the artist for it. The pianist plays quiet music with insight, restraint and a lovely tone, qualities that rapidly disintegrate with the arrival of more technically strenuous material.

title: Inquiry Asked on Shooting Of Truce Aide in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 26 (Reuters)  The FourParty Joint Military Commission was asked today to investigate the shooting of a jeep carrying three Indonesian members of the peacekeeping force in the Mekong Delta town of Can Tho yesterday.

title: Traffic in Looted Maya Art Is Diverse and Profitable
description: This is the second of three articles on the theft and destruction of important relics from the ruins of the ancient Mayan civilization in southern Mexico and Central America.

title: U.S. ACTS TO CURE COST OF ROUSING
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Nikon Administration announced today that it was moving to check skyrocketing housing costs by increasing the cutting of trees from national forests, thus increasing the lumber, supply, and by seeking voluntary agreement by the Japanese to hold down their purchase of American timber.

title: BAKER AND NEWMAN PLAY BACH SONATAS
description: The possibilities for assembling different aflBach concerts are infinite, although a program of the seven lightweight flute sonatas may not be everyone's first choice (three of them are spurious works in any case). Julius Baker, solo flutist of the New York Philharmonic, with Anthony Newman, harpsichord, and Nathan Stutch, cello, collaborated on the complete canon in Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, and they clearly thought very highly of the music, which is what really counts.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE ART CROWD. By Sophy Burnham. 395 pages. McKay. $8.95.

title: M'CORD REJECTED LENIENCY OFFERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The chief prosecutor in the Watergate trial disclosed tonight that James W. McCord Jr. one of those convicted, had twice turned down Government offers of reduced charges in return for telling what he knew about the case.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Deadlock in Turkey
description: In a country with as much experience of democratic practice as Turkey it was inevitable that elected members of Parliament would not accept dictation from the armed forces indefinitely. The refusal of a majority in the Grand National Assembly to elect the military's candidate for President, Gen. Faruk Gurler, and the subsequent defeat of a compromise bid to extend for two years the term of President Cevdet Sunay have intensified a constitutional crisis long in the making.

title: LEADERS CONFER ON ATLANTIC TIES
description: AMSTERDAM, March 26Some 350 delegates representing a generation of European and American leadership met here today and expressed an urgent need to renew a sense of community on the two sides of the Atlantic.

title: Bernard J. Rahilly Dead; An Official of W. R. Grace
description: Bernard J. Rahilly, vice president for corporate administration of W. R. Grace & Co., died Saturday at his home, 355 Woodland Avenue, Westfield, N.J. He was 55 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 27, 1973

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: MAGEE TRIAL JUDGE GIVES CASE TO JURY
description: SAN FRANCISCO (UPI) A jury of six men and and six women began deliberations Monday at murderkidnapping trial of Ruchell Magee after the San Quentin convict ended proceedings the way he started them four months ago, shouting names at the judge.

title: Record Sales and Earnings Figures Are Reported by Two Large Retail Chains
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation and the Allied Stores Corporation, two major merchandise chains, rang up record sales and earnings in the final quarter and fiscal year ended last January, the annual reports disclosed yesterday.

title: Loews Is Planning to Seek Stock of Talcott National
description: The Loews Corporation announced yesterday it intended to make a tender offer today to buy the common stock of the Talcott National Corporation at $17 a share. Talcott has about 3.3 million common shares outstanding

title: Davits and Buckley Screen 900 Nominees for Cadets at Service Academies
description: I like the idea that it's one of the best educational institutions in the country, and I've wanted to be in the Navy since I was 14, said George E. Manaskie of Bellmore, L.I.

title: A.B.A. Basketball
description: Fouled outBrown, Wuycik, C. Jones, Hallmon.

title: WEINTRAUB PLANS TO LEAVE COURT
description: TRENTON, March 26 Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub of the New Jersey Supreme Court announced today that he would retire from the bench on Aug. 31, leaving a record of judicial leadership under which the court drew a pragmatic line against permissive criminal decisions and mandated strong new consumer protections.

title: Johns Hopkins Tops Poll
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 26 (UPI)Johns Hopkins replaced Maryland today as the top team in the weekly poll of the United States intercollegiate Lacrosse Association.

title: Dealers Say Removal of Art Preserves It
description: If you walk up to a policeman in Mexico and ask for a Mayan relief, he would probably take you to his house. The problem is obviously not an American problemit is a Mexican problem. Prohibition never worked and never will work. I am against the destruction of monuments, but if you ask would I rather have a wall collapse at a Mayan site or have it in New York, I would rather have it in New York.

title: Sir Noel Coward, Playwright, Dies at 73
description: Sir Noel Coward, whose light sharp wit had enlivened the English stage for half a century as actor, playwright, songwriter, composer and director, died of a heart attack as he was preparing to have morning coffee yesterday in his villa, Blue Harbor, on the north coast of Jamaica in the West Indies. He was 73 years old.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 49

title: Police Share Political Files With Others
description: The Police Department shares information about the political activities of some New Yorkers with 11 city agencies, 16 specified Federal agencies, 5 state agencies and the intelligence units of local police departments throughout the United States.

title: ADOPTION OF 3 ASKED IN CHILD SALE CASE
description: JOLIET, Ill., March 26 (UPI) County authorities asked a family court judge today to put up for adoption the three children of a couple charged with selling their daughter.

title: A.T.&T. Issue Sells Well As Bond Prices Advance
description: With the fixedincome market brightening, the American Telephone and Telegraph company's mammoth $500million preferred  stock offering was priced late yesterday to give investors a yield of 7.28 per rent, and apparently the stock as pretty well spoken for. Prices advanced yesterday in most parts of the bond market. From Treasury bills to longterm Government and corporate bonds, most issues rose in price and declined in yield as traders reacted to Washington's efforts to clamp some sort of lid on borrowing costs.

title: People and Business
description: Roy C. Satchell has resigned as president of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, effective April 1 after only six weeks in the post. He said in a statement issued by the company that his reasons were wholly personal. He also has resigned as a director of the company.

title: Fun City Fun Game
description: When Nelson Rockefeller (a Republican) joins Alex Rose (a Liberal) to elect Robert Wagner (a Democrat) Mayor of New York (a mess), people are naturally going to ask, What's going on here? Here are the answers to that and other mystifying questions about the macabre politics of Fun City:

title: Active U.S. Role Hinted on Energy And Environment
description: The Government will probably have to take a more ac tive role in reconciling the nation's environmental and energy requirements if the United States is to avoid long  term problems, Darrell M. Trent, acting director of the Office of Emergency Preparedness, said yesterday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Last June's Hurricane Agnes halted oyster reproduction and killed most of the softshelled clams in Chesapeake Bay, but there is at least one happy note in the dirge of destruction: Surging flood waters created several new islands near the mouth of the Susquehanna River, and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources hopes that plantings of grasses and other plants will, stabilize the islands and provide resting areas for waterfowl and other wildlife.

title: MAYOR BIDS STATE REPEAL RENT LAW
description: Mayor Lindsay called on the Legislature yesterday to repeal the state's vacancydecontrol law, saying that rent increases in apartments removed from rent control under the law were commonly ranging from 70 per cent to 150 per cent.

title: Two Speakers at Jewish Parley Call for Rise in Women's Status
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Two speakers at a convention of the National Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress called today for a reinterpretation of traditional Jewish law restricting the role of women outside the home.

title: State Sums Up in H. Rap Brown Trial
description: The prosecutor at the H. Rap Brown trial summed up his case yesterday, accusing defense lawyers of diversionary tactics, speculation and innuendo.

title: RATE OF GROWTH IN RELIEF DROPS
description: ALBANY, March 26  The state's Commissioner of Social Services reported today that a 4.4 per cent growth rate in the state's welfare case load last year was the lowest since 1968.

title: World's Financial Chiefs Start Money Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 The first working session at the ministerial level of, the Committee of 20 nations set up to negotiate world monetary reform began here today.

title: METS WIN BY 52 AS MAYS HOMERS
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26Eleven days before the baseball season starts, a subtle change is taking place in the New York Mets' relationship with Willie Mays: For the first time, they need him more than he needs them.

title: Coward: Suave Symbol of an Era
description: With the death of Sir Noel Coward, the nineteentwenties, the thirties, even the forties move a little farther into the distance. Suave, debonair, Cowward was essentially a symbol of a more leisurely, perhaps more elegant time. He did so many things well that there might be a tendency to forget just how well he did them. First and foremost he was a playwright. He wrote plays all his life, a surprising number of them unproduced and unpublished. Three of his plays could probably enter the permanent repertory Hay Fever, Private Lives and Design for Living. These are some of the best comedies in the English tradition. They have a certain passion, and durable thinness (despite his promise once only to write fat plays to please fat critics) like a razor blade.

title: Continental Illinois Plans Realistic Stand on Rates
description: CHICAGO, March 26 (Reuters)  Donald Graham, chairman of the Continental Illinois Corporation, told the annual meeting today that the onebank holding company will do its utmost to keep its future options on primerate adjustments open to the realities of the marketplace.

title: METS WIN BY 62 AS MAYS HOMERS
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26Eleven days before the baseball season starts, subtle change is taking place in the New York Mets' relationship with Willie Mays: For the first time, they need him more than he needs them.

title: Multiracial Soccer Opens South African Games ...
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 26  White and nonwhite soccer teams competed for the first time here tonight in the South African Games. Visiting sports officials said that the multiracial event marked a milestone that could help put South Africa back into the Olympics.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)The Supreme Court ruled today that new court hearings may not be ordered when adverse findings of the Controller of the Currency in approving new national banks are deemed inadequate. In a brief, unsigned opinion, the Court said in a South Carolina case that the remedy was to vacate the Controller's decision and send the matter back to him.

title: CAMBODIANS REPORT CLASH NEAR CAPITAL
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 26 (Reuters)Communist troops reportedly clashed with Government soldiers today only five miles west of Phmom Penh's city boundary.

title: OldTime Country By Highwoods Five Sets Feet Tapping
description: The lively sound of bluegrass music, which is usually heard at the concerts of the Bluegrass Club of New York, was replaced by the equally lively sound of oldtime country music at the club's concert on Sunday at the New York University Law School, 40 Washington Square South.

title: Nixon Gives the G.O.P. Chairman More Authority as White House Prepares for 1974 National Elections
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 When a Republican Governor from the Weft called at the White House a few weeks ago to discuss a political matter, he was told he was in the wrong place. The people he wanted to see, he was told by the White House staff, were at the Republican National Committee.

title: Mothers Seize DayCare Offices to Protest New Form
description: About 500 personsmainly working mothers and their childrentook over the offices of the city's Agency for Child Development yesterday to protest its requirement that they fill out incomeeligibility forms.

title: NIMZOINDIAN DEFENSE
Judge Denies Plea for Bail For Woman, ExNazi Guard
description: Federal Judge Jacob Mishler) denied a request for bail yesterday by the lawyer for Mrs. Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan, whose extradition has been sought by West Germany to face murder charges.

title: Robert Goldwater, Critic, Dies; Led Museum of Primitive Art
description: Robert Goldwater, a leading American art critic, scholar and teacher, died yesterday at his home here. He was 65 years old and lived at 347 West 20th Street.

title: DISCLOSURE BILL CAUSES IMPASSE
description: TRENTON, March 26 Senate Republican leaders were deadlocked today over the question of imposing criminal or civil penalties on candidates who violate the provisions of a proposed campaigndisclosure law.

title: Prince Revels in A Litt Night Music
description: Almost every year Harold Prince sits on the aisle at the annual Tony Awards and makes at least one joyful trek to the stageas he did Sunday night to receive a Tony as the producer of the season's best musical, A Little Night Music.

title: Guerrillas Denounce Jordan On Black September Report
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 26 (UPI)Palestinian guerrillas denounced Jordan yesterday for publicizing what she said was a jailed Al Fatah leader's confession that Black September was nothing but a name that Fatah used occasionally for operations.

title: Senior Citizens Month Set
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 26 (AP)Proclaiming May to be Senior Citizens Month, President Nixon said today that it is a time for all people to renew the recognition, the respect and the active concern which properly belong to older Americans. Mr. Nixon said that most older people are not mere onlookers in our soceity. They remain vital, versatile and highly valued contributors to the quality of American life.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: Spanish Wine Labels Lead U.S. to Impose Import Ban
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (Reuters)Spanish wines designated Spanish Burgundy, Spanish Chablis, Spanish Sauterne, or Spanish Rhine Wine will be denied entry into the United States from April 15, the Treasury Department announced today.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Police Display Stolen Antiques
description: More than 100 antique dealers and collectors prowled the fantastically cluttered rooms of the police warehouse in Long Island City Queens, yesterday, seeking to recover valuables stolen from them during burglaries in the last several years.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: SUNDAY'S GAMES

title: SEATTLE 7 FREE IN RIOTING TRIAL
description: SEATTLE, March 26 (AP)Indictments against the Seattle 7 have been dismissed, bringing an end to the turbulent conspiracy case that began three years ago.

title: Arthur Daley
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26Jon Matlack was fielding grounders in a pepper game in front of the clubhouse, watched with appraising eyes by one of the more venerable Met pitchers. Now that he has reached the advanced age of 28, Tom Seaver qualifies as an elder statesman. But his opinions were always powerfully respected because he seemed smarter, more perceptive, more analytical and more penetrating than anyone else. He has been operating from a level of superiority for so long that even his nickname of Tom Terrific appears fitting and proper.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: GRAZ, Austria, March 25 (AP)Doug Palazzari of Colorado College scored four goals today and Earl Anderson of the University of North Dakota had three as the United States overwhelmed Italy, 110, in a Group B game in the World ice hockey tournament. The victory gave the United States a 211 wonlosttied record in the tourney.

title: OIL PRODUCERS MEET TO MAP PRICE PLANS
description: VIENNA, March 26 (UPI)Expprts from 11 nations producing 85 per cent of the world's oil met Monday to lay the groundwork for getting a better price in the wake of devaluation of the dollar, oil sources said.

title: 2 Trade Zones Authorized
description: The ForeignTrade Zone Board, of Washington, has authorized the establishment and operation of two foreign trade zone sites in the Greater Kansas City area. The two sites will be operated by the Great Midwest Corporation and The Radial Warehouse Company. The sites encompass initially 565,000 square feet.

title: The World Game
description: A generation ago two Princeton professors initiated the modern mathematical study of strategy, a subject known technically as the theory of games. There has been much progress in this field since then; but even now the mathematicians are unable to provide a cookbook of guaranteed strategic recipes for the diplomat, the general or the businessman. One reason is that the analysis has shown that any game or other competition with three or more participants has extraordinarily complex posstbilities since the players can make and unmake coalitions in complicated, changing patterns of rivalry and cooperation.

title: ExChief of F. P.C. Named Head Of Consumers Group on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 Consumer organizations, mobilking to oppose the campaign of the oil and gas industry for higher prices announced today that they had hired a former Federal Power Commission chairman, Lee C. White, to be their chief spokesman.

title: Somali Reports No Proof Of a Tanzanian BuildUp
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, March 26 (Reuters)A Somali factfinding team has found no evidence to support Uganda's Contention that Tanzania had Massed an invasion force, Somalia's Ambassador said here today.

title: JAVITS DECLARES HE'LL RECONSIDER
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Senator Jacob K. Javits, who flew lack from Europe last night assuming that Robert F. Wagner had the Republican nomination for Mayor wrapped up, said today he was reconsidering whether he should run for Mayor himself.

title: Van Pelt Signed by Giants To 3Year, $300,000 Pact
description: What had been planned as a friendly goodby to an old friend turned into a rousing welcome for a prospective star yesterday as the New York Giants announced the signing of Brad Van Pelt at a sendoff luncheon for Joe Morrison.

title: EDITH CLURMAN, 55, WIFE OF AN EDITOR
description: Mrs. Edith Clurman, a former dancer and the wife of Robert Clurman, an editor with The New York Times, died Sunday night at the age of 55.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Drowned When His Canoe Overturns
description: COCHECTON, N. Y., March (AP)William Joseph Kennedy, 49 years old, of Brooklyn drowned in the rapids of the Delaware River at nearby Skinners Falls yesterday when a canoe overturned, authorities reported.

title: Notre Dame's Shumate Heads AllN.I.T. Team
description: Notre Dame's John Shumate, voted the most valuable player in the 36th annual National Invitation Tournament, headed the alltournament basketball team announced yesterday.

title: OFFDUTY POLICEMAN SHOOTS BRONX YOUTH
description: An offduty patrolman shot a 17yearold youth in the stomach yesterday in an altercation that followed an alleged robbery incident on a Bronx bus.

title: Equity Financing
description: Smith Kline & French Laboratories and Esquire, Inc., were among the companies yesterday announcing stock repurchase plans. The former plans to repurchase about 124,000 of its common shares. It closed at 47, down  on the New York Stock Exchange. Esquire, Inc. plans to repurchase up to 250,000 of its common shares. The company's stock closed unchanged at 8 on the Big Board.

title: Assembly Unit to Consider A DeathPenalty Measure
description: TRENTON, March 26The The Assembly Judiciary Cominittee voted today to ignore a recommendation by Governor Cahill's Capital Punishment Study Commission not to restore a death penalty in New Jersey until the United States Supreme Court has ruled on its constitutionality.

title: GREEK AIRLINE ENDS OPPOSITION ON FARES
description: The last airline in the International Air Transport As sqciation holding out against an agreement to continue existing North Atlantic fares until Dee. 31 gave its approval today.

title: U.S. ACTS TO CM COST OF HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The. Nixon Administration announced today that it was moving to check skyrocketing housing costs by increasing the cutting of trees from national forests, thus increasing the lumber supply, and by seeking voluntary agreement by the Japanese to hold down their purchase of American timber.

title: Writers Elect Radding
description: ST. LOUIS, March 26 (AP)Jerry Radding of The Springfield, (Mass.) Union, was elected president of the United States Baskethall Writers Association today.

title: U.S. ENVOY SEEKS AMITY WITH INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, March 26United States Ambassador Daniel P. Moynihan, citing the new realities on the Asian subcontinent, has opened quietly aggressive diplomatic effort to heal the battered relationship between the United States and India.

title: EXIMBANK BACKS ALGERIA GAS DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Directors of the ExportImport Bank approved today a $402million financing package to bring one billion cubic feet of liquefied natural gas from Algeria to East Coast markets.

title: Senator Benton's Legacy
description: Former Senator William Benton, the advertising wizard who retired with a fortune at the age of 35, could boast an extraordinarily versatile career in business, education and politics. But Mr. Benton, who died here last week at the age of 72, left a legacy more precious than the immense sums he lavished on educational and other philanthropic institutions.

title: Forest Hills Project Rising, But the Controversy Lingers
description: The foundations of the longdelayed lowincome housing project in Forest Hills have begun to peep out of the muddy ground on 108th Street like spring buds, part mystery and part promise.

title: Utility Sets Expansion
description: The South Carolina Electric & Gas Company said yesterday, that the Atomic Energy Commission had granted it a permit for construction of a $340million nuclear power plant with an expected capacity of 900,000 kilowatts. The plant would be situated in Fairfield County. Construction is to get under way promptly and comipletion is slated for 1977.

title: JOHN J. M'DONNELL
description: SOUTH AMBOY, N. J., March 26 (AP)John J. McDonnell, former editor and president of The Perth Amboy Evening News, died at his home here today. He was 68 years old.

title: New Jersey Sports,
description: NEWARK, March 26The New Jersey college baseball coaches held their first luncheon of the year today and, since most of them haven't started the season yet, said things like We're going to do better, We will have a few surprises, We have some fine potential, and We're optimistic.

title: The Wagner Caper
description: The New York mayoralty campaign has moved from low politics to high comedy. It has put egg on the face of Governor Rockefeller, murder in the hearts of some of his Republican vassals, perplexity on the brows of the other candidates, of whom there are too many to tell without a scorecard, and a fine new sheen on the shellandpea candidacy of Robert F. Wagner.

title: Jersey Passes Racing Bill That Would Fatten Purses
description: TRENTON, March 26  The New Jersey Senate today passed a bill that would fatten purses at the state's three thoroughbred tracks and head off a threatened boycott by number of horse owners.

title: U.C.L.A. Five Keeps Title
description: The University of California, Los Angeles captured its seventh consecutive National Collegiate basketball title last night at St. Louis by defeating Memphis State, 8766, as Bill Walton scored 44 points. Details, Page 57.

title: MONSANTO TO LIFT NYLON YARN PRICE
description: Price increases ranging from 5 per cent to 8 per cent for most apparel nylon filament yarns were announced yesterday by the Monsanto Textiles Company, an operating unit of the Monsanto Company. The new levels become effective May 1. Monsanto made its move against the background of a tightening supply situation, both in the United States and Europe. Industry sources also noted that prices of nylon filament yarns had been depressed for some time. Monsanto said that the advances reflected higher manufacturing costs that have been escalating over the two years, and very strong worldwide demand.

title: White House Mythology
description: WASHINGTON On March 8 a distinguished group of legal, scholars, historians, diplomats and members of Congress gathered in Washington to discuss the respective roles of Congress and the President in the formulation and execution of American foreign policy. Of primary interest was a measure, sponsored by Senators Javits, Stennis and myself, known as the War Powers Act.

title: Posts for David Eisenhower
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 26 (UPI)Lieut. (j.g.) David Eisenhower of the Navy has received several job offers from newspapers and magazines but has not yet made up his mind a White House spokesman said today. Lieutenant Eisenhower will be discharged next Saturdayhis 25th birthdayand has decided to pursue a career in journalism or public affairs.

title: Lindsays on Vacation
description: Mayor and Mrs. John V. Lindsay left the city yesterday to join their children for a brief vacation at an undisclosed location in Colorado. The Mayor's office said he was expected back in the city this weekend.

title: Draft Chief Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI) The Senate confirmed today President Nixon's nomination of Byron V. Pepitone to be director of the Selective Service System.

title: Filipino Army Fights Frustrating W ar
description: COTABATO, The Philippines, March 23Maximum use, I said maximum use.

title: 3 New Flute Works Played by Dunkel
description: Paul Dunkel, a young man who wants to blow new life into the flute, introduced three freshly minted chamber pieces that involved his instrument at Sunday night's concert in Carnegie Recital Hall. It was the flutist's third and final such program this season, and while the ultimate effect on the repertory can only be guessed at the homent, no guessing is necessary about Mr. Dunkel's stature as musician and instrumentalist. Playing of his deft and stylistically impeccable kind is rare, whether the music is old.

title: Saigon Peace Candidate Released After 5 Years
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 26  Truong Dinh Dzu, a peace candidate in the 1967 presidential election, was released from jail today after nearly five years in which he was one of South Vietnam's bestknown political prisoners.

title: C.I.A. AIDE TO TELL OF I.T.T. DEALINGS
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Central Intelligence Agency and a special Senate subcommittee agreed today on an unusual arrangement whereby a C.I.A. official will testify tomorrow about his dealings with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in connection with the political situation in Chile.

title: Brinegar Rail Plan Urges Private, Reduced System
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Secretary of Transportation offered Congress today a plan to deal with the Northeast rail crisis by the creation of a Federally chartered private corporation with broad powers to establish a new and sharply reduced system of railroad service for the region.

title: Martha Graham Revives Clytemnestra
description: You have to take life as it surges through you, and sex is part of it, Martha Graham said yesterday in announcing, the revival of Clytemnestra, a full  length work teeming with lust and murder, which many consider her masterpiece.

title: ACCORD ON LEADER BLOCKED IN TURKEY
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 26 (Reuters)  President Cevdet Sunay tonight blocked an attempt by Turkey's main political parties to promote a leading jurist as his successor.

title: STOCKS RISE A BIT ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market moved slightly higher yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Big Balloon Orbits Earth Twice in 5Weep Test
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)A huge balloon as tall as a six  story building has orbited the earth twice within five weeks, the first balloon ever to do so while carrying scientific instruments.

title: Food Price Rise at Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)  The Defense Department said today that its concessions committee had approved price increases ranging up to 66 per cent and averaging nearly 25 per cent on some foods served in Pentagon snack bars and cafeterias. Most of the price increases, which take effect next Monday, are on breakfasts items, sandwiches and salads.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The old Chinese porcelains and pottery that Reynold Tom selected during a nineweek visit to mainland China last spring seem to have been chosen to solve American interior design needs.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 500 Seize Offices In DayCare Fight

title: Notes on People
description: On the fifth anniversary of her marriage to David Harris, the antiwar activist Joan Baez, the folksinger, sued him for divorce in Redwood City, Calif. They were married March 26, 1968, at St. Clement's Episcopal Church in New York. Lawyers for Miss Baez said that an arrangement had already been made on community property, that she sought joint custody of their 3yearold son, Gabriel, and that she would not seek alimony. Miss Baez, who often gave her concert audiences news of her husband while he was in jail for draft evasion, is now in Europe.

title: Lithuanian Saunas Draw Pravda Heat
description: MOSCOW, March 26The sauna fad has caught on in Lithuania, and Pravda is complaining that the highlife settings and exclusive, clubby atmosphere of some saunas smack more of merchants' revelry than good clean comradely fun.

title: U.S. MARSHAL SHOT AT WOUNDED KNEE
description: Wounded Knee, S.D., March 26A United States marshal was seriously wounded tonight as he stood in a Government bunker near a roadblock that came under fire for more than an hour from an, Indian bunker 500 yards away.

title: The Charm of Hanoi Seems to Have Outlived the War
description: HANOI, North Vietnam (AP) Much of Hanoi's charm has survived the war.

title: HAROLD H. GLASER
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., March 26Harold H. Glaser, president of the Northern New Jersey chapter of the Chartered Life Underwriters, died of a heart attack today in South Orange. He was 52 years old and lived at 9 Vossler Court.

title: Weintraub to Step Down As Chief Justice in Jersey
description: TRENTON, March 26Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub of the New Jersey Supreme Court announced today that he would, retire from the bench on Aug. 31, leaving a record ?? of judicial leadership under which the court drew a pragmatic line against permissive criminal decisions and mandated strong new consumer protections.

title: Weekend Fight
description: Mexico CityEvaristo Perez, 114 pounds. Mexico, knocked out Rudy Billones, 114, the Philippines, 6 rounds.

title: George Sisler, Baseball Star, Is Dead
description: ST. LOUIS, March 26 (UPI) George Sisler, a member of baseball's Hall of Fame, who twice batted over 400, died today at St. Mary's Health Center here. He was 80 years old on Saturday.

title: Theater: Nash's Echoes
description: Symbols were falling on my headindeed, they were falling like snow in a dirty blizzard at the Bijou Theater last night. The occasion Was Echoes, a new play by N. Richard Nash. It was not fun. Not fun at all.

title: Menninger Scores Jail as Futile Curb To Crime by Youths
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Angrily calling the jail just as much an anachronism as slavery was, Dr. Karl Menninger, the psychiatrist and author, told a Senate hearing today that the way to reduce juvenile delinquency was through prevention rather than punishment.

title: Van Pelt Signed by Giants To 3Year, $300,000 Pact
description: What had been planned as a friendly goodby to an old friend turned into a rousing welcome for a prospective star yesterday as the New York Giants announced the signing of Brad Van Pelt at a sendoff luncheon for Joe Morrison.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 27, 1973

title: SADAT TAKES OVER THE PREMIERSHIP
description: CAIRO, March 26President Anwar elSadat announced today that he was taking over the post of Premier in addition to the presidency to lead Egypt through a crucial period of military pressure against Israel and diplomatic activity aimed at a negotiated settlement.

title: ... While American Role Stirs a Controversy Here
description: Top American athletes apparently will compete in the South African Open Games this week, despite serious objections that could endanger future sports relations between the United States and black African nations.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: SENATORE BORLETTI, INDUSTRIALIST, DIES
description: ROME, March 26  Count Senatore Borletti, chairman of Italy's largest sewing machine company and a leading industrialist, was found dead this morning in the bathroom of his home at Blevio, near the lake of Como in Northern Italy, He was 64 years old.

title: Liddy Suffers Cut Ear In Fight With Cellmate
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)G. Gordon Liddy, who was sentenced Friday to at least six years and eight months in prison for his part in the Watergate bugging conspiracy, was involved in a fight with his cellmate today as he prepared to appear before a grand jury.

title: Public TV Licensees and C.P.B. Head for Confrontation on Program Control
description: The licenseholders of the nation's 233 public television stations may have this week their ultimate confrontation with the Corporation, for Public Broadcasting over who is to control and schedule programs for the public TV interconnection network.

title: City Evasion Charged on Plans For New North Bronx Hospital
description: Representatives of the Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center and the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation met with community representatives last night for the first of a series of discussions on programs for the new North Central Bronx Hospital.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The two contestants in the upcoming Republican gubernatorial primary unexpectedly shared the same podium at the annual luncheon of the New Jersey Federation of Republican Women here. Governor Cahill Representative Charles Sandman, Republican of New sey, stood face to face very briefly, shook hands, then turned around and parted without exchanging words.

title: ORDINARY HORSES WIN FOR TURCOTTE
description: Ron Turcotte has gained international fame riding Riva Ridge last year and Secretariat this year for the Meadow Stable. Besides riding those stars, though, Turcotte does not mind steering ordinary horses. His willingness to work has shown results in the Aqueduct jockey standing.

title: Bridge: Unorthodox Defense Offers Wide DividendsSometimes
description: There are moments when an unorthodox defensive move can pay considerable dividends. A good example is the diagramed deal, which helped a Shreveport, La., partnership, Jack Kennedy and Capt. David Hadden of the Air Force, to win the men's pair title at the recent Spring Nationals in, St. Louis.

title: Congress as the Crisis
description: WASHINGTONThe avalanche of newspaper articles on the socalled constitutional crisis would be more useful to the public if the issues they describe were not so patently false.

title: 20 Dead in Brazilian Flood
description: CARATINGA, Brazil, March 26 (AP)At least 20 persons were dead, several thousand were homeless and $16million in crops and property were destroyed because of floods along the Caratinga River in eastcentral Brazil, authorities said today.

title: Oil Pipe Ruling Contested
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI)The president of the Atlantic Richfield Company asked Congress today to reverse a court ruling that the Interior Department violated the law when it granted a right  of  way for the TransAlaska oil pipeline. Thornton F. Bradshaw, testifying before the Senate Interior Committee, said the decision should be reversed because each day of delay in construction of the pipeline added $5million to the unfavorable United States balance of trade.

title: Children Turn Maple Sap Into Syrup
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Enthusiasm runs high at the New Canaan Nature Center, where children and adults are collecting sap from sugar maples and turning it into rich syrup in shallow evaporating pans over a crackling open fire.

title: Elderly Warned of Con Games as Complaints Rise
description: Several times every week Police Lieut. Norbert H. Campbell visits senior citizens' clubs to talk about the shady, games some people play, confidence games in which the losers are generally old people and the stakes are their savings.

title: TV: Peary and the Pole
description: The youarethere newsreel documentary format works very well indeed for Peary's Race for the North Pole, an engrossing hour starting at 10 tonight on the Columbia Broadcasting System network. Using vintage black and white photography to authenticate reenactment, helpful maps, a crisp narration (by Lorne Greene) and a vivid simulation of the polar region, this stimulating program cleverly assembles the case of Robert Edwin Peary and his exploratory triumph in 1909.

title: Shift by McCord Is Linked to Advice of Former Counsel to Senate Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 Bernard Fensterwald, a maverick lawyer and periodic battler against the secret machinery of Federal law enforcement, began advising James W. McCord Jr. about three weeks ago and apparently provided the tinder that has touched off the new explosion of Watergate charges.

title: Establishment Power
description: Is there an American economic establishment? If so, how much power does it have?

title: 2 Accused of $1Million Cocoa Swindle
description: A man from Ghana and his New Yorkborn wife have been accused of swindling the Republic of Equatorial Guinea out of $l.2million by pocketing more than half, of the proceeds of $2.25million in cocoabean sales to a Wall. Street concern.

title: CHINA KEEPS OPTIONS ON THREE CONCORDES
description: Dispatch of The Times, London

title: Industry Shortages Seen Squeezing Economy
description: The signs of shortages of material and personnel are everywhere in the economy and the voices of those affected are becoming louder.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Federal Budget, Education and Health

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, MARCH 28, 1973
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: HENRI DEERING
description: Henri Deering, concert pianist, who made his debut at Carnegie Hall in 1925 and had played in most European capitals, died yesterday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home, York Avenue and 72d Street. His age was 78 and he had lived at 831 Madison Avenue.

title: Food Chain Will Close A Day in Price Protest
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 Consumers Supermarket, a food store cooperative with 13 stores in the Maryland and Virginia sulitirbs of Washington, announced today that those stores would be closed this Saturday in a protest aimed at stimulating the White House to take action against the outrageous spiral of food prices.

title: FIRING STEPPED UP AT WOUNDED KNEE
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S.D., March 27  Negotiators stepped up efforts today to bring an end to the monthlong takeover of Wounded Knee by dissident Indians as their confrontation with Government forces became virtually open warfare.

title: Elusive Maya Glyphs Yielding to Modern Technique
description: The hieroglyphic writing of the ancient Maya Indians, the most highly developed writing to emerge in the New World before the Spanish conquest, is slowly yielding its secrets after having baffled scholars for centuries.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Dr. Bertram R. Levy
description: Dr. Bertram R. Levy, director of the budget at New York University since 1967 and a forMer assistant dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, died yesterday after a long illness at his home at Westfield, N. J. He was 40 years old.

title: La Bourgeoisie Storms Sale at Le Pavillon
description: Le Pavillon, the quintessence of sophistication and haute cuisine for about 30 years, was invaded by the bourgeoisie yesterday as the defunct restaurant put up all its goods for auction.

title: Insufficient Answer
description: Private profit seems to have pushed aside public service as the dominant concern in the report submitted to Congress by Secretary of Transportation Brinegar on reorganization of the Penn Central and other bankrupt Northeast railroads.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Judge's Son Sentenced
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 27 (AP)Gerald R. Cain, the son of Common Pleas Court Judge Herbert R. Cain Jr., was sentenced to life imprisonment yesterday for his part in the slaying of Glenn Edwards, a college student in May 1971.

title: Stock Prices Climb
description: Share prices registered their biggest advance in 16 months on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The DowJones industrial average soared 17.01 points to 944.91, and turnover increased to 17.5 million shares from 15 million on. Monday. Page 63.

title: Blast Kills 2 on U.S. Vessel
description: SASEBO, Japan, March 27 (UPI)Two explosions ripped through a United States military vessel today, killing an American civilian and a Japanese firemen. A Navy spokesman said the explosions occurred while the command ship Piscataqua was taking on fuel. The spokesman said 12 other persons, 6 of them Japanese, were injured, one critically.

title: Stock Prices Climb
description: Share prices registered their biggest advance in 16 months on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The DowJones industrial average soared 17.01 points to 944.91, and turnover increased to 17.5 million shares from 15 million on Monday. Page 63.

title: Moorer Says Soviet Tests New ICBM's
description: WASHINGTON, March 27Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that the Soviet Union was actively testing three new intercontinental balIistic missiles and might deploy 60 improved multiplewarhead versions of an existing missile during the summer.

title: Push Needed on S.I.
description: Monumental are the platitudes uttered in behalf of sound planning. But there will be no planning, sound or otherwise, in the huge southern third of, Staten Island unless the State Assembly passes the Marchi bill for a South Richmond development authority.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Concord Settles Its Labor Dispute

title: EXPOLICEMAN GETS 3 YEARS AND REBUKE
description: A suspended police lieutenant accused of withholding information about police protection of gamblers was sentenced to prison yesterday and denounced as a traitor to society.

title: Judge Orders Step To Release Funds For Veterans' Aid
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)A Federal judge ordered the Nixon Administration today to take the first step toward releasing impounded money appropriated for a new veterans education program.

title: Nixon Is Expecting Visit By Tanaka This Year
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)  President Nixon said today that he expected to meet with Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan in Washington this year, probably in the summer.

title: Bond Prices Advance Amid Traders' Zestful Mood
description: The bond market, which has been celebrating spring by casting aside all its extreme gloom about higher interest rates, climbed fairly exuberantly yesterday.

title: FLATBUSH WOMAN BEATEN IN HOLDUP
description: A 78yearold woman whon?? neighbors describe as senile and childlike was beater nearly beyond recognition early yesterday by two me?? who robbed her threeroom apartment in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the polie reported.

title: Brando Has Long Backed Rights of Racial Minorites
description: HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27Marlon Brando's decision to use the Academy Awards ceremony as a platform for his outspoken political views comes after a long career of activity on behalf of racial minorities and other unpopular causes.

title: Memphis State Team Gets A Big Welcome at Home
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 27 (UPI)About 5,000 people gave the Memphis State basketball team an emotional welcome home today.

title: ALCOA FILES SUIT ON TRADE CENTER
description: The Aluminum Company of America filed a $43.5million suit yesterday against the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Tishman Realty 81. Construction Company in connection with the building of the World Trade Center.

title: Raider Rally Falls Short As Saints Triumph, 4 to 3
description: ST. PAUL, March 27 (AP)Minnesota pulled within 1 point of clinching a World Hockey Association playoff spot tonight by edging New York, 43, despite Ron Ward's 49th and 50th goals of the season for the Raiders.

title: Engineer Opposes City Plan to Curb Electric Heating
description: An air quality control engineer employed by Consolidated Edison said yesterday that, from an environmental viewpoint, a central supply of steam and electricity for heating was clearly preferable to buildings' supplying their own heat.

title: U.S.WILL CONTINUE RAIDS IN CAMBODIA TILL A CEASEFIRE
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The White House said today that the United States would continue bombing in Cambodia until the Communist forces in that country stopped their military operations and agreed to a ceasefire.

title: Market Place: To the Option To the Option
description: Once Upon a timeback before 1964corporate executives were paid salaries plus bonuses, and often they received something called a stock option as well.

title: 17 FOOD OUTLETS GET CITY HEALTH NOTICES
description: The City Health Department has cited 17 more food establishments for having failed to correct health code violations.

title: Mrs. Mitchell Fears Plot to Tie Watergate to Husband
description: Mrs. John N. Mitchell said yesterday that she thought somebody was trying to make her husband the goat for the Watergate scandal, and that she was not going to let that happen.

title: Payton Quits as President of L. I. U.'s Post Center
description: GREENVALE, L. I., March 27 Robert L. Payton, president of the C, W., Post Center of Long Island University, submitted his resignation tonight to the university's board of trustees, which accepted it, effective Aug. 31.

title: Ulster Protestants Back British Proposal
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 27The Unionist party, representing the Protestant majority in Northern Ireland, gave qualified, approval today to the British Government's plan for Ulster's future. But the voting at a specially convened meeting showed that the party was seriously, split.

title: Senate Extends Two Acts To Protect Environment
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI)  The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to legislation to extend the Solid Waste Disposal and Clean Air Acts for one year while Congress studies their effectiveness.

title: Good Neighbors
description: The neighborly impulse to help others in time of need has motivated people of good will for thousands of years founding of the world's organizations of mercy, among them the Red It led to the Cross, which has been serving as a good neighbor around the world. The American Red Cross, with its millions of volunteer workers, is only one of 115 such national societies, the Red Cross idea grew out of a neighbortoneighbor spirit of extending a helping hand. It reaches out across the country and the world to help the stricken and distressed, just as one does with the family next door in time of illness or trouble.

title: BRONX MAN KILLED AS SON, 8, WATCHES
description: A 28yearold Bronx man was shot to death last night by one of three holdup men who robbed his wife of $450 in the hallway of the apartment building where they live in the Highbridge section. The couple's 8yearold son witnessed the killing.

title: City Limits Income Checks on Tenants
description: Mayor Lindsay will permit to become law a bill that sharply restricts the city's use of incometax returns to verify the incomes of families in cityassisted middleincome housing.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: 936 Men Leave in Day
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 28  The withdrawal of the remaining American troops in Vietnam resumed yesterday.

title: The Cahill Candidacy
description: The announcement by Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey that he will seek the G.O.P. nomination for second term gives Republicans in that state a chance to affirm support for his generally enlightened policies.

title: New Books
description: Africa in World Affairs: The Next Thirty Years, edited by All A. Mazrui and Hasu H. Patel (The Third Press: Viking Press, $10). A study sponsored by World Law Fund, New York.

title: 7 Union Leaders Accused Of Racket in Fur District
description: Seven leaders of a furriers union were indicted here yesterday on charges of conspiracy, extortion and threats of violence in a pattern of racketeering activity in the city's garment district.

title: Sun Oil and Sonatrach Set Exploration Venture
description: The Sun Oil Company announced yesterday that it had concluded an agreement with Sonatrach, the Algerian National oil company, for a joint crude oil exploration and development project on 2.3 million acres in Central and Eastern Algeria.

title: Exports in February Topped $5Billion
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 The United States trade deficit worsened in February after a sharp improvement in January, even though exports in February topped the $5billion mark in a single month for the first time, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: As a Trainer Boland Is Off the Pace
description: Patrons who backed Bill Boland (the horse) did a little better than those who backed Bill Boland (the trainer) yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Rhodesian Blacks Criticize New Plan for Bantustans
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 27  The Rhodesian Government's plan to establish Bantustans  semiautonomous black African tribal regions like those in South Africawas attacked today by the African National Council, a black antiGovernment group.

title: POISON BAN OPPOSED BY WOOL GROWERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 Two Senate bills banning the I use of poisons in predator control programs met opposition today from a wool growers association.

title: 121386 or 343536=Prize of $200 a Week for Life
description: In a quizshow setting complete with a small band and a Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus clown named Buttons, officials of the New York State Lottery yesterday announced the winning numbers for the top price in the $200aweekforlife contest.

title: Red Smith
description: When Governor Rockefeller assigned Charles B. Delafield and eight others to find out what ailed New York racing and what to do about, it, Hot Horse Howie Samuels said it would be a pleasure to work with that distinguished body. Later, when the Delafield Commission's scrutiny of his Offtrack Betting Corporaion made Samuels uncomfortable, he dropped distinguished from his vocabulary. He suggested that M. Donald Grant, a commission member who is chairman of the board, of the New York Mets, could hardly be impartial because he worked for Mrs. Charles M. Payson, a horseowner. And as for Fred Capossela, the retired racecaller also on the commission, wasn't he drawing a pension from the New York Racing Association? Finally, when the commission recommended controls on OTB lest it destroy racing in the state, Hot Horse Howie called the report the rape of the city, likened it to recommending welfare payments to bookies, and cried that the whole aim of the Delafield proposals is to make the tracks rich.

title: ADIRONDACK PLAN NON FACES DELAY
description: ALBANY, March 27  The Senate gave final legislative approval today to a bill that would delay for a year implementation of a landuse plan for 3.7 million acres of privately held land in the Adirondack Park.

title: BERGEN PROSECUTOR DEFENDS G.O.P. UNIT
description: HACKENSACK, March 27Prosecutor Sherwin D. Lester has declined to take before a grand jury insurgent Republican charges that the Bergen County G.O.P. has violated the election laws by illegally supporting organization candidates in the primaries.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Military Gone From Chilean Cabinet
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 27 President Salvador Allende Gossens accepted the resignations of the three military members of his Cabinet today.

title: HOUSE UNIT ASKS DEAN TO TESTIFY
description: WASHINGTON, March 27Bipartisan leaders of a House subcommittee offered today to forgo questioning of John W. Dean 3d about the Watergate conspiracy if Mr. Dean, the White House legal counsel, would testify on the issue of executive privilege.

title: People in Sports: Hogan Advises Golfers Not to Age
description: Ben Hogan, who hasn't played much tournament golf the last few years, has some advice for other golfers. Don't ever grow old, he said. My knee won't let me play, and I've got bursitis in my right shoulder.

title: Clemente Medals Approved
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)A bill providing for medals honoring Roberto Clemente, the late baseball star of the Pittsburgh Pirates, was passed by the House and sent to the Senate today. Profits from the sale of the medals would go to the Robert Clemente Memorial Fund of Pittsburgh.

title: People and Business
description: On Monday, the Local Loan Company of Chicago will celebrate its 65th anniversary, and leading the celebration will be its chairman and founder, Fred B. Snite, who at 89 is still active in the company.

title: FUTURES PRICES OF MEATS DECLINE
description: The stiffening resistance of consumers to high meat prices continued to bring price declines in live beef cattle, live hog and pork bellies yesterday in futures trading. There were also sharp price declines in cash markets for hogs and, beefonthe hoof at terminals in Omaha, Nashville and Memphis, Tenn.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: LIVINGSTON, N. J., March 27Some told him his beautiful design would be excellent for a jigsaw puzzle. More recently, however, Hal Purdy has been issued a design patent for an unusual golfcourse concept.

title: MRS. CHARLES GRIFFITHS
description: Mrs. Susan Wilkins Griffiths, wife of Charles E. Griffiths, an assistant vice president of the Irving Trust Company, died Sunday in the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, N. J. She was 34 years old and lived at 55 Juniper Place, Matawan, N. J.

title: At $10Million, City Calls It a Losing Graffiti Fight
description: The city is spending $10mil lion a year without making an appreciable dent in the spread of graffiti and would have to allocate $24million to reduce the defacement appreciably.

title: STANDARD SECURITY IS SOUGHT BY USLIFE
description: The USLIFE Corporation announced yesterday that it had made a proposal to acquire the Standard Security Life Insurante Company of New York for stock valued at approximately $24million.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: The Electric Company TV Program Found Helpful to Children
