description: Children who watched The Electric Company television program, particularly those in the first and second grades, did better in learning how to read than children who did not watch the program, according to a report released yesterday.

title: Brooklyn Grocery Owner Is Slain During Robbery
description: A Brooklyn grocery owner was shot to death last night when apparently resisting a robbery attempt by three men who escaped with a wallet containing $30.

title: COURT RESTRICTS TAXES ON INDIANS
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The Supreme Court ruled today that states cannot impose income taxes on Indians who live and work on a reservation but that they may tax the gross receipts of any business the Indians operate elsewhere.

title: FIRING STEPPED UP AT WOUNDED KNEE
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S.D. March 27  Negotiators stepped up efforts today to bring an end to the monthlong takeover of Wounded Knee by dissident Indians as their confrontation with Government forces became virtually open warfare.

title: San Juan Taxi Strike Ends
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., March 27 (UPI)The taxi strike here which hurt the city's tourist industry for almost a month, ended today when the cabbies reached a temporary agreement with the Public Service Commission. The agreement called for a 20day moratorium on the strike while a Governmentappointed commission investigates complaints of the taxi drivers.

title: Stage: Walker's Strong River Niger
description: The River Niger flowed into Broadway last night, and The River Niger is big, wide and deep. It is one of the best black plays to be seen hereabouts, and should be at the Brooks Atkinson Theater for a long, long time.

title: WHITES BEAT BLACKS IN S. AFRICA SOCCER
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 27 (UPI)The white team registered a 40 victory over its black opponents tonight in the first clash between the races on a South African soccer field in the South African Games.

title: S.E.C. EXTENDING FEES TIMETABLE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has slowed the movement toward fully negotiated brokerage commission rates because of unprofitable conditions on Wall Street, G. Bradford Cook, the new chairman of the S.E.C., disclosed yesterday.

title: A Restaurant Adds a Dash of Freud
description: It was 10:20 P.M., and the curlyhaired star of the restaurant's floor show was 20 minutes late. You see, the therapy group she leads in Brooklyn had run overtime.

title: JOHN A. DONALDSON
description: RUTLAND, Vt., March 27John A. Donaldson, a retired vice president of Montgomery Ward & Co., mailorder house, and a former vice president of the BigelowSanford Carpet Company, died yesterday at his home here. He was 78 years old and lived also in Naples, Fla., and formerly had lived in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: LOUIS R. STEIN
description: Louis R. Stein, a news editor in United Press International's Latin  American department, died Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 51 years old.

title: 32 Reach the Philippines
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Wednesday, March 28 The final stage in the release of American prisoners of the Vietnam war began yesterday as 32 who had been held by the Vietcong were freed in Hanoi and flown to Clark Air Base.

title: Bill Urged on Key TV Films for Congress Library
description: WASHINGTON, March 27Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. told the country's broadcasters yesterday that he would push for legislation requiring the Library of Congress to collect and file film, videotape and audiotape of significant historic events made by television and radio stations.

title: Navy Photographer Lauded
description: WASHINGTON, March 27, (UPI)The Pentagon said today that Chief Photographer's Mate Donald T. Maury, on the staff of Pacific Stars and Stripes, had been named military photographer of the year for 1972. Chief Maury, of Philadelphia, was selected by the National Press Photographers Association and the University of Missouri in a competition held in cooperation with the Defense Department.

title: La Bourgeoisie Storms Sale at Le Pavillon
description: Le Pavillon, the quintessence of sophistication and haute cuisine for about 30 years, was invaded by the bourgeoisie yesterday as the defunct restaurant put up all its goods for auction.

title: Walton and the Record: It Speaks for Himself
description: ST. LOUIS, March 27Bill Walton refused to discuss his record performance of 44 points, his injured left ankle, or his future as a professional athlete last night after he had led the University of California, Los Angeles, to its seventh straight National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship and its 75th victory in a row.

title: Jersey Moves to Protect Tocks and Skylands Areas
description: MAHWAH, March 27 Richard Sullivan, State, Commissioner of Environmental Protection, said today that he would send to Governor Cahill this week identical proposals for joint statemunicipal planning of land use in the Tocks Island and Skylands regions of Warren, Sussex and Bergen Counties.

title: Notes on People
description: The oldest man on Active Army duty, Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, former director of the Selective Service, retired in a 17gunsalute ceremony outside the Pentagons The 79yearold general, who headed the Selective Service from 1941 to 1970, was praised by Secretary of Defense Elliot L. Richardson as a man who marshaled two generations of Americans in defense of freedom. General Hershey, who has been a manpower adviser to President Nixon since he left the. Selective Service, was never drafted himself. He enlisted as a private in the Indiana National Guard in 1911. While he headed the Serivce, 14,620,096 men were drafted and( according to the Selective Service, 18,321 were imprisoned for draft evasion.

title: Bank Head and 6 Indicted As Loan Sharks in Jersey
description: NEWARK, March 27The Essex and Morris County Prosecutors announced today the indictment of seven persons, including the president of a suburban branch bank, on charges of operating a large scale loansharking ring. Joseph P. Lordi, Essex County Prosecutor, said at a news conference he had never seen a shylocking operation of this magnitude since he had entered law enforcement in 1955. All seven were indicted by an Essex grand jury on charges of violating the state's loansharking law. Doing business as the Arrow Collection Agency, with offices at 1015 Springfield Avenue, Irvington, the operation made loans totaling millions of dollars to at least 500 people over the last 10 years at interest rates as high as 500 per cent, according to Joseph A. Falcone, an assistant Essex County prosecutor.

title: SADAT APPOINTS A NEW CABINET
description: CAIRO, March 27President Anwar elSadat, who became his own Premier yesterday, named a Cabinet today that appeared to spell continuity in foreign affairs and greater reliance on technical specialists at home.

title: Gottfried Topples Emerson 46, 64, 76
description: ST. LOUIS, March 27 (AP)Brian Gottfried, a rookie on the World Championship Tennis tour, surprised Roy Emerson today with a 46, 64, 76 upset in the first round of the $50,000 Holton tennis tournament.

title: Capital's Arena Stage to Tour Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The United States will send Washington's Arena Stage Company to the Soviet Union this fall with the first American dramatic presentations in the 15year history of the SovietAmerican culturalexchange program.

title: FRANK CAVETT DIES; WRITER WON OSCARS
description: Frank Morgan Cavett, a screen writer who won two Oscars, died Sunday in Santa Monica (Calif.) Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Westwood, Calif.

title: STRATFORD GROUP HEADED BY CARR
description: Robert M. Carr, senior partner of the New York accounting firm of Lutz & Carr, has been elected president of the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., it was announced yesterday.

title: ALBRIDGE SMITH 3D, PRINCETON LAWYER
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 27 Albridge C. Smith 3d, a partner in the law firm of Smith & Lambert, died of a heart attack today in Princeton Medical Center. He was 59 years old and lived at 62 Hodge Road.

title: Advertising: New Yorker Story
description: The management of The New Yorker magazine made it plain yesterday that it would have been pleased to have the entire population of Chicago restricted to quarters for the day. Then they would have been denied the presence at their annual meeting of Charles P. Schwartz Jr.

title: Bank Head and 6 Indicted As LoanShark Operators
description: NEWARK, March 27  The Essex and Morris County Prosecutors announced today the indictment of seven persons, including the president of a suburban branch bank, on charges of operating a large scale loansharking ring.

title: Ex  Treasury Chief Backs Nixon Plan
description: John B. Connally, former Secretary of the Treasury, asserted last night that the United States needed a new hardnosed trade policy to get an even break in the world marketplace.

title: INVESTMENT BANKERS WEIGH MERGER DEAL
description: Two investment banking concerns based in Pennsylvania Butcher & Sherrerd of Philadelphia and Singer, Deane & Scribner of Pittsburghannounced yesterday they were exploring the possibility of merger.

title: EL DIARIO MOVING ITS HINTING UNIT
description: Officials of newspaper craft unions here said yesterday that they had been notified that El DiarioLa Freese, orie of the country's largest Spanishlanguage dailies, would end its printing operation in New York City after Friday.

title: Music: Night of Mozart
description: The Mozarteum Orchestra of Salzburg played nothing but Mozart at its' first New York concert on Monday night in Carnegie Hall, which came as no shock. The orchestra from the Austrian town where Mozart was born never performs anybody else's music, possibly to make amends for the indignities he suffered while he lived there.

title: Dow Climbs 17.01 Points, Biggest Rise in 16 Months
description: A strong surge of buying swept into the stock market yesterday, sending prices sharply higher on rising turnover.

title: Chinas Man in Japan... Chen Chu
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27Chen Chu, who arrived in Tokyo today as the Chinese Communist Government's first Ambassador to Japan, left an impression during his service here of a blunt, persuasive diplomat.

title: HANOI TO AID U.S. SEEK THE MISSING
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, March 27A Pentagon official said here today that the North Vietnamese were ready to facilitate the United States military's search for missing American soldiers and unrecovered bodies as soon as prisoner exchanges are completed this week.

title: Ohio Mayor's Son Cleared
description: STOW, Ohio, March 27 (AP) A marijuana charge filed by Mayor Roger H. Howard against his 18yearold son was dismissed today for lack of proof. In Municipal Court, Judge William Pike threw out the charge after th ecity prosecutor said he had no evidence to prove the Mayor's charge that his son, Roger B. Howard, had supplied marijuana to a brother, Gary, 14.

title: 32 Reach the Philippines
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Wednesday, March 28 The final stage in the release of American prisoners of the Vietnam war began yesterday as 32 who had been held by the Vietcong were freed in Hanoi and flown to Clark Air Base.

title: JANETTA WHITRIDGE, CIVIC LEADER, DIES
description: Mrs. Janetta Alexander Whitridge, wife of Arnold Whitridge, a retired professor of history, arts and letters at Yale University, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived at 151 East 79th Street.

title: ExP.O.W. Offers Reason For Statements in Hanoi
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 (UPI)  An Army officer said today that he made voluntary statements for the Hanoi radio during the six years that he was a prisoner in Vietnam to let his family know he was alive.

title: City Forced to Abandon Preschool Health Tests
description: City Health Commissioner Joseph A, Cimino reported yesterday that becaute of staff shortages the physicians and nurses assigned parttime to public schools could no longer give preschool youngsters the physical examination and immunizations required by law before a child is admitted to school.

title: RECORDS POSTED BY GENERAL TIRE
Bing, Actor, Finds the Wait's the Thing
description: Sir Rudolf Bing, the actor sat on a bench in the corridor of the New York State Theater looking decidedly tense. He glanced around desperately. Has anyone got a cigarette? he asked at large. While a New York City Opera functionary went off to find him one, the man who managed the Metropolitan Opera for 22 years tried to explain how it felt to be getting ready for his debut tonight with the City Opera. He plays the arrogant and cynical Sir Edgar in Hans Werner Henze's The Young Lord, a nonsinging, nonspeaking role.

title: Hogan Pushes Study on Realty Tax Cuts
description: District Attorney Frank Hogan of Manhattan said last night that his office was investigating tax assessment reductions of $100,000 or more granted by the city's Tax Commission.

title: The Hands of 535 Little Men
description: SYRACUSEA legislative system that worked rather well when there were a comparatively few states and, consequently, a workable number, of representatives, is creaking and groaning under the burden of 100 Senators and 435 members of the House, fifty states and a population of about 205million.

title: Magee Trial Fails to Reach A Verdict for Second Day
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 27, (UPI)The jury in the murderkidnapping trial of Ruchell Magee, the other defendant in the Angela Davis case, failed today for the second consecutive day to reach a verdict.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Doctor Charged With Manslaughter

title: Tokyo and Peking Exchanging Envoys, After Steady Growth of Ties
description: TOKYO, March 27Ambassador Chen Chu of China arrived in Tokyo today aboard a Chinese airliner to take up his post as the Peking Government's first envoy to Japan.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: MARCHI STUDYING RUNNING MATES
description: Trying to make up for lost time, State Senator John J. Marchi, who entered the mayoral race on Monday, began to select his running mates yesterday.

title: 2D NORSE VESSEL LOST OFF JERSEY
description: The Anita, a Norwegian, freighter carrying 32 crew members, has been reported missing off the New Jersey coast in the vicinity where another Norwegian freighter, the Norse Variant sank Thursday.

title: PollutionControl Officials Cite Price of Clean Air for the City
description: Airpollution control officials began yesterday to estimate the cost of achieving clean air here and, as expected, there was some public grumbling.

title: Japan's Man in China
description: TOKYO, March 27  Heishiro Ogawa, Japan's first ambassador to the Communist Government in Peking, is a polished, experienced diplomat with what the Japanese consider the right combination of pedigree and credentials.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 28, 1973

title: CONVENTION SITE DUE FOR CHANGES
description: A change in approach and exit ramps designed to meet community objections moved the $200million convention center along the Hudson River between 44th and 47th Streets a step closer to the construction stage yesterday.

description: CONCORD, N H., March 27 (UPI)The New Hampshire House overwhelmingly defeated today a proposal to support a nationwide meat boycott next week.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: JAZZ The Manhattan School of Music isn't a place that sticks to one note; its musical taste is universal, For two years now, Rusty Dedrick, who worked with, among others, Benny Goodman and Claude Thornhill, has been on the faculty, teaching jazz, all sorts of improvisations.

title: Mrs. Maria Alves Martins, Sculptor, Diplomat's Widow
description: WASHINGTON, March 27Mrs. Maria Alves Martins, a sculptor known under the single name Maria, died yesterday in Rio de Janeiro. She was about 75 years old. She was the widow of Carlos Martins, who had been Brazilian ambassador and dean of the diplomatic: corps here.

title: NIXON TO LIMIT DATA ON FARMERS' TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, March 27President Nixon will soon issue an executive order limiting the data that the Department of Agriculture may get from farmers' income tax records, an official of the department said today.

title: Grumman Is Laying Off 1,000 To Meet U. S. Demands on F14
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., March 27  The Grumman Aerospace Corporation disclosed today that it would lay off 1,000 workers this year from its staff of 24,000 in an effort to meet a goal of reducing its operating expenses by $25Million in line with demands of the Department of Defense over the F14 fighter plane.

title: Books of The Times
description: EVENING IN BYZANTIUM. By Irwin Shaw. 368 pages. Delacorte. $7.95.

title: Senate, by 7219 Vote, Passes Bill Challenging Administration on End of Health Programs
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The Senate passed a bill today challenging the Administration's plans to end several major health programs. The vote was 72 to 19.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES $26BILLION BILL FOR HANDICAPPED
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 President Nixon vetoed a $2:6billion vocational rehabilitation bill today, describing it as part of a threatened Congressional spending spree that would dip into the pocketbooks of millions of men and women.

title: CANADA WILL STAY IN PEACE AGENCY
description: OTTAWA, March 27External Affairs Minister Mitchell W. Sharp announced today that Canada would keep its 290 ceasefire observers in Vietnam for at least 90 days more.

title: PLANTE 10 TEST RANGERS TONIGHT
description: For the first time in two years, the old man of the ice, Jacques Plante, will put on his goalie's mask in Madison Square Garden tonight when the streaking Boston Bruins play the Rangers.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)The Treasury Department said today it would impose a countervailing duty, effective May 11, upon imports of refrigerators, freezers and certain other refrigerating equipment from Italy. The action results from a finding that Italian exporters receive a subsidy on the refrigerating equipment they send to the United States. The Government said that this gave the Italian imports an unfair competitive advantage.

title: FRANCE DENIES SALE OF ARMOR TO UGANDA
description: PARIS, March 27Government sources here denied today that France was selling armored troop carriers to Uganda but acknowledged that France would furnish that country spare parts for its Frenchbuilt military planes. [A dispatch in The New York Times on Monday from Tanzania cited usually reliable sources as saying that Uganda had purchased 80 French armored personnel carriers to be equipped with surfacetoair missiles.]

title: Tigers Obtain Perry From the Twins for Fife, a Minor League Pitcher
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 27 (AP)  The Detroit Tigers obtained a former Cy Young Award winner, Jim Perry, from the Minnesota Twins today in a straight oneforone trade for a minor league pitcher, Dan Fife.

title: The U.S. and Japan's New Deal
description: TOKYOJapanese internal development and. American external trade are directly linked in the mind of Kakuei Tanaka, this country's pragmatic Premier. His thesis can be simply stated.

title: Miss Evert, New Pro, Plays Here Tonight
description: Chris Evert chases another big payday as a new professional player when she meets Sharon Walsh in a firstround match in the $30,000 Lady Gotham tennis tournament tonight at the Felt Forum.

title: No Respite for U.C.L.A. Foes
description: There appears to be no respite for the college basketball foes of the University of California, Los Angeles. The Bruins figure to be even more powerful next season because they had only three seniors on the team that won the seventh straight National Collegiate championship for U.C.L.A.

title: Senior Citizens Month Set
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 27 (AP)Urging renewed recognition, respect and concern for older Americans, President Nixon has proclaimed May as Senior Citizens Month.

description: Noel Coward was overpublicized and underestimated. Artists who strike a responsive chord with audiences are sometimes denigrated because of their very ability to entertain, to evoke bitter sweet tears, to leave them laughing and humming.

title: CELTICS SUBDUE HAMS, 117110

title: Knick Playoff on Friday On ClosedCircuit TV
description: Home Box Office, Inc., in association with Vided Techniques, Inc., will show the first National Basketball Association playoff game between the Knicks and the Baltimore Bullets on Friday via closedcircuit telecast from Madison Square Garden.

title: RETRACTION GIVEN ON SOLZHENITSYN
description: MOSCOW, March 27 (AP) Saying she was mistaken, the former wife of Aleksandr I. Solzheditsyn has retracted a statement attacking the Nobel Prize novelist for his behavior towward her.

title: U.S. Air Support Deemed Indispensable to Cambodia
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 23American air power is necessary and indispensable, said Maj. Gen. Sosthene Fernandez. Yes, you can say indispensable, he repeated with emphasis.

description: Eleven weeks after they went on trial for armed robbery ant attempted murder, H. Rap Brown and three codefendants watched the jurors file out of the courtroom yesterday afternoon to consider their fate.

title: ExEnvoy Says the C.I.A. Ordered Polls on Allende
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The Central Intelligence Agency commissioned polls to determine the probable outcome of the presidential election in Chile in 1970, Edward M. Korry, former United States Ambassador to Chile, said today.

description: GRAZ, Austria, March 27 (UPI)East Germany virtually clinched the World Class B ice hockey championship today by beating Rumania, 42, and emerging as the only undefeated team in the tournament.

description: There's such tremendous potential here that sometimes it's frightening, said Catherine French. But certainly it's a challenge.

title: Limits on Insurance Profits Asked for State NoFault Law
description: ALBANY, March 27A group of Democratic Assemblymen today proposed an amendment to the recently enacted nofault auto insurance law that would limit insurance companies' profits to 5 per cent or less on underwriting premiums and to 7 per cent or less on their investment portfolios.

title: Panthers Appear to Have Left Algeria
description: ALGIERS, March 27  The handsome villa at El Biar occupied by the Black Panthers lever since the party became an accredited liberation movement in Algeria in September, 1970, is shut and deserted.

title: CHINA WOULD BAR SEABED TO NATIONS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. March 27  China made a sweeping group of proposals today on a law of the sea. One proposal would require that only an international body be given the power to exploit directly the resources that lie on the sea floor or beneath it.

title: Heroes and Victims
description: NEW HAVENAll wars seem to require heroes around which civilian populations can cleanse themselves of guilt and reassert immortalizing principles. But this may be the first war in history in which returning priioners of war have been selected for that role.

description: WASHINGTON, March 27The Federal Communications Commission announced today that it would investigate the broadcasting of allegedly obscene radio and television programs.

title: Albania Is Said to Execute Priest for Baptizing Child
description: VIENNA, March 27 (AP)4 The Roman Catholic news agency Kathpress said today that a priest has been reported executed in Albania for secretly baptizing a child.

title: Animal Feed Tests Seek to Produce Unsaturated Fats
description: BOISE, IDAHO, March 27 (UPI)  An Idaho company is experimenting with a new way to feed animals that produces meat and cheese with a high content of polyunsaturated fat, which it said might eventually help reduce the number of human heart attacks.

title: First National City And Chase Expect Higher Quarter Net
description: New York's two largest banking concerns expect to report higher profits for the first quarter of 1973, their chairmen told their annual meetings yesterday, but due to the Nixon Administration's efforts to hold down the prime rate, the gains will be largely or entirely due to overseas operations.

title: HANNAY'S ENERGY INFUSES CONCERT
description: A not always perfectly focused energy was the predominant characteristic of Roger Hannay's concert at the Kitchen, 240 Mercer Street, Monday night. Devoted to what he called, rather paradoxically, electronic and multimedia music, the program swept inexorably through 12 short numbers in a variety of contemporary styles.

title: Rockefeller's Political Balance Sheet: Pluses Seen Despite Wagner Revolt
description: Governor Rockefeller's foray into the chaos that passes for New York City politics has all the earmarks of an absolute disaster, many of his fellow Republicans agreed yesterday.

title: 6 Soviet Intellectuals Warn of Danger in Moscow's Acceptance of World Copyright Law
description: MOSCOW, March 27Six Soviet intellectuals, including the physicist Andrei D. Sakharov, warned today that Soviet adherence to the International Copyright Convention could be used to deprive some Soviet authors of their rights rather than to protect them.

title: Alfred Firestein Dies at 48; President of Max Factor
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., March 27 (UPI)  Alfred Firestein, president and chief executive officer of Max Factor & Co. and a grandson of the founder of the cosmetics firm, died of a stroke last night. He was 48 years old.

title: Merger Vote Is Delayed
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., March 27 (UPI)  Chesapeake Industries, Inc., said today a planned vote by stockholders on the proposed merger of Chesapeake into A. J. Industries, Inc., had been delayed. Chesapeake's chairman, Ralph M. Johnson Jr., said the Cost of Living Council issued a statement that A. J. Industries violated the reporting requirements of the economic stabilization program. He said the plan may be modified.

description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Coward Burial Tomorrow At His Estate in Jamaica
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 27 (AP)Sir Noel Coward will be buried Thursday in a private ceremony at Firefly, his Jamaica mountaintop estate, his private secretary said. A public memorial service will be held later in London.

title: METS DEFEATED BY RED SOX, 3 TO 2
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 27  While the Mets' attack continued to sputter, a rookie, Harry Parker, continued his strong bid for one of the two remaining spots open on Manager Yogi Berra's pitching staff. Although he was officially the losing pitcher, the 25yearold University of Illinois mathematics major turned in five creditable inning while the Mets were dropping a 32 decision to the Boston Red Sox.

title: Survey of Textbooks Detects Less Bias Against Blacks but Little to Please Feminists
description: DETROIT, March 27Black have made it onto the ships of Columbus and into the history of the succeeding four centuries, and Indians are no longer mere savages to be conquered so that white settlers can civilize the land. But women are still largely ignored, and MexicanAmericans have little to contribute to American history.

description: LONDON, March 27 (UPI)The price of gold rose on the London market today to $91.50 an ounce, a record for official trading, before dipping at the close.

description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that Roosevelt Dunning would succeed Benjamin Ward as deputy police commissioner in charge of community affairs.

title: N.A.S.D. Expels 4 Brokers as Part Of Discipline Steps

title: Plumber Is Acquitted

Herborn, Las Vegas, not guilty of a charge of making a verbal threat to take the life of and inflict bodily harm on the President.

title: PRICES RISE AGAIN ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market turned in their best performance in about six weeks yesterday. Both lists made good advances in heavier trading.

description: The board of trustees of the Consolidated Edison Company has approved in principle the issuance and sale of additional shares of common stock. The exact size of the issue will be determined next month and the public offering is expected to be made late in May. In response to a question, an executive said the company plans to raise $120million plus.

title: Tepdino, Hitting at .429, Is Sent Back to Minors
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 27If Manager Ralph Houk is the executioner at cutdown time, Pete Sheehy is the executioner's messenger. Sheehy, the clubhouse chief, is the one who tells the condemned that the executioner wants to see them. Frank Tepedino didn't wait for the message.

description: PHILADELPHIA, March 27 (AP)The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a motion here yesterday in the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit to dismiss a court challenge by the PBW Stock Exchange of the commission's controversial 8020 rule.

title: Ford Will Hold Price Line On 1973 Domestic Autos
description: DETROIT, March 27 (AP) The Ford Motor Ompany, said today that it planned no price increases for 1973 model cars and trucks built in North America.

title: I.M.F. Committee Agrees On Money Reform Goals
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The 20 nations negotiating world monetary reform agreed in principle today that the new system should remain based on stable but adjustable currency values but that floating exchange rates should be permitted in particular situations.

title: ExW.A.C. Will See Duty as Secretary to a General
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, March 27  Fourteen thousand males to one female is not bad odds, said 26yearold Shirley A. Caruthers, after she was sworn in today as the first woman in the 309year history of the New Jersey Army National Guard.

title: ROBERT H. MORRISON, A JERSEY EDUCATOR
description: Dr. Robert H. Morrison, who played a leading, part in the expansion of colleges and universities in New Jersey as Assistant Commissioner of Higher Education, died Sunday in Chula Vista, Calif. He was 89 years old.

title: ROBERT D. FOOTHORAP
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., March 27  Robert D. Foothorap, former associate treasurer of the Board of National Missions of the United Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, died yesterday at the Montrose Veterans Hospital. He was 59 years old.

title: I.T.T. Unit Fills Key Post
description: Howard A. White has been elected a senior vice president of ITT World Communications, a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. He was also named executive director of the newly formed legal and regulatory administration department and will continue in his capacity as general counsel of the subsidiary.

title: Monday's Fights
description: Brisbane, Australia  Hector Thompson, 138 pounds, Australia, outpointed Joe Tetteh, 139, Ghana, 15 rounds.

title: 2 Children's Shows Adults Can Enjoy
description: Two favorite, longrunning children's theater companies have introduced new shows into their repertories  the Paper Bag Players with To the Rescue and the Bil Baird Theater with BandWagon.

title: Senate Committee Becks Bill for an Energy Council
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 The Senate Commerce Committee approved today a bill to create a threemember energy policy council that would advise bot the President and the Congress.

title: PRATER IS HOPEFUL OF A SECOND TRIAL
description: ERIE, Pa., March 27 (AP) William J. Prater's lawyer said today that the former United Mine Workers organizer found guilty of murder in the Yablonski slayings hoped to win a new trial and reversal of his conviction.

title: Administration's Rail Plan Draws Critical Comment
description: The Administration's plan to end the Northeast's rail crisis by restructuring the region's railroads brought critical reaction yesterday from a labor leader, railroad executives and a member of Congress.

title: Kennedy Son Quits Hospital
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 27 (AP)Joseph P. Kennedy 3d has been released from a hospital here, where he was treated for injuries suffered in an automobile accident. The eldest son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy suffered a slight brain concussion and chest and neck bruises Saturday, but Xrays, showed no broken bones, officials at Herrick Memorial Hospital said yesterday.

title: DR. LEO YANOWSKI OF FORDHAN DIES
description: Dr. Leo K. Yanowski, professor emeritus of chemistry at Fordham University, died on Monday. He was 71 years old and lived at 279 East 203d Street, the Bronx.

title: USAC Again Puts Off Auto Race in Phoenix
description: Continued flooding near Phoenix, Ariz., compelled the United States Auto Club yesterday to postpone again the opening race of the championship season. Meanwhile, Mario Andretti and Al Unser, in tire tests at Indianapolis, ran laps at better than 190 miles an hour. The opening race, originally scheduled for April 17, had been postponed to this Saturday. It was to have been run at FasTrack International Raceway (formerly Phoenix. International) at Cashion, about 20 miles west of Phoenix.

title: Combined Indicators Advance by 1.8%
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)The Government reported today that its composite index of leading economic indicators, a measure of the country's economic growth, increased a substantial 1.8 per cent in February.

title: Theater: Pirandellian Chinese Puzzle
description: There is a mystery and glamour to Pirandello plays. They are always so bright intellectually and yet so absorbing dramatically. Perhaps best of all is his Enrico Quattro, which, under the English title of Emperor Henry IV, arrived last night at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

title: Engine of Inflation?
description: Since last November, the cost of money has been climbing steeply. The securities markets have been in a state of apprehension over the continuing rise in interest rates. But the nation's continuing balance of payments problem and the upsurge of inflation both argue for letting interest rates rise higher. Higher interest rates not only tend to cut down business borrowing and check inflation but also to attract funds from abroad, thereby helping the United States balance of payments.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: A week agoaddled perhaps by a warm wind that brought with it the sweet aroma of an awakening salt marshthis writer predicted that migrating striped bass would arrive off Cape Cod and the outlying islands much earlier than usual.

title: Tenneco Unit to Expand
description: A multimilliondollar expansion in vinyl resin production was announced yesterday by Tenneco Chemicals, Inc., a subsidiary of Tenneco, Inc. The company said that it had started construction on a 300 million  pound  a  year polyvinyl chloride plant at a site in Pasadena, Tex.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, March 28The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended March 20:

title: AGNEW DEFENDS U.S. ON ROLE IN VIETNAM
description: Vice President Agnew defended this country's role in the Vietnam war last night, describing it as one of the most unselfish missions ever to be undertaken by any nation in defense of another.

title: Apportionment Challenge To Be Heard April 30
description: MOUNT HOLLY, March 28 (UPI)  A hearing on a challenge to the state's new legislative reapportionment plan has been rescheduled for April 30.

title: RIGHTS OF WIVES BACKED IN BONN
description: BONN, March 28The Cabinet today approved the draft of a bill to reform marriage laws that would establish the equality of the sexes in terms of family names and the right of a woman to work.

title: Amer hockey League
description: TUESDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: MEANY PROPOSES A PRICE ROLLBACK TO LATE '72 LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, March 28George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, asked Congress today to roll back prices to where they were last December to assure labor's cooperation in Phase 3 of the Administration's wageprice stabilization effort.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Pace College announced that it has become Pace Uniyersity, and disclosed tentative plans for a $20million I. M. Peidesigned tower opposite City Hall to house the university's law, nursing, education and graduate schools.

title: EUROPEANS SEEK UNITED OIL FRONT
description: The members of the Common Market were reported yesterday to be interested in creating a common front with the United States and Japan on oil matters to give consuming nations bargaining leverage against the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Urban Development Chief Quits Post in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 28Sy J. Schulman, executive officer in Westchester County of the state's Urban Development Corporation resigned today to become chief operating officer for the Westchester County Association, a private organization of businessmen.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NEW YORKSent Bill Sudakis, catcherinfielder, to Texas; sent following to Tidewater farm: Buzz Capra, John Glass, Tom Moore and Hank Webb, pitchers; Joe Nolan, catcher; Lute Barnes and Brian Ostrosser, infielders, and Don Hahn and Dave Schneck, outfielders; sent Randy Sterling, pitcher, to minor league complex for reassignment.

title: City Offering Shoppers Meatless Menus
description: Officials of several city, agencies conferred privately yesterday in City Hall to explore methods of checking the inflation that has sent costs for beef, fowl and pork soaring 27 per cent in a year.

title: Nixon Asked to Cooperate
description: Representative Peter A. Peyser, Republican of Westchester, called on President Nixon last night to cooperate with Congressional investigations of the Watergate affair. In an address to the Columbia University Association of Dental Alumni at the Statler Hilton Hotel, he said, It's time we put this Watergate affair to rest. The longer the questions remain, the more or a political football it is.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: SYPHILIS EXPERIMENT TERMED UNJUSTIFIED
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)A Government panel coneluded today that a Federal syphilis experiment involving Alabama black men was not justified.

title: Employes in Capitol to Get Meatless Meals
description: TRENTON, March 28State legislators, employes and administration officials will join the national meat boycott next week whether they want to or not.

title: Mikhail Kalatozov Dies at 69; Director of Cranes Are Flying
description: MOSCOW, March 28 Mikhail K. Kalatozov, a movie director, died yesterday at the age of 69.

title: Death Penalty in Georgia
description: ATLANTA, March 28 (UPI)Gov. Jimmy Carter restored the death penalty in Georgia today when he signed a bill that opponents say is unconstitutional.

title: EWSPAPBRTAKS NEAR A DEADLIN
description: Negotiators for the city's three major daily newspapers have a heavy schedule of bargaining talks with newspaper unions in the next 48 hours, but neither side appeared to be expecting any strike action when current contracts expire at midnight tomorrow.

title: F.B.I. Reports That Violent Crimes in the Nation Rose Slightly and Property Crimes Fell Sharply in 1972
description: WASHINGTON, March 28Violent crime increased slightly in 1972, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today, but property crime dropped so sharply that the nation experienced its first overall reduction in the crime rate since 1955.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 28 (AP)The national track and field committee of the Amateur Athletic Union voted unanimously today to continue its policy of no competition in Strack and field with the Union of South Africa. It said it would not issue travel permits for competition in that country. The ruling applies to individuals as well as teams.

title: INTEREST PANEL SOON TO RELEASE DUALRATE PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, March 28The Government's Committee on Interest and Dividends plans to announce in two to four weeks guidelines for operation of a new dual prime lending rate for banks and expects the present prime rate of 6 per cent not to be increased in the meantime.

title: 2 More Are Seized As Security Arrests Continue in Athens
description: ATHENS, March 28  A professor of constitutional law and a wartime Premier's daughter were detained by the military police today in the latest wave of security arrests in Athens.

title: Learning to Look Up, Not Down, as They Walk
description: Eight women from Great Neck began their historical tour of New York buildings here at 10:30 yesterday morning with a stop at a bubblecovered tennis court, circa 1972, under the 59th Street bridge.

title: Miss Censer Wed To Capt. R. B. Cato
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., March 28In the Cadet Chapel here this evening, Miss Ellen Malvina Censer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Censer of Eastchester, became the bride of Capt. Robert Bruce Cato, U.S.A. The Rev. James Ford, a Protestant minister and senfor chaplain at the United States Military Academy, performed the ceremony.

title: L.I. CONCERNS GET SPACE CONTRACTS
description: In a decision that will mean an infusion of at least $53million into the ailing economy of Long Island, two aeropsace companies there have been chosen to build the wings and tail fin for the nation's manned spaceshuttle vehicle.

title: MALCOLIW DAVIS, 52, OF TRAVEL MAGAZINE
description: Malcolm McTear Davis, editor for the last 23 years of Travel magazine, died of hepatitis yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived at 226 East 70th Street.

title: Partzka Warns Candidates To Back Kawaida Openly
description: NEWARK, March 28 Imanu Amiri Baraka warned Candidates for office in New Jersey today that black voters would actively work against tem if they did not openly support the Kawaida Towers housing project here.

title: Special Grand Jury Hears Mackell for Over 3 Hours
description: A special grand jury empaneled by Maurice H. Nadjari, the state's anticorruption prosecutor, questioned District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens for more than three hours yesterday.

title: North Stars Tie Blues, 33, On Late Goal by Prentice
description: ST. LOUIS, March 28 (UPI) Dean Prentice swept the puck past a kneeling Wayne, Stephenson in the third period tonight to give the Minnesota North Stars a 33 tie with the St. Louis Blues.

title: Privilege Waived by Mollenhoff as He Produces White House Data at Fitzgerald Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  Clark R. Mollenhoff, a former Presidential aide, cast aside any question of executive priviiege today when he produced a surprise batch of memos, some internal White House documents and one document marked confidential at the Civil Service Commission hearing for A. Ernest Fitzgerald.

title: Koch Abandons Mayoral Race, Citing Trouble in Raising Funds
description: Unable to raise enough money to give him a chance of winning, Representative Edward I. Koch said yesterday that he was Withdrawing as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

title: G.A.O. FRES REPORT ON COST OVERRUNS
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)Congressional auditors today attributed $19.1billion in weapons cost overruns on efforts by the military to get too much too fast, inflation and errors in estimating costs.

title: N.C.A.A. Gets a Question: Why Are Only Blacks Investigated?
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI)  Senator Marlow W. Cook, Republican of Kentucky, accused the National Collegiate Athletic Association today of limiting its player eligibility investigations to nick athletes only. Cook urged a House education subcommittee to demand that the N.C.A.A. answer questions about its criteria for investigation.

title: Julie Woodcock Sets Swim Mark
description: MOSCOW, March 28 (AP)Julie Woodcock of Philadelphia won the women's 200meter freestyle in 2 minutes 8.2 seconds, an American indoor record in an international swimming meet today. It was the third victory for the 16yearold Miss Woodcock. The mark was made in a 25meter pool. A teammate, Ann Brodell, finished second in 2:10.3.

title: THURSDAY, MARCH 29, 1973 News Summary and Index
description: Despite grumbling from Capitol Hill, Secretary of Defense Richardson insisted yesterday that President Nixon has clear constitutional authority to continue bombing in Cambodia to clean up a lingering corner of the war. The assertion came as several Senators challenged the President's authority to keep up the bombing once American troops are withdrawn froin South Vietnam. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: DEMOCRATS VOW RENTLAW FIGHT
description: ALBANY, March 28Democratic legislators vowed today to continue their fight to repeal vacancy decontrol, which permits landlords to raise rents on rentcontrolled apartments that become vacant, and to allow New York City to enact more stringent rentcontrol regulations than permitted by the State Division of Housing.

title: F.T.C. Information Aide
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 The Federal Trade Commission announced today the appoint. ment of Arthur L. Amolsch as director of public information.

title: Thomas Peacock Marries Miss Cole
description: Miss Sarah M. Cole and Thomas P. Peacock, a partner in the New York law firm of Nickerson, Kramer, Lowenstein, Nessen & Kamin, were married here yesterday evening. The ceremony was performed at the bride's home by Civil Court Judge Berton S. Sherman.

title: MISS EVERT WINS AT FORUM, 64, 60
description: Chris Evert unveiled a smashing new tennis dress and a serve to match, and Linda Tuero showed that parapsychology can pay off on a tennis court last night in the opening round of the $30,000 Lady Gotham tournament at Felt Forum.

title: C.I.A. Aide Says He Gave AntiAllende Plan to I.T.T.
description: WASHINGTON, March 28An official of the Central Intelligence Agency has testified that in 1970 he proposed to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation series of steps that it and other American companies might take to create enough economic, instability in Chile to prevent the election of Dr. Salvador Allende Godsens as President.

title: Significant Gas Sands Find Reported by Texaco Group
description: HOUSTON, March 28 (Reuters)Texaco, Inc., as group operator, said today it had discovered potentially significant gas sands in the Gulf of Mexico about 100 miles south of Morgan City, La.

title: LAYER CONQUERS BARTH, 62, 76
description: ST. LOUIS, March 28 (UPI) Rod Laver played listlessly, but good enough today to eliminate Roy Barth of San Diego from the $50,000 Holton tennis classic, 62, 76.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Boeing Company received a $49.3million contract from the Air Force for continued improvements to Minuteman missiles and facilities at Francis E. Warren Air Force Base, Wyo., it was announced yesterday. Automation Industries, Inc., was awarded a Navy contract for $11.8million to perform systems engineering for surface missile programs.

title: 7 Indicted in Bustout Plan to Bilk Food Wholesalers
description: Seven reputed Mafia figures were indicted yesterday on charges of having operated socalled bustout scheme that bilked 30 wholesale food dealers of $50,000.

title: BARGAINHUNTING LIFTS AMEX A BIT
description: Enthusiasm cooled off yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market as prices finished slightly higher to mixed. In the previous session, both markets had made large gains.

title: FRANCIS B. THURBER
description: PRINCETON, N. J. March 28  Francis B. Thurber, who served with the Office of Strategic Services in World War II, died in Princeton Medical Center today. He was 91 years old and lived at 62 Cleveland Lane here and at the Onteora Club in Tannersville, N. Y.

title: College, School Results
description: BASEBALL

title: Middle Age Needn't Be Like Dark Ages
description: They're caught between yesterday and tomorrow. The world they entered seems to have all but disappeared under changes as thorough as a bulldozer squashing an ant. And the one they face is undergoing convulsions that leave them sometimes baffled, sometimes lost, sometimes despairing  and sometimes hopeful.

title: JETS BEAT COUGARS IN OVERTIME, 4 TO 3
description: CHICAGO, March 28 (AP)Bobby Hull's 51st goal of the season and second of the game gave the Winnipeg Jets a 43 suddendeath overtime victory over the Chicago Cougais tonight in a World Hockey Association game.

title: Lindsay Appoints a Supporter President of Tax Commission
description: Alfred J. Ranieri, a Bronx lawyer who got his job on the city's Tax Commission through the intervention of his local John V. Lindsay Association coordinator, was elevated yesterday, by Mayor Lindsay to the acting presidency of the commission.

title: BURCH SCORES FAD OF 'TOPLESS RADIO
description: WASHINGTON, March 28Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that, although it was not the commission's job to censor broadcasting, it had been forced to begin an investigation of obscene sexoriented radio talk shows.

title: C. DORIS HELLMAN HISTORY TEACHER
description: Dr. C. Doris Hellman, professor of history at Queens College, died at Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday morning. She was 63 years old and lived with her husband, Morton Pepper, a lawyer, at 176 East 77th Street.

title: CURTIS A. HAINES
description: Curtis A. Haines, a retired vice president of the Electronics Systems Group of GTE Sylvania, Inc., died Tuesday in Clearwater, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived in Clearwater Beach.

title: 11 Are Dropped by Mets, But Theodore Wins a Job
Niles T rarnmell of N.B.C. Dies; Brought Stars to Radio in 30's
description: Niles Trammell, former president and chairman of the board of the National Broadcasting Company, died yesterday in North Miami, Fla. He was 78 years old.

title: A JUROR REPLACED
description: One of the jurors deliberating the fate of black militant H. Rap Brown was excused from further service yesterday because of ill health.

title: Records: Glenn Gould
description: Ever since Glenn Gould recorded Bach's Goldberg Variations 18 years ago, he has been friskily expanding his horizons, with varied reactions from the musical press.

title: Thieu Inaugurates His Democracy Party
description: SAIGON, South. Vietnam, Thursday, March 29Two days before departing on a trip to the United States, President Nguyen Van Thieu formally inaugurated a new political party yesterday in an effort to consolidate his control over South Vietnam.

description: WASHINGTON, March 28 The United States sought to extend the life of the FourParty Joint Military Commission in South Vietnam, but failed to gain Hanoi's support, an Administration official said today.

description: MAHWAH, March 28  Two levels of government have yet to decide on two critical issues that will influence the ecological future of Newark's virtually untouched 35,000acre watershed area at, the conjunction of Morris, Passaic and Sussex counties, 35 miles west of the city.

title: Meatless but Not Joyless: Eggplant Spaghetti and Other Delights
description: Steak does not yet cost $100 a pound, but meat prices have jumped enough lately so that many people are cutting back on their consumption of top round and chops. Some cooks have been eliminating meat entirely from their families' diets, either because they can't afford it any more or as a protest move.

title: CASES OUTPACE NEW JUDGESHIPS
description: TRENTON, March 29 (AP) The number of judges in the state has increased 16 per cent over the last five years, but the number of cases they have to handle rose by as much as 159 per cent in some categories during the same period, the administrative director of the courts said today.

title: CELTIC RALLY TOPS BULLETS 120101
description: BOSTON, March 28 (AP) Dave Cowens scored 13 of his 23 points in the third period defeat the Baltimore Bullets, 120101, tonight in the last game of the National Basketball Association's regular season for both teams.

title: ELEANOR STEBER BACK IN FLOURISH
description: Eleanor Steber has returned to New York concert life with quite a flourish, and the theme of her second Tully Hall recital this season, on Monday night, was a big oneAmerican Song From the Revolution to Man in Space. During the course of this cosmic trip, Miss Steber and her accompanist, Edwin Biltdiffe, took on no fewer than 30 songs by 28 American composers, six of whom were on hand to share in the applause.

title: China Promotes Tennis as Prelude to World Sports Entry
description: HONG KONG, March 28The prospect of Chinese players competing at Forest Hills and Wimbledon has been raised by a press report from Peking that a national tennis tournament was held in Shanghai from March 11 to last Saturday.

title: LIBYANS, IN AN ERROR, SEIZE ITALIAN BOAT
description: ROME, March 28  Port authorities in southwestern Sicily said today that a Libyan plane dropped three bombs near an Italian fishing boat in international waters yesterday as it strayed into the midst of Libyan vessels on a military exercise.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 28The 60day first phase of the Vietnam ceasefire came to an end today with fighting continuing, peacekeeping machinery in a state of disarray and the prospects for real peace in South Vietnam apparently remote.

description: Fifteen years ago, Mrs. Frangoise Firminhac bought. a pair of American cocker spaniels and became the first Frenchwoman to register the breed in her native land.

description: ACROSS

title: Indians Said to Block Surrender by 100
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., March 28One hundred of the Indians holding the historic hamlet of Wounded Knee have offered to surrender, a Government spokesman said today, but hardcore dissidents, vowing to die, are said to be keep. ping them in the village at gunpoint.

description: BOONTON, N. J., March 28 Melville S. Newcomb, who had been president of the Boonton National Bank from 1935 until his retirement in 1963, died yesterday in the Riverside Hospital. He was 76 years old.

description: A selfdescribed gambler identified by Federal officials as a reputed heroin distributor was indicted yesterday on charges that he failed to file tax returns and concealed his income.

description: ForwardsKen Charles, Fordnem; Phil HankInson, Penn; Bill Knight, PIN; Bill Schaeffer, St. John's.
