description: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's address last night, as recorded through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

title: U.S. Keeping 7,200 Civilians in the South
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 29The United States military mission in Vietnam has formally ended, but 7,200 civilian employes of the Department of Defense remain, most of them technicians helping the South Vietnamese armed forces.

title: A Soviet Gesture To Better Relations With London Seen
description: MOSCOW, March 29The Soviet Union today gave the first clear signal in nearly 18 months that it was interested in easing tensions with Britain as part of a renewed campaign to improve relations with the West.

title: CONSUMERS RALLY FOR MEAT BOYCOTT
description: The nationwide movement to boycott meat next week to protest high food prices gained momentum yesterday as community and women's groups began holding rallies and handing out leaflets to mobilize housewives support.

title: Kremlin Tackles the Visa Tax Problem
description: MOSCOW, March 29In the last 10 days the Soviet leadership has made progress toward neutralizing the uproar abroad over the heavy education taxes imposed on emigrating Jews, but without modifying its basic emigration policies.

title: UPRISING IS QUELLED AT BALTIMORE JAIL
description: BALTIMORE, March 29 (AP) Prison guards and the Baltimore police halted a major disturbance at the Maryland Penitentiary tonight and rescued eight hostages. Two of the hos tages were injured.

title: Mexican Butchers Shut Shops To Protest Rising Meat Prices
description: MEXICO CITY, March 29This capital city is in the throes of a mystery in which the prices of filets and Tbones are rising and butchers and innumerable Government officials are issuing charges and countercharges and contradictory explanations as to what is going on.

title: Muskrats Run on Giants' Open Field
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 29  The muskrats ramble over the debris where one day the Giants will play football. Six miles to the east, the Empire State Building is clear and towering.

title: LOSS IS REGISTERED AT WALSTON & CO.
description: Walston & Co., Inc., continued to show a decline in its operating results in the first fiscal quarter ended Feb. 22, according to its report issued yesterday by the major retail brokerage firm,

title: 1,800Year Sentence Upset
description: AUSTIN, Tex., March 29 (UPI)  A man sentenced to 1,800 years in prison for selling heroin won a new trial yesterday because, the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals ruled, the trial judge should have granted a change of venue. Attorneys for Bentura Flores had submitted local newspaper clippings about drug problems in the county along with a radio interview with the district attorney during which he said that the county had reduced the drug problem by handing out long prison sentences.

title: Former P.O.W.'s Charge Torture by North Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, March 29Former prisoners of war told chilling stories today of mental and physical torture at the hands of their North Vietnamese captors.

title: Velsicol Chemical Expands
description: Northwest Industries, Inc., said yesterday that its Velsicol Chemical Corporation subsidiary would build a $13.5million herbicide plant at Beaumont, Tex.

title: PENNSYL VANIA'S BAN ON ABORTION VOIDED
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 29 (AP)The State Supreme Court struck down Pennsylvania's antiabortion statutes today and overturned the conviction of a physician whose patient died after an abortion.

title: Georgia Governor Signs Bill Restoring Death Penalty
description: ATLANTA, March 29 (UPI)Rape, murder, armed robbery, kidnapping, airplane hijacking and treason may be punishable by death once again in Georgia, as Gov. Jimmy Carter has signed a bill restoring capital punishment in the state.

title: House Unit Acts to Renew Rein on the Postal Service
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI)In a first move by a Congress angry over the quality of mail service, the House Post Office Committee voted today, 22 to 1, to reassert its power over the United States Postal Service.

title: PRESIDENT WARNS HANOI TO COMPLY WITH TRUCE PACT
description: WASHINGTON, March 29President Nixon, in an address to the nation proclaiming the disengagement of United States ground forces from Vietnam, issued a new warning tonight to North Vietnam against failure to comply with the Paris peace agreement.

title: Integration Plans Ordered by H.E.W. In 25 School Zones
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)  The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has ordered 25 school districts in 12 states to submit new desegregation plans by April 10 or risk the loss of Federal funds.

title: Former P.O.W.'s Charge Torture by North Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, March 29Former prisoners of war told chilling stories today of mental and physical torture at the hands of their North Vietnamese captors.

title: The Screen: Phedre' Is a Graceful Homage to Racine
description: Pierre Jourdan's adaptation of Racine's "Phdre," with the French text translated by English subtitles taken from William Packard's alexandrine translation, is surprisingly interesting and unhackneyed for a film devoted to a kind of drama so completely at odds with what films are supposed to be about.Seventeenth-century French neoclassic drama requires a certain discipline even when you watch it in a legitimate theater, where the uncomfortable seats and bad sight lines help keep you awake. In a movie house, I would have expected instant sleep.This "Phdre," which opened yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room (which has alarmingly comfortable seats and very good sight lines), is a graceful homage to a play and a style of performance that, under less attractive circumstances, might have reduced me to the kind of acute, uncontrollable high spirits I sometimes experience at the opera, when the tenor can't get his arms around the soprano.Marie Bell, who has been a star of the Comdie Franaise, of her own theater and of French films for longer than I can remember, comes to us as the unhappy Phdre, tragically in love with her stepson, Hippolyte, in the full bloom of what has alsions expressed in verse from which all easily identifiable passion has been distilledare so intelligently embraced that Miss Bell's age and theatrical mannerisms are less an intrusion than a means of emphasis.Racine's theater deals in emotions almost as if they were abstract principles. It asks us to think first, feel later. Everything about this production directed by Mr. Jourdan (brother of the actor Louis Jourdan) invites such a ready long passed middle age.Yet the artificialities of the filmfrom its Poussin-like painted backdrops to its preoccupation with grand pas-distancing of response. The effect, if you can overcome an initial resistance, is soothing and reassuring, as if you'd been taken away from time.The camera glides about the colonnaded interior of Theseus's palace with a kind of discreet insistence that we pay attention. Only occasionly does it move in for tight close-ups or take one of those ladder-high positions from which birds and movie cameras view the world. Mostly, however, the camera, the sets, the costumes and the actors are simply instruments used in the cause of the playwright, so designed as not to interfere with him grossly.At this point, Miss Bell is somewhat too majestic to be entirely convincing, even at the center of a tragedy of intellect, but she is a living landmark not easily denied. With the exception of Tania Torrens, a beautiful, truly young woman who plays Aricie, the real love of Hippolyte, all of the other actors seem a bit seedy, which may or may not reflect their inability to adapt to film a florid acting style that isn't all that interesting today, even on the stage.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Baltimore Bullets, N.B.A. Eastern Conference semifinal playoff, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 8 P.M. (RadioWCBS, 8 P.M., WNBC, 7:56 P.M.) (TelevisionChannel E (cable), 8 P.M.)

title: METS WIN FINALE IN ST. PETERSBURG
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29  The New York Mets used a flurry of good pitching to produce a 21 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ABROAD SPECTRUM Here's a special film series that banks on your not be. ing able to bandy the names of the people who are the directors. It's the second annual New Directors/New Films showcase presented jointly by the Lincoln Center Film Society and the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street (9567284), where they're being shown.

title: SOUTHERN ROCKIES HIT BY SNOWSTORM
description: An early spring storm brought a foot of snow to the southern Rockies yesterday, crushing roofs of trailer homes and blocking roads to ski resorts, United Press International reported.

title: COUNCIL EXTENDS CONTROL ON RENT
description: The City Council yesterday approved overwhelmingly a threeyear extension of rent controls affecting more than one million dwelling units.

title: Charles Wuorinen, Harvey Sollberger At Cultural Center
description: Charles Wuorinen and Harvey, Sollberger perform and propagate their music so effectively, that one almost feels guilty when one doesn't like any given piece they, produce. Wednesday evening at the New York Cultural Center the two composers, who play the piano and flute, respectively, joined Fred Sherry, cellist, for a program that included works by both men. This reviewer wound up feeling halfguilty.

title: U.S. STILL PROMOTING SUEZ CANAL ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 A high State Department official said today that after studying the results of recent discussions with Arab and Israeli leaders, the United States believed that the only feasible way to achieve a Middle East settlement remained a lowkey, stepbystep approach.

title: Elder Leads By 1 on 64
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., March 29Just as he did a week ago, Lee Elder became a firstround tournament leader today. The 38yearold black golf professional from Washington, who fired an opening 65 in the Greater New Orleans open last week, turned in a career record sevenunderpar 64 in the $210,D00 Greater Greensboro open to lead by one stroke. He played the 7,021yard Sedgefield County Club course during a light rain.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: Las Vegas, Nev.  Freddie Jones, 150 pounds, Los Angeles, outpointed David Arrellano, 148, San Diego, 10 rounds.

title: Lower Drinking Age Vetoed
description: SANTA FE, N. M., March 29 (AP)Gov. Bruce King vetoed today a bill that would have lowered the legal drinking age in New Mexico from 21 years to 19. He said he was acting in light of the demonstrated seriousness of the drinking problem and the widespread parental concern over excessive drinking by young people.

title: West Side Studies 6 Highway Plans
description: Last April 1, the West Side Highway Project opened for business. Its mandate was to come up with a plan for reconstructing the obsolete, widely criticized and often feared highway.

title: Red Smith
description: When she started playing she was known around the Country Club of Maryland as Rip Mann's daughter. Now Rip is Carol Mann's father. Carol is a professional golfer, the United States Open champion of 1965, leading moneywinner in 1969, with a bagful of records like the 30 she shot on the Sunset Club's front nine in St, Petersburg, Fla., like her 66, 66132 in the Lady Carling, open at Palmetto, Ga., where she added a 68 in the third round for a 54hole total of 200. Not to mention the first round ever played as a pro, she said. It was at Sea Island, Ga. It was raining, I had a cold with a temperature of 104, and my score Wasn't a lot lower89.

title: Excerpts From S.E.C.'s White Paper
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Following are excerpts of the policy statement of the Securities and Exchange Commission on the structure of a central market system:

title: In Footsteps of Duchamp
description: More than half a century ago the late Marcel Duchamp discovered a vast esthetic continent, which, though fundamentally arid, has nonetheless attracted a phenomenal number of eager colonizers. The latest of these to be given a retrospective exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art is Bruce Nauman, who, at the age of 32, is described by the museum as a leading artist in the West Coast avantgarde. Just so may the residents of Fairfield County be described as pioneers. It's wonderful the way our spokesmen for the latest thing still cling to these antique appellations.

title: U.S. AUTO MAKERS SCORED BY NIUSKIE
description: WASHINGTON, March 29Senator Edmund S. Muskie denounced United States auto manufacturers today, charging they have failed to mdve fast enough and imaginatively enough in developing an efficient nonpolluting automobile engine.

title: STEP NICELY DOES AND WINS BY NECK
description: I have hopes for him, not plans, said Jack Dreyfus, the master of Hobeau Farms, after his colt Step Nicely won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. But Allen Jerkens, who trains for Dreyfus, was a little more definite. We'll go in tile Gotham. I think he'll like the distance.

description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

description: WEDNESDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Pension Reform Bill Gains in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Legislation for extensive reform: of private pension systems on which 35 million workers are relying for income when they retire was approved unanimously today by the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee.

title: Hint by Butz on Controls Triggers StockPrice Rally
description: The stock market displayed its sensitivity to the Nixon Administration's economic policies again yesterday with a swift and sharp rally in response to a hint that the President planned to announce new foodprice controls in his address last night.

title: That Unfinished Oscar Speech
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.For 200 years we have said to the Indian people who are fighting for their land, their life, their families and their right to be free: Lay down your arms, my friends, and then we will remain to gether. Only if you lay down your arms, my friends, can we then talk of peace and come to an agreement which will be good for you.

title: Boycott Pushed in Albany For Nassau's Delegates
description: ALBANY, March 29A decree that the tightly disciplined 13man Nassau County Republican delegation abstain from meat next week in sympathy with the nationwide meat boycott was issued today by the Nassau leader, Assemblyman Joseph M. Margiotta.

title: A Police Crackdown Impedes Homosexuals' Search for Chickens
description: Henry stood in the doorway of a Times Square penny arcade. It was a chilly night and he put his hands in his pockets and shivered.

title: Miss Roberts Has Nuptials
description: Miss Roberta L. Roberts, a promotion specialist with McGrawHill, Inc., and Steven F. Mittman, president of Steven Franklin Designs, Ltd., manufacturer of interior  design accessories, were married here at noon yesterday in the Regency by Rabbi Jack Stern.

title: Monetary Evolution
description: Finance ministers from all over the nonCommunist world flew to Washington this week to have another go at world monetary reform. One may well wonder whether their trip was necessary, since the basic action needed to resolve the extremely serious world monetary crisis of recent months had already been taken.

title: Delaware Basin Unit Removes One Obstacle to 2 Atom Plants
description: TRENTON, March 29  The Delaware River Basin Commission today conditionally cleared away a major obstacle to the construction of two large nuclearpower plants, one proposed for an island in the Delaware just south of here, the other along the Schuylkill River northwest of Philadelphia.

title: A New Jewish Museum To Open Here Sunday
description: More than 2,000 years of Jewish history and ritual unfold in graphic detail in New York's newest repository of classical Judaica  the Yeshiva University Museum, at 185th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: LAST P.O.W.'S LAND AT PHILIPPINE BASE
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Phi lippines, March 29The last 6 American prisoners held by th3 North Vietnamese arrived to night after being released Hanoi. All but one were she down late in December an most were B52 crewmen.

title: Murphy Assails Captains Group
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy and two other top police officials have critized the appointment as president of the. Captains Endowment Association of a police captain who had ben found guilty of lying during a department trial.

title: Ida Rosenthal, CoFounder of Maidenform Dies
description: Mrs. Ida Rosenthal, cofounder of Maidenform, the company credited with changing the shape of American women, died Wednesday at her home here. Her age was 87. She succeeded her husband, William Rosenthal, upon his death in 1958 as president and chief executive of one of the world's largest manufacturers of foundation garments.

title: Newspaper Negotiations Go On With Contracts Expiring Today
description: Negotiators for the Newspaper Deliverers Union and the city's three major daily newspapers pushed their efforts yesterday to work out a new contract agreement to replace the one expiring tonight.

title: Cartoon for Steak on Layaway Plan Stirred Connecticut Housewife to Call Meat Boycott
description: VERNON, Conn., March 29 Barbara Shuttleworth, a young housewife and clubwoman in this comfortable Hartford suburb, laughed when she saw a cartoon in a local paper last month that showed a woman asking a butcher if she could buy a steak on the layaway plan.

title: Needham Rate Bid Stirs Controversy
description: A suggestion by James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, that brokerage commissions might be raised for all but the smallest investors set off a swirl of controversy yesterday.

title: C.I.A.'s Action On Chile Unauthorized, ExAide Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 29Charles A. Meyer, former Assistant Secretary of State for InterAmerican affairs, said today that, so far as he knew, the Central Intelligence Agency was never specifically authorized to explore the possibility of using private American corporations to damage the economy of Chile to influence the 1970 election there.

title: CLARION DELIGHTFUL IN 3 BACH CANTATAS
description: The final Clarion Concert of the season, which took place at Tully Hall Tuesday night, was devoted exclusively to Bach's Cantatas Nos. 79, 80 and 11, and was an almost unreserved delight. Newell Jenkins, music director of the series, struck a nice balance between stylistic authenticity and the demands of large modern halls and common sense.

title: INDICTMENT CITES OFFICERS OF FIRM
description: Top officers of a financially troubled brokerage house were indicted yesterday for allegedly bribing a representative of another brokerage house to borrow $155,000 of inflated stock in exchange for cash.

title: S.E.C. White Paper Seeks Stock MarketRestructure
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The Securities and Exchange Commission today unveiled its master plan to restructure the nation's securities markets. Its aim is to establish a central market system. The system would encompass a network of brokers and dealers in offices and on exchange floors across the nation, linked together by electronic communication.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Planning Unit Approves ConventionCenter Plan
description: The City Planning Commission yesterday unanimously approved a proposal for a $200million convention center and exhibition hall in the Clinton of the West Side.

title: Ali Leads With a Jibe That Foreman Blocks
description: SAN DIEGO, March 29Muhammad All will show up on home television Saturday afternoon when he fights Ken Norton, a former sparring partner of Joe Frazier, in the Sports Arena here. The promoter, Lee Fruin, claims he has a $175,000 gate in hand and that all 14,500 seats may, be filled.

title: Thousands Watch 67 Prisoners Depart
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 29As tens of thousands of North Vietnamese watched and smiled and waved, the last 67 American prisoners flew out of Hanoi to freedom today.

description: FRIDAY, MARCH 30, 1973

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Planners Vote Convention Center

title: Commodity Price Index Off 2.2 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 146.4 from 148.6 last week.

title: Isidor Engelhardt, Who Founded Commuter Bus Lines, Dies at 74
description: Isidor Engelhardt, who had owned the Gray Line sightseeing bus concern, the 196465 World's Fair bus franchise and the Riverdale Transit Company, among other transportation ventures, died in Miami on Wednesday. He was 74 years old and lived at 1050 Fifth Avenue.

title: Republicans Expressing Concern Over Developments in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 You wake up in the morning and hope it goes away, but you go home at night and it's still with you.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: MONEY EXPANSION SLOWS MARKEDLY
CANCER UNIT ASKS ACTION GRANTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The nation's top cancer advisory group has decided to place directly before President Nixon its objections to one important aspect of Administration health policy.

title: Bid to Praise Dr. King Fails
description: NASHVILLE, March 29 (AP) The Tennessee House of Representatives refused today to approve a resolution praising the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. for contributions to human rights. The resolution was introduced by Representative Lois DeBerry.

title: Senate Slates Showdown Vote On CeilingImpoundment Issue
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 The Senate averted a filibuster today by agreeing to a showdown vote next week on proposals to combine a spending ceiling with a curb on the President's ability to decide which spending programs should be cut.

title: Blueprint for Rules
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 The Securities and Exchange Commission's longawaited white paper on the structure of a central market system is essentially a blueprint for rulemaking, some of it by the S. E. C. and some of it by Congress. The centralmarket system has been a highpriority item in discussions by the S. E. C., lawmakers and Wall Streeters for several years. As of yesterday, the S.E.C. pulled it all together and set down in detail the prospective rules and framework.

title: NEWARK WILL GET PROPERTYTAX CUT
description: NEWARK, March 29 Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, who has been warning residents of Newark of a huge increase in property taxes to make ends meet this year, announced today the first propertytax reduction in my three years in office.

title: Notes on People
description: Once again, Presidentelect Dr. Hctor J. Cmpora of Argentina seemed to be succeeding where his political mentor, Juan D. Pern, the former Argentine dictator, had failed. Dr, Campora and his family were permitted a private audience with Pope Paul VI; during which the Pontiff blessed the Argentine people.

title: J. E. GORTON DIES; SCOTTSBORO JUDGE
description: DECATUR, Ala., March 29James E. Horton, the judge who presided at the 1933 Scottsboro trial, in which nine black men were accused of raping two white women, died yesterday in an Athens, Ga., hospital. His age was 95.

title: Mrs. Sally Deitsch Married in London
description: LONDON, March 29Mrs. Sally Grace Deitsch of New York was married here today to David Warren WilsonYoung of London. The Protestant ceremony was performed at Chelsea Old Church by the Rev. C. E. Leighton Thomson.

title: Sadat Broadens His Emergency Powers
description: CAIRO, March 29President Anwar elSadat has proclaimed himself Military Governor General, which gives him the authority to use emergency powers in case of national crisis.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state's secondhighest court ruled against a motorcycle fan, holding that the New Jersey Highway Authority has the right to bar motorcycles from the Garden State Parkway. The Appellate Division of Superior Court found that the regulation bears a direct relationship to the public safety and is reasonable and not arbitrary.

title: Hackensack Gets Renewal Plan
description: HACKENSACK, March 29This city's Housing Authority, which lost a $2million Federal grant last month because of what officials concede was bad planning, indicated tonight that it intended to start the first phase of an ambitious urban renewal program with private capital.

title: Switch Causes L.I.R.R. Delays
description: A balky switch in Long Island City, Queens, caused delays of up to 45 minutes during the rush hours on the Long Island Rail Road last night, affecting 35,000 commuters on more than 50 trains. A spokesman for the railroad said that the trouble started at 5 P.M. and that scattered delays continued until 7:30 P.M.

title: HENRY BEHAR
description: Henry Behar, a founder and former president of Vintage Wines, Inc., died Wednesday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 78 years old.

title: Text of Talks by U.S. General on Leaving Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 29Following are the texts of two speeches made here today by Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, United States commander in South Vietnam. The first marked the deactivation of the Military Assistance Command, Vietnam; and the second, addressed to the South Vietnamese, was made just before he boarded a plane to leave the country.

title: Campaigns in City Will Be Monitored By Common Cause
description: John W. Gardner, chairman of Common Cause, announced yesterday that the citizens lobbying group would monitor campaign financing here this year in the primary and general elections for citywide offices and borough presidents.

title: CRITICS OF CUTBACKS ASSAILED BY AGNEW
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., March 29 Vice President Agnew tonight assailed the groundless and befuddled charges of the critics of Nixon Administration cutbacks in the area of human resources.

title: Auto Race Qualifying Put Off
description: HAMPTON, Ga., March 29 (UPI)Qualifying for Sunday's Atlanta 500 stock car race was postponed today because of rain. Qualifying for the first 15 positions will take place tomorrow at the Atlanta InternaItional Raceway.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 30, 1973

title: Japanese Report Granting Of Licenses to Import Gold
description: TOKYO, March 29 (Reuters) The Japanese Finance Ministry announced today the granting of import licenses for an undisclosed amount of gold for April, following a decision to free imports of industrial gold from the start of next month.

title: Assembly Passes Tuition Bill to Aid Vietnam Veterans
description: TRENTON, March 29The State Assembly passed by a vote of 60 to 0 today a bill that would give New Jersey's Vietnam veterans $500 a year toward their college tuition.

title: BOND PRICES RISE IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: The bond market continued to move toward higher prices and lower interest rates yesterday, spurred by speculation over President Nixon's evening telecast. The, spring rebound remained intact.

title: Delaware River Group Backs Two Atom Plants
description: TRENTON, March 29  The Delaware River Basin Commission today conditionally cleared away a major obstacle to the construction of two large nuclearpower plants, one proposed for an island in the Delaware ju'st south of here, the other along the Schuylkill River northwest of Philadelphia.

title: WPIXTV CANCELS JEWS FOR JESUS
description: WPIXTV yesterday canceled the boradcast of Jews for Jesus, a halfhour program, scheduled for presentation last night at midnight, because of objections by Jewish leaders.

title: DISCLOSURE BILL GAINS IN SENATE
description: TRENTON, March 29The Senate Conference Committee today released a strong campaign disclosure bill that includes criminal penalties for any candidate in state or local election who willfully fails to follow its provisions.

title: Elderly at Center Protest a Transfer
description: A group of 37 elderly people went to City Hall yesterday to ask that the city youth worker who had run their seniorcitizens program in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, be returned from her new post at a youth center in Crown Heights.

title: Harvard Fills History Post
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 29 (AP)Prof. Donald Fleming of Harvard was named today as director of the university's Charles Warren Center for Studies in American History. Professor Fleming specializes in the impact of science upon American thought and has taught at Harvard since 1958. The center gives grants and fellowships for history research.

title: People in Sports: Cowens M.V.P.
description: One of the smallest centers in the National Basketball Association, 6foot9 inch Dave Cowens of the Boston Celtics received more votes than the giants of pro basketball yesterday and was named the league's most valuable player. Following him in the voting by league players were Kareem AbdulSabbar of Milwaukee (72) and Nate Archibald of Kansas CityOmaha (61) It's of no great significance for me, Cowens said. I never look forward to it. But I'm grateful.

title: Minority Groups Score Rules Easing Renewal of TV Licenses
description: WASHINGTON, March 29Representatives of women and minority groups told Congress today that proposed measures to ease renewal of broadcast licenses would threaten their only tool to influence what goes over the airwaves.

title: Man Called Kingpin of a Mafia Ring and 5 Accused of Smuggling 11,000 Cartons of Cigarettes Into City
description: A man described as the kingpin of a Mafia bootlegging ring that cheated New York City and the state out of millions oik dollars was arrested yesterday, allegedly as he directed the unloading of 11,000 cartons ofruntaxed cigarettes within 200 feet of a Brooklyn police station.

title: Pentagon Clears All Fliers Of Falsifying Raid Reports
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)The Senate Armed Services Committee today approved 4,897 Air Force and Navy officers for promotion. The action was taken after the Pentagon certified that none of them had falsified reports on illegal bombing in Vietnam.

title: SZILAGYI'S PLAYING HAS BEAUTIFUL TONE
description: Bela Szilagyi, a prodigy at the age of 12 and a Leventritt Competition finalist later on, has survived the difficulties of maturing and become a fine pianist. Now approaching 40, Mr. Szilagyi, an artistinresidense at Capital University in Columbus, Ohio, serves the music of certain composers with distinction.

title: Council Votes 3Year Extension Of Rent Control for Million Units
description: The City Council yesterday approved overwhelmingly a threeyear extension of rent controls affecting more than one million dwelling units.

title: Mann Theatre Will Buy A National General Unit
description: The National General Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell the assets of its motionpicture theater business to the Mann Theatre Corporation of California for about $67.5million to be paid in a combination of cash and a $6.25million secured note. Eugene V. Klein, chairman and president of National General, which is engaged chiefly in insurance and book publishing, said the closing of the agreement was subject to Mann's completing bank financing.

title: Indochina: Phase II
description: Phase I of the Paris peace accords has now been completed with the withdrawal of the last American ground combat troops from Vietnam and the return of the last war prisoners from North Vietnam. This is a notable achievement of the Administration, and it is one that has brought great relief to the country as a whole.

title: BOAC Musiness Booms
description: LONDON (UPI)British Overseas Airways Corp. BOAC carried 2,632,000 passengers in 1972, an increase of 28 per cent over 1971, the airline said.

title: Kin of Pakistanis Held by India Arrive Here to Appeal for Help
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 29  A group representing the families of some 90,000 Pakistani war prisoners being held in India arrived here today to appeal for help in winning their repatriation.

title: SHARES ON AMEX UP 4TH DAY IN ROW
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market registered their fourth consecutive advance yesterday in slow trading.

title: VOTAPEK'S PIANISM BOLSTERS THE POPS
description: Ralph Votapek played Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 2 with the Boston Pops Orchestra in a concert at Carnegie Hall Tuesday night.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Westbury Track to Experiment With ThreeQuarter Mile Race
description: WESTBURY, L. I., March 29Roosevelt Raceway will experiment with a threequarter mile opening race for $6,000 claiming horses tomorrow night. This marks the first time since the 1954 season that the Westbury harness track has scheduled a race under the normal onemile distance.

title: Bill Delaying City Housing Court Scored
description: ALBANY, March 29  In a rare, sharply worded statement Richard A. Brown, Mayor Lindsay's lobbyist here, today labeled as a cruel hoax upon the tenants of the City of New York the final passage of a bill late yesterday that would delay only until July 1 the opening of a new Housing Court in the city.

title: Missouri Farm Town Stays Calm Despite Its Own High Food Prices
description: SLATER, Mo., March 29Round steak was bringing $1.79 a pound today at the U. S. Supermarket, about 50 cents more than at the turn of the year. But no one complained to Mrs. Betty Moore, the checkout worker, who stood beneath a sign urging customers to fight inflation. No irate housewives picketed on Main Street. There was no demand for horse meat.

title: KAISER TO REVISE ALUMINUM PRICES
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it planned, effective immediately, to book all new business for ingot and billet products only on terms of price in effect at time of shipment. The company explained that no changes would be made in the published prices of such products at this time but the action would have the effect of eliminating discounts on all new primary metal business.

title: CHASE SEES FUNDING IN OIL FALLING SHORT
description: BRUSSELS, March 29 (UPI) The international oil industry probably will not be able to find the trillion dollars needed to fill the world's energy needs by 1985, the Chase Manhattan Bank said today in the latest of a series of gloomy assessments of the world energy picture this week.

title: Stage: Affectionate Tribute to Irish Womanhood
description: Siobhan McKenna  Irish earthmother and actressreturned to Broadway last night with her onewoman show, Here Are Ladies, which opened at the Circle in the Square Joseph E. Levine Theater. I first saw Miss McKenna when she was a slip of a girl nearly 30 years ago in Paul Vincent Carroll's play The White Steed at London's Duchess Theater. Very young, she was a great actress then, and is a great actress still.

title: Lone Ranger and Tonto Fight Crime
description: He shambled around the corner with a street dude's diddlybop gait, and the Latin music from the transistor radio he carried blared at passersby.

title: WAR BOOK CITED IN ELLSBERG CASE
description: LOS ANGELES, March 29 Two years before Dr. Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. copied the Pentagon papers, two reporters traveled around the world gathering some of the same material that was to appear in them, the jury in the Pentagon papers trial was told today.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: EAST DIVISION Carolina vs. Nets

title: No More Massacres
description: Wounded Knee seems to be taking on the sad but classic pattern of so many latterday Indian rebellions: offreservation Indians, both physically and culturally more white than native, try to apply current techniques to the redress of Indian grievances. But the reservation Indians, especially the fullbloods, resent these interlopers almost as much as they do the United States Government, and they resent their own elected officials hardly less. The traditional result has been that the Federal Government puts down the internecine squabbling that inevitably erupts, and the Indians somehow come out with less than they had before.

title: Counterfeiter Sentenced
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 29 (UPI)Sheldon Kent, a former nightclub barker, was sentenced to 12 years in prison yesterday for counterfeiting United States savings bonds.

title: DAYAN ASSAILS BARS TO USE OF ARAB LAND
description: TEL AVIV, March 29Defense Minister Moshe Dayan complained today that some members of the Government were preventing Israeli settlement and land purchases in occupied Arab territory.

description: Colleges

title: Study Finds 70% Rise in Gun Deaths
description: In one week this month, 350 men, women and children in the United States were shot to death. Some were the victims of armed robbers, some were policemen killed in the line of duty and some were shot during family quarrels.

title: Governor's Veto Stands On Public Employes' Bill
description: TRENTON, March 29 A move to override. Govenor Cahill's veto of a bill granting public employes the right to file complaints of unfair labor practices failed in the Assembly today.

title: Welfare IslandManhattan CableCar Plan Disclosed
description: An aerial cablecar system to carry residents of the new town, being built on Welfare Island to a station in Manhattan is in the final stages of planning by the New York State Urban Development Corporation.

title: Music: Maazel Explores
description: The symphonies of Schumann can be among the hardest nuts to crack in the orchestral repertory, only partly because of their occasionally murky and clumsy scoring. As in any significant artist's works, something singular hides in them that must be captured and communidated. Lorin Maazel and the Boston Symphony Orchestra penetrated Schumann's world on Wednesday night at Philharmonic Hall, by way of the No. 2 in C.

description: FREEHOLD, N.J., March 29 (AP)  Remember James won the feature race at Freehold Raceway today, returning $7.80, $2.60 and $2.80 for $2 across the board. The winner paced the mile in 2:05 45.

title: El Al Is Granted Loan
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI)The ExportImport Ban today announced a direct loan to El Al Israel airlines of $1,589,400 to finance 45 per cent of the purchase of $3,532,000 worth of equipment in the United States. The bank said, if required, it could also provide a financial guarantee of a similar amount from nonU.S. source funds.

title: For Children Who May Be Parents Someday
description: The 13yearold students at Robert. Wagner Junior High School eagerly awaited their teacher's arrival yesterday, pleaded for five minutes more after the weekly class had ended and gave up attending a dance to learn about being parents.

title: Bill Seeks to Aid P.O.W.'s On Retirement and Pension
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) Senator Richard S. Schweiker, Republican of Pennsylvania, introduced a bill today to help returned prisoners of war toward early retirements and pensions.

title: CHARLES BURNS DIES; MEDICAL JOURNALIST
description: Charles Burns, a retired medical journalist and former international editor of Look magazine, died Tuesday of liver cancer in Brattleboro. Vt.

title: 3 G. O. P. SENATORS CRICIZE BOMBING
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Three Republican Senators said today that President Nixon did not have constitutional or any other legal authority to continue bombing in Cambodia now that the withdrawal of American forces from South Vietnam had been completed.

title: MISS POTTER KEEPS 3METER DIVE TITLE
description: PITTSBURGH, March 29 (AP) Cynthia Potter retained her threemeter diving title tonight with a victory over Christine Loock of Southern Methodist University in the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor diving championships.

title: PATH Spokesman Terms a Walkout By Carmen Likely
description: A spokesman for the Port Authority TransHudson (PATH) rail system said last night that efforts to reach a new agreement with the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen had failed and that a strike was probable at midnight Saturday.

title: U. S. SEEKS TALKS AT WOUNDED KNEE
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., March 29  A ceasefire between Indians holding Wounded Knee and the Government forces surrounding the historic Indian site entered its third day this afternoon as Government negotiators tried to set up a meeting tomorrow to resolve the monthlong impasse.

title: Questions and Answers on Meat Prices
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)Following are some questions and answers about the new ceilings on meat and how they may affect consumers:

title: The President's Turn
description: A growing number of Republican Senators no longer share the Administration's apparent hope that public apathy will allow President Nixon to ride out the Watergate storm by pretending that the affair does not really concern him. No amount of public apathy could justify Mr. Nixon's posture of disengagement; but the Administration can no longer claim that only the news media are interested in the Watergate caper.

title: City Opera's Young Lord, a Tarzan in Lederhosen
Rap Brown Guilty
description: Rap Brown and three codefendants were found guilty yesterday of armed robbery and assault in the holdup of a West Side bar. The jury said it was hopelessly deadlocked on the charge that the defendants had also tried to murder three policemen after the holdup. Page 14.

title: MEAT PRICE CURB EVOKES CRITICISM FROM CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Members of Congress from both parties and spokesmen for the meat packers and supermarkets voiced disapproval to day of the ceilings on meat prices announced last night by President Nixon in a reversal of policy.

title: GOV. EGAN CHIDES ALASKA AIR GUARD
description: ANCHORAGE, March 30 The Alaska National Guard, under examination by the Air Force Office of Special Investigation and the Federal Bureau of Investigation for alleged misuse of Government aircraft, was shaken late yesterday by Gov. William A. Egan's report that some of the charges against guard officers were true.

title: That Old Lucas Magic Sets Up Knick Victory
description: What you do a lot, you do well, was Jerry Lucas's explanation of his pinpoint shooting from long range last night as the Knicks jumped off to victory in their first playoff game against the Baltimore Bullets.

title: Judge Stays a Law On Computerizing Prescribed Drugs
description: A Federal judge has temporarily restrained New York State from implementing a new law mandating a computerized surveillance of prescriptions for narcotics and other frequently abused drugs.

title: Gliberals
description: BERKELEY, Calif.A brilliant black woman once said to me, Conservatives usually treat me as an individual. I thought of her comment recently when exchanging letters with Clark Whelton, a fine writer and decent man but whose columns about blacks remind me of the letterstotheeditor Steve Allen used to mimic wrote and told him.

title: Discount Rate Is Lifted To. 5 Per cent in Japan
description: TOKYO, Saturday, March 31 (Reuters)The Bank of Japan today raised its official discount rate by an unusually large 0.75 point to 5 per cent from 4.25 per cent, effective Monday, bank governor Tadashi Sasaki announced today.

title: MOSES HOMERS, YANKEES WIN, 41
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 30Jerry Hoses' threerun home run in the seventh inning powered the Yankees to a 41 victory over the Texas Rangeri tonight. It was the new reserve catcher's first homer in a Yankee Uniform.

title: LAYER, SMITH WIN IN 3SET MATCHES
description: ST. LOUIS, March 30 (AP)Topranked Rod Laver and secondseeded Stan Smith were extended to three sets before winning their quarterfinal matches today in the $50,000 Holton tennis tournament.

title: Lone Star Maps Spending
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 30 (UPI)Lone Star Industries, Inc. said today it would spend $57million on capital outlays this year including $7million on air pollution. The company's chief business is the manufacture of cement.

title: Muskie to Answer Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)Senator Edmund S. Muskie was designated today by Democratic Congressional leaders to respond next Monday night to the address made by President Nixon last night. Aides said that the national television and radio networks were being asked to carry the Maine Democrat's speech live as a news event.

title: THIEU DUE TO ASK NIXON ASSURANCE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 30President Nguyen Van Thieu is preparing to set out for the United States tomorrow, and officials at the presidential residence say that his principal purpose is to obtain directly from President Nixon the minimal assurances underwriting the survival of a nonCommunist South Vietnam.

title: PROSECUTOR FACES ASSAULT INQUIRY
description: William Schrager, a suspended assistant Queens district attorney, was ordered held for a grand jury inquiry yesterday after two women who had identified him as the man who sexually accosted them refused to change their stories.

title: College, School Results
WINE TALK
description: More on California wines. The disclosure recently that a California white wine, a Pinot Chardonnay from Freemark Abbey, had won a blind tasting here against the top wines of France drew a great deal of reader comment. Most of it reflected curiosity over the other wines. There was some understandable French chauvinism and there were a couple of skeptics, too.

title: Cahill Offers Plan to Speed Bergen Buses
description: TRENTON, March 30Governor Cahill has proposed a $12million masstransit plan for Bergen County that would convert the Penn Central freight tracks on the old West Shore division into an express bus commutation line to the George Washington Bridge and the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: Sadat's New Powers: Image of a Man Clearing the Deck
description: CAIRO, March 30President Anwar elSadat looked for all the world this week like a ship's captain clearing the deck and battening down the hatches for a stormor a battle.

title: Hyndman and McCue Gain Final in American Seniors
description: MIAMI, March 30  Bill Hyndman 3d of Huntington Valley, Pa., defeated Ray Palmer of Grosse Isle, Mich., 5 and 4, today in the semifinals of the American Seniors golf tournament.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., March 30Henry (Hank) Schmidt will retire from Montclair State College in June, but for Schmidt there is no daydreaming of bouncing around the waters near Cape Cod in his boat with a stiff summer breeze in his face. He is too busy for that right now.

Rationality in Steel
description: The pioneering agreement just reached by the United Steel Workers of America and ten major steel producers is a breakthrough toward rationality in collective bargaining that could benefit the entire American economy. The pact represents specific recognition of the damage inflicted on domestic steel production and on employment for steel workers by the expansion of imports whenever a steel strike is anticipated.

title: Owner of Dancer's Image Asks Court for Derby Cup
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., March 30 (AP)Attorneys for Peter Fuller argued today the State Racing Commission had no authority, under its 1968 rules, to deprive his horse, Dancer's Image, of the winner's cup for the 1968 Kentucky Derby. Fuller's principal attorney, Arthur Grafton, said the commission could do no more than deny Dancer's Image the firstplace purse.

title: Watergate Judge Presses Call for More Witnesses
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The judge in the Watergate case pressed the Government today to summon more witnesses before a Federal grand jury in view of substantive developments in the conspiracy. He did not identify the potential witnesses.

title: City Parade Will Hail All Who Served
description: At least 50,000 marchers are expected to parade north through the canyons of midtown Broadway today to honor the men who served in Southeast Asia during the 12year Vietnam war, parade officials said yesterday.

description: Tampa, Fla.Marlo Saurennan, 147 pounds, Philadelphia, outpointed Eddie Davis, 145, Tampa, 10 rounds.

title: Questions and Answers Concerning Meat Prices
description: WASHINGTON, March 30President Nixon ordered last night a ceiling on the price of beef, veal, pork, mutton and lamb at the processing, wholesale and retail level but not on the price of meat on the hoof or any other foods. Here are some questions raised by the President's action and tentative answers drawn from statements by Administration officials and consumer and industry experts.

title: VIETCONG ACCUSE U.S. AIDES IN SOUTH
description: PARIS, March 30 (Reuters)The Vietcong said today that thousands of United States military advisers disguised as civilians remained in South Vietnam and that their presence hindered a political settlement.

title: Four Rockland Officials Balk at Inquiry
description: NEW CITY, N.Y., March 30  Four high dockland County officials, including the chairman of the County Legislature, have refused to sign waivers of immunity in a major grand jury investigation of official corruption according to the County District Attorney, Robert R. Meehan.

title: TAIWAN REJECTS ANY SOVIET TIES
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 30A year ago a major topic of political speculation in Taiwan was what steps the Government might take to improve relations with the Soviet Union.

description: LONDONThose with weak stomachs for the unpleasant should step reading now.

title: BURCH REMARK PUTS 2 SHOWS OFF THE AIR
description: Two telephone callin radio shows are going off the air here and in Los Angeles following criticsm of socalled sexoriented programs by Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Deliverers and 3 Newspapers Continue Their Contract Talks
description: The Newspaper Deliverers Union and the negotiators for the three major city dailies recessed their bargaining talks shortly before 11 o'clock last night and planned to go ahead with further bargaining next week, averting any immediate strike threat.

title: Union Rejects Offer by PATH; Strike Threatened at Midnight
description: A lastditch offer from PATH officials was overwhelmingly rejected yesterday by the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen, which has threatened to strike the 14mile commuter line at one minute after midnight tonight.

title: AIDE TERMS NIXON WILLING TO ASSIST BUGGING INQUIRIES
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Responding to mounting criticism, the White House indicated today its readiness to compromise with the Senate's investigation of the Watergate case on the issue of furnishing witnesses and information from President Nixon's personal staff.

description: DETROIT, March 30 (AP)Domestic auto production fell slightly this week, according to the industry journal, Automotive News.

title: T.W.A. Shelves Plan For a New Service With Cut in Fares
description: Hours after receiving Government approval of a plan to offer a new kind of coasttoCoast fare as low as $89.50 oneway, Trans World Airlines said yesterday that it was shelving plans to offer the new bargain.

title: Alchemy of the Self
description: LONDON  Before one can grasp what a Moslem is, one must first be aware of what modern man has become. It is precisely the abysmal ignorance of the socalled educated man in our society that makes the crucial question of existence difficult of approach. Cursed with a superficial verbal coherence the educated man feels entitled to expound and express himself endlessly.

title: Six Films by Brothers Kuchar Shown
description: At a certain period in the history of the American independent cinema, the brothers George and Mike Kuchar occupied a position of special, almost unique, importance. This was a time, about 10 years ago, when it began to seem to many that perhaps there wasn't anything outside the mainstream except, say, the solemnity, of Marie Menken, Ray Wismewski, or Gregory Markopolous with Twice a Man. So you can imagine the thrill of learning that all the while, in the pastoral seclusion of the Bronx, two young fellows were laboring at a wholly new kind of art film with such adventures in 8mm. cinema as I Was a Teenage Rumpot, Lust for Ecstasy, A Town Called Tempest and The Naked Nude.

title: Casper's 131 Gains Shot Lead
New Voice Scrambler on Market
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The Technical Communications Corporation, of Lexington, Mass., received a patent this week for a voice scrambler that can be used for privacy in radio or telephone conversations.

title: February Inventories Up; Orders Show a 1.4% Rise
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Manufacturers' inventories rose strongly again in February but sales increased just as fast, the Commerce Department reported today.

description: COLUMBUS, OhioCome March, begin to yearn for home. I want to get on a highway and head southsouth to the Ohio River, south to Kentucky. Appalachia.

title: PERKY BERK WINS WESTBURY SPRINT

title: DOLLAR IS STEADY IN TOKYO MARKET
description: TOKYO, March 30The dollar showed continued strength in heavy trading on the Tokyo foreign exchange market this week, causing a revision in earlier predictions of its eventual parity with the yen.

title: Overseas Sterling Surplus
description: LONDON, March 30 (UPI)The overseas sterling area had a record surplus of about $4.96billion in its current and longterm capital transactions with the rest of the world last year, according to government estimates today. If allowance is made for the departure of Libya from the sterling area, this is nearly four times the 1971 surplus.

title: 3 COMPANIES CUT GAS DELIVERIES
description: Several large oil companies have started putting a limit on or trimming gasoline deliveries because of shortages in crude oil. And a number of independent service stations around the country are closing down or operating on curtailed schedules because demand for automobile fuel is outstripping the supply, The Associated Press reported.

title: Two Operas at Juilliard
description: It is one of the continuing oddities of New York musical life that in a city that crawls with opera zealots, a vast reservoir of worthwhile chamber works goes virtually untapped by professional artists. The inauguration of the Metropolitan Opera's season recently sent out rays of hope that the situation could eventually change; meanwhile, connoisseurs of the lesser varieties of opera (lesser in size, though not invariably in quality) must be content with what the music schools can do with their limited resources.

title: The Elderly Becom V. I. P.'s at a City Center Matinee
description: The program was printed in largesized type. The opera singers' voices were amplified electrically. The house lights were not dimmed in the regular way. The intermission was a little longer than usual.

title: Soviet Accuses U.S. of Role in '67 War
description: MOSCOW, March 30  A prominent Soviet newspaper correspondent has charged that the United States Central Intelligence Agency gave the orders in 1967 for the start of Israel's attack on her Arab neighbors.

title: TRIAL DATE IS SET FOR VESCO IN SUIT
description: NEWARK, March 30 (UPI)Superior Court Judge Max Mehler today set a trial date of Oct. 15 for Robert L. Vesco, former chairman of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., on charges that he acted improperly in gaining control of the oncepowerful mutual fund empire founded by Bernard Cornfeld.

title: Gen. Clifford R. Powell, 80; Jersey Senator Led Guard
description: BURLINGTON, N. J., March, 130 (AP)Maj. Gen. Clifford R. Powell, a retired commander of the New Jersey National Guard and a former State Senator and Assemblyman, died of a heart attack a Burlington County Memorial Hospital Wednesday. He was 80 years old and lived in Lumberton.

title: COLONELS TROUNCE SQUIRES BY 129101

title: Dog Aids Heroin Seizure
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 30 (UPI)  A German shepherd named Zorro sniffed out 44 pounds of heroin yesterday the largest heroin seizure West Coast history. Agents arrested Tang Kuang Heok, 38 years old, whe he claimed two suitcases at San Francisco International Airport. The heroin was estimated to be worth $14million in street value.

description: CAMDEN, March 30  The State Division of Consumer Protection obtained a temporary restraining order today against a burglaralarm company that has been recruiting distributors in South Jersey and Philadelphia through a pyramid sales scheme that promises quick, huge profits.

He is also a director of the Westington Electric Corporation, Standard Oil Company (Ohio) and the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.

title: German Chamber Appoints
description: Alfred H. Von Klemperer, senior vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, has been elected chairman of the German American Chamber of Commerce, succeeding Hans Stauffer, who remains a director. Eugene J. Schulte, president of the Ferrostaal Overseas Corporation, was named president of the chamber.

title: Through a Lens, Seeking
description: Edward Steichen left his imprint on photography by insisting that it could become an artin portraiture, commerce, in battle and, finally, in the service of the human family. His photographs of celebrated people ranged from Rodin to Garbo; his combat pictures on the carrier Lexington are part of the annals of war. When he created the great photographic exhibition for the Museum of Modern Art503 pictures from 68 countries called The Family of Mana new dimension was added to art and photography. In his mature years, he enlarged his own depth of field: art became secondary to the study and the portrayal of man's common humanity.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 31, 1973

title: The U. S. Pullout Finished, Bunker Quits Saigon Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (Reuters)President Nixon today accepted with deepest personal regret the resignation of Ellsworth Bunker as United States Ambassador to South Vietnam and announced that he would name a career diplomat, Graham A. Martin, to the Saigon post.

title: BROKER SURRENDERS IN STOCKFRAUD CASE
description: Kenneth Bove, president of the defunct securities firm of Kenneth Bove & Co., turned himself in yesterday to Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's office.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Holley Carburetor division of Colt Industries, Inc., has received a longterm contract estimated at $75million from the Ford Motor Company to manufacturer 40 per cent of Ford's original equipment requirements for an emission control component known as an air pump. It is anticipated that air pumps, which introduce compressed air into the exhaust system of an engine where it mixes with hot gases and further oxidizes unburned hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide, will be required on 1975 cars.

title: Rabbi Warns U.S. Judaism Is Facing Extinction
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 30A lading American rabbi has warned that spiritual Judaism in this country is headed for extinction.

title: SHOP TALK
description: With little dressmakers no longer flourishing, and not too many women adept at wielding a scissors and needle, an individual look is hard to come by. The stores are trying, however. They've singled out designers with a look of their own in the hopes that they will arouse a shock of recognition in at least some women.

title: Futures of Live Hogs and Beef Cattle Gain in Commodities Trading
description: Commodity futures prices for live hogs and live beef cattle on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange were quite strong yesterday.

description: It is rare for an artist to concentrate on the art of drawing as his sole medium, and it is risky as well. We tend to think of drawings, even perfectly finished drawings, as preparations for something still to be realized.

description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)Carlos C. Villarreal, a former California marketing executive, was appointed by President Nixon today to fill a vacancy as commissioner of the Postal Rate Commission, which supervises the new United States Postal Service.

description: A television town meeting, dealing with the transportation problems of the New YorkNew JerseyConnecticut urban region, will be broadcast at various times over every TV channel in the region this weekend.

description: The Consolidated Edison Company and two unions representing its 18,000 employes reached agreement on new twoyear contracts yesterday, averting a strike threatened for midnight.

description: WASHINGTON, March 30Dr. Arthur F. Burns conceded openly for the first time today that his successful effort to hold the prime lending rate at commercial banks below other market interest rates has been encouraging an excessive and potentially unhealthy expansion of bank credit.

description: BOARDMAN, Ore, March 30 (AP)A Navy A6A Intruder jet on a routine training mission out of Whidby Island Naval Air Station near Seattle crashed Wednesday near Boardman Naval Weapons System training Facility, killing, its two occupants. They were Lieut. Comdr. B. J. Keen, 34 years old, of Philmath, Ore., and Lieut. William A. Vasina, 26, of Binghamton.

description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The State Athletic Commission refused yesterday to go along with the French Boxing Federation's suspension of Emile Griffith and asked the French commission to withdraw the suspension. Griffith was suspended March 13 after fighting a 10round draw in Paris with Max Cohen when a sample of Griffith's urine submitted before the bout showed traces of amphetamine. The French authorities asked New York to suspend him, too.

description: ALBANY, March 30  Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson, in his capacity as acting governor, today signed into law a bill delaying until July 1 the starting date for a new Housing Court within the Civil Court in New York City.
