title: Rail TonMileage Up 3.7%
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The Association of American Railroads reported yesterday that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimate 15.9 billion tonmiles, 3.7 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same week totaled 512,054 cars, 1.4 per cent above the corresponding week of last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity trucking tonnage was 10.4 per cent above last year.

title: HUGH PAINE, 68, DIES; A STOCKBROKER HERE
description: Hugh E. Paine, a stockbroker and a leader in humanitarian activities, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 1 Beekman Place and in Willsboro, N. Y.

title: Cahill Wants Pennsy Track To Speed Buses in Bergen
description: TRENTON, March 30Governor Cahill has proposed a $12million masstransit plan for Bergen County that would convert the Penn Central freight tracks on the old West Shore division into an express bus commutation line to the George Washington Bridge and the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Miss Evert Earns Semifinal Meeting With Soviet Star
description: It will be Chris Evert, America's pride and joy, against Marina Kroshina, a pert blond teenager from the Soviet Union, in the semifinals of the $30,000 Lady Gotham tennis tournament tonight.

title: PAUL MUENCH
description: DUNEDIN, Fla., March 30Paul Muench, who retired two years ago as president of the ShorlaneBenet Company, Inc., a New York theatrical advertising agency, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Tuesday. He was 67 years old.

title: Jet Engine Award Made
description: MIAMI, March 30 (UPI)Aerodex, Inc., said today that the armed services' Board of Contract Appeals had awarded it $5.13million on a disputed claim for overhaul work on J57 military jet aircraft engines. Raymond Tonks, president of Aerodex, said that the company would file a motion for reconsideration of the $4million portion of the claim that had not been allowed by the board.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs EAST DIVISION Carolina vs. Nets.
description: Kentucky vs. Virginia

title: Books of The Times
description: CATHOLIC AMERICA. By John Cogley. 304 pages. Dial Press. $9.95.

title: Butz Foresees Record In Beef Imports by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz estimated today that 1973 beef imports would be a record 1.45 billion pounds, up 8 per cent from last year.

title: Notes on People
description: The Soviet Union's Minister of Culture, Yekaterina A. Furtseva, gave President Nixon a landscape painting in the White House and at a news conference later defended the ban in her country on works by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, the Soviet ovelist who won a Nobel Prize in 1970.

title: Owen I. A. Roche, Author And Trade Consultant, 62
description: Owen I. A. Roche, an author and consultant on international affairs, died last Saturday after a brief illness. He was 62 years old.

title: TRUCE COMPLAINT VOICED BY SAIGON
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, March 30 (AP)South Vietnam complained today to the International Commission of Control and Supervision that Communistled forces had carried out sustained shelling and infantry assaults on ranger camps at Tong Le Chan, 50 miles north of Saigon, and at Rach Bap, 30 miles north of the capital.

title: MRS. L. CLAIR NELSON
description: PELHAM, N.Y., March 30Mrs. Dorothy Emmett Nelson, the wife of L. Clair Nelson, senior vice president for legal affairs of Champion International, the forestproducts company previously known as U.S. Plywood  Champion Papers, died Wednesday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. She was 54 years old and lived at 136 Conies Avenue.

title: Iraqi Occupation of Kuwait Area Stirs Arab Concern
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 30  Iraq's military occupation of a disputed border area in Kuwait is viewed with concern in Arab countries as an example of power politics in the Persian Gulf.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Opera

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES REACHES PILOT PACT
description: American Airlines reached new labor agreement last night with its pilots, paving the way for an end to slowdowns and cancellations that have produced heavy recent losses.

title: Term Paper: A Russian Cookbook
description: The main dish for lunch was kulebiaka, a goldenbrown pie in a pastry crust filled with fish, rice and mushrooms. It was almost big enough to hide the petite, darkhaired girl who had enveloped herself in a chef's apron over blue jeans and sneakers.

title: Captain Says Resistance by P.O.W.'s Forced Captors to Be Brutal
description: WASHINGTON, March 30One of the senior American officers in the North Vietnamese prison camps said today that the prisoners forced their captors to be brutal to us by resisting their demands to the last possible point of human endurance.

title: ExReporter Upheld at Ellsberg Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, March 30The judge in the Pentagon papers trial today upheld a former reporter's right not to eveal the sources of his in formation.

title: House Foe of Spending Out  Nixons Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 The electronic scoreboard perched along the rims of the House balconies blinker fitfully.

title: NETS BOW, 10496, AS PLAYOFFS OPEN
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 30  Billy Cunningham and Steve Jones scored 47 points and the Carcilina Cougars won their first American Basketball Association playoff game by defeating the New York Nets, 10496, before a crowd of 4,725 in the Greensboro Coliseum tonight.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: PostAttica Plan Is Credited In Maryland Prison Strife
description: BALTIMORE, March 30 (AP) State corrections and penitentiary officers have credited a new riot control plan, developed after the 1971 prison riot at Attica, N. Y., with bringing a speedy end to a disturbance at the Maryland Penitentiary late last night.

title: Protestants Form a New Party In Ulster to Fight British Plan
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 30Protestant factions opposed to Britain's constitutional proposals for Northern Ireland broke away from the dominant Unionists today to form a new political party.

title: STORM HITS SOUTH AND THE SOUTHWEST
description: officials appear as sworn witnesses in open session and the White House's offer, made separately to the Senate Judiciary committee, to accept written questions and supply written answers.

title: Antiques.: Collecting Chinese Ceramics
description: Chinese ceramics have suddenly become the rage, both here and abroad, reported Ralph M. Chait this week, looking amazingly refreshed after a threeweek buying trip in Europe that would have exhausted anyone half his 81 years.

title: MEAT PRICE CURB EVOKES CRITICISM FROM CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Members of Congress from both parties and spokesmen for the meat packers and supermarkets voiced disapproval today of the ceilings on meat prices announced last night by President Nixon in a reversal of policy.

title: Watergate Judge Presses Call for More Witnesses
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The judge in the Watergate case pressed the Government today to summon more witnesses before a Federal grand jury in view of substantive developments in the conspiracy. He did not identify the potential witnesses.

title: Public TV Comes Under Fire As Senate Budget Hearings End
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)Public television was accused today of promoting liberal bias and at the same time, of encouraging conservative propaganda.

title: Laotian Official Sees Indications That Hanoi Troops Plan to Stay
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 30 The acting Defense Minister said today that there were growing indications that North Vietnam did not intend to withdraw its troops from Laos and might even be planning to seize more territory.

title: Ted Patrick Denies Assault in Kidnapping Case
description: Ted Patrick, central figure in a controversy in which parents have been kidnapping their children from religious groups, was arraigned yesterday on an assault charge filed by a young man who eluded abduction by his parents.

title: People in Sports: Suns Fill a Vacancy
description: Other coaches have had easier transitions from college to professional basketball. John McLeod of Oklahoma got the coaching job with the Phoenix Suns yesterday with the assignment of injecting some life into a team which has dropped to a 3844 wonlost record. Jerry Colangelo, general manager of the Suns, cited McLeod's credentials:

title: BOTH PRUZANSKYS TRIUMPH ON PINS
description: Dave and Stuart Pruzansky, brothers from Passaic, N. J., pinned their opponents in the second period last night to highlight the first round of the 15th annual Eastern Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championships at the New York Athletic Club.

title: PROCESSORS DOUBT PRICES WILL FALL
description: CHICAGO, March 30In the midst of widespread confusion in the meat industry today, packers, wholesalers and livestock feeders said they expected President Nixon's new ceiling on beef and pork to keep supermarket prices at their current high levels and do nothing to bring them down in the future.

title: RAYMOND P. CURRIER OF LEPROSY MISSIONS
description: Raymond P. Currier, who retired here as general secretary of American Leprosy Missions in 1960, died Wednesday on a visit to Thompson, Conn. He was 81 years old and lived at 6 Hillside Avenue, CrotononHudson, N.Y.

title: E.P.A. ORDERS CURBS ON 3 HAZARDS IN AIR
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)  The Government imposed new rules today to cut down the amount of three hazardous substances  asbestos, beryllium and mercurythat Americans breath.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: New Muscle for Congress

title: JOHN BRENNAN
description: John Brennan, a sales manaber with the Ocean Press division of United Press International, died yesterday of cancer at the Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at the Columbia University Club, 4 West 43d Street.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The Department of Commerce reported yesterday that department store sales last week were an estimated $827million, up 7 per cent from the yearearlier $771million. Total retail store sales were about $8.97billion, up 10 per cent from the yearearlier $8.138billion.

title: 15 Congressmen Organize a Lobby Against Staten Island Bill at Albany
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 Fifteen of the 18 House members from New York City, who sometimes have enough trouble moving their own bills through Congress, have joined in a lobbying effort to try to block a bill in the New York State Legislature in Albany. What is involved is adispute over the future of a park on Steten Island, plus a touch ofmayoral politics. At the urging of Representative John M. Murphy, Democrat of Staten Island, the New York House members have signed an appeal to Speaker Perry B. Duryea Jr. of the State Assembly, urging the defeat of a bill creating a South Richmond Development Corporation.

title: MRS. FREDERICK V. FELL
description: Mrs. Margaret Brilant Fell, wife of Frederick V. Fell, book publisher, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 59 years old and lived at 652 West Hudson Street, Long Beach, L.I.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
U.S. Bars All Food Shipments to Wounded Knee
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., March 30 Some 40 or 50 families of Indians caught inside the village of Wounded Knee when dissident Indians took it over last month will not be sent food even though some are reported to have run out of supplies.

title: Exxon Corp. Unit Raises Its Prices for Crude Oil
description: Price increases were announced yesterday on crude oil and several small imported, cars.

title: People and Business
description: Pierre  Paul Schweitzer, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, has informed its board of executive directors that he will retire at the end of his present term in August.

title: In Mexico's South, They Are Drugged With Music Too
description: OAXACA, Mexico, March 2 For young people who like beer with their mushrooms and a plant called tears of the Virgin with their marijuana, it is apparently the in season to be in this provincial capital.

title: WOR SIGNS GLICKMAN FOR JET BROADCASTS
description: Marty Glickman, who has been broadcasting the Giants football games over radio station WNEW since 1961, has been signed to broadcast the Jets games next season for station WOR. He will replace Merle Harmon, the WOR Jets broadcaster since 1964.

title: All TV Channels Here Will Air a Poll on Transit
description: A television town meeting, dealing with the transportation problems of the New YorkNew JerseyConnecticut urban region, will be broadcast at various times over every TV channel in the region this weekend.

title: DANIEL L. PARRY
description: BALDWIN, L. I., March 30Daniel L. Parry, who retired in 1967 as corporate secretary of the American Bureau of Shipping, died yesterday of cancer at the South Nassau Hospital. His age was 70, and he had lived here.

title: Farmer Is Seen Pitted Against the Retailer Boycott Is Cited
description: The initial reaction by cattle and hog dealers yesterday to President Nixon's freeze on wholesale and retail prices of beef, pork and lamb was one of disbelief and dismay.

title: 3 Boys Held in Drowning Of Friend in His Bathtub
description: Two 14yearold boys and one 15yearold were charged with murder yesterday in the bathtub drowning of a 16yearold friend in his father's apartment in the Inwood section of Manhattan.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two hundred men, women and children protesting Federal cutbacks in daycare funds tied up traffic on the Triborough Bridge yesterday morning. Six persons were arrested and three policemen received minor injuries.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OUTPUT It all this adds up correctly, the First Annual Computer Arts Festival, a plethora of punchboard production performance, will be running from tomorrow through April 14, and then pop up again for a day on April 17, at the Mercer Arts Center's Kitchen, the room in town best equipped to handle electronic's esthetic impulses, at 240 Mercer Street (4759865, afternoons).

title: Nixon Meat Price Decision Nearly 3 Weeks in Making
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The decision to impose a ceiling on meat prices was nearly three weeks in the making but so closely guarded that until shortly before President Nixon's announcement last night many advisers who had been involved were not sure what he would do.

title: VIDEOTAPE DEVICE ON SATELLITE FAILS
description: The videotape recorder on the Earth Resources Technology Satellit (ERTS1) has apparently failed and the spacecraft's earth surveying will now be limited to Nofth and South America, the National Aeronutics and Space Administration announced yesterday.

title: G.O.P. to Get Preference In Park Jobs, Says Aldrich
description: In an unusual display of Political candor, Alexander Aldrich, the State Park Commissioner, said yesterday that Republicans would get preference for temporary summer jobs in state parks.

title: High School Notes
description: Four men were peering at an old photograph of earnest young students in stiff high school graduation poses. Isn't that Moskowitz? one asked. There's McDowell, and there's Albeit, that jerk.

title: EXCONVICTS GET COAST VOTE RIGHT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 30 (UPI)The California Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that former convicts have the right to vote, and that their disenfranchisement was no longer needed to prevent election fraud.

title: WHALERS TURN BACK RAIDERS IN OVERTIME
description: BOSTON, March 30 (UPI) Terry Caffery's goal at 7 minutes 30 seconds of the overtime period, his third of the game, gave the New England Whalers a 54 victory over the New York Raiders in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

title: I Quit, Martin Tells Tigers
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 30Billy Martin ended a tumultuous week today by resigning as manager of the Detroit Tigers after having fined Willie Horton, one of his star outfielders.

title: Court Sentences Teachers To Give Volunteer Services
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 30 (AP)Fines of $250 each and Sentences of 40 hours of volunteer service have been imposed on 21 leaders of the teachers' union for defying an injunction to halt the recent school strike.

title: House Foe of Spending OutNixons Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 The electronic scoreboards perched along the rims of the House balconies blinked fitfully.

title: BERGEN G.0.P. HITS AT SANDMAN SUIT
description: NEWARK, March 30 The Bergen County Republican Committee and two of its offshoots urged a Federal Court today to dismiss a suit filed against them by Representative Charles W. Sandman on the ground that it raised serious constitutional issues.

title: Frances Griscom, 93, Dies; Oldest U.S Golf Champion
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 30 (UPI)Miss Frances Griscom, the oldest former national women's golf champion, died today at her Wateroak Plantation home. She was 93 years old.

title: City Parade Will Hail All Who Served
description: At least 50,000 marchers are expected to parade north through the canyons of midtown Broadway today to honor the men who served in Southeast Asia during the 12year Vietnam war, parade officials said yesterday.

title: Mayor's Daughter Is Convicted In Slaying of TeenAged Friend
description: Newark, March 30 (AP)June Hart, the daughter of the Mayor of East Orange, William S. Hart, was convicted today of manslaughter in the fatal stabbing of a friend during dispute over money.

title: Mixture of Goodwill and Parties Precedes Display of Soviet Art
description: WASHINGTON, March 30In an offbeat mixture of bubbling international goodwill, commercialism, dressup parties and artworld flattery, an exhibition of paintings from the Soviet Union has begun its unveiling in the National Gallery of Art.

title: A.T.&T. Political Donation Ruled Illegal
description: A Federal judge has ruled that $50,000 contributed by the New York Telephone Company to a campaign for the transportation bond issue in the state's 1971 election was an illegal political contribution.

title: Learning to Have a Secretary, Not Be One
description: By EILEEN SUMMERS What is the difference between authorized and outstanding shares?

title: Korea Set for I.M.F Loan
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)The International Monetary Fund said today a drawing of up to $20million Special Drawing Rights had been approved for South Korea through this year. The drawing authority is $10million special drawing rights below an earlier arrangement which the Koreans never had to use. The fund said in August, 1972, Korea took strong policy measures to stabilize the price level, after an accelerated increase in the first seven months of the year. Significant gains were made in 1972 in improving the balance of payments position, including roughly halving the trade deficit.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 31, 1973 ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: 2 MAJOR BROKERS LAY OFF WORKERS
description: Two major Wall Street brokerage firmsShearson, Hammill & Co., Inc., and Loeb, Rhoades & Co.said yesterday they had made substantial employe layoffs as a result of a decline in business.

title: Knicks Overcome Bullets, 9583
description: Playing progressively better after a ragged first quarter, the New York Knicks took the opener of their National Basketball Association playoffs series with Baltimore last night by a 9583 score while a capacity crowd of 19,694 screamed ecstatically at Madison Square Garden.

title: Hitting Woes Plague Mets
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30The New York Mets broke camp today and started a meandering trip north with 25 players and several major problems.

title: Despite Its Critics, American Film Institute May Be Here to Stay
description: LOS ANGELES, March 30After years of obscurity, controversy and internal discord, the American Film Institute will be in the limelight tomorrow night, when President Nixon comes here to present its Life Achievement award to John Ford, the director.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Rider Soccer Star Signs
description: PHIADELPHIA, March 30 (AP)The Philadelphia Atoms of the North American Soccer League have signed Bob Smith, a former Rider College star who was the team's thirdround draft choice. Smith was named the past three seasons to the allMiddle Atlantic Conference team, and was the M.A.C.'s most valuable player the last two years.

title: Executives Set Stock Lobbying
description: A group of more than 100 top executives of companies listed on the American Stock Exchange met privately yesterday in a New York hotel to organize a lobbying group that hopes to influence stock market legislation and regulation.

title: BRACCIALE VICTOR IN 4 PIMLICO RACES
description: BALTIMORE, March 30Vincent Bracciale Jr. who has won more races this year than any other jockey in North America, rode four winners at Pimlico Race Course today and ran his total to 11 for the week and 133 for the year.

title: Month's End
description: Today marks the end of Red Cross monththe time of year when the Red Cross conducts its annual appeal in residential areas to supplement funds raised in the business community through the United Fund of Greater New York. Contributions will help Red Cross continue to assist the community in meeting today's challenges. They will also help the Red Cross provide its traditional services to disaster victims, servicemen and veterans, offer health and safety training and expand blood collection and distribution facilities.

title: Nixon's Speech: A Clue to Future Path
description: WASHINGTON, March 30President Nixon's address to the nation last night on foreign and domestic matters was being viewed today as an indicator of both his mood and the manner in which he will lead the country in the future.

title: Uruguay Peso Rate Raised
description: MONTEVIDEO, (Reuters), March 30 (Reuters)  The Uruguayan Central Bank today incerased the buying selling rate of the United States dollar on the commercial exchange market to 837/845 pesos per dollar from 815/823.

title: Men's A.A.U. Basketball
description: NATIONAL TOURNAMENT

title: BUCKS WIN, 11090, IN WARRIOR SERIES
description: MILWAUKEE, March 30 (AP) Lucius Allen scored 9 of his 20 points in a decisive third quarter tonight, leading the streaking Milwaukee Bucks to a 11090 victory over the Golden State. Warriors in the first round of the National Basketball Association Western Conference semifinal playoffs.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs EASTERN CONFERENCE Knicks vs. Baltimore
description: Boston vs. Atlanta

title: Hanoi's People Still Curious and Friendly
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 29  Despite the heavy facade of official policy statements confronting any foreign visitor to North Vietnam, scores of Hanoi residents proved to be startlingly frank, curious and amiable to one visitor, believed to be the first VietnameseAmerican to come here since the country became independent.

title: RED CARPET DOWN FOR DOGS AT SHOW
description: CHICAGO, March 30Exhibitors will get the red carpet treatment in the International Amphitheater, when the twoday International Kennel Club of Chicago Show opens tomorrow morning.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Ted Patrick, the central figure in a controversy in which parents have been kidnapping their children from religious groups, was arraigned on an assault charge filed by a young man who eluded abduction by his parents. He pleaded not guilty before Manhattan, Criminal Court Judge William Shea, who set April 11 for trial.

title: Betty Furness Appointed To Bess Myerson's Post
description: Mayor Lindsay named Betty Furness as the city's new Consumer Affairs Commissioner yesterday. She replaces Bess Myerson, who resigned after four years in the job.

title: Betty Furness Given Myerson Poal
description: Mayor Lindsay named Betty Furness as the city's new Consumerd Affairs Commissioner yesterday. She replaces Bess Myerson, who resigned after four years in the job.

title: Bridg:
description: A player who reaches a close game contract and then brings it home by skillful play knows that he has a satisfying profit in rubber bridge and can be confident of a big score in a duplicate pair game. But it may be a different story in a headtohead team match, as the diagramed deal from the recent Spring Nationals demonstrates.

title: Music: Turkish Flavor
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, Pierre Boyle: conducting, with Maralin Nisica, Media Armstrong, Barbara Shuttieworth, George Shirley, Andrea Veils, Spiro Males, Saverio Barbieri, Terrence Hawkins Henry Butler, Cale Johnson, singers; Henry Butler, narrator; and Bruce PrincenJoseph, harpsichord. At Philharmonic Hall.

title: Butcher Sympathizes as Poor Families Back Boycott
description: John Kennedy, a $100aweek laborer with three children, walked out of a supermarket on the Lower East Side with a package of canned goods and a shellshocked look.

title: The Elderly Become V.I.P.'s at Cultural Events Here
description: The program was printed in largesized type. The opera singers' voices were amplified electrically. The house lights were not dimmed in the regular way. The intermission was a little longer than usual.

title: State Plan Offered to Cut Disparities in School Aid
description: ALBANY, March 30  Gov. ernor Rockefeller today made public a proposal by his stall for revising state aid to pub. lic schools to reduce the great disparities in spending between rich and poor school districts.

title: Dr. Sidney Farber, a Pioneer In Children's Cancer Research
description: BOSTON, March 30Dr. Sidney Farber, director of research of the Children's Cancer Research Foundation, died, apparently of a heart attack, in his office at 35 Binney Street this evening. He was 69 years old.

title: U.S. and Russians Hold Arms Sessions in Geneva
description: GENEVA, March 30 (Reuters) Soviet and American negoti, ators today completed the third week of a new round of talks on limiting strategic nuclear weapons with a twohour meeting at the Soviet mission here.

title: PUBLIC TELEVISION FORMS NEW GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Representatives of the country's public television stations voted today to form themselves into a new and what they hope is a stronger, central organization known as the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: ELI 15 FAVORITE AGAINST NORTON
description: SAN DIEGO, March 30 (AP) Muhammad Ali puts his people's champion reputation on the line tomorrow against Ken Norton, the hometown champion.

title: Spain's FoodStarless
description: MADRID, March 30 (UPI) Michelin issued its first Red Guide of Spain today and awarded no stars to any restaurants.

title: Lab Discovery May Aid Transplants
description: NOGALES, Ariz., March 30A young surgeon who turned his attention from the operating room to basic laboratory research has stumbled upon phenomenon that might make it possible to transplant organs without using dangerous immunitysuppressing drugs.

title: CONSUMERS TO BE CEILING ENFORCERS
description: Under the enforcement regulations for President Nixon's new ceiling on meat prices, the customer will have the right to demand the sales records used by a store to figure its top price for an item.

title: June Driscoll Has Nuptials
description: ORANGE, N. J., March 30 Miss June Driscoll, daughter of Mrs. Thomas J. Driscoll of Rutherford and the late Mr. Driscoll, was married this evening to Robert G. Mayer, It widower, of West Orange. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Albert B. Mayer of New York.

title: Rangers' LineUp
description: CHANNEL 9, WORTV, 2 P.M.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Can you lend me $10, Will? Bill Bradley asked.

title: Peking's Man in Washington
description: Huang Chen, one of China's most seasoned diplomats and a figure of marked importance within the country's Communist party, was named yesterday to head China's liaison office in Washington.

title: Stamp Museum Robbed
description: WESTON, Mass., March 30 (AP)  Thieves broke into the Cardinal Spellman Philatelic Museum on the Regis College Campus today and took from $50,000 to $100,000 in stamps, the police said.

title: N.L.R.B. Hits Texas Concern; Ousted Workers Ordered Back
description: EL PASO, Tex., March 30 (AP)The National Labor Relations Board said yesterday that the Farah Manufacturing Company, Inc., had violated Federal law by discharging employes and changing work rules at its El Paso plant so as to interfere with employes joining the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.

title: BURNS CONCEDES ADVERSE EFFECTS IN RATE PRESSURE
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Dr. Arthur F. Burns conceded openly for the first time today that his successful effort to hold the prime lending rate at commercial banks below other market interest rates has been encouraging an excessive and potentially unhealthy expansion of bank credit.

title: Richard J. Pietschmann, 62,1 Film, TV Sound Technician
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 30Richard J. Pietschmann, a sound technician for television, and motion pictures, who concentrated in recent years on recording specials and documentaries for the Columbia Broadcasting System, died of; a stroke Wednesday at the Nassau Community Hospital in Mineola. His age was 62, and he lived here.

title: Israelis Alarmed by Jews for Jesus
description: TEL AVIV, March 30Government leaders in Jerusalem are considering measures to curb Christian missionaries, who are said to have become more aggressive in Israel with the appearance of the Jews for Jesus movement.

title: MILWAUKEE OFFICER SURRENDERS TO LAW
description: MILWAUKEE, March 30 Richard C. Nowakowski, the chairman of the Milwaukee County Board of Supervisors, surrendered to law enforcement officers today, 24 hours after he was indicted on eight felony counts by a Milwaukee grand jury.

title: Art Review
description: About five years ago, Reg Butler shifted gear from a style inspired by primitive and African sculpture to what looked at first like a conversion to poprealism in lifesize, tinted, explicitly detailed female nudes. His new show at the Pierre Matisse Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, gives you the impression, as you enter, that there's been a mistake and you've somehow gotten into the O.K. Harris gallery in Soho, where our leading waxworkscastfromlife sculptors exhibit. But it takes only a minute to recognize that in spite of real hair wigs and realistic glass eyes and hyperexplicit femaleness, these are not realistic sculptures but the wildest, most obsessive fantasties.

title: Walking to Pretoria
description: Is it possible for white men to sit around a table and solve the problems of blackwhite relations? Can Europeans mould the future for blacks? Some believe it is possible. Prime Minister Vorster, classified by South Africa's race laws as a European, and U.N. Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of Austria, meet in South Africa to hold a dialogue. Black leaders are precluded from these talks which take place against the background of South Africa's legal network of racial discrimination  apartheid. The talks will be secret, but it is no secret that Mr. Waldheim wishes to discuss and construct a future for South Africa's expressed blacksat least the future of Africans in Namibia (SouthWest Africa).

title: A Sensuous Zoo Reopens in the Bronx
description: Spring comes to the city in various wayswith the first robin, by a date on the calendar or when the circus arrives. At the Bronx Zoo, it comes with the reopening of the Children's Zoo there.

title: MRS. F. C. LAUBACH
description: SYRACUSE, March 30Mrs. Effa E. Laubach, the widow of Dr. Frank C. Laubach, a literacy expert, died last evening at the age of 90.

title: Central School Board Decides to Shift Tilden Houses Pupils From Canarsie
description: Children living in the largely black Tilden Houses projects in Brownsville will be phased out of the CanarsieEast Flatbush school district in Brooklyn over the next eight years, under plan adopted unanimously last night by the Board of Education.

title: A Grocer Goes to Jail For Cutting Milk Price
description: BANGOR, Me., March 30 (AP)A Bangor grocer who was tired of explaining rising food prices to his customers went to jail today for selling milk 2 cents below the price set by the Maine Milk Commission.

title: Art From Soviet Museums in the Capital
description: The 41 modern French paintings on loan to the National Gallery of Art in Washington from the Pushkin Museum in Moscow and the Hermitage Museum in Leningrad, ranging from an enchanting early Monet to brilliant early Matisses and Picassos, are indeed a superb group of paintings from a halfcentury that is just now the most widely known, the most avidly collected and, for a wide public, the most admired and loved in the entire history of art. The selection is far from a summary of the periodit includes, for instance, no Manet and no Degasbut everyone will want to see it, either in Washington where it opens to the public tomorrow, or in New York at the Knoedler Gallery, May 326.

title: Farmer Killed in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 30 (Reuters)African nationalist guerrillas killed a white farmer in the Wedza area, about 70 miles southeast of Sailsbury today, according to headquarters of the security force here. The headquarters statement said that security forcer were searching for a guerrilla gang known to be in the area.

title: LESS PROFIT SEEN IN GHETTO HOUSING
description: Robert M. McGlotten, a special assistant to Peter J. Brennan, the Secretary of Labor, urged minority contractors here yesterday to deemphasize efforts at obtaining ghetto housingconstruction projects and concentrate instead on getting work where the money is.

title: GASIMPORT BAR LIFTED BY F. P. C.
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 The Federal Power Commission removed tonight what appeared to be the last legal obstacle to the importation of one billion cubic feet of natural gas a day from Algeria for 20 years.

title: Printers Strike El Diario Over Transfer of Operation
description: The 81 members of Local 6 of the International Typographical Union struck El DiarioLa Prensa this morning in a dispute over the newspaper's plan to print in New Jersey.
